title: A CRUEL DECEPTION
description: Next to falsely promising terminally ill patients and their families a cure for cancer, the cruelest deception is the claim that the pre-eminent drug for relief of pain and despair is being withheld from Americans by a misguided Federal law. But that is exactly what some medical authorities are claiming as they try to get Congress to revoke the present Federal sanction against using heroin as a painkiller for the terminally ill.

title: Deadly Refusal
description: Runners read obituaries of Jim Fixx last week with sadness and a touch of fear. His death by heart attack while running seemed a stunning contradiction of the idea the 52-year-old author promoted with the medical community's blessing, that exercise is essential for a healthy heart.

title: Lilco Cutting Off Strikers' Benefits
description: The Long Island Lighting Company says that it will halt health and hospitalization benefits for its nearly 4,000 striking employees beginning Wednesday.

description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it had settled complaints filed against two brokers from the securities firm of Rooney, Pace Inc.

description: Citicorp said average rates of 11.314 percent for 91-day paper, down from 11.37 percent last week, and 11.404 percent for 182-day paper, down from 11.623 percent, were set at Tuesday's weekly auction.

title: HURRICANE WATCH TO BE AUGMENTED
description: Because two light bulbs burned out in the image-encoding system of a satellite 22,300 miles over the Equator, weather forecasters for the next few weeks will have a skewed picture of the Eastern Seaboard and the hurricane- breeding grounds of the Atlantic Ocean around the Equator.

title: Jaeger to Rest
description: Andrea Jaeger , who has a sore right arm and shoulder, said that the injury would sideline her for the rest of the year after she competes in next week's Olympic women's tennis matches in Los Angeles. Miss Jaeger, practicing at the Silverado Country Club and Resort with the United States men's and women's teams, plans to return to her home in Largo, Fla., after the Games to rest and recover from the injury that prevented her from playing full time in tournaments this year.

title: HOMESPUN VIRTUES OF THE COUNTRY HAM
description: AMERICAN country hams are familiar to far too few people outside the Southern states. Up North, for example, the usual hams available are more or less run-of-the-mill cured pork, smoked or unsmoked, marketed with little or no aging. In addition, they must be kept under refrigeration to prevent spoilage.

Ex-Congressman Dies at 91
description: J. Carlton Loser, a Tennessee Democrat who served three terms in Congress from 1956 through 1962, died today at Baptist Hospital after suffering a stroke Friday. He was 91 years old. Mr. Loser, father of Judge Joe Loser of Nashville Circuit Court, served as District Attorney General in Nashville from 1934 until his election to the House of Representatives in 1956. As a prosecutor, he was known as ''the man who cleaned up Nashville.''

description: The Champion International Corporation and the St. Regis Corporation announced jointly yesterday, as exp ected, that they had signed a definitive agreement to merge the two big paper companies in a deal valued at $1.7 billion in cash and stock.

title: BENEATH OLD YORK, THE VIKINGS OF YORE COME ALIVE
description: York has rediscovered the lost chapter in its history.

title: FILM: 1951 'LOST ONE,' DIRECTED BY PETER LORRE
description: ''THE LOST ONE'' (''Der Verlorene''), the 1951 German film that opens today at the Film Forum, is the only movie that was directed by the late Peter Lorre, one of America's favorite character actors in the 1940's and 50's. Though ''The Lost One'' isn't exactly a masterpiece, it's an interesting expression of the frustration of Lorre's creative personality, after he found himself in a comfortable kind of dead end in the Hollywood studio system.

title: VIEWS VARY ON CHAMPION BID
description: The Champion International Corporation's proposal to acquire the St. Regis Corporation would create the nation's largest forest products company, and, analysts say, set the stage for an expected flurry of mergers and acquisitions in the industry.

title: Cryder to Seahawks
description: The New England Patriots traded Bob Cryder, a starter at offensive tackle, to the Seattle Seahawks yesterday for an undisclosed draft choice. . . . Matt Mendenhall, the Washington Redskin defensive end who had been trying to reclaim the starting position that he lost when he bolted training camp last year, now needs elbow surgery and will miss the season. . . . Louis Wright, the Denver Broncos' all-pro cornerback, pulled a thigh muscle in scrimmage and will not be able to practice until a week before the regular season.

title: NAVY EXPECTS TO MODIFY ITSF-18'S TO CORRECT FLAW
description: The Navy said today that it expected to modify the F-18's already in service to correct a design flaw that causes cracks in the aircraft's tail. But it said it would accept no more F-18's until the manufacturer changed the design.

title: Swiss Set Back U.S. on Rich
description: Although the United States recently requested the extradition of Marc Rich and Pincus Green, oil traders, the petition was rejected because it had not been translated into one of Switzerland's official languages, a Justice Ministry spokesman said today.

title: IMPORTED BOUQUET GARNI
description: ONE of the staples of French cooking, bouquet garni, is used in countless dishes to impart flavor to stocks, soups, sauces and the like. If you are fortunate enough to have a home garden, now is the time to make your own bouquets garnis and put them away for the winter. If you don't have a garden, the next best thing would be to buy quality prepackaged bouquets such as those pictured here, made by a company called Les Herbes Fran,caises et Epicerie Trading Inc.

title: U-Haul Layoffs
description: U-Haul International Inc. will lay off approximately 4,000 workers nationwide - up to a quarter of its work force - because of an inability to market new rental-line products, company officials said. U-Haul, the nation's largest truck and trailer rental company, expanded two years ago into renting a variety of different items, including party goods, sporting goods, recreational equipment and vehicles, as well as construction equipment and other items.

title: ELECTRO RENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31

DEFYING REASON; COLD LOGIC Becoming a police officer in New Jersey requires more than a knowledge of the criminal law or police reporting procedures. One must also demonstrate an ability to think logically. For example: Of the words grouch, Persian, Italian and dismiss, which is most closely related to automobile, fellow, pillow and orange? The answer, fans, is grouch - because it contains the letter ''o.'' Oh indeed.
description: Such questions are routinely included on New Jersey's civil service examination, which is used to hire municipal police officers. Applicants who can readily recognize a hypothetical burglary or pinpoint a location on a map complain that questions that test their abstract reasoning in this manner have little or no relevance to actual police work.

She was 68 years old and lived in Newton, Mass., since her retirement last year, when she moved from Manhattan.

description: A memorial service for Dr. George H. Gallup, founder of the Gallup Poll, will be held Aug. 20 at 3:30 P.M. at Trinity Episcopal Church, 33 Mercer Street, Princeton, N.J. Dr. Gallup died last Thursday at his summer home in Tschingel, Switzerland. He was 82 years old.

title: NEW YORK MUSICIANS BEYOND CATEGORIZATION
description: DUKE ELLINGTON used to say of his favorite musicians that they were ''beyond category.'' If the 1960's were the years of soaring rock and newly liberated jazz, the 70's a decade of rock and dance-music new waves and, in jazz, a creeping neoclassicism, the 80's may be remembered as the period when musicians and music itself grew too diverse, and too diversely influenced, to be categorized.

title: Election to Oust Mayor Voted in Chelsea, Mass.
description: As spectators chanted ''Recall! Recall!'' the Board of Alderman voted Monday night to schedule an election Oct. 23 on whether to remove Mayor James D. Mitchell from office.

title: GOVERNORS END PARLEY IN SPLIT OVER TAX RISE
description: The nation's governors ended their three-day annual conference here today with Republicans and Democrats engaging in sharp election-year arguments over whether taxes must be raised to reduce the Federal deficit.

title: STAGE: NEW CAST IN 'THE REAL THING'
description: THE hero of Tom Stoppard's ''Real Thing,'' a loquacious playwright named Henry, believes that words can replicate themselves endlessly, ''like a spiral of DNA.'' There are times when one wishes that Mike Nichols, the play's director, could be just as easily cloned; there's no better director of actors in our theater right now. Amazingly, Mr. Nichols has forged three fine acting ensembles in less than a year - the original company of ''The Real Thing,'' that of ''Hurlyburly'' and now the replacement cast that has settled into Mr. Stoppard's hit at the Plymouth.

title: California Notes At Tentative 7%
description: Strong investor demand for $1.4 billion of California notes allowed underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets to reduce yields slightly from the levels announced early yesterday. The notes are rated M.I.G.-1, the highest rating of Moody's Investor Service.

title: Sewer-TaxNotices Are Sent in Error
description: As many as 25,000 customers of the Jamaica Water Company here received notices by mistake last week that said their sewer taxes would rise by 10 percent, officials said today.

title: SAMPLING THE MYRIAD BRANDS IN MARKETS, PLAIN AND FANCY
description: SHOPPING for decaffeinated coffee in New York today means selecting from an increasing variety of brands and types. There are instant coffees, regular coffees preground and sold in vacuum tins and specialty decaffeinated coffees, the kind carried in the bean by fancy food shops as well as supermarkets and small grocers, to be custom ground. This reporter recently tasted eight brands of instant decaffeinated coffee, 13 brands of preground vacuum-packed decaffeinated coffee, 13 types of specialty decaffeinated coffees that were custom-ground from beans, and five decaffeinated espressos, either preground or freshly ground from beans.

title: CONCERT: ESCHENBACH LEADS MOSTLY MOZART
description: MOZART vied for attention with two other composers in Avery Fisher Hall Monday night, when Christoph Eschenbach led the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra through Haydn's Symphony No. 72 in D, the Violin Concerto No. 9 in G by Joseph Boulogne, Chevalier de Saint- Georges and two late Mozart masterpieces.

title: WINE TALK
description: THIS time of year hundreds of tourists make the trip north from Bordeaux to visit the Medoc, one of the most famous wine regions in the world. By bus and car they roll through the flat vineyards of Ludon-Medoc, Macau, Labarde, Cantenac, Margaux, St.- Julien and Pauillac and finally reach St.-Est ephe, northernmost of the famous Medoc wine communes.

title: Rick Carey's Golden Gloom
description: LOS ANGELES He knew he had won the Olympic gold medal in the 200-meter backstroke, but as he bobbed in the chlorinated water, Rick Carey shook his black-capped head in disappointment at not having set a world record. On the medal stand later, he didn't raise an arm in triumph; he didn't even smile. He didn't seem to be enjoying the moment, as Rowdy Gaines, Tiffany Cohen, Theresa Andrews and those on the American women's 400 freestyle relay team had in the gladness of their gold. Instead, he had wrapped himself in gloom, a golden gloom. ''I expected a little more out of myself for some reason,'' he was saying now. ''I've been that fast in workouts. I expected to be better in the Olympics.'' After leading the qualifiers yesterday morning with a time of 1 minute 58.99 seconds, Rick Carey had predicted that he would break his world record of 1:58.86 in Tuesday night's final. ''It will definitely be a world record,'' he had said. ''If I can bring it home, I hope I can go 1:57.'' In the final he didn't even break 2 minutes. His time was 2:00.23, fast for any other world backstroker, but slow for him. And in keeping with his reputation as a perfectionist, the 21-year-old University of Texas senior from Mount Kisco, N.Y., did not hide his disappointment. ''This was two seconds from my best,'' he said. ''I don't find this satisfying.

title: Fingers Is Out
description: What had started as a remarkable comeback from an elbow injury continued on hold yesterday when the Milwaukee Brewers announced that Rollie Fingers, their ace relief pitcher, would undergo surgery Friday for the removal of a herniated disk and would miss the rest of the season. Fingers, 37, was placed on the disabled list with the back problem July 24, the day after he had earned his 23d save of the season in a 6-4 victory over the Yankees at Milwaukee. The latest injury follows a year and a half of inactivity that ended this season, after Fingers had recovered from surgery to remove bone spurs and reattach a muscle in his right elbow.

title: Sonat Promotes Officer

Morgan Jr., 59 years old, has been elected vice chairman of Sonat Inc. and chairman of its largest subsidiary, the Southern Natural Gas Company, effective Sept. 1, Sonat announced yesterday. Mr. Morgan is now executive vice president of Sonat, president of Southern Natural Gas and chairman of Sonat Marine, another subsidiary. He will keep his Sonat Marine post and will retain operating responsibility for Southern Natural Gas. He joined the gas company, based in Birmingham, Ala., in 1960 as a member of its legal staff.

title: CULINARY TOUCH THAT'S ALL-AMERICAN

Almost every restaurant of national reputation that offered serious dining was staffed by chefs born abroad. In the last five years, however, young American-born chefs have begun to take their places in the kitchens of fine restaurants in many parts of the country. Not only are many of them proving to be superior cooks, they are also making contributions to a distinctly American cuisine.

''The bills will total at least $40,000, and so we have come up with a plan. The tuition and room and board for my wife's two boys will be shared by us and my wife's ex-husband, while the same expenses for my daughters will be paid by us and my parents. The children will finance their incidental expenses by working in the summer.''

title: Politicians Brawl In Kashmir Legislature
description: Fist fights and brawls broke out today between supporters of the governing party and the opposition in the Kashmir state legislature where the 29-day-old administration of Chief Minister G. M. Shah won a confidence vote.

title: A COFFEE DRINKER'S GUIDE TO DECAFFEINATED BRANDS
description: ORDER decaffeinated coffee in a restaurant these days and there is an increasing likelihood that you will be served brewed coffee, not a cup of hot water with a packet of instant on the side. In the past year or so, the number of brands and types of decaffeinated coffee sold at retail and for restaurant and institutional service has grown from a handful to several dozen. Decaffeinated coffee beans in several roasts and flavors for custom grinding have become available not only in fancy food stores but also in supermarkets, small produce markets and delicatessens. Consumers can even select coffee according to the method of decaffeination. And the coffee drinker for whom the flavor is a major consideration and who has been disappointed with the typically thin taste of decaffeinated coffee may now find more satisfying choices.

title: PENSION SWITCH TO BONDS AT BETHLEHEM, CHRYSLER
description: Two of the nation's largest corporations, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation, sold huge amounts of stock held in their pension funds last month to switch into high-yielding bonds. The moves will enable them to save hundreds of millions of dollars in pension fund contributions they must make over coming years.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: BEURRE BLANC, a white butter sauce, has been one of the most useful recent additions to the cooking of this country. When I first started cooking in America, the basic hot butter sauce was hollandaise, but today beurre blanc is universally known. An exceptionally easy sauce to prepare, it is much less tricky than hollandaise. You simply cook down shallots with wine and perhaps another liquid, and when the mixture is sufficiently reduced, you stir in butter bit by bit.

title: G.L.U.B., G.L.U.B. (A MODEST PROPOSAL TO REDISTRIBUTE WEALTH)
description: Now is the season when moguls hie themselves to the Hamptons and concoct think pieces for newspapers and magazines, many of which they themselves own. The scene is bucolic, suitable for inspiration. Gulls call angrily against the azure of sky and blue of ocean; on green and shady lanes is heard the satisfying steely crunch of stockbrokers downshifting their B.M.W.'s. Alert ears can pick up a thin, high thrum, the cicada-like noise made by tycoons scratching their chins in self-approval as they hatch economic nostrums.

title: Enough of 'Holier Than Thou'
description: When John F. Kennedy became President a generation ago, it was thought the issue of a candidate's religion was buried forever in America. After nearly 200 years of Protestant Presidents, the country was finally led by a Roman Catholic. And if a Catholic, why not a Jew, a Buddhist or a Moslem? Why not, for that matter, an agnostic or atheist?

title: Military Contracts

In addition, the Air Force gave a $39.2 million contract to the ITT Avionics division of the ITT Corporation for B-52 bomber aircraft equipment.

The horseplayers were back in town, and three hours later the thoroughbreds began to run at Saratoga Race Track for the 117th summer.

title: PITFALLS OF MAKING PLAYS 'RELEVANT'
description: A CURIOUS thing happened in the middle of the Greek National Theater's visiting production of ''Oedipus Rex'' the other day. A chunky gentleman in leather appeared from the wings and translated one of the lines then being delivered by a member of the chorus of ululating old men: ''He says, 'If violence and crime are honored, why should I take part in a sacred play?' '' Then he stomped off backstage, never to be seen again.

title: NEW JERSEY CHARGES CASINO BROKE LAWS ON ISSUING OF CREDIT

title: HERS
description: FOR the past week I've been spending my afternoons out in the honey house getting things ready for the harvest. I'm making sure the screens are all tight because once I get started clouds of bees will surround the place and try to get in, lured by the scent of honey. I've been checking the machinery, repairing what isn't running properly, and I've been scrubbing everything down so that the health inspector will be proud.

title: EX-POLICE INSPECTOR DENIES EXTORTION IN PHILADELPHIA
description: A former chief inspector of the Philadelphia Police Department denied on the witness stand today that he had played a leading role in an extortion ring that prosecutors contend reached from ''patrolmen on the street'' to the top command level of the department.

title: OLYMPIC BASEBALL BELONGS
description: LOS ANGELES Behind home plate, the five Olympic rings were chalked on the grass. Hanging between the light-tower stanchions above the outfield bleachers were the flags of the eight nations competing in the Olympic baseball tournament. When a bat hit a ball, the sound was different for Dodger Stadium - the clank of aluminum. When the plate umpire, an Asian, held up his hands to signal balls and strikes, he was wearing white gloves. But in the Olympics, as anywhere else in baseball, an umpire is an umpire is an umpire.

description: Moscow has been misrepresenting Washington's position on proposed talks on space weapons, according to Robert C. McFarlane, President Reagan's national security adviser. It appears, he added in a statement, ''that the Soviets were not serious about their proposal.'' (Page A1, Col. 3.) The Kremlin has found no change in Washington's approach to proposed talks on space weapons, according to a high Soviet diplomat, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh. As a result, he said, the American position offers no chance for negotiations to start next month. (A4:3-6.)

title: SIMPSON-MAZZOLI, ACT II

A conference committee must now decide how to reconcile the Senate and House bills, amid unexpected pressures from the Democratic ticket. Their enthusiasm is a result of a meeting today in which they won assurances that a troublesome script had been modified. After the meeting, Merrett Stierheim, the Dade County Manager, and Bobby Jones, Public Safety Director for the county, said an associate producer, John Nicolella, had assured them the series showed ''good police doing good police work.''

title: USE OF COMPUTER AS LITERARY TOOL GAINS

description: The Executive Commission of the European Economic Community today called a news conference for Thursday to report on its 10-year-old antitrust suit against the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: All Eyes Are on Carl Lewis
description: He arrived fashionably late, as has become his custom at these affairs. ''Carl Lewis and his party are on the complex property,'' the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee press officer said, reassuring the assembled reporters. Minutes later, a half-hour after advertised, the guest of honor, his mother and Joe Douglas, manager of the Santa Monica Track Club, entered the interview room and Lewis stepped to the microphones, smiling and striking a superman pose.

title: OLYMPIC HIGHLIGHTS
description: Maybe it is like a World Series with only the National League team or a Super Bowl with only the Dallas Cowboys. But boycott or not, the Games of the XXIII Olympiad are displaying marked American improvement in what this country usually regards as ''other'' sports. And on the fourth day of the competition, with the swimmers idle and the track competition not yet begun, those ''other'' sports helped swell the United States gold medal total.

title: IRAN SAYS HIJACKERS THREATEN TO KILL FRENCH ON JET
description: The hijackers of an Air France jet threatened Wednesday night to start killing hostages today unless the French Government freed five Iranians jailed in 1980 for an assassination attempt, the Teheran radio reported.

title: SEARS TRADING UNIT IS CUTTING STAFF
description: Sears World Trade Inc., the international trading subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company, has begun a major cutback of its staff as a result of cost-cutting measures and a reorganization following the resignation of Roderick M. Hills, the unit's chairman, in April.

U.S. EXCEEDS EXPECTATIONS

title: FOLK-ROCK: STEWART AND BAND
description: POPULAR mythology, history, astrology and romance are all ingredients in the bookish folk-rock songs of Al Stewart, the Scottish singer and composer who appeared at the Bottom Line on Monday and Tuesday. Mr. Stewart is best known for his 1976 hit, ''The Year of the Cat,'' a song that typifies his most interesting work. A long, ruminative folk-pop ballad, it combines cinematically evocative imagery with an easy striding pop melody.

title: U.S. Beats Greece, 12-5
description: The United States, in its first Olympic water polo game since 1972, defeated Greece, 12-5, today. Yugoslavia, the Netherlands and Spain also were victorious in opening matches.

Jesse Jackson said today that he would not run as an independent candidate for the Senate in South Carolina but would concentrate on supporting the Mondale-Ferraro ticket nationally while reserving his right to continue criticizing the Democratic Party and its national standard-bearers.

The case concerned an article that described Miss Parsons as having engaged in a homosexual relationship with one of her players. Through her attorney, J. Lewis Cromer , Miss Parsons said that she now wanted to leave the entire matter in the past.

In any case Peri Wolfman, one of the partners of Wolfman-Gold and Good Company - a minichain of stores that are known for their all-white wares - has introduced Doily Carte, a collection of French and American paper doilies meant to be used not only for showing off pastries but as stationery, place mats or to run along shelves.

description: People are always describing Bela Karolyi as bearish, and this is odd, because he is not a large, lunkish man and he does not seem at all ferocious.

title: State Largesse With City Funds Governor Cuomo has signed a pension supplement bill that New York City says will cost it $434 million over ten years. Recent retirees, their pensions hardly scratched by inflation, are among the beneficiaries. The Governor thinks they deserve it and that a city cash surplus this year should make the cost affordable forever.
description: The Governor thus lined up with legislators who were remarkably receptive to the call of municipal unions. No legislative pleasure is more seductive than conferring benefits to be paid with taxes imposed by someone else. No state act is more damaging than to thus foreclose debate over whether the city's pensioners in fact have a better claim than the homeless, or mentally ill, whose plight has been woefully neglected by the Cuomo administration.

title: 7 Shot Dead in Philippines
description: Two gunmen killed seven male boarders of a lodging house in gangland fashion in this southern Philippine city today, the police reported. A spokesman said the killers entered the Dance Inn early this morning, woke up the 10 residents, herded them into another room and opened fire with high-powered rifles. The police could offer no motive.

This approach should be based on the idea that, outside of matters of national security, no limit should be placed on immigration for those wishing to make a new life here.

Montana Power
description: The Montana Power Company said it was disappointed at the denial by the Montana Public Service Commission of any rate increase for the company's Colstrip 3 generating plant. The company, which requested a $96.4 million rate increase, said the commission voted to allow only a $4 million annual rate increase, none of which applies to construction of Colstrip 3. In view of the commission's decision, Montana Power said, ''There are many actions we will take, including long-term sale of the power or sale of the plant itself, before we would reduce the dividend payment to our shareholders.''

title: MUSIC: MOSTLY MOZART
description: GERARD SCHWARZ seems to have fallen in love this summer with mutilations of works by 18th-century composers. At the Waterloo Festival, of which he is music director, he recently presented Wagner's ''improvement'' of Gluck's ''Iphigenia auf Aulis.'' At the Mostly Mozart Festival, of which he is also music director, he will soon conduct Richard Strauss's reworking of Mozart's ''Idomeneo.'' In the Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday night, the program - for which he was responsible - ended with J. P. Salomon's arrangement for string quartet, flute and piano of Haydn's ''Surprise'' Symphony.

NEW GREENHOUSES BRING THE CITY'S MAGIC INDOORS
description: ELIE TAHARI'S memories of sleeping in Central Park are fond ones. When he first arrived in the United States 12 years ago with $60 in his pocket, he found his accommodations in the park for two weeks. ''I wasn't aware of the danger and because I had grown up in the desert in Israel, parks had a special meaning for me,'' he said, looking down at the park through the new, high greenhouse walls of his nearly completed Fifth Avenue penthouse. ''The people in the park were always friendly,'' he said. ''They talked to me, they shared food.''

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;
description: Robert Briscoe , an avid Dallas Cowboy fan from Levelland, Tex., paid $11,000 for the 1978 Super Bowl ring belonging to Thomas (Hollywood) Henderson , the former Cowboy who is now serving a prison term in California for sexual assault and bribery. Mr. Briscoe, a trucking executive, was the top bidder at an auction held in Mesquite, Tex., by the Internal Revenue Service. The I.R.S., contending that Henderson owed $156,881 in back taxes, had confiscated the ring and set the minimum bid at $4,500. The manufacturer of the ring - 10-karat white gold with two 40-point diamonds set in blue stars and surrounded by 25 smaller diamonds - put the value at about $5,000, less than half of what Briscoe paid.

title: The Duarte Difference
description: Jose Napoleon Duarte deserves a cheer, maybe two - and help. In two months as El Salvador's elected President, he's managed to build authority at home by opening minds abroad. When crusty House Democrats like Clarence Long say they now favor $306 million in economic and military aid, Mr. Duarte has proved himself a better salesman than the White House. He also won a hearing in skeptical Western Europe and the offer of $19 million in aid from West Germany.

title: Field Joining CBS
description: Frank Field, who was the weather forecaster and health and science editor at WNBC-TV for 25 years, is switching to WCBS-TV. A spokesman for WCBS said yesterday that Mr. Field would be senior meteorologist and senior health and science editor starting about Aug. 13. He will also contribute health and science reports regularly to the network on ''CBS Morning News,'' the spokesman said.

title: STAGE: CIRCUS OZ AT SUMMERFARE '84
description: Circus Oz, a band of young Australian acrobats, jugglers, gymnasts, aerialists, clowns and musicians, bills itself as ''the world's No. 1 contemporary circus,'' a serious overstatement even in the language of the greatest show on earth. Actually, the troupe is less a circus as we know it than a collective of variety artists. After a stand at the Olympics Arts Festival in Los Angeles, the company is in brief residence through this weekend at Pepsico's Summerfare '84.

title: Topics; Bright Baubles ; Opportunity Calling Until 1984 it was possible to make long-distance telephone calls for no more compelling reason than the desire or need to make long-distance calls. After the phone company's big breakup, however, it's a whole new phone game, modeled on the old green stamp template. A.T. & T. has announced it will award ''Opportunity Credits'' on a dollar-for-dollar basis for each month's long-distance charges totaling $15 or more. The credits may then be used to buy consumer products at a discount. Call Seattle, say, and talk for two hours to reduce the price of a pickup truck. Call a friend in San Francisco for a lengthy palaver and earn credit for some corduroy trousers. A long telephonic klatsch with someone in Tucson helps with the purchase of a digital coffee maker or cordless shrub trimmer.
description: The long-distance credit, however, is not the same as a toaster for a bank deposit or a croquet set for supermarket receipts. Personal long-distance calls are a matter of human relationships, usually guilt-ridden. Offering gifts for calling an ailing mother or a friend you've been meaning to write to for a year isn't just clever, it's inspired.

title: AIR AUTHORITIES SAY HIJACKERS CAN EVADE TIGHEST SECURITY

Some passengers, like Charlotte and Gaetana Otto- Bruc, who live in Monaco, were bent over the railing looking at the statue. Cathy Blake had opened up a huge box of imported chocolates as ''our contribution to the boat party.'' A couple of dozen people were dancing to ''Among My Souvenirs'' and ''Begin the Beguine'' played by Herb Meyers's five-piece band, and Rusty Weill and Claire Minsky were comparing rivers.

A TASTE OF BARONIAL LUXURY
description: It is a walk into the late 19th century: gold- leaf parlor sets, huge marble fireplaces, intricately stenciled walls, mahogany woodwork and allegorical scenes painted on 16-foot-high ceilings.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Peter Spencer , an agent for six players in the National Hockey League, has been accused of stealing from two of his clients: Ron Low of the Devils and the Oilers' Dave Semenko . The Royal Canadian Mounted Police said the offense involved the loss of $35,000 by the two players from June to December 1982. . . . John Cirillo , publicity director at Yonkers Raceway since 1981, has been named the Knicks' director of communications. . . . Doug Smith, all-Southeastern Conference lineman from Auburn, has signed with the Birmingham Stallions of the United States Football League, reportedly for $1.2 million over four years after turning down an offer from Houston of the National Football League. . . . The Arizona Wranglers of the U.S.F.L. have acquired the rights to Bob Horn , a linebacker who was recently waived by the New Jersey Generals.

title: NEEDLEWORK OF THE PAST
description: Samplers and pictures stitched by the tiny fingers of Rhode Island children of past centuries have been placed in the Metropolitan Museum of Art and can be seen there through Sept. 23 on the first floor of the American Wing.

title: MALARIA VACCINE IS NEAR, U.S. HEALTH OFFICIALS SAY
description: Federal officials announced today that scientists had cleared the last major hurdle to development of a vaccine against malaria, one of the most serious health problems in the world.

title: Australia Still Unbeaten
description: Unbeaten Australia, the favorite in the men's field hockey tournament, defeated West Germany, 3-0, tonight while the United States fell out of medal contention, losing to Malaysia, 4-1.

title: AFTER ALL, IT'S HOLLYWOOD
description: Regardless of the sulking Russians and their dependents, the Olympics are under way with a great surge of flag-waving pride.

title: FOR MCNAMARA, A SWEET AND SOUR NIGHT
description: The best women gymnasts in the United States could not quite tumble Rumania from the gold podium in team competition Wednesday night. They were good enough to win the silver medal, though, and good enough to score the first perfect 10's by American women in Olympic gymnastics history. Both achievements represented giant steps forward for this country in the sport.

title: 9 Killed by Bomb BlastAt Airport in India
description: Nine people were killed and 13 were wounded when a bomb exploded tonight at the airport in this southern Indian city.

title: On Keeping the Fans Of Michael Jackson Safe
description: Mayor Koch, on the high cost of security for the Michael Jackson concerts this weekend:

title: DEB SHOPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Docutel/Olivetti Shift
description: The Docutel/Olivetti Corporation said yesterday that B. J. Meredith had resigned as chairman. Mr. Meredith will be succeeded by Giovanni Fei, 59 years old, who is currently chief executive officer. Mr. Fei will retain the title of chief executive.

title: GENRAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FORUM GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $97,000 from discontinued operations.

title: CHINA'S MASTER TECHNICIAN OF THE ART OF HIGH JUMP
description: China's best prospect for the Olympic gold in track and field hardly looks like a world- class athlete. With his Nike shirt worn inside out, wire-rimmed spectacles and hunched back, 21-year-old Zhu Jianhua is plugged into his Sony Walkman, nonchalantly watching a pre-Olympic competition from the bleachers, as he waits for his event.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: MARTIN ABZUG rolled his eyes. ''It's been an experience!'' he exclaimed, summing up 40 years of marriage to Bella.

title: THOUGHTS OVER COFFEE
description: I'm a man of bad habits, one of which is reading the newspaper while eating. Since I don't have time for either activity, each one provides a good excuse for the other. The result is that I eat too much, and probably read too much, with the deep pollution of mind and body that those excesses cause.

title: GIBSON GREETINGS CARDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HELMERICH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2d American Wins Gold in Wrestling
description: Jeff Blatnick, a 27-year-old from Niskayuna, N.Y., who suffered from cancer two years ago, beat Thomas Johansson of Sweden tonight, by a score of 2-0, to win the gold medal in the super-heavyweight division (more than 220 pounds) in Greco-Roman wrestling.

title: SALVADOR REBELS BESEIGED IN BANK
description: A small group of guerrillas took about 100 people hostage at a bank here today after a bungled robbery in which a guard was shot and killed.

description: The International Business Machines Corporation, the world's largest computer manufacturer, today settled a decade-old antitrust case brought against it by the European Economic Community.

title: 'Greenmail' Curb Gains
description: The House Commerce and Energy Committee today approved legislation to put restrictions on ''greenmail,'' in which a company's management buys back its stock from a potential suitor at inflated prices.

title: AMERICAN WATER WORKS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOW TO PUT A MUSICAL ON THE STREET
description: EVERY August for the last 14 years, Theater for the New City has gotten standing ovations. That's because the troupe leaves its home at 162 Second Avenue and hits the streets of New York, putting on free outdoor performances from Snug Harbor to Coney Island and the South Bronx. Its audiences, which usually number in the hundreds, don't mind the lack of seats.

title: RENTING ON FRATERNITY ROW
description: On fraternity row at Southern Cal, there is hardly a fraternity brother or a sorority sister to be seen. More than a dozen of these immense fraternity houses on a tree-lined street east of the campus are off-limits to their usual occupants for the next two weeks because they have been appropriated for the Olympics.

OXFORD FIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $14,000 for the quarter and $137,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $84,000 for the quarter and $181,000 for the 6 months.

title: DISPUTED DIABLO NUCLEAR PLANT WINS PERMISSION OF U.S. TO START UP
description: The Diablo Canyon nuclear plant at San Luis Obispo, Calif., won permission today from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to begin operation.

title: INTERNATIONAL KING'S TABLE INC reports earnings for 12 wks to June 30
LEWIS BEGINS QUEST TODAY
description: Olympic track and field competition, also known as ''The Carl Lewis Show,'' begins Friday with the star himself.

Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BROWSER'S GUIDE TO SIDEWALK TREASURES
description: As early as 6 o'clock on Saturday and Sunday mornings dealers begin unpacking their wares in schoolyards, parking lots and old warehouses around Manhattan, getting ready to spend the weekend bargaining behind folding tables. Whether they specialize in vintage clothes or 1940's toasters, Victorian silver or refurbished linens, these dealers are the heart and soul of Manhattan's flea markets - a weekend event regularly attended by thousands of New Yorkers.

title: MONDALE'S NEW CAMPAIGN THEMES: PATRIOTISM AND HARD WORK
description: It was the presence of Geraldine A. Ferraro that stirred the most attention on the Democratic ticket's first campaign swing in the South this week. But it was Walter F. Mondale's unexpected message that dominated the drive that began in New York and moved on to two key Southern states, Mississippi and Texas. Mr. Mondale, who is heir to a liberal tradition that sought to appeal to key Democratic constituent groups, adopted themes that sounded uncharacteristically conservative, even like President Reagan's: the limits of government, reduced spending, the rewards of hard work, law and order, patriotism, realism, family and religious values, and, with a leaf drawn from the President, adopting the Summer Olympics as a symbol of the American dream and a source of campaign themes.

title: Bills Get Dennard
description: The Los Angeles Rams, overloaded with wide receivers, have traded one of them, Preston Dennard , to the Buffalo Bills. In return, they get help where they may need it most: defensive backfield. Arriving in Los Angeles is Chris Williams , who the Rams hope will be able to fill in for Johnny Johnson , an all-pro free safety who broke two ankle bones last week and is expected to miss most of the season.

title: LUMEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REDPATH INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: HARPER'S WOOS A NEW READER
description: With its latest redesign and marketing approach, Harper's magazine is turning from the armchair intellectual, an audience few advertisers would covet, to the affluent and well- educated businessman and woman.

title: Sun Refining-China Tie
description: Sun Refining and Marketing of the United States and the China Petro- Chemical Corporation International will build a lubricating oil plant in China, the two companies said today.

Year-ago results have been restated. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

CUOMO TO CHALLENGE ARCHBISHOP OVER CRITICISM OF ABORTION STAND
description: Governor Cuomo, seizing the offensive in a long-simmering conflict, has decided to confront the implied criticism of his position on abortion by the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York.

SOUTHLAND OFFICIAL IS CHARGED
description: Another top official of the Southland Corporation, one of the nation's largest retailers, was charged yesterday with conspiring to bribe New York State tax officials to fix sales- tax cases involving the 7-Eleven convenience store chain, which Southland runs.

title: A.B. Hooker, Special Counsel To Commerce Dept. Section
description: Arthur Bowles Hooker, special counsel to the Economic Development Administration of the Commerce Department, died of cancer Saturday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 59 years old and lived in Alexandria, Va.

title: Topics; Bright Baubles ; Sunken Treasures
description: There was a time when movies featuring galleons, Spanish gold, swordplay, storms and a giant octopus were Saturday afternoon staples. They were often based on a novel by Rafael Sabatini, the hero was often Errol Flynn, and if the heroine wasn't Olivia de Havilland it was because it was Paulette Goddard.

title: ZAHRINGER LEADS MET GOLF QUALIFIERS
description: George Zahringer 3d of the Sands Point Golf Club won the stroke-play medal today in the 36-hole qualifying of the Metropolitan Golf Association's Amateur Championship. Zahringer shot 70, 71-141, one over par for two circuits of the rugged course at Deepdale Golf Club.

title: MORSE SHOE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sovereign Oil
description: The Home Oil Company, a unit of Hiram Walker Resources Ltd., said it had reached an understanding to buy Dome Petroleum Ltd.'s 22.9 percent interest in Sovereign Oil and Gas P.L.C. for $40 million (Canadian). Sovereign, a British company, has about 8,000 barrels a day of North Sea oil production and 240,000 acres of unexplored rights, Home said.

title: MEDICARE-GLASER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Russia Purchases Grain
description: The Soviet Union, which began a sustained campaign of buying American grain more than a month ago, has bought an additional 700,000 metric tons of corn and 200,000 tons of wheat, the Agriculture Department said today. The grain is worth about $110 million at current prices. The Russians have bought more than 7.6 million tons of corn and wheat since the current surge of purchases began on June 29.

title: Caracas Starts InquiryOn Hijacking Security
description: The Venezuelan Government has ordered an inquiry into the possibility that security lapses allowed two hijackers to smuggle pistols and gasoline aboard an airliner that they commandeered for 36 hours.

title: Earthquake Strikes Armenia
description: An earthquake measuring 6 points on the 12-point scale struck Armenia today, but an initial report said there had been no casualties or destruction. The Tass press agency said the tremor was centered nine miles from Yerevan.

title: BUCKHORN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $801,000 for the quarter and $1,316,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $58,000 for the quarter and $256,000 for the 6 months.

title: BAY STATE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: ART: 100 MODERN SCULTURES AT STORM KING CENTER
description: THE Storm King Art Center is becoming indispensable to anyone seriously interested in post-World War II sculpture. The center's 200 acres, set in the rolling hills of the Hudson River Valley, are stocked with more than 100 sculptures, most of them done since the center was founded in 1960. To see strong work by Louise Bourgeois, Alexander Calder, Mark Di Suvero, Charles Ginnever, Robert Grosvenor, Alexander Liberman, Isamu Noguchi, David Smith, Kenneth Snelson and David Von Schlegell in a setting where each work has maximum room to breathe, is to gain direct access to the last two decades of sculpture in America.

title: Scoring the Match ; ;
description: The settlement reached yesterday in the Common Market's lengthy antitrust investigation of the International Business Machines Corporation ends the most bitterly fought governmental effort yet to limit the powers of the world's largest computer company. At first glance, the European Economic Community appears to have won significant concessions from the company, one of Europe's largest employers. But as Common Market officials were admitting in Brussels last week even before details of the settlement were known, I.B.M.'s concessions were primarily symbolic.

title: Unsmiling Carey Offers Apology
description: On Tuesday night, when Rick Carey of Mount Kisco, N.Y., won the Olympic gold medal in men's 200- meter backstroke swimming, the only emotion he showed was obvious disappointment with his time. After the medal ceremony, when he received a standing ovation from the crowd, he did not even acknowledge it with a smile or a wave.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Debt Ratings column of Business Day on Monday incorrectly described a change in the rating of Pitney Bowes Inc.'s senior debt. The Standard & Poor's Corporation upgraded it to AA-.

title: Champion Arranges Credit for Purchase
description: The Champion International Corporation said yesterday that it would finance the cash portion of its planned $1.8 billion acquisition of the St. Regis Corporation with a $1.05 billion credit from a group of banks headed by Chemical Bank and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

title: Gopi Krishna of India Is Dead; Wrote About Value of Yoga
description: Gopi Krishna, an Indian author and philosopher known for his writings about the value of practicing yoga, died Tuesday of pneumonia at his home in Srinigar in Kashmir State. He was 81 years old.

title: MAJOR REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31

title: CITY APARTHEID BUILT: TIN SHACKS (POP. 200,00)
description: Over the last five years, more than 200,000 people have been rehoused in a makeshift camp on the lee of a broken hill here, subjects of official policies that determine, by race or tribe, where and how people should live.

title: LEAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Slowing Seen For Canada
description: Canada's economic growth will slip in 1985 because ''there is no effective way for the Canadian economy to insulate itself'' from high interest rates in the United States, the Conference Board of Canada said today.

title: Brookshier's 'Penance'
description: Tom Brookshier , the football star turned CBS broadcaster, caused hurt feelings at the University of Louisville last winter when he said on the air, in a light-hearted manner, that the school's basketball players had ''a collective I.Q. of about 40.'' So yesterday he visited the university as a means of what he called voluntary penance.

title: THE DEBATE ABOUT BAILOUTS
description: Walter B. WRISTON, who is going off to play tennis for the rest of the month, just before his retirement from the chairmanship of Citicorp, the nation's biggest bank, rejects the charge that he or other bankers took ''unbankerly'' risks because they were convinced that the Government would never let the big banks fail. ''It's a total non sequitur,'' he declared in an interview, ''to say we are reckless because we expect that they will bail us out.''

title: JURY BARS SELLING LETTER BY MONROE
description: A jury in Surrogate's Court in Manhattan decided yesterday that a letter Marilyn Monroe wrote to Lee and Paula Strasberg could not be put up for public auction and had to be returned to the Strasberg estate as its rightful owner.

title: POLICE DEFENDED IN MACDONALD'S CASE
description: San Diego's Chief of Police today disputed charges that several victims who died in the July 18 shootings at a McDonald's restaurant in the city's San Ysidro community could have been saved if the police had acted more quickly.

title: American Team in CairoOver Suez Mine Reports
description: A 15- man American technical team arrived in Cairo today to help solve a mystery surrounding reported mine explosions in the Gulf of Suez last weekend that damaged three ships.

title: Agent Orange FundTo Provide for Tests
description: A Federal judge released $74,000 yesterday from a $250 million settlement for victims of the herbicide Agent Orange so they and their families could be screened for genetic damage or birth defects.

description: The United States soccer team was held to a 1-1 tie by Egypt tonight, ending American hopes of qualifying for the quarterfinal round.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SO FAR, SO GOOD, EXCEPT CASHING IN
description: Tomorrow is a day that for two years people here have been looking forward to as ''Black Friday.'' When the dawn breaks, Angelenos will discover if ''Black Friday'' has gone the same way as ''Paralyzed Freeways,'' ''Congested Airport'' and ''Smog Attack.''

title: ART: JUST THE SHOW FOR SUMMER IN HAMPTONS
description: There are two museums in the Hamptons in which I, for one, am happy to put in time any day of the week. One of them is the Guild Hall in East Hampton. The other is the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton. What they have to offer is a manageable and unpretentious exhibition space, together with fringe benefits that vary from one to the other. The Guild Hall is the bigger outfit of the two, with movies, plays and concerts in profusion, but the Parrish has a pretty little shop and a sculpture garden that seems to have been fork-lifted in by overnight express from antiquity. Let us hope that neither of these museums ever gets big ideas, because they are just fine as they are.

title: LESSONS OF THE GREAT WAR
description: Seventy years ago this week, the First World War began. The disaster of 1914 continues to haunt us, not only because the costs were so disproportionate to any reasonable ends but also because the statesmen of Europe seem to have stumbled into the war. In the nuclear age, this image is far from reassuring, for similar stumbling today could bring thermonuclear holocaust.

title: Surfer Killed by Lightning
description: A surfer was struck by lightning and killed today as he crossed the dunes here to view the waves during a brief but intense thunderstorm, the police said. The victim was identified as Peter Scola, 20 years old, of Surf City. Lightning also caused fires in a house and two stores, officials said.

title: Gulf Oil Slick ExpectedTo Reach Texas Today
description: A 50-mile-long oil slick threatening the Texas coast drifted back out to sea today, but experts predicted a half-million gallons of crude oil would wash ashore Friday evening.

title: FILM: KLEISER'S 'GRANDVIEW, U.S.A.'
description: ''Grandview, U.S.A.''begins and ends with montages of small-town people doing small-town things. The rest of it is not nearly so reassuringly ordinary. As directed by Randal (''Grease'') Kleiser, ''Grandview, U.S.A.'' depicts a little Middle Western community full of colorful oddballs, all of whom flaunt their eccentricities. The movie has about three times as many of these characters as it needs.

title: NUCLEAR EVACUATION PLANNING FAULTED
description: Fewer than half the nation's 54 operating nuclear power plants have Government- approved emergency evacuation plans, and many of the 24 approved plans are inadequate, according to a Congressional study released today. .

title: WILLIAMS REJOINS POPS
description: John Williams, who resigned his position as the conductor of the Boston Pops two months ago, citing ''artistic and creative differences'' with the orchestra, has withdrawn his resignation, it was announced yesterday.

'BEACH' OVER GEORGE' IN LAST ACT OF SEASON
description: On Broadway, there are only two numbers that matter: a show's weekly gross and its record in the summer softball league. And in Central Park yesterday, where the men of the footlights practiced the art of the horsehide, ''Brighton Beach Memoirs'' rallied to win the championship from the combined artistes of ''The Real Thing'' and ''Sunday in the Park With George.''

description: The second trial of Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne opened today with a prosecutor saying that the judge had purposely understated his income for 1979 and 1980 by more than $100,000 to avoid Federal taxes.

description: The United States women's basketball team, tested briefly in the first half, pulled away in the second tonight for an 84-47 victory over South Korea to extend its record to 3-0. The Americans are the only unbeaten team in the six-team field as South Korea suffered its first loss.

title: Survey on Sites
description: The idea of establishing a permanent site in Greece for future Olympic Games, rather than continue the system of moving them from country to country every four years, meets with the approval only of Greeks, Britons and American college graduates, according to a survey conducted June 25 to July 2 by the Gallup Poll.

title: HEROIN IS NOT NEEDED AS A PAIN KILLER

title: ART MAKE OF I-BEAMS AND CONCRETE
description: ''There is some violence in this piece, but there is beauty, too,'' said Chris Burden, the conceptual artist, as he watched 60 steel construction beams fall one by one into a 30-foot pond of wet concrete.

title: FILM: 'LA PETITE SIRENE' OPENS AT THE METRO
description: ''La Petite Sirene'' isn't the usual film about a love affair between a 14-year-old girl and a 40-year-old man, if there is indeed a usual version by now. Directed in 1980 by Roger Andrieux, it has a heroine, Isabelle (Laura Alexis), who is not the customary nymphet and who does not attract the interest of a man much her senior merely by removing a few key articles of attire. Isabelle is very serious and rather plain, at least compared with the other members of her family, all of whom are tall and blond. And her fixation on Georges (Philippe Leotard) has less to do with mature love than with fairy tales.

title: GILBERT ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest periods include gains equal to 6 cents a share for the quarter and 26 cents a share for the 6 months for early retirement and severance costs, a gain equal to 8 cents a share for the quarter due to improved pension plan experience and a gain equal to 12 cents a share for the 6 months from litigation settlement and receivables adjustment.

title: LANCE QUITS POST IN MONDALE DRIVE OVER 'OLD CHARGES
description: Bert Lance resigned today as general chairman of Walter F. Mondale's Presidential campaign after having a title, but no clear political role, for less than three weeks.

title: I.B.M. Ends Pact
description: Intermetrics Inc. said it had been notified that the International Business Machines Corporation had invoked the termination provision in a 1981 contract. Intermetrics, which develops computer software products and services, said I.B.M. made it clear that the termination did not reflect dissatisfaction with the work done by the company. The contract represented about 19 percent of Intermetrics' revenues for fiscal 1983, 17 percent for fiscal 1984 and about 15 percent for the first quarter of fiscal 1985.The company said the impact on its earnings could not be determined, but noted that the contract calls for termination payments by I.B.M.

title: AN ARREST ENDS FATHER'S 11-YEAR SEARCH FOR DAUGHTER'S KILLER
description: Between 12:25 P.M. and 1:05 P.M. on July 16, 1973, Concetta Serra, 21 years old, was stabbed to death in a downtown parking garage here. Eleven years later, last July 3, Anthony Golino, 33, was arrested and charged with her murder.

title: TAYLOR AND SHANNON TRIUMPH IN BOXING
description: Nicolae Talpos did not really need a reminder. He might not speak English, but he could surmise by the crowd's reaction that his opponent was the favorite in the fight. But just to be sure, Meldrick Taylor, his opponent, handed the Rumanian a tiny American flag when they met in the center of the ring before the opening bell, and Talpos walked back to his corner carrying his gift and wearing a smile.

Year-ago revenues include sales of $1.1 billion for the quarter and $2.3 billion for the 6 months of Permian Corp., which was sold in December.

title: HIGHEST ARGENTINE MILITARY COURT JAILS EX-RULER IN DISAPPEARANCES
description: Former President Jorge Rafael Videla was indicted and jailed today by the military's top court on charges related to the thousands of deaths and disappearances that took place under his rule.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: Texaco Capital Sells $500 Million in Notes

title: RESTAURANTS
description: Tuscan variety, minimalist setting.

title: FRIDAY, AUGUST 3, 1984 International
description: Low-altitude antisatellite arms have become an issue between American military officers and some civilian leaders, according to Administration sources. They said the military has expressed reservations about the need for the arms. (Page A1, Col. 1.) United States swimmers won three more gold medals in the Games of the XXIII Olympiad in Los Angeles. In two of the races, Americans also collected silver medals, and in the other race their relay team broke a world record. In the first four days of Olympic swimming, the United States has 14 gold and 7 silver medals in 19 events. The latest winners were Mary T. Meagher in the women's 100-meter butterfly, George Di Carlo in the men's 400-meter freestyle and the American team in the men's 400- meter freestyle relay. (A1:4-6.)

title: HARVARD MEN IN A CALENDAR
description: It could have been a textbook case in competitive strategy: a money- making idea, late-night planning and a dash to get to market first.

title: U.S. TAKES 3 MORE GOLDS IN SWIMMING
description: United States swimmers collected three more gold medals tonight in the Games of the XXIII Olympiad. In two of those races, Americans also won the silver medals, and in the other race their relay team broke a world record.

title: FORD WANTS PAY BASED ON PROFITS
description: The Ford Motor Company proposed today to base all future wage increases for its factory workers on profits through a profit-sharing plan. It was the company's first offer in the negotiations for a new labor contract that began on July 24.

title: SOUTHERN UNION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: There are no share earnings for the latest second quarter because net income was exceeded by preferred dividend requirements.

title: A 1920'S LAUREL AND HARDY MONTAGE
description: What made Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy funny? You may judge for yourself in ''Laurel and Hardy's Laughing 20's,'' a 75-minute compilation of sequences from the comedians' silent movies. It will be shown on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight.

title: THE NUMBERS INVOLVED IN THE DEATH PENALTY ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: Truckload of TorpedoesAngers Mayor of Denver
description: Mayor Federico Pena said today that the Federal Government was ''grossly negligent'' in its response to the crash of a truck carrying naval torpedoes at Denver's busiest highway interchange. He has sent a letter to President Reagan asking for an explanation.

title: WALKER, HIRAM RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. Year-ago revenues have been restated.

title: STREAK REACHES 7
description: The Mets suffered the ultimate outrage tonight when the Pittsburgh Pirates scored three runs in the eighth inning and sent them reeling to their seventh straight defeat. Ron Darling, unbeaten in more than two months, finally lost a game - on a pitch thrown by Jesse Orosco.

title: Republic-LTV
description: A Federal judge gave approval to the purchase of the Republic Steel Corporation by the Jones & Laughlin Steel subsidiary of the LTV Corporation.

title: Texas Eastern Bid Clears a Hurdle
description: The Texas Eastern Corporation said that a Texas State District Court, at a preliminary hearing, had refused to grant a temporary restraining order that would have blocked the company's purchase of Petrolane Inc. stock. Earlier, Texas Eastern said that the waiting period for its purchase of the stock had ended and that it intended to start buying the 29.1 million Petrolane shares, or about 56 percent of the total outstanding, that it had received in its $20-a-share tender offer.

title: London City ChiefQuits to Seek Showdown
description: Ken Livingstone, head of the Greater London Council, resigned today to force a showdown over the Government's plans to abolish the council.

title: MCDONNELL DOUGLAS SAYS IT WILL PAY COST OF FIXING F-18 FLAW
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation announced today that it would ''bear the costs,'' about $25 million, of correcting a design flaw in the Navy's F-18 warplane that has caused cracks in the fighter's tail. But it appeared that the Navy would pay the bill in the end.

title: AMERICA'S BEST SWIMMER
description: LOS ANGELES The best swimmer, man or

title: Nurses Screening CallsFor Ambulances Resign
description: City officials say they will try to save the city's program of screening calls for ambulances even though its five nurses have quit since the death of an elderly woman in January resulted in criticism of the system.

title: BUSY WEEKEND FOR LATIN LIVELY ARTS
description: New Yorkers who stay in the city this weekend can enjoy - largely for the price of a subway token - a hot South American weekend of Latin dance, painting, theater and food.

title: MONDALE AND FERRARO GREET BOISTEROUS CROWDS IN TEXAS
description: Walter F. Mondale and Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro brought their campaign to the open-air Spanish farmers market here today, appealing for support from a boisterous crowd in this predominantly Hispanic city.

title: RATE OF POVERTY FOUND TO PERSIST IN FACE OF GAINS
description: The national poverty rate remained at its highest level in 18 years last year, despite improvements in the economy, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: TENNESSEE REPUBLICANS CHOOSE CANDIDATES FOR SENATE RACE
description: Victor Ashe, a former State Senator, easily won the Republican nomination today for the Senate seat being vacated by the majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr.

title: Money Fund Assets Drop
description: After gaining more than $1 billion a week for three straight weeks, the assets of the nation's 335 money market mutual funds have dropped, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. The assets declined $630 million, to $180.38 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the institute said.

title: IN PRAISE OF SHRILLNESS
description: This is more like it, they tell me. This is the kind of woman we can relate to. Smart, charming, good looking and not shrill.

description: Postmaster General William F. Bolger has threatened to dismiss any Postal Service employees who walk off the job.

PAINTING: BY 15 FRIENDS OF FAIRFIELD PORTER
description: TO say that success in art is a matter of whom you know is not necessarily to be cynical. The making of art is as social an activity as it is solitary, with responses from friends and colleagues assisting esthetic progress if not guaranteeing it. And obviously, material prosperity is not achieved without being seen and talked about, especially by discriminating people.

title: POP: DIFFORD AND TILBROOK
description: THREE years ago, when they were leading the pop group Squeeze, the British songwriting-performing team of Chris Difford and Glenn Tilbrook seemed close to attaining a popularity and prestige to rival the Police. Masterful creators of witty romantic vignettes, Difford and Tilbrook earned comparisons with Lennon and McCartney and even with Gilbert and Sullivan.

title: Lady Bird Johnson 'Proud'
description: Lady Bird Johnson said Wednesday that she was ''proud'' of Geraldine A. Ferraro's selection as the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee but suggested the ticket faced an uphill battle in Texas.

title: SEYMOUR UDELL
description: Seymour Udell, the president of Ampco Printing - Advertisers Offset Corporation of New York, died of cancer Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Sands Point, L.I.

title: Fence for G.O.P. ParleyIs Nudged a Bit Closer
description: A Federal district judge, saying he was seeking to balance the need for security with protesters' rights to free speech, today ordered a fenced-in protest area at the site of the Republican National Convention moved within 350 feet of where the delegates will be.

title: China Wins Third Gold
description: Wu Xiaoxuan of China became her nation's first double Olympic medal winner, capturing the women's three- position rifle event. The gold medal was the Chinese shooting team's third.

title: AMOSKEAG BANK SHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: WATER POLO'S NO. 10
description: MALIBU, Calif.

title: EURYTHMICS ARE REFINING SYNTHETIC POP
description: Of the many groups that have been lumped together as the British synthesizer-pop movement, the Eurythmics, who are appearing tonight at the Forest Hills Tennis Stadium, come closest to transcending the ''synth-pop'' label. Annie Lennox and Dave Stewart, who will lead an ensemble of 10 tonight, have refined their almost symphonically rich high-tech pop style, which is a touch more sophisticated than the music of groups like Culture Club, Duran Duran and the Thompson Twins. And Miss Lennox, the Eurythmics' crewcutted lead singer and sometime flutist, possesses one of the loveliest voices in English pop. She skillfully projects her husky folkish alto into piercing jazzy wails.

title: COMMEDIA PICTURES PRODUCIONS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Park Rangers Seek BearThat Killed a Camper
description: Rangers and bear experts ventured into a closed section of Yellowstone National Park today looking for a bear that killed a camper and then vanished in 125 square miles of wilderness.

title: A Woman, 82, Is Found Slain In Her Apartment in 'Village'
description: An 82-year-old woman, her hands and feet bound, was found slain in her Greenwich Village apartment yesterday, the police said.

title: FARMERS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Who Shall Own How Much TV
description: The best thing to be said for the Government's decision to enlarge the number of television and radio stations that may be owned by a single company is that it probably won't do any harm. But that is modest comfort. The Federal Communications Commission's plan is poorly designed to yield the claimed benefit, namely to stimulate more diverse television programming.

title: MUSIC: 2 SCORES ON HOMERIC THEME
description: To say that the 1984 Festival for Contemporary Music at Tanglewood came to a Homeric conclusion Wednesday night would be both literally true and a little less grandiose than it sounds. For the second half of this final program, which traditionally features the full orchestra of Berkshire Music Center student-fellows in the Theater-Concert Hall, Gunther Schuller chose two scores on the theme of ''The Odyssey'': John Harbison's ''Ulysses' Raft,'' Suite I (1983) and Nikos Skalkottas's ''Ulysses,'' intended as an opera overture, now subtitled Symphony in One Movement and probably composed around 1943.

title: ICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After realized investment gains of $983,000 for the quarter and $1,233,000 for the 6 months. c-After realized investment losses of $3,000 and an extraordinary charge of $758,000. d-After a realized investment gain of $2,463,000.

title: CITY ISSUES ON ALERT ABOUT ROAD REPAIRS AND POSSIBLE DELAYS

title: A FLAW IS FOUND IN THE DESIGNING OF INDIAN PT. 3
description: A flaw in the design of the Indian Point 3 nuclear reactor might have prevented vital cooling systems from functioning automatically in an emergency, according to the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: Steel Quota Bill's Impact
description: A five-year quota on steel imports would produce short-term gains for domestic producers without reversing the industry's overall decline, according to a study by the Congressional Budget Office released today.

title: MOSCOW REITERATES IT SERIOUSLY WANTS BAN ON SPACE ARMS
description: The Soviet feature syndicate Novosti today rejected an American assertion that Moscow was not serious about its proposal to hold talks on banning space weapons.

title: Diner's Journal
description: One of the hallmarks of a good restaurant is the attention it pays to little things. It is often possible, for example, to predict the general quality of the food by the kind of salad a restaurant serves. If a chef takes time to present an attractive and tasty salad, chances are he pays equal attention to the entrees. In Mexican restaurants, my gastronomic barometer is guacamole, which in many places tastes like avocado- flavored baby food.

title: OPERA: HENZE'S 'RIVER' PERFORMED IN SANTA FE
description: Hans Werner Henze has become music's most noticeable political moralist, and nowhere has he catalogued the evils of collective man more vividly than in ''We Come to the River.''

title: PAR TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REAGAN'S AID CHIEF DEFENDS FUND CUTS TO FIGHT ABORTIONS
description: The Reagan Administration, facing mounting opposition from Congress, today defended its new policy of linking overseas population-control funds to agreements by private aid organizations not to promote abortions.

title: CORRECTION
description: Articles on July 20 and 22, about the killing of 21 people by a gunman in a California restaurant, incorrectly described the event's place in history. The worst American mass slaying on a single day occurred in 1955, when an explosion on a passenger plane killed 44 people; John Gilbert Graham was executed for having planted the bomb to collect his mother's life insurance.

description: Although Americans demonstrably do not care to have their television viewing habits altered by political conventions, they respond eagerly to broadcasts from the Olympic Games.

Jim Dale is leaving his 'cubbyhole' to play 'Joe Egg.'
description: Jim Dale enjoyed playing ''Barnum,'' but not enough to be saddled with it the rest of his life. ''People are now calling me Jim (Barnum) Dale,'' he said by telephone the other day from Dallas, where he is winding up a tour in ''The Music Man.'' He added: ''I had to get myself out of that cubbyhole by doing something very different.''

title: HOUSE VOTES TO DENY HELP TO NICARAGUAN INSURGENTS
description: The House today approved an intelligence budget for next year that included no money for Nicaraguan rebels and barred the use of any other Federal funds for them.

title: Topics; Bright Baubles ; For the Birds
description: Faced with a flower garden, hummingbirds will head first for the crimson rose or the scarlet petunia.

title: Ohio Districting, as Is,Approved for Election
description: A panel of three Federal judges has ruled that Ohio's current Congressional districts may be used in the Nov. 6 election but that the Legislature must get to work on drawing up new districts.

title: CUOMO ROLE IN HOSPITAL STRIKE URGED
description: A group of United States Representatives, New York State legislators and New York City Council members urged Governor Cuomo yesterday to intervene in the city's hospital strike.

title: No Headline
description: Franc Option In Philadelphia The Philadelphia Stock Exchange said yesterday that it

title: ALBEE SEEKING TO CLOSE AN ALL-MALE 'WOOLF'
description: Edward Albee said today that he intended the characters in ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' to be two heterosexual couples and would take steps to close a homosexual version.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Gifford Hill & Co. , a cement and construction materials company based in Irving, Tex., said it had completed the sale of substantially all of the assets of its Peerless Cement Co. unit to a subsidiary of St. Mary's Cement Ltd.

description: ''As Archbishop of New York, it is neither my responsibility nor my desire to evaluate the qualifications of any individual of any political party for any public office, or of any individual holding office.'' - Archbishop John J. O'Connor. (7:1.)

title: PENSION SYSTEM TO DROP STOCKS OVER APARTHEID
description: The trustees of the New York City Employees' Retirement System voted unanimously yesterday to withdraw gradually its investments in companies doing business in South Africa, making it the largest public pension fund in the nation to send such a protest against apartheid.

title: 4 Ex-Candidates Get Funds
description: The Federal Election Commission approved matching funds Wednesday for four former candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination. It approved $34,131 for Senator Alan Cranston of California, $16,699 for former Senator George McGovern of South Dakota, $3,890 for Senator Gary Hart of Colorado and $498 for former Gov. Reubin Askew of Florida.

title: STATEN ISLAND MIRAGE
description: One year ago, the Navy proposed that the Brooklyn-built World War II battleship Iowa return to New York City to lead a seven-ship, nuclear- armed Surface Action Group at a new base on Staten Island. While local political and business leaders have touted the proposed base as bringing thousands of jobs, the reality is far different.

title: BELLAMY CALLS ON KOCH TO OUST 2 WELFARE AIDES
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy, saying the Human Resources Administration has ''disgraced our city,'' yesterday called on Mayor Koch to dismiss the agency's Commissioner and a top deputy.

title: Ford and U.S. Steel Plan a Rouge Unit
description: The Ford Motor Company and the United States Steel Corporation announced plans today to construct and operate a $130 million galvanizing plant at Ford's Rouge works south of Detroit.

description: The suspended Waterford Police Chief, Joseph Palladino, was arraigned on six charges today in connection with a scheme to frame his former supervisor.

title: NEW RALLY IN CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets extended their rally yesterday, dominated by the belief that interest rates will decline further. For the fourth straight day, prices rose and yields fell for Treasury notes and bonds.

title: ABORTION FOES ASSAIL MONDALE TICKET
description: Even before the Democrats put together their national ticket last month, antiabortion activists had vowed to work for President Reagan's re-election. But with the nomination of Geraldine A. Ferraro, this movement has moved into higher political gear, and Governor Cuomo's remarks on the subject this week appear certain to intensify interest in the abortion issue.

title: Netherlands Tops U.S
description: Despite applying pressure for most of the game and dominating play against the world champions, the United States dropped a 2-1 decision to the Netherlands today in the women's Olympic field hockey competition.

title: Vanessa Williams Gets Role in NBC-TV Series
description: Vanessa Williams, dethroned as Miss America because nude pictures she posed for with another woman were published in a magazine last month, has landed a guest role in an NBC detective series, a network spokesman announced today.

title: U.S. Women Beat China in Volleyball
description: The United States women's volleyball team remained undefeated, beating China tonight in four games.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Economic Scene column in Business Day yesterday misidentified the author of the book ''Debt Shock.'' He is Darrell Delamaide.

title: No Headline
description: -AM to Observe Hiroshima Anniversary
