description: b-Includes special gains of $55,000 for the quarter and $460,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes special gains of $444,000 for the quarter and $440,000 for the 6 months.

title: Triton Extends Republic Offer
description: The Republic Corporation said Triton Group Ltd. had extended to Aug. 17 its offer to acquire Republic.

title: EXPOS CUT CUBS' LEAD TO HALF A GAME
description: Max Venable, a pinch-hitter, drew a leadoff walk in the ninth inning and eventually scored the winning run when the Chicago Cubs failed to convert what would have been an inning-ending double play today as the Montreal Expos triumphed, 6-5.

title: Saratoga Special To Chief's Crown
description: Chief's Crown, a colt from the first crop sired by Danzig, established himself as the class of the local 2-year-olds with a 2 3/4-length victory today in the $70,100 Saratoga Special.

title: IN DALLAS, A FEAST FOR THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Many visitors to Dallas know of only one place to shop: Neiman-Marcus. It is indeed a wonderful store, with five selling floors of fine foods and cookware, furs, Oriental art, Pratesi linens, America's best designer fashions and the clothes of Europeans such as Versace, Armani, Missoni, Valentino, Chanel and Ungaro that most stores in the area do not carry.

title: A LEADER'S PRIORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Toll in Airport BombingIn India Rises to 23 Dead
description: The toll in a bomb explosion at the Madras International Airport Thursday night rose today to 23 people killed and 24 wounded, the authorities said.

title: CUOMO PRAISES ARCHBISHOP'S STATEMENT
description: Governor Cuomo of New York said today that he was ''pleased'' with a statement by the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York that it was ''neither my responsibility nor my desire'' to assess the positions of public officials or political candidates.

title: THE PREMIER NETWORK THAT A.T.&T. BUILT
description: To the Editor:

title: YANKEES SWEEP INDIANS BY 9-0, 3-2
description: In a season in which good fortune has been scarce and fleeting for them, the Yankees climbed above the .500 mark for the first time last night with a 9-0, 3-2 sweep of the Cleveland Indians at Yankee Stadium.

title: OPERA: WORLD PREMIERE OF 'LOVE OF DON PERLIMPLIN'
description: Conrad Susa's ''Love of Don Perlimplin'' is often a very beautiful work, and even its lesser passages command respect. This one-act opera, which received its world premiere tonight at the State University of New York at Purchase, as part of the Pepsico Summerfare '84, takes its text from a play of the same name by Federico Garcia Lorca, who described it as an ''erotic lace-paper valentine.''

title: STOCK SURGE: BOON FOR REAGAN
description: The stock market this week has given the economic recovery a rousing endorsement, apparently casting off months of apprehension over Federal deficits. In the process, it has handed President Reagan more good news. The market surge caps a series of dramatic improvements in the economy. In recent months, as economic growth, employment and inflation successively brightened, a lackluster stock market was the most conspicuous exception to the pattern of improvement.

title: GOLD TO RETTON IN ALL-AROUND
description: The individual all-around gold medal in women's gymnastics was up for grabs until the final event tonight. Then Mary Lou Retton grabbed it.

title: From the Slopes
description: It isn't often that a major university looking for a new athletic director turns to the world of skiing for the choice, but that is what Colorado did yesterday in naming a successor to Eddie Crowder , who has retired. The new man is Bill Marolt , Alpine director of the United States Ski Team, which won five medals, three of them gold, at the Winter Olympics in Sarajevo.

title: ON-LINE SOFTWARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income. c-Including a non-operating gain of $200,000. Year-ago results have been restated for acquisition recorded as a pooling of interests.

description: Scientists have succeeded in infecting chimpanzees with acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, and have thus taken a crucial step toward development of a vaccine against the disease.

title: PSYCHIATRIC NURSES' JOB
description: To the Editor:

title: BARBARA DEMING
description: Barbara Deming, a writer, civil rights activist and pacifist, died of cancer Thursday at her home in Sugarloaf Key, Fla.

title: Brother of I.R.A. Chief Faces Conspiracy Charges in Ulster
description: A brother of the leader of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, was charged today with conspiracy to murder a policeman and two counts of illegal possession of weapons.

description: A Federal judge ruled today that USA Today printed weather information ''in a misleading way'' in its new international edition but refused to order the newspaper to print a disclaimer.

description: An anonymous donor, ''appalled'' by the condition of the lawn at the John F. Kennedy Memorial here, has offered to pay to have it spruced up before the Republican National Convention, county officials say.

description: The grass is so green in the Long Meadow in Prospect Park these days and the elm trees so lush that the greensward looks more like a 19th-century English landscape than a very urban park deep in the heart of Brooklyn.

title: POLE DEMANDS END TO ALL SANCTIONS
description: The official Polish Government spokesman reacted today to President Reagan's decision to ease some of the United States sanctions on Poland by saying he expected a fuller retreat on the curbs imposed after the declaration of martial law.

description: The financial success of simulcasts from Saratoga to Aqueduct this week was followed yesterday by a flurry of announcements concerning other simulcasting arrangements involving tracks in the New York area.

description: By any standards, Gerard Schwarz maintains an extraordinary schedule. Already the music director of the Y Chamber Symphony in New York, Lincoln Center's Mostly Mozart Festival, a series of programs called Music Today at the Abraham Goodman House, the Waterloo Summer Festival in New Jersey and the Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra, he was recently named principal conductor of the Seattle Symphony.

title: ABC OLYMPIC COVERAGE IS CALLED TOO PARTIAL
description: The president of the International Olympic Committee has protested what he calls the overemphasis on American athletes in ABC's television coverage of the Games.

description: The State Health Commissioner said yesterday that his department was increasing surveillance of struck hospitals in New York City to insure the welfare of patients.

title: BIGGS WINS BUT IS CRITICIZED
description: In a division in which some of the competitors look more like dancing bears than boxers, Tyrell Biggs is a polished practitioner in the manly art of self- defense. On his toes, left jab whistling in an opponent's face, he piles up plenty of the points with the judges. The trouble is, Biggs makes few, if any, with everyone else in the arena.

title: FOR THE POLES, SOME CURRENCIES ARE MORE EQUAL THAN OTHERS
description: There is a riddle going around here these days that asks, ''Why is Poland just like the United States?''

title: MINIMAL EFFECT IN SOUTH SEEN FROM LANCE MOVE
description: Southern Democrats said today that the resignation Thursday night of Bert Lance as general chairman of Walter F. Mondale's Presidential campaign would have little or no effect on the chances of the Democratic ticket in the South.

title: Scorn Not the Disclosure Law
description: The criminal conviction and House floor reprimand of Representative George Hansen of Idaho brings much anguish to many of his colleagues. Instead of feeling cleaner for the enforcement of the 1978 financial disclosure law, some members voice regret about their own Ethics in Government Act. But ''who would have the courage to come forward'' and soften that law, asks Speaker O'Neill.

title: REAGAN LIFTS SOME U.S. SANCTIONS AGAINST POLAND
description: The Administration announced today that President Reagan was easing some economic sanctions against Poland because of ''a significant move in the direction of national reconciliation'' by the Polish Government.

title: Reliance Agrees To Buy Days Inn
description: Reliance Capital Group, a private investment partnership headed by Saul P. Steinberg, the New York City financier, said it had agreed to acquire Days Inn of America Inc. Terms were not disclosed, but last week, Goldman, Sachs & Company, adviser to the sellers, is understood to have told bidders that more than $300 million was wanted.

title: Some U.S. Boxers Irked
description: Despite the success in the ring thus far, problems have arisen in the American boxing camp. Mark Breland, the Brooklyn-born welterweight and gold medal favorite, is one of three boxers who reportedly are no longer training with the United States Olympic coach, Pat Nappi, and the rest of their teammates.

description: Gearhart Industries said the New York Stock Exchange had begun proceedings to delist Gearhart common stock.

title: TIRED OF LOSING
description: Charlie Simmer , the longtime scoring star of the Los Angeles Kings, wants the team to trade him. It's not the West Coast ambience that has Simmer itching to get out, but rather losing season upon losing season.

description: Geraldine A. Ferraro, the Democrats' Vice-Presidential candidate, has not decided how to spend the $138,000 campaign war chest she raised for re-election to her House seat from Queens, a legislative aide said today.

Although the latest chapter of his story ended with two consecutive defeats to Mark Gorski of Costa Mesa, Calif., in the two- of-three heat 1,000-meter sprint final at the Olympic Velodrome, their smiles said the two had made United States Olympic history.

title: SAM HOUSTON DAY
description: Sam Houston Day, former managing editor of the old New York Journal- American, died of pneumonia yesterday at the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow, L.I. He was 87 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

title: HYPERBOLYMPICS
description: Now that the Olympics are upon us, we're starting to hear a lot about the ''world-class.'' They've flown into L.A. from all over: world-class sprinters, world-class decathletes, world-class windsurfers, world-class partiers and all the rest. There's even a guy on America's cycling team who developed his world-class speed as a bike messenger in Manhattan.

title: Letter; On the Handicapped; Proper Measures of Human Worth To the Editor:
description: It is unfortunate that your July 9 editorial ''Who Will Pay the Bills for Baby Doe?'' focuses on the financial aspect of providing care to handicapped infants who survive. While I applaud your acknowledgment of society's obligation to support handicapped infants and their families, your closing question - ''But who will pay for an adequate level of continuing care?'' - reflects an ignorance of the substantial achievements made by handicapped individuals and the work of their families during the past decades to develop services that meet their needs.

title: LED THE FIGHT FOR SOCIAL PROGRAMS
description: Representative Carl Dewey Perkins of Kentucky, the driving force behind much of the nation's social legislation, died early this afternoon in Lexington, Ky., after becoming ill on an airplane trip from Washington.

title: Increase Some Graduate School Loans
description: The cost of a graduate education at Harvard or Stanford University can easily exceed $10,000 a year. But the federally subsidized loans available to graduate and professional school students have been frozen since 1976 at $5,000 a year, with a total of $25,000. That effectively bars poorer students from the more elite schools.

description: Greece and the United States signed an agreement today covering Greek workers at the American military bases here, formally ending a month-long strike.

title: New Medicare Plan Faulted
description: A Medicare program being put into effect to save money by paying flat fees to hospitals will probably not work because doctors will admit more patients to keep hospitals profitable, according to researchers who studied admission patterns.

Though Texas is in the throes of the fad for what started as mesquite-grilled meat in tortillas, the rest of the country doesn't even know what they are. Talk about turning a sow's purse into a silk ear!

The models recalled were 1977 Thunderbirds, Cougars, LTD II's and Rancheros with 302, 351M and 400 CED V8 engines, and 1978 and 1979 Granadas and Monarchs with 250 CID six-cylinder engines.

description: Depositors have drained nearly $12 billion from the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company since the beginning of the year, most of it after the run accelerated in the spring, the bank said today.

Eto won the silver medal and Haralambos Holidis of Greece defeated Nicolae Zamfir of Romania, 2-1, to take the bronze medal.

title: METS GAIN FULL GAME ON CUBS
description: After seven consecutive losses that spun them into second place, the Mets finally revived with a roar tonight, hit three home runs off John Candelaria and defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-1.

title: Jaguar Shares Sell Out
description: Institutions, car buffs and small investors vied for shares in today's heavily oversubscribed flotation of Jaguar P.L.C. The rush to apply for the 177.9 million shares in the luxury auto maker created a traffic jam outside the branch of Barclays Bank handling the issue. Hill Samuel, the merchant bank that organized the sale, is expected to announce allocation of the shares Monday and trading is to begin Thursday.

description: A group of inmates who were held in the Westchester County Jail obtained an unusual $250,000 settlement yesterday to end a lawsuit that accused correction officers of abusing the inmates during a jail disturbance.

title: Men's Turn Now
description: Nadia Comaneci of Rumania was the first gymnast to earn the perfect score 10 in the Olympics, doing it in 1976 at Montreal. But at these Olympic Games, it is the men who are racking up 10's right and left, and one gymnastics coach thinks it's a matter of a psychological pendulum swinging too far in one direction after having swung too far in the other direction.

title: DIPLOMAT'S WIDOW AIDS THE YOUNG
description: Behind the marbled symbols of power and plenty that mark the face of this city of limousines, luxury hotels and expense-account restaurants are facts and figures that speak of another Washington.

description: The Senate's assistant majority leader said today that the final military budget for 1985 would grow 5 percent after accounting for inflation, rather than the 7.5 percent that President Reagan and the rest of the Republican leadership have insisted on.

title: W.M. Frohock Is Dead at 76; Harvard Professor Emeritus
description: Dr. W. M. Frohock, professor emeritus of French literature at Harvard University and an internationally known critic and author, died of cancer Tuesday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 76 years old.

title: LINEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CHIEF SPONSER MOVES TO RESCUE IMMIGRATION BILL
description: Senator Alan K. Simpson, chief sponsor of a comprehensive immigration bill, moved today to rescue the legislation, which Walter F. Mondale and many other Democrats have been trying to kill. Mr. Simpson called for the appointment of a House-Senate conference committee to develop a compromise version of the legislation acceptable to President Reagan and to the Democratic- controlled House. The Wyoming Republican said Mr. Reagan had given an assurance he would sign a compromise immigration bill if it were less costly than the one passed by the House. The White House said last week that the House version was ''unacceptable.'' Despite differences in the House and Senate versions of the bill, both measuress would prohibit employment of illegal aliens, authorize penalties against employers who hire illegal aliens and offer legal status to many illegal aliens already in the United States. The House passed the bill by a five-vote margin, 216 to 211, on June 20. The Senate approved a similar bill, 76 to 18, in May 1983. The bill has been back in the Senate for six weeks, but the Senate has not requested a conference, the normal procedure for reconciling differences on major legislation. Opponents of the bill said that if a conference committee came up with a compromise measure they had enough votes to block its approval on the floor of the House. The Democratic candidates for President and Vice President, Mr. Mondale and Geraldine A. Ferraro, strongly oppose the measure and have denounced it in speeches.

title: STUDENT VISAS DROP ANCHOR
description: Governments' efforts to control people typically lead to unanticipated consequences as the authorities try to cope with the evasions and avoidance always prompted by the controls. Immigration controls are no exception. A particularly important and offensive but little-noticed consequence for the American immigration system relates to foreign students.

title: SATURDAY, AUGUST 4, 1984 International
description: A cutoff of discount-priced oil to Central American and Caribbean countries ''that initiate warlike actions'' against their neighbors is a new policy instrument adopted by Mexico and Venezuela. A spokesman for Mexico's Ministry of Foreign Relations said the new condition would apply only to future actions. (Page 1, Column 2.) Saudi Arabia freed some Americans it had imprisoned on a variety of offenses, according to Saudi and American officials and a recently freed prisoner. A State Department official said 17 Americans, about half of the estimated 33 in Saudi prisons, had been released under a general amnesty and that additional releases were imminent. (1:4.)

description: Philippe Heberle won France's first gold medal of the Games today, finishing first in the Olympic men's air rifle competition.

title: Haughton Likes His Chances

The brown 3-year- old colt is essentially Haughton's teammate in what will be the 23d Hambletonian for this Hall of Fame driver, who has won the event, the most prestigious in harness racing, four times in the last decade. The Hambletonian offers a purse of $1,219,000, a record for the race.

description: Driven by capricious winds and churned by a choppy sea, a 85-mile-long oil slick advanced down the Gulf Coast today, sending feelers ashore and threatening prime fisheries and the coast's lucrative tourist industry.

description: The Selective Service System today defended its use of a mailing list compiled by a national chain of ice cream stores to advise young men that they were liable for draft registration.

description: The heaviest trading in Wall Street history sent stock prices soaring again yesterday as investors gained confidence that the economy had entered a sounder phase. It was the best week ever for the stock market in terms of both volume and price gains.

The Chinese were favored to win the team gold medal; their star, Li Ning, was favored to win the individual all-around gold medal; and Li, Tong Fei and Lou Yun all were expected to win medals in various of the individual apparatus finals.

description: It was a question that Vince Van Patten had not answered definitively until last March, when it became apparent to the former child actor that he needed to do some soul-searching.

description: In yet another day of lopsided victories for the United States men's and women's basketball teams, the women made the most significant achievement. Their 91-55 defeat of China, the fourth straight victory, assured the women of a spot in the gold medal game Tuesday night.

description: The Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York accused Governor Cuomo yesterday of misrepresenting the implications of a statement the bishop made in June on abortion and politics.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $70,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $145,000.

title: U.S. Team Takes Equestrian Gold
description: In an upset, the United States won the team gold medal today in the Olympic equestrian event, edging the favored British riding team, 186 points to 189.2. In individual competition, Karen Stives of Dover, Mass., took a silver on Ben Arthur.

title: Comserv Plans A Restatement
description: The Comserv Corporation said it plans to restate financial statements for 1981 and 1982. Comserv said the restatement results from its discovery of additional contingency commitments and possible contract irregularities.

title: White Pair Wins FightTo Adopt Black Boy
description: A white couple battling a state policy that discourages interracial adoptions won the right today to adopt a mildly retarded 3-year-old black child when county social service agents agreed they would make better parents than other applicants.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: MURDER FOR PLEASURE: The Life and Times of the Detective Story, by Howard Haycraft. (Carroll & Graf, $10.95.) ''Murder for Pleasure,'' the first historical analysis of detective stories published in the United States, appeared in 1941, exactly 100 years after the publication of the first detective story - Edgar Allan Poe's ''The Murders in the Rue Morgue.'' Katherine Woods wrote in The Book Review that the book ''makes an encyclopedic appeal to real students of this genre; and not merely in the comprehensiveness of its main historical text, but also in its bibliography and lists of authors, in its detective story quiz, and in its chapters on the rules and the democratic alliances of detective fiction.'' THE BRIDGE ON THE DRINA, by Ivo Andric. (University of Chicago, $8.95.) A widely translated Yugoslav book, ''The Bridge on the Drina'' was published in 1945. In 1961 Ivo Andric won the Nobel Prize in Literature. The book is about Serbian men and women and how a bridge constructed in the 16th century and destroyed in World War I affected their lives. In his review, Stoyan Christowe wrote: ''Mr. Andric possesses keen insight into human motivation. His characters attain stature and become memorable not so much by their actions as by the author's probing into their souls and minds. He dissects, analyzes, interprets. There is no indirection or implication. Everything is said, stated, but always in readable prose.''

title: SOME OF THE BARRICADES STILL STAND IN LEBANON
description: Sipping thick Arabian coffee from a small paper cup, the Lebanese army colonel waited last week in his jeep outside the Empire Theater. The movie house sits on the eastern, Christian edge of the Green Line, in the heart of the old downtown, the financial and entertainment district of what had been the richest, liveliest city in the Arab world. In the nine years since the Empire showed its last film, barricades have grown around it protecting front-line positions in Lebanon's unending cycle of war.

title: North Lebanon Rivals Battle to Control City
description: Rival Moslem militia groups fought each other with grenades and mortars early today in a continuing battle for control of Tripoli, Lebanon's northern port and second biggest city.

title: OFFICE DEVELOPMENT UNEARTHING CITY'S BURIED HISTORY
description: OUT of necessity rather than by choice, developers in New York City have become the financial angels of archeological excavations that increasingly are uncovering glimpses of the city's Colonial past.

description: Catherine Moffat Mueller, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Paul A. Mueller of Lancaster, Pa., was married there yesterday to David Creighton Boyer Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Boyer of Centreville, Del. The Rev. Larry L. Lehman performed the ceremony at the Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity.

title: Maternity Leave
description: To the Editor:

title: Fatal Disease in Texas Linked to Lake Water
description: A 3-year- old boy has died and another was in critical condition today, both victims of a rare disease officials believe they contracted while swimming in Texas lakes.

title: FRIENDLY GAMES OF COMBAT
description: Many years ago while watching two neighbor lads lopping off the tops of goldenrod with wooden swords and throwing a hatchet into a plank propped against a weathered outbuilding, I wondered - having beheaded a goodly number of black-eyed Susans in my own childhood - if the urge for combat is a genetic trait.

title: FILM LAURELS FOR A LEGENDARY HORSE
description: Simon Wincer sat in the back of a taxicab with three cans of film on his lap one sweltering afternoon in Manhattan last summer, cursing the heat and the midtown traffic.

title: Miss Vergara Marries Richard McConnell Jr.

The Rev. Joseph Dragon performed the ceremony at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in West Chester, Pa.

title: ISRAELI WOMEN SEEK NEW ROLE
description: What started here this week as a somewhat academic look at ''Woman as Jew, Jew as Woman,'' took on the atmosphere of a women's support group as Israelis sought advice from their American counterparts on how to revitalize a lagging feminist movement in their country.

title: WHAT'S BEHIND CASTRO'S SOFTER TONE
description: Once again, Fidel Castro is talking as if he wants to improve relations with the United States. Whether he will make headway is not clear, but there is no mystery about his motivation. Cuba's economy has more than a few problems and there are those who believe President Castro is not comfortable being almost entirely dependent on the Soviet Union. He would like to be doing business with the United States, these experts say, buying and selling goods, taking advantage of American technology and welcoming American tourists. He says he would also prefer not to be spending so much time and energy on national defense.

title: CLEANUP UNDER WAY
description: Cleanup crews worked round the clock Friday night and today to swab up an estimated 5,000 tons of tar-like crude oil that smeared miles of the Texas coast from the Louisiana line to below Galveston Bay.

title: MAKE EDUCATION TOP PRIOROTY
description: AS citizens, we have a moral and social responsibility to insure that public education continues as the cornerstone of our democracy. Without a viable system of public schooling in our nation, our very democratic way of life runs a risk of not surviving. This point was dramatically noted by H. G. Wells, who stated, ''Human history becomes more and more a race between education and catastrophe.''

title: A BOOKSHELF OF SUMMER READING

Abrams, $35), evolved from the author's observation that many artists build furniture that is tangential to their art but reveals a high level of inventiveness.

title: Great White Sharks Seen
description: Shark alerts were posted today along coastal sections of the Golden Gate National Recreation Area after confirmed sightings of at least three great white sharks. The warnings were put up after a teen-age surfer sighted what was believed to be a 10-to- 15-foot shark about 100 yards off the rocks at the south end of the popular beach area 20 miles north of San Francisco.

title: THE WORDS OF MUSIC
description: In demonstrating how words in current use differ in their specialized meaning among musicians, Donal Henahan inadvertently demonstrated his own point (''The Words of Music,'' On Language, July 1). ''Babbitty'' may refer, among the general public, to values evoked by Sinclair Lewis's novel, ''Babbitt;'' but, among musicians, it might rather refer to the writings of Milton Babbitt, the noted composer, theorist and teacher. CARY M. MAZER Assistant Professor of English

description: The city's Landmarks Preservation Commission has approved the basic design for a 28-unit apartment house to be built in the heart of the Greenwich Village Historic District on the Avenue of the Americas between Waverly and Washington Places.

description: Ridership on the Long Island Rail Road continues to increase, meaning fewer seats for rush-hour passengers, but to accommodate commuters, the line is making some adjustments to its schedule and reshuffling its available coaches while it awaits the delivery of new cars.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
THE 'PAPER CHASE' ODYSSEY CONTINUES
description: The almost Odyssean wandering of ''The Paper Chase'' has emerged as a precedent-setting example of the uneasy relationship between quality and commerciality in American popular culture. The series was first seen by home viewers on broadcast television, on CBS, where it came to be considered a cut above the customary network fare - ambitious and incisive, even high- brow at times. But after one season, the show was canceled, a victim of lackluster ratings. Devoted fans were there but in insufficient numbers, and ''The Paper Chase'' took on the mystique of being a show ''too good'' for commercial television.

title: TODAY, CAUTION FIRST
description: No flags will fly on Tuesday, the 20th anniversary of the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution. No Presidents will meet, no ceremonies will mourn the millions who died from the decision made that fateful day. But if we cannot celebrate the resolution, we must remember it. For the ghosts of Tonkin are today being resurrected in a Congressional debate over another Gulf - the Gulf of Fonseca, in Central America.

title: IN FRANKLIN TOWNSHIP; THE GROWTH MARCHES ON
description: Until recently, the commercial base of Franklin Township, N.J., which stretches from New Brunswick to Princeton, had been mostly agricultural. But seven years ago, hoping to spur commercial development, township officials allocated about $7 million to a program to improve such public facilities as roads and sewage systems.

description: A high school and college English teacher (John P. Stevens High School, Edison, and Adjunct Instructor, Middlesex County College, Edison) who agrees that more emphasis should be placed on science in the elementary and middle schools of New Jersey? Yes!

description: The Long Island wine industry, which was established in the early 1970's and came as a surprise to many people, appears healthy and is expanding at a rate that should persuade even the skeptics.

title: Radiation Leak From Truck
description: Low-level radioactive material leaking from a parked truck contaminated six people, but officials said the contamination level was mild and hosed them down with water. State radiation protection officials evaluating the uranium hexaflouride leak at the Truckstops of America store on U.S. Route 84 east of Santa Rosa said the radiation level at the scene Friday night was minimal.

title: TAINTED SPIRIT OF THE OLYMPIAN OLYNPICS
description: To the Editor:

title: VALUABLE REISSUES SHED LIGHT ON PIANO ASTISTRY
description: Early recordings by the brilliant American pianist William Kapell are the highlight of a recent crop of keyboard disks. Kapell had it all - a superb technique, boundless energy and a sharp musical intelligence - but a 1953 plane crash cut short his career. Since then, Kapell has attained legendary status, and his commerical recordings, all currently out of print, command top prices from collectors. (RCA has announced that it will eventually reissue some of these, at least; a complete restoration of Kapell's commercial recordings would involve six or seven LP's, and should not prove an impossible ideal.)

title: PERES EXPECTING CHANCE TO FORM ISRAELI COALITION
description: Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader, says that he expects to be chosen to form a new Israeli government soon and that he intends to seek the widest coalition possible.

title: ;  'One of the Kids'For the first time in the 38-year history of Little League baseball, a girl is on the roster of a World Series team. Her name is
description: Victoria Roche, and she is a reserve outfielder for Brussels, winner of the European Little League regional tournament. The Brussels team is composed of 11- and 12-year-old youngsters of many nationalities whose parents work for International Telephone and Telegraph in Belgium.

title: NEW LIFE IN SIGHT FOR OLD CAROUSEL
description: ONE recent Saturday morning, a group of New Haven residents filled seven 55- gallon drums with shoveled pigeon droppings. They have spent months scraping paint off wood, and have held drives to raise thousands of dollars, $5 or $10 at a time.

title: TWO FAILURES BRING CHANGES FOR WEATHER DATA SATELLITES
description: While weather forecasters are lamenting that in recent weeks two satellites have become ''blind,'' they are counting their blessings in having regained another.

title:
CAMERA;
HAND-HELD LIGHT METERS CAN MAKE A DIFFERENCE
description: When a photographer invests in an automatic camera, he expects it to produce correctly exposed pictures every time the release button is pressed. This does not always happen. Although the through-the-lens metering system used in most modern 35mm cameras is useful and practical, hand-held light meters often measure light more accurately.

title: Games' Security Guards Complain of Pay Delays
description: Security guards hired for the Olympics have complained of delays in getting their paychecks.

title: Illini Chooses '85 to Use Its TV Football Ban
description: In order to give its senior players some reward during a season in which they cannot play in a bowl game, the University of Illinois has decided to take its one-year television ban in 1985 instead of 1984.

title: RIGHT NOTES
description: To the Editor:

title: 18 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 18 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
FOR SOME WITH VIVID MEMORIES, EVERY DAY IS FATHER'S DAY
description: THE little girl had laid out her tools on the glass- topped coffee table: a comb, nail clippers, a razor, a shaving brush, a washrag, a towel and a bowl.

title: HOW TO FIX A DOOR THAT WON'T STAY OPEN OR CLOSED
description: WHEN a door won't stay open or closed by itself - that is, when it tends to swing slowly closed after it has been left open, or when it swings slowly open and won't stay in the partly closed position unless latched shut - chances are that the door jamb is out of plumb. In other words, the door jamb against which the hinges are fastened is not standing exactly vertical; it is leaning slightly toward one side or the other.

title: Elmer Smith, 91, Outfielder Who Hit First Slam in Series
description: Elmer Smith, former Cleveland Indian outfielder who in 1920 hit the first grand slam in World Series history, died Friday of emphysema at his home.

title: NEW OPERA IS THRIVING AFTER YEARS OF NEGLECT
description: Every three months, the Central Opera Service, a subsidiary of the Metropolitan Opera, puts outs its Bulletin, a major portion of which is a listing of operatic premieres, domestic and international, recent and forthcoming. The summer 1984 issue, which is not atypical, contains a positively dizzying number of such novelties. And they're hardly all grimly serious, gratingly dissonant, modernist statements about the human condition, either, or worthy folk operas of the sort our more provincial regional companies have traditionally purveyed.

title: Teacher Is Wed To Sarah Blake
description: Sarah Ludlow Blake, a daughter of Mrs. Henry W. English of Sharon, Conn., and New Haven and the late T. Whitney Blake, was married in Sharon yesterday to Robert Alexander Southworth Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Southworth of Little Boar's Head, North Hampton, N.H. The Rev. H. Philip West Jr. of the Sharon United Methodist Church performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:

title: HONG KONG, DESPITE ACCORD, IS STILL ON EDGE
description: Christine Loh is skeptical about the agreement on Hong Kong this week between China and Britain.

title: LEVEL OF ACID RAIN IN STATE 'DANGEROUS'
description: PRELIMINARY results of the first statewide testing for acid rain show that ''dangerous levels of acids are present in more than half of the rain, sleet and snow that falls here,'' according to the biologist in charge of the testing.

title: RIDING HERD AT PHILIP MORRIS
description: TOBACCO has long been part of Hamish Maxwell's life. His father, Sir Alexander Maxwell, headed a British tobacco importing concern and served as Britain's Tobacco Controller during World War II. Cigarettes were always around the Maxwell house, and today Hamish Maxwell smokes two packs a day, varying his brands. Throughout his career - and this year he celebrates 30 years with Philip Morris, America's largest tobacco concern - selling cigarettes has always been his job.

title:
THE SOCIAL SECURITY SOLUTION;
THINGS MAY NOT BE SO BAD AFTER ALL
description: TWICE during the last decade the

title: MUSICAL: A FANTASY ABOUT LIFE
description: The virtues of friendship, loyalty and courage are gently and appealingly evoked in Toni Mulett's children's musical, ''The Magical Forest'' (''El Conejito Azul,'' or ''The Blue Bunny'' in the Spanish version). The outdoor show, which opened the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater's annual summer tour on Thursday, in Riverside Park, will be visiting neighborhoods around the New York metropolitan area for the next month, offering some performances in English, others in Spanish. The show, which lasts a little more than an hour, is free to the public.

title: DEBRIS FROM THE TONKIN RESOLUTION
description: Twenty years ago this month, an incident at sea, minor in itself, set in motion events that would carry America into its most divisive war. The events in the Gulf of Tonkin and the war in Vietnam that followed pitted the nation against itself, set the stage for the abdication of one President and the resignation of another and generated a rebellion in Congress that placed that body in temporary command of foreign policy while shattering the imperial Presidency.

title: Maria West to Be a Bride
description: Maria Selden West and David Martin Hochschartner, teachers at the North Country School in Lake Placid, N.Y., plan to be married Sept. 8. Mr. and Mrs. Herbert B. West of Darien, Conn., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norbert Hochschartner of Manchester, N.H. Miss West's father is president of the New York Community Trust. Her fiance's father is a financial consultant.

title: Japan Won't GiveUp on Whaling
description: Trust the Japanese to find a way to launder whales. So it seemed last week, when an advisory panel to the Fisheries Agency proposed that Japan end commercial whaling in the Antarctic Ocean in return for permission to hunt whales there for ''research'' purposes.

title: High Hopes For Louganis
description: Greg Louganis has played the moment over and over in his mind.

description: Odd that Lacey Fosburgh's penetrating CAT scan of San Francisco's body and soul somehow failed to reveal the one larger reality controlling the future fate of the maverick metropolis.

description: The military Government and leaders of three political groups have signed an agreement calling for elections Nov. 25 and a return to democracy March 1.

title: OUT, DARN FLEAS!
description: THERE is a ritual of summer I could do without: ridding the pets of fleas. This may seem like a minor irritation that comes with keeping animals, but when you have three dogs and three cats, you realize the magnitude of the problem.

title: U.S. Skeet Shooter Takes Gold Medal
description: Matthew Dryke of the United States won the the gold medal in the Olympic skeet competition with a record- tying 198-point performance.

title: WHY A TALLER SKYSCRAPER? BECAUSE IT's NOT THERE
description: In May 1906, at a time when no building in the world was taller than 40 stories, a New York City developer named Theodore Starrett proposed a tower of 100 stories with manufacturing on the lower levels, offices higher up, apartments above that and hotel rooms at the top. Last week, in a world where a 110-story building in Chicago is king, New York's most conspicuous developer, Donald Trump, proposed a tower of 150 stories with offices on the bottom, a hotel in the middle and ''super luxury'' apartments on top.

title: Broadcast TV
description: ''Northern Lights'' is a bonny wisp of a Scottish television play that comes to WNET/Channel 13 on Saturday at 9 P.M. It is just the thing for a sultry summer night that is begging not to be taken too strenuously but wants something with a touch of humor, a touch of story line and a touch of talent in the telling.

title: Karen Poziomek Wed to Ronald Mann
description: The marriage of Karen Marie Poziomek, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward J. Poziomek of Bel Air, Md., to Ronald Jay Mann, a son of Peggy Lebair Mann of Slingerlands, N.Y., and the late Dr. Jay D. Mann, took place yesterday. Rabbi Charles Lippmann and the Rev. William Hamilton, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Rudy's Beau Rivage in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: AN UNFINISHED RACHMANINOFFOPERA COMES ALIVE AT LAST
description: Opera and Rachmaninoff had a passionate but troubled marriage that ended in divorce in 1908. The great composer-pianist had led two seasons at the Bolshoi, and conducted opera elsewhere before that. He had collaborated closely with the great bass Feodor Chaliapin on much of the Russian repertory. He had composed three stage works, and had at leat two more on his mind.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: There are only three of them left now, but since the seven original members of the Sound Avenue Quilters started getting together in the early 60's to help one another and their neighbors quilt, they estimate they have stitched and chatted their way through 150 or more quilts.

title: ITALIAN FARE IN AN INTIMATE SETTING
description: LOCANDA, a new Italian restaurant in Merrick, is under the same management as Caminari's in Locust Valley. With its stylish contemporary decor, Locanda has a very different look from the parent establishment, which is done with classic old World formality.

title: Angolans Report 143 Rebels Were Slain One Week in July
description: Angolan Government troops killed 143 insurgents in five southern provinces between July 17 and 24, the official press agency said today.

title: MEDICAL STUDENTS AND MARTYRDOM
description: I read, in Michael Harwood's article, that anesthesiology is a specialty in which I am not responsible for overseeing patient care and have reasonable working hours. I read this the weekend after I had been in the hospital for 48 hours, getting three hours' sleep on Saturday night.

title: A SILENT CLASSIC GETS SOME 80'S MUSIC
description: At first glance, there would seem to be little in common between Fritz Lang's silent film classic ''Metropolis'' - the visually dazzling science-fiction epic made by the Viennese director in 1925-26 - and the quintessentially 1980's sound of Giorgio Moroder, the Oscar-winning composer of ''Flashdance,'' as well as the scores of ''Midnight Express,'' ''American Gigolo'' and ''Scarface.'' And apart from the fact that both artists eventually moved to California, there is not much to suggest a shared sensibility or concerns.

title: WHOSE PARTY IS IT, ANYWAY?
description: Richard Reeves is a syndicated columnist and the author of ''American Journey: Traveling With Tocqueville in Search of Democracy in America.''

title: POWER FAILS AT MALL ON L.I., FORCING OUT 6,000
description: More than 6,000 people were forced to leave the Sunrise Mall in Massapequa, L.I., yesterday afternoon after a power failure cut off lights and air-conditioning to its shops and walkways.

title: PRAGMATIC, LEGAL PAC'S
description: To the Editor:

title: Benefit Swim Plan Eagerly Supported
description: I enjoyed reading the fine article on the swimming program for the disabled conducted at the State University of New York at Purchase (''About Westchester,'' July 15). The program is truly a wonderful aid to its participants.

title: CELEBRATING ZUCCHINI
description: Although Russell Baker refers many times to ''planting'' squash, he overlooks the truism that ''zucchini grows whether you plant it or not'' (''Squash,'' Sunday Observer, June 24).

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: Hospital Dismisses Doctors Tied to Buying of Diplomas
description: Two doctors working at Morristown Memorial Hospital have been dismissed because of their links to a medical school diploma-selling scheme.

title: THE ECONOMY CHEERS REAGAN AND CHALLENGES THE DEMOCRATS
description: THE performance of the economy and how it affects the lives of Americans, rich, poor and middle-class, is shaping up as a major issue at this month's Republican National Convention in Dallas, as it was at last month's Democratic National Convention in San Francisco.

title: Not a Member Of Umbrella Group
description: I found the article on Jody Ruth Cohen's appointment as assistant Rabbi to a West Hartford congregation most interesting. A serious factual error was committed, however, in stating that only one other female Rabbi has served a congregation in Connecticut, and that was Rabbi Elizabeth Rolle in 1981-82.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CASTLES IN JORDAN, A WILD RIDE IN VIRGINIA
description: To a Stronghold Of Lawrence In Jordan

title: REACTOR ENDS RUN THAT BROKE RECORD
description: WHEN the Connecticut Yankee nuclear reactor in East Haddam shut down on Wednesday, some embarrassed officials at the plant breathed a little easier.

title: U.S. MAY CLOSE MAJOR MILITARY SCHOOL IN PANAMA
description: A disagreement with Panama may force the United States to close a major military school in that country, the State Department says.

title: COUNTY SEEKING INTERNS
description: OFFICIALLY, it is Westchester County's Public Administration Internship Program, but to County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke it is really a ''management-training program'' similar to those conducted by major corporations.

title: PRETTY PLACE IN LAKEVILLE
description: ONCE undernourished, gastronomically speaking, the northwest corner of Connecticut is currently thriving. Within the past year a number of new restaurants have opened. One of the prettiest, and judging by the crowds, successful, is The Woodland, located in a gray clapboard building along Route 41 in Lakeville.

title: Older Tourists
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 AlligatorsCaptured II. L
description: Two alligators were trapped early this morning in Caroons Lake by a Federal game warden who tracked them down with a spotlight and used a noose to haul them out, the Nassau County police said.

title: The Market's Big Climb
description: Since Wall Street makes money whether investors are buying or selling, last week's record volume bodes well for brokerage industry profits, which have been battered this year. ''They're coming off a brutal first half and this has brought smiles to a lot of sour faces,'' said Jeffrey M. Schaefer, senior vice president of the Securities Industry Association. ''A lackluster July may turn into a dynamite August.''

title:
ANTIQUES;
FOR AUTO BUFFS, IT'S NEW HOPE OR BUST
description: FOR a look at life in the fast lane and slower modes of travel, too, the Bucks County, Pa., community of New Hope - it is just across the Delaware from Lambertville - is the place to be Saturday and next Sunday.

title: CHINAGLIA THREATENS TO TAKE COSMOS OUT OF LEAGUE
description: Giorgio Chinaglia, who has taken control of the Cosmos from Warner Communications but has not yet been officially approved by the other eight owners in the North American Soccer League, is threatening to pull the Cosmos out of the league if the owners deny his request to play in the Major Indoor Soccer League this winter.

title: FOOD STAMP BILL COULD HURT G.O.P.
description: A bill to increase food stamp benefits for millions of Americans, passed overwhelmingly this week by the House of Representatives, poses awkward political problems for President Reagan and Republican leaders of the Senate.

title: Miss Colussy Plans to Wed In December
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Dan A. Colussy of Vancouver, British Columbia, formerly of New York, of the engagement of their daughter Deborah Leigh Colussy to Craig Sidney Thompson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney O. Thompson of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Phoenix.

title: FALLOUT FROM CONTINENTAL'S COLLAPSE
description: WAS the rescue of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company just the end of a chapter on a big troubled bank or the beginning of a new book on the woes of the American banking industry? That is the kind of question the financial community is asking in wake of the the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's $4.5 billion takover of the once mighty Chicago bank.

title: SHAKESPEARE FANS TO GATHER AT DREW
description: MADISON FOUR years ago on two successive Sunday afternoons, a scholar of Southern literature spoke about Tennessee Williams's ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' and a sociologist commented on changing ways of life after Thornton Wilder's ''Our Town.''

title: A MINOR TRADGEDY
description: It is high time for some energetic

title: COMPLAINT BY GOVERNOR REJECTED BY P.S.C. CHIEF
description: The chairman of the State Public Service Commission has rejected a complaint from Governor Cuomo that one of the members of the commission had spoken out improperly on a major utility rate case and should be disqualified.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Male Haven
description: At its founding in 1922, the Burning Tree Club in Bethesda, Md., was declared an exclusive haven for golfers. United States Presidents, Supreme Court Justices, corporate figures all have been members.

ANTIQUES;
A SPECIAL COLLECTION OF SILVER
description: IN 1935 a Hartford businessman,

title: What TakesPrecedence inNew Jersey
description: For the New Jersey Supreme Court, the public interest sometimes outweighs legal precedent on the scales of justice. In three decisions last week - one on drunken driving and two on the liability of drug manufacturers and doctors - the court lived up to its reputation for innovation.

title: INMATES IN VIRGINIA STAB 2 AND HOLD 7 AS HOSTAGES BOYDTON, Va., Aug. 4 (UPI) - Convicts at Mecklenburg Correctional Center stabbed two guards today, held six more guards and a prison employee hostage, took over a cell block and issued 14 demands to end ''barbaric'' prison treatment.
description: The two injured guards were released shortly after the uprising by about 40 convicts at lunchtime and were taken to Community Memorial Hospital in South Hill. Both were in stable condition.

title: BAR CONDEMNS ARRAIGNMENT DELAYS IN MANHATTAN
description: A City Bar Association report released yesterday sharply criticized what it called ''intolerable'' delays in the arraignment of people arrested in Manhattan.

title: CAMEOS: GIFT FROM THE SEA
description: DEBORAH BLUMENTHAL, who writes frequently about health and beauty for The New York Times Magazine, lives in New York.

title: A WORKING PRINCE FOLLOWS THE HORSES
description: In a small room at Santa Anita, Prince Philip, president of the International Equestrian Federation, awaited the start of the third day of the grueling three-day event Friday afternoon.

title: MONTANA AREA IS IN BITTER FIGHT OVER COAL MINE AND A RAILROAD
description: In the grassy ravines of eastern Montana, not far from where Col. George Armstrong Custer and 200 of his men fatally blundered into the Battle of the Little Big Horn, another High Plains battle is being fought, this one without bloodshed. It is over a proposed coal mine and a planned railroad that could have an impact on the development of coal throughout the West.

title: JETS' JONES BREAKS COLLARBONE
description: The Jets' season, which opens Sept. 2, suddenly took on a distressing aspect tonight when the team's explosive wide receiver, Johnny (Lam) Jones, was sidelined for up to 10 weeks with a broken right collarbone.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: Long ISLAND is a cunningly designed swatch of geography. On the map everything appears to be simple enough. It is long and narrow, so that if you go north for a certain time you reach Long Island Sound, and if you go south you find yourself wading in Atlantic surf. Go east, old fellow, and there comes a time you can go no farther, and go west, young man, you are suddenly plunged into Queens or Brooklyn.

title: TURNER WOOS WEST CANADA IN CAMPAIGN
description: Prime Minister John N. Turner carried his election campaign to western Canada this week in an effort to end the bitterness that existed between the people of the region and his predecessor, Pierre Elliott Trudeau.

title: Inquiry Is Ignored at Christening GROTON, Conn., Aug. 4 (AP) - The Providence, the Navy's most powerful nuclear-powered attack submarine, was launched today as Attorney General William French Smith said it should be used to ''maintain peace in a dangerous world.''
description: ''In comparison with other ships of her class, this submarine is quieter, faster and militarily more capable,'' Mr. Smith said in his christening address at the Electric Boat Shipyard.

description: There is a new look to the televised evening news here, and some Western diplomats think it has something to do with Radio Marti, a special segment of Voice of America radio programming that may be broadcasting to Cuba by the end of the year.

description: At the Democratic Convention of 1984,

title: Dance
description: In an unusually varied repertory of traditional Korean dances, ceremonial rituals along with folk and court dances will be performed by the Hyun Ja Kim Dance Company on Thursday and Friday at Asia Society, Park Avenue at 70th Street. The 16- member company, dressed in flowing robes and moving to drum rhythms, will present Jung-Jae, elegant dances performed at court, and the explosive Changgo-Choom or drum dancing.

description: Easter Sunday, April 22, 1984

description: ANEW law signed by Governor Cuomo in June
