title: LI WINS 3 GOLDS; U.S. TAKES TWO
description: Li Ning of China won three gold medals and one silver, and the Americans gave their best individual apparatus showing in history tonight, in the final men's gymnastics competition of the 1984 Olympics.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
BEST FOOT FORWARD? NOT EXACTLY
description: THE foot fetishists are in the news again. In Mineola the police arrested a 20-year-old man who they say climbed into second-story windows at night to tickle young women's feet and steal their shoes.

title: Kriek Is Tested But Reaches Final
description: According to the mysterious computer that ranks the world's tennis players, there are eight men who play better tennis than Johan Kriek, the former South African who became an American citizen three years ago. The top four are John McEnroe, Ivan Lendl and Jimmy Connors and Mats Wilander. No argument there.

title: RIGHT NOTES
description: To the Editor:

title: GOOD AND BAD SPORTS; The Cheating Urge A high-ranking Boston bridge team is officially accused of using facial gestures and other signals to cheat on bidding during the recent national championships in Washington. Why is the urge to break the rules so powerful in a sport where relatively modest sums of money are at stake?
description: Bridge produces frustration that hits a deeper passion than mere greed.

title: Miss Vogelbach Wed to an Artist
description: Marjorie Kerr Vogelbach, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Vogelbach of Thompson Ridge and Lake Pleasant, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Lake Pleasant family home to F. Clayton Pond, a son of Catherine Pond Phillips of Highland Beach, Fla., and Woodstock, Vt., and the late Frank Nelson Pond. The Rev. Howard C. Shaffer, a retired Reformed Church minister, and the Rev. Steven A. Spergel, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: PUBLISHERS WRESTLE WITH INACCURACIES
description: At a time when brisk sales are bringing book publishers out of a prolonged slump, the industry finds itself facing a different kind of pressure. It is having to defend itself against charges that too many publishers will print anything that sells, without regard to truth or fairness. Publishers say this criticism is unfounded, but doubts raised about the accuracy of several recent books have led some companies to question longstanding practices.

title: TWO U.S. EMBASSIES SHARE BEIRUT DUTY
description: As of this week, the United States has embassy offices in both East Beirut and West Beirut.

title: More PowerTo the Schools?
description: More than a year ago, President Reagan began to position himself as a champion of education reform, calling for a return to ''basics'' to combat the ''rising tide of mediocrity'' cited in a Presidential commission's report. Since then, Mr. Reagan has repeatedly opined that such reform should begin with what he calls ''good old-fashioned discipline,'' and he has expressed an intention to use the Justice Department as his hickory stick.

title: TICK-BORNE DISEASE STUDIED
description: WHEN an Irish setter belonging to John Fisher of Madison began to limp one Saturday morning recently, her owner assumed she had cut her paw while chasing frogs in the pond near his house.

title: BEFORE OR AFTER THE END OF THE WORLD
description: Carol Sternhell teaches journalism at New York University. A HANDBOOK FOR VISITORS FROM OUTER SPACE

title: ROYALS GET 15 HITS TO BEAT TIGERS, 9-5
description: Pat Sheridan and Don Slaught each collected three hits and drove in two runs to pace the Kansas City Royals to a 9-5 victory over the Detroit Tigers today. The loss was the fourth in five games for Detroit.

title: ; South Korea Upsets Brazil
description: South Korea, paced by Chang Yoon Chang and Kang Man Soo, upset favored Brazil today to move into contention for a berth in the medal round of the men's volleyball competition.

title: Miss Ballantyne Marries on L.I.
description: Margaret Ann Ballantyne, an instructor in Spanish at Manhattanville College, and Luke Francis Mannion, an assistant professor of mathematics at St. John's University, were married yesterday at St. Aidan's Roman Catholic Church in Williston Park, L.I. The Rev. John M. Ryan, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Ex-Prosecutor Cleared In U.S. Extortion Case
description: All the charges in an indictment against a former upstate prosecutor have been dismissed in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: BALDWIN AND ZAHRINGER GAIN
description: Two former amateur champions of the Metropolitan Golf Association will meet Sunday in the 36-hole final of the 82d championship at Deepdale Golf Club.

title: TOWER'S COSTLY GAMBLE TO SELL RECORDS
description: MORE than 40 years ago, when Tommy Dorsey and Glenn Miller were the rage and 78's the style, 16-year old Russ Solomon scared up $250 to start a makeshift record shop in the back of his father's Tower Drugstore, next to Sacramento's Tower Theater. Demand was high and, since overhead was virtually nonexistent, the high school entrepreneur kept beefing up inventory, tripling his floor space in just a couple of years.

title: FERRARO'S SOUTHERN DEBUT SOFTEN'S LANCE'S QUICK EXIT
description: The mood was buoyant Thursday night as the packed jet carrying Walter F. Mondale and Geraldine A. Ferraro arrived in Minnesota after the Democratic team launched its 1984 Presidential campaign in Mississippi and Texas. ''We've got the White House off balance, we're defining the terms of the election, we're off to a successful start,'' said an exuberant aide to Mr. Mondale. He added: ''And Ferraro! Did you see those crowds in Austin and San Antonio? There is true excitement out there about Gerry Ferraro.''

title: Arsenal and Explosives Seized in Los Angeles
description: The police have reported seizing a vanload of explosives, electronics equipment, blasting cord and dozens of weapons at the home of a self-employed fireworks technician.

title: 'HAY FEVER' GONE HAYWIRE
description: 'HAY FEVER,'' playing at the Arena Players Repertory Theater, was Sir No"el Coward's first foray into the world of elegant high comedy. Through the following years, Coward's best works continued in this vein, with plays such as ''Private Lives,'' ''Blythe Spirit'' and ''Present Laughter.''

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: EVEN summer reading runs political these days, reflecting campaign excitement, the platforms, polls and party rhetoric. ''Exile: The Unquiet Oblivion of Richard M. Nixon,'' by Robert Sam Anson (Simon and Schuster, New York, $17.95), is one of the most recent books on the country's 37th President.

title: EFFORTS TO MEET LANDFILL DEADLINE LAG
description: THE date Dec. 18, 1990, may lack significance for most Long Islanders, but many public officials in Nassau and Suffolk Counties look forward to it with dread. On that date, the 8,500 tons of raw garbage produced each day on Long Island may no longer be deposited in landfills.

title: AN EARLY DROPOUT SETS U.S. GOALS
description: '' For their business,'' said J. Morton Davis of Lawrence, ''businessmen always believe in setting objectives and having a plan of action to implement. And here, in the most important business - our country, our lives, our future, our children's lives - we have no sort of defined goals or plans of action. We do short-term, expedient things.''

title: CON EDISON FACING ISSUE OF SPENT FUEL
description: BUCHANAN INDIAN POINT 2 has produced more than 43 billion

title: SUNDAY, AUGUST 5, 1984;  International
description: Mine-sweeper helicopters were ready for shipment to the of Gulf of Suez as Government officials weighed a decision on whether to send the craft to clear what are believed to be mines in the Gulf. There have been reports of damage to commercial shipping in the area by a recent series of mysterious explosions. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
A SHEAF OF MEMORIES FROM ANOTHER LOS ANGELES
description: The Olympic Games in Los Angeles in 1932 and now again in

title: U.S. and Cuba End a Round Of Talks About Immigration
description: The United States and Cuba have concluded a second round of talks on immigration issues and have agreed to continue the talks later, the State Department said Friday.

title: NOT JUST ANOTHER FISH STORY
description: OSCAR MILLARD is an author and screenwriter who lives in Pacific Palisades, Calif.

title: Edith Barton Sheerin Wed To Robert Rush Patterson
description: Edith Barton Sheerin, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Charles W. Sheerin of Saranac Inn, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Robert Rush Patterson, the son of Mrs. Robert Patterson of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Patterson.

title: CITY OPERA: 'BOH EME' CAST CHANGES
description: The current New York City Opera production of ''La Boh eme'' acquired new protagonists Friday evening, when Jerry Hadley and Elizabeth Hynes undertook the roles of Rodolfo and Mimi at the New York State Theater.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: MERRICK
description: as the 30,000 residents of the Long Island town of Merrick are called - will describe their South Shore community precisely the same way.

title: MUSIC AFTER MOZART
description: To the Editor:

title: HI! TO A GOOD NEIGHBOR POLICY
description: AFTER the move to the new house, the Proctors talked it over and concluded, ''We didn't want to wait for people to come to us.'' ''It doesn't happen that way in suburbia,'' said 29-year-old Cathy Proctor, recalling how hard it had been to meet people in Merrick and how few friendships they made in their six years there.

title: NATIONAL DANCE HALL OF FAME IS PLANNED FOR SARATOGA PARK
description: A National Dance Hall of Fame will be established in the Washington Bath building in the Saratoga Spa State Park under terms of an agreement reached this week between state park officials and a group of arts supporters.

title: ROOMS WITH A VIEW
description: PAUL GOLDBERGER is the architecture critic of The New York Times.

title: THE UNCERTAIN ART OF POLITICAL COMMERCIALS
description: It has become a commonplace to say that television and politics are inseparable, but the question is how and in what way. What does one do to the other? ''It's all television,'' party professionals say, meaning that what we see on screen is what determines elections. Even party professionals, however, seldom articulate the thought beyond that. It is possible they do not know what to say. Politics, as practiced on television, is an art, not a science, and mostly it is played by ear.

title: UNCONVENTIONAL SAN FRANCISCO
description: As much as I love San Francisco's beauty, charm and passion for freedom and tolerance, I can't let pass one error in gay history that appeared in Lacey Fosburgh's article.

title: AGED HOMEOWNERS GET AID
description: She described herself as ''house rich and cash poor.'' In her 80's, she has lived in the same house for 40 years. She said she and her ''sickly'' bachelor son have been scrimping since 1976, following her husband's death after an illness involving costly nursing care. Notwithstanding all the economies she practices, she said, ''today we can't seem to put together a dollar, much less spend it.''

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; The Worms' Turn
description: Worms are reputedly a $4 million- a-year industry in Maine, so when 60 worm diggers in Lincoln County went on strike in April for a penny rise in the 4 cents they were getting for each worm, dealers squirmed. But not for long.

title: TWO VERY YOUNG DEVOTEES ATTEND A JACKSON CONCERT
description: My son Charlie, age two, was leaping through the kitchen in a Superman pajama top, waving his sword at the Cuisinart, when his sister gave him the news. ''Something really incredible is happening tomorrow,'' Audrey said. ''We're going to see Michael Jackson. In person. For real.''

title: BEST WEEK EVER ON WALL STREET
description: Wall Street went wild last week, as institutions poured billions of pent-up dollars into stocks and fueled the biggest week in Wall Street history. Encouraged by falling interest rates and prospects that economic growth had moderated to a sustained pace, trading on Thursday broke all previous records as 172.8 million shares changed hands, and the Dow soared 31.47 points. The earlier record had been 159.9 million shares set on Jan. 5. Then on Friday, the record was broken again as 236.5 million shares were traded and the Dow jumped 36 points ahead. The market barometer closed the week at 1,202.08 up 87.46, breaking the previous record gain of 81.24 points set two years ago.

title: EUROPE WORRIES ABOUT KEEPING RECOVERY CLEAN
description: During the 1970's, Western Europe made a promising start toward clearing up the environmental mess left by 20 years of unfettered economic growth. New laws forced industry to adopt cleaner working habits, while the recession and rising energy prices curbed the burning of polluting fuels and the production of hazardous wastes. European economies cut sulfur emissions 15 percent in the last decade (about 10 percent less than in the United States), and sharply reduced smoke and dust pollution. For the first time in a century, salmon are being caught in the Thames off London Bridge.

title: Satellite Turns A Blind Eye on The Weather
description: Because of a burned-out light bulb, a United States weather satellite was lost last week. Indeed, burned-out bulbs have caused failure of two other weather satellites.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption with an article last week on film-making ventures in the state misidentified a principal in the 'Cry Wolf' television film. he is Bruce Graham, the project's producer

title: Julie Skakel Becomes a Bride
description: Julie Corcoran Skakel, the daughter of Rushton W. Skakel of Greenwich, Conn., and Windham, N.Y., and the late Ann Reynolds Skakel, was married yesterday to John Scott Kracke, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Helmut John Kracke of East Williston, L.I. The Rev. Mark Connelly performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich.

title: O'ROURKE WEIGHS WOODFIELD DECISION
description: A YEAR after the Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, named a task force to advise him on the future of Woodfield Cottage, the county's secure detention facility for juveniles at the county's Grasslands Reservation in Valhalla, he is, he says, nearing a decision on the issue that left his task force divided.

title: CAPITAL CRIMES
description: MURDER ON EMBASSY ROW By Margaret Truman. 316 pp. New York: Arbor House. $15.95.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ZAN HAGEN'S MARATHON

title: PLANS FOR OIL LEASES WOULD PROTECT WHALES
description: The Interior Department, setting final conditions for the sale of oil leases in the Beaufort Sea off northern Alaska, has agreed to measures to protect the endangered bowhead whale.

title: The Dark at the Tunnel's End
description: Our colleague, M. A. Farber, so convincingly described the dark side of New York City's subways last week, it seems implausible that anyone will ever find light at the end of the tunnel. No improvement is likely without even more capital to restore a starved, neglected railroad. But even more capital will be wasted if dispirited managers fail to get a grip on their mission. The dirt, discomfort and delays are only symptoms of a long decay that a civilized community should attack as intolerable.

title: House Is FirmOn Latin Aid
description: Democrats and Republicans divided sharply last week over President Reagan's Central American policies. The Democratic-controlled House rejected the Administration's requests for $117 million in additional military aid for El Salvador this year. And for the fourth time in 14 months, the House acted to halt C.I.A. financing of forces fighting the Government of Nicaragua. Senate committees, where Republicans hold the majority, went the other way on both issues. The Administration said it would keep pushing its proposals.

title: Miss Nappa Wed To D. E. Arpert
description: Jeanne Nappa, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Nappa Jr. of Franklin Lakes, N.J., and Hilton Head, S.C., was married yesterday to Douglas Eric Arpert, a son of Mrs. J.B. White of Wyckoff and Ocean Grove, N.J. and the late Eric Sheridan Arpert. The Rev. Robert J. Duncan performed the ceremony at Grace United Methodist Church in Wyckoff.

title: A CLASH OF SYMBOLS
description: Jonathan Culler's most recent books are ''On Deconstruction'' and ''Roland Barthes.'' THE CONQUEST OF AMERICA

title: VISITING THE ISLAND'S VINEYARDS AND TASTING THE WINES
description: There are more than a dozen Long Island wines on the market, made by four wineries, and more are coming. The vineyards and wineries are open to visitors, and the wines are available to purchase at the wineries as well as in local wine shops. New York State law does not permit vineyards to sell food, but the vineyards and wineries welcome picnics.

title: No Headline
description: Michelle Rose Marries

title: Burundi to Hold Elections
description: Burundi will hold a presidential election on Aug. 31, the state-run radio reported Friday. The broadcast, monitored here, said the election was ordered in a decree by Col. Jean-Baptiste Bagaza, leader of Burundi since he seized power in a military coup in 1976.

title: 2 Big PartiesIn Israel UrgedTo Join Forces
description: Two Israelis make an argument, three make a political party, Israelis like to joke. But last week, with official returns alloting Knesset seats to 15 parties and a majority nowhere in sight, President Chaim Herzog decided that Israel's problems may be too serious to leave to the mercies of narrow-gauge bargaining.

title: HARDENED POSITIONS ON THE MX
description: Until last week, Congressional conferees had resolved most of the differences between the House and Senate defense authorization bills. Then they came to that intercontinental ballistic hot potato, the MX missile.

title: Q AND A
description: Delinquent Subtenant Question:

title: '1940'S RADIO SHOW' NOT QUITE IN STEP
description: MONTCLAIR

title: UPPER VOLTA, AT FETE, VOWS TO DO BETTER AS BOURKINA FASSO
description: The military leaders of Bourkina Fasso, formerly Upper Volta, celebrated their first year in power today with a pledge to break with their West African country's colonial past and to better feed its population, among the world's poorest.

title: AFTER DECADE, NIXON IS GAINING FAVOR
description: When Richard M. Nixon resigned as President on Aug. 9, 1974, he left the White House physically ill, emotionally drained, publicly reviled and facing the probability of both criminal prosecution in the Watergate scandals and personal bankruptcy.

title: LANDMARK HOTEL BEING RAZED
description: -known of Atlantic City's beachfront luxury

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM A DAVID RABE DRAMA TO THE KIROV
description: Streamers Starring Mathew Modine, Michael Wright, Mitchell Lichtenstein, David Alan Grier, Guy Boyd, George Dzundza; directed by Robert Altman, 1983 Media Home Entertainment 118 minutes. $69.95

title: American Vows a Visit To Ulster Despite Ban
description: A New York lawyer who has been banned by Britain from visiting Northern Ireland said today that he would defy the Government order.

title: THE REGION ; A BIT SAFER OUT THERE
description: Only in a city whose population and problems were of the dimension of New York's would 290,000 serious crimes in six months be a notable improvement. Statistics released last week by the New York City Police Department showed a continued decline in most crime categories and a 3 percent overall drop in major crimes compared with the first six months of 1983.

title: CABLE-TV PLAYS KEY LOCAL ROLES
description: -TELEVISION systems in New Jersey are trying to inform, entertain and educate while seeking direct involvement with specific community needs.

title: AVOIDING DISCOURAGING WORDS AT THE RANCH
description: President Reagan resembled a bashful cowboy the other day when he was asked about the apparent collapse of the ''Star Wars'' talks with the Soviet Union. The President, looking wistful in his denim vacation clothes, silently searched for words amid the glory of the chaparral. At his side, murmuring through the fixed smile that seems required of American political spouses, Mrs. Reagan was overheard prompting him: ''We're doing everything we can.''

title:
INDUSTRIAL POLICY REVISITED;
AMERICA: STILL A TOUGH COMPETITOR
description: -called national industrial policy - government participation in private industrial planning - tell us the American economy is in trouble: We have lost our overall competitiveness in world markets; our economy is de-industrializing, and new job opportunities will become increasingly scarce and concentrated at the low end of the wage scale. If you listen too much to this litany of woes, you might begin to believe it. But if you look at some pertinent numbers, you get a different picture.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN COLOGNE
description: STEPHANIE REED MARKHAM is a writer who lives in Bonn.

title: ; 133-Pound Title to Japanese
description: Shinji Hosokawa of Japan showed devastating throwing and mat fighting skills tonight to take the extra lightweight 133-pound judo title.

title: HOMELESS: NO LONGER A STEREOTYPE
description: A PANEL appointed by the Governor has uncovered ''an unexpected and somewhat surprising picture'' of Connecticut's homeless: a mix of well-educated, highly skilled people who hit hard times and the stereotypical ''bag ladies'' and skid- row alcoholics.

title: HIJACKERS ASKING IRAN FOR ASYLUM
description: The three hijackers of an Air France jet who surrendered here Thursday have asked for political asylum in Iran, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Self-Made Lawyer
description: On Alcatraz Island in the 1940's, Cecil Wright was known as ''the Great Brain.'' While spending more than 15 years in prisons for stealing $2.43 in stamps from the Strasburg, Ill., post office, he taught himself law.

title: RUMANIAN WOMEN ROW TO FIVE GOLDS
description: The powerful Rumanian women's rowing team swept to five consecutive gold medals and came within a second of upsetting the favored American eight-oared crew in the finale of six Olympic events this morning at sun-splashed Lake Casitas.

title: WHERE BRITAIN HAILS HER SEAFARING TRADITION
description: C. NORTHCOTE PARKINSON, who began as a painter specializing in marine art, assisted in the founding of the National Maritime Museum at Greenwich.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the July 15 review of the ''Asia in Asia'' video cassette, the lead singer was misidentified. He is Greg Lake. Also, the song ''Don't Cry'' is not included in the cassette.

title: 520 UNITS; RX FOR NURSES' HOUSING
description: A shortage of affordable housing for nurses at the New York Hospital-Cornell University Medical Center in Manhattan will be eased with the completion of a 520-unit residential building planned by the hospital. All appropriate permits from the city have been secured, according to a hospital spokesman, and financing for the $63 million project is to come from either the State Dormitory Authority or Housing Authority using tax-exempt bond revenue.

title: A CENTURY AT ZERO LONGITUDE
description: MARGOT SLADE is an editor of The Week in Review.

title: MUSEUM IN SEARCH OF A HOME
description: CONNECTICUT, the state that has produced such notable spies as Nathan Hale and John Downey, might soon be home to a repository of espionage items, if the Willimantic Museum Association can find a place for it.

title: PLAYHOUSE SEEKS COMEBACK
description: FOR most nonprofit regional theaters, survival is the issue and success is the goal. The Candlewood Playhouse in New Fairfield is no exception.

title: CREW OF 8 TO FLY IN SPACE SHUTTLE
description: The space agency has announced a crew reshuffling for future space shuttle flights, including an eight-man international team, the largest so far, for a 1985 Spacelab mission for West Germany.

title: NOVELISTS AND NORMALITY
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Nancy Pivirotto to Wed

title: Sally Thacher Weds Dr. S. F. Hussain
description: Sally Newell Thacher of Washington, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred B. Thacher of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Syed Farooq Hussain of London, a son of Barkath Unisa Begum Hussain of London and the late Syed Khader Hussain. Superior Court Judge Henry H. Kennedy Jr. performed the ceremony at the bride's home.

title: HOW TO FIX A DOOR THAT WON'T STAY OPEN OR CLOSED
description: WHEN a door won't stay open or closed by itself - that is, when it tends to swing slowly closed after it has been left open, or when it swings slowly open and won't stay in the partly closed position unless latched shut - chances are that the door jamb is out of plumb. In other words, the door jamb against which the hinges are fastened is not standing exactly vertical; it is leaning slightly toward one side or the other.

title: Joanne Zigarelli Bride Of Brendan J. Ingham
description: Joanne Zigarelli, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Zigarelli of Mendham, N.J., and Delray Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Brendan Joseph Ingham, general manager of the Horizons and Cottages, a resort complex in Paget, Bermuda. The bridegroom is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Field Ingham of Warwick, Bermuda.

title: Lawyer Seeks to Dismiss Grenadian Coup Charges
description: A defense lawyer has asked that all charges be dropped against 10 of the 20 people accused of killing former Prime Minister Maurice Bishop and seven other people just before the United States-led invasion last fall.

title: CONCERT: TANGLEWOOD AND DUTOIT
description: Charles Dutoit, the Swiss conductor of the Montreal Symphony since 1977, has established a reputation in recent years as one of the most interesting conductors of his generation - that generation being the one older than young but younger than old.

title: BEETOVEN BELONGS TO EVERYONE
description: A 10-YEAR-OLD boy watching Walt Disney's ''Fantasia,'' a middle-aged executive reminiscing over an old 50's record called ''Full Moon and Empty Arms,'' a teen-ager relishing a chase scene in an old Lone Ranger television show, and a factory worker viewing an X-rated movie: What do these people have in common?

title: SHARING AND SHARING ALIKE
description: I HAVE always taught my three daughters to share,

title: 'Good Neighbors Are Good News'
description: On April 22, 1979, a headline in the Long Island Weekly read: ''Mentally Disabled: Issue in Kings Point.'' The same concerns voiced by the Crane Neck Association in your article of June 24, 1984 (''Hostel for Retarded Stirs Row''), i.e. ''safety, property values and a sense of well-being in the community,'' were expressed by some citizens in Kings Point both in that 1979 article and in a public meeting. Kings Point has much in common with Crane Neck. It is one of the most affluent communities in the country and has strict zoning codes.

title: No Headline
description: Peggy Kerry Is Married

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: WHAT does New Jersey have that New York City doesn't? For one thing, a MADD (Mothers Against Drunk Drivers) chapter. According to MADD officials, there are 11 chapters in New Jersey but none in New York City, although there are groups in Long Island and Westchester and Orange Counties.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on page 15 in some copies of the Arts and Leisure section today includes an outdated list of movie theaters for the opening of ''Cloak and Dagger''; the entry is also incorrect on page 17 of The Guide (section 2A). The film is to open Friday at the R.K.O. Warner Cinerama Twin (Broadway at 47th Street), the 86th Street East (Third Avenue) and the Gemini (Second Avenue at 64th Street).

title: LOOKING FOR THE HEARTLAND IN QUEENS, U.S.A.
description: At a rally a few blocks outside her Queens Congressional district, Geraldine A. Ferraro introduced Walter F. Mondale to the neighbors last week. The rally not only dramatized the themes the Democrats are running on this year; it also showed how close Middle America can be to Times Square.

title: AROUND THE WORLD WITH GRAND GUIGNOL
description: Bernard McCabe is a member of the English Department at Tufts University. ON THE YANKEE STATION

title: MEDICALS STUDENTS AND MARTYRDOM
description: In general, residency-training years coincide with prime child-bearing years, and women frequently are reluctant to postpone having children until the completion of their training. As the percentage of women in residency programs increases, larger numbers are making the decision to have children during residency.

title: Art
description: When people talk about American abstract painting, they generally mean either the Abstract Expressionists - Pollock, Newman, Rothko, Still - or the generation of Kenneth Noland, Helen Frankenthaler and Frank Stella, all of whom are happily in full operation today. Unless they are dealers, collectors, historians or survivors of the period, they may not remember that there was something called the American Abstract Artists Association, and that that association kept the notion of abstract painting alive at a time when attention was more likely to be focused either on the painting of the American scene or on the huge program of public works that was initiated by the Federal Government in the 1930's.

title: Women Lawyers Unit Describes Its Role
description: We have read with interest the two- part article on women lawyers in New Jersey (June 24 and July 1) and would like to supplement its scanty information about the New Jersey Women Lawyers Association.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
IN BROOKLYN, A MODEST COLLECTION IS SHOWN TO ADVANTAGE
description: In one way the Brooklyn Museum is not in the photography business at all. Though it started acquiring photographs in the 19th century, and though it claims to be

title: U.S. WEIGHS RISK THAT ATOM WAR COULD BRING FATAL NUCLEAR WINTER
description: The Federal Government has embarked on a broad program to assess the theory that fires set by even a limited exchange of nuclear weapons would blot out so much sunlight with smoke and soot that life on earth would be all but extinguished.

title: ULSTER SETBACKS FEARED IN DUBLIN
description: The Irish Government is deeply worried that the modest momentum built up in recent months toward improvement in the situation in Northern Ireland is being lost.

title: Surgery Professor Weds Dr. Nelson
description: Dr. Mary Jo Nelson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lowell Burton Nelson of Longboat Key, Fla., and Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Edward Louis Seljeskog, the son of Mrs. Sigsbee R. Seljeskog of Minneapolis and the late Dr. Seljeskog. The Rev. Paul Youngdahl performed the ceremony at the Mount Olivet Lutheran Church in Minneapolis.

title: LEWIS CAPTURES 100-METER TITLE BY 2 YARDS
description: Carl Lewis streaked to an impressive victory in the 100-meter dash tonight, winning the first of the four gold medals that he is seeking in the Olympic Games.

title: A LISTLESS 'MEET ME' PLAYING IN DARIEN
description: THE best news about the Darien Dinner Theater this summer resounds offstage. The debt-ridden Connecticut showplace does not so much have a renewed lease on life as a new provider of it.

title: Barbara Roome Is Married
description: At the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Barbara Shaw Roome, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Willemse Roome of Greenwich, was married to Boris Gonzalez Lobo, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jorge Gonzalez Diez of Vero Beach, Fla., Jerez de la Frontera, Spain, and Madrid. The Rev. Walter D. Wagoner performed the ceremony.

title: SHADE ON SUNNY SIDE OF THE STREET
description: They are not for everyone, blazing heat or no, but each August they blossom in the city in patches of color that enliven the streets.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Cleveland Indians, at Yankee Stadium, 2 P.M. Lou Piniella Day ceremonies begin at 1 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Pirates, at Pittsburgh, Sid Fernandez goes after his fourth straight victory since being called up from the Met farm system. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.) Boxing

title: Miss Peeples Is Betrothed
description: Mrs. Donald Allan Devendorf of Springfield Plantation, Midway, Ga., and Frank Kohler Peeples of Savannah, Ga., and New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Daryn Stewart Peeples, to Stuart Stratton Beringer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Marshall Beringer of Rye, N.Y. The wedding is planned for October.

title: FACTORY-BUILTS HELP TO MEET NEWARK NEEDS
description: SOME time tomorrow, two large tractor - trailers are scheduled to rumble down Sanford Avenue in Newark's Vailsburg section carrying enough large preassembled construction panels, all numbered and in order, to build a four-bedroom bilevel house.

title: THE NEW GERMANS
description: Konrad Kellen is a political analyst and the author of ''Khrushchev: A Political Portrait.''

title: SEARCH FOR WITNESSES WIDENS IN INQUIRY ON DAY-CARE CENTER
description: Federal and city investigators questioned dozens of children yesterday in a widening inquiry into sexual abuse at a Bronx day-care center. They also said they had been looking into similar allegations at a second Bronx day-care center since May.

title: John Hettrick Jr. Marries Jane Cox
description: At St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Buffalo yesterday Jane Anne Elizabeth Cox, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Cox of Buffalo and Sea Island, Ga., was married to John Lord Hettrick Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hettrick of Buffalo. Msgr. Daniel J. Szostak performed the ceremony.

title: POLL FINDS RISING CONFIDENCE IN SCHOOLS
description: Americans' confidence in their public schools and in the teachers and others who run them has surged dramatically in the last year, the Gallup Poll reported yesterday.

title: Dr. Herbert Wed To Fellow Doctor
description: The marriage of Dr. Robin Herbert, a resident in internal medicine at the Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center in the Bronx, to Dr. Darwin Deen Jr., a member of the faculty at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University, took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Roy A. Herbert, in Pound Ridge, N.Y. The Rev. Elizabeth Alcaide of the Community Church of New York performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. Deen of New York and Ruth Robinson-Deen of Santa Monica, Calif.,

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: DEAD men may tell no tales, but old Westchester church graveyards are full of them. At least that appears to be the case with the Old Dutch Church of Sleepy Hollow in North Tarrytown. A new, 33-page booklet entitled ''Tales of the Old Dutch Graveyard'' has just been published by the Junior League of Westchester-on- Hudson, Inc., which includes the county's river municipalities from Peekskill to Hastings-on-Hudson.

title: COUNTY URGES STATE TO SPEED ITS TRANSFER OF INMATES
description: VALHALLA

title: Selective Legislating
description: Elsewhere on Capitol Hill, political considerations seemed to loom even larger as Congress set about selectively working its way through a backlog. The House, which has been sharply criticized by President Reagan for blocking anticrime legislation, approved five law-and-order bills favored by the White House.

title: Czechoslovak Student Crosses Border on Kite
description: A Czechoslovak engineering student seeking political asylum soared over the Austrian border on a motorized kite today, landing in front of a hangar at Schwechat Airport, a police official said.

title: CAN COMPACT DISKS DESTROY LOUDSPEAKERS?
description: This department receives a great deal of mail, and I have to set myself guidelines on how to handle it all. Here are some of the rules evolved for this purpose: 1) I lap up compliments and often acknowledge them gracefully. 2) I reluctantly admit errors if anyone has caught them. 3) I envy people with secretaries and rarely answer letters with dictation marks. 4) I provide no personal consultation but pick out questions of general interest and from time to time reply to them in print - as in the following examples.

title: Miss Closson To Be Bride
description: Dr. Martha Bronson of Cambridge, Mass., and A. Burton Closson 3d of Cincinnati have announced the engagement of their daughter Lucinda Rodgers Closson to Paul Joseph Dean, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Gunther Dean of Bangkok, Thailand, and New York. An October wedding is planned.

title: MISTAKING EQUALITY FOR ADVANTAGE
description: After you have equalized with the black pieces, it is a curious and remarkably pervasive psychological trap to think that you have the advantage and rush optimistically into an attack. But it is all an illusion - though hard to escape.

title: Hong Kong'sFuture Clearer
description: In one of the most complicated eviction proceedings in the annals of real estate, Britain agreed last week to terms for turning the keys to Hong Kong over to China when its 99-year lease on the 399- square-mile colony runs out in 1997.

title: POPULARITY BLIGHTS THE NATIONAL PARKS
description: In Yosemite National Park in California, trees will no longer grow in the compacted ground of a long-used campground. The increasing traffic in the back country of Wyoming's Yellowstone National Park has forced the grizzly bear into a shrinking area and threatened its future there. On the cool plateau above Bryce Canyon in Utah this summer, cars circle to find a parking place, and people wait outside the dining room until their names are called on a loudspeaker.

title: THE VANISHING CAMPAIGN BIOGRAPHY
description: Ronald Steel is the author of ''Walter Lippmann and the American Century.''

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
WHY THE GAS STATION WAS COVERED WITH FLOWERS
description: The gas station on the corner looks as if it belongs to another time and place. Set at an angle where three shady streets meet, it is no more than a scrap of asphalt with two gas pumps and a single lift. At the corner where the sidewalks meet, a few shrubs and a bit of azalea struggle for life on a triangular piece of ground.

title: Article 110982 -- No Title
description: A contribution of $300,000, to be divided in equal installments over the next three years, has been pledged to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund by the Starr Foundation, a Manhattan-based philanthropic organization.

title: Laxalt Is Chosen To Nominate Reagan
description: Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada, one of President Reagan's closest friends, will nominate him for re-election at the Republican National Convention in Dallas, a campaign committee spokesman said today.

title: WHAT'S BEYOND THE BIG MARKET SURGE
description: ON Wall Street, as in nature, there is often a calm before the storm. Last Monday, for example, institutional investors were so reluctant to invest in the stock market that their apathy caused one veteran trader, Robert J. Chamine, a managing director of Wertheim & Company, to declare it ''the slowest and most boring period'' he had ever seen in the stock market.

title: MEDICAL STUDENTS AND MARTYRDOM
description: As a general practitioner, I read Michael Harwood's article, ''The Ordeal: Life as a Medical Resident'' (June 3), with great interest and the experience of two years of practice.

title: MEMORIES OF PATCO HAUNT POST OFFICE LABOR TALKS
description: The Government's current dispute with 600,000 postal workers might be all the more dramatic were it not for President Reagan's mass dismissal of striking air traffic controllers three years ago this week.

title: Delegates Won't Get Bible After Protest
description: A protest to the White House from a national Jewish leader has headed off plans to include a New Testament of the Bible in the 5,000 welcome kits for delegates to the Republican National Convention.

title: Guided Tours
description: To the Editor:

title: Ohio Lottery Winner Dies
description: William Yant, a truck driver who won $1 million in the Ohio Lottery three weeks ago, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack. The police said Mr. Yant, who was 56 years old, and his wife, Sandra, won the Ohio Lottery Winner's Handicap at River Downs in Cincinnati July 14.

title: Steel Company Lays Off More Office Workers
description: About 125 white-collar employees are being laid off at Bethlehem Steel in a new round of job cuts at one of the nation's largest steel companies.

title: WHAT LEAD DOES (OR DID) FOR YOUR CAR
description: THE octane rating of a gallon of gasoline tells chemists at what temperature and pressure the gasoline and air mixture in an engine will explode prematurely, before the spark plug fires, and thus not burn evenly.

title: Joyce Boland Marries Vincent DeVito on L.I.
description: Joyce Elizabeth Boland, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Boland of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday to Vincent G. DeVito, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Angelo DeVito of Hicksville, L.I. The Rev. Francis Schneider performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Glen Cove, L.I., assisted by the Revs. John McCann and Alan Placa.

title: SUMMER SHOWQS UNDER A TENT
description: THERE are no lobby lights to dim, so Julie Granieri, the house manager at Connecticut Stage in New Milford, rings a handbell to announce curtain time.

title: THE GRAND OLD MAN WHEN YOUNG
description: Sheldon Rothblatt is chairman of the department of history at the University of California, Berkeley. GLADSTONE

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION ; A DUMPING PERMIT, A HINT OF CHEKHOV
description: For the last nine summers, I've been fortunate to spend my days in an enclave on the Peconic bluffs overlooking Long Island Sound. But even in paradise one has to do something about garbage.

title: BUT DEEP-ROOTED PROBLEMS PERSIST
description: THE New York Stock Exchange study of ''U.S. International Competitiveness: Perception and Reality'' is another contribution to the growing literature on industrial policy. It claims that the industrial policy remedy is not needed and should not be tried: For the economy, as for a bicycle, the motto is: ''If it ain't broke, don't fix it.''

title: NATURE WATCH
description: Rudbeckia hirta

title: LANDSCAPERWITH A LARGE SHOWCASE
description: EDMOND DeLAURENTIS was doing some landscaping 15 years ago when his client gave him a free hand, saying he could do whatever he chose and ''we'll see what it looks like.''

title: Drawing a Bead On Malaria
description: In recent years, science has come to view a mosquito called anopheles and a microparasite named plasmodium falciparum as a tougher team than had once been thought. What had seemed to be slow but steady progress against the carrier and cause of malaria became a holding action and then a slow retreat as the disease organism and mosquito developed immunity to the pesticides and drugs used against them.

title: ELECTRONIC SPYING TERMED U.S. PERIL
description: The National Security Agency has told Congress that United States advantages in advanced technologies, including development of nuclear weapons, are threatened by the poor security of the nation's communications networks.

title: WHY DETERRENCE WORKS
description: Francois Sauzey is the editor of Trialogue, the quarterly journal of the Trilateral Commission. THE ILLOGIC OF AMERICAN NUCLEAR STRATEGY

title: NOW, AT LAST, TAPES TO JOG BY
description: The cassette has worked its way into the mainstream of recordings so gradually that we sometimes forget just how ubiquitous it has become. If we needed a reminder, the recent activities of such a major organization as CBS Records confirm what the national figures show: that the cassette has become the major medium for recorded music in America.

title: LEAD INDUSTRY DIGS IN ITS HEELS ON GAS ADDITIVES
description: WASHINGTON

title:
DINING OUT;
FRENCH ARRIVES IN YORKTOWN
description: WHILE most people are wary of being fooled by gold-plated brass, at The Coachlight Inn they must drop their guard and jump in with both feet to find the gold brass-plated. Ignore the stale tobacco smell, loud voices and thumping juke box from the partitioned bar at the entrance and be rewarded in the back dining room with some fancy cooking at prices that are a bargain for this kind of quality and culinary inventiveness.

title: ;  Eligibility LostA newspaper advertisement has cost a Florida State University linebacker his eligibility on the eve of the football team's fall practice.
description: Gerth Jax, an outside linebacker, appeared in the advertisement for a local exercise studio in the July 22 edition of The Tallahassee Democrat. Bob Goin, the school's associate athletic director, said Jax's appearance was in violation of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules. Jax worked at the exercise studio and says he did not get paid for participating in the advertisement, which showed him lying on a grassy field, wearing shorts and holding an F.S.U. football helmet.

title: POLAND IS TURNING THE WHEEL WITHOUT TURNING THE CORNER
description: With the release of political prisoners continuing, the long-playing drama in which large sectors of Polish society are pitted against the state has run through yet another cycle, and new political configurations are taking shape.

title: CORRECTION
description: Last week's Westchester Guide gave incorrect dates for two field programs sponsored by the Greenburgh Nature Center. At 2 P.M. today, there will be a free field trip exploring the Bronx River, and next Sunday, for $2, the site will be Wood Frog Pond at the Nature Center on Dromore Road off Central Avenue. Call 723-3470 for more information.

title: MUSIC AFTER MOZART
description: To the Editor:

title: TENNIS JUNIORS TO VIE IN MOUNT KISCO
description: THIS is the day for some 200 young tennis players converging on the Saw Mill River Club in Mount Kisco for the yearly county junior championships, which start Wednesday. They all know about Terry Phelps, Melissa Brown, Bill Stanley and Kathy Horvath, illustrious graduates of the tournament who have gone on to success in collegiate and world-class competition.

title: ; U.S. Women Victorious
description: Beth Anders scored both goals as the United States women's field hockey team defeated New Zealand, 2-0, but the American men fell to Spain, 3-1.

title: Novelists And Normality
description: To the Editor:

title: 'I WAS THINKING, STICK, STICK'
description: LOS ANGELES Behind the lavender fence, Mary Lou Retton's coach, Bela Karolyi, was waiting to encourage her. But even before he could give her any advice about the vault on which she needed a perfect 10 to win the Olympic gold medal, Mary Lou Retton looked up at him with those big cocker-spaniel eyes. She wasn't waiting for her coach to say something. Instead, she had something to tell him.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Aug. 5, 1984Fiction1 THURSTON HOUSE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $3.95.) Three generations of a San Francisco family. 2 HOLLYWOOD WIVES, by Jackie Collins. (Pocket, $3.95.) The struggle for money and power in Tinseltown. 3

title: LONDON THEATER HAS A DOUBLE LIFE
description: Like most American theatergoers who arrive in London on the morning after an all-night flight, I couldn't imagine wasting any time catching up on sleep. But what to do? It was Thursday lunchtime - eight hours before a curtain would go up. Desperate for any kind of theatrical fix, I headed into the West End theater district for an informal walking tour.

title: Pretoria Official to Resign
description: The Minister of Community Development, S. F. Kotze, said today that he would step down soon as a Cabinet Minister and Member of Parliament.

title: HARVARD EX-DEAN APPOINTED BISHOP OF STOCKHOLM
description: A former dean of Harvard Divinity School has been named Bishop of Stockholm in the Church of Sweden, a state-controlled Evangelical Lutheran faith. The appointment has stirred a level of curiosity and hope rarely seen in one of the world's few surviving state churches.

title: Businessman and Nun In Defense of Newark
description: I have read and reread Joy Krauss's essay, ''Hatred Still Felt In Newark'' (Opinion Page, July 15). Other than being a self-serving item for that page, I can only interpret the article as another misguided bit of liberal confusion.

title: PAPERMAKING'S DIVERSE FOLLOWING
description: ''IT'S a very exciting moment for papermaking - more and more people are looking into it, exploring it,'' said Sybil Robins, the owner and director of the Craftsman's Gallery in Scarsdale. ''I can't think of anybody I knew of 10 years ago who was doing hand papermaking. Now there are quite a few. Artists are coming from various points of view - people who have worked in other media - and they each bring their own experiences to it.''

Truman, John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, but more assertive than that of George McGovern, the party's 1972 nominee.

STAMPS;
ONE FOR SMOKEY BEAR

Miss Hendryx is a harsh yet elegant funk singer.

title:
LEISURE;
IT'S TIME FOR REVIVAL OF THE GOOSEBERRY
description: Nowhere in the world is the gooseberry more highly esteemed than in England. Gooseberry bushes were mentioned in 13th century bills of purchase sent by the fruiterer to Edward I and again in Turner's ''New Herbal'' of 1548. From 1860 onward, local gooseberry clubs in Lancashire and Cheshire held contests for the largest fruits.

title: A Trying Time for the Mets
description: Far from the tumult of the Olympics and the stock market, it was a memorable week for the Mets, too: After winning seven straight games, they lost seven straight. And a corner of the world that had been roaring suddenly grew sullen.

title: METS OVERCOME PIRATES BY 4-3
description: The Mets, who career from one streak to another, won their second straight game tonight when they brushed past the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-3, on a walk with the bases loaded in the eighth inning.

description: SHE'S known as the ''mother'' of the State Assembly. ''I hold their hands, dispense Kleenex and listen to their problems,'' said Susie M.C. Chichester of the Burlington County community of Cinnaminson.

title: Sept. 15 Wedding For Sara LeBlond
description: The engagement of Sara LeBlond to Brian Petrovek has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Richard K. LeBlond 2d of New Canaan, Conn., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. August Petrovek Jr. of West Hyannisport, Mass.

title: FAMILY SIZE: SMALL IS BEAUTIFUL
description: If it does nothing else, the International Conference on Population, in Mexico City next week, will have achieved a major victory if it succeeds in alerting the American people in general - and the Reagan Administration in particular - to the seriousness and complexity of the world's population problems.

title: PLAYING UP CINNAMON
description: IT IS NEARLY ALways a rule of thumb that most green herbs and dried spices are ''born'' to play a subdominant role in a dish - a hint of vanilla, a trace of thyme, a suggestion of cayenne or nutmeg. If used with anything that smacks of gusto, these flavors become overpowering and unpleasant. There are times, however, when these seasonings may be deliberately brought forth as a major characteristic of a specific dish.

title: Washington Criticized For 75 Payroll Systems
description: The Federal Government, which has 75 distinct payroll systems, could save $54 million a year by consolidating the systems and eliminating duplicative practices, the General Accounting Office reported today.

title: THE INCREDIBLE SHRINKING SQUARE FOOT
description: UNLIKE much else in this world, standards of measurement are not a subject of dispute. A foot, for example, is 12 inches long. Or to be more precise, it is the distance traversed by a plane of light through a vacuum in just under a billionth of a second, according to the National Bureau of Standards.

title: WOMEN'S DEBUT BECOMES A HIGHLIGHT
description: When the ancient Olympic Games were revived in 1896 in Greece, the program included a marathon. Like all other events there, in track and field and other sports, the race was for men only.

title: Man Slain at Reception
description: A man burst into a wedding reception here tonight and began to ''shoot indiscriminately,'' killing one man and wounding three other people, officials said. The killer fled to a nearby park, said a police dispatcher who declined to identify himself. The police said the bride and groom were not injured.

title: YANKEES KEEP ROLLING

title: WHY 'AFTERSCHOOL SPECIALS' ARE SPECIAL
description: On this hot and humid July afternoon, a small crowd of passers-by has assembled on West 86th Street to witness a scene now familiar to most New Yorkers. It's obvious from the camera and the overhead boom that a film is being shot here, even though the two pretty girls walking arm in arm down the sidewalk could be typical Upper West Side teen-agers. But, in fact, they're Sarah Jessica Parker and Christine Langner, two veteran actresses, and their stroll is being filmed for an upcoming ABC ''Afterschool Special.''

title: MUSIC: SONGS BY ELLY AMELING AT MOSTLY MOZART
description: The Mostly Mozart festival, well- known for its middle-of-the-road values and justly criticized for the blandness that sometimes results, has taken a discreet plunge into the world of authentic instruments. Thursday night's concert at Avery Fisher Hall featured the Haydn Baryton Trio playing a Haydn baryton trio, Steven Lubin playing a fortepiano modeled on one built in Mozart's day, and a band of restored or replicated strings to accompany Elly Ameling and, in a concerto, Mr. Lubin.

title: ;  Defectors Find Home
description: A pair of players who defected from Czechoslovakia have been signed by the Minnesota North Stars, whose general manager, Lou Nanne, says they already have shown their ''intestinal fortitude'' by leaving their Communist homeland. ''Their potentials are excellent,'' Nanne added, speaking about Miroslav Maly and Jiri Poner, who were selected in the fourth and fifth rounds by Minnesota in the National Hockey League amateur draft earlier this summer.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

DESPITE RENT VOTE, TENANTS PRESS SUIT
description: Tenants and landlords got an early answer this year on rent levels, when the Westchester Rent Guidelines Board voted last Tuesday - three months earlier than they voted last year - to freeze rents on one-year leases and to allow a 3 percent increase on two-year leases.

title: 'THE KILLER DECADE'
description: To the Editor:

title: HEADLINERS
description: Stick to the Script When changes in an Albee play are needed, Edward Albee will make them himself, thank you. That goes for sex changes, too, the playwright insisted last week in protesting an all-male production of ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' Heeding Mr. Albee's wishes, Theater Arlington in Arlington, Tex., canceled the run of a ''Woolf'' version in which Mr. Albee's quarrelsome heterosexual couples were cast as homosexuals. Denying longstanding rumors, Mr. Albee said he had ''certainly not'' ever intended the play to be homosexually oriented. Cliff Redd, the managing director of Theater Arlington, took it philosophically. ''This is an experimental production,'' he said. ''And the experiment is a success because we finally know Albee's intentions about the play.''

title: KEEPING A BASEBALL TEAM AND REVIVING THE JAYCEES
description: Harvey Mackay has $5.3 million in the bank to buy baseball tickets.

title: ;  Comings and GoingsThe Milwaukee Brewers said that
description: Rollie Fingers , the relief pitcher, had successful surgery in San Diego to remove a herniated disc, an ailment that will sideline him for the rest of the season. . . . The Philadelphia Phillies announced they had placed on the 15-day disabled list Garry Maddox , the outfielder, who has a strained lower back. . . . James Martin, who has proved his winning ways as baseball coach for Tuskegee Institute, will now get to try his hand with the school's football team. Martin has been selected to succeed Lonzo Bullie as head football coach after Bullie was dismissed in April when school officials chose not to renew his contract after a 4-6 record last season. . . . Bobby Czyz , the 22-year- old super middleweight from Wanaque, N.J., was released on bail from the Passaic County Jail after pleading not guilty to charges of attempted sexual assault and burglary. He was arrested at his home Friday in connection with an alleged break-in at the home of a Bloomingdale woman and was ordered held on $100,000 bail by Superior Court Judge Joseph N. Donatelli.

title: EXECUTIVES IN RETIREMENT
description: Retirement once meant receiving a gold watch for many years of service and graduating to endless rounds of golf in a sunny clime. But that is quickly proving to be a myth as the nation's population grays. From the advanced ages of participants on corporate and community boards to the numbers of retired executives starting their own businesses, it is increasingly apparent that retirement does not mean withdrawing from an active business life. In fact, many executives in the traditional retirement age bracket, 57 to 64, are moving full steam ahead into second careers and continuing as long as their health allows.

title: PEKING TRIES AN END RUN AND WOOS SOVIET ALLIES
description: Following their great ideological rift a quarter century ago, China lumped the Soviet Union and its Communist allies together as apostates beyond the pale of Marxist salvation. Today, Peking still blames Moscow for blocking normal relations, but it has no such complaints about Eastern Europe.

Then a satisfied smile crosses his face as he sees the waterfowl regain altitude and resume their flight.

title: FENCING ; ; American in Sabre Finals
description: Peter Westbrook of the United States came back from a 6-1 deficit to defeat the gold medal favorite, Gianfranco Dalla Barba of Italy, today and advance to the finals of the men's Olympic individual sabre competition.

title: A VISIT TO HIROSHIMA AND THE PEACE MUSUEM
description: THOUGH I had dreaded visiting Hiroshima, my discomfort was lessened by the warmth of the Japanese we had encountered in the 10 days before our arrival in that city. The sight of lovely ladies in brocaded silk kimonos as we entered the lobby of our hotel pushed any trepidation I might still have felt from my mind. They stood, some alone, some in groups of three, and the subtle, gleaming colors, placed against the background of the waterfall at the far end of the room, reminded me of the scenes on Japanese painted screens. ''I love it,'' I said, squeezing my husband's arm, and was not even disappointed when Leonard and I found out they were there for a kimono trade show taking place at our hotel.
