description: Hundreds of ancient Indian ruins in remote New Mexico mountains have been destroyed by logging operations, and thousands more are similarly threatened, according to a lawsuit against the United States Forest Service.

title: THE UNNATURAL ATHLETIC-ACADEMIC LINK
description: Consider the accomplishment of Miguel Vasquez, the trapeze artist of Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus. Vasquez has achieved what few others have done in sport - he single-handedly, and in a single performance, redefined the standard against which excellence is measured in his field of endeavor. His feat was the first public performance of a quadruple somersault in a two-person trapeze act. Until 1982, the superb trapeze acts were those in which performers regularly executed triple somersaults. What is the appropriate comparison for Vasquez's achievement - a perfect game in baseball? A 3:30 mile? An 80-yard field goal in football?

title: MUSIC: WILLCOCKS LEADS RIVISED MOZART REQUIEM
description: The drawing card at Mostly Mozart Friday night was Sir David Willcocks, the distinguished British choral conductor, who made his festival debut leading Haydn's ''Mass in Time of War'' and Mozart's Requiem.

title: Lyn Corno Weds William Herbert
description: Lyn Corno, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Eugene Corno of Tempe, Ariz., was married yesterday to William Fairfax Herbert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Carrington Herbert of Laurens, S.C. The Revs. Wendy Smith and Timothy Raasch performed the Episcopal ceremony in Palo Alto, Calif., at the Stanford Memorial Church at Stanford University, from which the bride received a doctorate in educational psychology.

title: Kidnappers in Beirut Release Maronite Aide After 8 Days
description: An aide to the Maronite Catholic political leader, Camille Chamoun, was freed by kidnappers Friday night after eight days in captivity.

title: NOW'S THE TIME ALL GOOD TOMATOES AID THE FAMILY MENU
description: WELCOME the Jersey tomato, the Long Island tomato, and the tomatoes ripening in farms and gardens throughout Westchester, Connecticut and the rest of the surruounding area. The time has come for tomato lovers to rejoice and to plan menus around one of the more treasured fruits of summer.

title: No Headline
description: Conflicting opinions at a hearing in Indianapolis last week on a city ordinance that permits bans on pornographic books and movies deemed to violate the civil rights of women:

title: John Haskins Engaged To Margaret C. Couper
description: Margaret Channing Couper and John W. Haskins, instructors at the Hurricane Island Outward Bound School in Maine, plan to be married Sept. 15.

title: W. H. Lyons Wed To Miss Siegfried
description: Judith Siegfried, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Siegfried of Long Beach, Calif., was married yesterday to Warren Hay Lyons, a son of Sylvia Lyons of New York and the late Leonard Lyons. Brother Bimalananda of the Self Realization Fellowship performed the ceremony at the Lake Shrine Gandhi World Peace Memorial in Pacific Palisades, Calif.

title: CHINA SUMMER: WATERMELON IS KING
description: When Cao Wenyu's watermelons were hijacked, the crime outraged even People's Daily, a Communist Party paper that normally sets its editorial sights on loftier issues. Mr. Cao was driving a ton and a half of watermelons from suburban Tongxian into Peking one morning last month when a dozen youths halted his truck and demanded that he sell the lot to them for $78. Mr. Cao knew that his load was worth at least $108. He refused, whereupon the young men squeezed or kicked some of his melons and ran off with others.

title: Hansen GetsA Reprimand
description: The Ethics in Government Act that tripped him up, Representative George Hansen told members of the House last week, has created a ''paperwork jungle'' that could in time leave them all ''convicted felons.'' But in the end, his colleagues voted 354 to 52 to reprimand the Idaho Republican.

title: U.S. WEIGHS MOVE TO HELP EGYPT RID RED SEA OF MINES
description: The United States Navy began loading mine- sweeping helicopters aboard transport planes in Virginia today as Government officials weighed a decision to fly the craft to the Gulf of Suez to clear what are believed to be mines.

title: U.S. BOXING TEAM REMAINS UNBEATEN
description: Seven days of Olympic boxing have been completed and the United States team is still undefeated. Paul Gonzales and Evander Holyfield capped a perfect first week tonight when they scored impressive victories that raised the American record to 16-0.

title: Kristen Jane Morsches Married at Fort Myer
description: Kristen Jane Morsches, a daughter of Comdr. Robert W. Morsches, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Morsches of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to Robert W. Ray, a son of Col. Robert L. Ray, U.S.A., and Mrs. Ray of Camp Casey, South Korea.

title: GREEN AT THE HEART
description: August Heckscher , New York City's Park Commissioner from 1967 to 1973, is the author of ''Alive in the City'' and ''Open Spaces - The Life of American Cities.'' THE FALCONER OF CENTRAL PARK

title: SKI BOWL BECOMING A CULTURAL CENTER
description: If things go according to plan, next summer there will be a

title: EXPERTS QUESTION PROGRAM TO CUT HOSPITAL DEATHS
description: Members of the Senate Health Subcommittee and medical spokesmen have expressed concern about a new Federal program to reduce ''avoidable deaths'' and ''inappropriate admissions'' by specific numbers in the nation's hospitals. They said it appeared to be a ''quota system'' for health care.

title: LABOR AIDES ENLIST MARGIOTTA
description: JOSEPH M. MARGIOTTA is keeping a low public profile while he serves the remaining month of his 14-month jail term, but he is nevertheless quietly re-entering Nassau politics behind the scenes.

title: Hitchhikers Find Cache
description: A cache of gold and silver religious items was found this week along the Connecticut Turnpike by two hitchhikers. The items were believed stolen from Maine churches four years ago.

title: HISTORIC FREIGHT CAPTURES RACE-OFF FOR HAMBLETONIAN
description: Historic Freight won a $35,000 claiming race last June 6 at the Meadowlands, but no one thought enough of him to pick him up. Almost two months later, the big, powerfully built colt won again at the Meadowlands, and this time it was in a three-horse race- off in the record $1,219,000 Hambletonian today.

title: TIME FRAMES OF THE PAST
description: IF TIME IS OF THE ESSENCE, so too are timepieces. Increasingly so. In addition to performing their obvious function, they are now important fashion accessories, not to mention status symbols. And, for reasons of sentiment, nostalgia and individuality, there is a growing trend toward wearing and collecting antique watches. Designers and retailers, often the first to spot or create such movements, seem to be among the most avid devotees of older watches. Among those who collect both wrist and pocket watches are Karl Lagerfeld, Calvin Klein and Norma Kamali. Clifford Grodd, the president of Paul Stuart, owns about 30 antique watches. Geraldine Stutz, the president of Henri Bendel, has only one, but it is a striking one: a Dent pocket watch that was converted into a wristwatch and dates back to about l890. Bill Blass, who admits to collecting just about everything except watches and clocks, is rarely seen without his handsome l930 gold and blue enamel Cartier Tank watch.

title: Backstage at the Kirov Pacific Arts Video Records 80 minutes. $59.95
description: Derek Hart, a British dancer- turned-filmmaker, obtained special access to Leningrad's famed Kirov Ballet through the auspices of his producer, Armand Hammer. The result is the kind of insider's look at dancers, stagehands, teachers and company brass that few foreigners obtain. Mr. Hart also had the film technology Soviet directors do not: a portable Steadicam television camera that follows the corps de ballet in Act II of ''Swan Lake'' with remarkable fluidity.

title: BONN AWAITING HONECKER DESPITE SOVIET PRESSURE
description: A West German Government spokesman said today that Chancellor Helmut Kohl still expected the East German leader, Erich Honecker, to visit next month despite denunciations of Bonn in Soviet and other Eastern European newspapers.

title: A 'TEMPEST' THAT BRINGS US A FOREIGN FLAIR
description: When were you last so amazed and alarmed in a theater that you attempted to dive under the seat in front and lie there, mumbling little prayers for deliverance? Until the other day, I don't think I'd felt that way since - oh, since I'd been fully convinced a pantomime Dragon was about to ingest first St. George, then my mother and father, and finally the six-year-old me. But there I was, suavely settling into my place in that charmless array of giant brown cubes that calls itself the Center for the Arts at the State University of New York at Purchase, when a couple of megatons of high explosive appeared to go off. Crash, bang, and there in the murk was the silhouette of a ship, surrounded by huge, raging billows I'd neither time nor inclination to realize were actually long pieces of energetically undulating cloth. And then, just as suddenly, we were on deck, the sails were convulsively falling, the mast was splintering, people were drowning, and all was blackness and silence. This, I and the rest of the audience used to clamber back into our skins, recovering what little dignity we could.

title: 'On the Yankee Station'
description: Don't be put off by the nasty piece that opens this interesting collection of 15 stories. In ''Next Boat From Douala,'' Morgan Leafy, a youngish, fat, white diplomat in postcolonial West Africa, catches gonorrhea in a local brothel. Then, drunk after a Christmas party, he lies in a Volkswagen bus with Doreen, the wife of his colleague Brian. Conscience catches him at the crucial moment - ''Then he thought of impregnating Doreen, his putrid seed in her womb, Brian's innocent alarm at the diseased monster he'd inadvertently produced. He thought of Brian diseased too, a loathsome spiral of infection, a little septic carbuncle festering in Africa behind him.'' He desists, and the lady is displeased. This tale is told in graphic physical detail with what reads like a pastiche of Graham Greene as a backdrop: ''Fat sausage flies . . . whirled and battered about him. Ungainly on their wings, one landed in his gin and drowned there, straddled on the cubes.'' Comic? It's hard to supply the demanded hearty laughter. The moral too, is glib.

title: ROCK STARS OF THE 60'S TURN TO GUITARISTS FOR HELP
description: It seems to be the season for resuscitating 1960's rock guitar heros.

title: THE BUSINESS OF COMPOSING
description: David Hamilton is the music critic of The Nation and the author of ''The Listener's Guide to Great Instrumentalists.'' STRAVINSKY

title: WHERE SHAKER SIMPLICITY ENDURES
description: WILMA DYKEMAN, who lives in Newport, Tenn., and Asheville, N.C., is a novelist and historian whose books include ''The Tall Woman.''

title: BOXING TEAM'S UNITY PERILED BY CONTROVERSEY OVER COACHES
description: LOS ANGELESMany of them came from the streets, poverty's children who took pride in their ability to survive in an environment where there were no rules, and now are just as proud that they are fighting by those set down by the Marquis of Queensberry.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A RUSSIAN DESIGNS OLYMPICS MEDALS
description: Although there are no Russian athletes at the Olympics in Los Angeles, the Games' leading medalist, Alex Shagin, is a Russian. He doesn't win medals; he designs them.

title: ARCHITECTURE IN THE GARDEN
description: IN ''ITALIAN GARDENS AND THEIR VILlas,'' Edith Wharton wrote that ''the old Italian garden was meant to be lived in - a use to which, at least in America, the modern garden is seldom put.'' She also noted that ''the grounds were as carefully and conveniently planned as the house. . . .'' Although Mrs. Wharton's observations were recorded 80 years ago, the relationship between a house and its gardens is still a timely issue. Also timely is the Italian-Renaissance notion that architectural ornament is as important as the choice of plants. Pergolas, pavilions, gazebos and gateways, planned in harmony with the landscape and the main house, form outdoor garden rooms - magical lived-in places linked by shaded woodland walks, open fields of wildflowers or hidden trysting places.

title: Nancy Siedlarz Wed To Robert Bruechert
description: The marriage of Nancy Clarissa Siedlarz and Robert William Bruechert took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd in Rosemont, Pa. The Rev. Andrew C. Mead, assisted by the Rev. James W. England Jr., the bride's grandfather, performed the ceremony.

title: BEST SELLERS Aug. 5, 1984
description: Fiction1 18 ''. . . AND LADIES OF THE CLUB,'' by Helen Hooven Santmyer. (Putnam, $19.95.) Life in an Ohio town, 1868 to 1932. 2 27 LINCOLN, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $19.95.) Fictionalized account of the Civil War Presidency. 3 322 THE AQUITAINE PROGRESSION, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $17.95.) A lawyer is caught in a conspiracy to seize the Western world. 4

title: AN ATTEMPT TO ILLUSTRATE POLLUTION
description: LINCROFT VSIBLE only from the air, the ''aprons'' of brown water marking the large cities of the Eastern Seaboard are among the most dramatic signs of pollution. More than anything else, these stains tell northerners returning from the still-blue waters of Florida and other southern points that their vacations are truly over.

title: MAJOR NEWS ; Vienna MayHave to Wait
description: Prospects faded again last week for talks with the Russians about space weapons. Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko accused the Reagan Administration of ''looking for proposals that would be rejected.'' Said Robert C. McFarlane, the White House national security adviser: ''It appears that the Soviets were not serious about their proposal'' for a meeting Sept. 18 in Vienna.

title: GETTING TO THE PLANE ON TIME
description: PAUL GRIMES writes the Practical Traveler column.

title: Rabbi Is Chaplain At Yale
description: Mr. Bass's article makes passing reference to a ''female rabbi'' who ''works at the Yale University campus for a Jewish student-faculty organization.''

title:
ART;
UNAFFILIATED AND ORIGINAL
description: EFFECTIVE art removes us, for a short while, from an awareness of our immediate surroundings. It suspends time, equilibrium, perspective, visual coding and previous assumptions. This is all part of the creative process.

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS ; Widow's Chance To Conceive
description: The French judicial system may have been ruled as much by its heart as its head last week when it ordered that sperm deposited by a man now dead be made available to his widow.

title: Tokyo
description: To the Editor:

title: ZONING TRADE-OFF IS GAINING SUPPORT
description: Lower Manhattan would get a new firehouse at the bottom of an office tower and the tower would get seven extra stories on top if a trade-off approved by the local community board becomes a reality.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: FOOTBALL-PRESTO-TO MAGIC
description: CHARLES JESSAMY believes in magic. That might seem a bit childish in a rather large 33- year-old but, he points out, not everything is what it appears to be.

title: Miss Kops Weds Philippe Burnham in Glen Cove
description: Susan R. Kops, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Kops of Monsey, N.Y., was married yesterday to Philippe H. Burnham, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold A. Burnham of Glen Cove, L.I., and Cabourg, France. The ceremony was performed at Welwyn Manor in Glen Cove by the Rev. Charles G. Newbery of St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., and Rabbi Nathaniel H. Schwartz.

title: A VERY SPECIAL CAMP
description: SOME 30 Connecticut children who have cancer will have an opportunity later this month to enjoy such traditional summer camp activities as volley ball, canoeing, swimming and nature studies, performing in a talent show, wearing colorful camp hats and T-shirts and singing around a camp fire.

title: 20 Are Killed in Peru As Rebels Raid Church
description: Leftist guerrillas have shot and killed 20 people during a Protestant service in a rebel-contested area, according to the police.

title: Locked UpIn Argentina
description: Jailed last week on charges stemming from the murders and disappearances that swept Argentina, Jorge Rafael Videla will not be able to claim that he was just following orders. General Videla led the coup that brought the military to power in 1976 and was President for the next five years, the time of almost all of the more than 8,000 disappearances, hundreds of executions and uncounted instances of torture.

title: STANDING UP FOR THE FALLEN
description: Edward Hirsch, who teaches at Wayne State University, is the author of ''For the Sleepwalker,'' a book of poems. SELECTED POEMS

title: Dog Days
description: We know a man who lives at the top of New England, where the farms are growing back to forest. He's seeing moose tracks replace the deer tracks around his place. These are three times larger, less prim and pear-shaped and have a magisterial impact. They look rangier and seem to move directly across the woods and fields and ponds (a moose can submerge completely while eating water lilies), wherever the moose has wanted to go, as if the wilderness had somehow got its second wind and was returning after all.

title: MUSINGS ON A VANDAL
description: I read with empathy Edwin Ritchie's ''Musings on a Lost Lighthouse'' (Opinion Page, July 1). The author's despair drives him to ask some frightening questions about the effects of unresolved anger on a global scale.

title: UNCONVENTIONAL SAN FRANCISCO
description: As an Easterner, attending law school in the San Francisco Bay area, I generally agreed with Lacey Fosburgh's positive portrayal of San Francisco (''San Francisco: Unconventional City for the Democratic Convention,'' July 1).

title: LEWIS WINS FIRST GOLD MEDAL
description: On the busiest day of the Games of the XXIII Olympiad in Los Angeles, Carl Lewis last night began his quest for four gold medals with a victory in the 100-meter dash, Li Ning of China won three gold medals in gymnastics and Rumania dominated the women's rowing events with five commanding performances.

title: DANCE: RADIS TROUPE FROM CHICAGO
description: Some choreographers create dances that look as if they have been cut from the same bolt of cloth. Others seem to restitch the pattern. Jackie Radis, a Chicago-based choreographer who opened Dance Theater Workshop's monthlong ''Out-of- Towners & Others,'' belongs in the second category.

title: Alice Young to Wed Thomas Shortall
description: Alice Young, the founding partner of the New York office of the international law firm of Graham & James, plans to be married Sept. 22 to Thomas Leonard Shortall, a vice president in institutional sales of Smith Barney & Company in New York.

title: Mail Loss Baffles a City
description: Hundreds of pounds of official letters, about 3,000 to 4,000 pieces, have disappeared somewhere between the revenue commissioner's office and the post office in Norfolk. Officials said the loss had cost the city $2,900 in extra postage and put it weeks behind in collecting business license fees from thousands of license renewal forms. An inspector for the Postal Service, R. T. Welborn, said, ''We are still looking into the matter.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My preference is to have a wide coalition, which would include us, the Likud, small parties and the religious, because if you go for unity, go for unity and don't take it halfway.'' - Shimon Peres, Israeli Labor Party leader. (1:5.)

title: THE GLOBAL VOLUNTEER
description: EDWARD SWAN took early retirement two years ago from

title: Miss Stargatt Plans to Wed In February
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bruce M. Stargatt of Wilmington, Del., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah H. Stargatt, to Dr. George J. Feldman Jr., a son of Mr. Feldman of Washington and the late Marion Schulman Feldman. A February wedding is planned.

title: LOS ANGELES MAYOR RELIEVES 100 OF JOBS ON ADVISORY BOARDS
description: Mayor Tom Bradley has dismissed more than 100 appointed commissioners and brought more women, members of minorities and political supporters to power in what he calls an age, sex and ethnic balance.

title: JORDAN LEADS U.S. OVER SPAIN, 101-68
description: The first half today, despite Michael Jordan's exhibition of elasticity, at least provided some hope to the other Olympic men's basketball teams that the United States can be challenged.

title: Next Inauguration Is Planned Day After Jan. 20, Panel Says
description: The Presidential inauguration will take place Monday, Jan. 21, 1985, and will again be held on the West Front of the Capitol, the Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies announced Friday.

title: BREAKING DOWN
description: At any given moment in life, the average adult American has seven serious maintenance problems. You would never suspect this from watching television, because in the America depicted by television, maintenance problems do not exist.

title: A NONPROFIT NICHE
description: ''I DIDN'T think I would do well

title: THE ROLE OF THE GRAND JURY
description: TO you who are in prison: Somewhere along the line, you came before a grand jury. Twenty-three men and women decided whether the facts warranted a trial (by petit jury) of your case. They did not decide whether you were guilty or innocent.

title: ;  Puckett's Return
description: Linda Puckett , who coached the women's basketball team at Southeastern Louisiana University to an Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women national championship, is taking a high school coaching job.

title: MILITARY-INDUSTRIAL COMPLEXITIES
description: The phrase ''military-industrial complex'' has taken on certain political colorations over the years. Last week, all shades of its usage were in full blossom as some of the giants of the military hardware world dealt with the vicissitudes of the trade.

title: JUSTICE STEVENS IS SHARPLY CRITICAL OF SUPREME COURT CONSERVATIVES
description: Associate Justice John Paul Stevens criticized his colleagues on the Supreme Court in a speech here today as reaching out to express broad, ill-considered opinions in three major cases that he said should have been decided on narrower grounds.

title: WOMEN'S SALARIES MAJOR STATE ISSUE
description: TRENTON

title: State's Farms Should Be Saved
description: Joseph J. Makovich seems to be more concerned with real-estate values than with the cultural and health values of preserving Connecticut farms and the fresh foods they produce. (Letter to the Editor, July 8)

title: MERCANTILE BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BOWNE & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $562,000 for the quarter and $747,000 for the 9 months. The latest quarter and 9 months results include operating results of Plow & Watters Printing Canada Ltd. for which the purchase of an 80 percent stake was completed on March 30. The latest 9 months results include long-term capital gains on the sale of securities, after provision for income taxes, of $490,000, or 5 cents a share. Retroactive effect has been given to the discontinuance of operations of Bowne Information Systems Inc. for the year-earlier quarter and 9 months results. The year-earlier 9 months results include a long-term capital gain on the sale of GTE common stock, after provision for income taxes, of $1,105,000, or 11 cents a share.

title: BLACK CHURCH IS RECLAIMING SOCIAL GOSPEL
description: There are times when the Allen Church in Jamaica, Queens, might seem more like a social-service organization than a house of worship.

title: Gov. Askew's Campaign Ended $152,901 in Debt
description: Former Gov. Reubin Askew of Florida who dropped out of the Democratic Presidential race, is $152,901 in debt, the Federal Election Commission said Thursday.

title: German Trade Deficit
description: West Germany's balance of payments deficit narrowed to 1.07 billion marks, or about $373 million, in June from a shortfall of 3.35 billion marks in May, the nation's central bank has announced. The central bank said on Friday that June's deficit nearly matched the June 1983 payments balance deficit of 1.018 billion marks.

title: No Headline
description: Trade Publisher Promoted

title: VOLLEYBALL ; ; U.S. Tops Peru, Gains Final
description: Debbie Green helped assure the United States of its first volleyball medal by leading the women's team to a 16-14, 15-9, 15-10 victory today over Peru to advance to the gold- medal game against China Tuesday night.

title: 8 Ohio Lotto Winners To Split $24.6 Million
description: Eight winners of Saturday's Ohio Lotto drawing will share $24.6 million, the biggest lottery jackpot in North American history, lottery officials said today..

title: ELDERLY FIND SOLACE AND SAVINGS AS THEY SHARE HOMES AND LIVES
description: When 74-year-old Joan Howitt broke a hip last winter, the fear of not knowing where she would live when she left the hospital almost broke her spirit.

title: CITY'S TRANSIT AGENCY GETS A FEDERAL GRANT
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato yesterday announced a $35.9 million Federal grant for the Transit Authority that will be spent on day-to-day operations.

title: Anne Fanning and Douglas Haigh Reiniger Marry
description: Anne Fanning, a daughter of Mrs. Philip Gleichenhaus of New York and the late Mr. Gleichenhaus, was married yesterday to Douglas Haigh Reiniger, a son of Virginia Reiniger of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and Haigh Reiniger of Old Lyme, Conn. Judge Leah R. Marks of New York State Family Court performed the ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: CHURCH-STATE ISSUE TO BE SHARPENED
description: The next Supreme Court term is shaping up as a potential watershed in the constitutional relationship between government and religion.

title: CONCERT: 'VINTAGE ALICE' AT MOUNTAINS FESTIVAL
description: ''Music ih the Mountains'' is a summer series in New Paltz dedicated to new American music - or more specifically to conservative, melodic American music. Its third season ended Saturday with an orchestral program led by the festival's director, Gundaris Pone. It was well played; one could only wish that the music itself had justified the festival planners' faith in it more persuasively.

title: FIRST WOMEN'S OLYMPIC MARATHON TO BENOIT
description: With a daring that successfully challenged the finest female distance runners in the world and an ease that surprised even herself, Joan Benoit took a calculated risk, ran away from the field after passing the three-mile mark, and won the first Olympic marathon for women this morning.

title: Aides of Lisbon's Ex-Colonies In Africa Review Cooperation
description: Officials of the five Portuguese-speaking nations in Africa met in Guinea-Bissau today for three days of talks aimed at improving cooperation and easing tensions.

title: DONALD J. GRANT
description: Donald J. Grant, an advertising executive and a former senior editor of Advertising Age, died of pneumonia Saturday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 45 years old and lived in New York City.

title: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company is listed on the Montreal, Toronto, and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: ECONOMISTS SEE BIG BUDGET GAP, WHOEVER WINS
description: On the basis of all they have said in the election campaign about taxes and spending, neither President Reagan nor Walter F. Mondale would significantly reduce the Government's record budget deficits, according to many of the nation's leading economic forecasters.

title: AMERICANS RUFFLE JAPAN'S PASTIME
description: TOKYOWhat some people think of as the great American pastime has too many Americans to suit the commissioner of Japanese baseball.

title: Dispute on Party Funds
description: Congress is on the brink of cutting off Federal funds for the Democratic and Republican National Committees, money that would have underwritten their participation in the National Endowment for Democracy, a program in which business, labor and the political parties seek to promote the growth of democratic institutions in foreign nations.

title: BASKETBALL ; ; U.S. Women Rout Canada
description: Cheryl Miller and Anne Donovan led the United States to an 18-2 spurt at the start of the second half today as the American women routed Canada, 92-61, in basketball.

title: WIDCOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ISRAELI MODEL OF ENDURANCE: SHIMON PERES
description: Shimon Peres, who was chosen today to form a new Israeli Government, has arrived at the high point of his political career after years of bruising struggle, much of it within his own Labor Party. The Prime Minister- designate, who turns 61 years old Aug. 16, began his work in the Government as a close aide of Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion, whom he served for 12 years, most of them in the Defense Ministry.

title: STEWART & STEVENSON SERVCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HOW GUATEMALAN RIGHTISTS WON AN EDGE
description: To the Editor:

title: ARE HAPPY DAYS OF '82 BACK?
description: Like hundreds of portfolio managers in charge of big pools of money, Andrew Furtak of the $1.3 billion IDS Stock Fund heard the rumble of a market rally last week and sprung into action.

title: LLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $559,000 for the quarter and $630,000 for the year, losses from the disposal of discontinued operations of $1,200,000 for the quarter and $2,200,000 for the year, and an extraordinary gain of $1,900,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $616,000 for the quarter and $1,800,000 for the year, and a loss from the disposal of discontinued operations of $116,000 for the quarter and year. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Minnesotan Is Seized In Wedding Killing
description: The police arrested a man today in connection with a shooting at a wedding reception in which one guest was killed and three others were wounded, the authorities said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: Here is Queenie Quesky addressing her students - or so she recalls - on the occasion of their immersion in Shakespeare's sonnets.

title: RADICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OLYMPIC HIGHLIGHTS
description: The summer of 1984 may be remembered as a time when women were judged fit to run: for Vice President and for the gold medal in the Olympic marathon. Since 1896, at the first modern Games in Greece, men have contested the grueling 26-mile, 385-yard event while women were not considered strong enough. That notion was put to rest yesterday in the streets of Santa Monica, Venice, Marina del Ray and central Los Angeles and on the track at the Memorial Coliseum.

title: 49 Die in Bangladesh As Plane Plunges
description: A Bangladesh passenger plane crashed today while trying to land in a driving rainstorm, killing all 49 people on board.

title: DEFENSE TO PRESENT CASE IN RETRIAL OF FEDERAL JUDGE ON TAX CHARGES
description: The defense of Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne of Las Vegas is to unfold beginning Monday in a retrial that may conclude this week.

title: BIG BANKS WORRIED BY AN F.D.I.C. PLAN
description: The near collapse and multibillion- dollar rescue of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company has been an embarrassment for the nation's biggest banks. It could be expensive for them as well.

title: POLITICIANS AND RELIGION: DISCUSSION SIGNALS SHIFT
description: Governor Cuomo's exchange with the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York over the role of religion in politics is seen by several politicians as evidence that defensiveness among Catholics is declining.

title: AMREP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DANCE: SARAH BRUMGART AT MERCE CUNNINGHAM STUDIO
description: Ballet is full of displays of sheeer technique. But content, whether formal or dramatic, seems more the point in modern dance.

title: Saatchi's U.S. Unit Makes Staff Changes
description: Saatchi & Saatchi Compton, the United States arm of Britain's No. 1 agency, is bringing in five high-priced executives and promoting a couple of its own top guns.

title: POPULATION PARLEY TO OPEN IN MEXICO TODAY
description: The chief United States delegate to the International Conference on Population said today that the Reagan Administration's decision to cut off international aid for abortions ''does not reflect any radical changes'' of policy or lessen its commitment to international family planning programs.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
FIRST GASPS, THEN CHEERS
description: LOS ANGELESFirst there were gasps, then there were cheers, and later there were questions, hard questions. The first women's Olympic marathon in history was turning into a controversy over an issue that could have been a matter of life and death.

title: ISRAELI PRESIDENT DESIGNATES PERES TO FORM CABINET
description: Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader, was asked today to form a new government of Israel.

title: Watching Price/Earnings Ratios
description: Not all money managers are buying the argument that the rally will be short-lived. John M. McCarthy, chairman of the $2 billion Affiliated Fund, a mutual stock fund, for instance, argues that the stock market is due for a revision that will lead to significantly higher stock prices.

title: Grace Assails Congress As 'Clowns' on Deficit
description: -cutting panel, said yesterday that two-thirds of the members of Congress were ''clowns'' and that they were to blame for not cutting the Federal deficit.

title: LAWMAKERS URGE REAGAN TO DELAY SHIPMENT OF PLUTONIUM TO JAPAN
description: Five Senators and 10 members of Congress have urged President Reagan to delay an order that would allow 417 pounds of plutonium - enough for 30 nuclear bombs - to be shipped from France to Japan.

title: Italy Wins Cycling; U.S. Takes Bronze
description: Italy captured the last cycling gold medal today winning the 100-kilometer team trial in Olympic-record time. Americans took the bronze, capping a sensational performance that yielded nine medals, the first of Americans in Olympic cycling since 1912.

title: MUSIC: STRAUSS'S 'INTERMEZZO' AT SANTA FE OPERA
description: We in this country know so little first hand of Richard Strauss's ''Intermezzo'' that its appearance this summer at the Santa Fe Opera comes as both a surprise and a delight.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Derailment Closes Jersey Turnpike
description: Four tanker cars carrying liquefied petroleum gasoline derailed Saturday under an overpass of the New Jersey Turnpike, and the state police closed the highway for five hours this morning as a precaution.

title: HAWKINS CHEMICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HEAD OF WARNACO UNIT MOVES TO GENERAL MILLS
description: Richard F. Kral has been elected executive vice president in charge of the fashion group at General Mills.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Musto to Begin Federal Sentence
description: Former State Senator William V. Musto is scheduled to surrender to begin a seven-year racketeering sentence today at a Federal prison in Sandstone, Minn.

title: A FREED POLE URGES SOLIDARITY MEETING
description: A leader of the outlawed Solidarity labor union who was recently released from prison under the Government's amnesty called today for a meeting of the union's leadership.

title: A Turnaround for Decker
description: Two and a half weeks ago, Mary Decker thought she might miss the Olympic Games.

title: MUSIC: BERLIOZ OPERA AT TANGELWOOD
description: LENOX, Mass.

title: Yugoslav Tells of Plot To Topple Communism
description: A senior Yugoslav leader said today that opponents of the Government were trying to overthrow the country's Communist system and create a Western-style democracy.

title: Building in Antwerp Bombed; A Link to Basques Suspected
description: A bomb damaged the Palace of Justice here today but caused no injuries, the police reported.

title: PURCHASERS CITE LAG IN GROWTH
description: The economy's growth rate continued to moderate in July, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday.

description: Actress Becomes Student In Criminal Court

Market Place;
Rally Displays Sheer Force
description: THE stock market won gold medals last week

title: SEAL FLEET INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FIELD HOCKEY ; ; Britain Goes to Semifinals
description: Britain, charging into the semifinals of the Olympic men's field hockey tournament, beat the Netherlands, 4-3, today. In another match, New Zealand got its first victory.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Cubs , at Chicago. The Mets, who dropped three of four games to the Cubs in Shea Stadium last weekend, try to recover in the standing as they open a four-game series in a late afternoon start at Wrigley Field.

title: FARED ROBOT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $442,000 from the sale of certain assets. c-Net loss.

description: To the Editor:

title: POLLUTION RESEARCH & CONROL reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $147,000. c-Includes a tax benefit of $20,000. Certain year-ago results have been reclassified for comparative purposes.

title: ;  Say It With Flowers Bursting with ''festive federalism'' colors of orange, purple and vermillion, Los Angeles' city flower, the Bird of Paradise, was a natural choice for the more than 1,300 bouquets presented to most of the Olympic medal winners.
description: In order to complete the bouquets in Olympic colors, however, exotic flowers are still flown in from the Netherlands, Hawaii and the Orient every two to three days. ''We wanted to stay away from roses, carnations and the traditional flowers,'' said Marti Frucci, an associate vice president in the organizing committee's awards department.

title:
U.S. REWARDS FOR POLAND, BUT...;
AND THAT WEAK AMNESTY?
description: The Reagan Administration may have made a serious mistake last week in deciding so hastily to respond to Poland's new amnesty law with an easing of economic sanctions.

title: Eastwood Wins by 2
description: Bob Eastwood, who went 12 years without a victory, acquired his second title of the PGA Tour season today in a two- stroke triumph in the Danny Thomas- Memphis Classic.

title: METS WIN IN 10 ON FOSTER'S HIT
description: George Foster, who aroused the Mets with his clubhouse oratory Friday night before they snapped a seven-game losing streak, aroused them in a more tangible way today: With two down and the bases loaded in the 10th inning, he delivered the single that defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3-1.

title: SUIT DEMANDS UTILITIES CEASE USE OF PAYMENTS FOR CHARITIES
description: A suit has been filed seeking to prohibit the State Public Service Commission from letting utilities charge their customers for charitable donations the companies make.

title: RAKISH STAGE AND SCREEN STAR
description: Richard Burton, a Welsh coal miner's son whose celebrity was defined as much by his rakish personal life as his remarkable acting skills, died of a cerebral hemorrhage yesterday in Switzerland. He was 58 years old.

title: MOSES AND ASHFORD JOIN THE GOLD MEDAL LIST; U.S. 1-2 IN HURDLES AND WOMEN'S 100
description: Today was one of those lovely days for American track and field in the Games of the XXIII Olympiad.

title: Miller Wins by 2
description: Alice Miller held her game together today after a near bogey on the 13th hole to retain her title in the West Virginia Ladies' Professional Golf Association Classic.

title: POWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
REALTY INCOME TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $111,087 from the early extinguishment of debt. c-Includes a gain of $83,581 from the early extinguishment of debt and a gain of $342,521 on the sale of investments.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Revamping Brings Merrill Lynch Shifts
description: A raft of executive appointments at Merrill Lynch & Company have been announced by William A. Schreyer, its president and chief executive officer.

title: Mondale Seeks an Economist
description: Walter Mondale needs a staff economist for the campaign. His top economic advisers, such as George L. Perry at the Brookings Institute; W. Boman Cutter, associate director of President Carter's budget office, and Van Doorn Ooms, the House Budget Committee's chief economist, might land top jobs in a Mondale Administration, but they're too senior to get pulled into the campaign.

title: Under the Human Volcano
description: Delegates to today's World Population Conference in Mexico City need only look out the window to see the baleful shadow of a human volcano. Of 17 million people in Mexico's capital, two of five are jobless; a sixth lack sewage; all breathe a toxic smog. Government struggles to promote birth control in a mostly Roman Catholic society, to brake a growth that beggars it.

title: Advertising; Publisher Seeks Rich Readership
description: AFTER a multitude of conversations with magazine publishing companies and a considerable amount of help from an investment banking firm that specializes in magazines, Mark B. Inabnit, a magazine entrepreneur out of Texas, has sold his company. Now, he has the money to turn another concept into reality.

title: SWANTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $121,000 for the quarter and $306,000 for the 6 months. c-After a gain from discontinued operations of $199,000 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $201,000 for the 6 months.

title: Gail Friedman Is Married
description: Gail Robin Friedman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Friedman of Yonkers, and Gary A. Mendelson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Mendelson of Freeport, L.I. were married yesterday. Rabbi Maurice J. Davis performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in New Hyde Park, L.I. The bride is a paralegal with the law firm Clair & Daniele in New York, where Mr. Mendelson is an actuary with William M. Mercer-Meidinger Inc.

title: JUDO ; ; 144-Pound Title to Japanese
description: Yoshiyuki Matsuoka of Japan won the gold medal in 65-kilo (144-pound) judo today. Hwang Jung Oh of Korea won the silver, and Marc Alexandre of France and Josef Reiter of Austria tied for the bronze.

title: SOCCER ; ; Italy Shuts Out Chile, 1-0
description: Behiamino Vignola scored on a penalty kick 6 minutes 50 seconds into the first overtime to give Italy a 1-0 victory over Chile today in the quarterfinals of the Olympic soccer tournament. A crowd of 67,039 watched the match at Stanford Stadium.

title: HIROSHIMA, MONUMENT TO HOPE
description: Hiroshima is a synonym for horror. But today, 39 years after it was destroyed by an atomic bomb, Hiroshima should also be recognized as a monument to hope.

title: MODERN DANCE ARRIVES IN SARATOGA SPRINGS
description: When members of the Jose Limon Dance Company brought an injured performer to the Saratoga Hospital in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., late last month, they were assisted by a medical technician who had seen them perform and was full of comments about the program. Modern dance had arrived at this upstate town, better known as the summer home of the ballet.

title: Sally Brickell Is Married To a Veterinary Student
description: The wedding of Sally Ann Brickell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Mitchell Brickell of Plandome, L.I., to Jeffrey Roy Kaplan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Kaplan of Manhasset, L.I., took place yesterday.

title: MONTANA'S SURPRISES
description: HELENA, Mont.

title: DIFFERENT RESULTS WITH SOVIET BLOC
description: When the Olympic swimming competition ended Saturday night, two conclusions were obvious.

title: Muffled Controversy
description: The official United States policy

title: CHYRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in August 1984.

title: Dr. Allen Feldman Marries Nancy Susan Getnick
description: Nancy Susan Getnick, the daughter of George S. Getnick of Valley Stream, L.I., and the late Helen Schrier Getnick, was married yesterday to Dr. Allen Robert Feldman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Feldman, also of Valley Stream. Rabbi Simon Resnikoff performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: Advertising Sales At $428 Million
description: As the Olympics passed the midway point, ABC-TV has already earned more than $428 million in advertising sales, according to broadcast trade journals.

title: NOVA SCOTIA DAM'S EFFECT ON COAST ECOLOGY FEARED
description: Nova Scotia's plans to build a huge plant to harness the power of tides in the Bay of Fundy has touched off a dispute over how severely it will affect the coastal environment from northern Maine to Cape Cod.

title: QUARTERLY ROUNDUP OF SALES AND EARNINGS OF 274 COMPANIES
Swede Loses Silver For Using Steroids
description: Thomas Johansson of Sweden, who lost to Jeff Blatnick of the United States in the super-heavyweight Greco-Roman wrestling final, tested positively for steriods and must forfeit his Olympic silver medal, a Swedish official said today.

title: Britain Asks Oil Price Aid
description: Oil analysts have disclosed that for the first time the British Government has asked major oil companies for help in maintaining stable prices in light of increased production by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: BUSH ASSERTS MONDALE FAILED AS LEADER IN THE LANCE AFFAIR
description: Vice President Bush opened up a new avenue of attack on Walter F. Mondale today, accusing the Democratic Presidential nominee of failed leadership in handling the departure of Bert Lance as general chairman of his campaign.

title: U.S. Calls Bank Robbers Unsophisticated Thieves
description: The average bank robber is an unsophisticated criminal who does not study the bank or disguise himself from cameras and usually steals about $3,300, the Justice Department said today.

title: CHILL IN BLOC: SOVIET CHIDES GERMANS
description: The quiet detente developing between the two Germanys, with its prospect of the first visit ever to Bonn by an East German leader, has drawn some unusually public displays of irritation from the Kremlin. Twice in the last two weeks Pravda, the Communist Party daily, bitterly denounced Bonn's latest economic agreements with East Berlin. It charged that the West Germans were using an ''economic lever'' to undermine their Communist neighbor's ''stability'' and, more broadly, postwar Europe's peaceful structure.

title: Joan Chasan Married to Zeb D. Alford
description: Joan S. Chasan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Chasan of Syosset, L.I., was married yesterday to Zeb D. Alford, a son of Mrs. J. Burton Alford of McComb, Miss., and the late Mr. Alford. District Court Judge Alvin L. Zimmerman of Harris County, Tex., performed the ceremony at the Remington Hotel in Houston.

title: 'INSIDE TRADERS' WITH BILLIONS AT STAKE
description: To the Editor:

title: E.I.L. INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
;  Knight, Sweet Knight
description: The new comedy act of Knight and Holgado is expected to entertain crowds as long as the men's Olympic basketball competition continues.

title: 'SUMMERFARE' OFFERED FROM WATERLOO VILLAGE
description: Waterloo Village, near Stanhope, N.J., is a lovely restored 18th-century town, and the home since the mid-1970's of the Waterloo Festival and its summer music school, directed by the conductor and trumpeter Gerard Schwarz. The festival and its surroundings alike are beautifully on display tonight at 10 as Channel 13 offers the first of three ''Summerfare'' programs offering music from New Jersey.

title: Four Beech Aircraft Plants Struck by Machinists Union
description: About 3,000 machinists went on strike today against the Beech Aircraft Corporation's four commercial airplane plants.

title: Elizabeth N. Billington Wed to Donald H. Fox
description: Elizabeth Newkirk Billington, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David P. Billington of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Donald Hardie Fox, a son of Hannah P. Fox of Princeton and the late Rev. Frederic Ewing Fox. The Rev. Dr. John Marks, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: Israel Pleads for Sovi
description: The Cabinet of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir called today for international efforts to seek the release of Yosef Begun, a Soviet dissident who was sentenced last year to seven years in jail for distributing anti-Soviet literature. In a Cabinet statement, Mr. Shamir said the health of the 52-year-old Jewish activist was worsening.

title: NEW YORK'S INVITATION TO SALES TAX EVASION
description: To the Editor:

title: SUN DEVOTEES JOIN WORKERS ON OILY SHORE
description: On a normal Sunday afternoon in August, the six-mile stretch of sun- drenched beach known as the Jamaica area on this Gulf Coast island would be as crowded as Coney Island. Today it had about as many people on it as a stretch of desert.

title: BIG-TICKET BICYCLE
description: Two gold-medal winners on the United States Olympic cycling team say corporate support and high-technology equipment have helped to propel the United States ''way ahead'' of other countries in design.

title: LAND OF LINCOLN SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FERRARO SAYS REAGAN WOULD RAISES TAXES IN A SECOND TERM
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro charged today that President Reagan's declaration that he had no plan to raise taxes amounted to a campaign promise he would break if re-elected.

title: BERKSHIRE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SZABO OF RUMANIA EARNS 3 GOLDS
description: Mary Lou Retton had already made off with the big prize, but tonight Ecaterina Szabo won almost all the little ones.

title: Wine Bill's Prospects Improve
description: Prospects for Representative Tony Coelho's bill to help American wine producers sell their product abroad look brighter, after a turnabout by farmers.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: What is the name and origin of the Olympic melody played so frequently on telecasts of the Winter and Summer Games?

title: No Headline
description: -Level Dioxin

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: FUGITIVE IS KILLED IN GUN BATTLE
description: An escapee from a Tennessee prison was killed and another was wounded today in a gun battle with Connecticut state troopers who had been chasing them, the state police said.

title: SHORT-TERM RATES CALLED CREDIT KEY
description: Long-term bond yields have fallen sharply in the last two months but, for the decline to continue much further, some analysts say that short-term interest rates must fall, too.

title: FORCING BATTLE ON THE BUDGET PROCESS
description: Two Senators, a Republican and a Democrat, showed last week what is killing the Congressional budget process, which was once touted as the best hope for restraining government spending. Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the Republican chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, joined with the Republican leadership in a move to waive the budget act, push aside a filibuster by one its defenders and take up the appropriation bill for agriculture. It was a case of Mr. Domenici's turning on a law of which he, as Budget Committee chairman, has been the chief advocate.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 6, 1984

title: Let Stock Crime Fit the Punishment
description: Congress, at long last, has approved stiffer penalties for illegal insider trading in securities. The Securities and Exchange Commission asked for them two years ago. Investors who benefit from information not available to the public could be fined up to three times the amounts they gained. But the bill leaves a critical question unanswered: What's illegal trading?

title: Hutton Broker Enjoys Exciting' First Week
description: When Jeffrey J. Douglass and 11 other freshly trained account executives started at E. F. Hutton & Company last Monday, they knew that salesmanship would be a key to future success.

title: TELECREDIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $382,000, or 7 cents a share, from the sale of Telecredit's equity in DMC Systems Inc.

title: Burford Out of Lineup
description: Anne McGill Burford appears to be content to withdraw from the Administration batter's box with two strikes against her. The former Environmental Protection Administrator, who asked President Reagan last week to drop her as chairman of the National Advisory Committee on Oceans and Atmosphere, later said: ''I don't think I am going to do anything for a while in terms of political things.''

title: 'GRSAT PIZZA CAPER' IN FIRE I. VILLAGE REVIVES DEBATE ON LITTER ORDINANCE
description: At Town Pizza, a regular slice with a soda costs $1.75, and a slice with eggplant is $1.85. Eating them outside the pizzeria can cost $25 more.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Amfac Inc., San Francisco, has appointed Robert C. Lowell vice president and assistant to the president; Keith V. Mabee vice president, corporate communications; John R. Stamps, vice president, administration, and Richard D. Baum vice president, employee relations.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: BURGER ASSAILS LAWYERS' ADS AND CONTINGENT FEES
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger said today that such practices as advertising by lawyers and the use of contingent fees in certain cases deviated from the traditional standards of the bar.

title: FEW DIVIDENDS ARE SEEN FOR JAPANESE COMPETITORS
description: The biggest winner in the European Economic Community's antitrust action against the International Business Machines Corporation, some experts had insisted, would be the Japanese computer industry. Since a settlement of the case was announced last Thursday, however, there have been no victory celebrations here.

title: OVERSCHEDULING BY MANY AIRLINES ASSAILED AS A KEY CAUSE OF DELAYS
description: At Kennedy International Airport one recent day, 63 planes were scheduled to arrive in the hour beginning at 3:45 P.M. But the most the airport could handle, even with clear weather, was 44.

title: COMPUTER AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE REGION ; ;  Ex-House Aide Shot Riding in Car
description: A former aide to Representative Stewart McKinney, Republican of Connecticut, was shot in the head by another motorist early today on Interstate 95, the state police said.

title: COST OF BRITAIN'S COAL STRIKE
description: Five months into the bitter strike by most of Britain's coal miners, analysts and politicians are struggling to measure its economic cost.

title: NEW LAW ALLOWS STATE BANKS WIDER USE OF VARIABLE RATES
description: Banks may now charge variable interest rates on some consumer loans, including auto loans and credit card balances, under a law signed Saturday by Governor Cuomo.

title: ABUSE CASE PROMPTS REVIEW OF HIRING AT DAY-CARE CENTERS
description: Allegations of sexual abuse at a Bronx day-care center have prompted city officials to begin an extensive review of hiring and screening practices for employees at the 385 privately operated day-care centers that receive city funds.

title: Alexander's Names Suitors Alexander's Inc., the New
description: York department store chain

title: Afghanistan Rebels Release A Captured Japanese Envoy
description: An official at the Japanese Embassy in Afghanistan, held captive for six weeks by guerrillas, returned here today.

title: Debt Rating
description: GAF Corp. senior debt was raised to BBx from B and preferred stock to Bx from CCC by Standard & Poor's Corp. Corporate Notes

title: Sri Lanka Seeks a Study Of Madras Airport Blast
description: Sri Lanka's Prime Minister, Ranasinghe Premadasa, has proposed that India and Sri Lanka hold a joint inquiry into the bomb explosion at Madras Airport, the state radio said today.

title: FEAR OF A LONG COURT BATTLE LED PARTIES TO COMPROMISE
description: The European Economic Community and the International Business Machines Corporation, working toward last week's compromise in a landmark antitrust case, both wanted to avoid a legal battle before Europe's highest court, though for very different reasons, according to sources close to the negotiations.

title: BASEBALL ; ; Japan Loses to Canada, 6-4
description: Canada backed three young pitchers with an attack of 15 singles today to beat the previously undefeated Japanese, 6-4, but Japan has still clinched a spot in the tournament semifinals.

title: People
description: * Kerry M. Rubie, regional managing director-Asia, and Segio Suarez-Solis, regional managing director-Latin America, have been elected to the board of the Leo Burnett Company, Chicago.

title: LETTER: ON PEST CONTROL
description: DISPATCH FROM THE MOSQUITO FRONT

title: SPONSORING OF GAMES APPEARS TO BE SUCCESSFUL
description: The Games of the XXIII Olympiad are only half over, but evidence is growing that private enterprise has succeeded in pulling off what only government has done before.

title: VALTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Miss Rottmund Wed To Allan L. Pashcow
description: Louise Marie Rottmund, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Rottmund of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Allan Lawrence Pashcow, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Pashcow of Massapequa Park, L.I. The Rev. John Denniston, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Old Westbury (L.I.) Gardens.

title: DAVIS WATER & WASTE INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Jackson Is Still in Debt, His Campaign Reports
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson's unsuccessful Presidential campaign is about $350,000 in debt despite its recent financial statement that indicated otherwise, his campaign manager says.

title: PRATT-READ CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that the net income for the year-ago quarter includes investment tax credits amounting to 9 cents a share.

title: SHANNON FIRST AMERICAN BOXER TO LOSE
description: There were 22 seconds remaining in the second round and Robert Shannon had dutifully gone to a neutral corner, where he watched as Referee John Poucher of Ireland gave the Korean Sung Kil Moon a standing 8-count. From Shannon's perspective, a turning point in the bout had been reached, and in anticipation of another American victory, he turned and blew a kiss to the crowd. A last kiss, as it turned out.

title: TREVOR NUNN TO DIRECT FILM ON LADY JANE GREY
description: Paramount Pictures, which will bring back the biblical epic next summer with its $22 million ''David the King,'' has also decided to resuscitate another out-of-favor movie genre - the historical saga.

title: Miss Kohn Wed To L. J. Wurzel
description: Martha Anne Kohn, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Kohn of Locust, N.J., was married yesterday to Lawrence J. Wurzel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Wurzel of Sands Point, L.I. Rabbis Sally Priesand and Martin S. Rozenberg performed the ceremony at the Monmouth Reform Temple in Tinton Falls, N.J.

title: TEXT OF ACCEPTANCE SPEECH GIVEN BY PERES
description: Following is the text of an acceptance speech today by Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader and Prime Minister-designate, as translated by The Associated Press from the Hebrew:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: A Long Route to Rome

title: A.T.&T. Gets Union Help
description: The Communications Workers of America, whose members collect more than $300 million a year from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in pay and benefits, will be giving $2 million back in a novel advertising campaign.

title: WHAT OF WARSAW'S DEBT?
description: The Administration's decision last week to ease some of the sanctions on economic and scientific cooperation with Poland is a step in the right direction. It does not, however, solve the larger, underlying problem created for the United States by our decision in December 1981 to impose sanctions on Poland.

title: WEIGHT LIFTING ; ; Rumanian Sets 3 Records
description: Nicu Vlad, a Rumanian Army officer, broke three Olympic weight lifting records tonight in winning the 198- pound class.

title: New Soviet Guidelines On Movies' Content
description: The Government has imposed strict new guidelines on movies, requiring them to reflect current problems and workers' lives, the head of the leading Soviet film studio said last week.

title: L.I. HOSPITAL STRIKERS VOTE ACCORD
description: Striking workers at Hempstead (L.I.) General Hospital voted yesterday to return to work in exchange for an agreement to abide by whatever settlement is reached in the walkout by workers at 29 hospitals in New York City.

title: OF BUSING, SECESSION AND FABLES
description: Not long ago, a citizens' group in the rural hamlet of Hemingway, S.C., decided to do something that has a strong historical precedent in South Carolina, which in 1861 became the first of the Southern states to leave the Union. They petitioned to have Hemingway secede from Williamsburg County, which is mostly black, in favor of joining neighboring Florence County, which is mostly white.

title: ; Italy Wins Gold in Foil
description: Italy won the gold medal in men's team foil competition tonight. West Germany won the silver and France won the bronze.

title: SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Rh^one-Siltec Subsidiary
description: Rh^one-Poulenc S. A., France's nationalized chemicals group, has announced that it will join with Siltec, a California- based silicon maker, to produce silicon wafers used to make semiconductors.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: FOR DALLAS, A GROWING CULTURAL IDENTITY CRISIS
description: DALLASNot far from the skyscrapers of this city stand a Methodist church built in 1900, a log cabin from 1847 and a bank, general store and hotel that are 100 years old. Period pieces all, they were plucked off the prairie in small Texas towns, buttressed and repainted, and deposited in an outdoor museum alongside one of Dallas's innumerable freeways.

title: FOR TOURISTS, A CITY SHINES IN DARKNESS
description: When people yawned Sunday morning at the First Baptist Church in America it was not because of the sermon.

title: KRIEK FINDS HIS SERVE AND TAKES FINAL
description: As he tossed and turned Saturday night in his hotel suite on the eve of his final- round match against Michael Westphal of West Germany in the North American Open tennis tournament, Johan Kriek could recall only the nightmarish images of their previous encounter.

title: EVEN OUTSIDE, JACKSON IS MAIN EVENT
description: Inside Madison Square Garden, the show was Michael Jackson and his brothers. Outside, the show was people who couldn't get inside.

title: Futures/Options; Young Markets Play Key Role
description: LAST week's spectacular surge in stock prices

title: JETS EXPERIENCING A SENSE OF URGENCY
description: A sense of urgency overtook some of the Jets today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Censoring Black America

title: 60-Second Debate; Will a tax
description: increase be necessary

title: BILL COSBY BEGINS TAPING NBC SERIES
description: Lamont, the goldfish, was dead. Belly-up and motionless, with nary a quiver in fin or gill. Unfortunately, 5-year-old Rudy - the person with whom Lamont had shared a meaningful (at least to her) relationship - appeared not to have grasped the situation, judging by the fact that she was energetically bombarding him with a hailstorm of fish food and crooning as if he were responding to her every word. For Rudy's family, the question was a heartrender: How to break the dire news?

title: Italian Prices Up in July
description: Italian consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in July, climbing to a level 10.5 percent higher than in July 1983, for the smallest 12-month rise in more than a decade, the State Statistical Institute said on Friday.

title: PROFIT RISE SLOWED IN 2D QUARTER
description: Buoyant economic expansion continued to lift corporate profits in the second quarter, but the earnings growth slowed from the vigorous level of recent quarters, partly because of intense competition and high interest rates.

title: JIM DANDY IS WON BY CARR DE NASKRA
description: Carr de Naskra finally unleashed his explosive potential today to score a devastating 12 3/4-length victory in the $126,200 Jim Dandy Stakes at Saratoga Race Track.

title: Deukmejian of California Will Nominate Bush
description: Gov. George Deukmejian of California has been chosen to give the nominating speech for Vice President George Bush at the Republican National Convention, Mr. Deukmejian's office said Saturday.

title: Flag Owner Still Mystery
description: After Carl Lewis won the gold medal Saturday night in the Olympic 100-meter dash, he grabbed an American flag from a spectator, ran with it, then returned it.

title: LI TOWERS ABOVE ALL THE COMPETITION
description: The men of the American gymnastics teamhave a nickname for Li Ning, the 20- year-old Chinese acrobat who won three gold medals and a silver in the individual-apparatus competition Saturday night.

title: E.P.A. PUTS POLLUTION CONTROL AT $526 BILLION
description: The cost this decade of Federal air and water pollution controls mandated by Congress may be $526 billion in public and private expenditures, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: VIRGINIA PRISON UPRISING ENDS WITH RELEASE OF LAST HOSTAGES
description: Under threat of a state police assault if they failed to meet a 7 A.M. deadline, 32 rebellious prisoners at Virginia's Mecklenburg Correctional Center released the last of nine hostages just after sunrise today.

title: No Headline
description: Quotation of the Day

title: REDSKINS' OVERLOOK DRAFTEE
description: CARLISLE, Pa.

title: DIVING ; ; Chinese Woman Leads
description: Li Yuhua of China outlasted Kelly McCormick of Columbus, Ohio, in a seesaw battle today to become the top qualifier for Monday's finals in women's springboard diving.

title: ZAHRINGER TAKES MET AMATEUR CROWN
description: George Zahringer 3d of the Sands Point Golf Club won the Metropolitan Golf Association's 82d Amateur championship today as John Baldwin of Meadowbrook faltered on the second half of their 36-hole finale. Zahringer beat Baldwin, 6 and 5, at Deepdale Golf Club.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN OF AUSTIN reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company went public in August 1983.

title: CITY OPERA: 'CARMEN,' NEW VERSION SET IN 1936
description: The curtain hardly has risen before we know this is going to be a strange sort of ''Carmen.'' A subversive-looking fellow sidles up to Bizet's gypsy seductress with an order: ''Look for Don Jose of Lizzarrabengoa.'' With that bit of invented text, Frank Corsaro tries to establish the tone and the dramatic rationale for his staging of ''Carmen,'' which had its New York premiere on Saturday night at the City Opera. Originally done for the Opera Company of Philadelphia, Mr. Corsaro's production moves the Carmen story about a century forward, setting it in the context of the Spanish Civil War. Carmen, we come to understand, is a member of a guerrilla band engaged in smuggling guns to the anti-Franco forces. Jose is a corporal in the Fascist army with access to munition stores. An explosive situation, obviously.

title: MONDALE LIKENS FEDERAL DEFICITS TO A 'TRAPDOOR' UNDER ECONOMY
description: In his first national radio speech of the Presidential campaign, Walter F. Mondale said today that the Federal budget deficits were ''like a trapdoor under our economy,'' posing a threat to investment, agriculture and international trade.

title: BREAKING BAD NEWS TO A CHILD
description: Is there an ideal way for a child to

title: CACI GROUPS OF COMPANIES reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: WORKERS' BID FOR BRASS PLANT
description: In an effort to save the last vestige of a company that once ranked among New England's most important manufacturing concerns, 260 workers at the Bridgeport Brass Company are attempting to buy the company's rod and wire factory here through an employee stock ownership plan.

title: MONDAY, AUGUST 6, 1984 International
description: Israel's opposition leader was asked to form a new government. Shimon Peres, the Labor Party's leader, received the mandate from President Chaim Herzog nearly two weeks after national elections that left both the Labor Party and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud bloc without a parliamentary majority. (Page A1, Column 6.) An explosion in the Red Sea that severely damaged a Liberian-registered tanker, might have been caused by a mine. The tanker, the Olympic Energy, was sinking, according to unconfirmed reports that did not mention casualties. The explosion appeared to be the worst in a series in the key waterway that have damaged at least five other ships since Thursday. The State Department says a total of 15 ships have recently been involved in such incidents. (A1:2.)

title: TIGERS LOSE 2 TO ROYALS; LEAD CUT TO 8
description: Pat Sheridan keyed a four-run first inning with a two-run homer and Charlie Leibrandt pitched eight shutout innings as the Kansas City Royals beat Detroit, 4-0, to sweep today's doubleheader and the four-game weekend series with the slumping Tigers.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Yale Urged to Add Tenured Women
description: The Yale University faculty includes a far smaller percentage of women than the national average, a university report said today.

title: TREASURY ISSUES DOMINATE SCHEDULE
description: Treasury financings dominate the credit markets this week, with auctions of three-year notes, 10-year notes, and 30-year bonds totaling $16.75 billion, as well as the regular weekly sale of bills.

title: SAVE OUR BANKS THROUGH 'CLEVER DEREGULATION'
description: To the Editor:

title: Hiroshima Anniversary
description: Somber note will be taken today

title: URS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The year-earlier share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated for a 5 percent stock dividend on May 4, 1984.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:

title: Hazy Recollections Of the Final Steps
description: At first, she was embarrassed. Gabriela Andersen-Schiess of Sun Valley, Idaho, a dual citizen of the United States and Switzerland representing the Swiss in the first Olympic marathon for women, finished 37th.

title: No Headline
description: A Dance Hall of Fame Is Planned in Saratoga

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Posters, the art of advertising, of drawing people to see art, and other things, have become esteemed as an art for their own sake, and exhibitions of poster art are common events in today's art world. The show of posters on view through Aug. 17 at New York University's Grey Art Gallery and Study Center, 33 Washington Place, corner of Washington Square East (598-7603), is, however, an uncommonly different one in theme.

title: CONRAIL BIDDERS REPORTEDLY CUT TO 2
description: The Reagan Administration, approaching the end of its search for a new owner for Conrail, has virtually eliminated all but two bidders for the Government-owned rail line, according to sources.

title: Bally's Picks Ogilvy
description: Bally's Park Place Casino in Atlantic City is assigning its account to Ogilvy & Mather Partners.

title: Mine in Lebanon Kills Israeli; Attacks on Troops Up Sharply
description: An Israeli soldier was killed and two were wounded in Lebanon today when their armored personnel carrier hit a mine near the eastern village of Amiq, a military spokesman said.

title: A SLOGAN FOR KENYA'S TAXIS: 'SEE YOU IN HEAVEN'
description: If art reflects life, then the baked clay model the hawkers sell says something about how Kenyans live. It says a lot, too, about how some of them die. The simple sculpture depicts a communal taxi van. The vehicle sags on expiring springs. Four people are pressed into familiarity across the front seat. One of them, half in and half out, is the driver. Those in the rear are packed like sardines. Men hang from the open back door in the manner of Beirut gunmen. Slogans on the side proclaim, appropriately, ''See you in heaven.'' Amid the luggage atop the vehicle, two chickens cast a querulous gaze.

title: MUSIC: ELLY AMELING AT CARAMOOR
description: The best concert singers possess a movable intimacy, and can make a gigantic, impersonal concert hall seem as cozy and familiar as a 19th-century drawing room. At the Caramoor Festival Saturday night, the soprano Elly Ameling went one step further. She sang to the great outdoors - the trees and the stars her only limits - and yet such is Miss Ameling's artistry that one felt that she was divulging personal secrets to a few special friends.

title: VOLUNTEER'S GOAL: 'BUY BRONX'
description: Suzanne Pincus is a former Miss Utah who now lives on Park Avenue and has a summer place in Southampton. But her heart, she says, is in the Bronx.

title: A-ARMS PROTEST IN HIROSHIMA
description: Some 20,000 antinuclear campaigners held a rally in central Hiroshima tonight to hear protest songs and speeches marking the 39th anniversary Monday of the world's first atomic bomb attack.

title: The Worth of Hong Kong
description: France's Henry IV once offered a worldly reason for his conversion to Catholicism: ''Paris is worth a mass.'' Just as flexibly, China's Communist rulers have apparently concluded that a thriving and profitable Hong Kong is worth leaving it with British-style courts and Western-style freedoms. Though vital details are still unresolved, the bargain so far struck on Hong Kong's future does credit to British diplomacy and China's realism.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS ; ;  The Gwynn Gamble After Chris Gwynn, a member of the United States Olympic baseball team, had 30 percent of his knee cartilage removed last month, he didn't think he had ''a chance'' to play in the Olympic demonstration games at Dodger Stadium.
description: Gwynn, the brother of the San Diego Padres' Tony Gwynn, the National League's leading hitter, tore the cartilage in an exhibition game July 6 in Memphis and underwent surgery July 13. He began rehabilitation the same day but still missed 17 additional exhibition games.

title: OVERSTATED GAINS IN THE WAR ON HEALTH COSTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Call for Utility Resignations
description: Roger Fischer, chief of the Michigan Public Service Commission staff, has called for the resignation of the chairman of the Consumers Power Company, John Selby, and other top-ranking officials of the utility.

title: MINI-BRAVETTES COME HOME WITHOUT TITLE, BUT SATISFIED
description: The Mini-Bravettes of Brentwood, L.I., headed home from Kansas yesterday without a world softball title. But while they lost, they said, they also won.

title: ROBINSON DISMISSED AS GIANTS' MANAGER
description: Frank Robinson was dismissed early this morning as manager of the San Francisco Giants and replaced by Danny Ozark, the third-base coach. .

title: Samuels to See Chinaglia
description: Howard Samuels, the president of the North American Soccer League, said yesterday he would meet with Giorgio Chinaglia today or tomorrow on the pending transfer of ownership of the Cosmos to Chinaglia and in connection with a plan for indoor competition.

title: A RESPITE FOR FAMILIES OF DISABLED CHILDREN
description: Leaving her 4-year-old son, Sasha, for so much as a day would have been unthinkable to Mary Gyori a year ago. Now she is planning a month's trip to Australia, and she will go with the knowledge that the boy, who is deaf and legally blind, who cannot talk and who seems largely oblivious to the presence of others, will be in capable, caring hands.

title: A MURDERER ESCAPES FROM CAMP IN JERSEY
description: Authorities searched today for a 37- year-old convicted murderer who escaped Saturday night from a minimum-security camp situated outside the walls of Rahway State Prison.

CIRCUS CIRCUS ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HE'S HURDLED INTO HISTORY
description: LOS ANGELESSoon after Edwin Moses breezed through his first qualifying heat in the Olympic 400- meter hurdles last Friday, he was asked if he ever thought about losing.

title: HANDBALL ; ; Denmark Defeats U.S.
description: Undefeated Denmark, led by Klaus Sletting Jensen's 6 goals, beat the United States team handball squad, 19-16, Saturday night in Olympic round-robin competition. The Americans do not have a victory.

title: LOU PINIELLA DAY: HE SALUTES FANS
description: Lou Piniella, who ended his playing career earlier this season and became a full-time coach with the Yankees, saluted his fans yesterday in ''Lou Piniella Day'' ceremonies at the Stadium.

title: Mary Seybold Is Wed To Dr. Jeffrey Kasher
description: Mary Christine Seybold, a doctoral candidate in molecular biophysics and biochemistry at Yale University, and Dr. Jeffrey Steven Kasher, a postdoctoral fellow in the department of human genetics at Yale, were married yesterday in the university's Dwight Chapel. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman and the Rev. Richard E. Nye of the United Church of Christ officiated.

title: CORPORATE PHONE LISTS TO BE AUCTIONED BY MAIL
description: How valuable are the telephone directories of some of the nation's top banks, investment and accounting firms, insurance companies and corporations - especially those that include not only direct office numbers for managers, but also home addresses and phone numbers and, in at least one instance, such data for summer homes?

title: MORELAND SLAM LEADS CUBS
description: Keith Moreland blasted a grand slam in the third inning today to power the Chicago Cubs to a 4-3 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: Yanks Take No. 8 With a One-Hitter
description: The Yankees rolled to their eighth consecutive victory yesterday at Yankee Stadium, beating the Cleveland Indians, 4-0, on one-hit pitching by three hurlers. Vic Mata hit a homer, and Brian Dayett batted in two runs.

title: Iran Says It Is Halting Attacks on Gulf Ships
description: The Iranian Minister for Revolutionary Guards, Haj Mohsen Rafik Dost, said today that Iran would not attack tankers in the Persian Gulf and would not widen the Iran-Iraq war, the official Syrian press agency reported.

title: ; Finn Captures 3d Gold in Single Sculling
description: A towering Finn, Pertti Karppinen, used a devastating closing sprint today to capture his third consecutive Olympic gold medal in the men's single sculling 2,000-meter race, matching a record of supremacy in Olympic rowing's glamour event first set 20 years ago.

title: PERUVIAN DUBIOUS OF HALTING REBELS
description: President Fernando Belaunde Terry says he is pessimistic that the Peruvian Army will be able to make much headway in its new drive against leftist guerrillas in the Andean highlands.

title: Rain Soaks Grain Crop In Northern Ukraine
description: Rainfalls in the northern Ukraine have badly hampered the grain harvest and cut back the flow of processed grain to state silos by more than a third, according to a report published today.
