TINY INSECT THRIVING ON GLACIER BY EVEREST
description: ON a glacier in the high Himalayas, midway between Annapurna and Mount Everest, a Japanese zoologist has found a species of midge that, unlike any other known insect, spends its entire life cycle in the snow and ice of a glacier. Its wings and antennas are short and apparently it cannot fly.

title: FASTER SETTLING OF MASS CLAIMS
PROFIT TAKING EASES PRICES
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday as last week's sharp rise in Treasury note and bond prices was partly reversed when traders began to take profits.

title: Baker Is Seeking 50% of Medford
description: Baker, Fentress & Company told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it plans to raise its stake in the Medford Corporation to 50 percent or more in an apparent effort to block an attempt by the Amalgamated Sugar Company to take control of Medford. Baker, Fentress, a management investment concern based in Chicago, said it intends to increase its Medford holdings ''in order to protect and increase its investment position in, and control of, Medford.''

title: Pact by Chile and Argentina On Border Is Reported Near
description: A Vatican spokesman said today that Chile and Argentina were near agreement on a treaty to end their frontier dispute over the Beagle Channel.

title: ;  A Close Call
description: A private jet carrying Jack Nicklaus , his wife, one of their two sons and a crew of two skidded off a runway Sunday as it landed in a heavy rainstorm at an airport near the small Rocky Mountain town of Eagle, Colo. Neither Nicklaus, who was on his way to Vail to play in the Jerry Ford Invitational starting yesterday, nor anyone else aboard the small jet was injured.

title: TEXTILE RULES JOLT HONG KONG
description: Textile manufacturers and trade officials here are voicing alarm over the decision announced by the Reagan Administration last Friday to tighten textile import regulations.

title: B. ALTMAN SALES MEMO STRESSES VALUE OF SITES
description: B. Altman & Company, which has opened only seven stores in its 119- year history, could be expanded nationally and its store sites offer the potential for ''significant additional value'' if some of the space is converted to offices and other uses, according to a confidential memorandum to prospective buyers.

title: TEST PLANE WEATHERS STORMS TO STUDY LIGHTNING PROBLEM
description: A SPECIALLY protected aircraft meant to be struck by bolts of lightning is helping researchers learn how to protect planes from powerful surges of electricity. It has been flying through a region of Florida that has more thunderstorms than any other area in the nation.

title: BASEBALL ; ; U.S. Advances to Final
description: Oddibe McDowell hit a two-run home run and scored the go-ahead run today to give the United States a 5-2 victory over South Korea, propelling the Americans into the final against Japan.

title: BENOIT GEARS DOWN TO LIFE'S OTHER JOYS
description: The guest list has to be completed, and the critical decisions of who sits next to whom must eventually be considered. Joan Benoit's attire for much of the last four years has consisted of running clothes and shoes, but now there will be a wedding dress to think about. And have you ever tried to purchase the Love stamp issue from the Postal Service in large quantities?

title: Foreign Loans Drop Slightly
description: United States loans to foreign borrowers totaled $352.82 billion in March, a slight drop from the December total, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: Mortgage Bonds For Wisconsin
description: A $125 million issue of single-family mortgage revenue bonds of the Wisconsin Housing and Economic Development Authority was tentatively priced with a maximum yield for interest-paying bonds due in 2006 of 10 5/8 percent.

title: SOLE CHIEF NAMED IN PHIBRO SHIFT
description: Phibro-Salomon Inc., the big Wall Street investment banking and commodity trading house, yesterday announced that, after operating with two chief executives for nearly a year, it had decided to operate with just one.

title: RETIRED REPORTER
description: John C. Devlin, an author and journalist who, during 28 years as a reporter for The New York Times, covered a wide range of stories about nature and conservation, died of cancer July 24 at the Connecticut Hospice in Branford, Conn. He was 73 years old and lived in South Norwalk, Conn.

title: ECONOMIC WARNING AT POPULATION PARLEY
description: The United Nations International Conference on Population opened today with warnings about the role of population in the worldwide struggle for resources and the growing economic disparities between developed and developing nations.

description: TRW Inc. has tentatively agreed to acquire D.A.B. Industries for $12.75 a share, the companies said.

description: Robert W. Frick has been elected vice chairman of the Bank of America and head of its international operations, the bank announced yesterday.

description: There were 39 weeks in the latest 9-month period and 40 weeks in the year-ago 9-month period.

description: The snail darter lost its status as an endangered species today.

title: UNERASE: RESTORER OF THE LOST FILES
description: IT was with some trepidation that I decided last week to erase the disk containing my next column. Such an ultimate test, in the face of a vacation-imposed deadline, of the UnErase feature of the Norton Utilities software package (available at $80 from The Norton Utilities, telephone 213-399-3948) could have my editor beating me over the head. Worse yet, the family could be left wondering what had happened to their summer travels. Nevertheless, the program did claim to be able to resuscitate ''lost'' files. Taking a deep breath, I directed the computer to erase the file labeled T8-14-4.

title: CS in Chapter 11
description: CS Group Inc. said it had filed under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The company, which is based in Dallas, does business under the name Walnut Hill Industries. It is engaged in the design, production and sale of ladies apparel to the retail trade, and the sale of textiles at wholesale.

title: TOPICS ; Hungers ; Sex and Roach at Yale
description: Cockroaches have inhabited earth for hundreds of millions of years. The dinosaurs couldn't crush them, and man hasn't had any luck either.

title: RESORT WEAR FLIRTS WITH BOLDER COLORS
description: The next season for the designers and producers of fashion on Seventh Avenue is resort. The clothes are geared to women who live in the Sun Belt, where cold winters are brief or nonexistent, as well as to Northerners who take midwinter vacations in milder climates. The clothes constitute the biggest collection of warm- weather designs that most designers attempt each year.

title: AMERICAN AGGREGATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: ROCK:BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN IN CONCERT
description: WITH all the excitement swirling about the Jacksons, let us not forget Bruce Springsteen. He did have a No. 1 album this summer, after all, with ''Born in the U.S.A.'' And he is playing to more ticket- buyers in the New York area than the Jacksons or anyone else has ever done in a single engagement - 202,000 of them, to be exact, in 10 long- since-sold-out concerts in the Brendan Byrne Arena in the Meadowlands of his native New Jersey. The first of those concerts was Sunday night, and they continue in pairs, with rest days in between, through Aug. 20.

title: REAGAN AND BUSH OFFER 2 VIEWS ON TAX INCREASE
description: President Reagan today disowned any attempt at ''hedging'' his stated opposition to increases in personal income taxes. while Vice President Bush said later that ''any President would keep options open'' on the question.

PANTASOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 13

description: The Control Data Corporation said a unit, the Arbitron Ratings Company, had signed a letter of intent to acquire a significant minority interest in Burke Marketing Services Inc. Control Data said it will also acquire an option to buy the entire company after five years. Terms were not disclosed.

CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Black Women FormingCoalition for Recognition
description: A group of black women, some of them saying they feel slighted in the wake of the Democratic National Convention, are forming a nonpartisan political caucus to groom, endorse and support candidates.

title: Flexible Adviser
description: Dr. John Anderson, the team psychologist for the American boxers, is an engaging, 40-year-old man who is a Lieutenant Colonel in the Air Force. He is a cadet counselor and associate professor of psychology at the Air Force Academy. Dr. Anderson approaches his job with a sense of humor, and many of the boxers have singled him out for praise.

title: BARRY, R.G. CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 23
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $275,000 reversing a tax credit of $275,000 taken in the first quarter.

description: Terry Schroeder struck for three goals as the United States water polo team beat the Netherlands, 8-7, and kept intact its unbeaten record.

title: PRESIDENTIAL REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including gains of $183,000 for the quarter and $187,000 for the 6 months from the sale of properties and investments and a provision of $245,000 for the quarter and 6 months for losses on investments. c-Including gains of $1,188,000 for the quarter and $1,224,000 for the 6 months from the sale of properties and investments.

title: ;  Buyer's Market
description: J. William Oldenburg , the owner of the Los Angeles Express, says that ''if the right buyer comes along with the right price,'' he might sell all or part of the team as a way to help rebuild his beleaguered financial empire. But he also vows to fight any effort by the United States Football League to take over the club, which he bought for $4.9 million last December.

title: Cabs and City Hall 'Off Duty'
description: There are 11,787 regulated taxicabs in New York City, enough to take an army corps into battle, as the cabs of Paris did in 1914. But they are too few to take people home when they most want to be taken. The difficulty of finding a cab, and the condition of many cabs that can be found, greatly depress the quality of New York life.

title: DEMOCRATS HIT THE ROAD: TICKET WITH NO SCRIPT
description: The script is not finished and the props are not made, but the curtain has gone up nonetheless. The Democratic Presidential campaign has taken to the stage.

title: MENTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Canada Stops Japan
description: Canada, sparked by the hitters Paul Gratton and Garth Pischke, swept past previously unbeaten Japan today to move into medal contention as the United States men clinched a semifinal berth hours before they even took the court. The Canadians defeated Japan, 15-10, 15-8, 15-9, improving their record to 4-1 in Group B play and giving them a shot at finishing first in their pool.

title: U.S. SENDS COPTERS TO HELP REMOVE MINES IN RED SEA
description: Navy mine-sweeping helicopters have been sent to the Red Sea to help Egypt clear the waterway of explosives that have recently damaged commercial ships, Defense Department officials said today.

title: LAUTENBERG BILL SEEKS MORE EDUCATIONAL TV
description: Citing what he said has been a sharp drop in the number of hours of ''productive'' programming for children, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg yesterday introduced a bill that would require television stations to broadcast at least one hour of daily programming ''designed to enhance the education'' of children.

title: AROUND THE NATION ; Egg-Throwing Causes a Bus Walkout
description: Four hours after partial bus service was restored for 20,000 commuters in the ninth day of a transit strike, 15 buses were pulled off city streets today after a driver was pelted by eggs, the police said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bausch & Lomb, Rochester, has elected Stephen P. Kelbley senior vice president-finance.

title: AIR CARGO EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SWIMMING ; ; Slim Lead for U.S. Duet
description: The United States team of Tracie Ruiz and Candie Costie took a narrow lead over Canada and Japan after the first day of synchronized swimming, a new Olympic sport.

title: PADRE PITCHING QUELLS REDS
description: Kevin McReynolds doubled with two out in the top of the ninth and scored on Luis Salazar's single tonight, sending the San Diego Padres to a 1-0 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: DICKENSON MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SENATE APPROVES PENSION MEASURE TO BENEFIT WOMEN
description: The Senate today approved legislation designed to make it easier for women to receive retirement benefits under employee pension plans, either their husbands' or their own.

title: CENTURY PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
18 MORE CHILDREN CITE SEXUAL ABUSE
description: Officials said yesterday that 18 more children had reported being sexually abused at a Bronx day-care center, raising the total to 30.

title: LEADER OF TORIES TAKES CAMPAIGN TO QUEBEC
description: Brian Mulroney, leader of Canada's opposition Progressive Conservative Party, has taken his campaign to his native Quebec in an attempt to reverse the long-standing domination of the province by the governing Liberal Party.

title: DAHLBERG INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Chicago White Sox, twilight-night doubleheader, at Yankee Stadium, 5:35 P.M. The Yankees, still streaking, introduce another young and talented player.

title: NEW PREDICTIONS SEE RISE IN CO2 TRANSFORMING EARTH
description: ANCIENT, gnarled pine trees struggling to survive at timberline in the mountains of Nevada and California have grown surprisingly fat, perhaps presaging momentous changes in the landscape of all the Earth.

title: Accounts
description: * The Instructor Book Club, a division of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, to Peter Vane Advertising.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: BRIGHT colors represent the first big fall trend to emerge from early sales of next season's fashions in New York stores. ''The other trend, the acceptance of men's looks in women's clothes was predictable,'' said Kalman Ruttenstein, a vice president of Bloomingdale's. ''That's because all the important designers were offering mannish styles. But the interest in strong, almost neon, colors was a bit less expected. It has been seen in the sales of the smallest accessories to the biggest coats.''

title: LISTLESS U.S. TEAM GAINS IN BASKETBALL

title: Python Kills Baby in Crib
description: A 10-foot python kept as a family pet escaped from its cage today and strangled an 11-month-old boy in his crib, the authorities said. Police Chief Phil Gates said the infant, Matthew Lloyd, was dead on arrival at a hospital. ''Investigation and evidence indicates,'' Chief Gates, said, ''that the baby was injured by the 10-foot python that had apparently escaped from an enclosure that was in the upstairs part of the house.''

title: India Is Eliminated
description: India, the defending champion, and winner of eight Olympic gold medals, was eliminated from gold-medal contention today when it was held to a scoreless tie by West Germany. The deadlock sent the West Germans into Thursday's semifinals as the Group A runner-up behind Australia, which kept its record perfect with a surprisingly close 2-1 victory over the United States, which has not won a match.

TUESDAY, AUGUST 7, 1984 Markets
description: Continued strong interest in the market brought the volume on the New York Stock Exchange to 203.1 million shares, just off the record of 236.6 million set Friday. A strong surge in the morning that pushed the Dow Jones industrial average up almost 21 points before noon lost its vigor in the afternoon. By the close, the average was up only 0.88 point, at 1,202.96. But stocks that gained in price still outscored losers, 1,093 to 672. One analyst said that the cooling was caused by profit-taking, but said the rally was ''only resting temporarily.'' (Page D1.) The continuation of the unprecedented volume spurred a surge in interest by small investors. Some mutual fund and investment companies reported a doubling of the calls coming in from the public. But the institutions are still doing the major share of trading. (D8.)

Interest on the notes is paid at maturity but is adjusted weekly at three- tenths of a percentage point above the average bond equivalent yield for 91- day Treasury bills set at the Treasury's weekly auctions. At yesterday's auction, the average bond equivalent yield was 10.99 percent.

description: The Giants aren't the only team in their division unsure about a starting quarterback. title: TUESDAY, AUGUST 7, 1984 International
description: Mine-sweeping helicopters will be sent to the Red Sea to help Egypt clear the waterway of explosives that have recently damaged commercial ships, Reagan Administration officials said. At least four helicopters will be sent in response to a request from the Egyptian Government and recommendations of Navy mine-warfare experts, State Department officials said. (Page A1, Column 4.) Contact with Andrei Sakharov's wife in Gorky was reported by friends of the couple after almost three months of silence. They said Yelena G. Bonner, wife of the physicist, reported that her husband was being held at a Gorky hospital, and that she had been formally charged with anti-Soviet activities. (A1:2.)

title: CANADIAN WINS SPRINGBOARD GOLD
description: Sylvie Bernier of Canada knew that she was diving well today, but she did not know how well. Not until the last diver was approaching the 3-meter springboard did Miss Bernier allow her coach to tell her how the standings looked.

title: AMR Sells Planes

AMR said the sale, which was part of a long-range program to make American a stronger freight company, was made necessary by inadequate yields from the aircraft and the carrier's expanding widebody fleet of combination passenger and freight aircraft.

description: A 25-year-old deputy sheriff and former Congressional aide who was shot in the head, apparently by a passing motorist, as he drove along Interstate 95 in Connecticut early Sunday was removed from life-support systems and pronounced dead yesterday.

description: A Federally financed study of more than 800 men who had suffered heart attacks has demonstrated for the first time that counseling to reduce characteristics of ''Type A'' behavior can cut in half the chances of suffering another attack.

The matter is expected to be resolved this week, and to have long-range impact on horse auctions.

title: HIJACKING SEEN A PART OF POLITICAL STRUGGLE IN IRAN
description: Western diplomats and Iranian exiles said today that they believe the hijacking of an Air France jetliner to Teheran last week may have figured in political maneuvering over who will succeed Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;

Under the title ''American Themes,'' the festival will offer 9 plays in 24 performances through Aug. 26.

title: ;  A Free Man The former Knick guard
description: Luther (Ticky) Burden walked out of a Nassau County court in Mineola a free man yesterday after his sentencing for possession of $400, part of the money stolen in a bank robbery four years ago. Judge Edward Baker sentenced the 30-year-old Burden to the two years he had already served in an upstate prison for his conviction of masterminding the holdup, which occurred at the Guardian Bank of North America in Hempstead. That conviction was overturned by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court last January.

The occasion is the forthcoming Philharmonic tour of Asia.

description: The Indiana Pacers are giving about 30 players a chance to make their dreams come true, offering tryouts at what the team calls a ''Walter Mitty camp'' during three days this week. The camp was the idea of the Pacers' new head coach, George Irvine , who said: ''The odds aren't very good of somebody eventually sticking, because it's so competitive to make it in the N.B.A. But it does give these guys an opportunity.'' Opportunity or no, the camp is misnamed, since you have to be something more than a Walter Mitty to even get a shot.

title: F.D.A. APPROVES DRUG TO TREAT TOURETTE SYNDROME
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved the use of a drug to treat Tourette Syndrome, a rare disease that causes involuntary muscular movements and uncontrollable vocal sounds, with a third of its victims involuntarily shouting obscenities.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE IN NEVADA DENIES TAX EVASION
description: Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne denied today that he intentionally filed false tax returns for 1979 and 1980 or that he had concealed a $75,000 loan from the Federal Judicial Ethics Committee.

title: CONCERTS FOR CHILDREN, WITH THE FUTURE IN MIND
description: ''I'm concerned, as anyone would be in my position, for our future,'' said Martin E. Segal, the chairman of Lincoln Center. ''The children are our future, not just as audiences but as citizens and taxpayers. I want them to care about the arts in New York.''

title: EARNINGS ; ;  Tax Benefits Aid Digital Gain
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, the nation's second-largest computer maker, yesterday reported sales and earnings for the year and fourth quarter that were helped by tax benefits but penalized by a $20.4 million write-down of the company's investment in Trilogy Ltd., a company pursuing wafer-scale semiconductor technology.

title: PHILADELPHIA SUBURBAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
200 NAVY MEN OFF FOR GULF OF SUEZ TO COMBAT MINES
description: The Administration sent Navy minesweeping helicopters and about 200 servicemen on their way to the Middle East today to help Egypt rid the Gulf of Suez area of explosives that have damaged commercial shipping.

title: Diving's State of the Art
description: LOS ANGELES Of all the Olympic athletes here, if not all the athletes anywhere, the diver Greg Louganis is arguably better at his sport than the others are at theirs.

title: MCGILL MANUFACTURING CO INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
The Limited Net Up 7%
description: The Limited Inc., which operates a chain of clothing stores, reported today its second-quarter profit rose 7 percent over the 1983 period, on 10.3 percent sales gain. Limited said earnings were $16.9 million, or 28 cents a share, up from $15.8 million, or 26 cents a share. Sales rose to $290.2 million from $263.1 million.

title: ;  Woman Shot Dead In Flatbush Club
description: Gunmen raided a Brooklyn social club at dawn yesterday, killing a woman, wounding a man and and robbing up to a dozen customers.

title: GRADUATES' JOB OUTLOOK
description: New college graduates are receiving salary offers that average about 2.5 percent more than their counterparts were getting a year ago, according to the College Placement Council, but there is little of ''the feverish activity of the boom years 1980-1981.''

title: REAGAN ON THE DEFENSIVE
description: To the surprise of some of his own supporters, President Reagan's re-election campaign has been thrown on the defensive and caught up in uncertain statements and apparent contradictions over the issue of raising taxes to reduce the Federal deficit. Two weeks ago the President's top aides seemed delighted by the unusual statement of Walter F. Mondale that he would raise taxes if elected President. A senior White House official predicted then that Mr. Reagan would easily dismiss the Democratic Presidential nominee's parallel contention that the President would also raise taxes in 1985.

title: SYM-TEK SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 Boys Die as Train Hits Car
description: Two teen-age boys were killed when an Amtrak train struck their car at a crossing after they drove past waiting vehicles and warning lights, the authorities said today. No one on the train, which was bound for Seattle from Chicago, was hurt in the accident in this northwestern Montana town Monday evening. The victims were identified as James M. Sapa and Raymond C. Johnsrud, both 16 years old and both from Columbia Falls.

description: Bradley Pierce owned and managed New York nightclubs for 15 years, staying up all night and living what he remembers as ''a pagan life.''

title: THE CITY ; ;  Columbia Unites Academic Posts
description: Columbia University yesterday announced a reorganization of the leadership of its schools of health sciences, combining what had been separate administrative and academic positions into a single job - dean of the Medical School and vice president for health services.

title: LAW FIRM FILES A COMPLAINT OVER FERRARO FINANCE FORMS
description: A law firm with ties to conservative Republicans accused Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro today of violating the Ethics in Government Act by not providing details of her husband's financial activities since her election to Congress six years ago.

title: CONTINUING PLIGHT OF BROKERS
description: Wall Street brokers may be cheering the record stock volume of recent days, but the sudden rally will hardly cure all the security industry's ills.

description: Islamic Holy War, the group that the Iranian radio says is responsible for laying mines in the Red Sea, is so shadowy that its existence is a matter of debate.

description: At the American Book Awards last year, the poet John Ashbery said there appeared to be about 3,400 Americans who regularly buy poetry and at least 20,000 who write it.

title: DEMAND IS STRONG FOR TREASURY NOTES
description: Buoyed by good investor demand at yesterday's auction of new three-year Treasury notes, prices rose and yields declined in the credit market's yesterday.

title: SOVIET CONTINUES ITS DERISION
description: The Moscow city championship hardly ranks among major Soviet track-and-field meets, yet many a track suit at Lenin Stadium last weekend sported the ''C.C.C.P.'' of Soviet national teams.

title: Schub Recital to Open L.I. Beethoven Festival
description: A recital by the pianist Andre- Michel Schub will open the fifth Beethoven festival next month at the Planting Fields Arboretum, Oyster Bay, L.I. The festival, sponsored by the Friends of the Arts Inc., features three days of outdoor and indoor performances, beginning with Mr. Schub's recital Sept. 7 at 8 P.M. His program will consist of three piano sonatas - Op. 31, No. 2; Op. 27, No. 2 and Op. 57 - and Variations in C Minor.

title: BRIGHTER VIEW OF U.S. TRADE
description: Has the United States lost its ability to compete in world markets? With the American foreign trade deficit having ballooned to an annual rate of $103.8 billion during the first half of this year, far above last year's record total of $61.1 billion, worries persist that the sudden surge of optimism on Wall Street is ignoring the persistent troubles of the real economy.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Chicago White Sox, at Yankee Stadium, 1 P.M. Phil Niekro, fresh from Atlanta ceremonies in which his Braves uniform jersey was retired Monday night, goes after victory No. 14.

description: Legislation to get more doctors and dentists to serve the poor by increasing their Medicaid fees was signed into law today by Governor Cuomo.

description: BUYING kitchen equipment is a bit like buying clothes: spending a little more for quality at the outset usually pays off in the long run.

title: BONN LIMITS EXPORT OF CHEMICAL-ARMS MATERIALS
description: West Germany agreed today to restrict the export of chemical manufacturing equipment that can be used to make chemical weapons, the Government announced.

description: Attorney General William French Smith's sensitivity has increased recently, but not enough to put duty ahead of ceremonial or political errands.

title: ON 'REAL' PEOPLE AND CREDIBILITY
description: a year ago, a Nashville socialite, Eugenia Wimberly Fort Hooker, was busy working as a professional interior decorator. This month, Mrs. Hooker, who is known as Tish, appears in advertisements for the Germaine Monteil Cosmetiques Corporation as a ''real'' over-40 woman.

title: Michigan General Bid by Investor
description: Robert Verratti, an investor in Radnor, Pa., told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he intended to begin preliminary discussions with the Michigan General Corporation regarding a possible business combination.

title: PRESS FOR PHILIPPINE REFORMS
description: A year after the assassination of opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the Philippines is in the midst of its most severe economic and political crisis in decades. Yet the attention focused on the vast capital flight and foreign debt burden, the May parliamentary elections and the investigation of the Aquino assassination has obscured a development that may have far more significant long-term consequences for that country and for America's position in Asia: the rapidly expanding strength of the Communist-dominated New People's Army.

title: MONDALE EASES PLEDGE TO DISMISS REAGAN RIGHTS PANEL APPOINTEES
description: Walter F. Mondale is backing away from a vow he made in the primary campaign to dismiss President Reagan's appointees to the United States Commission on Civil Rights. Aides to Mr. Mondale clarified his intentions today.

title: Liberian Official Killed
description: Liberia's Assistant Foreign Minister, Todd Tuwa, and five others aboard a twin-engined Beechcraft airplane died last Saturday when the plane crashed near the Ghanaian border, airline sources said today. The private plane was on a flight from Monrovia to Abidjan.

title: PRICE CLOUD OVER ALUMINUM
description: For the aluminum industry, a potent recovery has been checked this summer by an unexpected tumble in prices.

title: Beatrice-Esmark
description: The Beatrice Companies said it had completed its $2.7 billion acquisition of Esmark Inc., making it the world's largest food and consumer products company.

title: 57 Are Charged by U.S. In 2-Year Drug Inquiry
description: The authorities today announced a crackdown on an international ring they said shipped 54 tons of illicit methaqualone to the United States.

title: EMERSON ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
E.P.A. Balks at Pollution Curb
description: Cancer-causing air pollution produced by burning wood, oil and coal will not be regulated until experts understand the hazards, despite evidence that they may kill hundreds of Americans a year, the Environmental Protection Agency said Monday.

title: UGANDA REPORTED TO BAR A U.S. AIDE
description: Uganda reportedly suspended a United States military aid program today and barred an American colonel from visiting the country in response to criticism by the Reagan Administration about human rights abuses.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am pleased to report that the higher revenue base indicated in the revised projections strengthens our hope for a future tax cut.'' - Governor Cuomo. (A1:6.)

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Jackson Asks for Veto Of Carolina Redistricting
description: In his first foray into state politics since moving his residency to his native state, the Rev. Jesse Jackson has asked Gov. Richard Riley of South Carolina to veto a proposed State Senate reapportionment plan.

HATFIELD'S EXPLANATION OF PAYMENTS DISPUTED
description: Former associates of Basil Tsakos, a Greek entrepreneur who paid $40,000 to the wife of Senator Mark O. Hatfield, have given the Senate Ethics Committee sworn statements disputing the Senator's explanations for the payment, according to other former associates of Mr. Tsakos.

title: SEBASTIAN BRAGGIOTTI
description: Sebastian Braggiotti, who appeared on the Broadway stage and on tour from the 1920's to the 1950's, died in a nursing home in York Harbor, Me., on July 29. He was 80 years old.

title: Eye on the Clock
description: Although a decision has not yet been reached, a plan is being considered by officials of the L.A.O.O.C. to establish a cutoff time for the men's marathon on Sunday under which stragglers in the field of 115 entrants would not be allowed to finish the 26- mile 385-yard race on the track of the Coliseum.

title: Steeler Criticizes Stoudt
description: Robin Cole, the veteran Pittsburgh linebacker, says the Steelers should be a better team this season than last because Cliff Stoudt is no longer their quarterback. ''Our leader at quarterback I don't think had the mental capabilities,'' Cole said.

title: Rockwell Contract
description: The Rockwell International Corporation has received a $323 million contract for guidance and control assembly systems for the MX missile, the Air Force said. It said work would be performed at the company's facilities in Anaheim and Santa Monica, Calif.; Lisbon, Me.; Tulsa, Okla.; Clearwater, Fla.; Huntsville, Ala.; Windsor Locks, Conn.; Denver, and Broadview, Ill. The Pentagon is to build 100 of the intercontinental ballistic missiles for about $20 billion, with the first 10 to be deployed in December 1986.

title: Louganis Gains In Springboard
description: Greg Louganis of Mission Viejo, Calif., appearing at the top of his form in his bid for a sweep of the Olympic diving gold medals, today built an overwhelming lead in winning the preliminary phase of the springboard competition.

title: Conferees on Alien Bill Named
description: The Senate tonight appointed seven members to serve on a conference committee to reconcile differences with the House on a comprehensive immigration bill.

title: Vladimir Tendryakov, Russian Rural Writer
description: Vladimir F. Tendryakov, a Soviet author who was occasionally criticized for depicting the seamy side of rural life, has died, the newspaper Pravda reported today. He was 60 years old.

title: EPIDERMIOLOGY EXPERT WAS 63
description: Dr. Abraham M. Lilienfeld, a teacher and leader in the field of epidemiology, died of a heart attack Monday in a Baltimore railroad station. He was 63 years old.

Esther Phillips, 48, Is Dead; A Rhythm-and-Blues Singer
description: The blues singer Esther Phillips, who got her start with Johnny Otis and was acknowledged by the Beatles as a major innovator of rock, died today in U.C.L.A.-Harbor Medical Center in Torrance, Calif. She was 48 years old and had been ill for some time.

title: Intense Fighting Reported in Afghanistan
description: Warplanes bombed villages in northern Afghanistan, leaving up to 300 civilians dead, and Moslem guerrillas killed nearly 200 Soviet and Afghan troops in a third week of intense fighting, Western diplomats said today.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; U.S. Says Soviet Press May Cover G.O.P. Parley
description: The State Department says it will not bar Soviet diplomats and journalists from observing the Republican National Convention in Dallas this month even though Dallas is usually off limits to Soviet citizens.

title: METS ARE BEATEN TWICE
description: For six tumultuous hours before a standing-room crowd of 39,271 fans in Wrigley Field, the Mets and the Chicago Cubs waged their battle for first place today with big innings, knockdown pitches and one team fight. And when it all subsided, the Cubs had swept a doubleheader from the Mets for the second time in 10 days and plunged them 3 1/2 games into second place.

title: FAMILY PLANNING: GLOBAL AID URGED
description: The president of the World Bank said today that quadrupling financial aid for family planning programs to $2 billion annually could make a ''vast difference'' in slowing the world's population growth.

description: A member of the West German counterintelligence service, who failed in his attempts to sell sensitive material to East Germany, was sentenced today to a year's probation for spying.

description: A tiny rubber-glove company has won another round in a 23-year legal battle with Johnson & Johnson.

title: TRIUMPH AND DEFEAT FOR AMERICAN WOMEN; SOUTH KOREA TROUNCED
description: The United States, with its main competition at home in the Soviet Union, easily won its first gold medal in women's basketball tonight, defeating South Korea, 85-55.

title: ECHO BAY MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PANEL QUESTIONS DEFENSES AGAINST ENERGY SURGE IN A NUCLEAR BLAST
description: A scientific panel said today that it was ''uncomfortable'' with some of the military's methods of shielding electrical equipment against the vast pulse of electromagnetic energy that would follow high-altitude nuclear blasts.

title: Communities Gear Up For Protest on Crime By The Associated Press
description: Hundreds of communities in 20 states geared up yesterday to take to the streets after dark in a ''National Night Out'' against crime, with outdoor block parties, concerts and citizen patrols designed to show criminals that people were fed up with being afraid.

title: WHITE SOX SNAP YANKEES' STREAK AT 8
description: LaMarr Hoyt needed a weather break to correct his pitching problems in the first game of the doubleheader at Yankee Stadium last night, but Ron Guidry didn't encounter any problems in the second game. Guidry, in fact, dazzled the Chicago White Sox by striking out 13 as the Yankees won the second game, 7-0.

title: Sonoma Debt
description: Sonoma Vineyards said termination of a limited partnership sale and a high debt burden may force it to consider voluntary filing for reorganization if it cannot work out an interim plan with its creditors.

title: STOCKS ERRATIC AS PACE SLOWS
description: Fearful that last week's sharp rise in stock prices may not endure, large numbers of investors either stayed on the sidelines or cashed in their stock for profit yesterday. The result was that share prices moved up and down like a yo-yo, and trading volume slowed markedly from its recent furious pace.

title: KAPPA NETWORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Jackson Suspended
description: Reggie Jackson of the California Angels, that most flamboyant of long- ball hitters, was suspended yesterday for two games by Bobby Brown, the American League's president, because of an incident that led to a different kind of slugging. The suspension takes effect Saturday, unless Jackson asks a hearing, and the Angels said no decision had been made on whether to request one.

title: MSA REALTY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company commenced active operations on April 4, 1984.

title: GREEK OIL TANKER ATTACKED BY IRAQ
description: Iraqi planes attacked and damaged a Greek tanker today about 30 miles south of Kharg Island, the Iranian oil terminal in the Persian Gulf. It was the first attack on neutral shipping in nearly a month.

title: TESTIMONY ON BETTING OPENS TRIFECTA HEARING
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board's hearing on four harness drivers accused of keeping their horses from finishing in the money at Monticello Raceway began yesterday with testimony concerning the technicalities of parimutuel wagering.

title: 2.8% Swiss Inflation Rate
description: Consumer price inflation held steady at an annual rate of 2.8 percent in July for the second consecutive month, the Federal Office of Industry, Trade and Labor said today. The agency said the figure for June and July compares with annual rates of 2.9 percent in May, 3.2 percent in April and 3.4 percent in March.

title: TECHNALYSIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
In ABC's Corner
description: Eyup Can of Turkey scored an upset in yesterday's boxing competition when he defeated Yong Mo Heo of South Korea in a flyweight bout. At least it was an upset according to Howard Cosell, who has been touting the Korean on ABC.

title: Arthur Bramford Dies at 71; Retired Securities Evaluator
description: Arthur J. Bamford, retired regional director of Management Planning Inc. in Princeton, N.J., a securities evaluation concern, died of a heart attack July 30 at a hospital in Miami. He was 71 years old and lived in Key Biscayne, Fla., and Bronxville.

title: U.S. PACT ON TESTING OF CHIPS
description: The Defense Logistics Agency yesterday said it had reached an agreement with the National Semiconductor Corporation, which was convicted in March of violating Federal rules for testing electronic chips for military equipment, that will insure that such tests are made in the future.

title: Distillers Co. To Shut 2 Units
description: Britain's biggest whiskey maker today announced the closing of two of its eight whiskey plants in Scotland in an effort to increase efficiency in the face of fierce foreign competition.

title: OLYMPICS A SUCCESS IN RATINGS FOR ABC
description: At its halfway point, by most accountings, ABC seems to have had a stunning success in its broadcast of the 1984 Olympic Games. The ratings are good, advertising is just about sold out, and the network's division has delighted even its competitors with its coverage.

title: IRAN LAUDS SHIP ATTACKS BUT DENIES ROLE
description: Iran expressed praise today for the recent attacks on commercial ships in the Red Sea and said mines had been sown there by the same Moslem extremist group that took responsibility for the bombing of the United States Marine garrison in Beirut last October. But it denied Government involvement in the attacks.

description: Walter F. Mondale, who has proposed six nationally televised debates with President Reagan, today teasingly suggested a seventh one, between Mr. Reagan and Vice President Bush.

description: Daniel Ortega Saavedra, leader of the Nicaraguan junta, said Monday night that the Government would relax press censorship, restore the right to strike and allow people to petition the courts for release from jail.

title: Seattle Officer Skeptical Of Slaying Confessions
description: The man who heads the police investigation into the 26 known murders attributed to the ''Green River killer'' said today that he doubted the statements of two prisoners in San Francisco that they abducted, raped and killed at least 11 of the women in a three-month Seattle area crime spree in 1983. The two are in jail in on unrelated charges.

title: A Wasteful Mortgage Lottery
description: Want to save up to $4,000 a year on home mortgage bills? So do tens of thousands of other first- time home buyers who this week lined up at banks across New York State to apply for loans at four percentage points below the going rate. But there's a catch: Only about 3,500 loans will be available, first come, first served. So most of the people who camped in line for days waited in vain.

title: CRAMPED THEATER CLUB SEEKS CITY CENTER SITE
description: In an attempt to both widen its audience and shore up its finances, the Manhattan Theater Club is negotiating to move its main stage from the current 150-seat theater on East 73d Street to a 300-seat venue in City Center, 131 West 55th Street.

title: Transcontinental
description: The Transcontinental Energy Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent with investors associated with Schottenstein Stores under which they would acquire a majority stake in Transcontinental. The agreement calls for the investors to attempt a restructuring of Transcontinental's debt outstanding, both secured and unsecured. On the American Stock Exchange today, Transcontinental closed at 50 cents, off 12.5 cents.

title: Giants' Coach Is Harder to Please Now
description: Football coaches own all the formal manuals that ordain the ultimate strategies in everything from practice drills to trick plays. And some act as if they also have an unofficial guide to coaching, which must include one of the profession's classic cliches: ''React to losing one way, and one way only: get tough.''

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY: The concert in Central Park had just ended and the crowd began to disperse and head for the streets. Our group, which included two tots in strollers and two elderly women, decided it would be prudent to stick to the paths. The usual bottleneck ensued and foot traffic in the tunnel linking the Great Lawn with the western perimeter of the Metropolitan Museum of Art was at a standstill. The tunnel was hot and airless. It was late, we were tired, tempers were frayed. There were people end to end and side to side and none of us were moving. There was a good deal of pushing, pointlessly of course: There simply was no way to hurry the stalled flow of humanity. The situation had the potential for ugliness.

title: MOSTLY MOZART COMMISSIONA LEADS SALIERI OVERTURE
description: THE allegations in ''Amadeus'' to the contrary, Antonio Salieri definitely did not poison Mozart. There may have been some collegial rivalry between the two composers, but it was kept within the bounds of decency; therefore, it was not inappropriate for Monday's Mostly Mozart program in Avery Fisher Hall to begin with Salieri's overture to the opera ''Axur, re d'Ormus.'' This clattering energetic work, punctuated every few seconds with a cymbal crash or two, made a propulsive curtain-raiser, and Sergiu Comissiona conducted the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra with vigorous authority.

description: The Soviet press said today that an American Marine consulate guard reported beaten in Leningrad was detained by the police because he was rowdy and drunk, and it accused the United States of using the incident to ''scare Americans away from traveling to the U.S.S.R.''

title: WHAT PRICE MANHATTAN SKYLINE SYMMETRY?
description: To the Editor:

title: CALIFORNIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $806,000 on the sale of real estate investments. c-Includes a gain of $127,000 from the sale of real estate investments.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
PLATES FOR SWITCHES IN UNUSUAL SIZES
description: FOR those who care about hardware details and prefer an alternative to plastic, Baldwin Brass Manufacturers makes a group of unusual wall plates designed to give switches and outlets an elegant look. Several new items will be added to the line in late August.

title: UNITED WESTBURNE INDUSRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Putting the Shot On Lighter Side
description: The world record for the men's shot-put is 72 feet 10 3/4 inches, set last June by Udo Beyer of East Germany. Augie Wolf, who will represent the United States Saturday in the Olympic shot-put, reached 75 feet last Friday in a workout.

title: Two Brokers Suspended
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday suspended two stockbrokers for fraudulently selling stock in the World Gambling Corporation, which said it was trying to open a casino in Atlantic City.

title: RALLY CHANGES SOME OPINIONS
description: THE explosive rally in stock prices last week

title: Occupational Hazard
description: Whether it was ironic or deserved, the Urban Mass Transportation Administrator and his party arrived almost an hour late in New York City last Monday.

title: SOVEREIGN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a tax charge of $6,425 for the quarter and a tax credit of $100,575, or 1 cent a share, for the 6 months. c-Including a gain of $49,246, or 1 cent a share, from realized investments.

title: MUSIC: ALICIA DE LARROCHA PRESENTS A MOZART RECITAL
description: ALICIA DE LARROCHA, elegant as ever, played a recital of Mozart's piano music Tuesday in Avery Fisher Hall. All that was missing was something to prod the vivid, capricious side of her playing into action.

title: U.S. Sailors Win 2 Golds, 4 Silvers
description: American yachtsmen took two gold medals and four silvers in Olympic yachting today to add to a gold won the day before. The results, any of which could change if protests are filed, gave the United States a gold or silver medal in each of the seven classes of Olympic yachting.

title: MOVING? IT'S WISE TO RESERVE EARLY
description: Customarily, June through September is the peak season for household moves - and for the packing, the planning and the angst that accompany them. Americans who are moving this summer face more than the usual share of frustrations. Industry spokesmen call this the busiest moving season in memory, and many interstate van lines are booked a month in advance.

title: Dr. Daniel Merriman Is Dead; Ex-Marine Biologist at Yale
description: Dr. Daniel Merriman, a retired professor of biology at Yale University and a noted marine biologist, died Monday at his home in Bethany, Conn.

title: SHAWN RESPONDS IN 3 PAGES
description: A couple wrote to The New Yorker

title: Argentine Mutiny Ends
description: SAN MIGUEL DE TUCUMAN, Argentina, Aug. 8 (Reuters) - About 600 policemen surrendered to federal forces today after an eight-day mutiny over pay, the official press agency Telam said. The agency said the mutiny ended without violence after provincial government officials talked with policemen inside the barricaded police headquarters.

title: MARITIME TELEGRAPH & TELEPHONE CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HERS
description: I WAS out in the woods early in the morning

title: F.C.C. STOPS REGULATING COMMERCIAL SATELLITES
description: The Federal Communications Commission deregulated the nation's commercial satellite operators today, concluding that the market was sufficiently competitive to justify an end to reviews of customer rates.

title: Judge Testifies At Racing Inquiry
description: Anthony Stellone, who was the presiding judge of racing at Monticello Raceway on July 1, testified yesterday that he believed that four harness drivers in the 11th race on that date gave less than their best efforts.

title: ITT Discounts Long Distance SECAUCUS, N.J., Aug. 8
description: (Reuters) - The ITT Corporation said its Communications

title: CHICAGO PNEUMATIC TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain from certain foreign tax credits of $178,000. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $1,868,000 for the quarter and $2,665,000 for the 6 months. Year-ago results are reclassified to reflect the discontinuance of the drill business.

title: John Little, 77, Artist;Owned Fabrics Studio
description: John Little, an abstract expressionist artist who founded a New York company that made fabrics and wallpaper with designs inspired by abstract expressionism, died July 30 at his home in East Hampton, L.I., after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

title: DRUG DEFENDANT RULED COMPETENT
description: A defendant in a narcotics case who is reported to have tried to kill himself in jail is competent to stand trial, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: Don't Divert the Superfund
description: A lawyer's dream of paradise is said to be that everyone is resurrected and sues to claim his property back from his descendants. The House risks creating a close terrestrial equivalent in its revision of the Superfund law regulating the cleanup of abandoned toxic dump sites.

title: Required Reading; Rebuilding Cities
description: Representative William J. Coyne, Democrat of Pennsylvania, in his July report to constituents:

title: Mississippian Weighs Independent Senate Bid
description: Johnnie Walls says he could win as an independent candidate for a United States Senate seat from Mississippi but will wait before deciding whether to enter the race ''as a Democrat who has been locked out.''

title: THERMAL PROFILES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BEIRUT ACTS TO SEND ARMY TO SHUF AND KEY ROADS
description: Prime Minister Rashid Karami announced today that the Government had agreed on compromise peace steps to put army units into disputed Shuf mountain areas and astride the country's two major highways.

title: Jersey Utility Proxy Ruling
description: Striking down a state merger law that was passed on the eve of a proxy contest, a Federal judge today ordered a new shareholders' election in a takeover battle between two New Jersey natural gas holding companies.

title: KRAUSKOPF QUITS AS THE CITY'S CHIEF OF SOCIAL SERVICES
description: The head of New York City's Human Resources Administration resigned yesterday, saying that widespread criticism of his performance had crippled the agency's effectiveness.

title: HIGH RATES, SMALL INSTITUTIONS
description: One of the latest challenges to the New York banks for the consumer's long-term savings dollar has come from a two-story, shoebox of a building on 25th Street in this shorefront community. The building sits between Atlantic and Pacific Avenues, a fitting location for a savings and loan that sees itself serving a coast- to-coast market.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. The Mets, having been roughed up in Chicago, send out Bruce Berenyi to try to turn things around as they open a four-game series against Pittsburgh. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Chicago White Sox, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. A matchup of opposites: Tom Seaver, 11-6 in his comeback year with the White Sox, against Dennis Rasmussen, who is 6-3 as he tries to launch a successful career with the Yanks. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Golf

title: Mancini Fights Sept. 8
description: Ray Mancini, who took a bad beating recently in losing the World Boxing Association's lightweight crown to Livingstone Bramble, is ready to try again. An announcement from New Orleans by Barry Mendelson, a promoter there, said that Mancini had agreed to fight Kenny Bogner on Sept. 8 at a 5.500-seat amphitheater on the grounds of the World's Fair.

title: Continental Illinois Asset-Cut Plan
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation said yesterday that it was preparing a formal plan for the Federal Reserve Board for reducing its assets and restricting its future growth.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Caterpillar Choice Seen as Next Chief
description: George A. Schaefer has been named vice chairman of the Caterpillar Tractor Company, the company said yesterday.

title: Murder Confessions Called Hoax by Police
description: One of two jail inmates who sought out reporters to confess murdering several young women in Oregon and Washington now says it was a lie and part of an escape plot, the authorities said today.

title: 60 Child Custody Cases Dismissed in Vermont
description: A judge today dismissed all but eight cases in which Vermont officials sought custody of 112 children from a sect whose disciplinary practices were alleged to be abusive toward the youths.

title: British Banks Cut Base Rate
description: Britain's three largest banks today reduced their base lending rates half a percentage point, reflecting an unexpected drop in the British money supply last month.

title: Fort Howard Promotes Executive to President
description: Donald H. De Meuse has been elected president of the Fort Howard Paper Company.

title: Neo-Nazi Kills Jew in France
description: A 19-year-old neo-Nazi who confessed to killing a 75-year-old woman told the police he did it because she was Jewish, the police said today.

title: U.S. Rivals Shooting 1-2
description: Darrell Pace of the United States took the lead, and his longtime American rival, Rich McKinney, was second on the opening day of men's Olympic archery today.

title: VETERANS SPEAK OUT ON AGENT ORANGE
description: In camouflage fatigues and pin- striped business suits, veterans of the Vietnam War flocked to a Federal courtroom in Brooklyn yesterday to speak out on the proposed $180 million settlement of the Agent Orange lawsuit.

title: WEST GERMANS GAIN FINAL
description: Erhard Wunderlich scored 9 goals today as West Germany advanced to the championship game against Yugoslavia by beating Denmark, 20-18, in the Olympic men's team handball competition.

title: CONNECTICUT OPENS BRIDGE REPAIR BIDS
description: Connecticut opened bids today for the first project in its three- year, $727 million program for repairing 520 bridges.

title: ADVANCED COMPUTER TECHIQUES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $88,000.

title: EFFORT TO DETER ABUSE STARTS IN WESTCHESTER
description: Westchester County today announced the start of a program to deter incidents of the sexual abuse of children.

title: LEWIS WINS 3D GOLD IN U.S. 200-METER SWEEP
description: Carl Lewis won his third gold medal tonight in the Games of the XXIII Olympiad, and he had company on the victory stand. Lewis, Kirk Baptiste and Thomas Jefferson finished first, second and third in the men's 200-meter final, giving the United States the first such sweep in track and field in these Olympics.

title: Shift at Spectra-Physics
description: Spectra-Physics Inc. said Samuel D. Colella will resign on Aug. 31 as president and chief operating officer. Mr. Colella's duties will be assumed by Herbert M. Dwight Jr., who continues as chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Colella has served as chief operating officer since 1981. Based in San Jose, Calif., Spectra- Physics makes lasers for scientific, industrial and commercial applications and laser- beam systems for construction alignment, agricultural machine control and contract research.

title: PRODUCTS TO ASSIST THE GARDENER
description: Some new products may help lighten the gardener's tasks.

title: LIVING AT THE BEACH IN ONE ENORMOUS ROOM
description: FROM the beginning, Michael Kooper had provided all the design cues. ''I didn't want a beach house that was in any way like an apartment,'' he explained. ''I had always wanted to live in a loft. And what could be better than living in a big open space on the ocean? ''

title: NIEKRO ROUTED IN 5-RUN THIRD
description: Earlier this week, the Atlanta Braves retired Phil Niekro's number. The Yankees hope American League teams aren't retiring Niekro's knuckler.

title: Page of Colonial Charter Stolen in Massachusetts
description: Someone pried open a display case at the Statehouse Archive today and stole the first page of Massachusetts' original colonial charter, granted by King Charles I in 1629, the capitol police said today.

title: HANDY & HARMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Corsaro 'Carmen' on PBS
description: Frank Corsaro's New York City Opera production of Bizet's ''Carmen'' will be televised on Public Broadcasting Service's ''Live From Lincoln Center'' on Wednesday, Sept. 26 at 8 P.M. The performance will be simulcast over WNCN-FM. The cast will include Victoria Vergara as Carmen, Jacque Trussel as Don Jose, and Robert Hale as Escamillo.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Dr. Abraham Lilienfeld yesterday omitted some survivors and the surname of his daughter. He had seven grandchildren. His daughter is Julie L. Meister.

title: ENERGAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Comparative year-ago results are not available because the company was spun off from the Pioneer Corp. in October 1983. Year-to-date results are for the period beginning Oct. 19, 1983.

title: 19 in Grenada Face Trial In Slayings
description: A Grenada magistrate ordered 19 former Government and army officials today to stand trial in the slayings of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop and seven supporters.

title: Politicards
description: For collectors of political

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: COMPUTERS are increasingly important in everyday life, and now they are gaining a role in the home workshop. New electronic power tools from Sears, Roebuck & Company and computer-designed electric drills from Black & Decker provide greater control than ever, along with increased versatility and easier handling.

title: SATELLITE DISH VIES WITH CABLE
description: Contrary to widespread belief, the hottest item in video is not the video cassette recorder. Though VCR sales are increasing rapidly, their rate of growth is currently exceeded by what is without doubt the most exotic and futuristic of all video items - the satellite dish.

title: CHEM-TRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MONDALE VOWS CHANGE IN PANEL ON CIVIL RIGHTS
description: Walter F. Mondale pledged today to ''restructure'' the United States Commission on Civil Rights and said again that he would dismiss all appointees named to the panel by President Reagan.

title: THUNANDER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DOMINION TEXTILE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Montreal and Toronto stock exchanges.

title: ITT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CASINO AGENCY BARS 4 MORE MEN
description: Four reputed crime figures were barred from casinos here today.

title: A.T.& T.-Canada Link
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company asked permission today to extend its domestic video-conferencing service to Canada. The company, in a filing with the Federal Communications Commission, said it had reached an agreement with Canadian telephone companies that would allow its customers to establish video conferences between 23 American cities and such Canadian cities as Montreal, Toronto, Ottawa, Quebec, Vancouver, Calgary and Edmonton.

title: UNITED BRANDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sri Lanka Forces Battle Tamil Separatists
description: Government forces battled two groups of Tamil separatists who attacked a police station and blew open a bank in northern Sri Lanka today, the police said.

title: THE CITY;
description: Two holdup men took an estimated $1 million worth of diamonds from a company in the diamond district yesterday, but one suspect was caught before he got out of the building.

title: THURSDAY, AUGUST 9, 1984 International
description: The key to curbing births is the development of free-market economies, according to the Reagan Administration. Its new population policy was presented at an international population conference in Mexico City by James L. Buckley, the president of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty and chief of the United States delegation. (Page A1, Column 6.) Carl Lewis won his third gold medal at the Games of the XXIII Olympiad. Lewis, Kirk Baptiste and Thomas Jefferson finished first, second and third in the men's 200-meter final, giving the United States the first such sweep of track and field medals at these Olympics. (A1:2-4.)

title: New York Book Fair Scheduled Sept. 1-3
description: More than 200 small noncommercial publishers will display and sell their wares at the 10th New York Book Fair, Sept. 1, 2 and 3 in the Exhibition Rotunda of Madison Square Garden. Admission is free.

title: Sloop Is First
description: The sloop Boomerang was the first overall finisher and the first in Class A on corrected time in the third race of the Pan Am Clipper Cup series today. The 150-mile, Oahu-Molokai-Oahu race began Monday night.

title: HOME BEAT
description: WITH their high sides and small square windows, the chairs look slightly like a confessional.

title: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net realized losses on investments of $19,908,000 for the quarter and $3,738,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes net realized gains on investments of $5,872,000 for the quarter and $2,568,000 for the 6 months.

title: Comings and Goings The Vancouver Canucks completed a trade in which they acquired
description: Rob McClanahan by dealing Dave (Tiger) Williams to the Detroit Red Wings yesterday. Williams, a tenacious left wing, holds the National Hockey League's record for penalty minutes, with 2,994. . . . Mike Barber, the veteran tight end of the Los Angeles Rams, underwent surgery on a torn knee ligament and will be out about six weeks. .

description: Results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Bio-Med Devices in May 1984.

title: Maree Is Out of 1,500 Run
description: Sydney Maree, the South African- born runner who obtained his United States citizenship just four months ago, has withdrawn from the Olympic 1,500-meter race because of a hamstring injury, the United States Olympic Committee said today.

title: Jackson Penalty Eased
description: Bobby Brown, the American League's president, has decided that Reggie Jackson's role in an on-the- field brawl July 21 was not quite so villainous as originally thought.

title: A GARDEN PARTY IN HELL'S KITCHEN
description: Hell's Kitchen Garden Party, Clinton

title: The U.N. Today
description: Aug. 9, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: NCR-Universal
description: Universal Money Centers Inc. said it had reached an understanding in principle under which it would purchase 500 automatic teller machines from the NCR Corporation and NCR would own part of Universal. Payment for the machines will be half in cash and half in Universal stock, the company said, giving NCR about a 12 percent stake in the company. Universal said it would place the machines in retail locations and financial institutions as part of its program to expand its national network.

title: Quality Care
description: Quality Care Inc. said it had ended talks on its purchase by one company but had recently acquisition talks with another. Quality Care, based in Rockville Center, L.I., did not identify which companies were involved, but said that the latest talks were in the preliminary stage and that no offer had been made. The company provides health-care services to patients at home.

title: SUGARLOAF MOUNTAIN RESORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Florida Bank Sales
description: First Florida Bank Inc. said it had agreed to acquire the First Bank and Trust Co. of Belleair Bluffs, Fla., and the First Gulf Beach Bank and Trust Co. of St. Petersburg Beach, Fla., for about $31.7 million. First Florida, based in Tampa, said the two banks have total assets of $205 million. The acquisition requires regulatory approval and is expected to be compleated early next year, First Florida said.

title: Young & Rubicam GetsMore Nynex Business
description: Young & Rubicam has been awarded the Nynex Business Information Systems account.

title: NEGOTIATIONS APPARENTLY STALLED IN HOSPITAL STRIKE
description: The renewed negotiations initiated by Governor Cuomo in New York City's hospital and nursing-home strike apparently stalled yesterday.

title: PROJECTED PAY OF POSTAL EXECUTIVES BRINGS PROTEST
description: A spokesman for the American Postal Workers Union today protested that the Postal Service, which wants to freeze the wages of clerks, mail handlers and letter carriers, has projected increses averaging 8.1 percent for the agency's postmasters and supervisors.

title: H.R.A. RESIGNATIONS: A QUESTION OF RESPONSIBILITY
description: Yesterday morning, just a few hours before he accepted the resignation of James A. Krauskopf as head of the Human Resources Administration, Mayor Koch complained to reporters about what he felt was the unfairness of recent attacks on people who run the city's welfare bureaucracy. In a reference to Gail M. Kong, who resigned under pressure Tuesday as administrator of city programs for abused and neglected children, Mr. Koch said: ''I weep for her. What did she do? She gave everything possible to this city. She can't guarantee that 35,000 people out there aren't going to abuse their children.''

title: PACIFICORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss after a provision of $82 million for a terminated nuclear power plant. The company was formerly Pacific Power & Light.

title: IRAN JET HIJACKING IS ENDED IN ROME
description: Two Iranian teen-agers, said to have identified themselves as opponents of the Teheran Government, freed about 300 hostages from a hijacked Iranian airliner and surrendered to the police here today.

title: THURSDAY, AUGUST 9, 1984 The Economy
description: The President, if re-elected, won't try to combine a tax rise with changes in tax structuring, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan told a Congressional panel. In ruling out a tax increase in 1985, he said a balanced budget could be achieved by the end of the decade from additional revenues generated by a steadily growing economy and less Government spending. The Administration revised its forecast of economic growth from the fourth quarter of 1983 to the end of 1984 to 6.5 percent, from the April estimate of 5 percent. (Page A1.)

title: SHARDS OF SOLIDARITY: PUTTING THEM TOGETHER AGAIN
description: With more and more hard-core Solidarity activists being freed under the terms of a sweeping Government amnesty, Poland's outlawed trade union movement is finding it even more difficult to unify and reorganize its ranks. For one thing, it has all but lost its rallying cry, the demand to free political prisoners. For another, Solidarity has sprouted separate and potentially contentious branches since it was banned and its leaders were imprisoned.

title: TAPING OF TESTIMONY ALLOWED IN SEX CASES
description: Children who are the victims of sex crimes will be allowed to give videotaped testimony to grand juries under a bill signed today by Governor Cuomo.

title: CENTRAL VERMONT PUBLIC SERVICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DANCE: CUNNINGHAM AT JACOB'S PILLOW FESTIVAL
description: Liz Thompson, director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, wisely refrained from trying to explain Merce Cunningham to a relatively new audience when the company opened there Tuesday night for its first Pillow season in 25 years. ''Merce will always be an 'emerging artist,' '' Miss Thompson said simply, using the latest term for developing dance talent. ''He is always full of new ideas.''

title: American Medical
description: American Medical International is offering $100 million of 13 1/8 percent notes due in 1994 at a price of 99 3/8 to yield 13.237 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The notes, rated A-3 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's, were offered with a yield about 5/8 percentage point greater than for 10-year Treasury notes.

title: Austrian Downs American
description: Peter Seisenbacher of Austria won the gold medal in the 189-pound judo division tonight, defeating Robert Berland, the first American ever to reach an Olympic judo final.

title: Panel Calls for a Limit On Election Day Polls
description: The Senate Commerce Committee today approved a nonbinding resolution calling on news organizations to limit their use of polls of people who have just voted and to refrain from making early projections of election results.

title: LEADER OF CATHOLIC BISHOPS DRAFTS STATEMENT OPPOSING PARTISANSHIP
description: In the midst of rising clamor over the role of religion in politics, Bishop James W. Malone, president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, has drafted a statement that tells bishops they should avoid acting ''for or against political candidates.''

title: LOUGANIS TAKES FIRST IN SPRINGBOARD DIVING
description: Greg Louganis finally shucked off at least half the burden of expectations that he has been carrying for so many years when he won the gold medal in the men's 3-meter springboard Olympic diving competition today.

title: INVESTOR INTEREST RISES IN NEW STOCK OFFERINGS
description: Rising stock prices the past week have helped increase investor interest in new public stock offerings of several companies, securities dealers said.

title: AN OLYMPIC GOLD MEDAL CAN MEAN MILLIONS
description: As Ernesto Canto of Mexico strode around the track of the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum on Friday, a commanding lead in the 20-kilometer walk assuring him of an Olympic gold medal, thousands of his countrymen thunderously cheered him on, ''Viva Canto! Viva Mexico!''

title: INSTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $22,000 for the quarter and $98,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income after tax credits of $22,000 for the quarter and $90,000 for the 6 months.

title: ELECTRONIC MODULES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LUMONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
4 Concerts to Benefit New-Music Distributor
description: More than 20 artists will appear Sunday at the Public Theater in four benefit concerts for the New Music Distribution Service.

title: VOLCKER SEES EASED DEBT TERMS
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congresss today that because of recent gains made by debtors in the third world, it was time to move to a ''new phase in financing'' in which lenders would offer more favorable credit terms.

title: WHEN GETTING EVIDENCE INVOLVES 'DIRTY BUSINESS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Ambrosiano Payment
description: Banco Ambrosiano Holding S.A. told its creditors that nearly $300 million, representing half of their admitted claims, will be paid on Aug. 13 under an asset liquidation plan, said accountants Touche Ross & Company.

title: MPSI SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AN ERROR TO FORGET THE TAINT
description: Richard M. Nixon has become everyone's favorite unpaid consultant. When it comes to influence in the right circles, he runs rings around fellow ex- Presidents Jimmy Carter and Gerald R. Ford.

title: Striking British Miners Stone Vehicles
description: Striking miners stoned vehicles taking workers into a mine in central England today after a night of violence in which raiders smashed windows and wrecked cars belonging to nonstrikers.

title: EASTOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses for the reversal of deferred income tax liability of $20,000 for the quarter and $2,029,000 for the 6 months, and gains from the sale of real estate of $2,707,000 for the quarter and $3,360,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes gains from the sale of real estate of $232,000 for the quarter and $563,000 for the 6 months.

title: Protest by Koreans Rejected by Panel
description: A five- member commission of the International Amateur Boxing Federation rejected tonight a South Korean protest of the light-welterweight quarterfinal bout on Tuesday in which Jerry Page of the United States beat Kim Dong Kil.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Anderson Greenwood & Co. , a Houston-based company that manufactures precision valves for the process industry, said it had acquired Prince Valve Inc., a privately held company based in Norman, Okla. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Tass Mocks Smith Charge MOSCOW, Aug. 8 (Reuters)
description: Tass denied today charges

title: TWO ARE CHARGED WITH ABUSING BOYS IN JERSEY CHILD-CARE CENTERS
description: State and Monmouth County officials today announced the arrests of two men on charges of sexually abusing children at two child-care centers in Wall Township.

title: VOLUME OFF
description: The stock market closed lower for the first time in seven days yesterday. When airline issues fell sharply, the selling fever spilled into other stocks and the industrial average closed moderately lower.

title: THE RAT RACE ISN'T FOR TOTS
description: Our son Edward is only one year old and already people want to make money off him. Recently, I and other parents of small children received a letter importuning us to send our babies to a ''readiness'' program that purports to prepare them for the feverish competition at the better nursery schools. The letter begins on a note of fear, if not terror: ''In the next several months, you will be forced to make a decision which can affect your child's future. Which school will your child be able to attend?''

title: MOTIVES IN COUNTRIES' CAMPAIGNS
description: SINCE the opening ceremonies of the Olympics, Saudi Arabia's Olympic soccer team has had more television exposure, because of the country's 60-second spots, than all the other countries' teams combined. This month, nearly every major publication is running four-page color advertisments featuring the team plus pictures of Saudi Arabia's soccer stadium in Jidda, the country's temples and its modern eye hospital in Riyadh.

title: TEHERAN BLAMES U.S. AND ISRAEL FOR RED SEA MINES
description: Iran accused the United States and Israel today of placing mines in the Red Sea in a ''new conspiracy'' to try to discredit Teheran's Islamic Government.

title: IRT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-After loss from discontinued operations of $21,000.

title: OLYMPIC HIGHLIGHTS
description: Carl Lewis, booed when he won his second gold medal, was cheered last night when he won his third one, leading an American sweep of the 200-meter dash. All that Lewis, winner of the 100 meters and long jump, needs now to match Jesse Owens's 1936 feat is for no one on the American 400-meter relay team to drop the baton Saturday. In a day of redemption and records, Greg Louganis set a world mark in winning the men's springboard diving, and Mark Breland, booed in his previous fight, recaptured the public with a spectacular first-round knockout.

title: G.O.P. Delegate Profile
description: Republican leaders in recent years have repeatedly stated the party's commitment to broadening its base, especially among minority groups. But the makeup of its 1984 national convention delegation suggests limited progress in this direction.

title: NEWBERY ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: PROPOSAL ON A.T.&.T. PROFIT MARGIN
description: The Federal Communications Commission said today that it was considering the development of a new ''formula system'' that would make it relatively easy to revise the profit margin of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company on a regular, two-year schedule to reflect changing financial circumstances.

8 HURT IN COLLAPSE OF 2 BUILDINGS
description: Seven members of a demolition crew and a policeman who rushed to help them were injured yesterday when the interiors of two attached century-old apartment buildings collapsed in the Chelsea section of Manhattan. Three of the four stories in both buildings caved in at 8:25 A.M.

title: Du Pont to Trim Fiber Production
description: The Du Pont Company said it would reduce production of polyester filament yarns by about 10 percent by shutting part of its Camden, S.C., fiber plant's capacity and laying off 400 workers, effective Sept. 30.

description: State officials today warned parents that three people impersonating social workers had visited families in Monmouth and Sussex Counties and demanded custody of their children.

title: FRENCH SENATE REJECTS A PLAN FOR USING A REFERENDUM MORE
description: The French Senate rejected a Government proposal early today for a constitutional amendment that would expand the number of issues that could be submitted to a national referendum.

description: Delmed Inc. said its board had rejected as inadequate a proposal from W.R. Grace & Company to acquire three million Delmed common shares and warrants to buy three million more.

description: Dean Lukin became Australia's first- ever Olympic weight-lifting gold medalist tonight, taking the superh eavyweight class and spoiling the bid of Mario Martinez to win the United States' first gold in the sport in 24 years.

title: C.D. Yields Flatten Out After bounding upward for six months, average yields on money market deposit accounts and six-month certificates of deposit saw little growth nationally in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.
description: Even the New York area, the scene of a rate war among large banks, saw little movement; a majority of banks reported either flat or declining average yields on both the money market and six-month instruments.

title: Criminal Is Renominated For Missouri House Seat
description: A felon, Alex Fazzino, won a primary election for the Missouri House of Representatives Tuesday and said his victory was a decision by a ''jury of his peers.''
