Letter: On East Timor ; Widen the Red Cross Role To the Editor:
description: As the author of a letter co-signed by 123 U.S. representatives and sent to Secretary of State Shultz before his recent visit to Indonesia, I was pleased to see your editorials mentioning our appeal concerning the tragic conflict in the former Portuguese colony of East Timor (July 11 and in part July 21).

title: U.S. PUTS 5 MORE IN SEMIFINALS
description: With Emanuel Steward and Thomas Hearns, his buddies from the Kronk Gym, watching from ringside seats, Mark Breland climbed through the ropes tonight determined. The amateur welterweight champion from Brooklyn, who has had difficulty living up to his rave reviews, more than made amends when he stopped Genaro Leon of Mexico at 2:39 of the first round.

title: Columnist Jailed for Drugs
description: A London society columnist was sentenced to 16 weeks in jail today for possessing cocaine. Peter Theodoracopulos, 47 years old, who writes for The Spectator under the name Taki, admitted having 23.1 grams of cocaine worth more than $3,000 when he was searched by customs officers at Heathrow Airport. He is to appeal against the sentence.

title: ARMORED AND DEFENSIVE
description: Horns honked impatiently yesterday afternoon on Willoughby Street in downtown Brooklyn. A traffic agent, Ronald Joseph, went to investigate.

title: NEW TAXES: WHOSE AND HOW?
description: The real issue dividing President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale is not whether to raise taxes to curb the Government's budget deficits but whose taxes to raise and how to raise them. According to sources in the respective camps, neither candidate has faced up to the magnitude of the deficit problem. Once they do, a Mondale administration would likely seek to raise more in income taxes than the Democratic candidate has proposed publicly, possibly with a multiyear surtax. By contrast, in a second term, Mr. Reagan would probably ask Congress to enact a tax on the income that people actually spent, possibly a national sales tax.

title: BIDDING IS WEAK FOR NOTES, BONDS
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday, with short-term rates falling while longer-term note and bond yields rose slightly.

description: Paul Westphal, the 33-year-old veteran guard who formerly played for the Knicks, took his contract dispute with the Phoenix Suns before an arbitrator at the National Basketball Association's headquarters here yesterday. At issue is whether Westphal is entitled to a $300,000 guarantee for the coming season under the terms of a two-year contract that he signed when he joined the Suns last year.

description: Ray Burris allowed only four hits in seven innings and teamed with Bill Caudill to shut out the Minnesota Twins today as the A's won, 5-0.

description: Senator Paul Laxalt, Republican of Nevada, the head of President Reagan's re-election campaign, is being paid a $50,000 salary this year by the Republican National Committee, according to committee officials and public records.

title: Human Resources - and Human Need
description: When James Krauskopf resigned yesterday as head of New York City's Human Resources Administration, he said it was ''the best thing for the services H.R.A. provides . . . that a change be made.'' He was talking about a change in commissioners, but that won't solve whatever's wrong at H.R.A. The entire structure needs a going-over - and the first question should be, ''Are we looking at a dinosaur?''

title: NIXON REDUX, REASSESSED
description: Americans still find Richard Nixon endlessly fascinating, partly because they find him so puzzling - such a seeming bundle of contradictions and conundrums. He has been a major national figure for almost 40 years now, a central part of the political experience of three generations. Few leaders in history have gone so high and been flung so low. And yet he has endured.

title: Douglas Is Victor By 1 at Wykikyl
description: Bruce Douglas of the Winged Foot Golf Club, in Mamaroneck, N.Y., shot a 6 under par 66 and finished with a 54-hole total of 209 to win the Westchester Golf Association Open title today at the Wykikyl Country Club. The tournament was interrupted by heavy rains Tuesday night. Bob Heins of Old Oaks, Purchase, three-time defending champion, finished second, with 70-210.

title: Pillow's 'Jazz Parade' To Offer 2 Premieres
description: Two world premieres and a demonstration of theatrical break dancing will be the highlights of the five-day ''Jazz Parade'' at Jacob's Pillow, in Lee, Mass., beginning Aug. 21.

title: HEARINGS ARE CLOSED AT TRIAL ON ARMS SMUGGLING
description: At the Government's request, a Federal judge has held closed pretrial hearings in the case of two New York businessmen charged with trying to smuggle 500 rifles and a large amount of ammunition to Poland, according to parties in the case.

title: HOUSE PANEL APPROVES EL SALVADOR AID
description: A key House subcommittee today unanimously approved most of the military and economic aid requested for El Salvador next year.

title: North Western
description: The Chicago and North Western Transportation Company is offering $80 million of 15 3/4 percent bonds due in 2004 at a price of 98.578 to yield 16 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The bonds, which are rated Ba-3 by Moody's and BB by Standard & Poor's, were offered with a yield 3.28 percentage points above 20-year Treasury bonds.

title: Ralph James Watkins, Economist and Adviser
description: Ralph James Watkins, an economist, authority on statistics and government adviser, died Saturday in Waldorf, Md. He was 87 years old.

title: BUSH MAKES NO DEBATE COMMITMENT
description: Vice President Bush today wrapped up a four-day political swing through the Northwest, trying to get back on track with an upbeat message the Republican Presidential campaign believes will appeal most to American voters.

title: MOTHER SAYS SHCHARANSKY IS BEING PENALIZED
description: The mother of Anatoly B. Shcharansky said today that he had been placed on a strict regimen at Chistopol prison, a move she suspects portends an extension of his term there.

title: TESTING CHILDREN FOR LEAD POISON By The Associated Press
description: The City Health Department said yesterday that it was sending out mobile medical teams to give free tests to young children to find out if they had lead poisoning.

title: PRIDE AND SPIRIT SPUR PAYTON
Chester Beckley Dies; Ship Salvaging Expert
description: Chester A. Beckley, a marine salvage expert who salvaged more than $1 billion in vessels and cargo, died Monday at the Torrey Pines Convalescent Home in La Jolla, Calif. He was 94 years old and lived in San Diego.

title: ABC'S COVERAGE OF THE OLYMPICS
description: WHAT do the Olympics look like on television? An athletic competition, for one thing; an American celebration, for another. Annoyed by the celebratory aspect, the International Olympic Committee last week took issue with ABC. The network, the committee said, was diminishing the ''international flavor'' of the games, showing partiality to American competitors. Many critics agreed, although none of them asked the television viewers. Viewers have been watching the Olympics in numbers that have surprised even ABC.

title: MUSIC: DAVID HIGGS IN ORGAN RECITAL
description: DAVID HIGGS, one of the brightest, most promising young concert organists to have appeared on the American music scene in years, gave a recital at Riverside Church on Tuesday night that offered abundant evidence of his remarkable talents.

title: U.S. Wins Its First Gold
description: The United States won its first-ever Olympic equestrian team show-jumping gold medal in a competition marred by mysterious breaks in the leather girth of one of the Italian horses.

title: JETS' CARTER KEEPS BUSY WHILE HEALING
description: He spends part of his morning in a swimming pool, trying to get back some of the flexibility lost because of a pulled hamstring. And in the afternoon, while his teammates engage in full- contact scrimmages on the practice field, Russell Carter is often inside somewhere, doing mild limbering exercises or lifting weights.

title: Paperwork Reduction
description: Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., a New York Repbulican, is not alone in his feeling that ''Washington is famous for endless paperwork, bureaucratic red tape and lengthy delays of consideration on benefits claims.'' In a press release, Mr. Fish disclosed that he had introduced legislation to reduce Federal paperwork. And he seemed also to be taking his own advice: his release is on a single sheet of paper, with both sides used, instead of the usual second sheet.

Cohan made his way across ''the Garage,'' as this section of the New York Stock Exchange's trading floor is known, toward Michael LaBranche, a floor specialist, heard someone call ''an eighth,'' and after exchanging nods with another broker had bought 500 shares of American Telephone & Telegraph for a client at 19 1/8 a share.

title: SEXUAL ABUSE IS INVESTIGATED AT 3 MORE DAY-CARE CENTERS
description: Three more city-financed day-care centers, all in the Bronx, have come under investigation for sexual abuse, officials said yesterday.

title: A STEAMER MOORED ON THE NILE: THE VIEW FROM A WRITER'S CABIN
description: NOT counting the room I'm writing in now - that's quite another story - the room that has meant most to me in life is one that no longer exists. I am glad of it: I would hate to think of other people using it now, fouling it with cigarette smoke, perhaps, or debasing it with trendy furniture. I want my rooms to be always Me, or Us anyway, so I am happy to think that this particular chamber long ago saved itself from alien tastes and tendencies by sinking to the bottom of the River Nile.

title: JENSEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Houston Lighting
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation and the Houston Lighting and Power Company said they had signed a 10- year, $1.3 billion cogeneration contract guaranteeing Houston Lighting 225 megawatts of electricity from Diamond Shamrock. Houston Lighting will purchase the energy at a price that is 12 percent less than the full avoided cost of a lignite plant, the companies said. The contract is based on lignite prices that are currently half those for natural gas.

title: Port Authority AccountTo McCafferty Agency
description: McCafferty & Ratner Inc. beat out five other finalists for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey account.

title: D'AMATO CALLING FOR PRIVATE OWNERSHIP OF PRISONS
description: Warning that overcrowding in the nation's prisons had reached ''epidemic proportions,'' Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said yesterday that prisons could be put up more cheaply if private developers got tax incentives to build them and then leased the buildings to state and local governments.

title: Halts at Harvester
description: The International Harvester Company said that because of slow sales, it would shut operations involved in making self-propelled combines at a plant in East Moline, Ill., for five months starting in early September. Earlier, Harvester said it would halt combine-making activity at the plant for the month of September, but it recently decided to extend the shutdown, laying off 300 to 400 workers. Harvester also said it would halt production of high-horsepower farm tractors at a plant in Rock Island, Ill., from Oct. 29 through Nov. 26 as a result of sluggish sales.

title: WARY LEADER OF BAR GROUP
description: When the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace, the West Coast research organization, first sought out John C. Shepherd in 1977, it was looking for a good lawyer to represent its interests in a complicated case involving a bequest in Missouri. While working on the case, Mr. Shepherd, whose practice is based in St. Louis, met most of the officers of the institution. Shortly thereafter the institution, which is affiliated with Stanford University, named him to its Board of Overseers and its executive committee.

description: ''Olympic Games for Humans, Not Apes,'' was the heading on letters mailed from the suburbs of Washington to 20 African and Asian Olympic committees in early July. Supposedly written by the Ku Klux Klan, this hate mail threatened violence against nonwhite athletes at the Los Angeles Games, the kind of violence the Russians said they feared when they were organizing their boycott of this year's competition.

description: The House gave final Congressional approval today to a bill strengthening efforts to collect child support payments, including the mandatory withholding of wages for delinquent payments.

title: Costly Allergy
description: Paul Cummings, who won the United States Olympic trials at 10,000 meters, covered that distance in 27 minutes 43 seconds, an American record, on April 28 in Los Angeles. Last Monday, he watched from the sidelines as Alberto Cova of Italy won the gold medal in the event at the Olympics in 27:47:54, more than four seconds slower.

title: TRANSIT SURVEY FINDS SMALL RISE IN COMFORT
description: ''Modest'' gains were made in the second quarter of this year to improve the comfort of passengers on the city's subways and buses, but they have been overshadowed by service disruptions, according to a Transit Authority survey released yesterday.

title: INTEGRATION EFFORT PRAISED BY STATE
description: Nine years after being ordered to alleviate racial segregation in its schools, the Mount Vernon Board of Education has been told that its integration plan is working.

title: DELOREAN JURY STARTS DELIBERATING DRUG CHARGES
description: Jurors began deliberating in the trial of John Z. DeLorean today after the judge instructed them to consider the law but also to use their common sense in deciding whether the defendant was guilty of conspiring to distribute cocaine.

title: LINEAR INSTRUMENTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: PROBLEMS OF PORTRAYING LITERARY GIANTS ON STAGE
description: -creation of a literary figure on stage poses many obstacles for the actor, not the least of which is how to provide transitions between extracts from the author's life and letters. When playing Mark Twain in his exemplary monodrama, ''Mark Twain Tonight!,'' Hal Holbrook paused to light a cigar, and a billow of smoke smoothed his way into the next scene. In two one-man shows seen recently in London, Michael Pennington's evening as Anton Chekhov and Alec McCowen's version of Rudyard Kipling, as written by Brian Clark, each actor solved the transition problem by stopping to sip a cup of tea.

title: PERINI INVESTMENT PROPERTY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $311,000 from the sale of property. The 1984 results reflect an additional interest expense in connection with the financing of a building.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE - Reduced Reggie Jackson's two-day suspension for igniting a fight on July 21 to one day.

title: CHICAGO DIVIDED ON MOVE AGAINST SCHOOLS' CHIEF
description: About 350 parents and community activists booed, jeered, shouted racial epithets and waved competing placards at a school board meeting today as they lined up for or against the ouster of the superintendent of Chicago's public schools.

title: INSITUFORM OF NORTH AMERCA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: CITY ACTS TO RESHAPE AREA NEAR CONVENTION SITE
description: The Department of City Planning yesterday proposed the rezoning of blocks around the new convention center to encourage the development of hotels, housing and retail centers.

title: Article 120139 -- No Title
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: PROPERTY TRUST OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a recovery of allowance for possible losses of $623,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Including a gain of $1,176,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: ANCHORS MAKE ROOM FOR THE HOME TV
description: WHEN it comes to making a place in the home for the television, broadcast journalists do seem different from you and me. They have more television sets, for one thing.

title: PARTY LINES CLEAR IN MICHIGAN SENATE RACE
description: A clear ideological confrontation in Michigan this fall was assured Tuesday when Jack R. Lousma, a former astronaut, won the Republican nomination to oppose Senator Carl Levin, a liberal Democrat.

title: LIFE INSPIRES CZECH EMIGRE'S FICTION
description: Like Danny Smiricky, the protagonist of his bountiful new novel, ''The Engineer of Human Souls,'' Joseph Skvorecky was born in a small town in Bohemia in 1924, endured and in some ways enjoyed the German occupation during World War II and the postwar Communist rule, left Czechoslovakia after the Soviet invasion of 1968 and settled in Canada, where he now teaches English literature at the University of Toronto.

title: ON MISSING THE SOVIET UNION
description: LOS ANGELES One was the stereotypical Russian, big and burly with ruddy pink cheeks. The other man was smaller, thinner. But both were wearing yellow blazers, identifying them instantly as Olympic judges. Despite the absence of Soviet-bloc athletes, dozens of Russian sports officials are here as judges, timers, whatever. After an introduction, an American offerred his hand.

title: JET IS 50 FEET FROM A COLLISION
description: A commercial jetliner with 146 people aboard came within 30 to 50 feet of colliding with a twin-engine airplane over northern Virginia today, Federal Aviation Administration officials said.

title: JOYS OF THE UNIVERSE, SEEN FROM ROCKLAND COUNTY
description: Darkness is approaching. The vault above is clear. Oh, happy night, bumming around the universe.

title: Madlock Out for Season
description: It may be only early August, but Bill Madlock, the Pittsburgh Pirates' four-time National League batting champion, says his season is over. The problem is a bone spur in the right elbow, a contributor to a disappointing year in which he has hit only .254.

title: MUGABE'S 'VANGUARD' PREPARES FOR ONE-PARTY RULE
description: To the thump of African drums and the strains of the ''Internationale,'' Prime Minister Robert Mugabe opened his party's first congress in 20 years today.

title: Moving Long Avoided
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: 'DISTORTION' LAID TO U.S. ON UNESCO
description: Members of an advisory panel on Unesco appointed by the State Department accused the Reagan Administration yesterday of using ''misleading tactics'' and spreading ''distorted information'' to support its decision to withdraw from that organization unless major changes are carried out.

title: Symposium on Art At Whitney Saturday
description: A daylong symposium on American abstract art and sculpture will be presented at the Whitney Museum of American Art Saturday, beginning at 10 A.M. It will be presented in conjuction with the exhibition ''Abstract Painting and Sculpture in America 1927-44,'' which ends its national tour at the Whitney Sunday.

title: NEW UNITED BRANDS CHAIRMAN
description: Carl H. Lindner, the Cincinnati multimillionaire who is already chairman of the Penn Central Corporation, Fisher Foods Inc. and his own company, the American Financial Corporation, has added another title to the list: the chairmanship of the United Brands Company, a corporation that has long earned the bulk of its profits from the Chiquita brand banana.

title: Rockets Sign Olajuwon
description: Akeem Olajuwon, the 7-foot center who will team with 7-4 Ralph Sampson on the National Basketball Association's biggest front line, signed with the Houston Rockets yesterday, seven weeks after they had made him the No. 1 choice in the draft. General Manager Ray Patterson said the six- year contract was the longest ever offered to an N.B.A. rookie.

title: AMERICAN OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. There were no share earnings for latest and year-ago quarters because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: PACHYDERM TURNS POLITICAL
description: Elephants do not belong just to Republicans.

title: Basques Riot Over a Death
description: Several hundred youths broke store windows, overturned police cars and fought with policemen here today to protest the killing of a suspected Basque guerrilla on Tuesday, the police said. Eduardo Irizar Imaz, a suspected member of the Basque separatist guerrilla group E.T.A., was shot dead after he opened fire on civil guards. The police charged the rioters and made several arrests.

title: REAGAN RAISES NEW OBSTACLE TO HOUSE BILL ON IMMIGRATION
description: The Reagan Administration has raised a new objection to the House version of a comprehensive immigration bill, saying it goes too far in protecting the rights of legal aliens and Hispanic workers.

title: SALVADOR ARMS-AID CHARGES DETAILED
description: Government officials made public today photographic and other evidence that they said supported contentions that the insurgents in El Salvador get most of their weapons, ammunition and equipment from Soviet-bloc nations through Nicaragua.

title: Metropolitan Life
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company was identified as the company acquiring Security Pacific Plaza, headquarters of the Security Pacific Corporation, in Los Angeles.

title: U.S. REACHES FINAL
description: Craig Buck and Karch Kiraly sparked a 15-6, 15-10, 15-7 victory over Canada tonight. sending the United States men's volleyball team into the gold-medal game against Brazil.

ASIANS AFOOT
description: New York is not only a national cultural center, but also an international one with institutions both private and governmental, both richly endowed and verging on poverty, specializing in all the arts. If New York is a treasure house of Asian resources, it is due in large part to such institutions as the Asia Society, now handsomely settled at 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street.

title: NEW-PRODUCT COST CITED
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, citing heavy spending on an array of new products, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1984 gained only 1.1 percent on a 5.2 percent advance in sales.

title: FRDDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Sid Fernandez, unbeaten in his rookie season, tries to keep the Mets from sinking farther out of sight in the pennant race.

title: SCOTS MUSIC AND DANCE
description: A free performance of traditional Scottish bagpipe music and highland dancing will be presented Sunday from 1 to 3 P.M. at the Inn on Lake Waramaug in New Preston, Conn.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
German Retail Prices
description: West German retail prices fell two-tenths of 1 percent last month from June, but were up 2.1 percent from July 1983, the Federal Statistics Office said today.

title: TESORO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: There are no share earnings for the latest third quarter because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in computing depreciation for substantially all oil field service equipment and a change in reporting Bolivian operations adopted in the second quarter of fiscal 1984.

title: MONDALE, TALKING ON ABORTION, CHEERED IN SOUTH
description: Walter F. Mondale brought his campaign to the buckle of the Bible Belt today and drew loud applause when he declared that he could not support a constitutional amendment banning abortion.

title: Wells, Rich TreasurerIs Moving to Saatchi
description: Gerald Kessler has been named executive vice president and chief financial officer of Saatchi & Saatchi Compton Inc. Mr. Kessler, 43 years old, succeeds Gerald Germain, who resigned last week to join Doyle Dane Bernbach.

title: HOLYFIELD OF U.S. IS DISQUALIFIED
description: In perhaps the most bizarre development in what has been an Olympic boxing tournament filled with controversy over officiating, the American light heavyweight Evander Holyfield was disqualified tonight with five seconds remaining in the second round of his semifinal bout for hitting Kevin Barry of New Zealand on the break.

title: SCOUTING;
description: The Early Risers

title: WHEN A DRUG KING RULES ABOARD
description: Street-wise drug pushers, peddling joints to school children or cocaine to Yuppies, are the easiest link to identify in the drug chain. Big-time dealers are more elusive. Yet Federal and state judges have stiff fines, long sentences and forefeiture of all assets at their disposal when one is convicted. But what can we do when the culprits are foreign governments?

title: AID FOR REBELS IN A HAMLET IN SALVADOR
description: Evelin, 19 years old, sat on the porch of her adobe shack, one of a handful in this tiny hamlet in the grassy hills of central El Salvador.

title: Business Digest; FRIDAY, AUGUST 10, 1984
description: Markets

title: CITY INSPECTORS INDICTED IN INVESTIGATION OF BRIBERY
description: A supervisor and 10 inspectors from the New York City water, sewer and electrical control bureaus were indicted yesterday on Federal charges involving bribes from contractors.

title: OLD TALES CURE NEW ILLS FOR ISOLATED KENTUCKIANS
description: Bobbie Ann Mason, a writer who grew up in Mayfield, ends one of her stories with a passage depicting a woman's dilemma as to whether she should leave her family farm to join her computer-salesman husband in a Louisville suburb.

title: Koch's 5th Chef Resigns From Gracie Mansion Staff
description: The gastronomic habits of Mayor

title: Utility Mails Rebates Tied to 3 Mile Island
description: The Jersey Central Power and Light Company will begin mailing $20 rebate checks on Friday to each of its 740,000 customers, the State Board of Public Utilities announced.

title: FILM FESTIVAL IS RESCREENING ITS 45 BEST IN SHOW
description: Forty-five movies of the 1970's and early 80's share three qualities - distinction, success and premieres at the annual New York Film Festival. Beginning this evening, and running through Aug. 26, these innovative and provocative films will be screened at Alice Tully Hall in Lincoln Center. The retrospective, called ''The Second Decade,'' includes about one-fifth of the films shown at the festival from 1973 to 1982, according to Joanne Koch, executive director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

title: OLD AND VERY OLD MANSIONS ALONG THE HUDSON
description: ONLY 80 miles from Times Square, Hyde Park, on the east bank of the Hudson River in Dutchess County, draws as many as 2,500 visitors on a summer day. Their major objective is the home of Franklin D. Roosevelt, 32d President of the United States, who was born there and who is buried there, and the museum that portrays his life and his Administration. But there are other attractions in Hyde Park, an area where the new millionaires of the Gilded Age built part- time summer mansions in the late 1800's. Two of them, the Vanderbilt mansion and the Mills mansion, are maintained as museums of a bygone opulent age.

title: BIG MAC'S OLYMPIC GIVEAWAY
description: McDONALD'S will not know until September how many Big Macs, french fries and Coca- Colas it gave away during its Olympic medal campaign, but the number is sure to be mindboggling.

title: CORRECTION
description: A brief article yesterday about a symposium on abstract painting and sculpture at the Whitney Museum of American Art gave incorrect dates for the symposium and for the closing of a related exhibition, ''Abstract Painting and Sculpture in America 1927-44.'' The symposium is Sept. 8; the exhibition closes Sept. 9.

title: Hart Plans to Campaign For Mondale in the Fall
description: Senator Gary Hart plans to campaign hard for Walter F. Mondale this fall, Mr. Hart's press secretary says.

title: THE LOOK OF URBAN CONFETTI
description: Perhaps the largest field of play at the Olympic Games is no less than southern California itself. Since the start of an Olympic arts festival June 1, 43 arts sites, 28 sports sites, 3 villages and other locales have been adapted and decorated for the Olympics.

SCULPTURE: PURYEAR POSTMINIMALISM
description: MARTIN PURYEAR is one of the most gifted sculptors of the postminimalist generation. His work retains the minimalist commitment to simple forms and to the gravity of floors and uprightness of walls. Like other postminimalists, however, Puryear has rejected the reformist spirit of minimalism and is determined to bring to a vocabularly of simplified forms a broad range of meaning.

description: The United States women, needing a victory over West Germany to win an Olympic field hockey medal, saw their hopes dashed today when they were tied, 1-1.

title: Austria Says Refugee Flow From East Bloc Is Still Rising
description: The number of Soviet bloc refugees seeking political asylum in Austria has continued to rise this year, according to Interior Ministry figures issued today.

description: CSB Overseas Capital Corporation, a subsidiary of the Dade Savings and Loan Association of Florida, is offering $150 million of 13 1/8 percent Eurobonds at a price of 100.

description: Following is the text of a statement issued today by Bishop James W. Malone, president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops:

title: No Safe Arms 'Limit' in Space
description: The Soviet-American impasse about a space negotiation turns on one critical question: Should weapons be banned from space or merely limited?

title: U.S. SAYS UGANDA RIGHTS ABUSES ARE AMONG MOST GRAVE IN WORLD
description: The State Department told Congress today that abuses of human rights in Uganda had become ''among the most grave in the world,'' but said the situation did not warrant cutting off United States military assistance.

title: U.S. and Belgium Bar Sale of Lathe to Soviet
description: The United States has agreed to help Belgium buy a Belgian-made high technology lathe for the Belgian Army to keep it from being sold to the Soviet Union, Government officials said tonight.

title: NAVY GAINS ON SHIP COST AND DELIVERY PROBLEMS
description: After years of commissioning warships that were delivered late, cost more than planned and were poorly constructed, the Navy is experiencing a marked reversal in fortune.

title: PASTORAL SUSSEX RACES END THE LONDON SEASON
description: The London social season ended for the summer, not with a ball or a formal dinner but with horse racing - an event prescribed by tradition. Queen Alexandra, wife of King Edward VII, described it in the early 1900's as ''the pleasantest week in the year.''

title: Bridge: Expert Takes a Helpful Hint From Teammate Gracefully
description: Suppose that in a team contest you reach a slam and fail, largely because an opponent has made a frivolous overcall. This jeopardizes potential victory in the event, you are already feeling irritated and then one of your teammates points out that you could have improved your play and made the slam.

title: IN MUSEUMS THIS WEEKEND
description: New York is rich in museums large and small, all of which have exhibitions and events of unusual interest almost any weekend of the year. The following is a selection from what is available this weekend:

title: PERRY COMO ON L.I.
Applications DueFor Home Lottery
description: Today is the last day applications will be available for a free, citysponsored lottery whose winners will be entitled to purchase, for $250 each, one of 33 two-family buildings. The applications must be returned by 4 P.M. Monday.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday CAROUSEL' AT N.Y.U.

title: A RETREAT FOR MUSIC IN CONNECTICUT FOOTHILLS
description: On a hazy Saturday, visitors to Music Mountain, which describes itself as America's oldest continuous summer chamber-music festival, stroll around the peaceful grounds before entering the small white clapboard hall near Falls Village, Conn., to take their seats for the afternoon's concert. Soon the audience settles in and the rich sound of a Beethoven string quartet fills the pine-paneled hall.

title: Chile's Caesar, in Black and White
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, Chile's President, does not often talk to the press. Now we know why. In an interview with Edward Schumacher of The Times, the general compared himself to the ''best Roman Emperors,'' claiming a gift for applying military tactics and secrecy to political decisions.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about four benefit concerts for the New Music Distribution Service, a promoter and distributor of contemporary-music recordings, gave an incorrect date. The concerts, in two auditoriums at the Public Theater, will be at at 4 and 8:30 P.M. on Aug. 26.

title: TRILOGY DROPS 'WAFER-SCALE' CHIP
description: Trilogy Ltd., which gave up on its effort to produce a super computer last June, said today that it had abandoned its plans to design, build and market a high-speed ''wafer-scale'' computer chip.

title: New Chief ExecutiveNamed by Brouillard
description: James H. Foster was named president and chief executive officer of Brouillard Communications, a division of the J. Walter Thompson Company. The 51-year-old executive succeeds Joseph Brouillard, the founder of the financial and public relations subsidiary, who will retire later this year.

title: Italian Production
description: Italy's industrial production fell 2.9 percent in June from May, but was up 2.8 percent from the period a year earlier, the Statistical Institute said today. In the first half of the year, the agency said, industrial output was up 3 percent from the period a year ago.

title: Dayton-Hudson In Dillard Deal
description: The Dayton-Hudson Corporation said it had agreed to sell the major assets of two of its department store companies to Dillard Department Stores of Little Rock, Ark.

title: Successor to Chairman At First National State
description: Robert R. Ferguson Jr., president and chief executive officer of the First National State Bancorporation of Newark, has been elected chairman of the board.

title: SUSPECTS ARE DESCRIBED IN ENGLISH CHARTER THEFT
description: The state authorities today released drawings of two suspects in the theft here Wednesday of the first page of the English charter that established the Massachusetts Bay Colony in 1629.

title: ALABAMA MATCHES 2 LEADING FILLIES
description: The Alabama Stakes here Saturday seems reminiscent of last Saturday's Whitney Handicap. Both events drew a field of only five and shaped up as virtual match races. Last week it was Slew o' Gold against Track Barron for leadership of the handicap division, and this week it is Life's Magic against Class Play for leadership of the 3-year- old fillies.

title: ;  Rams' Dickerson Hurt
description: The Los Angeles Rams had a training-camp scare when Eric Dickerson , who set a National Football League rookie record last season by rushing for 1,808 yards, collided with the defensive back Nolan Cromwell during passing drills and suffered a neck injury.

title: SCULPTURE: 'DEGAS TO CALDER' AT THE GUGGENHEIM
description: ''FROM DEGAS TO CALDER'' is the title of an exhibition that can be seen at the Guggenheim Museum through Sept. 8. Made up of sculptures and works on paper that range in date from the early 1880's (Degas) to 1972 (Calder), it also includes work by Archipenko, Arp, Brancusi, Max Ernst, Naum Gabo, Alberto Giacometti, Joan Miro, Henry Moore and others. (Calder is, by the way, the only American artist in the bunch.) Everything in it belongs to the Guggenheim itself.

title: Division Chief Leaves Becker John Ward, the executive in
description: charge of the commercial

title: AROUND THE WORLD ; U.S. Report Describes Bulgarian Arms Sales
description: Arms shipments gave Bulgaria its largest export earnings in 1982, as the Warsaw Pact nation increased its weapons sales to the third world, according to an analysis by Wharton Econometric Forecasting Associates, a research group based in Washington.

title: PHILHARMONIC REPLACES WORK BY BLOCH AT MALAYSIA REQUEST
description: Malaysia, a predominantly Moslem country, has asked the New York Philharmonic to replace a work by a Jewish composer on a concert program there. The orchestra has agreed to comply.

title: SEMICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a special gain of $620,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Including a special gain of $1,159,000. Results for the latest periods include the dilutive effects of the assumed conversion of $5,981,000 of 13 percent convertible subordinated debentures into 648,698 shares of common stock and the add-back of realted interest expense effect to income.

title: YANKEES DRIVE OUT SEAVER IN FOURTH
description: Yankee Stadium fans greeted Tom Seaver with a standing ovation when he went to the mound in the first inning last night, and they saluted him with a standing ovation when he left the mound in the fourth. They roared even louder in between.

title: DR. CHARLES MESSELOFF
description: Dr. Charles R. Messeloff, a specialist in cardiovascular diseases who was medical director and chief of medicine at Beth Abraham Hospital in the Bronx from 1967 to 1975, died of pneumonia Tuesday at the hospital.

title: FENCING ; ; Rumania Takes Bronze
description: Rumania, led by Alexandru Chiculita, took the bronze medal in team saber fencing tonight, edging West Germany by a score of 8-7.

title: Net Up 19% At Woolworth
description: The F. W. Woolworth Company said yesterday that its net income for the second quarter ended July 31 rose 19 percent, to $19 million, or 62 cents a share, from $16 million, or 50 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: AUCTIONS
description: A READER of Dickens can buy a copy of ''Nicholas Nickleby'' at Barnes & Noble for $4.05 - or get one at the Swann Galleries for about $200. The $4.05 is for a discounted Bantam paperback; the $200 is a typical price for what a first edition in book form will bring at an auction at Swann, which describes itself as the largest rare-book auction house in the United States.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE WAR OF THE END OF THE WORLD. By Mario Vargas Llosa. Translated by Helen R. Lane. 568 pages. Farrar Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: NIGERIA'S DISCIPLINE CAMPAIGN: NOT SPARING THE ROD
description: The television advertisement can be seen many times each evening throughout Nigeria.

title: PIRATES ROUT METS
description: Manager Dave Johnson closed the Mets' clubhouse briefly last night and told his team that ''every championship club goes through hard times, so don't let it eat at you.''

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: SOMEWHERE in Hollywood are a sushi maker and a candy peddler who have more than a passing interest in the fate of ''Strangers Kiss,'' which opens at the Embassy on Monday.

title: TAXES AND SPENDING (1)
description: Aside from the selection of Geraldine Ferraro, Walter Mondale's

title: TAX CASE OF FEDERAL JUDGE IN NEVADA GOES TO JURY
description: The three- count felony indictment against Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne went to a Federal jury here today.

title: ILL SINGER CANCELS FOR MONTH
description: Barbara Hendricks, the soprano, has cancelled her scheduled appearances at the Tanglewood Festival in Lenox, Mass., on Aug. 18 and at the Mostly Mozart concerts Aug. 20 and 22 in New York. For the New York concerts, she will be replaced by Pamela Coburn. Miss Hendricks was taken ill in Europe and has dropped all of her North American appearances for August.

title: THE PAY CUT APPROACH TO COMPARABLE PAY
description: To the Editor:

title: 10 Years After Watgergate, Nixon Foes Hold Reunion
description: It looked like your typical New York

title: CANOEING ; ; Barton of U.S. in Final
description: Greg Barton placed second in his semifinal heat of the 1,000-meter kayak competition today to become the first American to reach the finals since the event was added to the Olympics in 1936.

title: COLONIAL PENN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AROUND THE WORLD ; Sri Lanka Says 70 Tamils Died in 2 Days of Clashes
description: About 70 Tamil separatists were killed in clashes with security forces in the last two days, Government officials said today.

title: PERENNIAL HOPE OF THE SCATTERED CAYUGA NATION-LAND
description: Once a year, the United Parcel Service truck arrives at a small storefront on Main Street with a package from the United States Government to the tiny Cayuga Indian tribe. Inside is a stack of muslin cloth, a continuing, annual payment for a treaty signed with the Cayuga Nation nearly 200 years ago.

title: NEWLY BUILT UNITS OUTSELL A MAJESTIC REHABILITATION
description: In an 800- acre wooded tract in this Westchester community on the Hudson River, just south of Peekskill, homebuyers have an unusual choice: apartment-like condominiums created out of a former resort hotel or new townhouse condominiums in clusters of two and three units. So far, the townhouses seem to be favored.

title: Exxon Price Rise
description: The Exxon Company U.S.A., a unit of the Exxon Corporation, said it had increased its price for barge- and cargo- size lots of distillate by a half cent a gallon in the Northeast. The move raises the barge price for No. 2 oil - the basic component of heating oil and diesel fuel - in New York harbor to 76.50 cents a gallon, an increase of 2 cents a gallon in the past week.

title: JUDO ; ; South Korean Takes Gold
description: South Korea captured its second gold medal in Olympic judo today when Ha Hyoung-zoo defeated Douglas Vieira of Brazil in the half-heavyweight (209 pounds) division. Vieira won the silver medal.

title: TIMES SQ. PROJECT ATTRACTS LAW FIRM
description: One of Wall Street's most prominent law firms has agreed to relocate to Times Square as part of the $1.6 billion redevelopment project proposed for the area.

title: ;  Kelcher Back Again
description: While Dean continued holding out, another big-name defensive lineman was heading back to the 49er camp.

title: ROYAL DUTCH/SHELL GROUP OF COS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Royal Dutch Petroleum and Shell Transport & Trading are both listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: NEGLIGENT HOMICIDE IS NO PRIVATE ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: THOMPSON WINS HIS 2D OLYMPIC DECATHLON
description: Daley Thompson, an emotional and uninhibited Briton, won the decathlon gold medal tonight in the Games of the XXIII Olympiad, just as he did in 1980 in Moscow. But he fell a tenth of a second short of matching the world record of the archrival who had taken the record from him.

title: ELLEN RASKIN
description: Ellen Raskin, a writer and illustrator of children's books, died of complications resulting from a connective-tissue disease Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center.

title: GULF RESOURCES & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $11,780,000 for the quarter and $12,328,000 for the 6 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $113,000. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $838,000.

title: LATE SURGE SENDS DOW UP 27.94
description: After a three-day lull, the stock market surged upward again yesterday. Traders, spurred by share prices that appeared to be holding steady and falling interest rates paid on bonds, poured into the market and drove the Dow Jones industrial average up 27.94 points, to close at 1,224.05.

title: Bank Stake in
description: Creusot-Loire LE CREUSOT, France, Aug.

title: Beatrice Issues Bonds, Warrants
description: Beatrice Finance, a subsidiary of the Beatrice Companies, issued $200 million of 10-year Eurobonds with warrants to buy common stock through underwriters led by Credit Suisse First Boston. Each $1,000 of the 10 1/2 percent bonds due in 1994 was accompanied by one 10-year warrant to buy 27.3 shares of Beatrice common stock at a price of $36.625. Beatrice stock closed on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday at $28.50, up 25 cents a share.

title: COMMODORE INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $3,700,000, or 12 cents a share, from a tax credit.

title: AS ISRAELIS TALK, NEW OUTPOST RISES
description: -Occupied West Bank, Aug. 9 - Four Israeli families established a new outpost in the midst of this Arab town Wednesday night, just hours before national unity talks on Israel's West Bank settlement policy began in Jerusalem.

title: BIOGEN NV reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Democrats Adopt Stand That Repudiates Bigotry
description: The Democratic National Committee, at the behest of Walter F. Mondale, adopted a resolution today repudiating ''people who promote bigotry, racism and anti-Semitism.''

title: BOND PRICES INCREASE SHARPLY
description: Bond prices rose sharply yesterday, as demand from securities dealers and investors was more than enough to absorb the $16.75 billion of Treasury notes and bonds sold this week, including yesterday's $4.75 billion auction of new 30-year bonds.

title: HATFIELD LETTERS CITE PIPLINE BENEFITS
description: Letters signed by Senator Mark O. Hatfield have extolled a trans-African oil pipeline venture as having ''profound and potentially beneficial impacts.'' on American energy resources and foreign policy.

title: Digicon in Talks Regarding Equity
description: Digicon Inc. said it was involved in preliminary negotiations on the possible sale of a substantial equity interest in Digicon to a company it did not identify.

title: SCIENTIFIC SOFTWARE-INTEROMP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REAGAN MEETS ADVISERS ON CAMPAIGN STRATEGY
description: President Reagan, taking time out from his holiday to assess the latest problems of his re-election campaign, conferred at lunch today with two of his top political advisers about travel plans, opinion polls and the debate with Democrats over taxes.

title: STEROID USE LAID TO SOME MEDALISTS
description: More than a dozen Olympic athletes who used banned anabolic steroids have won medals during the current Games, but they escaped detection because they stopped taking the drugs several months ago, a controversial physician who prescribes steroids contended today.

title: AROUND THE NATION ; Spraying for Fruit Flies Expanded in Miami Area
description: Helicopters will spray pesticide on opulent waterfront homes on islands in Biscayne Bay because two Mediterranean fruit flies were discovered at the nearby Port of Miami, officials said today.

title: CAN THE U.S. REMAIN NO. 1?
description: HAS the United States been slipping as the world's leading industrial power? Worries on that score persist despite the recent upsurge of the American economy and the strength of the dollar.

title: JESSE OWENS: A MONUMENT STIRS REGRETS
description: By Therman White's reckoning, three or four visitors a day make their way to this tiny crossroad, past the overgrown pastures and tumbledown houses, in search of the vacant lot where the citizens of Alabama have raised a lonely granite monument to the memory of a native son named Jesse Owens.

title: CMT INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $81,000 for the quarter and $150,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes extraordinary gains of $340,000 for the quarter and $576,000 for the 6 months.

title: JOHNNY CARSON SUING THE NATIONAL ENQUIRER
description: Johnny Carson sued The National Enquirer Wednesday for $51 million, claiming the tabloid weekly printed a bogus article about the settlement in his divorce from his third wife.

title: Jets Sign Carmichael as Wide Receiver
description: Harold Carmichael, the 6-foot-8-inch wide receiver who starred as a Philadelphia Eagle for 13 seasons, was picked up by the Jets today to bring experience to a depleted corps of wide-outs.

title: Cinema Verite View Of a Brooklyn Boxing Gym
description: With all the uproar about professional boxing in recent years, it has been easy to overlook the sport's positive aspects, many of which have to do with boxing gyms. It is in these often crowded, sometimes airless rooms that many young men continue to climb off the streets, gain the respect of people who care and commit themselves to a discipline and a dream.

title: MANITOWOC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Required Reading;  Strategic Buttons
description: Lionel H. Olmer, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, in a speech before the World Electronics Conference, London, June 24:

title: Archery ; ; U.S. Leads After 2 Days
description: Darrell Pace and Rick McKinney of the United States expanded their leads over the rest of the men's field in archery today, the second of four days of competition. McKinney said that his countryman was almost out of reach.

title: INSURANCE PRICE WARS EASING
description: Price wars in commercial insurance rates, which have generated huge underwriting losses for the nation's property-casualty insurance industry, appear to be easing.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, has appointed Edward F. Truschke to the post of senior vice president, social policy.

title: Kite and 3 Others Tied
description: Tom Kite, who missed the cut in last week's PGA Tour event, shot a six-under-par 66 today and pulled into four-way tie for the early lead in the first round of the Buick Open, the final tuneup for the Professional Golfers' Association Championship next week.

title: SMOTHERS BROTHERS GIVE A TOUR OF POLITICAL ADS
description: POLITICS is everywhere on television, along with analysis, commentary and excessive intellectualization. ''And If I'm Elected . . . '' is a fine counterweight. It is funny without being absurd, and serious without being solemn. It is also apt for this election year. The half-hour program examines political advertising over the last 50 years, and finds most of it wanting. This Home Box Office special, with Tom and Dick Smothers as hosts, will be shown tomorrow at 10:30 P.M.

title: REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT PROPERTY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $695,137 for the quarter and year from the sale of property.

title: BRIEFING;
description: Ranking the Admirals

title: SENATE AND HOUSE UNABLE TO AGREE ON SALVADOR AID
description: The Senate and House failed to agree tonight on a compromise military aid increase to El Salvador this year.

title: POLKA SINGER IN JERSEY
description: Marion Lush, who sang his way into the Polka Hall of Fame, will appear tonight at the All American Polka Fest, a three-day event at Action Park in Vernon, N.J. Also scheduled to appear this weekend are Jimmy Sturr and his Orchestra, the Kryger Brothers, Chicago Push, the Brass Connection and the Matusz Dance Girls.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE forlorn Hudson River piers in Lower Manhattan have little in common with Biloxi, Miss., or with New Orleans, but that hasn't deterred the owners of Gulf Coast, a convivial new Louisiana-style restaurant at the corner of West and 12th Streets. It takes a fertile imagination to partake of the illusion that you are deep in Dixie - the dining room's view takes in traffic, docks and the Jersey City skyline - but if you are looking for a casual evening and some exceptionally spicy food, this is a good choice.

title: OFFICER IN JERSEY SLAIN BY GUNMAN WITH A POINT-BLANK SHOTGUN BLAST
description: A 41- year-old police officer died this morning after being shot ''without the slightest justification,'' according to the Essex County Prosecutor. A 21-year- old man surrendered two hours after the shooting Wednesday night and was charged with murder.

title: JAPAN'S DRIVE TO AUTOMATE
description: Japanese companies, though strong in making computers and telephone systems, are only beginning to link the systems together for maximum use, as advanced companies in the United States have done.

title: Stockman's Mother Runs
description: Carol Stockman, mother of David A. Stockman, the United States budget director, has won the Republican nomination for Berrien County treasurer, a seat she sought unsuccessfully 16 years ago. Mrs. Stockman, 56 years old, defeated the incumbent treasurer, William Hein by 127 votes.

title: STANDEX INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ISRAELI VOTERS' REAFFIRMATION OF DEMOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME COMPUTERS LAG, TOO
description: Shinichiro Takagi dialed a telephone number, put the phone in a coupler and watched as his computer screen sprang to life. ''Welcome to the Personal Computer Telecommunications Network!!!'' it said, followed by a stream of English and Japanese characters.

title: STATUE OF LIBERTY SHOW
description: ''Restoring Liberty: A Bright Future for an Old Flame,'' an exhibition detailing the restoration being done on the Statue of Liberty, is on view through Sept. 14 at the Municipal Art Society's Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street. Free. Monday through Saturday, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.; closed Sundays. The exhibition is produced by the society and the French-American Committee. Information: 935-3960

title: CLOROX CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a one-time after-tax gain of approximately $2,650,000, or 10 cents a share.

title: SCREEN: A MAGNANI BIOGRAPHY
description: ''MY NAME IS ANNA MAGNANI,'' the first feature film directed by Chris Vermorcken, a Belgian woman, is an adequate but not particularly illuminating documentary on the life and work of the now-legendary Italian actress who died in 1973. The best thing about it is that it can be seen - at the Thalia, starting today - on a double bill with Roberto Rossellini's ''Open City,'' which contains one of the greatest of all Magnani performances.

title: Attendance Put At 4.5 Million
description: The Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee announced today that the attendance through Wednesday was 4,541,575. Official reports indicate that the 1972 Games in Munich had the previous highest total, 4,435,583.

title: EDGCOMB STEEL OF NEW ENGAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that results do not include any effect from the operations of Edgcomb Metals which was acquired on June 29.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Continental Corp. Elects President
description: John H. Bretherick Jr. has been elected president of the Continental Corporation, the nation's eighth largest property and casualty insurance company, it was announced yesterday.

title: Royal Dutch Net Up 13.2% By United Press International The Royal Dutch/Shell
description: Group reported yesterday that

title: Posner Trial Date Is Set
description: A Federal judge today set Dec. 10 as the date for a tax-evasion trial for Victor Posner.

title: EXPOS END CUBS' STREAK AT 6
description: Andre Dawson's two-out single scored Tim Raines from third base in the 10th inning tonight, and Dan Schatzeder pitched a four-hitter, striking out 11 and lifting the Montreal Expos to a 1-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: FOREST OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONTINENTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PEOPLE EXPRESS OUTLINES CHICAGO FARES
description: People Express, the discount air carrier, yesterday made its expected bid for a share of the hotly contested New York-Chicago airline market, triggering at least one big competitor to lower its fares.

title: Chemical Arms Draft Denounced by Russian
description: A top Soviet negotiator denounced a United States draft treaty banning chemical weapons today, saying its terms were unacceptable and unrealistic and could cause international conflicts.

title: U.S. SURE OF SILVER OR BETTER IN POLO
description: A goal by Doug Burke with 26 seconds to play gave the United States a dramatic 8-7 victory over West Germany today and assured the Americans at least a silver medal in water polo.

title: LEAR SIEGLER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest quarter and year figures include operating results of the Bangor Punta Corp., which was acquired Feb. 1.

title: HCW Purchases
description: HCW Oil and Gas Inc. said its HCW Oil Income Funds had signed preliminary agreements to buy proven producing oil and natural gas properties for about $47 million.

title: Woman Is KilledIn Jump off Bridge
description: A woman was killed yesterday afternoon when she jumped from the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge into the East River after being talked out of taking her 4-year-old son with her, the police said.

title: GARBAGE CAN BOMB KILLS 3 IN BEIRUT
description: A bomb concealed in a garbage can exploded today in Moslem West Beirut, killing 3 people and wounding 15. Within minutes, armed militiamen rushed into the streets to assert control.

title: AMERICAN BANKERS INSURNCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $698,000 for the quarter and $1,034,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes realized investment gains of $91,000 for the quarter and $102,000 for the 6 months.

title: BROADWAY
description: -year-old performer, whose blend of standup comedy, political satire and straight theater has been seen primarily in fringe clubs and theaters, is being brought to the Lyceum Theater by Mike Nichols, Emanuel Azenberg and the Shubert Organization. Rehearsals for the new two-hour show, ''Whoopi Goldberg Variations,'' will start next month, and performances will begin Oct. 6.

title: CATHOLICS URGED TO PRESS VIEWS HELD BY CHURCH
description: America's Roman Catholic bishops released a statement yesterday urging Catholics to press the church's positions on public policy issues but also urging the clergy to avoid supporting political candidates.

title: SAUL, B.F. REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income including gains from the sale of properties of $1,440,000 for the quarter and $8,644,000 for the 9 months and tax credits of $594,000 for the quarter and $3,362,000 for the 9 months. c-Including a gain of $136,000 from the sale of property.

title: A $560 Million Bid By IC for Pneumo
description: IC Industries, in a move that would increase its military business sharply, said yesterday that it had signed an agreement to buy the Pneumo Corporation for about $560 million in cash and stock.

title: FOOTE, CONE & BELDING COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CENSUS OFFICIALS AND DEMOCRATS DIFFER ON WHY POVERTY RATE IS UP
description: Census Bureau officials and Democratic members of Congress clashed today over whether Reagan Administration policies were responsible for the increase in the national poverty rate reported in the last three years.

title: Foote, Cone
description: Earnings Off Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc., which is predicting a better than 35 percent

title: ; Yugoslav Upsets Horvath
description: Sabrina Goles of Yugoslavia stunned top-seeded Kathy Horvath of the United States, 6-2, 7-6, in women's tennis today to gain the semifinals.

title: A YEAR LATER, BLACKOUT UNEXPLAINED
description: A year after a water-main break caused a three-day blackout in the garment center during one of its busiest weeks, the cause of the break is still unknown. And the lawsuits against Consolidated Edison and the city to determine who should pay damages have not yet been heard.

title: HEALTH EXTENSION SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. CRIME: NO END IN SIGHT TO WRONG NUMBERS
description: To the Editor:

title: ;  Capital Movement
description: Jack Kent Cooke , owner of the Redskins, is trying to get involved in another major league way in Washington. Cooke says he has applied to the National League for an expansion franchise in the capital, which has been without a baseball team since the Senators left for Texas after the 1971 season.

title: Waldenbooks Sold
description: The K Mart Corporation said it had completed its acquisition of Waldenbooks from Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. for $295 million. K Mart said that Waldenbooks, which operates 845 bookstores, would be run as a separately managed company, and that Patrick Padden Jr., who has been K Mart director for new business development, would become executive vice president of Waldenbooks. Carter Hawley, which is based in Los Angeles, said again that it expected second-quarter results to include an after-tax gain of about $60 million on the sale.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ; ;  Dean's Demands
description: The off-the-field complexities of the sports world these days continue to keep lawyers busy and the fans wondering about more than the final score. A case in point concerns Fred Dean , the veteran defensive end whose 17 1/2 sacks led the National Football Conference last season.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ; Queen Elizabeth II Invited to Visit China
description: The Government said today that it had invited Queen Elizabeth II to visit China, in what would be the first trip by a British sovereign to a Communist country.

title: 2D-YEAR GIANT GETS A CHANCE
description: It wasn't until 6 o'clock this morning, while he was lying in bed, that Robbie Jones realized that there was a kind of irony in the Giants' next exhibition, this Saturday night in Indianapolis against the Colts.

title: 'BRUTALITY' CHARGED TO U.S. BROTHERS
description: The brothers Dave and Mark Schultz, former collegiate champions from Oklahoma, were accused of ''excessive brutality'' in their Olympic matches today, and a special official was assigned to monitor the rest of their bouts.

title: GROWTH FUND COMEBACK
description: EDWARD J. MATHIAS, president of the T. Rowe Price New Horizons Fund, avoids forecasting the future direction of the stock market, but he flashes a money manager's smile in assessing the recent explosive rally in equities. ''It was as if someone had put a match to a tinderbox,'' he said yesterday.

title: HOME OWNERS FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The association became publicly owned in June following an initial offering of 1,343,219 shares. The share earnings for the latest periods are on a pro forma basis.

title: MODIGLIANI DREDGERS FIND 3D SCULPTURE
description: Experts recovered a third sculpture head today from the Royal Canal, where Amedeo Modigliani is said to have thrown some of his work 75 years ago.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ; Colombia Signs Truce With Second Rebel Ring
description: The Colombian rebel group known as M-19 and the Bogota Government plan to sign a truce Sunday to end one of Latin America's oldest insurgencies, guerrilla and Colombian Embassy spokesmen said here today.

title: Chesebrough Buys Icahn Stake
description: Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. said it had repurchased 1.8 million of its shares from Carl Icahn, the investor, and agreed to acquire the Polymer Corporation from ACF Industries Inc., a company controlled by Mr. Icahn. The share purchase, which represented about a 5 percent stake in the company, was made at $38.125 a share, which was Tuesday's closing price for the stock on the New York Stock Exchange. Today, Chesebrough-Pond's closed at $35.125, down 87.5 cents.

title: BOULEVARDIER'S GUIDE TO OUTDOOR CAFES
description: NEITHER smog nor heat nor threat of rain nor honking traffic will stay New Yorkers from their appointed weekend rounds of outdoor cafes - and this summer the choices are greater than ever. Stretches of Columbus Avenue, the Upper East Side and Greenwich Village are beginning to resemble Jones Beach as umbrellas pop up on sidewalks and terraces, in gardens and plazas.

title: IN EUROPE, CAFE GIVING WAY TO TV
description: Though still some way from its full potential in New York, the cafe elsewhere is an endangered species. Even in Paris, heartland of such places, the number of cafes has declined since television began to keep older people at home and younger people came to prefer something more jazzy. (Even the Cafe de la Regence, where Jean-Jacques Rousseau used to play chess, is no more.)

title: People
description: * Marlene R. Dale and H. James Ritts 3d have been named senior vice presidents of Dancer Fitzgerald Sample.

title: POLAND FREES A KEY DISSIDENT
description: Jacek Kuron, the most prominent of the Solidarity supporters imprisoned under martial law in December 1981, was freed today under the Government's recent amnesty.

title: ALTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After gains on the redemption of debentures of $71,000 for the quarter and $108,000 for the 9 months.

title: Roland Kibbee Is Dead at 70; Won Three Emmys for Writing
description: Roland Kibbee, a writer who won three Emmys in a career that spanned radio, feature films and television, died of cancer Sunday at Encino Hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: BELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ARTIFICIAL VALVES FOR HEARTS SAID TO HAVE WELDING FAULTS
description: A tool design engineer who worked on the manufacture of artificial valves for human hearts said today that many of them had welding faults that could lead to death-causing fractures.

title: ENGINEERED SYSTEMS & DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AHMANSON, H.F. & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Workers Back Kroger Offer
description: Clerks and cashiers at 70 closed Kroger Company stores in southeastern Michigan voted overwhelmingly to accept a new company offer they hoped would be a step toward reopening more than half the stores, a union official said.

title: NO KARAJAN IN BERLIN RECORDING PACT
description: The Berlin Philharmonic will make a series of recordings for CBS Masterworks later this month without its celebrated conductor, Herbert von Karajan.

title: Freed Killer GuiltyIn Assault Case
description: Willie Bosket Jr., whose slaying of two subway passengers in 1978 led to stiffer penalties for juveniles who kill, was convicted yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan of attempted assault.

title: OPPONENT OF HATFIELD IN OREGON QUESTIONS THE SENATOR'S PRIORITIES
description: A Democratic state legislator running against United States Senator Mark O. Hatfield said today that the Senator's assistance to a Greek entrepreneur ''raises many questions about the kind of representation Oregon has been receiving'' in Congress.

title: ART: DRAWINGS BY 77, FROM 1900 TO THE PRESENT
description: THE walls of the Forum Gallery, 1018 Madison Avenue, at 79th Street, are packed as tight with drawings as 19th- century salons were with paintings. And well they might be, for the show they present numbers 77 artists, 22 of them with two or more works each.

title: IS IT SPORTSDRAMA OR OBJECTIVE NEWS?
description: One day last week Jim McKay, the evening anchor for ABC's Olympic coverage, thrilled at one point by a particular American victory, said, ''If I said I was an objective reporter I'd be lying through my teeth.''

title: COMMODORE POSTS 24% RISE
description: Commodore International, a manufacturer of microcomputer systems, said yesterday that earnings in the fiscal fourth quarter, ended June 30, rose 24 percent as sales soared 41.7 percent.

title: LILCO AND STRIKING UNIONS REACH ACCORD
description: The Long Island Lighting Company and the unions representing the 3,900 Lilco employees who have been on strike since July 10 reached a tentative contract settlement yesterday.

title: TRANS-LUX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Nautical Setting On Lower Fifth
description: LESLIE REVSIN has been on the move since she made history in 1972 as the first woman chef at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. After a stint at P. S. 77 and several other Manhattan restaurants, she opened her own place, then moved on to 24 Fifth Avenue and the Bridge Cafe. For the last two months, she has been running the kitchen at One Fifth and putting her personal stamp on the menus. And she is cooking better than ever.

title: TRIMAC LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RIOTING ERUPTS ACROSS ULSTER
description: Masked youths fought with policemen in four cities today and at least 60 people were arrested, the police said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Chicago & North Western Transportation Co. said it had signed a long-term contract with Northern States Power Co., of Minneapolis, calling for delivery of a minimum of one million tons a year of low-sulphur coal to electric generating facilities in Minneapolis-St. Paul.

title: PHILADELPHIA JURY GETS POLICE CORRUPTION CASE
description: A Federal jury began its deliberations today on seven former police officers whom prosecutors described as having corrupted their law-enforcement units into an ''enterprise'' devoted to extortion and bribery.

title: THE SCREEN: 'DAGGER', SPY GAMES
description: THE last thing we need right now is another movie about a boy caught up in the world of computer games - but ''Cloak and Dagger,'' while fitting that mold, is clever and enjoyable anyhow. Some of its success is attributable to Henry Thomas's ability to make the film's game-obsessed hero absolutely convincing; Mr. Thomas appears to have taken his character, Davey Osborne, every bit as seriously as Davey takes the game of the title. But the movie's secret weapon is Dabney Coleman, who looks very dull and suburban in his role as Davey's father - and very racy in his

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: PEOPLE born between July 23

title: CORRECTION
description: A Reuters dispatch in the Finance/ New Issues column of Business Day on Wednesday misidentified the lead underwriter for a Euronote financing by a subsidiary of the Atlantic Financial Federal Savings and Loan Association in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. It was Banque Paribas.

title: MASSACHUSETTS TOWN ROCKED BY VIOLENCE FOR A SECOND NIGHT
description: Crowds of white and Hispanic residents battled each other with rocks, bottles and firebombs in a rundown neighborhood for the second night tonight as the police tried to quell the melee with tear gas.

title: Money Funds Assets Decrease $1.3 Billion
description: The assets of the nation's 333 money market mutual funds declined $1.3 billion, to $179.08 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: BILL IN SENATE WOULD PROTECT WORKERS WHO ALLEGE WASTE
description: Legislation aimed at increasing protection for workers who allege waste or fraud in Government agencies was introduced in the Senate today.

title: U.S. SAYS RED SEA MINE UNIT GETS SET TO SAIL
description: Preparations for deploying United States minesweeping helicopters in the Red Sea are well advanced, with the Navy ready to move them from its base at Rota, Spain, within the next few days, the Department of Defense said today.

title: HEALTH-CHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $246,000 for the quarter and $876,000 for the 6 months; after a gain of $4,940,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations and a tax credit of $96,000, all for the quarter and 6 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $800,000 for the quarter and $1,368,000 for the 6 months.

title: U.P.I. LOOKING FOR NEW CASH
description: United Press International Inc., the financially troubled news service that changed hands in 1982 after many years of unprofitability, is seeking investment capital to meet a projected operating deficit of nearly $7 million in 1984, according to confidential company documents being circulated to prospective investors.

title: EL CHICO CORP reports earnings for Year to June 1
description: b-Comparable year-ago results are not available. Until November 1982, El Chico Corp. was wholly owned by another company.

title: F.C.C. DELAYS CHANGING ITS TV OWNERSHIP RULE
description: The Federal Communications Commission, yielding to opposition from Congress, reversed itself today and voted unanimously to delay a rule that would have allowed expanded ownership of television stations.

title: Swiss Price Increases
description: Swiss wholesale prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in July and were up 3.4 percent from a year earlier, the Government said today.

title: GULF AMERICAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain from discontinued operations of $15,000.

title: Topics; Civil Wrongs; Highway Law Repair
description: Congress has halfway made it possible for New York and other cities with old Interstate highways to live with its inflexible 1982 highway law. The law demands that states, no matter what their safety rules, allow huge double-trailer trucks on all Interstates.

title: HARCOURT BRACE JOVANOVICH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Malaysian action is reminiscent of the book-burning by the Nazi regime and should have been resisted and rejected by the Philharmonic. The only self-respecting action that should have been taken by the orchestra was to refuse to perform in Malaysia if the Malaysians seek to tell the orchestra what music to play.'' - Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations

title: Add Blacks and Women, Jackson Urges Mondale
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson says that his ''enthusiasm level will be nil'' if Walter F. Mondale has not appointed more blacks and women to his campaign by Labor Day.

title: NOVO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SCOUTING;
description: Jumping Horses Harder to Find

title: HIGH U.S. OFFICIAL ACCUSED OF TAKING $64,000 IN PAYOFFS
description: The deputy regional administrator of the United States General Services Administration was arrested on a Manhattan street yesterday after he pocketed a $4,000 bribe from a businessman whose company sold supplies to the Government, Federal authorities said.

title: Korean Semiconductors
description: South Korea's semiconductor exports increased 56 percent, to $577 million, in the first half of this year from the period a year earlier, the Korea Electronics Promotion Association said today. It said the United States accounted for 48 percent of the total. For the year, semiconductor exports should total $1.08 billion, up 27 percent from $850 million a year ago, the agency added.

title: THE MISSING DESK: MYSTERY AND MORALITY TALE
description: Mayor Raymond L. Flynn, in office since January, still doesn't have a desk. He has a comfortable couch, a coffee table to prop his feet on, a bust of John F. Kennedy given to him by the President's widow, and a brand new Mario Cuomo poster. But he has no desk.

title: DIVING ; ; Chinese Lead in Platform
description: Two Chinese divers, Zhou Jihong and Chen Xiaoxia, finished 1, 2 today in qualifying for Friday's women's platform final. Twelve women made the eight-dive medal competition.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HARLEM CELEBRATES ITSELF WITH A WEEK
description: It started nine years ago as Harlem Day. Now, it has expanded and become Harlem Week, celebrating with cultural, athletic and other activities the existence of the internationally known 78-year-old black community. Although Harlem is undergoing dramatic change, it is taking time out to look back.

title: FILM: 'RED DAWN,' ON WORLD WAR III
description: TO any sniveling lily-livers who suppose that John Milius, having produced ''Uncommon Valor,'' directed ''Conan the Barbarian'' and written ''Apolcalypse Now,'' has already reached the pinnacle of movie-making machismo, a warning: Mr. Milius's ''Red Dawn'' is more rip-roaring than anything he has done before. Here is Mr. Milius at his most alarming, delivering a rootin'-tootin' scenario for World War III.

title: FRIDAY, AUGUST 10, 1984 International
description: The election of Jose Napoleon Duarte as President of El Salvador has at least temporarily swung Congress behind President Reagan's policy toward that country, according to several lawmakers. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, in a highly unusual statement on Teheran radio, denounced the reported mining of the Red Sea and criticized Teheran radio, which is run by his own Government, for implying sympathy for the actions. The Iranian leader also denied that Iran had been involved in recent airline hijackings. The Ayatollah's statement was seen by diplomats and Iranian exiles as a new indication of political conflicts within Iran's leadership. (A1:3-4.)

title: SHIP-IN-BOTTLE TIPS
description: Ship-in-a-bottle techniques will be demonstrated Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Whaling Museum, on Main Street in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. Hours are 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily. Admission is $1; 75 cents for those 6 to 14, and the elderly. Information: (516) 367-3418.

title: No Headline
description: A Fair Offer

title: Amcast Contract
description: The Amcast Industrial Corporation said it had received a three-year agreement valued at $100 million to supply aluminum parts for air-conditioning compressors for the Harrison Radiator division of the General Motors Corporation. Amcast said the supply contract is for the complete line of air-conditioning compressors that Harrison assembles for all G.M. cars and trucks.

title: THE MYOPIA OF HUMAN RIGHTS ADVOCATES
description: In my post, I constantly encounter representatives of human rights groups whose strong feelings about human rights abuses in the world is manifest and at times moving. Too often, however, the depths of their analysis does not match the depth of their emotion - and the consequences can be harmful to human rights.

title: Texas Sues Over Oil Spill
description: The State of Texas filed a lawsuit today asking a Federal District Court to assess damages and cleanup costs against owners and operators of a British tanker that spilled 1.9 million gallons of crude oil in the Gulf of Mexico. The complaint, filed in Galveston, did not specify the amount of damages.

title: DIVIDED HOUSE PANEL BALKS ON FERRARO BID FOR WIDER MAILING RIGHTS
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro has received thousands of letters from all over the country since her nomination as the Democratic candidate for Vice President. But House Republicans today tried to make her Congressional office a dead-letter drop, at least politically.

title: AN ILL-CHOSEN GREEK SITE FOR THE OLYMPICS
description: To the Editor:

title: Northrop Award
description: The Northrop Corporation said it had received a $96 million contract from the Lockheed Corporation's Missile and Space Company subsidiary to provide equipment to test missile parts for the Trident II program. Northrop said the units, to be built at its Electro-Mechanical division here, would test parts for operational readiness before the parts are loaded on Trident missiles. Delivery will begin in 1986.

title: 2 ARE OVERCOME BY TOXIC FUMES AND DIE ON L.I.
description: Two men cleaning a cesspool behind a Howard Johnson's restaurant on Long Island died yesterday after they were overcome by toxic fumes, the police said.

title: From Glen Island Casino, A Glenn Miller Anniversary
description: To mark the 40th anniversary of the

title: Conservative LawyerIs Confirmed as Judge
description: J. Harvie Wilkinson 3d, a conservative, 39-year-old Virginia law professor, won Senate confirmation today for an appointment to a Federal appellate court despite charges that he had conducted an ''intense and unprecedented lobbying campaign'' for the judgeship. The vote was 58 to 39.

title: ELDORADO MOTOR reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $224,423 for the quarter and $896,032 for the year.

title: SABINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a net gain of $278,000 from the sale of non-oil and non-gas assets. c-Including a net gain of $17.9 million from the sale of Canadian operations.
