title: DMG INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $225,000. c-Net loss.

title: AROUND THE NATION ; Chicago Suburb Ponders Cash-Backed Integration
description: The Chicago suburb of Oak Park is considering offering cash incentives to tenants and landlords to integrate apartment buildings and keep the community ''racially diverse,'' officials say.

title: Transamerica Has More Hershey Oil
description: The Transamerica Corporation and three subsidiaries told the Securities and Exchange Commission that they had increased their holdings in the Hershey Oil Corporation to 1,676,500 shares, or 29.2 percent of the total outstanding.

title: No Headline
description: Giants Back Has Tumor PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y. Aug. 9 - The Giants announced today

title: BRIEFING;
description: Recognition, as a Cost

title: 2 FOOTRACES PLANNED IN CENTRAL PARK
description: Two races sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club will take place this weekend in Central Park.

title: Combustion Plans To Shut Foundry
description: Combustion Engineering Inc. said it would close its foundry here because contract talks with United Steelworkers Local 210 have ''reached an impasse.''

title: ;  New Role for Miller
description: Buddy LeRoux , on his way out as a partner in the Boston Red Sox, has hired Marvin Miller to work with an appraiser in determining the value of LeRoux's share in the team. For their part in the appraisal work, Jean Yawkey and Haywood Sullivan , who recently beat back LeRoux's effort to gain control of the team from them in the courts, have hired Tal Smith , former president and general manager of the Houston Astros.

title: IRAQI PLANES ATTACK IRANIAN OIL PLATFORM TO BACK BLOCKADE
description: Iraqi warplanes attacked and damaged an Iranian oil-loading platform in the Persian Gulf today, the second air strike in two days supporting Iraq's declared blockade of Iranian oil ports.

title: EQUESTRIAN TEAM IS JUMPING FOR JOY
description: Equestrian sports are different in the Olympics because each entry consists of two animals, the human and the horse. A good rider is not enough, and a good horse is not enough; there must also be a good chemistry between the two.

title: CITY OPERA: FOUR NEW VOICES IN 'BARBER OF SEVILLE'
description: WHEN the New York City Opera opened its summer season last month, a new production of ''The Barber of Seville'' was the showcase offering. It proved to be a misdirected venture, loaded down with lame and humorless stage business that consistently bled the score of its effectiveness. Luckily, Beverly Sills, the company's general director, knew a fiasco when she saw one. Under her goading, the Toby Robertson staging has been was stripped down to its essentials and, to judge from Wednesday evening's performance, transmuted into an enjoyable, if still not inspired, version of Rossini's sturdy farce.

title: TEMCO SERVICE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $7,250 from reduction of a foreign tax credit. c-Including a tax credit of $13,050.

title: BRIEFING;
description: Kasten's Bid for Whip

title: 4 TROUPES TO DANCE
description: Four Brooklyn dance companies, members of the Brooklyn Dance Consortium, will perform Sunday at 2 P.M. in Brooklyn's Empire-Fulton Ferry State Park, between the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges.

title: WHITE HOUSE TIGHTENS ITS CONTROL OVER REPUBLICANS' PALTFORM
description: The White House is making a great effort to control the writing of the Republican campaign platform and tamp down any dissent that might mar the unity of the party convention when it renominates President Reagan in Dallas later this month.

title: Ferraro Names Nine To Campaign Staff
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro announced nine appointments today to make blacks, women and Hispanic advisers prominent participants in her campaign for Vice President.

title: The Laws On Cafes
description: The Department of Consumer Affairs has issued licenses to 281 sidewalk cafes, both enclosed and open air.

title: Racing Judge Disputed
description: An attorney for one of four harness drivers accused of keeping their horses out of the money in a race at Monticello on July 1 gained an admission yesterday that Joseph Romano Jr.'s strategy had not varied from seven previous races with the same horse, including one in which he had finished first a couple of months earlier.

title: VMX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $470,000 for the quarter and $1,361,000 for the year.

title: MEYERS PARKING SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid in June.

title: HI-G INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $112,000. c-Net loss

title: WESCO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $6,545,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the sale of stock. c-Including gains of $157,000 for the quarter and $2,046,000 for the 6 months from the sale of stock.

title: WORKING PROFILE: Lawton Chiles
description: MOVING FOR VISIBILITY ON KEY ISSUES

title: Turner May Compete Against MTV
description: The Turner Broadcasting Company said yesterday that it was considering starting a rock video network to compete with MTV Networks Inc.

title: No Plans for Bearer Bonds WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP)
description: The Treasury Department

title: 'YOU WILL!' 'I WON'T!'
description: President Reagan and the Democratic candidate, Walter Mondale, have established the first subject for campaign debates, which the White House must know cannot be avoided.

title: EUROPEANS AND LATINS TO DISCUSS CLOSER TIES
description: West Germany reported today that foreign ministers from Western Europe and Latin America would meet in Costa Rica next month to discuss broader political and economic cooperation.

title: BLUEGRASS IN BROOKLYN
description: Three free bluegrass and country music performances are planned this weekend as part of the ''Celebrate Brooklyn'' series at the bandshell in Brooklyn's Prospect Park, Prospect Park West and Ninth Street.

title: MOTOR CLUB OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $250,000 for the quarter and $888,000 for the 6 months. c-Including gains from discontinued operations of $71,209 for the quarter and $88,652 for the 6 months and tax credits of $853,000 for the quarter and $1,141,000 for the 6 months.

title: CRITICIZES THE GOVERNMENT RADIO
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini today denounced the reported mining of the Red Sea and criticized the official Teheran radio - which is controlled by his own Government - for having implied that it supported the planting of mines.

title: HOSPITAL WALKOUT: GOVERNOR STEPS IN
description: Shortly after New York City's hospital and nursing-home strike began on July 13, Governor Cuomo said the state would provide no new funds to achieve a settlement.

title: Topics ; Civil Wrongs; WHEN JUDGES BELONG
description: How bad is it for a judge to belong to private clubs that discriminate by race, sex, religion or national origin? The Association of the Bar of the City of New York argues forcefully that it's downright unethical and should be forbidden by the American Bar Association's Code of Judicial Conduct.

title: HARPER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CENTURY TELEPHONE ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Prime Rate Cut in Canada
description: The Royal Bank of Canada, the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and the Bank of Montreal, the nation's three largest banks, today lowered their prime lending rates one-half percentage point, to 13 percent.

title: USLIFE INCOME FUND CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Including net realized gains from security transactions of $126,506, or 3 cents a share, for the latest year and $2,885,561, or 57 cents a share, for the previous year. Net income figures represent net investment income.

title: ADAMS RESOURCES & ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $945,000 for the quarter and $1,151,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $472,000 for the quarter and $1,278,000 for the 6 months.

title: PAPP GOES LATIN AT THE PUBLIC
description: THE fourth Festival Latino de Nuevo York gets under way today, bringing 450 performers, directors and other theater folk together at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, near Astor Place, for an outpouring of the arts as celebrated in Spain and Latin America and by the Hispanic peoples of the United States.

title: SPORTS FANS CONVENING
description: Bobby Thomson, the former New York Giant, is among the baseball players who will appear this weekend at the National Sports Collectors Convention in the Aspen Hotel, on Route 46 West in Parsippany, N.J. He will sign autographs Sunday from 9 to 11 A.M. Eddie Lopat, Johnny Kucks and Gene Hermanski will be there this weekend also.

title: BRIEFING;
description: Stars for Dallas Show

title: CANADA IS EDGED BY U.S. PAIR
description: At first, she would not say anything on the subject, and then Kelly Kryczka of Canada said all the things that a disappointed silver medalist is supposed to say.

title: SOVIET UNION, CITING INEFFICENCY, GROUNDS ITS SUPERSONIC AIRLINER
description: The Soviet Union's supersonic jetliner, which opened its passenger service with an ear-splitting roar from a snowy airfield six and a half years ago, has been grounded, a Soviet official confirmed today.

title: PENSION MEASURE AIDING WOMEN GOES TO REAGAN
description: The House today gave final approval to legislation that would make it easier for women to earn pension beneifts.

title: Hallmark-Binney
description: Hallmark Cards Inc. has completed its $204 million acquisition of Binney & Smith Inc., the makers of Crayola- brand crayons and other art products, the companies said.

title: AROUND THE NATION ; Philadelphia Officers In Inquiry on Dog Use
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode called on the District Attorney's office today to investigate whether any crimes were committed by police K-9 officers whose dogs reportedly attacked unarmed men and women.

title: CUOMO VETOES RENT-REGULATION COMPROMISE
description: Legislation giving the state, rather than a landlord group, authority to write regulations for nearly one million tenants of rent-stabilized apartments in New York City has been vetoed by Governor Cuomo over the objection of tenant groups.

title: FILM: 'PHAR LAP,' TALE OF AUSTRALIAN RACE HORSE
description: THE movie ''Phar Lap'' is as much of a crowd pleaser as the champion Australian race horse for whom it is named. In a gently rousing style that should appeal in equal measure to adults and children, it tells of the rise of this legendary prize winner, who was something of a four-legged Rocky. ''Phar Lap'' isn't a surprising movie; it has too much dialogue on the order of ''That horse is going to be a champion - can't anyone understand that? He's going to be a champion!'' for that. But in its own way, it's a winner.

title: Dining Out Guide: By the Water
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: Page Petroleum Change
description: Lawton L. Clark, president of Page Petroleum Ltd. since its formation in 1971, said yesterday that he would retire from the company effective Oct. 1 to pursue other business interests. The company, which is based in Calgary, Alberta, said Mr. Clark's duties would be assumed by Donald D. McCuaig, chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Clark, who is Page's largest shareholder, will continue as a director.

title: Debt Ratings
description: Ideal Basic Industries' ratings on senior debt and industrial revenue bonds were lowered to BB-, from BBx, by Standard & Poor's.

title: Topics ; Civil Wrongs ; Firing and Hiring
description: Last October President Reagan nearly killed the United States Commission on Civil Rights, an independent watchdog agency, by firing half its members because they disagreed with his civil rights policies. The commission was saved only after Congress enlarged its membership from six to eight, protected the tenure of the members and divided appointment responsibilities between Congress and the White House.

title: SERVICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Coastal Corp. Offering $600 Million of Notes
description: The Coastal Corporation is offering $600 million of subordinated exchangeable variable-rate notes through Drexel Burnham Lambert as sole underwriter.

title: PUBLISHING: ENDOWMENT GIVES 4 WRITERS $25,000
description: THE National Endowment for the Arts has just awarded senior fellowships of $25,000 each to four American writers - Stanley Kunitz, the poet and translator; William Meredith, the poet and editor, and Peter Taylor and Richard Yates, short-story writers and novelists.

title: Briefing;
description: That Guy With Gerry?

title: EQUESTRIAN ; ; West Germans Triumph
description: Reiner Klimke rode a brilliant test on Ahlerich today, pulling West Germany past Switzerland and giving the German riders the Olympic gold medal in team dressage.

title: 4TH FESTIVAL OF 'FOLK' OPENS TODAY IN TIMES SQ.
description: BEFORE the first New York Folk Festival three years ago, folk festivals conjured up a picture of guitar-playing acoustic performers bound together by the tradition of Pete Seeger, Woody Guthrie, the Weavers and Odetta. And the music they made, if not strictly traditional in origins, had strong musical and spiritual ties to ''roots'' styles.

title: RONALD BROMLEY SMITH
description: Ronald Bromley Smith, a former executive of the M. W. Kellogg Company, an engineering and construction concern, died of a heart ailment Saturday at Indian River Memorial Hospital in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 76 years old.

title: CENTURI INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New Unemployment ClaimsDown by 33,000 in Late July
description: New applications for unemployment compensation totaled 347,000 in the week that ended July 28, down 33,000 from the preceding week, the Labor Department reported today.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES ; THE OTHER JURY
description: Los Angeles

title: CITY MAPS NEIGHBORHOODS BY COMPUTER TO HELP SAVE THEM FROM DECLINE
description: What looks like a cobalt-blue blob floating on the computer screen is, in fact, a map. An operator zooms in by tapping a button. The blob is large enough now to show the streets clearly. The operator draws a luminous green border around a six-block area. With another tap, the outlines of each building lot in that area jump to the screen.

title: SPAIN'S DEFENSE TEST FOR U.S.
description: The intense effort to re-establish an American dominance in men's basketball - a position that was taken for granted for decades - will reach its climax Friday night when the United States meets Spain with a chance to win its ninth gold medal and extend its Olympic record to 77-1.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about the financial value of Olympic athletes' gold medals misidentified the sources of photographs of Carl Lewis bought by The New York Times Magazine. They were Duomo, an agency specializing in sports photographs, and Paul Sutton.

title: Pearl Bailey to Perform At Republican Luncheon
description: Pearl Bailey will accompany Nancy Reagan to Dallas for the Republican National Convention and will sing at a luncheon for Republican women, Mrs. Reagan's press secretary says.

title: MR. GASKET CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DOW LOSES 6.04
description: In a renewed burst of energy yesterday, stocks moved sharply upward early in the day, but were pulled back amid profit taking and fresh fears that interest rates are rising.

title: LIBYAN ADMITS ILLEGALLY BUYING ARMS ON S.I.
description: A Libyan national who Federal authorities said had ''a direct link to Libyan Government officials'' admitted in a Brooklyn court yesterday that he had illegally bought three handguns with silencers from an undercover agent posing as an illicit arms dealer.

title: OVERDUE GOOD NEWS FOR CITY PENSIONERS
description: To the Editor:

title: EGYPT LINKS LIBYA AND IRAN TO MINES
description: President Hosni Mubarak said today that Iran and Libya might be responsible for the recent explosions that have damaged ships in the Red Sea. But he acknowledged that Egypt had no proof.

title: U.N. SWAN SONGS: ONE BITTER AND ONE SWEET
description: For Yehuda Z. Blum, Israel's chief representative here, the United Nations has been an arena of nearly constant hostility during his six-year assignment.

title: SENATE VOTES HIGHER LIMITS ON PUBLIC BROADCAST FUNDS
description: The Senate has passed and sent to President Reagan a bill that would increase the maximum spending authorization for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting for the rest of the decade.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10.

title: Olympia's Stake In Hiram Walker
description: Olympia & York Developments Ltd. increased its stake in Hiram Walker Ltd. to 9,151,413 common shares, or 12.7 percent of the shares outstanding, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: CANADIAN LIBERALS STUMBLE, BUT THE RACE GOES ON
description: Over the last week there have been increasing indications that Prime Minister John N. Turner's election campaign has faltered, while the fortunes of his challenger, Brian Mulroney, leader of the opposition Progressive Conservative Party, seem sharply on the rise.

title: FIELD HOCKEY ; ; Malaysians Edge U.S.
description: Malaysia's men's field hockey team outscored the United States, 9-8, in a shootout after a 3-3 tie in the regulation game to leave the American men with the wooden spoon, emblematic of last place in the tournament.

title: Businessman HurtIn Car Bombing
description: A 50-year-old businessman who faces charges of paying for a machine-gun attack on a gambler to whom he owed money was burned this morning when a bomb exploded in his car.

title: V.A. Lowers Mortgage Rates
description: Interest rates for basic home loans backed by the Veterans Administration will be lowered by one-half percentage point, to 13.5 percent, effective Monday, the agency announced yesterday.

title: SATURDAY, AUGUST 11, 1984 International
description: A compromise Salvadoran aid plan was approved by Congress. It would give El Salvador an extra $70 million in military assistance during the current fiscal year. Though below President Reagan's request for $117 million, the compromise represented a significant endorsement of his Administration's efforts to support the Government of President Jose Napoleon Duarte. (Page 1, Col. 6.) Concerts in Malaysia were dropped by the New York Philharmonic. It had scheduled two concerts in Kuala Lumpur from which, at the request of the Malaysian Government, a Hebrew-inspired work was to have been deleted. The work was Ernest Bloch's ''Schelomo, A Hebrew Rhapsody for Cello and Orchestra.'' The cancellation was announced after widespread protests from Jewish organizations and government officials. (1:5.)

title: F.D.A. TO INVESTIGATE ALLEGATIONS ABOUT ARTIFICIAL VALVES FOR HEARTS
description: The Food and Drug Administration said today that it would investigate the allegations of a tool design engineer who asserted that there were welding defects in some artificial valves for human hearts.

title: FOOD COSTS RISE
description: Prices at the producer level rose a moderate three-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Labor Department reported today.

title: ONE HARLEM, THEN THE OTHER
description: It's Harlem Week '84. Posters plastered on store windows uptown proclaim: ''A Decade of Progress . . . Much More to Do . . . A Better Harlem Is Up to Us.''

title: Richard Deacon Dead at 62;A Comic Film and TV Actor
description: Richard Deacon, an actor whose comically pompous roles included Lumpy Rutherford's father in the television series ''Leave It to Beaver'' and the overbearing producer Mel Cooley in ''The Dick Van Dyke Show,'' died here Wednesday. He was 62 years old.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 12.

title: DEPARTING CUOMO AIDE WAS NOT 'FRUSTRATED'
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-OFFICIAL OF SCHOOL SAYS IT SCREENED JEWS
description: A private academy screened its Jewish applicants by marking their applications with symbols shaped like bagels, its former personnel director says in a lawsuit.

title: WHO CAN SPEND $100,000 ON A HOME?
description: To the Editor:

title: PINOCHET'S PLEDGE TO STAY ON BRINGS SOME BITTER REACTIONS
description: Some political leaders and officials here have reacted angrily to a statement this week by the Chilean President, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, that he has no intention of hastening the country's transition to democracy.

title: CONGRESS PASSES EXTRA $70 MILLION IN AID TO SALVADOR
description: Congress approved a compromise today that would give El Salvador an extra $70 million in military aid in the current fiscal year.

title: THE DATE SEEKERS
description: To the Editor:

title: ;  Dolphin's Lost Season
description: Bob Kuechenberg, the offensive lineman who has been with the Miami Dolphins longer than any other player, said that an eye injury would force him to miss the season, but that he might return next year. ''Several months down the line, and not before, I'll make a decision,'' said the 36- year-old Kuechenberg, who called talk of retirement ''very premature.''

title: ;  Tripucka Offer Cut
description: General Manager Jack McCloskey of the Detroit Pistons says they have reduced their contract offer to Kelly Tripucka , their star free-agent forward. ''We've lowered the offer,'' McCloskey said, ''first, because they didn't accept it last season, and secondly, based on the entire year that Kelly had.''

title: AUTO PLANTS TRY TEAMWORK
description: Every morning at 8:30, the members of Work Group 17-25 at the General Motors assembly plant here walk to their meeting area and turn on the television set to watch the company's version of the morning news.

title: Ford-Mazda Plan
description: The Ford Motor Company has asked the Mazda Motor Corporation to supply auto parts to its small-car factory to be built in northwest Mexico, an official of the Japanese company said. Ford plans to complete the $500 million plant in Hermosillo, Sonora, in 1986, with planned production of about 130,000 units a year. Ford, which has a 24.4 percent equity stake in Mazda, has said it plans to sell cars produced at the Mexican plant in Mexico, the United States and Canada.

title: Sale by Storer
description: Storer Communications Inc. said it had agreed in principle to sell its cable television system in the Minneapolis suburbs to Hauser Communication Inc. for $40 million. The sale, subject to regulatory approval, should be concluded by year-end, Storer said. The system has nearly 1,000 miles of cable and serves more than 23,000 subscribers, it said.

title: May-HRT Deal
description: The May Department Stores Company said its Volume Shoe Corporation division had agreed to acquire 83 shoe store sites and certain inventory from HRT Industries Inc. and its Shoe Stop Inc. subsidiary.

title: ; NEW YORK'S BALLOT FOLLIES
description: ''What do they want? Elections with pictures on lampposts? No! The revolution has no time to waste in such foolishness.'' This is what Fidel Castro said to the Cuban people in 1961 as he canceled the popular elections that he promised upon coming to power.

title: Westinghouse
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation received a $106 million Air Force contract for electronic countermeasure pods for a variety of military planes, the Defense Department said. The contract combines purchases for the Air Force and for the Netherlands, the department said.

title: Yugoslavia Wins Bronze
description: Stjepan Deveric blasted a shot past the goalie Franco Tancredi in the 81st minute today to give Yugoslavia a 2-1 victory over Italy and the bronze medal in the Olympic soccer tournament.

title: I.B.M.'S SUCCESSOR TO PC DUE TUESDAY
description: The International Business Machines Corporation is expected to introduce a high-powered successor to its aging Personal Computer Tuesday before 1,500 computer dealers, software writers and industry analysts invited to Dallas for the occasion.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ; 21 Maoist Guerrillas Reported Killed in Peru
description: At least 21 Maoist guerrillas have been killed in clashes in the Ayacucho region, 6 of them in a revenge attack by Indians, the authorities said.

title: Two Found SlainIn Ruins of Home
description: The bodies of a man and his wife were found in the ruins of their home here after a fire this morning. The police said that the couple had been slain and that the fire had apparently been set to cover up the killings.

title: PENTAGON BUDGET STILL DEADLOCKED
description: The 1985 military budget remained tied in legislative knots today as Congress adjourned for the Republican National Convention and Labor Day.

title: REBEL ASSAILS U.S. OVER SOUTH AFRICA
description: The leader of the most prominent exiled group fighting white minority rule in South Africa criticized United States policy in the region today, saying the Reagan Administration had given South Africa a license to attack its neighbors.

title: ZHOU OF CHINA SCORES UPSET ON PLATFORM
description: It is not fair to call them understudies, exactly, but they have been known as second-best, until today.

title: DELEGATE TO MEXICO MEETING SAYS U.S. STILL BACKS FAMILY PLANNING
description: A United States delegate to the population conference here asserted today that the Reagan Administration's emphasis on economic factors in curbing population growth did not mean a lessening of support for family planning.

title: LONDON FETE CELEBRATES '42D STREET'
description: An opening-night party in the ornate Lancaster Room of the Savoy Hotel here celebrated the arrival of ''42d Street,'' the American musical, originally a movie, that sprang out of the need to banish the grim realities of the Depression in the 1930's.

title: FEMALE SOVIET ASTRONAUT SAYS THAT WOMEN HAVE A PLACE IN SPACE
description: When Svetlana Savitskaya crawled out of the hatch of a Soviet space station last month to become the first woman to walk in space, she said today, her commander ''gallantly'' floated aside to give her his place. That gesture to her womanhood seemed to be one of the few the 36-year- old test pilot was willing to accept.

title: No Headline
description: SATURDAY, AUGUST 11, 1984

title: ;  Braves 3, Padres 1
description: Claudell Washington and Dale Murphy hit consecutive third-inning homers, and Steve Bedrosian and Donnie Moore combined on a six-hitter to lead the Braves to victory over San Diego in the first game of a double-header.San Diego suffered its fourth straight loss, and Atlanta snapped a three- game losing streak.

title: What to Do With the Customs House One of the nation's spectacular public buildings, the Federal Customs House at the southern tip of Manhattan, has been empty since the World Trade Center took in the Customs service 13 years ago. Washington intends next week to pick a new occupant for the building's three lowest floors, including the magnificent rotunda.
description: Of the two serious contenders, one is a museum to commemorate Jewish history, particularly Hitler's Holocaust. The other is a consortium of arts organizations that would perform, rehearse, sell tickets and open a museum of trans-Atlantic liners.

title: MURDER TRIAL ORDERED FOR PARTICIPANT IN FEUD
description: James Hawkins Jr., whose family attracted national attention over its feud with a neighborhood gang, must stand trial on charges that he murdered two reputed drug dealers.

title: ;  Comings and Goings
description: Frank Robinson , dropped as manager of the San Francisco Giants last week, has joined the Milwaukee Brewers, whom he will serve as batting coach. . . . The Brewers have placed Jim Sundberg , their regular catcher, who has been grappling with back problems, on the disabled list. . . . Oddibe McDowell , the starting center fielder for the United States Olympic baseball team and the top draft choice of the Texas Rangers, is believed to have broken the ring finger on his left hand in a fall and will not be able to join the Rangers' Class AA club at Tulsa as scheduled. . . . The San Diego Chargers traded Billy Shields , a tackle who had walked out of camp this week in a contract dispute, to the Minnesota Vikings for John Turner , a safety. . . . The Seattle Mariners have placed the outfielder Dave Henderson on the disabled list and have recalled Ivan Calderon , an outfielder, from Salt Lake City.

title: British Banks Cut Prime Rate LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP) -
description: Three of Britain's major banks

title: COURT CURBS A USE OF NEWS REPORTS
description: Two aides to the Arizona Attorney General have been charged with contempt of a Federal District Court in Brooklyn for giving other law-enforcement agencies copies of two newspaper articles.

title: P.L.O. SAID TO TRAIN N YEMEN
description: An Israeli intelligence study asserts that the Palestine Liberation Organization has established a new military base in Yemen, Israeli intelligence sources said today.

title: VOTERS IN EVEN SPLIT ON PARTIES AND TAXES
description: Voters are split almost evenly over which party could do better ''dealing with taxes'' while 62 percent agree with the statement that President Reagan is a ''rich man's President,'' according to a Democratic-commissioned poll released Thursday.

title: MORE NURSES IN MINNEAPOLIS ARE GRETTING ODD JOBS
description: Registered nurses who struck 16 hospitals here began returning to their old jobs today under the second phase of their new contract.

title: ; Grappling With Reality
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.

title: ZIMBABWEAN TAKING CHARGE
description: Before the elections in 1980 that brought Robert Mugabe to power, there were many who predicted that civil war would erupt in this divided land, a contest for the spoils of freedom. The thinking was rooted in recent history. Throughout the years of guerrilla campaigns that finally ended white minority rule in the country once called Rhodesia, there were two distinct national armies in the field, divided from each other by tribe and personality. One fought under Mr. Mugabe's banner, the other was loyal to his archrival, Joshua Nkomo. Both were committed to an independent Zimbabwe under their own leaders.

title: Iraq Reports Its Naval Forces Attacked Target in Gulf War
description: Iraq said its naval forces attacked and destroyed ''a small naval target'' today.

title: MULLIN, A 'VIRTUOSO,' STIRS THE U.S. TEAM
description: If he were not playing here, he'd be playing somewhere. Chris Mullin's basketball work habits were obvious a long time ago, but they were never more graphically demonstrated than the evening seven weeks ago tonight, when the United States men's Olympic basketball team made its first public appearance.

title: REAGAN PLANS TO OPEN CAMPAIGN IN CALIFORNIA
description: President Reagan plans to return to his home state of California for the traditional Labor Day opening of the Presidential campaign.

title: 'Boogie' Run Extended
description: Melvin Van Peebles's musical ''Waltz of the Stork Boogie'' will extend its run through Aug. 26 at the Harry DeJur Playhouse, 466 Grand Street.

title: GM Rehires 2,000
description: The General Motors Corporation said it had recalled 2,000 hourly workers effective Monday for assignment to various parts operations in its manufacturing system. G.M. said the recalls would reduce to 30,000 the number of hourly workers on indefinite layoff with rehire rights. Another 21,400 workers are on temporary layoff, the auto maker said.

title: Unsanctified MarriageCosts Teacher Her Job
description: A teacher of Spanish at a Roman Catholic high school here has been dismissed because she married a non-Catholic and refused to sign a pledge that she would raise her children as Catholics.

title: POLITICS AND MORALITY: DISSENT IN CATHOLIC CHURCH
description: The swirl of debate between Roman Catholic bishops and politicians over whether officeholders should push to enact their personal moral values into law has magnified a growing problem of dissent within the church. Bishop James W. Malone, president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, argues in a statement released this week that political figures cannot draw a line between ''personal morality and public policy.'' In so doing, the bishops rejected the position of many politicians that their private views ought not to be legally binding on those who disagree.

title: GOLD MEDALS WON BY TWO AMERICANS
description: Bruce Baumgartner and Dave Schultz gave the American freestyle wrestling team its fourth and fifth gold medals today, and Yugoslavia's Saban Trstena won a gold on an injury default.

title: SYNCHRONIZED SWIMMING ; ; Ruiz Is the Solo Favorite
description: Tracie Ruiz of Seattle looked set to win a second Olympic gold medal in synchronized swimming today after dominating the solo routine preliminaries.

title: On Censoring Music The point of international cultural exchange, we thought, was to display a national culture at its best. That purpose was betrayed by the New York Philharmonic when it initially agreed to eliminate a piece from a planned Malaysian concert program because the music had ''Jewish elements.'' After a chorus of criticism, the Philharmonic has now decided to do the right thing and cancel the Malaysian concerts rather than submit to censorship.
description: Malaysia, a predominantly Moslem country, has an official policy banning the presentation of ''works of Jewish origin.'' The Malaysian ear is indeed discriminating.

title: ;  Coach Takes Stand
description: When the National Collegiate Athletic Association imposed a series of sanctions against Illinois for football- recruiting violations, the university froze Coach Mike White 's salary and barred him from making recruiting trips for a year.

title: Books of The Times; THE YOUNG LARKIN
description: JILL. By Philip Larkin. 247 pages. The

title: FENCING ; ; Italians Win Saber Gold
description: Italy captured its third gold medal in fencing Thursday night, defeating France, 9-3, in the final of the men's saber competition.

title: Slot Machine Pays$363,480 Jackpot
description: A 67-year-old nurse from Gloucester City, N.J., won a $363,480 jackpot today from a slot machine at the Golden Nugget casino.

title: RCA Satellite
description: The RCA Corporation's RCA Astro-Electronics unit said it had signed a $260 million contract to design and build an Advanced Communications Technology Satellite, or ACTS, and supporting ground stations for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Lewis Research Center in Cleveland. RCA said the satellite would include capability for baseband processing, satellite beam switching, forward error correction and complex ground networking. The satellite launch is scheduled for 1989.

title: CANOEING ; ; Swedish Woman Wins 2 in Kayaks
description: With her King and Queen looking on, Agneta Andersson captured Sweden's first two gold medals of the Los Angeles Games today, winning the 500-meter kayak singles and then teaming with Anna Olsson to take the kayak pairs race over the same distance.

title: WHAT'S IN A NAME? JACKETS, T-SHIRTS, ETC.
description: They may not yet spell the finish of designers' initials, nor do they seem likely to put such logos as alligators or polo ponies on the endangered-species list.

title: PALMS AND A PAVILION FOR BATTERY PARK CITY
description: A domed, glass-enclosed pavilion with New York City's first grove of palm trees, and a three- and-a-half-acre park with elaborate benches, gardens and gates will embellish Battery Park City, officials said this week.

title:
DE GUSTIBUS;
WHY COLD IS NOT SO HOT
description: We Americans like our hot foods steaming, our cold foods icy. It is one of many cultural differences between us and most if not all of the rest of the world. We have such a fetish about these extremes in temperature that it is a point of pride to advertise frosty drinks on a muggy summer's day and a bubbling pot of beef stew on a bone-chilling winter's evening.

title: MONEY MANAGERS: BIG, WARY BUYERS
description: The Equitable Investment Corporation, a money manager of more than $5 billion in stocks, was one of the giant institutional investors leading the charge into the market yesterday and Thursday. But like many of those jumping aboard the rally train, Equitable's chairman, Donald R. Kurtz, is not convinced it will have a long trip.

title: 6.5% of Revlon Held by Clore
description: Alan E. Clore, who led a successful proxy fight to take over the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation of Houston more than two years ago, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he controls 6.5 percent of Revlon Inc., the big cosmetics company.

title: EX-BRONCO INDICTED IN PILL USE
description: Otis Armstrong, a former all-pro running back who says he has been in almost constant pain because of a spinal condition that forced him to retire from the Denver Broncos four years ago, has been indicted on charges of fraudulently obtaining large quantities of a prescription painkiller. And he has vowed to continue seeking the drug.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''At a minimum, women are equal to men in space. Women are actually better at some space tasks than men.

title: IF A TAX DEDUCTION HAD A FIXED WORTH
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. LEADERS ESTIMATE COST OF MONDALE PLANS
description: House Republican leaders today issued an analysis of Walter F. Mondale's Democratic platform, saying that it was ''bloated with political promises'' that would cost taxpayers $400 billion.

title: ;  Reds 5, Astros 4 CINCINNATI (AP) - A leadoff home run by Skeeter Barnes in the 12th inning gave Cincinnati the victory in the first game of a doubleheader.
description: Barnes, who entered the game in the ninth as a pinch-hitter and grounded into a bases-loaded double play, hit the first pitch from Julio Solano (0-2) deep over the left-field wall. John Franco (4-0) earned the victory in relief.

title: WILLIAM I. RIEGELMAN
description: William I. Riegelman, a corporate and estate-and-trust lawyer in New York for more than four decades, died yesterday at the White Plains Hospital Medical Center, where he had been since suffering a heart attack a week ago. He was 71 years old and lived in White Plains and Great Barrington, Mass.

title: CORRECTION
description: The TV Sports column yesterday incorrectly quoted an assessment of the United States' swimming program by Jim Lampley, an ABC commentator. He said the program was the best over all in the world.

title: Poland's Turn In the history of Communist Poland, the longest-lasting regime was that of Wladyslaw Gomulka. Born of strikes and demonstrations in 1956, it began with reform, soon lapsed into cynicism and brutality and finally succumbed in 1970 in a shower of strikers' blood. It squandered probably the only, if remote, chance of Communist legitimacy in Polish hearts and minds.
description: Since then, the cycles of failure have grown ever shorter. Edward Gierek was followed by Stanislaw Kania. He's been followed by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski. Protest - revolution, really - had advanced to the point of creating genuinely democratic institutions, through Solidarity. Then bureaucratic Communism lapsed into open dictatorship through martial law. For years, the standoff between these two forces has paralyzed the society.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ; East German Defends Talks With the West
description: East Germany published a top-level defense of discussions with the West today, despite Soviet attacks on its efforts to improve relations with Bonn.

title: YANKS SWEEP BY 6-4 AND 10-1
description: Don Baylor tonight remembered a time this season when things weren't going so well for the Yankees.

title: BANKERS ACCEPTANCES
description: -known investment possibilities available to bank depositors is the category known as bankers acceptances. Yet these instruments are relatively safe, offer substantial liquidity and generally have higher yields than many other investments with comparable maturities.

title: AUDIBLE EDUCATION DEVICE
description: WASHINGTON

title: Record Sale at Sarato
description: Robert Sangster of Britain and Sheik Mohammed ibn Rashid al-Maktoum of Dubai, the two bloodstock investors responsible for history's most expensive purchases of yearling race horses, bid against each other until Sangster paid $4.6 million Thursday night for a colt by Northern Dancer and Bubbling at the Saratoga Select Yearling Sales.

title: TOBACCO DEBATE: IMPORTS AND HEALTH
description: Tobacco has played an important part in this city's history, from Colonial times, when it was the leading local crop, to current times, when talk about tobacco is one of the leading cottage industries on Capitol Hill.

title: MONDALE PLANNING BID FOR CALIFORNIA
description: Walter F. Mondale will undertake a full-scale campaign effort to win California in the fall election, his campaign chairman, James A. Johnson, announced here today.

title: 2 WILDLIFE WORKERS DISMISSED FOR KILLING 3 BABY RACCOONS;
description: Two students who worked for the Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries, asked to rescue three baby raccoons, responded by clubbing them to death and have been dismissed, a department spokesman said today.

title: HOUSE VOTE APPOVING MILITARY AID FOR SALVADOR
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 234 to 161 by which the House of Representatives today approved an amendment appropriating $70 million in emergency military aid for El Salvador. A ''yes'' vote is a vote for the aid. Voting ''yes'' were 89 Democrats and 145 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 154 Democrats and 7 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. There are 2 vacancies in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, yes; Erdreich, yes; Flippo, yes; Nichols, yes; Shelby, xxx.

title: BUT STATE AND CITY TELL OF CONFUSION AMONG OFFICIALS
description: New York City's Human Resources Administration did not deliberately hinder an investigation by the Bronx District Attorney's office into charges of sexual abuse at a Bronx day-care center, according to two reports released yesterday.

description: Two stories on the front page of

title: SCOUTING;
description: Helping Athletes

title: FOR THE CITY'S KOREAN GREENGROCERS, CULTURE OFTEN CLASHES WITH THE LAW
description: Sang Chun stood among nearly 100 Korean greengrocers at the Hunts Point Market in the Bronx earlier this week and waved a crumpled pink summons at the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs.

title: AIRLINE SEEKS SCHEDULE ACCORD TO CUT DELAYS
description: Eastern Air Lines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday to permit airlines to jointly revise their schedules to reduce flight delays that have plagued carriers and passengers this year.

title: U.S. Inquiry On Textiles
description: The Commerce Department said today that it had begun an investigation into charges that 13 developing countries were illegally subsidizing textile shipments to the United States.

description: To the Editor:

title: TWO NIGHTS OF RIOTING BRING A CURFEW TO LAWRENCE, MASS.
description: It was touched off, city officials say, by a family feud.

title: CHICAGO POLICE OFFICER GUILTY;
description: Federal jurors today convicted a Chicago police officer of racketeering and extortion, making him the third person found guilty by a jury in an investigation of alleged judicial corruption.

title: Upset in Final
description: Third-seeded Peter Van Lingen of Brentwood, Tenn., a former member of the South African Davis Cup team, upset top-seeded Keith Diepraam of Sugarland, Tex., today, 6-1, 6-1 in the singles final of the National 40-and-Over Hardcourt Championships.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review of the film ''Red Dawn'' yesterday gave its rating incorrectly. It is PG-13.

title: FLORENCE M. CROWTHER
description: Florence M. Crowther, a literary agent and the widow of Bosley Crowther, former motion-picture critic of The New York Times, died of cancer Thursday at the White Plains Hospital Medical Center. She was 75 years old and lived in Somers, N.Y.

title: Bid for Resource
description: Resource Exploration Inc. said it had received an acquisition offer from the National Gas and Oil Company of Newark, Ohio. L. Michael McGurk, Resource's vice president, valued the offer, in stock, cash and warrants, at $3.20 a share. On July 19, Resource entered into a letter of intent to be acquired by the Belden & Blake Energy Company. Mr. McGurk said the Belden offer, under which Resource shareholders would receive one unit of limited partnership in Belden in exchange for five shares of Resource common, was valued at $4 a share. Resource, with nearly five million shares outstanding, was bid $3.125, up 12 1/2 cents from Thursday, in over-the-counter trading.

title: ARCHERY ; ; American Sets Record
description: Darrell Pace of Hamilton, Ohio, increased his lead in Olympic men's archery today with a world record straight-shooting performance at the 90-meter distance.

title: Face Lift for 3 Facades
description: The cake, which was chocolate,

title: RATES RISE IN CREDIT MARKETS
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose yesterday, reversing part of the declines that occurred earlier in the week.

title: LATIN FESTIVAL ACCUSED OF 'IDEOLOGICAL BIAS'
description: A dispute has arisen between a group of Cuban-American artists and writers and the Public Theater involving the political representation at the Public's Festival Latino de Nueva York.

title: U.S. JUDGE IN NEVADA CONVICTED OF FILING FALSE INCOME TAX FORMS
description: Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne of Las Vegas was convicted by a Federal jury today of filing false income tax returns for 1979 and 1980.

title: Take Ads on Abortion, Transit Agency Is Told
description: The city's transit system must accept advertising by Planned Parenthood that mentions abortion, a Federal district judge ruled today.

title: U.S. MEN DEFEAT SPAIN FOR TITLE
description: Spain did take a 2-0 lead today to put the Americans behind momentarily, but the suspense ended soon after that. The United States made 12 of its first 14 shots - 6 of them from 12 feet or more - to take a 25-17 lead.

title: CUBS FALL BY 4-2 TO EXPOS
description: Gary Carter's solo home run broke a 2-2 eighth-inning tie tonight and the Montreal Expos went on to defeat the Chicago Cubs, 4-2, for their fourth consecutive victory.

title: No Headline
description: HOUSE PASSES BILL TO WIDEN CLEANUP OF TOXIC WASTES

title: BLACK UNION LEADER ENDORSES THE PRESIDENT
description: A black union leader has endorsed President Reagan's re-election, saying the worker had ''a friend in the White House.''

title: ILL-DEVISED NATO ANGLE IN A 'STAR WARS' CRITIQUE
description: To the Editor:

title: Workers' DeathsStill Unexplained
description: Autopsies have ruled out drowning as the cause of the deaths of two workers who were cleaning a cesspool behind a Howard Johnson's restaurant on Long Island, the Nassau County Medical Examiner's Office said yesterday.

title: METS LOSE AGAIN, BENACH STRAWBERRY
description: 'Too Understanding' Neither Strawberry nor Johnson was available for comment before the game. On Thursday night, however, after a lopsided loss to the Pirates, the manager talked about his general approach to hard times.

title: U.S. CROP OUTPUT RISING SHARPLY FROM POOR '83
description: Crop production in the United States, shriveled last year by drought and Government acreage programs, is rebounding sharply as farmers put idled land back to work and the weather improves, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: MAURICE EDELBAUM, A CRIMINAL LAWYER, DIES AT 78 IN FLORIDA
description: Maurice Edelbaum, a New York criminal lawyer who achieved prominence defending organized-crime figures and others in some of the most publicized criminal trials of the late 1960's, died yesterday in the Washington Manor Nursing Home in Hollywood, Fla.

title: BRIEFING
SCOUTING;
description: A Boxing Fan Hits His Limit

title: PRODDED BY CUOMO, HOSPITALS AND UNIONS NEGOTIATE
description: Under pressure from Governor Cuomo, negotiators held direct talks yesterday in the four-week-old New York City hospital and nursing home strike.

title: SAUDIS SEEKING U.S. MISSILES
description: The United States and Saudi Arabia have had informal discussions about Saudi interest in purchasing large numbers of additional American made Sidewinder air-to-air missiles, a senior United States official said tonight.

title: AT OTHER DAY-CARE CENTERS IN CITY, DEEP DISMAY
description: Several dozen children wearing T-shirts with the name East Harlem Triangle Day Care Center on them headed off to Central Park with their teachers for a Muppets show. Along the way, passers-by shouted insults at them.

title: A MOUNTED OFFICER REFUSES TO RIDE INTO SUNSET
description: Get along little dogies. Barney Devine - tall in the saddle on his faithful and unflappable horse, Jim - heads them up and moves them out of the bus lane on 42d Street. When Officer Devine draws his trusty ticket book from its leather holster, even the most obstinate motorists get along.

title: FANS TREK TO TOWN WHERE PRESEY HAD HIS ROOTS
description: Like a handful of others who still live in this small, North Mississippi town, Janelle McComb can remember the days when Elvis Aron Presley was just another poor kid from the other side of the rail yard.

title: Air Florida Slots
description: The Federal Aviation Administration, for the second time, denied permission for Eastern Airlines to take over from the bankrupt Air Florida 16 takeoff and landing slots at Washington and New York airports.

title: MTV a Sellout
description: At $15 a Share The initial public offering of

title: A Texan Tries the IRT
description: The woman, carrying a briefcase,

title: SHOWTIME FINDS AUGUST RIGHT TIME FOR PAY TV
description: Television programming, which usually fades in the summer doldrums, is having a busy August on Showtime, a cable network that is available in about half of Manhattan. Not only is the service presenting two new controversial comedy series, but a production of Tennessee Williams's final adaptation of ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,'' starring Jessica Lange and Tommy Lee Jones.

title: GIANTS FACE COLTS' FAN CLUB
description: ''Without a doubt, this will be one of the greatest weekends ever in this city. Maybe ever in this country. We will cheer and sing and stomp as no one has ever before. We'll tear the place down to show how thankful we are that our dreams have come true.''

title: American Air Cuts Its Chicago Fares
description: American Airlines, responding to the fare war between People Express and United Air Lines, announced yesterday that it would offer substantially lower fares of from $59 to $129 on flights between Chicago's O'Hare International Airport and New York- area airports.

title: ;  Baltimore Is Looking
description: Mayor William Donald Schaefer of Baltimore was outraged when Indianapolis lured the Colts away from his city earlier this year.

title: EQUESTRIAN ; ; Klimke Wins Dressage
description: Reiner Klimke, who led West Germany to the Olympic team dressage championship on Thursday, won the individual gold in the event today at Santa Anita race track.

title: Vatican Gives Warning To Nicaraguan Priests
description: The Vatican issued a stern new warning today to Nicaraguan priests serving in Government posts, saying they were violating Roman Catholic Church law.

title: TELEXES INDICATE ASSOCIATE OF HATFIELD DISCUSSED ARMS SALE
description: The Greek financier who obtained Senator Mark O. Hatfield's help in promoting a trans-African pipeline project was also involved in negotiating the overseas sale of military equipment whose export is subject to American controls, according to copies of telexes obtained today.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Only a month after performing brilliantly in the All-Star Game, Dwight Gooden has been routed in two straight starts. He tries to get back on the winning track tonight before his record dips to .500. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.)

title: Bridge: Another 600 Duplicate ScoreBut One on the Minus Side
description: One of the commonest duplicate or Chicago scores is 600, resulting from a contract of three no-trump when the declarer is vulnerable. All these elements were in place on the diagramed deal, from the recent international team playoffs in Memphis, but there was one rather vital departure from the norm.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FIVE MEN ARE ARRESTED IN GEORGIA KLAN ATTACKS
description: Five Georgia Ku Klux Klansmen were arrested today on Federal charges of breaking into homes at night to attack an interracial couple and a white woman believed to be associating with blacks.

title: SAVE THE GRIZZLY AND YELLOWSTONE
description: Once, centuries ago, one million grizzlies roamed the West; as recently as 280 years ago, 50,000 lived beyond the Mississippi. In 1805, when Lewis and Clark's party entered what is now Montana, members killed several bears daily. By the 1920's, Yellowstone's visitors could sit on crude bleachers and at dusk watch bears feed on garbage. As recently as 13 years ago, tourists in cars could toss scraps to scavenging bears, though most of those were black bears rather than grizzlies.

title: ;  Brett's Historic Bat
description: When George Brett signed a ''lifetime'' contract with the Kansas City Royals several months ago, not all the terms were disclosed.

title: What Uganda's Flag Is Hiding Five years after its liberation from the butchery of Idi Amin, Uganda is again a killing ground. In recent months more than 100,000 people have been massacred or starved, according to reports the State Department finds credible. Other diplomats assert that many died in camps served by international relief agencies, whose activities Uganda suspended last March. But no villainous tyrant is to blame. The blame falls on a feeble Government unable to control its army and unwilling to ask for the outside help it so plainly needs.
description: Rather than acknowledge a failure to contain tribally based rebellion, President Obote wants the world to believe that there is nothing amiss. But the reports alone caused him angrily to suspend the training of four of his officers in the United States and to cancel a visit by an American military attache. What is Mr. Obote hiding?

title: AROUND THE WORLD ; Colombian Advocate Of Peace Talks Is Killed
description: Two gunmen on a motorcycle today shot and killed Dr. Carlos Toledo Plata, a Member of Parliament and founding member of the M-19 guerrilla movement who strongly advocated peace talks with the Government.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; FORD BACKS RICHARDSON FOR THE U.S. SENATE
description: Former President Ford today endorsed Elliot L. Richardson for United States Senator from Massachusetts.

title: MAYOR ORDERS A REVIEW OF THE AGENCY, AND PICKS MANHATTAN LAWYER TO DO IT
description: Mayor Koch yesterday ordered a review of the ''structure and function'' of the Human Resources Administration, which lost its commissioner and a top deputy to resignations this week.

title: U.S. TRADE STANCE IRKS EUROPEANS
description: The United States is becoming embroiled with European governments over exports of advanced technology goods to Communist countries in Eastern Europe.

title: Sidewalk Diversions
description: Some of the city's finest street performers - among them ventriloquists, folk singers, jazz musicians, marimba players and a pair of 12- year-old break dancers - all shared the same corner in Times Square yesterday.

title: Cosmos Beaten, 3-2; Cabanas May Go
description: Alan Willey scored a pair of goals and John Bain added three assists to lead the Minnesota Strikers to a 3-2 victory over the Cosmos in a North American Soccer League game tonight.

title: 18 TREATED IN CHEMICAL FIRE
description: A fire at a farm chemical plant early today spread fumes from burning fertilizers, herbicides and pesticides into nearby homes, sending 18 people to the hospital to be treated for nausea. The authorities blocked off an area extending a half-mile from the Western Farm Service Company, three miles west of this central California town, and advised residents the area to evacuate.

title: CITY OPERA: 'LA BOHEME'
description: The romantic leads remained intact in the New York City Opera's ''Boh eme'' Thursday night, but there were some interesting changes in other roles.

title: WALTER TEVIS, 56, A SCREENWRITER
description: Walter Tevis, who changed careers in midlife from college English professor teaching Milton in Ohio to fulltime freelance writer of successful novels and screenplays in Manhattan, died of lung cancer on Thursday at University Hospital-New York University Medical Center. He was 56 years old.

title: A WEEK WHEN JAMAICA IS ONE, BIG REGGAE PARTY
description: Well into the early morning hours, the deep, pulsating rhythms of reggae music are heard across the city. Hotel rooms are scarce and restaurants and coffee shops are crowded with musicians and fans.

title: Swimming Against Hunger
description: At 10:45 A.M. today, a long-distance

title: CORRECTION
description: The Entertainment Events listing on Wednesday misidentified the movie theater where ''The Whole Shootin' Match'' is playing. It is the Bleecker Street Cinema.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LOOK AND LEARN The Metropolitan Museum of Art is a university for self-learners. While many out-of-towners enter primarily to take in as much of everything as they can, those who live in town have a rare opportunity to educate themselves, as though in college, on any one era or part of the world, as seen through the art and artifacts on display.

title: Sperry Order
description: Of $78 Million WASHINGTON, Aug. 10

title: Baron James de Rothschild,Former Investing Executive
description: Baron James Nathaniel Charles Leopold de Rothschild, a French descendant of the British branch of the Rothschild financial family and former administrator of a French investment company, died Tuesday, family sources reported here. He was 88 years old.

title: COURT BACKS F.B.I. ON CHICAGO SPYING
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that the Federal Bureau of Investigation may spy on domestic political groups in Chicago that advocate violent acts, even if the groups do not commit violence.

title: U.S. PROTEST OF HOLYFIELD LOSS IS DENIED
description: The protest committee of the International Amateur Boxing Federation today upheld a referee's decision to disqualify the American light heavyweight boxer Evander Holyfield for failing to obey the command, ''stop,'' during the second round of his Olympic semifinal bout against Kevin Barry of New Zealand Thursday night.

title: NO MALAYSIA VISIT FOR PHILHARMONIC
description: The New York Philharmonic announced yesterday that it had canceled two concerts in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.

title: Desegregation Plan Criticized ;
description: Desegregation Accord Called Biased by U.S.

title: BILL WOULD LIFT ONUS FROM HOST IN CAR ACCIDENT
description: A legislative study commission endorsed a bill today that would exempt social hosts from civil liability if a guest drinks too much alcohol and has an automobile accident.

title: No Headline
description: Final March May Grow LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 - The Los Angeles Olympic Organizing

title: FRENCH COURT ORDERS 4 BASQUES' EXTRADITION
description: A French court has ruled that four Basque separatists should be extradited to Spain on murder and assault charges.

title: HIGH POLICE OFFICERS CONVICTED IN PHILADELPHIA
description: The two highest-ranking police officers ever indicted here were found guilty by a Federal jury today of running a ring that extorted over $350,000 in bribes from gambling operators.

title: FREE FOLK CONCERT SET
description: A free folk concert on Aug. 26 at 4 P.M. with the composer David Amram and others at Cunningham Park, Queens, begins a series of free performances sponsored by Carnegie Hall and the City's Department of Cultural Affairs.

title: Saudis Cite Cut in Oil Output
description: Saudi Arabia has confirmed oil market reports that it had cut back on its production of oil.

title: CONGRESS BLOCKS POSTAL SERVICE PLAN FOR 2-TIER WAGE SYSTEM
description: Congress today voted to block plans by the Postal Service to begin hiring new employees at lower wages than present workers receive.

title: TENNIS ; ; Last American Eliminated
description: One day after the top-seeded woman, Kathy Horvath of the United States, was eliminated from the Olympic tennis tournament, the top-seeded man, Jimmy Arias of the United States, was knocked out of it.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ; Soviet Travel Agency Calls U.S. Warning 'Silly'
description: The head of the Soviet travel agency Intourist today branded as ''silly and ill intentioned'' a State Department advisory warning of harassment of Americans in Leningrad.

title: POPULATION GROWTH: HOW U.S. POLICY EVOLVED
description: The new United States policy on world population, formally presented this week at the United Nations conference in Mexico City, is the product of two distinct - and not always compatible - advocacy groups within the Reagan Administration, a variety of experts on the subject say. One force behind the new stand, according to Marshall Green, the State Department's senior policy adviser on population in the late 1970's, has been ''the right wing of the right-to-life movement, which has supporters within the White House staff.''

title: FOR ADULTS, FALL SCHOOL CATALOGUES
description: DECEMBER brings Christmas. June brings weddings. August brings thoughts of September and the first day of school. Even those who no longer spend their days in class and their nights doing homework think about school. In greater numbers each year adults turn to classes as a way to meet people, refresh their knowledge of French and economics, or learn sign language or sushi from scratch.

title: CONTACTS WITH DELOREAN JURORS BARRED AFTER ABC INCIDENT
description: Federal District Judge Robert M. Takasugi today issued a court order reaffirming a ban on contacts with jurors in the cocaine-trafficking trial of John Z. DeLorean.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Sailing Success

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES ;
description: 'I Should've Pushed Her'

title: ROMEO AND JULIET IN GERMANY
description: All that backstage commotion in central Europe is now erupting into a once unimaginable spat between Soviet and German Communists. The East Germans, having dutifully sacrificed a pot of gold medals at Los Angeles, refuse to humor the Russians again by also passing up gold loans from West Germany. And despite fierce Soviet pressure, Erich Honecker is holding to his plan to be the first East German leader to visit Bonn, next month.

title: BRAZIL'S HARD LIFE WITH AUSTERITY
description: -yearly visits to Brasilia, economists from the International Monetary Fund this month will wade through reams of weighty documents in order to gauge the Brazilian Government's compliance with an austerity program worked out by the two parties late in 1982.

title: U.S. 2d on Goal Differential
description: The United States and Yugoslavia played to a 5-5 tie in the Olympic water-polo championship match Friday night, but a better goal differential gave the gold medal to the Yugoslavs.

title: Lewis Earned The Copyrights
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
DID SHE OSE OR DID SHE WIN?
description: SOME create monuments. Some create ideas. Parents create children and in the process re-create themselves, either in shades of their own image or in some form of the image they wish to create in others, but cannot create in themselves.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
A TERMINAL DISTASTE FOR FLYING
description: FOR some of us, ''Fear of Flying'' is more than the title of Erica Jong's novel. For about 18 percent of us, according to a Boeing survey, it is a way of life. We are the white-knuckle flyers, the ones who suffer volcanic intestinal upheaval whenever we purchase airline tickets. We are the ones who order a drink on the plane, not because we are thirsty, but because we are monitoring the turbulence of the fluid in the glass.

title: THE SAILING LIFE ABOARD TALL SHIPS
description: ''Whales!'' The lookout's cry sent a shiver of excitement through the passengers and crew aboard the Alexandria, a three-masted topsail schooner that was slicing through gentle seas off the New England coast. It was the first day of a dazzling, 470-mile passage from Martha's Vineyard to Halifax, Nova Scotia.

title: ZUBIN MEHTA PLANS TO GO HOME AGAIN
description: Some years ago Zubin Mehta was quoted as saying that he would never conduct any orchestras in India or Russia, countries hostile to Israel. Now he is taking the New York Philharmonic on a tour of the Far East, partly sponsored by Citi bank, N.A., that will begin in Tokyo on Aug. 15 and culminate with five concerts in Delhi, Calcutta and Bombay, ending Sept. 19.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: CHEAPER FLIGHTS TO LONDON
description: An off-season air-fare war is developing on the trans-Atlantic run to London. From Nov. 1 until March 31, 1985, it will be possible to go from most American gateway cities to London and back on scheduled flights for less than it now costs by most charters. From New York, for example, the round-trip fare on Air- India, British Airways, Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines will be $378 for midweek travel and $428 on weekends. The restrictions: you must buy your tickets at least 21 days before departure and must stay away from seven days to six months. There is a $50 penalty for passengers who cancel.

title: A COMPANY WHERE SMALL IS BEAUTIFUL
description: LIKE many of Israel's small companies, Alchut Electronics cut its

title: Powerhouse Plan
description: With major office, hotel and retail facilites for Manhattan's West Side on the drawing board the developers of a new office project in West 39th Street hope to profit from expected growth in the area by creating a narrow 25-story tower that will incorporate a vacant Con Edison substation.

title: FOLLOWING THE DREAM
description: THE AMERICAN WINE revolution really dates from the late 1960's. Those were the days when a kind of general love affair with Europe, especially France, combined with an economy that still generated disposable income to change the eating and drinking habits of a lot of us, possibly forever.

title: JACKSON'S STANCE POSES QUESTIONS FOR CAMPAIGN
description: In a recent speech to the National Urban League, the Rev. Jesse Jackson criticized Walter F. Mondale as failing to address issues important to blacks. But he went on to say that, if asked, he would support the Democratic ticket and work for its election.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR Women, Crime And Jail Capacity
description: The recent article ''Violent Crimes by Women Increasing'' has brought attention to the problems of women in the criminal justice system. However, it is inadequate in the conclusion that an increase of women committing violent and drug-related crimes has caused the need to expand the women's facility in the Nassau County jail.

title: Margaret Peters Becomes a Bride
description: Margaret Anne Peters, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Peters 3d of Terra Alta, W.Va., was married yesterday to Michael Garland Proctor, a son of Clayton Billings Proctor of Goshen, Conn., and Bonita Springs, Fla., and the late Carolyn Spelman Proctor. The Rev. Bruce Reed, a Methodist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Peters home.

title: PUTTING TOGETHER SALADS FROM LEFTOVERS
description: -LIBBING in the kitchen is always fun. Summer is no exception, especially when it comes to making salads. A meal can easily be put together from a mixture of raw and cooked things composed according to what is at hand and dressed with a good oil. The salad might be the main dish, eaten with French or Italian bread, or served as a first course to be followed by something light, such as pasta.

title: THE OPINIONATED POET
description: REQUIRED WRITING Miscellaneous Pieces 1955-1982. By Philip Larkin. 328 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: Miss Schulman to Marry Kevin Breslin
description: Announcement has been made by Toni Schulman of New York and Lowell Schulman of Purchase, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Barbara Schulman to Kevin Breslin, a son of Jimmy Breslin of New York and the late Rosemary Breslin. An October wedding is planned.

title: EINSTEIN COLLEGE PICKS A NEW MEDICAL DEAN
description: The dean of Stanford University's School of Medicine has been named dean of Yeshiva University's Albert Einstein College of Medicine.

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS A BILL TO PERMIT SCHOOL WORSHIP
description: President Reagan, accusing the Democrats of ''bottling up'' his Administration's legislative package, today signed a measure prohibiting public high schools from barring student gatherings for religious or political purposes outside class hours.

title: OF BIOTECHNOLOGY, 'BUGS' AND ROOSTERS
description: A drive through the Weizmann Science Park, in Rehovot south of Tel Aviv, gives a vivid snapshot of Israel's lean, no-frills high-technology industry.

title: LONG ILSAND JOURNAL
description: LAST winter, to raise funds for the New York Public Library, Joanna and Daniel Rose gave an ''Edwardian Dinner'' at their Manhattan apartment. But as hosts themselves, the Roses couldn't participate in any of the other ''Table of Contents'' events, much to Mrs. Rose's chagrin.

title: L.I.U. PWill Resign in '85
description: The president of Long Island University, Albert Bush-Brown, announced today that he will resign early next year.

title: O'MEARA LEADS BY SHOT ON 202
description: Mark O'Meara carded a 64 in the third round today and took a one- stroke lead into the final round of the Buick Open.

title: JAPANESE INVENTIVENESS
description: It is incredible how persistent one bad idea can be. This is the notion that, in order to be ''cooperative'' and ''coordinated,'' the efforts of a large group of people must be

title: 'TALLULAH': GLITTER AND SELF-PITY
description: WHEN ''Tallulah,'' a musical biography, opened Off Broadway last year, it was not well received by the majority of critics. Nevertheless, the people involved with ''Tallulah'' held firm in their belief that they were working with a viable musical entertainment. So they have moved ''Tallulah'' to East Hampton. As Helen Gallagher, in the title role, says, ''We've brought Tallu to the John Drew.''

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: THE eighth-largest trading company in Japan, Kanematsu-Gosho Ltd., will open a two-story office and warehouse in Franklin Township next year for its Eastern Seaboard operations.

title: 57 IN ENGLEWOOD
description: High costs have priced many families out of the housing market in Bergen County, N.J. But Tributary Woods, a development of clustered town houses under construction in Englewood, will give middle- income buyers the opportunity to purchase homes starting at $115,000 with down payments as low as 5 percent.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: originally ''Maria Stuarda'' - is part of a trilogy of operas by Gaetano Donizetti dealing with the lives and loves of 16th-century English queens. All three works present challenging opportunities for a great singing actress and Dame Janet Baker - who is emphatically among that number - chose to make her farewell to the operatic stage in the title role of ''Mary Stuart'' at Covent Garden in April, 1982.

title: ECHOES OF VIENNA'S HERITAGE
description: A stroller in Vienna doesn't have to be a compulsive reader of what is written on house walls to note how often the names of Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert recur on the commemorative tablets that abound in many neighborhoods. This is a place where the sight of graffiti is rare but where plaques abound recalling the great moments of a long history, the enduring glories of a mellow civilization and, above all, the giants of music who lived here.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDTIOR
description: uf912 Rules That Govern Driving Privilege In the article, Mrs. McLean fails to recognize - as do most opponents of the seat-belt law - that driving is not a right, guaranteed by any instrument of our Government, state or Federal. Rather, it is a privilege granted to qualified persons by a state and a failure to abide by the rules governing that privilege may result in its revocation.

title: MOVIES FOR EVERY TEEN-AGER'S WISH

title: DIFFICULTIES FOR KENYA MOUNT WITH POPULATION
description: Not long ago, a boy's school decided to put on a fireworks display and advertised it widely. Advance publicity, however, did not prevent some people from panicking when the bangs and crashes began to reverberate. They called friends and asked what was going on. Soon, wire services were receiving inquiries from Kenyans abroad about rumors of unrest.

title: LETTER TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Ideas for Hiring The Middle-Aged Publishing Allen M. Widem's recent Opinion article (''Age 59, Experienced but Jobless,'' July 15) was a thoughtful choice. There are many of us - 59, experienced, competent and jobless that share Mr. Widem's frustration in what is becoming a national problem as longevity stretches.

title: Kyle Pulling Engaged To Mary Jane Knapp
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Knapp of Orchard Lake, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Jane Knapp, to Kyle Bruce Pulling, a son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Bruce Pulling of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. The wedding is planned for Oct. 27.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; House Builds UpThe Superfund
description: The nation doesn't have a minute to lose in its fight against the dangers of toxic waste dumps, House Democrats said last week as they pushed through a sixfold increase in the Environmental Protection Agency's program charged with cleaning up the sites. By a vote of 323 to 33, the House passed a bill that would authorize the spending of up to $10.2 billion over a five-year period by the agency's Superfund.

title: FEMINIST SEEKS PRESIDENCY FOR CITIZENS PARTY
description: Sonia Johnson, a Virginia feminist who was excommunicated from the Mormon Church after she supported the proposed Federal equal rights amendment in the 1970's, was nominated today as the Presidential candidate of the Citizens Party.

title: FLORIDA'S DEATH ROW POPULATION BOOMS
description: When Florida's death penalty statute was upheld by the United States Supreme Court in 1976 after years of litigation, state officials said the law would be a powerful weapon against violent crime. Since then, Florida has executed seven convicts, more than any state, and Florida's crime rate has in fact been declining.

title: COLTS DEFEAT GIANTS IN INDIANA DEBUT
description: Since they met in the 1958 National Football League championship game, the one that gave pro football its biggest modern impetus, they have come to this: The New York Giants are now in New Jersey, and the Baltimore Colts are in Indianapolis.

title: DE CASTELLA HEADS DEEPEST OF FIELDS
description: The man the running world calls ''Deek,'' Rob de Castella of Australia, is the favorite to win the gold medal in the Olympic marathon here Sunday.

description: For casual and easy warm-weather street wear, some women about town have adopted suspenders as a new accessory. They vary from proper versions - often the same ones worn by men, who are appearing in them with increasing frequency - to more rarefied styles.

Safety and Sex
description: The way the Federal judge saw it, Eastern Airlines considered Kenneth F. Ulane a competent pilot for 12 years - until the flier had an operation one day and became Karen F. Ulane. The airline then discharged the pilot as a safety hazard.

title: BRAZIL'S RULING PARTY SELECTS CIVILIAN AS CANDIDATE
description: Brazil's ruling Social Democratic Party today nominated a civilian politician to be the party's candidate for president.

title: Carol Anne Jacobson To Be October Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Jacobson of New York and Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carol Anne Jacobson to Dr. Steven J. Weiss, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William I. Weiss of West Orange and Long Beach Island, N.J. The wedding is to take place in October.

title: 101,799 SEE FRANCE TAKE GOLD
description: The stirring strains of ''The Marseillaise'' rang out over a Rose Bowl packed with 101,799 people tonight, as France won the Olympic gold medal in soccer. The French defeated Brazil, 2-0.

title: ENDPLAY WITH A HUNGARIAN ACCENT
