title: ON TOWARD ROME
description: Field Marshal Lord Carver was Chief of the British Defense Staff from 1973 to 1976. His books include ''War Since 1945,'' ''A Policy for Peace'' and the forthcoming ''The Seven Ages of the British Army.'' MARK CLARK

title: SALEM CHARTER WAS ONE OF 6
description: As the authorities continued searching for whoever stole part of the Massachusetts Bay Company charter from the state archives in Boston, a manuscript dealer said today that the document was one of six existing versions.

title: DANISH BY DESIGN
description: The Danes have a way with design, and they are world famous for it, but perhaps their best piece of design they have kept for themselves - their capital city of Copenhagen. Built on a very human scale, the city seems to have been made primarily for people and their pleasures. Where else would the world's longest running and possibly most beautiful amusement park, Tivoli, stand right in the middle of downtown? Where else would the main shopping street, the five-block-long Stroget, be entirely closed to vehicular traffic? And what other important city would have its major attractions within walking distance of most of its large hotels?

title: CUOMO SIGNS BILL LETTING CITY ADOPT NEW TAX-BREAK POLICY
description: Governor Cuomo has signed a measure permitting New York City to adopt a new program of tax incentives to spur economic development.

title: PRINCIPLE VS. VALUE
description: ''Words are the tokens current and accepted for conceits,'' wrote Francis Bacon almost four centuries ago, ''as moneys are for values.''

title: Seta Marie Nazarian Wed to William K. Albrecht
description: Seta Marie Nazarian, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nazar Levon Nazarian of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., was married yesterday to William Kenneth Albrecht, a son of Alice Cooper Richardson of Portland, Ore., and William Price Albrecht Jr. of Iowa City. Archbishop Tiran Nersoyan, the bride's cousin, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Armenian Church in Tenafly, N.J., assisted by the Rev. Arnak Kasparian.

description: It was 1965 and a gangling teenager stood on the tips of her toes and

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Housing Families With Lower Incomes After reading Edward A. Grause's article, ''Why Just Two Stories High?'' (Opinion Page, July 8), I wondered how long he lived in East Meadow. He contends we need more than two-floor buildings to give housing to moderate- and low-income families.

title: MOSTLY MOZART: ORIGINAL INSTRUMENTS AT PLAY
description: The second of the Mostly Mozart Festival's path-breaking ''Mostly Mozart on Original Instruments'' concerts Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall was in fact all Mozart. And while it took place on a night normally given over to chamber music, this was actually an orchestral concert - however reduced and refined the orchestral sound was, in comparison to modern groups playing modern instruments.

title: NEW POSITION FOR SOCCER STAR
description: WITH the popularity of the football Giants and the basketball Nets, the chances that the state's sportswriters would name a soccer player New Jersey's Professional Athlete of the Year had been rather remote, especially since interest in the Cosmos had started to wane considerably in recent months.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
A PRESIDENT SHOULD INSPIRE
description: THE commuter plane flies low over Connecticut on a spring day, and I point out the sights to a Midwestern colleague: the gleaming office towers of Hartford, the new green of the deciduous trees, the textured brown of freshly tilled fields, the white church spires and a pair of sailboats by the breakwater in New Haven Harbor.

title: SHAGGY REFUGEES FROM THE WEST
description: OUT on their Western ranges, wild burros are multiplying so fast that they are crowding out the deer and the antelope, not to mention the bighorn sheep and several species of rare plant life. The burros are drawing discouraging words from almost everyone, including environmentalists, hunters and the Pentagon.

description: WASHINGTON IT has been a century since Catholics in

description: Fiction

title: CIVIL WAR PRISON TO GET MONUMENT
description: Nearly 3,000 Confederate prisoners who died of disease, exposure, wounds and hunger will be honored with the first monument in this city to the prison camp that stood here in the last year of the Civil War.

title: No Fanfare for Flame
description: Considering the hoopla and assorted anxiety over who would light the Olympic flame in the opening ceremonies, there seems to have been a decided lack of interest in who will douse the fire Sunday.

title: UNDONE BY LYNDON JOHNSON
description: Joseph P. Lash, author of ''Eleanor and Franklin,'' is at work on a group portrait of the New Dealers. HUBERT HUMPHREY

title: THE REGION ; The Higher MathOf Tax Cuts
description: Is there a tax cut in New York State's future? Republicans in the Legislature think so and now Governor Cuomo and other Democratic leaders appear to be leaning in that direction too.

description: Anna Karenina Starring Maya Plisetskaya and Alexander Godunov; choreographed by Miss Plisetskaya to music by Rodon Shchredrin, 1974 Video Arts International 81 minutes. $49.95

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dewey Petty of Louisville, who said he made his livelihood betting, earned the largest payoff in Kentucky history when his Pick-Six combination at Churchill Downs paid $103,882.40. Petty picked the winners of the third through eighth races Friday.

title: Clay Crown to Maleeva
description: Top-seeded Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria defeated Lisa Bonder, 6-4, 6-3, in the women's final of the $574,000 United States Open Clay-Court tennis championships today.

title: CARTOONIST DREW 'BIG GEORGE'
description: Virgil Partch, creator of the comic strip ''Big George,'' whose work appeared in the New Yorker and other magazines, died Friday in an automobile accident along with his wife, Helen, the California Highway Patrol reported today.

title: SOME YOUNG DOCTORS FIND STRIKE IS HINDERING THEIR TRAINING
description: One of the hidden losses of the strike by nonmedical hospital employees has been the training of young doctors at the city's teaching hospitals, according to doctors and hospital officials.

title: PARACHUTISTS TRY TO EASE TENSIONS
description: AFTER years of bitter battles at town meetings, in state courtrooms and at the State Capitol, homeowners and parachutists at New England's most popular parachuting grounds are finally sitting down to talk amicably in Ellington.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
BROTHERLY STRIFE
description: WHEN A MAN HAS A brother, he is forced from the start into a deep rivalry that may well prepare him for some of life's later great battles. But a brother may also mire him in preadolescent squabbles. A brother makes a boy grow up fast, but, in certain ways, keeps the man a child forever.

title: COACH SAYS DECKER DIDN'T SEEK LEAD AT POINT OF COLLISION
description: Dick Brown, Mary Decker's coach, said today that Miss Decker was not trying to regain the lead from Zola Budd when they collided Friday night in the women's 3,000-meter final of the Games of the XXIII Olympiad.

title: Mary Dudley Has Nuptials
description: Mary Ryan Dudley, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Roane Dudley of Gloucester, Va., was married yesterday to W. Barry McCarthy Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. McCarthy of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Ronald Seguin performed the ceremony at St. Bede's Roman Catholic Church in Williamsburg, Va.

title: Putting on the Brakes
description: For some time, economists have been reporting that the economy was entering the slow-growth phase that normally marks the third year of a recovery. This week's flow of economic statistics should confirm this view. On Tuesday, for example, national retail sales figures for July should be up five-tenths of 1 percent, compared with the gain of eight-tenths of 1 percent in June. The gains will be relatively strong largely because of continued vigorous auto sales, said Jack W. Lavery, chief economist at Merrill Lynch. Auto makers are still subsidizing financing costs, he noted, and without auto figures, the gain would be considerably less. ''Consumers are still confident, but their mood may be changing,'' Mr. Lavery said. ''We expect the outstanding consumer credit figure for June on Tuesday to show a rise of $6.5 billion, down from the $10.2 billion rise in May.''

title: 'BONE TO OWNERS'
description: To the Editor:

title: TALKING DIVORCE-CHANGING LAWS ON PROPERTY
description: THE allocation of the family home and other real-estate holdings at the time of a divorce never has been easy, but changing laws and court rulings are making the task even more complex.

title: JAPAN PLAYS LITERARY HOST: NAGGING DOUBTS AND GLITTERING PRIZES
description: Donald Keene, a professor of Japanese at Columbia University, is the author of ''Dawn to the West: Japanese Literature in the Modern Era.'' He spends part of each year in Japan. TOKYO HE big cultural event of the spring in Japan was the international PEN Congress in Tokyo. Predictably, it was a success, thanks to the efforts and generosity of the Japanese hosts. The delegates were housed at an expensive hotel in the heart of the city. The food (including the banquet attended by the Governor of Tokyo) was excellent, and drinks, beginning at 3 in the afternoon, were unlimited and free. Newspaper coverage of the meeting of the world organization of poets, essaysists, editors and novelists was on a scale unimaginable in most other countries. Dialogues and roundtable discussions were prominently featured, even in magazines that cater to a mass audience, and the flow of television programs originating from the congress still continues.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: SEVERAL hours after protestors from Greenpeace U.S.A. scaled the 160-foot- high water tank at the Ciba- Geigy Corporation's chemical plant in Toms River, three investigators from the State Department of Environmental Protection's Bureau of Field Operations arrived at the security gate for an unannounced inspection of the company's landfills.

title: International
description: Iraq said it had destroyed five ships and shot down three Iranian F-14 jets near the Strait of Hormuz in the Persian Gulf. A military spokesman in Baghdad said five ''large naval targets'' had been left blazing in the sea and three planes that had been protecting an ''enemy naval convoy'' had plunged into the gulf. There was no immediate comment from Iran. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: Flooding Cuts Swiss Roads
description: Heavy rains and landslides Friday night and early today blocked a railroad line and several roads in central Switzerland. Several rivers overflowed their banks in valleys south of Lucerne. There were no reports of casualties.

title: Puerto Rico: Modern Lilliput?

title: Executive in Shift
description: After months of speculation, Steve Ehrhart , the executive director of the United States Football League, made it official yesterday - he is leaving his post to take over as president of the Memphis Showboats. At the same time, it was announced that Pepper Rodgers, who coached the Showboats to a 7-11 record in its first U.S.F.L. season last spring, would remain as head coach.

title: SETTLING BUSINESS ON THE WEST BANK
description: IN the fiercely nationalistic settlement of Gush Etzion on the West

title: THE ART OF BLUFFING
description: Bluffing - the art of convincing the opponent that there is a lot more to your move than meets the eye - does have its place in the strategy of the game, but it requires subtlety and can be used only sparingly.

title: Caroline Kenny Wed to Teacher
description: Caroline Lee Kenny, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Kenny 3d of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married there yesterday to Christopher Charles Burchfield, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William H. Burchfield of Hopewell, N.J. The Rev. Stephen Babos performed the ceremony at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Times Magazine on June 10 about the writer Ved Mehta misstated his relationship with The New Yorker.

title: CASE CHALLENGES THE LEGAL SYSTEM
description: It was inevitable that the case would come to be called ''Rosemary's Baby.''

title: Marion A. Dillon Affianced To Thomas Patrick Morris
description: Marion Alice Dillon and Thomas Patrick Morris, graduates of William Smith and Hobart Colleges, respectively, plan to be married Sept. 15.

title: A CHANCE FOR AMATEUR PLAYERS
description: EVEN ahead of the usual definition of amateur as ''one that engages in a particular pursuit as a pastime rather than as a profession,'' my Webster's notes that the term refers to a person with ''a marked fondness, liking or taste'' for an activity.

title: Dorothy B. Miller Is Wed to William A. Heard 3d
description: Dorothy Bullitt Miller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Forster Miller of Orange, Conn., was married in New Haven yesterday to William A. Heard 3d of Kensington, Md., a son of Mr. Heard Jr. of Midland, Tex., and Mrs. M. Tyson Gilpin of Boyce, Va. The Rev. Michael Barber, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Dwight Chapel at Yale University.

title: HISPANIC COMPLAINT BELITTLED IN RIOT-STRUCK TOWN
description: The Police Chief of Lawrence, Mass., which was rocked by two nights of ethnic rioting earlier this week, denied today that there were any special reasons for tension between his mainly non-Hispanic police force and the city's growing population of Hispanic residents.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
THE FUTILITY OF ECONOMIC NOSTALGIA
description: In their 1984 platform, the Republicans should commit themselves to a more stable and reliable monetary policy. The development of such a policy could be a major achievement of a second Reagan Administration. But a return to the gold standard, recommended by some as a plank in the Republican platform, would be neither a feasible nor a desirable step. The anti-inflationary rules of monetary policy we need will have to be deliberately and rationally selected, not resurrected from some dimly remembered past.

title: High-Voltage Wire Kills Two
description: Two workmen helping re-create the scene of an electrocution earlier this week for a safety inspection were killed Friday by a shock from the same high- voltage wire. The victims were Hudy Putney, 67 years old, and Melton Putney, 53.

title: THE SCOOP ON ROME'S SWEET SNOW
description: In Juvenal's time Roman citizens reportedly went to stalls at the foot of the outlying mountains to buy la dolce neve, sweet snow, brought down from the mountains and mixed with honey and fruit. Modern Romans do not travel quite so far in their pursuit of the sweet snow, or gelato, as it is called today, but they are still very particular about how and where to enjoy this delectable food. so much so that last year, according to a recent study, they consumed 28 1/2 pounds of gelato per person - more than the average for any other Italian city.

title: TRIBALISM, NOT FEMINISM
description: Abigail McCarthy is the author of the novel ''Circles: A Washington Story.'' THE BOOK CLASS

title: SALADS AND VEGETABLES AND MORE
description: AT first glance, the menu at Beanstalk suggests that this attractive yet informal cafe-restaurant in Woodbury (with a branch in Manhattan, at Rockefeller Center) might be a health food restaurant. Or at least a ''healthy food'' restaurant. Why else would they serve hot carob instead of hot chocolate?

title: U.S. Detains 79 Tongans
description: Immigration agents have detained 79 people from Tonga who said they planned to attend the Los Angeles Olympics but were really trying to slip into the country illegally, the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service said today.

title: R.O.T.C. BOOMING AS MEMORIES OF VIETNAM FADE
description: Squads of college men and women charged through the leafy woods and across the rolling hills of this military post, their faces smeared with mud and camouflage grease and their green fatigues soaked with rain as they skirmished to the rattle of rifle fire, the burp of machine guns and the boom of cannon.

title: METS WIN TO HALT SLIDE AS GOODEN STRIKES OUT 10
description: Fittingly, and finally, the Mets' six- game losing streak ended last night with Dwight Gooden adding to his list of strikeout milestones. In beating the Pirates, 3-1, Gooden struck out 10 for his ninth double-digit strikeout game of the season, bringing his total to 181 and breaking Jerry Koosman's 1968 record of 178 for a Met rookie.

title: A BROOKLYN MAN IS CHARGED WITH MOLESTING FOUR CHILDREN
description: A Brooklyn man has been arrested and charged with molesting four children, aged 8 and 9, in his apartment, the police said. The children, two boys and two girls, assisted the police by convincing the suspect to open his front door, authorities said.

title: Denise Alexandre Bride of a Builder
description: Denise Evans Alexandre, an associate editor of Mademoiselle, and Jonathan Bert LeComte, a general contractor in Old Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert T. Hollett performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: THIS 'SATYAGRAHA' IS DISTINGUISHED BY ITS GERMAN DESIGNER
description: Opera, music and theater lovers with access to the venturesome Bravo arts channel (available in the New York area in most suburbs though not in Manhattan) will have a rare opportunity to encounter something really unusual tomorrow night at 10 (and again on Aug. 25 and Sept. 22 at 5 P.M.). At those times, Bravo will telecast the 1981 Stuttgart Opera production of Philip Glass's opera ''Satyagraha.''

title: NOMINATION TO PRISON PANEL RAISES CONCERNS
description: Governor Cuomo has nominated a former sheriff of Albany County to the State Commission of Correction, and some advocates of prison change have expressed concern over the choice of a former sheriff to oversee conditions in local jails run by other sheriffs.

title: LAW ON REFERRALS
description: To The Editor:

title: GOVERNOR INTERVENES IN TEXAS PRISON VIOLENCE
description: Gov. Mark White of Texas has suggested that a dramatic increase in violence among inmates in Texas prisons may have resulted in part from the elimination of a system using inmates as guards that a Federal court found ''tough, corrupt and brutal.''

title: DEMOCRATS BREEZE AS G.O.P. RUNS INTO EARLY HEADWINDS
description: At this early stage of the campaign, President Reagan is ahead in many public opinion polls. But Walter F. Mondale has positioned himself for the kind of challenge few politicians of either party thought possible a month ago.

title: Town May Get Guru's Name
description: Residents of this tiny central Oregon town, which was taken over by the followers of the guru Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, will vote next month on a proposal to rename the community Rajneesh after him.

title: WHERE CIVILIZATION IS AN ECHO
description: This is where it all begins. If there's a strip of sand where the Atlantic Ocean gives up its realm and the land begins, I'm standing on it. This is the spot - near the bend of Cape Hatteras - where the Gulf Stream approaches within 12 miles of shore in summer, the place where the continental shelf turns into a precipice, and the shallows reach for the brink of the Hatteras Abyss, 16,000 feet below them.

title: BRADLEY SEEKS PERMANENT OLYMPIC SITE
description: IF Senator Bill Bradley had had his way, there would have been no Olympic Games in Los Angeles. The Denville Democrat is the author of a Senate resolution that calls for a permanent site for the Olympics to reduce the influence of world politics on and to cut the costs associated with them.

title: JAPAN ACTS TO REVISE SCHOOL SYSTEM
description: Japan has taken a first formal step to reshape its national school system, which has received praise from abroad for its efficacy but has been attacked by domestic critics for stifling creativity.

title: PARALLELS SIFTED BY HOUSE UNIT IN SHOREHAM CASE
description: WASHINGTON

title: SHOPPING AROUND FOR PROPERTY TAX IS THREAT TO ORDER
description: THERE is an interesting, multi-issue, so-called property tax shopping situation unfolding in northwest Westchester. It is one that may have implications beyond the localities involved. The issues are property taxes, zoning, planning, development and politics.

title: LOUDSPEAKERS FOR OUTDOORS
description: Music al fresco ranks high among the pleasures of summer. But then there are mosquitoes and outdoor acoustics. It's hard to say which is worse, and attempts to deal with either have proved only partially successful.

title: STRATFORD KEEPS ITS KINGLY STANDARDS
description: -UPON-AVON

title: WARNING EAST BERLIN FOR SLIGHT LEAN WEST
description: Three months after imposing martial law in Poland, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, flew to East Berlin in March 1982 for a hero's welcome by East Germany's Communist leaders, who were among the sharpest critics of Polish liberalization and had repeatedly called for a crackdown. So some readers must have found it odd last week to find the East German weekly Horizont, which broadly reflects official thinking, reaffirming the right of Communist parties everywhere to ''follow their own paths and arrive at their own solutions and conclusions.''

title: Deborah J. Schwartz Weds Dr. S. D. Roth
description: Deborah Jane Schwartz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred L. Schwartz of New York, and Dr. Steven D. Roth, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Roth of New York, were married yesterday at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel in New York by Rabbi Robert Summers.

title: Craig C. Fischer Weds Miss Morgan, TV Aide
description: Megan Lincoln Morgan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Alexander Morgan of Canton, Ohio, was married yesterday to Craig Charles Fischer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Diedrich Fischer of Mount Prospect, Ill. The Rev. Dr. Loren McClanahan performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Canton.

title: Alison De Laney Becomes a Bride
description: Alison Ann De Laney, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John K. De Laney of Middlebury, Vt., formerly of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to Harold Chapman Granger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Harold Granger 2d of Greenwich, Conn., and Cuttyhunk, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Olin Robison, president of Middlebury College, performed the Protestant ceremony at the Mead Memorial Chapel at the college.

title: THE GOLEM IS A MYTH FOR OUR TIME
description: On the occasion of New York Shakespeare Festival's production of ''The Golem'' by H. Leivick, opening this Thursday at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, I have been asked to express an opinion about why the myth of the golem - an artificial man created, among other instances, to defend the Jews of Prague in the sixteenth century - has interested so many creative people in the past and continues to do so even today in our epoch of science and technology. In the Yiddish tradition I will answer the question with a question: why shouldn't this legend have influenced and intrigued creative minds? It possesses the tension and the suspense of the supernatural. It is based on a faith almost as old as the human species - namely, that dead matter is not really dead but can be brought to life. I am not exaggerating when I say that the golem story appears less obsolete today than it seemed one hundred years ago. What are the computers and robots of our time if not golems?

title: MEN, BOYS AND WIMPS
description: TWO chapters into James Dickey's ''Deliverance,'' the classic moment of classic American fiction recurs, perhaps for the last time. The hero and narrator has a case of the middle-aged blahs, a stifled hopelessness, a stomach- sinking sense that nothing matters, least of all anything he routinely does himself. He therefore accepts an invitation to go white-water canoeing with three friends. On the morning of his departure, his wife asks him whether he really wants to go. Not much, George Stade, a professor of English at Columbia University, is the author of ''Confessions of a Lady- Killer,'' a novel, and the editor of ''European Writers,'' a 12-volume reference work. he says, and then he tells her how low he feels. ''Is it my fault?'' she says. ''Lord, no,'' he says to her, but to the reader he confides that ''It partly was, just as it's any woman's fault who represents normalcy.'' So he takes off.

title: CANADIAN POTATOES FLOOD NORTHEAST MARKETS
description: For 20 years, Vyron Chapman has been selling part of his potato crop to a grocery store only four miles from his farm near Utica, N.Y. But in the last few years, growers in Canada have been able to sell their potatoes to the store at a lower price than Mr. Chapman's.

title: Simenon's Memoirs
description: To the Editor:

title:
NUMISMATICS;
FOR THE SMITHSONIAN
description: The United States Mint has donated more than 100 contemporary U.S. coins and medals to the Smithsonian Institution. The gift includes a complete set of the gold and silver coins struck to commemorate the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles. It also includes examples of the eight gold medals - four one-ounce and four half-ounce pieces - issued since 1980 as part of the American Arts Gold Medallion series.

title: Cardinals' Jeff Griffin Booked in Arson Case
description: A St. Louis Cardinals cornerback, Jeff Griffin, has been booked on suspicion of second-degree arson in connection with a fire at a sportswear store that he is an owner of, the authorities said.

title: A SERIAL ABOUT THE MILITARY GAMBLES ON PATRIOTISM
description: ''Call to Glory'' is as ambitious a television series as you are likely to see this season. Considering the supporting players in the opening episode alone - the real John F. Kennedy, the real Adlai Stevenson, even, briefly, the real Fidel Castro - it is as ambitious a series as you are likely to see any season. In its heart this fictional drama, which mixes in news footage with a story about the Air Force, may be only a soap opera, but in its outer wrappings, lavishly appointed, is the stuff of high drama. ABC, whose production this is, has decided that patriotism is back, and ''Call to Glory'' shows us military men who act while nations tremble and the flag flies over a moderately idealized America. In fact, this isn't bad television at all. The series, making its debut in a two- hour presentation, starts tomorrow at 8 P.M.; future Monday-night episodes will be an hour long.

title:
ANTIQUES;
BICYCLES:RARITIES ONE CAN RIDE
description: FREEHOLD DISCARDED, rusted and bent, a pedal missing, paint gone - collectors look beyond condition to judge an antique bicycle a ''gem.''

title: Surgery for Zahn
description: Geoff Zahn , the California Angel left-hander who has won only one of his last seven starts, has undergone surgery to repair a small bone chip in his left knee at Centinela Hospital in Inglewood, Calif. Zahn, 37, has had problems with the knee since he injured it earlier in the season.

title: CHAMBER MUSIC: A PRIVATE TREAT GONE PUBLIC
description: Edward Schneider writes frequently about recorded music.

title: Response to Alampi On Pesticide Views
description: Although appalled by the June 3 Opinion Page article by Alan Caruba against proposed pesticide legislation (S. 1342), I felt it unnecessary to write a rebuttal. Compared to Senator Raymond Lesniak's factual, rational explanation of the need for his proposed legislation (in the same issue), Mr. Caruba's piece was shown to be just a public relations article with little basis in fact or reality.

title: U.S. SETS MARK WITH 9 GOLDS
description: They had entered the Olympics touted by their coach, Pat Nappi, as the best amateur boxing team ever fielded by the United States. Some of the boxers even boldly predicted a sweep of the 12 divisions, which was dismissed as so much ring bravado. Well, they came close. The Americans set an Olympic record today, winning nine gold medals, among them impressive victories by Mark Breland, Frank Tate and Henry Tillman.

title: TV SETS: NEW FUNCTIONS, NEW FORMS
description: The principle of form following function was first formulated by Victorian biologists trying to account for evolutionary change. A half-century later, it was adopted by architects and designers of the Bauhaus persuasion, eager to dispense with non-functional frills. At present, the process of functional change giving rise to new forms runs rampant in video. Witness what's happening:

title: THE REGION ; Searching forBogus Diplomas
description: Though couched in cautious legalisms, the diagnosis was still unlikely to reassure many patients: There are 6,500 doctors practicing in hospitals in New York State ''whose credentials and qualifications are unknown to the state.'' That unsettling assessment came last week from a committee appointed by Governor Cuomo to determine whether the use of counterfeit medical degrees is widespread in New York.

title: Washington's Mayor Subject of Criticism
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of the District of Columbia had ''a personal relationship'' with a city employee much of the time she admits selling cocaine, according to Mr. Barry's lawyer.

title: PINE BARRENS LANDOWNER FEELS BESIEGED
description: ''I HATE to say it, but I've about had it with this place,'' Joe Forsyth said as he drove his old Dodge pickup down the overgrown road that led to the only real clearing here on his 260 acres of salt marsh and woods.

title: Banach and Schultz Get Golds
description: Mark Schultz and Lou Banach joined their brothers as Olympic gold medalists in freestyle wrestling tonight, but Hideaki Tomiyama of Japan and You In Tak of South Korea kept the United States from sweeping the final four titles.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: YELLOW & PINK

title: A Lawyer Is Wed To Miss Bucknell, Ph.D. Candidate
description: Katherine Cobb Bucknell, a daughter of Louise W. Carter of Wayne, Pa., and the late John Addison Cobb Bucknell, was married yesterday to James Robert Maguire Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maguire of Shoreham, Vt. The ceremony was performed at St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne by the Rev. Dennis R. Clark, a Roman Catholic priest, assisted by the Rev. Rudolf A. Moore, an Episcopal priest.

title: FERRARO'S DAYS TEST AGENTS
description: For the Secret Service agents protecting Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, life is unpredictable.

title: Regarding Our Rights And Our Laws
description: In the article, ''Seat-Belt Law Brings 'Big Brother' Closer to Home'' (Westchester Opinion, July 29), Jennifer P. McLean makes the point that legally requiring the use of safety belts is an infringement on ''the rights of a free people . . . to do what is bad for us.'' She may very well be correct, but it is hard to comprehend why she is fighting so hard for her right to kill or maim herself.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Nurse and Mouse

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of technical and editing errors, the Paperback Best Seller list in some copies of The Book Review today includes a number of incorrect listings. A corrected version appears in the main news section, on page 44.

title: WORKING PARENTS CAN'T STOP Working Parents Can't Stop After three employees of the Praca Day Care Center in the Bronx were arrested for sexually abusing children, an angry mob of New Yorkers surrounded the building. Police had to extricate the six employees trapped inside. Yet three days later, after more charges of abuse, some parents brought their children back. ''Why stop the whole world?'' one mother said. ''We've still got to go to work.''
description: It was safe to assume, of course, that the center's position in the limelight made it unlikely that her son was at risk. Nonetheless, she might have preferred to keep him at home - but that could have put her job at risk. Most children in day care are there because their parents are working, or looking for work, or in school or training.

title: LETTERS ; Danger on the Job
description: To the Editor:

title: A BOOK THAT SHOWS ART DEALERS TO BE HUMAN, TOO
description: Art dealing, as someone once said, is like conducting an orchestra. The only way to learn it is to do it. Among the books to read, there are the memoirs of great European dealers of the recent past like Ambroise Vollard and Daniel- Henry Kahnweiler. There is S. N. Behrman's immensely diverting life of Duveen. Among American growths, there are Julien Levy's ''Memoir of an Art Dealer'' and John Bernard Myers's recent and hugely mischievous ''Tracking the Marvelous.'' It probably helps to have been to business school. It is also a help to have family money, if you know how to use it, and to have served an apprenticeship with the best dealer who will take you on. But fundamentally, like the aspirant conductor, you just have to stand up in full view of the public. If you're no good, they'll tell you.

title: TRAFFIC STIRS A STORM IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: THE 60-year-old highly visible Soldiers' War Memorial here has become the focus of an emotional debate.

title: 26 COMPETITORS REPORT BURGLARIES
description: In a continuing investigation of burglaries at the Olympic Village at the University of Southern California, police said today that 26 athletes have reported a total of $5,275 in cash missing from their rooms, in addition to clothing and other personal items.

title: Bush Meets Latins in Quito
description: Vice President George Bush met today with the presidents of Argentina, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador and Venezuela to discuss regional problems of indebtedness, narcotics and war. Also present were officials from Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama and Peru.

title: WALLS TUMBLING DOWN FOR 'GREAT ROOMS' OPENING INTERIORS ENDS INFORMALITY TO SMALLER HOUSES
description: A RECENT television commercial showed a busy couple settling down to eat a fancy TV dinner in their dining room, instead of the kitchen where they usually dine. ''So this is the dining room,'' exclaimed the husband, clearly taken by his discovery of a part of the house that he had hardly noticed before.

title: DRAMATISTS AS DIARISTS-FROM FRINGE TO ESTABLISH-MENT
description: W ith the New York theater giving its regular midsummer imitation of Death Valley at its most arid, it's time to turn to the bookshelf; and looking over it, one finds that already it's a bumper year for theatrical diaries, notebooks, call them what you will. Here's the playwright Athol Fugard, somberly anguishing over the future of his family, his friends and his art in his native South Africa, and here is the performer-producer Judith Malina, chirpily describing how she met Julian Beck, how he solemnized their friendship by placing a key ring on her wedding finger, and how together they proceeded to found the Living Theater. And here is the director Peter Hall, so flummoxed and distracted by the pangs of bringing Britain's National Theater to life that he begins speculatively toying with thoughts of suicide, or at least of going into a mental hospital and getting electric shock treatment.

title: H
description: Archbishop John Whealon has joined other leaders of the Roman Catholic Church in criticizing Catholic lawmakers who say they oppose abortion but do not work against it.

title: IN SHORT
description: FICTION

title: A FEW SPECIES MAKE A NUISANCE OF THEMSELVES ;
description: Tam Hartell is a writer who gardens in Philadelphia.

title: JAPANESE INVENTIVENESS
description: Tohru Moto-oka of Tokyo University states that the Japanese tradition of group cooperation will be necessary to achieve new breakthroughs in science and technology. Wouldn't it be ironic if the fifth-generation computers they are developing prove to be the very tools that permit

title: Tennessee Air Crash Kills 3
description: A propeller-driven cargo plane crashed into a warehouse and burned shortly after taking off from the Memphis airport today, killing all three people on board, officials said. The DC-3 plane, owned by Aviation Enterprises Inc. of Memphis, was apparently unable to gain altitude after taking off for Chicago about 1 A.M.

title: BYSTROM UNIQUE ON FREE-AGENT LIST
description: Major league clubs received from the Player Relations Committee last week a list of players who are eligible to be free agents at the end of the season. The list has 85 names - 67 players who definitely can be free agents and 18 who can be if their clubs don't exercise contract options for 1985.

title: PAGEANT'S PROPER ACTION AGAINST MISS AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: If you've had your fill of Olympics watching, film buffs at least will have some choice television fare this week, starting with a sturdy pair of Tyrone Power vehicles from the good old days, on Channel 9. They are ''Suez'' (1938), on Sunday at 1 P.M., and ''Nightmare Alley'' (1947), on Monday, same time.

title: TAKING A DAY'S EXCURSION ON QUIET, UNSPOILED WATERWAYS
description: ANYONE who owns or can borrow a trailerable or car-top boat or a canoe with an outboard can enjoy a delightful one-day exploration of the upper reaches of the Wading and Mullica Rivers.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Modeling Sweaters From Australia Individual designs in hand-knitted sweaters from Australia will be modeled during a noon luncheon at the Hudson River Museum Cafe Wednesday. The cost is $10 and may be paid at the door by check or cash, but reservations for the gourmet meal with wine must be made today during museum hours, or tomorrow during staff hours between 9 A.M. and 5 P.M. The telephone is 963-4550 and seating is limited to 160.

title: 'SCRATCH FLAT IS AND WAS THE WORLD'
description: John Anthony West is a novelist, playwright and Egyptologist. His ''Traveler's Key to Ancient Egypt'' will be published next year. CEREMONIAL TIME

title: Terry Menchel Married On L.I. to a Law Student
description: The marriage of Terry Menchel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Menchel of Merrick, L.I., to Jeffrey Hurwitz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Garson Hurwitz of Rochester, took place yesterday at Temple Beth-El in Cedarhurst, L.I. Rabbi Gilbert Rosenthal performed the ceremony.

description: Robert Murphy is a professor of anthropology at Columbia University and has worked in the Amazon area. AMAZON JOURNEY

title: WAS DECKER AFRAID TO PUSH ZOLA?
description: LOS ANGELES DID she or didn't she? Did Zola Budd cut in front of Mary Decker and obstruct her, causing the American favorite to fall in the Olympic 3,000-meter run? Did the barefoot teen-ager's inexperience create the collision?

title: PAKISTAN RULE SAYS U.S. AND WEST ARE TOO SOFT ON DRUG DEALERS
description: President Mohammad Zia ul- Haq, said today that he is willing to introduce the death penalty in Pakistan for drug traffickers but that he feels hampered because of ''soft laws'' for drug offenses in the West.

description: States set a world best in the women's 800-meter wheelchair race held

title: 6 SRI LANKA SOLDIERS KILLED BY MINE, RAISING WEEK'S TOLL TO 57
description: Six Sri Lankan soldiers were killed today when a jeep hit a land mine laid by Tamil separatists, the authorities said. The incident brought the death toll in a week of violence to 57.

title: CORRECTION
description: In some copies of the July 29 issue, a passage of Barbara W. Tuchman's review of ''Archduke of Sarajevo'' appeared incorrectly. It should have read, ''The heir himself once said to his nephew Charles in a revealing remark obtained from his widow, 'Make no mistake. You won't have an easy time with me as emperor.''

title: Pamela J. Joyner Weds Gary Love
description: Pamela Jean Joyner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis B. Joyner of Chicago, was married yesterday to Gary Lorain Love, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Love, also of Chicago. The Rev. Eugene Gray, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Rockefeller Memorial Chapel at the University of Chicago.

title: GERMAN FOLK FESTIVAL
description: The Plattduetsche Volksfest-Vereen of New York and New Jersey, said to be the oldest and largest charitable German-American organization in North America, will hold its 110th annual folk festival in North Bergen today and next Saturday and Sunday in Schuetzen Park.

title:
ANTIQUES;
IN KENT, AN OLD AND POPULAR SHOW
description: KENT, a tiny town in western Connecticut, lies alongside the Housatonic River near the New York State line. For 36 years, its chief summer attraction for many out-of-town visitors has been the annual Kent Antiques Show - a popularity perhaps rivaled now by the chance of catching a glimpse of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Kissinger, new homeowners in the south part of town.

title: Lincoln's Cabinet
description: To the Editor:

title: FISHING FOR PROFIT ON THE BASS CIRCUT
description: -a-year job as a tool inspector for Sargent & Company in New Haven last January, Russ Hall decided to do what he had managed to spend more time doing than working, anyway - go fishing.

title: United Arab Emirates Group Starts Talks on OPEC Prices
description: A United Arab Emirates delegation conferred today with Kuwait's leader on ways to protect OPEC prices in an oil-glutted world market.

title: Who Will Stop Ailing Racer?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Edwin Way Teale
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE GLITTER OF GOLD GAINS IN FACADE AND LOBBY DOOR SOME OWNERS SAY GILDING MAY ENHANCE VALUES
description: THIS month, whenever the wind is calm and humidity is low, workers climb to the top of the 40-story Carlyle Hotel at Madison Avenue and 76th Street to clean and delicately regild its peak with tissue-thin 23- karat gold leaf.

title: Israeli Officers Present Lebanon Pullout Plan
description: Israeli Army officers serving in southern Lebanon have presented a detailed plan for an immediate withdrawal from the area, the Israeli radio reported today.

title:
GARDENING;
PROPAGATING SHRUBS BY CUTTING
description: THERE are many reasons why a gardener might wish to propagate some tree or shrub. Perhaps he or she has admired one in the garden of a friend, only to find that it is unavailable from either the local nursery or any mail- order company. If so, it may be possible to beg a cutting or two, with which to propagate one's own.

title: TROUBLE SEEN FOR ATLANTIC CITY
description: THE decline of Atlantic City could be imminent, according to the preliminary findings of an independent survey entitled ''Atlantic City: Will the Long- Term Gamble Pay Off?''

title: Olga Schluger Is Wed In Neponsit Ceremony
description: Olga Ellen Schluger, a student at Brooklyn Law School, and Philip Bennett Prince, an associate at Goldman Sachs & Company, were married yesterday at the West End Temple in Neponsit, Queens. Rabbi Joseph I. Weiss and Rabbi Stephen Pearce performed the ceremony.

title: THE FLAW IN SOCIAL SECURTIY'S 'CATCH-UP'
description: To the Editor:

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
LICENSING SHOREHAM MAY BE THE BEST WAY
description: THE people are not well served by public policy makers who court votes by bending with every passing gust of popular sentiment rather than exercising real leadership in terms of intelligent action based upon sound and sober judgment. One good illustration is the current controversy over the future of Long Island's Shoreham nuclear energy plant, where kowtowing to transitory public whim can have the most critical consequences for Long Island's residents and business if Shoreham is abandoned.

title: THE NATION ; Conviction for aSitting Judge
description: In April, jurors in Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne's first trial couldn't agree on a verdict. Last week, in a Federal courtroom in Reno, he was convicted of filing false income tax returns for 1979 and 1980.

title: REPLACING AN OLD CEILING FIXTURE
description: REPLACING an old lighting fixture in the ceiling because it no longer works or because you want a newer or more decorative one is not especially difficult for the do-it-yourselfer who is reasonably familiar with house wiring. However, confusion sometimes arises about taking the old one down and hanging the new one because the methods used to hang various fixtures from the ceiling box are not all the same.

title: Yugoslavia Is Champion
description: Yugoslavia scored three straight goals in the last six minutes today to beat West Germany, 18-17, for the Olympic gold medal in men's team handball.

title: PLANS FOR CARNEGIE HALL
description: Carnegie Hall has announced program plans for its Recital Hall in the 1984-5 season, with an emphasis on what is sometimes called ''vernacular'' music: jazz and folk music of various kinds, and American musical theater. This is the second season for which the Carnegie organization has significantly increased its sponsorship of events in the smaller auditorium, which functions as a rental hall during much of the season.

title: PINOCHET'S HARD LINE STIRS UP HIS FOES
description: During the 11 years he has ruled Chile, General Augusto Pinochet has devoted much of his considerable power to purging the country of Communists. But that hasn't stopped them from re-emerging in the last year as the focus of Chile's bitter political stalemate and the force behind much of the internal violence.

title: NEW YORK'S SUBSIDEZED MORTGAGES DRAW FIRE
description: There was a run on New York State banks last week, but not by worried depositors. Instead, hopeful home-buyers camped out in front of the doors, lured by $179 million worth of subsidized mortgages with an interest rate under 11 percent - several percentage points below market.

title: STATE STUDIES SWAN POPULATION
description: ALTHOUGH mute swans are not native to Connecticut, the large birds have adapted very well to conditions on the state's ponds and rivers since they first arrived in the late 1950's.

title: FILM ; A HOLLYWOOD TEAM PLAYS IN ATLANTA
description: ATLANTA

title: IRAQ ASSERTS IT SET FIVE SHIPS ON FIRE IN BATTLE IN GULF
description: Iraq said today that its forces had destroyed five ships and shot down three Iranian F-14 jet fighters in a battle in the Persian Gulf.

title: STORM ISN'T OVER FOR H.R.A. - OR KOCH
description: With the resignations last week of James A. Krauskopf, the beleaguered Commissioner of the Human Resources Administration, and Gail M. Kong, a top deputy, many City Hall officials expressed hope that one of the most troubling situations in the history of the Koch administration had finally run its course. But such hopes are likely to be dashed, some of the Mayor's critics believe, because the wide array of political, social and management problems that have bedeviled the agency and brought about the resignations remain unresolved.

title: PLATINI IS SHOWING HIS BEST TO COSMOS
description: It takes little time even for the uninitiated to soccer to determine Michel Platini from the rest of the players in a game. He is usually the one with the longest hair and with his jersey hanging out over his shorts.

title: OLYMPIC HIGHLIGHTS
description: Mark Breland and Carl Lewis, who will be able to turn gold into millions, paced impressive performances as the nearly all-American Games of the XXIII Olympiad neared their conclusion.

title: ECLECTIC ACING IN TROUPE'S DEBUT
description: THE East Hampton Theater Company, which has been performing at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, has moved up and out. It has left its amateur status in East Hampton and has moved what is now a professional theater company into the Bridgehampton Community House for its debut production of Christopher Durang's comedy ''Beyond Therapy.'' The major attraction of this production is that its highlights hold out hope for the company's future artistic growth and development.

title: 6 MAXI YACHTS IN FINAL RACE
description: Boomerang, the new 81-foot maxi boat launched early this year by George Coumantaros of New York, leads a 64-boat fleet at the start of the final race here in the Pan Am Clipper Cup yacht racing series.

title: OPERA: HANDEL'S 'IMENEO' IN FAUNTLEROY PRODUCTION
description: Handel's ''Imeneo'' at the La Guardia Music Theater Friday night was as much an act of faith as a product of scholarship. The opera was first done in London in 1740 and then two years later in Dublin, but afterward, the constituents of the score seem to have gone in several directions. This scattering of sources has left 20th-century musicologists to come up with some kind of coherent version from the different fragments and variants that have survived.

title: THE FEW AND FADED HOPES OF 'FATHER ZIMBABWE'
description: In the days when he hoped and planned for power, Joshua Nkomo called himself ''Father Zimbabwe.''

title: Q&A
description: Deduction Question: In 1978, the State Legislature passed a bill allowing tenants to take a proportional share of a building's property taxes as a tax deduction. I have never received any such statement, nor has anyone I know. How come? . . . J. H. O'C., Manhattan

title: Recent Sales
description: Andover $84,900 *2*14 Terrace Drive, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*older bilevel; oak floors, pool with patio, *2*woodstove; taxes $1,800. Chester $114,000 *2*15 Hedges Road, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*100-year-old restored farmhouse; wrap-around *2*porch, 1.6 acres; taxes $1,836. Middletown $76,500 *2*3 Village Lane, 3-bedroom, 1-bath, *2*29-year-old ranch; porch, fireplace in living *2*room; taxes $1,635. Oakland $123,500 *2*49 Page Drive, 4-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*25-year-old colonial; modern kitchen, *2*Florida room, patio; taxes $2,400. Short Hills $143,000 *2*60 Wellington Avenue, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*35-year-old colonial; new roof, living room *2*fireplace, finished basement; taxes $2,755. Summit $365,000 *2*122 Prospect Street, 6-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*46-year-old colonial; slate roof, screened porch, *2*2-car garage; taxes $3,917. OTHER AREAS Wantagh, L.I. $104,000 *2*190 Brent Drive, 3-bedroom, 1-bath, *2*33-year-old ranch; basement, dining room; *2*taxes $2,500. Stratford, Conn. $61,900 *2*131 Evelyn Street, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*half of new 2-family house; country kitchen *2*with dining area; taxes $571 Elmsford, N.Y. $76,000 *2*166 Sears Avnue, 3-bedroom, 1-bath, *2*21-year-old frame ranch; porch, aluminum siding, *2*deadend; taxes $2,020.

title: T
description: HE WORLD

title: COMMUNITY LEADERS SEEK SHARE OF U.S. HOMELESS AID
description: COMMUNITY leaders concerned about the county's homeless were heartened last week when an increase in funds won approval in Congress, but they were continuing efforts to insure that Westchester gets a share of the Federal allocation for emergency food and shelter.

title: FARM BELT DEMOCRATS ATTACK BLOCK OVER PRIVATE VENTURES
description: When President Reagan named John R. Block, a prosperous Illinois hog farmer, to be Secretary of Agriculture, farmers applauded the choice of a man who knew at first hand the value of land, the whims of weather and the power of the local banker.

title: Elizabeth S. Petri Wed in Maryland
description: At All Saints Episcopal Church in Chevy Chase, Md., yesterday Elizabeth Stone Petri, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Arthur Petri of McLean, Va., was married to Robert Charles Henske, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John McClanahan Henske of Greens Farms, Conn., and Ocean Reef, Fla. The Rev. John E. Howanstine performed the ceremony.

title: FALL TO SEE NEW WILDCLIFF ARTS CENTER
description: NEW ROCHELLE EAST COAST ARTS at Wildcliff, the new arts center based in the former wildlife and nature facility, will open its first season this fall with original works of drama, art, music and dance, according to its artistic director, Joe Cacaci.

title: Job for Drunken-Driving Foe
description: Candy Lightner, founder of Mothers Against Drunk Drivers, will add the title of chief executive officer. She is now president and chairman.

title: A Solidarity Leader Is Freed by Warsaw
description: Jan Rulewski, a leader of the outlawed Solidarity labor movement, said today that he had been released from jail under a Government amnesty for political prisoners.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN ELMONT
description: SINCE Elmont's boundaries were established at the turn of the century, two aspects of life in this bedroom community just across the New York City line in Nassau County have remained constant.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When I tell them to do something they always ask me why. Why, why, why; I'm not used to being asked why.'' - Staff Sgt. Robert R. Collins, who drills cadets in the Reserve Officers Training Corps. (40:6.)

title: NOT AS PAWNS OF THE CHURCH
description: In 1976, when he and Presidential candidate Jimmy Carter were being hassled by pro-life demonstrators, Chicago's Mayor Richard Daley, in the voice of an incredulous schoolmaster that he used to explain political truisms to the press, said that Catholics would not make their voting decisions on the abortion issue. ''They don't vote that way,'' he observed, closing the discussion.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: ON the North Shore line, the Long Island Rail Road is conducting track work: two words, short and clickety- clack sharp, that reverberate hollowly in a commuter's ear.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEOCASSETTES
description: Rear Window Starring James Stewart, Grace Kelly, Wendell Corey, Thelma Ritter; directed by Alfred Hitchcock, 1954 MCA Home Video 113 minutes. $59.95

title: Dedication Was Key for U.S. Winners
description: Right to the end, even after the gold medals hung from their necks, members of the United States men's Olympic team followed the direction of the coach.

title: AFTER THE COUP AT PHIBRO-SALOMON
description: DURING the last several Saturday and Sunday mornings while the staff of Montefiore Medical Center has been on strike, the portly, bespectacled figure of John H. Gutfreund has been seen preparing meals and washing dishes at the Bronx hospital. He resolutely refuses to discuss it, saying only, ''You do what you do because you have to.''

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Jazz

title:
GARDENING;
PROPAGATING SHRUBS BY CUTTING
description: THERE are many reasons why a gardener might wish to propagate some tree or shrub. Perhaps he or she has admired one in the garden of a friend, only to find that it is unavailable from either the local nursery or any mail- order company. If so, it may be possible to beg a cutting or two, with which to propagate one's own.

title: LETTERS
description: The Tax Bill To the Editor:

title: Westchester Journal
description: Courageous II Westchester came to Newport, R.I., last weekend in a flurry of patriotic hoopla. A brass band played, red, white and blue bunting waved in the wind and fireworks went off in bright daylight as Joyce Greene of Scarsdale cracked a bottle of American Champagne over the bow of the 12 meter yacht Courageous II.

title: HEADLINERS;
description: Office Sans Furniture Boston, which gave the country a famous armored car robbery known as ''the Brinks job,'' apparently has been the scene of something that might be called the desk job. Ever since he came to office in January, Mayor Raymond L. Flynn has wanted to carry out his duties seated at a large carved mahogany desk once used by Mayor James Michael Curley.

title: MAKING FRIENDS, AND FOES, BY PHONE
description: JOHN KOCH and Thadine Connorton of Elmont are getting married because of it, and Diane Walsh of Mastic says, ''It's meant a whole new life to me. Psychologically, it's the No. 1 thing in my life.''

title: BELL ASKS APPROVAL TO TRANSMIT DATA
description: OFFICIALS of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, which earlier this month asked the state's Board of Public Utilities for permission to increase by almost 64 percent the rate charged for basic telephone service, hope that offering low-cost data transmission to users of business and home computers will eventually help ease the pinch on customers facing rising rates.

title: T
description: HE WORLD

title: CONCERT: SYLVAN WINDS AT MOSTLY MOZART FESTIVAL
description: Like a party that has joyfully exceeded its bounds, the Mostly Mozart Festival spilled outdoors onto the plaza of Lincoln Center this year. On Friday night, the Sylvan Winds presented the last in a series of weekly programs around the plaza's fountain. A good crowd showed up - not only ticket-holders to the evening's concert, but neighborhood residents and even a few dogs that sprawled on the concrete, luxuriating in the cool summer evening.

title: Statistical Confidence
description: Jack Rosenthal's feature on ''Error of Margin'' brought refreshing clarity to the ''statistics-speak'' that often characterizes reporting of political polls (On Language, July 15). However, one critical point was missing: the notion of statistical ''confidence.''

title: THE REGION ; 'C.S.-1' NabsG.S.A. Deputy
description: The deputy director of the regional office of the Federal agency that obtains supplies for other Federal agencies was charged last week with taking $64,000 in bribes from a private supplier. United States Attorney Raymond J. Dearie said that the bribes, paid by a manufacturer identified only as ''C.S.-1'' or ''Confidential Source-1,'' went to Edward H. Wyatt Jr., deputy regional administrator of the General Services Administration, in exchange for making the businessman's dealings with the government ''hassle-free.''

title: WHAT'S DOING IN THE HIGHLANDS
description: Scotland's Highlands shimmer with a physical beauty as varied as their weather. But amid the mountains, lochs, rivers and coastline are echoes of a violent history: Bonnie Prince Charlie's rebellion against the English, the massacre at Glencoe, the Highland clearances, and more.

title: HOSPITAL STRIKE TALKS STEP UP AS CUOMO STEPS IN
description: The war of attrition between striking hospital workers and New York City's private nonprofit hospitals ground into its fifth week, producing violence on the picket lines, concern over the well-being of patients, the intervention of Governor Cuomo, renewed negotiations and, finally, some movement toward a settlement last week.

title: October Wedding For Hilary Mills
description: Mr. and Mrs. James T. Mills of Upper Montclair, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hilary Frances Mills, to Brian John Lambert, a son of Maura Lambert and Robert Lambert, both of Cleveland. The wedding is planned for late October.

title: HUNTERS OF THE BERING SEA
description: PEOPLE OF THE ICE WHALE

title: Five New Yorkers Arrested In Theft of Traveler's Checks
description: Five New Yorkers suspected of using stolen traveler's checks to purchase thousands of dollars in merchandise have been arrested after one of the group used one of the checks to pay a hotel bill.

title: UNION IN TURMOIL OVER FUND DISPUTE
description: THE largest labor union for public employees in the state is facing a defection by members employed by Suffolk County in a dispute over control of union funds.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
A TIME FOR TESTING WINGS
description: I LOVE ivy geraniums, especially in pink. It was mid-May

title: POWERHOUSE PLAN
description: With major office, hotel and retail facilites for Manhattan's West Side on the drawing board, the developers of a new office project on West 39th Street hope to profit from expected growth in the area by creating a narrow 25-story tower that will incorporate a vacant Con Edison substation.

title: Ellen Petrick Wed to S. A. Underwood
description: Ellen A. Petrick, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley R. Petrick of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., was married yesterday to Steven A. Underwood, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Underwood of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. The Rev. Ronald S. James performed a Protestant ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: KNOPF'S PRIZE-WINNERS
description: Nobel Authors

title: Lewis Feat on Tape Delay The 400-meter relay race in which Carl Lewis won his fourth gold
description: medal, wasn't seen on live television in the United States last night.

title: Animal Liberation
description: Activists struck a second time last month at an animal laboratory at the University of Pennsylvania. The raiders, who said they belonged to the Animal Liberation Front, carried off three cats, two dogs and eight pigeons at the School of Veterinary Medicine.

title: SEAPORT READIES FOR HURRICANE
description: IF a hurricane threatens the Connecticut coast this year, employees and volunteers at Mystic Seaport will swamp small boats and secure great ships, cover an 1880 printing press with polyurethane and haul thousands of artifacts, books and documents to higher, safer ground.

title: T
description: HE NATION

title: MUSEUM LETS GERMANS SEE THE OLD WEST
description: As sounds of Indian whoops and drums drifted into a log cabin filled with rifles, Western saddles, buckskin jackets and deerskins, about 200 children and adults listened intently. Some stared up at the buffalo, deer, bear and moose heads lining the walls. Others studied a huge, stuffed black bear standing next to a stone fireplace.

title: FROM JOHN WINTHROP TO MISTER SOFTEE
description: Jonathan Raban is the author of ''Arabia: A Journey Through the Labyrinth'' and ''Old Glory: An American Voyage.'' DISCOVERING THE VERNACULAR LANDSCAPE

title: Government Employment Up After Two Years of Declines
description: The number of people working for Federal, state and local governments has resumed its gradual increase since World War II, after two years of unusual declines, according to the Bureau of the Census.

title: Triumph for New Zealand
description: Ian Ferguson became a triple gold medalist today as he led New Zealand's kayak team to a first-place finish in the Olympic 1,000-meter fours race.

title: IEADS & TRENDS ; ConvertingType A'sTo Type B's
description: While investigating the link between fats in the blood and heart disease nearly three decades ago, cardiologists Meyer Friedman and Ray H. Rosenman became aware of a curious phenomenon: Patients were wearing away the fabric on the chairs in their San Francisco waiting room. Such behavior was one element in their concept of the Type A personality - those hurry-up, take charge individuals shown to be three times more likely to have heart attacks.

title: William L. Wallace 3d Weds Martha DuBois
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., was the setting yesterday of the wedding of Martha Sherman DuBois, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Clark DuBois of Fairfield, Conn., and William Lockhart Wallace 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace 2d of Orange, Conn.

title: Pace Gains Gold In Men's Archery
description: Darrell Pace of Hamilton, Ohio, shattered his own Olympic record today to win the gold medal in the men's archery competition.

title: FOR 2 CAPTIVE-BORN MANATEES, A STEP TO WILD
description: A festive crowd gathered around the lagoon at the Homosassa Springs Nature World recently to welcome two new arrivals: Sunrise, 22 months old, and his half-sister Savannah, 23 months old. The two were the first manatees to be born and raised in captivity. Now they will eventually be released into the wild.

title: Aviator Has Her First Crash After Flying Almost 60 Years
description: Edna Gardner Whyte, a pioneer aviator, was in good condition today with a broken nose, bruises and cuts suffered in her first crash after nearly 60 years of flying.

title: BALANCE OF POWERS AN ISSUE IN TRENTON
description: THE State Supreme Court last week added fuel to one of the state government's longest-running debates: Exactly where are the boundaries that separate the three branches of government?

title: FROM 1917 TO 1984, MUSICALS OFFER PLENTYTO SING ABOUT
description: Show tunes from the musical theater - some new, some disinterred from the dust of the past, some hardy perennials that seem able to survive every vicissitude of fashion - make up the contents of a number of recent recordings.

title: U.S. BEATS BRAZIL FOR THE GOLD MEDAL
description: With the help of several important adjustments, the United States men's volleyball team tonight defeated Brazil, 15-6, 15-6, 15-7, to reverse a one- sided defeat of five days ago and win its first gold medal.

title: Jo Ellen Gerstenmaier to Be the Bride Of Carl J. Ally, Advertising Executive
description: Lois Rolfing Gerstenmaier of Akron, Ohio, and John H. Gerstenmaier of Naples, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jo Ellen Gerstenmaier to Carl J. Ally, the son of Mary Smith of St. Clair Shores, Mich., and the late Carl Ally. The wedding is planned for Sept. 8.

title: SUCESS OF GAMES IN LOS ANGELES LIKELY TO CHANGE FUTURE OLYMPICS
description: The largest, the best attended and, for the United States, the most successful Olympic Games in history will end Sunday in a ceremony blazing with fireworks and laser beams.

title: Men's Crown to Pakistan
description: Pakistan won the gold medal in men's field hockey today with a 2-1 victory over West Germany in the first Olympic final to go into overtime.

title: A BOXING GYM WHERE 2 WORLDS MEET
description: UP and down the block is the sort of scene that might be expected around a boxing gym: empty storefronts, a rubble-strewn vacant lot and railroad tracks where children throw rocks at passing trains.

title: ZIMBABWE PLANS ONE-PARTY RULE BUT DOES NOT SEEK HASTY CHANGE
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe's ruling party adopted a new party constitution today calling for the creation of a Marxist-oriented, one-party state in this Western-modeled democracy.

title: A REAL BARN RAISING
description: CONVERTING FARM BUILDINGS into quaint country houses has become such a common practice that when these utilitarian structures are exquisitely renovated to serve their original purpose - to house horses and farm gear - the very idea seems unusual. Especially when John Saladino, one of this country's leading interior designers, is the person chosen to carry out the scheme.

title: A Rally for British Miners
description: Thousands of wives of striking coal miners marched through London today to demonstrate their support for the 22- week-old walkout. The women, many with their children, silently laid black flowers along Whitehall, Britain's street of government, before staging a rally in a London park.

title: PLAN TO FREE BARBIE REPORTED
description: A onetime Bolivian associate of Klaus Barbie, the former Nazi accused of being a war criminal, planned to kidnap senior French officials to secure the release of Mr. Barbie from his prison in France, a Government official said Friday.

title: OPERAS THAT AREN'T BROKEN SHOULD NOT BE FIXED
description: Folk wisdom, the sediment of centuries of trial and error, tends to settle into terse commands. ''Close cover before striking.'' ''Refrigerate after opening.'' ''Face ladder descending.'' ''Dont (sic) walk.'' ''Yield.'' ''Call your mother.'' Man never thinks so clearly, it seems, as when he is in an imperative mood. Consider the simple beauty of the pragmatist's motto, ''If it ain't broke, don't fix it.'' That's a warning that should be printed on the title page of every opera in the standard repertory, right there where stage directors might read it, if they should ever happen to open the score.

title: SOVIET AGAIN ATTACKS GERMANYS FOR CLOSER LINKS
description: The Soviet press asserted today that West Germany was moving away from the ''letter and spirit'' of the Moscow Treaty signed 14 years ago, which laid the foundations of West German-Soviet detente.

title: Japanese Inventiveness
description: Steve Lohr's article, ''The Japanese Challenge: Can They Achieve Technological Supremacy?'' (July 8), notes the deficiencies in American productivity and the need for many improvements in this country. There is a management challenge from Japan as well as a labor challenge.

title: FOUNDER OF PUBLISHING HOUSE
description: Alfred A. Knopf, one of America's outstanding publishers, whose imprint bore his own name and whose books symbolized quality for more than half a century, died of congestive heart failure yesterday at his home in Purchase, N.Y. He was 91 years old.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates , at Shea Stadium. Ron Darling, who has been trying to win No. 11 since before the All-Star break, will oppose Jose DeLeon of the Pirates. (Television - SportsChannel, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.)

title: SATELLITE TELEVISION GROWING IN COUNTY
description: HUNDREDS of Westchester and Putnam County residents have been spending thousands of dollars to watch ''birds'' from the comfort of their own living rooms, bedrooms and dens.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption on page 1 of the Arts and Leisure section today, with the drawing of the cast of ''The Golem,'' misidentifies one actor. The third figure, counterclockwise from the upper left, is Ron Weyand.

title: Japanese Wins Open Judo
description: Yasuhiro Yamashita of Japan overcame a leg injury today to keep his seven-year unbeaten record alive and win the Olympic gold medal in the open judo competition.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: FLOATING ALOFT, ANTIQUITY IN NORTH AFRICA
description: Balloonists Aiming High In the West

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: The late Maggie Sherwood was best known in the photography world as the feisty presiding spirit of the Floating Foundation of Photography, a unique exhibition space and center of photographic construction that, in its early days, had no fixed address, since it was located on a houseboat that tied up at the 79th Street Boat Basin and other spots along the waterways of New York City and vicinity. The Floating Foundation specialized in bringing photography instruction to inmates of prisons, hospitals and other institutions, and its informal exhibitions featured work by a wide range of photographers, some very well known, some unknown, and some who became known after exhibiting there.

title: Barbara Costello, Teacher, Wed to Alfred F. Lyons Jr.
description: Barbara Marie Costello, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Timothy W. Costello of Garden City and Head of the Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Alfred Francis Lyons Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lyons of Hingham, Mass. The Rev. Gerald Leibenguth performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City.

title: A TROUBLED SUMMER FOR STRAWBERRY
description: On the Mets' charter flight from California a few months back, Darryl Strawberry got into an argument with a teammate that was on the verge of turning physical until other players and coaches intervened.

title: WORKS FORM JAMAICA SHOW AN ISLAND EVOLUTION
description: IN the United States, Jamaica is famous for its reggae and rum, its beaches and bauxite, but its reputation for art lags far behind that of another Caribbean island, Haiti. Fortunately, the National Gallery of Jamaica has done something about this by organizing ''Jamaican Art: 1922-1982,'' in collaboration with the Smithsonian Institution Traveling Exhibition Service. Fortunately, too, for Connecticut, the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford is the host of the show, having examined Haitian art a year or two ago. Prospective visitors should take note that it closes next Sunday.

title: ON JERSEY, BRITISH MOOD JUST OFF FRANCE
description: Jersey, a small, nice place just off the Normandy coast, sells itself as the spot having the most sunshine in the British Isles. It tells the French it has a year- round ''micro-climate'' (as if Jersey had worked out some exclusive representational deal on blue sky in the English Channel), and it tells them too that it is both olde and quaynt, a shopper's paradise, able to turn the purchase of a bottle of Scotch minus the value-added tax into a moment of ecstatic tremblings, mild tachycardia. Pitching to the British, Jersey goes over the same ground as bargain-basement-in-the-sun, but insists that the island, while loyal to the crown, is also quite continental, Frenchy. Eat a snail, buy a quid's worth of plonk, then escape to watch Benny Hill on the hotel telly.

title: Blueberry Muffin Recipe In Mondale Cookbook
description: Yes, ''The Mondale Family Cookbook'' has a recipe for blueberry muffins.

title: WARD SPRAINS RIGHT ANKLE
description: Bad luck and bad play continued to plague the Jets tonight, as they lost their second consecutive exhibition game and the services, at least for a short time, of another key player.

title: IN SEARCH OF THE ULTIMATE ISLAND
description: ''I wish I were in mine island,'' Byron used to wail when things were not going to his poetic, or lordly, liking. He was not the first man to imagine that isolation would be blissful, and he was certainly not the last. Getting away from it all is, if we are honest, much the same as getting away from

title: 'TOWERS AND TRENCHES' MEET AT PRINCETON SUMMER SCHOOL
description: Alan Miller, a special-education teacher in Alaska, traded teaching for note-taking this summer to study the evolution of technology.

title: WAR MEMOIR BY SANDINISTA IS BEST SELLER
description: A memoir of life as a Sandinista guerrilla has become a best-selling book in Nicaragua.

title: U.S. to Appeal Court Award Of $3 Million on Test Fallout
description: The Justice Department on Friday filed a notice of intent to appeal a Federal district judge's ruling that fallout from atomic testing in Nevada in the 1950's had caused cancer in residents.

title: AN INVITATION TO AN ESTHETIC TEATIME AT THE COPPER-HEWITT
description: ''Have some wine,'' the March Hare said in an encouraging tone. Alice looked all round the table, but there was nothing on it but tea. ''I don't see any wine,'' she remarked.

title: Patricia Fitzgibbons Is Bride in Capital
description: Patricia Jean Fitzgibbons, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John B. Fitzgibbons of Ilion, N.Y., was married yesterday to Milton F. Heller 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Heller Jr. of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. James Myers, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Universalist National Memorial Church in Washington, assisted by the Rev. William L. Fox Jr., a Universalist minister.

title: Rockets Get Wiggins
description: With Akeem Olajuwon joining Ralph Sampson , the Houston Rockets will be overstocked with big men this season but short on guards. So yesterday they traded one of their bigger men, Caldwell Jones , to the Bulls for Mitchell Wiggins and Chicago's 1985 second- and third-round draft choices.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE speeding train rounded the bend in the quiet commercial area of Franklin Lakes and a moment passed before the engineer realized that the orange school bus a quarter of a mile down the track had stalled at a rail crossing. Even with the train's brakes fully applied, the crash was unavoidable. The bus and two nearby parked cars were carried down the track in a tumble of debris and dust. Victims were everywhere. Fire and ambulance crews were on the scene in minutes.

title: MAINE WOODS HOLIDAY
description: The lingering mist of early morning covers the river as it winds among the fir, spruce and cedar forest that stretches for 60 miles north to the Quebec border. A landlocked salmon hits the fly, shattering the tranquillity with a series of explosive leaps and runs. Twenty minutes later, the angler nets the salmon, a hefty four-pound fish, in an eddy off the river's main flow.

title: An Invitation to Taking A Stroll in Ridgewood
description: Howard Mansfield's Personally Speaking article, ''A Short Step Into Nostalgia'' (July 22), is a one-sided look at walking. Where I live, walking is an interesting voyage with each step.

title: RELIGIOUS FRICTIONS HEAT UP IN NIGERIA
description: This grimy industrial city in north central Nigeria has become the center of intense controversy over the use and abuse of power. The debate touches on strains between Islam and Christianity along the seam between Arab and black Africa. It also concerns the abduction in London last month of Umaru Dikko, an important figure in the civilian Government that was overthrown by the military on Dec. 31.

title: Nuptials Planned By Miss Trainer
description: Mr. and Mrs. H. Potter Trainer Jr. of Middleboro, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Trainer, to Peter Wright Duble Jr., a son of Mr. Duble of Hamden, Conn., and Nancy Stead Duble of North Haven, Conn. A December wedding is planned.

title: Uruguay Vows to Free 154 Political Prisoners
description: The military Government has said that it will release 154 political prisoners, delivering on a promise it made to political groups during recent negotiations on returning the country to civilian rule.

title: THE DEMOCRATS' STAKE IN '84 BORDEAUX
description: Verne W. Newton has a modest wine collection of good vintages. Forget about the Ferraro factor, Central America, Texas, the polls, deficits and debates. Why become preoccupied with the irrelevant? The inescapable fact is that events in France, not the United States, will determine who wins in November. In vino veritas, in wine there is truth, and the truth is this: When Bordeaux wines have a good vintage year, the Democrats win. When they have a poor one, Republicans win.

title: Eternal City
description: To the Editor:

title: THE OTHER OLD PHILADELPHIANS
description: David Levering Lewis teaches history at Howard University and the University of California, San Diego. He is the author of ''When Harlem Was In Vogue.'' ONE MORE DAY'S JOURNEY

title: MIAMI BEACH IS STRIVING TO REBUILD AS A CLASSY HOME AND PLACE TO VISIT
description: A decade ago Miami Beach officials had plans to develop the south point of the city into a worldwide resort with luxury hotels, condominiums, office buildings and romantic canals that would rival those in Venice.

title: U.N. STUDIES PLANS TO SLOWWORLD POPULATION GROWTH
description: ALMOST two centuries after Malthus, the United Nations International Conference on Population convened in Mexico City for an update on density and destiny. It was an appropriate setting. Some 3,000 delegates from more than 130 countries had only to gaze out the windows of the glass- sheathed Ministry of Foreign Relations for a firsthand view of the problem. Mexico, despite what is considered an effective family planning program, will double in size in less than three decades.

title: Joan E. Goody, Architect, Wed
description: Joan Edelman Goody, an architect in Boston, and Peter Davison of Gloucester, Mass., the poet and senior editor of the Atlantic Monthly Press and poetry editor of The Atlantic, were married yesterday. James Vorenberg, dean of the Harvard Law School, performed the civil ceremony at Agassiz House of Radcliffe College in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Tamara Lipshie Wed To Perry S. Williams
description: Tamara Leah Lipshie, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Lipshie of Lakeville, Conn., and New York, was married yesterday to Perry S. Williams, a son of Kathleen Williams of Acton, Mass., and Richard Williams of Oak Harbor, Wash. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Westbury Hotel in New York.

title: RESTORING A MADISON AVE. PAVILION
description: In 1928, when Louis Sherry's decided to open an ice- cream parlor and restaurant on Madison Avenue at 62d Street, the firm of McKim Mead and White designed an elegant pavilion for the establishment featuring fluted bronze columns, bronze doors and large sheets of plate glass set in a facade of limestone and granite.

title: WHEN THE MIDDLE EAST CAPTIVATED WESTERN PAINTERS
description: WASHINGTON, D.C.

title: No Headline
description: Karen Igler Is Engaged

title: SPECIALISTS SOUGHT FOR TRAUMA CENTER
