description: HARTFORD OFFICIALS of the St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center here hope their emergency room will become the first in the state to be staffed entirely by physicians who are certified specialists in emergency medicine.

title: Julia Knerr the Bride Of Douglas D. Miron
description: Julia Snow Knerr, who will attend the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, and Douglas David Miron, who will become an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, were married in a Quaker ceremony in Philadelphia yesterday at the Greene Street Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:

title: Valerie Asciutto, City Aide, to Wed
description: The engagement of Valerie Asciutto to Michael Henry has been announced by Louis Asciutto of Demarest, N.J., father of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Henry of Brooklyn.

title: Anne Woodward Will Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. M. Cabell Woodward Jr. of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Cary Woodward, to Jonathan Freeman Boucher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger W. Boucher of Bristol, R. I. The wedding is to take place in November.

title: Miss Young Wed To a Film Maker
description: Dariel Ann Young, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth E. Young of Skaneateles, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Daniel Curren, a son of Mrs. John R. Curren and the late Mr. Curren of New Haven. The Rev. David Mulholland performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church in Owasco, N.Y.

title: Anne Louise Tripp Weds Dean Miller, an Engineer
description: Anne Louise Tripp, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Daniel Tripp of Huntington and Sag Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Dean Jerome Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Douglas Miller of Fort Atkinson, Wis. The Rev. David Hay Stewart performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Sag Harbor.

title: NEW DELHI SEEKS EXTENDED PUNJAB RULE
description: The Indian Government, troubled by terrorist activity in Punjab, will propose a constitutional amendment to maintain direct control over the northern state for one more year, officials said today.

title: IN FIRST DISTRICT, 4 SEEK ONLY SEAT CONTESTED ON BOARD
description: WHITE PLAINS JACK GAFFNEY is challenging County Legislator Tim Carey for the Conservative line and defending his Democratic line against Al Gaines. For his part, Mr. Carey is challenging the authenticity of petitions aimed at giving Dan Sadofsky a share of the Republican line.

title: THE WORLD ; Israel's LaborGets a Chance
description: Israel last week concentrated on grave domestic concerns. President Chaim Herzog, citing economic problems ''that may well be the most dangerous and difficult this state has ever known,'' asked Shimon Peres, a fellow Labor Party member, to try to form a government.

title: THE WORLD ; Latest ResultsIn the Arms Race
description: Two years ago, Paul H. Nitze, then the American negotiator at Geneva, reported a tentative agreement with his Soviet counterpart to limit each side to 75 launchers of medium- range missiles, most of them to be aimed at Europe. The proposal was rejected in the White House and the Kremlin (which the Reagan Administration insists was never ready to accept it).

title: Costa Rica's Cabinet Resigns Amid Charges
description: All 14 members of President Luis Alberto Monge's Cabinet resigned today, making way for a Government reorganization following widespread accusations of corruption.

title: WOMAN ATHLETES TOPPLE SPORTS MYTH
description: In the final moments of the Olympic marathon last weekend, the first that women were allowed to run in the history of the Games, Kathrine Switzer, announcing for ABC, told viewers that gold medalist Joan Benoit's world record of 2 hours, 22 minutes and 43 seconds - set in the 1983 Boston Marathon - was faster than the marathon run by the great Emil Zatopek in the 1952 Olympics. ''As I said it, I knew the danger of those kinds of comparisons,'' said Miss Switzer, who ran the 1967 Boston Marathon bundled in a sweatsuit because women were not allowed to compete and who led the successful lobby for the women's Olympic marathon as the director of sports programs for the Avon Company. ''It's comparing apples and oranges, but I was trying to make a dramatic point because these are considered the ultimate performances.''

title: A Spectacular for Finale
description: David Wolper, the showman who made the opening ceremonies two weeks ago a razzle-dazzle Hollywood extravaganza, said today that the closing ceremonies Sunday ''will be as spectacular or more so.'' ''There will be many surprises that are designed for night viewing that will include a new use of all kinds of electronic media taking us into another space era,'' he said.

title: From Silver to Victory
description: Nelson Vails of New York and Rebecca Twigg of Colorado Springs, silver medalists in Olympic cycling races, were winners of races at the National Track Cycling Championships at the Lehigh County Velodrome in Trexlertown, Pa., Friday night. Vails won the senior men's sprint final, and Miss Twigg was first in the senior women's pursuit final, an 8-lap 4,000-meter race.

title: TWO WOMEN WIN ACCLAIM
description: THE emergence, on a substantial scale, of work with its vitality rooted in women's experiences is one of the more original and interesting phenomena of late 20th-century art.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
WHY THE G.O.P. NEEDS A HEART OF GOLD
description: Our foreign friends often assume that international problems must be shelved in an American Presidential election year. Yet 40 years ago this summer, while Republicans and Democrats fought over President Roosevelt's re-election, representatives of the Allied nations convened in Bretton Woods, N.H., to design the world's postwar economic system.

title: OUTDOOR HEALTH EMERGENCIES
description: ALTHOUGH its ponderous title might dismay some prospective readers, ''Management of Wilderness and Environmental Emergencies'' (Macmillan), edited by Paul S. Auerbach and Edward C. Geehr, is a superlative reference work for those who deal with so-called ''environmental emergencies,'' including frostbite, hypothermia, heat illness, lightning injuries, insect and snake bites and mushroom and toxic- plant poisoning.

title:
GARDENING;
PROPAGATING SHRUBS BY CUTTING
description: THERE are many reasons why a gardener might wish to propagate some tree or shrub. Perhaps he or she has admired one in the garden of a friend, only to find that it is unavailable from either the local nursery or any mail- order company. If so, it may be possible to beg a cutting or two, with which to propagate one's own.

title: DOCTOR FINDS THOOTHPICKS INJURE 8,000 YEARLY
description: About 8,000 people are injured in the United States each year by toothpicks they swallow or that inadvertently puncture an eye or ear, according to studies by a Federal health researcher. There have even been a few toothpick deaths.

title: TAKES AND SPENDING
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, the well-known

title: CARE INCREASING EFFORTS TO EXPAND ITS INTERNATIONAL BASE
description: In recent months, CARE, the private relief organization that was established to help postwar Europe and evolved into a development agency active around the world, has been increasing its efforts to expand its international base, according to the organization's executive director.

title: 8 Hurt in Bilbao Bombings
description: Eight people were hurt Friday night in two bombings of French targets here, the police said today. They said the bombs, in a French bank office and a Renault car dealership, appeared to be responses to a French court ruling that four suspected Basque separatists should be extradited to Spain.

title: U.N. PARLEY URGES BAN ON PROMOTING USE OF ABORTION
description: The United Nations International Conference on Population adopted a recommendation Friday night that abortion ''in no way should be promoted'' as a family planning method.

title: QUAKERS IN RARE DRIVE FOR MEMBERS
description: The nation's oldest body of Quakers is embarking uneasily on its first membership drive in more than 300 years, a concept foreign to a community built as a model of tolerance and consensus.

title: No Headline
description: Susan Garafola Marries

title: A Call to Consolidate Two Primary Dates
description: The approaching Sept. 11 Democratic Congressional primary in the 20th Congressional District (the seat being vacated by Representative Richard Ottinger) illustrates another example of government waste of taxpayer dollars and legislative decisions which, in effect, discourage voter participation in the voting processes.

title: A Word on Weighing Others' Safety
description: The article contains a very dangerous assumption. The author writes, ''It (the seat belt law) is an outrageous infringement on our right to decide what is good for us as individuals and on our right to decide how we will act.''

title: AMID RISING PRESSURE, TALKS INTENSIFY IN HEALTH WALKOUT
description: Negotiations to end New York City's hospital and nursing-home strike intensified yesterday as pressure to reach a quick settlement increased sharply.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Week in Business column last week incorrectly described the new position of L. Patton Kline, president of Marsh & McLennan. He will become vice chairman.

title: A 'BOY WONDER' GROWS UP AND EXPANDS HIS HORIZONS
description: '' I've always had original, interesting ideas - visions of things

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: An article on page 1 of the Arts and Leisure section today discusses the coming Asian tour of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra and quotes the conductor, Zubin Mehta, on appearances in countries ''hostile to Israel.'' The article makes no reference to Malaysia's request to delete a composition with a Jewish theme - with which the orchestra at first complied - or to the resulting cancellation of scheduled concerts in Malaysia. The Arts and Leisure section went to press before that issue became public.

title: Marie J. Dempsey and Hugh D. Carter Exchange Wedding Vows in Quebec
description: Marie Jeannette Dempsey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Bourne Dempsey 2d of Murray Bay, Quebec, and Sarasota, Fla., was married yesterday to Hugh Dinwiddie Carter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Carlyle Carter Jr. of Richmond. The Rev. Clement Bedard performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in L'Eglise du Sacre Coeur in Pointe au Pic, Quebec.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Artists' Rights
description: It has been illegal in New York State since Jan. 1 to display a work of art publicly ''in an altered, defaced, mutilated or modified form'' - or in a way that hinders an artist's reputation. In the first test of the new law, Robert Newmann obtained an injunction in May that barred the Palladium Theater in Manhattan from altering an exterior wall where he was sandblasting a mural.

title: CHESAPEAKE DECLARING WAR ON PROPOSED MILITARY TESTS
description: Preparations for nuclear war are not traditional topics of conversation among people of the Chesapeake Bay, an area famous for its fishing villages, seafood restaurants, oyster harvests and crab cakes. Now, however, commercial and sports fishermen have joined the State of Maryland to protest the construction of a large device in the southern Chesapeake meant to zap ships with electromagnetic pulses that mimic those of a nuclear blast.

title: VOLCANO WARNING BRINGS ECONOMIC WOES TO CALIFORNIA RESORT
description: Six years ago swarms of earthquakes began to rock this popular ski resort in the High Sierras.

title: The Road Runners
description: As a 47-year-old female runner from Booklyn, I want to thank Robert Reinhold for reading my mind (''Rigors of the Road,'' About Men, July 8).

title: CAR PHONES: BIG RANGE, TALL TOWERS
description: THE Southern New England Telephone Company makes the new technology sound like something halfway to Star Trek: telephones in cars, telephones on boats, even telephones worn on the belt that can make or receive calls with nearly the same sound quality as an office phone, and all with enough circuits that a dial tone is always available.

title:
STAMPS;
BASEBALL'S GREAT HUMANITARIAN
description: Roberto Clemente, one of the greatest of the great baseball players, is on a new 20- cent commemorative, the fifth in the ongoing American Sports Series. It is being put out this Friday in Carolina, Puerto Rico, his birthplace.

title: A TAX BILL BEGINS TO TAKE SHAPE
description: THE 1984 Presidential election

title: HEADLINERS;
description: Unflagging Pole

title: BUILDERS PRESS SEARCH FOR A DUMP SITE
description: IT has been three months since

title: How New Ideas Shape Politics
description: A person reading Richard Reeves's article, ''How New Ideas Shape Presidential Politics'' (July 15), who subsequently listened to Mario M. Cuomo's keynote address at the Democratic Convention, might have reacted to the speech with a feeling of

title: PROPOSED TOXIC RULES DISPUTED
description: WHEN Nassau health officials meet this week to hear public opinion on proposed guidelines for handling and storage of hazardous chemicals in the county, at least part of the discussion will center on what some people see as another potential hazard: ''overregulation'' of local industry.

title: Miss Bidart, J. M. Harris Are Married
description: Cynthia Anne Bidart, a daughter of Nancy Lion Bidart of Hemet, Calif., and Leonard Bidart of Winnemucca, Nev., was married yesterday to Jonathan Miller Harris in an ecumenical service in the chapel of St. George's School in Newport, R.I. The Rev. George E. Andrews 2d, headmaster of the school and an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Mario Costa, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: 30 FOOD PLACES CITED BY CITY
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 30 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: Tremors Shake Italian Town
description: A series of earth tremors hit this town outside Naples today, the police said, but there were no reports of injuries.

title: THEATER: 'REAL DREAMS,' A JAUNT AROUND THE 60'S
description: During summer vacation 1969, nine American college students decide to go on ''active service in the people's war.'' Forming a kind of homefront war corps, the students hang around a not-so-safe house in Cleveland, quote Mao and Che, stockpile arms and wait for battle orders, which arrive with the casualness of a milk delivery.
The 1983 amendments to the Social Security Act were designed

title: Risa Garfield and M. A. Doherty Exchange Vows
description: Risa Carol Garfield, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Garfield of Forest Hills, Queens; Kauneonga Lake, N.Y., and Natanya, Israel, was married yesterday to Michael A. Doherty, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Doherty Jr. of Woburn, Mass. Rabbi Gerald Skolnik performed the ceremony at the Forest Hills Jewish Center.

title: Mary Stowell Has Nuptials
description: The marriage of Mary Thayer Stowell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel C. Stowell of Riverside, Conn., to Andrew William Nelson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William James Nelson of Pelham Manor, N.Y., took place yesterday. The Rev. Donald G. Stauffer performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside.

title: WOULD DICTATORSHIP MAKE A DIFFERENCE?
description: Jose Yglesias is a novelist and journalist. LOVE AND DEATH IN A HOT COUNTRY

title: LOUGANIS LEADING PLATFORM EVENT
description: Greg Louganis set himself up for his second men's Olympic diving gold medal by overwhelming Li Kongzheng of China today in the optional portion of the men's platform preliminaries.

title: THE WINE INDUSTRY TURNS TO BUBBLES
description: NAPA VALLEY, Calif.

title: BEST SELLERS Fiction1
description: 19 ''. . . AND LADIES OF THE CLUB,'' by Helen Hooven Santmyer. (Putnam, $19.95.) Life in an Ohio town, 1868 to 1932. 2 28 LINCOLN, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $19.95.) Fictionalized account of the Civil War Presidency. 3 15 2 FIRST AMONG EQUALS, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden Press/Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) Three young men vie to be chosen Prime Minister by the Queen of England. 4

title: THE POWER OF POLITICAL CONSULANTS Ron Suskind, who is on the staff of The New York Times, has worked as a political consultant and a campaign manager in Connecticut and Virginia. By Ron Suskind I'VE GOT THIS SENATOR in his office,'' says Robert Goodman, ''and I'm shooting for three hours.'' The 55-year-old media consultant leans over the dinner table in a Maryland restaurant, sharing the events of his day. As he talks, his taut, wiry body begins to vibrate, hands waving, voice rising with the measured beat of a theatrical entertainer. ''I fire questions at him. I berate him. I say, 'Don't give me that stuff. Answer the question. Tell me what you feel.' The whole time, he's on camera. I've never brought the camera in this close. Finally he forgets it's there. He's sweating, getting mad, tie loosened, vulnerable.''
description: There is no script to the television commercial Goodman is describing, just the lights and cameras and the consultant peppering the candidate with questions. The goal of the advertisements is to change the voters' perception of an already well-known public figure, and Goodman wants his subject - in this case, Senator Roger W. Jepsen, Republican of Iowa - with his defenses down. ''That works,'' he says. ''The voters have heard about this person, or seen him from a distance, but now they're close. Here's who he really is. Voters are saying, 'Hey, I didn't know him before.' ''

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE BATTLE OF DIENBIENPHU, by Jules Roy. (Carroll & Graf, $8.95.) To write ''The Battle of Dienbienphu,'' published in 1965, Jules Roy - a journalist, novelist and former French Army officer - interviewed the participants and examined the records and site of the 1954 battle that ended French power in Indochina. Our reviewer, Robert Shaplen, wrote, ''Roy relates the basic facts perceptively and brilliantly and uses his novelistic technique to examine the motives and personalities of the various participants; he makes the whole tragedy come poignantly alive.'' Mr. Shaplen added that Americans reading the book will better comprehend Asia's revolution. WINTER'S TALE, by Mark Helprin. (Pocket Books, $4.50.) Mark Helprin won the National Jewish Book Award in 1982 for ''Ellis Island and Other Stories'' and lavish praise for ''Winter's Tale,'' published in 1983. The novel focuses on a series of interconnected heroic lives, chiefly that of Peter Lake, orphan, burglar, lover, idealist, mechanic first class. Benjamin DeMott wrote in The Book Review that ''a piercing sense of the beautiful arising from narrative and emotional fantasy is everywhere alive in the novel. And because the novelist commits himself throughout to the pursuit of nourishing truths - truths of justice, hope and cheer remote from the more fashionable truths of alienation and despair - 'Winter's Tale' stands forth in its own right as restorer and comforter.''

title: Derbyshire
description: To the Editor:

title: IN PLEASTANTVILLE, GIANTS INSPIRE FANS, FINANCE
description: IT'S happening again. Our sleepy little all-American village is being invaded. I'll never forget the first time I realized what was happening, several years ago. I was rolling my cart down the aisle of the Grand Union, when rolling another cart toward me was the largest human being I had ever seen. ''That's a GIANT!'' whispered my son. ''Shhh. I warned him. He'll hear you. Some people are larger than others but we don't call them names.'' He looked at me as only a 10-year-old football fan could. The giant was, of course, a Giant. It was a humbling experience.

title: HOW TO AVOID ANXIETIES AT A CLOSING
description: IN the lexicon of lawyers, closing the deal on a home purchase is a pro forma execution of documents. But many sellers and buyers feel as though they are in shock - and when problems arise, they may daydream about executing one another rather than the documents.

title: FUNK: CHICAGO AT RADIO CITY
description: Although the pop-jazz group Chicago has never been critically admired, for 17 years it has attracted a large audience with tuneful, horn-inflected music that glosses half a dozen idioms. Combining horn arrangements that mingle echoes of Memphis soul with older swing band models and group vocals inspired by the Beach Boys, Chicago's forte hasn't been musical invention so much as skillful stylistic homogenization.

title: HARTFORD LOSES ITS LAST MOVIE THEATER
description: FORTY years ago downtown Hartford had 10 movie houses. As of this month, it has none. The Wadsworth Atheneum recently closed the 300-seat cinema in the museum's basement. The theater had specialized in retrospectives and thematic film series.

title: SINGING FOLK SONGS IN MANY LANGUAGES
description: AS a student of anthropology, Gail Leoniak feels very strongly about preserving different cultures; she's disturbed by what she calls the ''homogenization'' of contemporary life.

title: TIGERS' MORRIS WINS HIS 15TH
description: Jack Morris, backed by three home runs, became the American League's first 15-game winner tonight as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Kansas City Royals, 9-5.

title: BUILDING A NEW EMPIRE OUT OF PAPER
description: STAMFORD, Conn.

title: STOLEN ALASKAN ARTIFACTS ARE FOUND IN SEATTLE
description: After a monthlong investigation, Alaska state troopers have recovered from a Seattle warehouse several artifacts stolen from an Indian village about 100 miles north of here. An investigator said they had been sold to a New York collector for $2 million.

title: Child Born to Dryfooses
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ochs Dryfoos of Ridgefield, Conn., on Aug. 3 in the Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. The child, who has been named Pamela Marie, is a granddaughter of Mrs. Andrew Heiskell of New York and the late Orvil E. Dryfoos, who was publisher of The New York Times from 1961 to 1963, and a great-granddaughter of Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger of New York, and the late Mr. Sulzberger, who was chairman and publisher of The Times from 1935 to 1961. The child's mother, the former Mary Gertrude Racine, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Racine of Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: MOST JERSEY REPRESENTATIVES HAVE EDGE IN FUND RAISING
description: Almost all of New Jersey's members of Congress have so far raised significantly more campaign funds than their challengers in the November elections, according to the latest Federal campaign finance reports.

title: THREE EAST END SHOWS THAT ARE WORTH SEEKING OUT
description: WITH numerous East End galleries competing for attention during the summer season, it isn't easy to focus on a few for special mention, particularly when the overall quality level is as high as it has been so far this year. Some, however, are off the gallery- goers' usual route but well worth seeking out.

title: Chadian Rebels Report Capture of a Top Official
description: Chadian rebels fighting the Government of President Hissen Habre said today that they had captured the Defense Minister.

title: Sheila Gruson Marries Thomas Lourie
description: Sheila Gruson and Thomas C. Lourie were married yesterday at the Spanish Institute in Manhattan. The ceremony was performed by Acting State Supreme Court Justice Milton L. Williams.

title: Yankees Trounce Indians
description: Phil Niekro put away his knuckleball for most of the game today and his Yankee teammates again put on their hitting shoes. The outcome was yet another impressive Yankee victory, a 10-1 trouncing of the Indians at Cleveland Stadium.

title: Man Slashes 3 Officers Outside Bar in Queens
description: Three off-duty police officers were slashed with a knife outside a Queens bar early yesterday after they took a crossbow from a 19-year-old man who had threatened them with the device, the police said.

title: A SECOND BIG WEEK FOR WALL ST.
description: Frenzy, confusion and panic buying continued to mark Wall Street last week, as stock prices cooled down, then roared ahead and cooled down again on Friday. Volume on the Big Board broke all records for the second week in a row, with 754.5 million shares changing hands. Institutions continued to dominate the buying, apparently not wanting to miss out on a rally that has seen the Dow jump more than 100 points in two weeks, but individuals did join the action more. After torrid trading on Monday, and slower trading on Tuesday and Wednesday, Thursday looked like a slow day until trading exploded late in the day. The Dow jumped more than 30 points to close up 27.94 points on the day. Friday saw a continuation of the last hour with the Dow surging 22 points in the morning. But the rally weakened and by the end of the day the Dow had lost six points, to end the week at 1,218.01, up almost 16 points on the week.

title: BUSINESSES SEEKING SOCIAL WORKERS
description: FOR years, most of the students at the University of Connecticut School of Social Work have served internships in welfare departments, youth service bureaus and other similar agencies.

title: RIGHTS UNIT'S IDEAS GAIN IN BAR GROUP
description: If you polled the 300,000 members of the American Bar Association, it is not certain they would support free legal aid for Haitian refugees, or a call for Congress to apologize for the wartime internment of Japanese-Americans or ending tax deductions on meals eaten at private business clubs that discriminate.

title: Final to Sweden's Edberg
description: Stefan Edberg of Sweden thwarted a late bid by Francisco Maciel of Mexico and scored a 6-1, 7-6 victory for the men's tennis title at the Olympics today.

title:
DINING OUT;
A NEW FACE IN BRONXVILLE
description: TONY TANAKA had been Izumi's jovial sushi master for so long that we assumed he had been declared by informal concensus a Bronxville landmark. We were surprised last May to find an unfamiliar face wielding the seasoned rice and fresh fish behind the sushi bar. But, as they say, everything changes, nothing changes, and Japan Inn, which now occupies the premises, continues to serve the community in much the same way as did its predecessor.

title: POLISH VESSEL HITS A MINE IN RED SEA
description: A Polish cargo ship struck a mine at the southern entrance to the Red Sea today, causing a ''strong explosion'' that damaged the ship but caused no casualties, the official Polish press agency P.A.P. said.

title: POST AUTHORITY VOTES $51 MILLION PROJECT FOR PATH IN JERSEY
description: A $51 million program to improve access to the Exchange Place PATH station here and upgrade safety on the system will get under way next year, officials of the agency said today.

title: LEWIS TAKES 4TH GOLD MEDAL TO MATCH OWENS
description: The Carl Lewis Show ended tonight in triumph and a world record. The 23- year-old Lewis, from Willingboro, N.J., won his fourth gold medal in track and field in the Games of the XXIII Olympiad.

title: Flower Chase
description: A year ago Dr. Rolf Martin of Brooklyn College invited the public to hunt for the sandplain gerardia, a wild flower approaching extinction. He said the Rare and Endangered Plant Exchange, a committee of American botanists, would pay $100 to the first person to send him a color photo of the flower and tell where it was growing.

title: A STREET CORNER IN HE OLD HOME TOWN
description: A WELL-DRESSED elderly man is standing on a street corner in my old hometown as I come running up. I catch my breath, stretch my bare legs. It is cold. He is curious but cautious. I nod good morning.

title: China Reports Accord To Improve Cuba Ties
description: China and Cuba have agreed to improve trade, cultural and technological ties despite their differences on international matters, Foreign Minister Wu Xueqian of China said today.

title: A CHILDREN'S BOOK GOES TO THE STAGE
description: A LITTLE girl has to care for her younger brother, who is involved with a gang. A boy whose mother is hospitalized is sent to a home for homeless children and is devastated - running away and getting into trouble - when his teacher/mentor leaves, until he finds a lost child to take care of himself. Another mother runs for Mayor of Bedford, giving her children a lesson in ''grass-roots politics.''

title: OFF-DUTY OFFICER SHOT ON IRT TRAIN
description: An off-duty New York City detective traveling on the IRT subway through lower Manhattan on his way home from work yesterday afternoon was shot by a man who apparently tried to rob him, the police said.

title: U.D.C. FLOATING A LOAN IN THE RISKY RETAIL WATERS
description: IN its 16-year history, the New York State Urban Development Corporation has evolved from a developer of low-income housing to a lender for economic-revitalization projects in depressed areas. Under the agency's current administration, however, a new goal has emerged - a good return on the U.D.C.'s investment dollar.

title: FOR THOSE IN THERAPY, THE AUGUST DOLDRUMS
description: It was August 1983, and every psychiatrist in the Western world seemed to be on vacation. Dr. Stanley E. Greben of Toronto was among them. But before he left, he invited one seriously depressed patient to visit him at his chalet in northern Canada.

title: KEEP NEAR-GREATS FROM THE INNER CIRCLE
description: IN 1936, Ty Cobb became the first

title: THE ROAD RUNNERS
description: As another 42-year-old jogging enthusiast, I hope Robert Reinhold will seriously consider the need to run defensively and make safety an integral part of his morning jogs. An intelligent jogger would wear reflective gear or bright clothing at ''6:30 on a gray, wintry morning in Jefferson City, Mo.'' or in any other city. In addition, he would surely avoid headphones, which might keep him from being alert and aware of potential danger on the road or highway. DORIS M. DAVIS Delmar, N.Y.

title: San Francisco to Keep 3-Language Ballots
description: The City Attorney's office has ruled that the San Francisco Registrar must continue to print trilingual ballot materials.

title:
GARDENING;
PROPAGATING SHRUBS BY CUTTING
description: THERE are many reasons why a gardener might wish to propagate some tree or shrub. Perhaps he or she has admired one in the garden of a friend, only to find that it is unavailable from either the local nursery or any mail- order company. If so, it may be possible to beg a cutting or two, with which to propagate one's own.

title: U.S. BILL WOULD GIVE CITY $15 MILLION SUBSIDY FOR NEW HOMES
description: New York City would get about $15 million to subsidize mortgages for 500 new single-family homes under the terms of a bill passed by Congress.

title: Firefighters' Union In Jersey Backs Reagan
description: A union representing 6,500 New Jersey firefighters has endorsed President Reagan for re-election, according to a union spokesman.

title: BEST BOOKS LISTED FOR HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS
description: The works of Shakespeare, the Declaration of Independence, Mark Twain's ''Huckleberry Finn'' and the Bible lead the list of works that every high school student ought to be required to read, in the opinion of some scholars, journalists, teachers and governmental and cultural leaders.

title: HEADLINERS;
description: Nashville on $2.50 a Day Now comes a politician who has found it his duty to be a derelict. At the request of a hometown magazine, Representative Bill Boner of Tennessee recently let his beard grow a few days, donned cheap clothes and, with $5 in his pocket, set out to spend a weekend among Nashville's homeless and poor.

title: Books
description: To the Editor:

title: STEERING CLEAR OF THE OMNIPRESENT SUMMER GAMES
description: THEY were driving to Aqueduct,

title: SMITH LECTURES LAWYERS ON KREMLIN 'LAWLESSNESS'
description: W HILE Government officials from supposedly apolitical agencies often make policy speeches to ''nonpolitical'' forums, the Justice Department's two top officials went farther last week than most of their predecessors to lay out a political theme of their Administration. The forum was the American Bar Association's convention in Chicago; the theme was anti-Soviet.

title: PUTTING COCONUTS TO TASTY USE
description: in her community, at least - well-known maker of desserts, end-of- the-meal sweets ranging from pecan and custard pies to Bavarian creams and eggnogs. I admired all these things, but it was the coconut cakes - with their thick layers of meringue and chenillelike tufts of freshly grated coconut - that tickled my palate to the most salivating degree.

title: THE NORTH CAROLINA RACE GOES NATIONAL
description: When North Carolina Governor James B. Hunt Jr. a few days ago asked Senator Jesse Helms to join him in a pledge to accept no more out-of-state campaign contributions, it's no wonder the Senator declined. By most estimates, as much as three-quarters of Mr. Helms's campaign funds come from out of state, by and large from people who don't know a thing about flue-cured tobacco or Tarheel basketball.

title: LENDING MONEY WITH MINIMUM PAIN
description: As the price of money from traditional loan

title: Cubs Down Expos On a Single in 9th
description: Keith Moreland hit a single to score Ryne Sandberg from third base with one out in the ninth inning to lift the Chicago Cubs to a 2-1 victory over the Montreal Expos today.

title: 3-Satellite Launching Delayed a Second Time
description: The launching of satellites from three nations was postponed a second time today because the payloads may have been contaminated by strips of plastic that peeled off an air- conditioning hose.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
 BLOOMING LILIES
description: When it comes to perennials, there are those who swear by daylilies - members of the Long Island Daylily Society, for example. And today, the society shares this enthusiasm with the rest of the Island when it holds its annual daylily plant sale at the Clark Garden in Albertson. In addition to the sale of what is described as ''tried and true varieties'' (there's a limit of 10 items per customer), the program, which begins at 1 P.M., includes a lecture on the plants, followed by a question-and-answer session. The Clark Garden is on I.U. Willets Road, and admission is $1, or 50 cents for children and the elderly.

title: BLUES: KOOPER AND KAYE
description: Al Kooper, the 1960's blues-rock trailblazer, and Lenny Kaye, the rock journalist turned musician, who shared the bill at the Bottom Line Thursday, are almost opposite sensibilities. A founder of the Blues Project and of Blood, Sweat and Tears, and more recently a successful record producer, Mr. Kooper is a sophisticated conceptualizer of adventurous stylistic and aural hybrids, and his inventiveness is complemented by his polished guitar and keyboard technique. Mr. Kaye, in contrast, is a proud primitive whose music is inspired equally by Lou Reed and by early British blues groups like the Yardbirds.

title: DANCE: MASKED DRAMA BY SOUTH KOREAN TROUPE
description: One of the funniest events of the dance season took place on Thursday at Asia Society's Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium, when the Hyun Ja Kim Dance Company presented a sample of sundae-dogam or masked dance drama from Kyung Sang Province in South Korea. It isn't surprising to learn that the theater form was banned from the Korean court during the 17th century. There can seldom have been such raucous goings-on at Asia Society.

title: Fuel Tank Explosion Injures 4 in Florida
description: A 10,000-gallon fuel tank exploded at a dock here today shooting a fireball hundreds of feet in the air, injuring four people and destroying a warehouse, mobile homes and boats, the authorities said.

title: SUPPLY OF NANNIES CAN'TMEET DEMAND
description: -fashioned in this modern world, but a nanny is just what an increasing number of parents are looking for to help care for their children. To respond to this demand, three nanny-training programs are scheduled to open in Connecticut within the next two months.

title: Fires Sweep Oregon Region
description: Fires started by lightning scorched 49,000 acres of brush and grass in southeastern Oregon Friday, sending smoke 20,000 feet over the area. Nearly 300 firefighters were battling the blazes. Two parachutists employed by the Federal Forest Service suffered bruises battling a blaze in the Umatilla National Forest.

title:
ART;
SCULPTURE AT MERCER COMMUNITY COLLEGE
description: AD REINHARDT'S peppery maxim that a sculpture is something one bumps into when one stands back to look at a painting has never decisively been given the lie.

title: New York's Quality of Life When Nobody Cares The New York Times/Neal Boenzi
description: Twelfth Avenue and West 56th Street.

title: Mary Beth Maslow Is Wed To Jeffrey Scott Davidson
description: Mary Beth Maslow, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Maslow of Livingston, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Scott Davidson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Davidson, also of Livingston. Rabbi Herbert Weiner performed the ceremony at Temple Sharey Tefilo- Israel in South Orange, N.J.

title: HIGH TIME TO COORDINATE AIRLINE'S SCHEDULES
description: To the Editor:

title: Michelle G. Kleinman Wed to Gary M. Reiff
description: Michelle Gail Kleinman and Gary Michael Reiff, both Harvard Law School graduates, were married yesterday at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Myron M. Fenster performed the ceremony.

title: DAYS OF MAGIC AND DISASTER
description: Herbert Gold, who lives in San Francisco, is the author of the novel ''True Love'' and other books. THE HAIGHT-ASHBURY

title: MISSING BODY IN MURDER DELAYS 2D MARRIAGE
description: An Etna man who was convicted of killing his wife faces a legal Catch-22 that has prevented him from remarrying because her body was never found.

title: SPLITS LEAVE BUDGET PROCESS WOUNDED
description: Congress went home last week for its second summer recess, leaving behind it the irksome issue of military spending still unresolved, the final piece of the ''down payment on the deficit'' untidily out of place - and renewed doubts about the viability of the Congressional budget process, once considered the best hope for restraining Federal spending. Because of the military spending deadlock, this may well be the first year since passage of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Act of 1974 that Congress does not approve, as the act requires, a budget resolution setting targets for spending and revenues for the upcoming fiscal year.

title: RELIGION COMES FIRST
description: Should Catholics, as Catholics, stay out of politics? This, ironically, seems to be the position of New York's Catholic Governor, Mario Cuomo, in his campaign against the state's Catholic bishops and Archbishop, John J. O'Connor.

title: Oil Spill Cuts Tourism In Texas Resort Town
description: An oil spill that blackened the beaches of this resort city last week has cut tourism so severely that officials have mounted an advertising campaign to lure revelers back.

title: LAWYERS OBJECT TO CHARGES OF LITIGIOUSNESS
description: Many lawyers and laymen have got used to the notion that the nation is drowning in a flood of lawsuits begotten by an abundance of lawyers serving a too contentious populace. At the annual convention of the American Bar Association here last week, Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor described the phenomenon as ''legalflation.''

title:
FASHION;
EMERGING FROM THE SHADOWS OF PARIS
description: -based novelist and journalist who is interested in fashion.

title: DEREGULTION PRIORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: THE REGION ; Court UpholdsKean's Vetoes
description: Governor Kean, who on occasion has suggested that the New Jersey Supreme Court may have exceeded its authority, had his own powers expanded by the court last week. In another in what has become a summer- long series of major decisions, the state's highest court upheld the Governor's right to reduce or eliminate items in the budget passed by the Legislature before he signs it into law.

title: Gail M. Peterson and George A. King Are Married
description: Gail Mina Peterson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank P. Peterson of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to George Alexander King, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald E. King Jr. of New York. The Rev. William T. Wood performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Peterson home.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: A YEAR ago, the Bergen Community Museum became the Bergen Museum of Art and Science. With its new name came a new focus and a new director, Judith Harris of Hackensack, a natural for the job.

title: 'BEST OF BRODWAY' IS FAR FROM IT
description: '' THE BEST OF BROADWAY'' is the convenient, if erroneous, title of the Coachlight Dinner Theater's ''concert of music and lyrics.'' Assembled with what looks like remote-control efficiency rather than real ingenuity, this is not the best that Coachlight can offer.

title: HOW NEW IDEAS SHAPE POLITICS
description: I read, with great interest, Richard Reeves's article.

title: KICKING THE HABIT
description: One of the things I did to break the cigarette habit was to promise myself eternal life. ''If I give up these smokes,'' I said to myself, ''I won't have to die.''

title: A MISCONCIEVED 'MERCHANT OF VENICE'
description: SHAKESPEARE wrote all sorts of ''problem plays'' - works that don't necessarily deal with problems but that create them, for audiences, actors and directors. ''The Merchant of Venice'' is one of the most familiar and most problematical.

title: PURCHASE ENDING 5TH SEASON
description: DO you know the way fireworks displays tend to end with a whirlwind of explosions? That is how Summerfare '84 is closing out its fifth season today on the Purchase campus of the State University of New York, starting with a free Craftfare exhibit on the mall at noon and proceeding at 2 P.M. to one of the feature events of the arts festival, a multimedia premiere of Bach's St. Matthew Passion. Performed on the Flentrop grand concert organ and original baroque instruments, with the Pro Arte Chorus of Connecticut and the Christ Church Boys Choir, all conducted by Anthony Newman, the music will be further enhanced by rear projections of the famous Albrecht D"urer woodcuts, and front projections of a complete English translation, using the titling system that has been such an enormous success at the New York City Opera.

title: A TROUPER, 12, LEADS A DOUBLE LIFE
description: ANY teacher who assigns Kim Fertman one of those ''What I Did Last Summer'' compositions at the Accompsett Intermediate School in Smithtown in the fall will be getting back something a bit out of the ordinary.

title: LIFE'S MAGIC ENTRY 1 AND 2 IN ALABAMA
description: The Alabama Stakes at Saratoga Race Track today was supposed to be a duel for national leadership of the 3-year-old fillies, but the only competition that took place was within the D. Wayne Lukas stable.

title: Votes in Congress;Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: Blondie Live! MCA Home Video 55 minutes. $29.95

title: LEFTISTS POSE LITTLE THREAT TO BOLIVIA'S GOVERNMENT
description: Almost daily, the United States Embassy here hears rumors predicting that Bolivia is about to fall into the hands of international communism. Alarm is spread by local politicians and businessmen and repeated by Latin American military envoys who find the current experiment in civilian democracy disturbing. Echoing these views, the daily newspaper El Diario complained recently that the United States was ''looking on with indifference'' while ''the communists are advancing as much as the drug traffickers.''

title: 1 Killed and 1 Injured In Jersey Copter Crash
description: One man was killed and another escaped with a concussion today when the private helicopter they were riding crashed into a wooded area of the Army base here, officials said.

title: Ruling Eases Eviction Fr
description: A New Jersey appeals court has ruled that a person renting an apartment in a building converted to condominiums can be evicted on two months' notice if the owner sells a unit to someone who plans to occupy it.

title: AMERICA'S 'ATHLETIC IMPERIALISM'
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruth-Ann Bernstein Bride Of David Charles Brofsky
description: Ruth-Ann Bernstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Bernstein of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Charles Brofsky, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Brofsky of Ardsley, N.Y. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. performed the ceremony at the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale.

title: DISPUTE CONTINUES ON AID TO DISABLED
description: Congressional efforts to overhaul the Social Security disability program have reached an impasse, with the Reagan Administration objecting to legislation that would liberalize terms of eligibility.

title: Pinelands' Problems Termed Deep-Seated
description: Franklin E. Parker's Opinion Page article of July 8 on the success of the Pinelands Commission, of which he is chairman, requires a response.

title: RETURN TO MIDEAST IS AN UNHURRIED DEPLOYMENT
description: WASHINGTON JUST three months before the Presidential election, the Reagan Administration sent American servicemen back to the Middle East last week to help Egypt clear mines from Red Sea shipping lanes. Widely perceived as a noncontroversial humanitarian mission, the open-ended deployment nonetheless ran the risk of bringing unpleasant surprises in a region that has proved hazardous for President Reagan.

title: WILD-GAME DISHES FOR THE BRAVE
description: IF the Walter Mitty in you dreams of stalking

title: GENIUS CAME LATER
description: Hugh Kenner is the author of ''A Homemade World: The American Modernist Writers.'' VISION IN SPRING

title: A REVIEW OF THE LATEST IN PANORAMIC EQUIPMENT
description: Panoramic or ultra-wide- angle photography, dates back to the earliest years. In 1845, six years after photography was invented, Friedrich Von Martens, a German living in Paris, constructed his own panoramic camera. The lens moved horizontally in a 150-degree arc and produced an image measuring 5x15 inches on to a curved film. When the pictures were seen, they created a sensation. The broad, sweeping vistas of mountain ranges and city scapes were quite unlike pictures taken with conventional cameras.

title: MOBILE-HOME PROTECTIONS WIDENED MEASURE LIMITS FEES AND REQUIRES WRITTEN 1-YEAR LEASE OFFER
description: NEW regulations extending protections for the state's 286,000 mobile-home residents have been passed by the Legislature and signed into law by Governor Cuomo, his office announced last week.

title: A BOAT TRIP TO THE FOUNTAIN OF YOUTH
description: IF THE familiar saying ''You're as old as you feel'' is true, I'm sometimes 80 and my mother and father, who are past 80, have become a couple of teen-agers. But that wasn't always so.

title: FRESH AIR CAMPERS ARE INTRODUCED TO RURAL JOYS
description: After moving quietly through the woods on a hay wagon, the boys had just arrived at a clearing when their driver made an announcement.

title: AMERICA'S ACTIVIST BISHOPS
description: WHY DOESN'T A NICE MAN LIKE ARCHbishop Weakland stick to his prayers and leave business affairs to us?'' asks a Milwaukee jeweler. Throughout the country, similar questions float on a rising tide of apprehension about what Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland of Milwaukee and the committee of bishops he heads are up to as they compose a set of religious reflections, or pastoral letter, on Roman Catholic social teaching and the United States economy.

title: STATE DISMISSES 5 ASSESSORS OVER TRAINING
description: A New York State regulatory board has dismissed five elected upstate property assessors and is preparing to dismiss 103 more for failing to attend required training courses.

title: REVOLUTION AS RITUAL
description: THE WAR OF THE END OF THE WORLD

title: BRITISH PAPER SAYS LIBYA EXECUTED 4 LINKED TO THE KILLING IN LONDON
description: A British newspaper said today that Libya had executed four men over the April killing of a policeman outside its London Embassy. The London killing had prompted Britain to sever diplomatic ties with the Arab nation.

title: L.I.R.R. PROJECT IN ENVIRONMENTAL SNAG
description: WHEN is a transportation project ''material'' in nature and when is it not? This question will be placed before the New York State Supreme Court on Thursday, with the future of the Long Island Rail Road's $25 million electrification project from Huntington through to Northport riding on the court's answer.

title: Disharmony for The Philharmonic
description: In the end last week, Malaysia got the word: the New York Philharmonic Orchestra will not be coming out to play. Thus concluded days of sweeping condemnation of Malaysia's Moslem Government by American Jewish groups, and sometimes shrill blasts against the Philharmonic by Mayor Koch.

title: CLOSER TIES URGED BY U.S. AND SOVIET
description: President Reagan and Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, have reaffirmed in separate letters that they want better relations between their two countries, according to copies of the letters released here today.

title: Wesley Lang Jr. to Marry Mary Gillin in November
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Gillin of Bryn Mawr, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter Mary Margaret Gillin to Wesley Warren Lang Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lang of Garden City, L.I. The wedding is to take place inNovember.

title: THE NATION ; Congress MovesOn Women'sWell-Being
description: Capitol Hill was much preoccupied last week with the welfare of women.

title: EAST END SLIDES
description: The watchful eyes of some 100 volunteer monitors have been among the most effective preservation tools of the Friends of the Upper East Side Historic Districts since the nonprofit organization was founded two years ago. But until now, the ''watchdogs'' have had to rely on incomplete records and their memories to tell them when subtle changes had been made on designated landmarks.

title:
DINNG OUT;
A FAIR, A FOLkSONG, ARESTAURANT
description: A PART from being a centuries-old event in the north of England and the name of a hauntingly beautiful folk song, Scarborough Fair is also the name of a six-month- old restaurant in Sea Girt.

title: BURTON'S LAST ROLE: A SUPPORTIVE FATHER
description: Robert Cushman frequently reports on the London cultural scene.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
BEER GARDENZ
description: VALHALLA ALFERO'S GROVE has a lot of traditions. At least that is what Jennifer Tobin says, and the place is one of her favorite hangouts. ''It has a lot of traditions,'' she said one warm, clear night not long ago. ''Ice fights, dancing on the picnic tables. And see that big, fat tree over there? The big tradition is to stand on your head with your feet against the tree and pour beer down your throat.''

title: DEAR MOM: HERE IS MY LETTER FROM CAMP
description: TWO weeks have passed since I dropped my 12-year-old son off at camp. Each day I stand in the middle of the road, waiting for the postman to arrive with news from my son.

title: A QUESTION OF SECESSION
description: A GROUP of homeowners and a developer with attractive empty land will ask tomorrow night if they can secede from the village of Croton-on- Hudson and join the town of Cortlandt.

title: SACRIFICING THE BOY
description: CANNIBALISM AND THE COMMON LAW

title: DRUGS DRUGGISTS SHUN
description: To the Editor:

title: BUDD: 'MY WORLD WAS SHATTERED'
description: Zola Budd, the 18-year-old South African recently granted British citizenship that enabled her to participate in the Olympic Games, was involved in a controversial incident last Friday night in the women's 3,000- meter final. After taking the lead, Miss Budd collided with Mary Decker, after which Miss Decker fell and was unable to complete the race. In this article written for the Monday issue of The Daily Mail in London. Miss Budd presents her version of the incident.

title: Required Reading Blame for Deficit
description: Exchange between Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, vice chairman of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, and Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan over who should get the blame for budget deficits at an Aug. 8 committee hearing:

title: ONE OF STRIKING UNIONS APPROVES LILCO ACCORD
description: Members of one of the two unions on strike against the Long Island Lighting Company approved a contract offer this evening that would end their five-week-old walkout. The union, Local 1049 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, voted 1,272 to 854 in favor of the pact, which achieves the union's goal of avoiding a pay cut. The other union, Local 1381, is scheduled to vote on Monday. During the balloting today, members of the union, which represents about 2,550 linemen, mechanics and other ''physical workers,'' said that while they were unhappy about the contract terms, most doubted that a longer strike would have brought better ones. ''It sounds like we won, but we lost,'' Frank Walsh, a lineman, said this afternoon as he left the polling place, the one-story brick headquarters of the local. He and others pointed out that although the proposed contract freezes wages, as the unions proposed, instead of cutting wages by 5 percent, as Lilco wanted, the strike has cost the members more in lost wages than Lilco proposal would have.

title: Vernitron Promotes Officer to President
description: Albert Diamond has been named president of Vernitron Inc.

title: Mango Pesticide Curb Shifted
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that mangoes containing residues of the pesticide ethylene dibromide may still be imported for a year after a ban on other fruit bearing the chemical goes into effect Sept. 1.

title: Jennifer Chandler Wed in Princeton
description: Jennifer Fleur Chandler, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James J. Chandler of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Stephen Burnet Hauge, a son of Helen Resor Hauge and the late Dr. Gabriel Hauge of New York. The Rev. Dr. A. Orley Swartzentruber performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: The Drug War's Second Front Is there any hope for drug enforcement? News from the domestic front is bleak. The U.S. Customs Commissioner, William von Raab, believes his agents catch only 6 percent of the thousands of boats smuggling drugs into the country. Even with so much heroin available, however, New York's prosecutors think that more than half the city's felonies are now committed to support the habit.
description: But the news from the drug war's diplomatic front abroad has brightened. It surely deserves a greater concentration of American effort.

title: BOXING ; FOR PAUL GONZALES, TIME TO ENJOY GOLD
description: He looked like a teen-ager among the offical-looking men in suits and blazers and the women dressed as if they were on the way to Sunday services. Paul Gonzales joined them for brunch today on the lawn at the First Interstate Athletic Foundation as the guest of honor, wearing an Olympic T-shirt and jeans, and only one accessory - a gold medal draped around his neck.

title: Rebecca East Is Wed To Dr. John Iwasaki
description: Rebecca East, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David East of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. John Iwasaki, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Carl Iwasaki of Denver. The Rev. Egen Yoshikami, a Buddhist priest, performed the ceremony at the Byodo-In Temple on Oahu, Hawaii.

title: COPTER CRASH NEAR COLISEUM
description: A California Highway Patrol helicopter surveying traffic crashed today on the Harbor Freeway near the Memorial Coliseum, injuring three people who were aboard.

title: Patty Sheehan Wins
description: Patty Sheehan rallied from a double bogey to sink an 8-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole to take her second straight Henredon Classic Ladies' Professional Golf Association championship today.

title: SIKH REBEL IS CHALLENGING RELIGION'S LEADERS
description: In a rare confrontation, a Sikh chief who is backed by the Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is challenging the traditional Sikh religious leaders.

title: PERUVIAN REBELS HALT U.S. DRIVE AGAINST COCAINE
description: The United States Government's most important cocaine eradication program, in a valley between the Andes and the Peruvian jungles, has been suspended because of a wave of guerrilla raids in the area, United States officials say.

title: EUROPEANS MAY JOIN SEARCH
description: Libya denied today that it was responsible for the planting of explosives in the Red Sea, and Iran repeated a denial of involvement.

title: The Truth About Agent Orange Vietnam veterans, says Rena Kopystenoski, a veteran's wife, ''do not ask for money, but for the truth, for someone to admit what has been done, and to try to stop what shall prove to be the beginning of a nation of mutations.''
description: So she told United States District Judge Jack Weinstein at the hearings he conducted in Brooklyn last week on the settlement of the Agent Orange case. Some Vietnam veterans favor accepting the settlement. Others deride the $180 million as a pittance and want to continue their suits against the herbicide's manufacturers.

title: January Triumphs
description: Don January won his second consecutive $225,000 du Maurier Champions senior tournament, firing a 5-under 66 today to finish the 54-hole tournament at 19-under-par 194 at the Royal Ottawa Golf Club.

title: STEEL DEBATE CENTERS ON TRADE LAWS
description: The debate in the United States over foreign steel subsidies is beginning to center on one theme: that existing trade laws have failed to bring order to the steel market.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section on Aug. 5 about Jazzmobile Inc. incorrectly described the Harlem Cultural Council. The council, founded in 1964, is still active; it provides assistance to minorities in arts programs.

title: Carnegie Group Cites 18 People for Heroism
description: A 36- year-old engineer who died after saving a man from a gas-filled manhole was among 18 people in the United States and Canada who were awarded the Carnegie Medal for heroism today.

title: Wanda Mushel Marries
description: The marriage of Wanda Mushel, the public relations manager of Aris Isotoner Inc., a glove manufacturer in New York, to Steven Lockwood, an associate with the New York law firm of Breed, Abbott & Morgan, took place yesterday at the Tammy Brook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J. Rabbi Joseph Chernamos performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Mushel of Boynton Beach, Fla., and Mr. and Mrs. Donald Lockwood of North Woodmere, L.I.

title: SETTLEMENTS ISSUE HAMPERING ISRAELI UNITY TALKS
description: Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader who is seeking to form an Israeli Government, was reported today to have complained in talks with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir that the Likud bloc's West Bank settlement policy was obstructing the progress of their coalition talks.

title: PRISONER RELEASE HAILED BY WALESA
description: Lech Walesa, founder of the banned Polish union Solidarity, said in an interview broadcast today that if the Polish Government continued to release political prisoners ''it will be a sure sign that something is really changing'' in his country.

title: Slaying in Colombia Delays Guerrilla Pact
description: The signing of a truce between the urban guerrilla group known as M-19 and the Government has been indefinitely postponed as a result of the slaying last week of an M-19 founder, official sources said today.

title: Advertising; At Coleco, The Adam Is Reborn
description: COLECO INDUSTRIES has planned a symbolic rebirth for its Adam home computer. The Adam, according to a new $15 million television advertising campaign beginning Wednesday, is now the educational tool every family needs.

title: WOMEN GAIN IN POWER STRUCTURE
description: The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee is traditionally one of the most powerful figures on Capitol Hill. So it was a significant moment last week when the current holder of that august position, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, approached the microphones at an unusual news conference and said: ''You see surrounding me the reasons why these bills are such a success. They kept my nose to the grindstone.''

title: Looking for Congress
description: Congress has not been exactly breaking any records for hard work this year. The nearly monthlong recess that began over the weekend is the fifth holiday - members prefer to call these ''district work periods'' - since Congress convened Jan. 23.

title: Mondales, at a Radio Show, Get 'No Special Treatment'
description: Walter F. Mondale and his wife, Joan, got a hometown greeting today when they visited the radio show ''Prairie Home Companion.''

title: Senator Seeks Investigation Of Former High Navy Official
description: Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, has asked the Navy to investigate whether a former top Navy official who helped negotiate more than $5 billion in contracts with the General Dynamics Corporation, had committed any impropriety in taking a job with the nilitary contractor.

title: PIPELINE PROJECT HAD ITS BEGINNING FOUR YEARS AGO
description: A proposal to build an oil pipeline across the midriff of Africa that eventually was promoted by Senator Mark O. Hatfield began to take shape about four years ago when Basil A. Tsakos, a Greek businessman, sought to interest officials of the United States Government in the project, according to one of his former associates.

title: BORROWERS ARE CUTTING RATE RISKS
description: As much as corporate treasurers wish to avoid risk, they have little choice these days but to finance their operations with floating-rate debt. And until recently, the only way they could hedge against a rate rise was by immersing themselves in the complexities of financial futures, a step that many refused to take.

title: California Jaycees Back Women as Members
description: Directors of the California Jaycees voted unanimously Saturday to urge the national organization to allow women full membership in the community service group.

title: Economic Calendar Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.
description: Monday

title: Will We Ever Fly on Time?
description: I'm really sorry: The schedule said 6 P.M. - just time to finish work and make it to the airport. But after rolling away from the gate on time, the plane sat on the ground till 7:15 . . .

title: FOR THREE UNWED MOTHERS, REGRETS AND HOPE FOR THEIR BABIES'FUTURES
description: More than a fourth of the out-of- wedlock births in New York City last year were to women 19 years old or younger. Many, if not most, of the women were poor. Many came from broken homes in squalid neighborhoods and some were themselves born out of wedlock. But each has her own story. The three women portrayed here are participants in Project Teen Aid, a counseling and child-care program for teen-age mothers, at Public School 67 in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn.

title: COSMOS DEFEAT JUVENTUS, 2-1
description: Giuseppe Damiani of Italy and Wladyslaw Smuda of Poland, both of whom are coveted by the Cosmos, made special appearances here tonight as guests of the Cosmos in their 2-1 victory over Juventus.

title: 47 Nations Win Olympic Medals
description: Forty-seven nations won medals at the 1984 Summer Olympics, 11 more than in Moscow four years ago and only one off the record.

title: SALAZAR, 15TH, SAYS HE LET DOWN FANS
description: The cheers, Alberto Salazar said, were inspiring but also made him feel as if he were letting people down. With 11 miles to run in the men's marathon today, Salazar knew what the fans along the route did not: An Olympic medal was already beyond his reach.

title: English Ballet Ensemble
description: The English Ballet Ensemble, a chamber group of Royal Ballet dancers, will perform in a three-week American tour starting tomorrow.

title: ANOTHER CARTLAND ROMANCE, THIS ONE FOR CHILDREN
description: Once upon a time, in a strange and enchanted part of the paperback book kingdom, there lived a very clever Queen who could spin words into gold. Every day the Queen went to the library of her great estate outside London and began to spin a tale. As the words flew from her mouth, the secretaries collected them in great barrels, and when they had enough words to fill the barrels - 7,000 was about right - it was time for tea. Then the barrels of words were shipped off to places like the United States where the words were poured into books, and the books were put on racks in bookstores, supermarkets and drug stores, and millions of women bought them. That is how Barbara Cartland, queen of the romantic novel, turned words into gold.

title: Gibe by Soviet
description: The Soviet Union charged today that the Los Angeles Olympics were a sports flop and that United States athletes had dominated most events only because stronger Soviet and East German athletes had not been present.

title: Indian Leaders Unhappy With Reagan, Poll Says
description: A National Indian Youth Council poll of 1,050 American Indian leaders nationwide has found dissatisfaction with the Reagan Administration's actions concerning Indians, a council leader said.

title: Tanglewood Concerts Will Start Tomorrow
description: ''Tanglewood-on-Parade,'' a day of concerts, including appearances by Yo-Yo Ma, Seiji Ozawa and Gunther Schuller, will be held starting at 2 P.M. tomorrow.

title: 8th in Row for Cubs' Sutcliffe
description: Ron Cey broke a sixth-inning tie with a 2-run home run and Rick Sutcliffe won his eighth decision in a row as the Chicago Cubs beat the Montreal Expos, 7-3, this afternoon.

title: REAGAN REMARKS ON TAXES
description: Following are recent remarks on taxes by President Reagan, Vice President Bush and Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan: July 25. President Reagan at a news conference: ''I have no plans for a tax increase. I believe it would be counterproductive with regard to the present recovery, or expansion. Indeed, I believe that the tax cut we had is largely responsible for the recovery that we're having.

title: One Fortune Cookie's Story
description: Fortune cookies once promised romance and adventure, as in: ''You will meet a tall, handsome man,'' or, ''You're going to take a trip.''

title: DISPELLING MYTHS ABOUT THE ONLY CHILD
description: Studies of only children and their families are providing new knowledge about the developmental potential of those who grow up without siblings, from infancy through adulthood. The findings counter the notion that having brothers or sisters is necessary for proper social, intellectual and emotional growth.

title: PORNOGRAPHY: ESTHETICS TO CENSORSHIP DEBATED
description: What is pornography? Six panelists, most of them well-known in the city's literary and intellectual precincts, who were brought together in New York last week by Harper's magazine, never quite managed to answer that question, but their spirited two-hour discussion covered everything from esthetics to censorship, from the causes of violence against women and the meaning of ''sexual liberation'' to the shortcomings of ''uptight intellectuals.''

title: 4 on a Delta Airliner Hurt in Air Turbulence
description: Four passengers on a Delta Airlines flight from Bermuda to Atlanta were injured Saturday when the wide-bodied jet encountered severe air turbulence over the Atlantic Ocean, an airline spokesman said.

title: Honest Appraisal
description: time labor leader, defected to the other side? No, but he is in a new and intriguing position.

description: Archery MEN Darrell Pace, Hamilton, Ohio Rick McKinney, Glendale, Ariz.
