title: FIREFIGHTER DIES IN NEWARK BLAZE
description: A firefighter died and six other people were slightly injured early yesterday morning when a fire roared through 4 stories of a 15-story office building in downtown Newark.

title: BEIRUT PUBLISHES LIST OF HOSTAGES
description: Under growing pressure from the relatives of thousands of missing people, the Government published a list today of more than 700 people described as being held in military or police jails.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Dodgers at Los Angeles. After four days at home the Mets take off for an 11-day trip to California. (Television - Channel 9, 10:30. Radio - WHN, 1050; 10:30 P.M.).

title: ANIMAL SPECIES RARE IN WILD PRESENT A PROBLEM AS THEY FLOURISH IN ZOOS
description: Species that are vanishing in the wild have been bred so successfully in captivity that zoos are now in a quandary over what to do when they run out of room for individual animals and do not need them for the ultimate goal of preserving the species.

title: HELP TO SALVADOR CHEERS U.S. AIDES
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials say that the $70 million in emergency military aid for El Salvador approved by Congress will enable the Salvadoran Army to counter the threat of a major offensive by the rebels in September.

title: Li Weihan, 88, Dead; Chinese Party Adviser
description: Li Weihan, a senior Communist Party figure and a onetime political leader of the army under Mao Zedong, died Saturday in Peking, the Government television network reported. He was 88 years old.

title: Helms Promises to Seek A Conservative Platform
description: Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, contending that most Americans agree with President Reagan's policies, says he will ''not let go unchallenged'' anything in the Republican platform that contradicts the conservative philosophy he shares with Mr. Reagan.

title: Accounts
description: * Avon fashions division to John Emmerling.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BOYS TOGETHER. English Public Schools 1800-1864. By John Chandos. 412 pages. $29.95. WRITING of his own years at Eton in ''Enemies of Promise,'' Cyril Connolly spoke of ''The Theory of Permanent Adolescence'' - that is, the theory ''that the experiences undergone by boys at the great public schools, their glories and disappointments, are so intense as to dominate their lives and to arrest their development.'' He wrote of how he dreaded leaving school, how brilliant friends faded into sadness and obscurity after leaving Eton, how ''the greater part of the ruling class'' of England had been permanently scarred by what happened to them as schoolboys.

title: Do Jodi Ann Levine on L.I.
description: Jodi Ann Levine, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Levine of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to David Paul Avergun, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Avergun of Valley Stream, L.I. Rabbi Harold I. Saperstein performed the ceremony at the Woodbury (L.I.) Country Club.

title: Dr. Robert Armstrong Dies; Anthropologist at Texas U.
description: Robert P. Armstrong, an anthropologist who studied esthetic sensibilities in primative cultures, died of cancer Thursday in Dallas. He was 65 years old.

title: How to Be Surprised By the Cyclone
description: For 58 years, people have been riding the Cyclone, the venerable Coney Island roller coaster. This year, in a new wrinkle, people are sometimes riding backwards.

title: HAROLD G. SKLAR
description: Harold G. Sklar, a former elementary school principal in Manhattan, died Saturday at the Miami Heart Institute in Miami Beach. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan and Miami Beach.

title: THE REPUBLICANS' AMNESIA
description: President Reagan kicked off his re-election campaign with a declaration that the Democrats are ''going so far left, they've left America.'' I'm concerned that our party - the Republican Party - is moving so far in the direction of the New Right that it is abandoning its own best traditions.

title: Politics on the Field
description: The Presidential Seals from the

title: BRELAND HAS JUST BEGUN
description: LOS ANGELES FOR two weeks the Olympic boxing tournament resembled feeding time in an aquarium for the sharks. All those good young American boxers were up there in the ring and all those sharks, alias promoters, were sitting there at ringside, waiting to get the eventual gold medals in their jaws. Almost on cue, after Mark Breland won his welterweight gold medal Saturday, he returned to ringside in his blue ''USA'' warmup suit. Moments later Don King approached him.

title: UMPIRES EJECT 13 IN BRAWL
description: Pascual Perez was the central figure in brushback incidents that resulted in the ejection of four pitchers, both managers, five other players and two replacement managers as the Braves beat the San Diego Padres today, 5-3.

title: MONDALE, PENTAGON SPENDER
description: It looks as if Walter F. Mondale finds little wrong with the policies of the Weinberger Pentagon that could not be put right with a few token gestures.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank Leumi le-Israel has elected to its board Morton L. Mandel, chairman of the Premier Industrial Corp., Cleveland.

title: 2 Colombians Are Arrested At Pier on Cocaine Charges
description: Federal Customs Service agents arrested two Colombian men carrying two duffle bags of cocaine worth an estimated $7.5 million on a Brooklyn pier early yesterday, according to a spokesman for the agency.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.81

title: COE LEFT HIS MARK ON 1984 OLYMPICS
description: Track and field competition in these Olympics will be remembered for Carl Lewis's four gold medals, Edwin Moses's second gold medal in eight years, Daley Thompson's second straight decathlon victory, Joan Benoit's commanding triumph in the first Olympic marathon for women and Mary Decker's spill in the women's 3,000 meters.

title: Final Medals Standing
description: Country

title: SUBWAYS: THE $3-PER-GALLON-GASOLINE CURE
description: To the Editor:

title: A Race Too Far
description: The way Barry Ward figured it, scheduling a 2,740-mile, coast-to- coast marathon to end in California just three months after the 1984 Summer Games would be a natural.

title: Sir Kenneth MacMillan Gets ABT Post
description: Sir Kenneth MacMillan, principal choreographer of Britain's Royal Ballet, has been appointed artistic associate of American Ballet Theater. Sir Kenneth will assume the position Sept. 4, at the start of the company's rehearsal period for the 1984-85 season.

title: 2 CARTER HOMERS BEAT YANKS, 6-0
description: Pardon Joe Carter when he says he'd never seen Ron Guidry before today. He is only 24 years old and, up until this year, he spent all of his career in the minor leagues. For that matter, when Guidry was a Cy Young winner in 1978, Carter was spending the summer in Oklahoma City, waiting to enter Wichita State University after just finishing high school.

title: U.S. Takes Gold
description: Joe Fargis of the United States, riding the appropriately named Touch of Class, edged his friend aside in a jumpoff today to capture the individual show-jumping gold medal with an impeccable display.

title: Market Place; A Stampede By Institutions
description: THE stock market took its lead last week

title: VACATIONING: REUNITING FAMILIES
description: THEY live far apart, parents in

title: Something to Brag About
description: With the nation's military defense posture a major issue in the Presidential campaign, the forthcoming debuts of the Air Force's B-1 strategic bomber in California and the X-29 advanced- technology demonstrator aircraft on Long Island seem to be taking the form of forums for top Reagan Administration officials to brag about what the President is doing to keep the nation safe.

title: Republican Woman Chided Over Ferraro
description: The chairman of California's Republican central committee has scolded a member of the committee for expressing enthusiasm over the nomination of Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro of Queens for Vice President on the Democratic ticket.

title: It's Carl Albert's Town
description: It would not take long for anyone arriving in McAlester, Okla., to decide that the little city has a certain affection for its most famous resident, 76-year-old Carl Bert Albert, the former Speaker of the House of Representatives. There is a Carl Albert Parkway, a Carl Albert Lake, a Carl Albert statue and now a Carl Albert Federal Building, so designated in a resolution that won final approval in Congress last week.

title: Kroger Stores
description: The Kroger Company will reopen about 40 of the 70 Detroit-area supermarkets it closed last month following approval Friday of a contract with its unionized meat cutters, a company spokesman said. Kroger, the nation's second-largest food retailer, will rehire about 2,800 of the 4,700 workers it laid off July 21, said Paul Bernish, a spokesman for the Cincinnati-based company.

title: Matter of Muscle?
description: When Richard N. Perle, Assistant Secretary of Defense for international security policy, and other arms control hardliners in the Pentagon talk about ''throw weights,'' they are not commenting on recent Olympic feats. A major issue in United States arms control policy is how persistently to press the Russians to agree to steps that would lead to equivalent ballistic missile ''throw weights,'' that is, the amount of weight, exclusive of the missile rocket, that the boosters can lift into ballistic space trajectory.

title: BRIDGE: FRUSTRATION OFTEN THE RESULT WITH A FREAKISH DISTRIBUTION
description: Powerful freak hands often prove to be a disappointment.

title: SOME GROUPS UNHAPPY WITH PG-13 FILM RATING
description: The first PG-13 films are now arriving at theaters but the new rating - which is only advisory - has failed to soothe the fears of mainstream church groups and single-cause coalitions, which have been concerned about rising levels of sex and violence in movies.

title: Gomez Takes U.S. Clay Final
description: Andres Gomez, playing a nearly- flawless first set, beat Balazs Taroczy, 6-0, 7-6, today for the men's title in the United States Open Clay-Court tennis tournament. It was a match between two clay specialists.

title: POP: AT RITZ, BAD MANNERS, BRITISH GROUP
description: BAD MANNERS, a frolicsome troupe of British musicians who have had a string of hits in England, brought their engaging brand of musical fun to the Ritz on Friday night. That fun revolves around ska, the rollicking fusion of reggae and rhythm and blues that became popular in England in the 1960's and enjoyed a revival in the late 70's as a vehicle for expressing interracial solidarity among a younger generation of musicians.

title: SOCCER VIEW FROM A BLIMP
description: PASADENA, Calif.

title: PACT JEOPARDIZED IN HOSPITAL STRIKE
description: Only hours after an agreement was near in New York's hospital and nursing-home strike, the accord was jeopardized yesterday in a bitter disagreement over economic issues, representatives of both sides said.

title: TAX-EXEMPT ISSUES DOMINATE SCHEDULE
description: No Treasury note or bond auctions are scheduled this week, although there is a full slate of tax-exempt issues and a potentially large supply of corporate offerings.

title: MONDALE CAMPAIGN IS WORKING TO WIN JACKSON AND BLACK VOTERS
description: When the Rev. Jesse Jackson stood smiling beside Walter F. Mondale at the Democratic National Convention last month and the two men looked out over thousands of exuberant delegates waving little American flags together, there was a sense of unity in the air.

title: ; SUBWAYS: THE $3-PER-GALLON-GASOLINE CURE
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. to Name Reagan And Bush in One Ballot
description: In a break with tradition, the Republican National Convention will nominate both President Reagan and Vice President Bush for new terms on a single roll-call next week.

title: A DRAMA ON CHANNEL 5, 'TROUBLE WITH GRANDPA'
description: ''THE TROUBLE WITH GRANDPA'' is a curiosity: a half-hour drama sufficient unto itself. Moreover, it is slender, almost gossamer in construction, with hardly a wisp of a plot. Maybe it is only a vignette. But bless it whatever it is because in its approach is maturity and in its brevity is charm. These are scarce commodities on television. The Capital Cities production will be seen on WNEW- TV, Channel 5, at 8:30 tonight.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 13, 1984

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The reaction was, 'Gerry, I'm not going to tell you how to run the country, you're not going to tell me how to run my business.'

title: Guyana Premier Steps Down
description: Prime Minister Ptolemy Reid of Guyana has retired, and President Forbes Burnham has named the Vice President for Production, Desmond Hoyte, as his successor, the President's office said Saturday night.

title: DANCE: 'ESCALIO' OFFERED AT PAPP'S LATIN FESTIVAL
description: A NUMBER of things seemed to be going on in ''Escalio,'' presented by Pepatian on Saturday night at the Public Theater's LuEsther Hall, as part of Joseph Papp's Festival Latino en Nueva York. The theater seats were adorned with small paper bags filled with dirt and slips of paper with quotations from the writing of Clemente Soto Velez, whose 1937 ''Escalio'' inspired the multimedia piece. Program notes describe the book as ''a philosophical treatise on the revolutionary aspects of nature.'' The title itself means ''land left for tillage,'' and the piece did take place on a dirt- filled stage dotted with mysterious earth structures.

title: People
description: * Jay Greenberg has been promoted to vice president of marketing at the Memorex Corporation, Santa Clara, Calif.

title: Emily Dreifus Wed to Mark Maremont
description: Emily Louise Dreifus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jed Dreifus of Memphis, was married there yesterday to Mark David Maremont, a son of Michael D. Maremont of Chicago and the late Jill F. Maremont. Rabbi Harry Danziger performed the ceremony at Temple Israel.

title: Five Are Inducted Into Hall of Fame
description: The street signs said Cooperstown, but the feeling was more like Dodgertown here today as Pee Wee Reese and Don Drysdale received the loudest cheers of five former ballplayers who were formally inducted into the National Baseball Hall of Fame.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Rating

title: Bombs in Sri Lanka Kill 19 at a Police Station
description: At least 19 people were killed Saturday night when bombs wrecked a police station outside this northern city, witnesses said today.

title: SUBWAYS: THE $3-PER-GALLON-GASOLINE CURE
description: To the Editor:

title: A MIDEAST ODYSSEY
description: Judith Miller is chief of The Times's Cairo bureau.

title: U.S. Official Says Town Had Clues to Unrest
description: Clues that ethnic unrest was brewing in this industrial city were apparent at least three years before hostility between Hispanic residents and other people erupted last week in two nights of rioting, a Federal Justice Department official says.

title: Alexander Keneas, 46, Dies;A Movie Critic for Newsday
description: Alexander Keneas, a film critic for Newsday who had been at the newspaper since 1972, died of lung cancer Friday at his Manhattan home.

title: 'INSIDE STORY' SERIES LOSES FINANCIAL BACKING
description: ''Inside Story,'' the public television series that for four seasons has examined the role of the press in society, has lost its sponsor support, and except for a special program, will not return to television unless new backing is found.

title: A STRIKING CLOSING CEREMONY
description: There was singing and dancing. There were fireworks and a laser show and a 23,000-square-foot stage. There was a simulated flying saucer, suspended from a helicopter, with flashing lights that hovered overhead for a few minutes and then flew off.

title: CORSICAN VOTE: NEW MEETS OLD BUT THEY SELDOM MIX
description: There were 10 parties and 610 candidates, but as he shook hands with voters at their polling place here this morning, Clement Biggi seemed unconcerned.

title: 6 IN CONGRESS VOW TO FIGHT REAGAN ON POPULATION AID
description: Six members of Congress said here today that they would try to block the Reagan Administration's new population policy through legislation if changes cannot be achieved through compromise.

title: THE GAINS BY INDEX OPTIONS
description: Stock index options enjoyed record volume in the stock market's recent bull run. The activity encouraged those who predict that index options will eventually become an indispensable tool for equity investors.

title: Argentina Pact Progress
description: Argentina has reached an agreement with the International Monetary Fund that could open the way for rescheduling its $47 billion debt, President Raul Alfonsin said Saturday.

title: Deborah C. Li Married to David Cohen
description: Deborah Chunroh Li, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Tingye Li of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to David Lloyd Cohen, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sumner Cohen of Lake Success, L.I. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony at the Shadow Brook restaurant in Shrewsbury, N.J.

title: LOPES OF PORTUGAL WINNER OF MEN'S MARATHON
description: When the favorites had faded and most of the experienced marathoners had dropped from the front of one of the greatest fields ever assembled, it was left to Carlos Lopes of Portugal to grab a surprising victory in the men's marathon this evening in the final event of the Games of the XXIII Olympiad. He completed the 26-mile-385-yard course in an Olympic record time of 2 hours 9 minutes 21 seconds. He bettered the time of 2:09:55 set by Waldemar Cierpinski of East Germany at Montreal in 1976. Lopes finished 215 meters ahead of John Treacy of Ireland, who won his country's first medal in the 1984 Games with a second-place time of 2:09:56, just a second behind the Olympic record that had stood before this evening. Charles Spedding of Britain was third in 2:09:58. Lopes had won the world cross-country championship and had world-class success at 10,000 meters. But that did not explain how a 37-year-old loan officer from a Lisbon bank could run away from the best-known and most successful marathoners in the world to win his nation's first gold medal in track and field. Especially since he had suffered minor injuries on his left leg and arm after being hit by a car less than a month ago. ''There is no explanation,'' Lopes said. ''That's how it is.'' While the capacity crowd at the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum waited for a field that included the dominant names of the last several years, it first saw Lopes emerge from the tunnel at the southwest corner of the stadium.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Finance Executive Leaves MGM-UA
description: After a 20-year career with the company, Jason Rabinovitz has announced that he is leaving his position as senior vice president of finance at the MGM-UA Entertainment Company.

title: Finn Disqualified; 11 Fail Drug Tests
description: Martti Vainio of Finland, the silver medalist in the 10,000-meter run, has been disqualified for using steroids and will have to give up his medal, the deputy head of the Finnish team said today.

title: Street Hazards
description: Like most other visitors, 16-year-old

title: JAPAN FALTERS ON NEXT STEP IN COMPUTERS
description: Japan's celebrated effort to catapult the nation to the world lead in creating computers that think like human beings - producing machines that can reason like a lawyer or simulate a doctor's deductive diagnostic skills, for example - is running into stumbling blocks.

title: MALEEVA, NO. 6, TRIES TO BREAK A PATTERN
description: THE cycle is one that has become all too familiar in women's tennis: It begins with the sudden emergence of a bright, new star, a pony-tailed teenager who can captivate her audiences with her charm while destroying an opponent with a two-fisted backhand at the same time. But when the cycle completes itself - often just as suddenly as it began - the joys of youth have given way to the problems of adolescence and adulthood.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Transit Semantics
description: Riders waited and waited before 9

title: Isuzu in Malaysian Deal
description: Isuzu Motors Ltd. said Friday that it would acquire 25 percent of Automotive Manufacturers (Malaysia), which makes passenger cars and commercial vehicles for the Japanese company.

title: Washington Watch; Skeptic's View Of Forecasting
description: WASHINGTON

title: NEW BETHLEHEM MARKET: MORE THAN A FRUIT STAND
description: -Occupied West Bank, Aug. 10 - A new fruit and vegetable market opened on the outskirts of this biblical town the other day, but it will be more than just a place to buy tomatoes and melons.

title: 'STRANGERS KISS,' IN THE HOLLYWOOD OF 1955
description: THE Hollywood of 1955 is the setting for ''Strangers Kiss,'' a film whose characters are caught up in the making of a movie and are much more concerned with behind-the-scenes machinations than with what eventually ends up on the screen. To some extent this also seems true of the makers of ''Strangers Kiss'' themselves, though their film has enough independence and zeal to overcome much of its myopia.

title: LODZ GHETTO SURVIVORS RECALL A VANISHED WORLD
description: Nearly 1,500 Holocaust survivors gathered here today to meet old friends, to reminisce and to search for fragments and figures from the past.

title: Home Savings In Acquisition WASHINGTON, Aug. 12
description: The giant Home Savings of America of Los Angeles

title: A Rare Success in Philippines
description: Amid the prevailing gloom in Philippine industry, Stanford Microsystems Inc. is a glittering exception, the sort of enterprise, economists and Government officials say, that the country needs in greater numbers to overcome its economic troubles.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 13, 1984: MONDAY Florida Pwr & LtMinn Mng & MfgMeredith Corp

title: DALLAS IS GIRDING FOR DELEGATES AND DEMONSTRATIONS
description: Thousands of demonstrators preparing to set up a tent city in Dallas before the Republican National Convention promise to be good guests, and Dallas has responded by providing basic amenities. It has also set aside several hundred guest rooms - at the county jails.

title: Jane R. Buder Married To a Medical Student
description: Jane Robin Buder, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Buder of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Eric Joseph Shapiro, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Shapiro of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. Rabbi Stephen D. Franklin performed the ceremony assisted by Cantor Helene Reps at the Plaza Hotel.

title: JOSEF GRUNWALD, RABBI, DIES AT 82
description: Rabbi Josef Grunwald, who transplanted the remains of a devastated Hungarian Hasidic congregation to Brooklyn after World War II and rebuilt it there, died Friday night at the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla after a stroke. He was 82 years old and lived in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

title: BOND RALLY MAY FACE A HURDLE
description: The recent bond market rally, which has cut long-term interest rates by a percentage point since early July, may soon be tested by new data showing that the economy is still growing under a full head of steam.

title: UNWED MOTHERS ACCOUNTING FOR THIRD OF NEW YORK BIRTHS
description: More than one of every three babies born in New York City last year were born out of wedlock.

title: QUESTION LINGERS AS GAMES CLOSE: WHAT IF EVERYONE HAD COMPETED?
description: The numbers are staggering. When the Games of the XXIII Olympiad ended today, the United States had won 83 gold medals and Rumania was second with 20. The United States had won a total of 174 medals and West Germany was second with 59.

title: Evaluation of Teachers Is Called 'Perfunctory'
description: The methods school districts use to evaluate teachers are ''perfunctory'' and inadequate for making decisions about merit pay, the author of a study by the Rand Corporation says.

title: CHIEF OF NAVY OPERATIONS REBUTS REPORTS OF LACK OF PREPAREDNESS
description: The Chief of Naval Operations, stung by reports that the Navy is not ready to fight, has dispatched an angry message to other senior naval officers to give them ammunition to deny the allegations.

title: ARIEH SHARON, ARCHITECT AND PLANNER IN ISRAEL
description: Arieh Sharon, an architect and town planner who profoundly influenced Israel's physical appearance, died July 24 in Paris during a visit there. He was 84 years old.

title: Chad Opposition Forms A Separate Rebel Group
description: Rebels from Chad ended five days of talks today by setting up a third force opposed both to President Hissen Habre and to the main guerrilla group.

title: A Top Official Resigns From Seagull Energy
description: Dan H. Montgomery has resigned as president, chief operating officer and a director of the Seagull Energy Corporation.

title: Man Charged in Car Death
description: A man whose 21-month-old son was killed in a car accident has been charged with violating several traffic laws. On Friday night, a car driven by William E. Puls, 37 years old, of Columbia, Md., struck the rear of a vehicle that had stopped, the state police said. The man's son Sean was thrown against the dashboard and died later in a hospital. Mr. Puls was charged with speeding, negligent driving, failure to reduce speed to avoid a collision and two violations of the state's new child-passenger restraint law, the police said.

title: THE STAGE: 'MAHAGONNY,' AT PUBLIC
description: ''MAHAGONNY'' has been presented in a variety of musical and theatrical forms, as everything from a cabaret song cycle to an all-out opera. Among the many versions I have seen, El Teatro do Ornitorrinco's production, a burlesque clown show, is the earthiest, the most vulgar and, ultimately, the most self- destructive. It opened the Festival Latino en Nueva York at the Public Theater this weekend.

title: MONDAY, AUGUST 13, 1984 International
description: Members of Congress vowed to block the Reagan Administration's new population policy if changes cannot be achieved through compromise. Six members - five Democrats and one Republican - objected to the Administration's new policy of denying family planning funds to international private organizations that ''perform or actively promote'' abortion whether or not United States funds are used for that purpose. Representative James H. Scheuer, Democrat of New York, said the policy was ''a bizarre misapplication of United States power and influence.'' (Page A1, Column 4.) A cocaine removal program in Peru sponsored by the United States has been suspended because of guerrilla raids in the cocaine-growing area, American officials said. (A1:5.)

title: FINANCIAL DIFFICULTY FOR HATFIELD SUGGESTED BY '82-83 DISCLOSURE
description: Financial disclosures filed by Senator Mark O. Hatfield for 1982 and 1983 indicate the Oregon Republican may have been experiencing financial difficulties at the time he became involved with a Greek businessman seeking to construct an oil pipeline across Africa.

title: PEOPLE EXPRESS VS. THE GIANTS
description: People Express Airlines is growing like a gawky teen-ager, bursting its seams. Overflowing its base in the old North Terminal of Newark International Airport, it is filling the skies here with its planes.

title: John S. Edwards Dies at 72; Chicago Symphony Manager
description: John S. Edwards, general manager of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra for more than 17 years, died Saturday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Chicago. He was 72 years old.

title: MERGER BID A BRITISH PUZZLER
description: Sugar and tea may be natural companions in the typical British parlor, but mixing them in the City of London is proving to be another matter.

title: REAGAN CONCEDES POSSILBLE TAX RISE AS A 'LAST RESORT'
description: In a new attempt to clarify the Administration's position, President Reagan and Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan today opened the door to the possibility of tax increases for next year, but only as ''a last resort'' and only if accompanied by some tax reductions.

title: ZIMBABWE CREATES A POLITBURO TO HEAD NEW POLITICAL STRUCTURE
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe today announced the membership of a new Central Committee for his ruling party and a 15-member Politburo. The Politburo will become the supreme authority in one of the few African nations that has more than a single political party.

title: Congo Shuffles Cabinet After Politburo Meeting
description: The leftist Government was reorganized today after a meeting Saturday night of the Politburo of the ruling Congolese Workers Party.

title: CHILD-ABUSE REPORT: 'THEREWAS NO COVER-UP'
description: To the Editor:

title: Republicans Disagree On Platform's Tax Plank
description: Republican conservatives continued today to push for a tough plank against tax increases in the party's 1984 platform, even though a representative of President Reagan said he wanted to include Mr. Reagan's new ''never say never'' position in the party document.

title: FERRARO TO DISCLOSE HER TAX FORMS, BUT HUSBAND'S WILL REMAIN PRIVATE
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro said today that she would release her income tax returns as part of her effort to make a full disclosure of her financial affairs, but that her husband would not release his.

title: MONDALE DEMANDS SPECIFICS
description: Walter F. Mondale greeted President Reagan's statement on taxes today with renewed demands that Mr. Reagan disclose his plans for reducing the Federal budget deficit by specifying which programs would be cut and what taxes would be raised if he was elected to a second term.

title: Futures/Options; Treasury Option Spreads
description: JUST before the stock market exploded two weeks ago, many

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Did Ted Williams ever pitch in a major league game?

title: A HARLEM BLOCK PROUD OF GAINS AND ITS CHILDREN
description: Summer can seem especially harsh in the poorest parts of Harlem, where the sun bakes tightly packed brick tenement buildings on streets with no trees. But there are oases, and one can be found on a block where the 36 five-story walkups are clean and well cared for and shaded by young, green trees.

title: Rematch Offer
description: A businessman here has offered a $65,000 purse for a rematch between Mary Decker and Zola Budd, the South African Broadcasting Corporation said today. He was identified as Joe Berardo, a bank and mining company director.

title: BRISK SUMMER FOR CITY OPERA
description: The New York City Opera is showing that it can sell summer opera to New York. After five weeks of its first summer season, audiences have been big, and there are many new faces in them.

title: David A. Nover Weds Miss Zinbarg, Teacher
description: Elizabeth Dee Zinbarg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Zinbarg of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to David Allen Nover, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Nover of South Orange, N.J. Rabbi Alexander M. Shapiro performed the ceremony at Oheb Shalom Congregation in South Orange. He was assisted by Cantor Henry Rosenblum.

title: A TIME OF FRUSTRATION FOR JETS' O'BRIEN
description: It is only his first summer as a pro starter, but problems are compounding for the Jets' young quarterback, Ken O'Brien. And he has not been able to solve them successfully.

title: The Calendar ;  Monday
description: The August doldrums are upon Washington. It will be unusually quiet this week, with President Reagan in California until Wednesday and Congress recessed until September. The Democratic candidates, Walter F. Mondale and Geraldine A. Ferraro, will be campaigning in the South and West.

title: AMUSEMENT PARK SAFETY STIRS A FEDERAL DEBATE
description: A spate of amusement park accidents, including the Great Adventure fun-house fire that killed eight people in New Jersey and recent fatalities on park rides, has stirred support in Congress for reinstating Federal jurisdiction over safety at the parks.

title: OPERA: RACHMANINOFF'S 'MONNA VANNA' FRAGMENT
description: The operatic world lost a lush, brooding score, but probably not a masterpiece, when Rachmaninoff abandoned his projected opera ''Monna Vanna'' after completing a piano- vocal score of one act in 1908. The fragment, with orchestration provided by Igor Buketoff, was given its world premiere here Saturday evening by the orchestra most closely associated with Rachmaninoff during his American years, the Phildelphia Orchestra. Mr. Buketoff conducted.

title: Free Brazilian Concert
description: The season's final Summerpier concert, ''Brazil Comes to the Big Apple,'' scheduled for last Friday but canceled because of threatening rain, will be held this evening at 8. Tonight's performance will be by Thiago de Mello and Amazon. Sponsored by the South Street Seaport, the free concerts are held on Pier 16, at Fulton Street and the East River.

title: ZAHN OF ANGELS IS OUT 15 DAYS
description: The California Angels left-hander Geoff Zahn, who underwent knee surgery Saturday morning, has been placed on the 15-day disabled list, the club announced.

title: FOSTER HITS HOMER
description: Ron Darling's first successful pitching effort in five weeks, George Foster's second home run in two days and a timely two-run double by Ron Hodges yesterday sent the Mets packing for the West Coast in bouyant spirits.

title: PENTAGON SPENDS MORE IN FEWER DISTRICTS, RESEARCHER SAYS
description: The Pentagon has concentrated more spending in fewer states as a result of the military buildup undertaken by the Reagan Administration, according to an outside analysis of taxes received and allocated by the Defense Department in the fiscal year 1983.

title: CABLE CAR RAMMED, KILLING 1 AND INJURING 30
description: A speeding automobile struck a cable car full of tourists on one of San Francisco's steepest hills today, killing the driver of the car and injuring about 30 people on the cable car, the police said. The driver apparently was intent on commiting suicide, officers said.

title: PauletteCorbettBrideof
description: Paulette Stephanie Corbett, a daughter of No"el C. Corbett of the Bronx and the late Charles E. Corbett, was married yesterday to Mark Robert Damiano, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph R. Damiano of Yonkers. Msgr. Cajetan J. Troy performed the ceremony at St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church on Richardson Avenue in the Bronx.

title: Louganis Captures Second Gold Medal
description: With a display of power and grace that astounded even those who are used to his dazzling performances, Greg Louganis won his second gold medal of these Olympic Games today, taking the men's 10-meter platform competition with a world-record score of 710.91 points.

title: SUBWAYS: THE $3-PER-GALLON-GASOLINE CURE
description: To the Editor:

title: REVANCHE IS SWEET
description: LONDON

title: Pa L Led at Stanford
description: Pauline Louise Lord, the daughter of George de Forest Lord of Stonington and Killingworth, Conn., and Ruth du Pont Lord of New Haven and East Lyme, Conn., was married yesterday to David Hicks Harlow, the son of Mrs. Philip Hall of Newport, N.H., and the late Harry Walter Harlow. The Rev. Wendy Smith performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Stanford University Memorial Chapel in Stanford, Calif.

title: DECISION NEARS ON GIANT QUARTERBACK
description: Facing a week of decisions, on who will play where for the Giants, on which players will start, and on which players won't be Giants at all, Coach Bill Parcells said, ''From now on, whatever happens you can take pretty seriously.''

title: LEARNING TO UMPIRE THE 'BEST GAME IN THE WORLD'
description: Every morning for five weeks this summer, 34 men and women started their day by debating 1 of the 10 official rules of baseball. The other day it was Rule No. 7, which deals with the runner.

title: Bill on Prenatal Care ForTeen-agersSigned
description: Governor Cuomo has signed legislation allowing pregnant teen-agers to get prenatal care without their parents' consent.

title: I.B.M.'S NEW ROLE IN EUROPE
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has always been considered an outsider in Europe, an American behemoth whose presence has been tolerated only because its products were so sorely needed. But now that it has settled its nettlesome, decade- long antitrust dispute with the Common Market, the company is accelerating a campaign to change that image.

title: MUSIC: AMERICAN WORKS AT FESTIVAL IN GROTON
description: The University of Connecticut at Avery Point is situated on a small peninsula that juts out into the harbor some miles outside of Groton. This branch of the university, associated with the nearby United States Coast Guard Academy, specializes in the maritime sciences; as such, it may seem an unlikely setting for a festival of American music. Yet, on Saturday night, the first of five programs co-sponsored by the William Billings Institute of American Music, took place in a hangarlike cafeteria within the university's student union.

title: A PEEK AT CHINA'S FOREIGN POLICY PROCESS
description: McCLEAN, Va. - In a remarkable statement during a personal interview granted to me in Peking, Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang has described with unprecedented candor and detail the foreign policy making roles and relationships of China's top party and Government leaders and institutions. His statements indicate that much of the conventional wisdom in the West about how and where policy making takes place is out of date.

title: Reagan's Cost-Control Chief Derides Mondale Over Taxes
description: J. Peter Grace, the head of President Reagan's cost-control commission, said Saturday that Walter F. Mondale was ''nuts'' if he thought a tax increase was essential for reducing the Federal deficit,

title: Rise in Cost of Linerboard Spurs Industry Protest
description: Makers of cardboard boxes are protesting an increase by paper manufacturers in the price of linerboard, the raw material used to make the boxes.

title: VIOLA, TWINS SHUT OUT MARINERS
description: Frank Viola tossed a six-hit shutout and Andre David banged four hits to lead the Minnesota Twins to a 3-0 victory over the Seattle Mariners today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary on July 30 of Dr. Harold C. Syrett, professor of history at Columbia University, misidentified George B. McClellan Jr., whose memoirs the professor edited. McClellan was Mayor of New York City from 1903 to 1909.

title: REAGAN SAID TO JOKE OF BOMBING RUSSIA BEFORE RADIO SPEECH
description: Preparing for his regular radio broadcast Saturday, President Reagan reportedly made a joke about national security, saying: ''My fellow Americans. I am pleased to tell you I just signed legislation which outlaws Russia forever. The bombing begins in five minutes.''

title: SUBWAYS: THE $3-PER-GALLON-GASOLINE CURE
description: To the Editor:

title: Prices Drop For Gasoline
description: Despite Saudi Arabia's reduced oil production and American motorists' increased fuel consumption, gasoline prices have dropped for the 13th consecutive week, Dan Lundberg, an oil industry analyst, said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GOOD LOOKING

title: HEALTH CARE DENIAL-WITH A PROVISO
description: To the Editor:

title: PREP SCHOOLS' FLEETING BOW TO THE 'UNDERCLASS'
description: To the Editor:

title: LOUIS VUITTON'S GLOBAL MARKET PUSH
description: Seven years ago, Louis Vuitton S.A. was a quiet, family-owned company known mainly for its distinctively monogrammed trunks, suitcases and handbags. It had only two stores and $17.5 million a year in sales.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Aug. 13, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: DENIS WATSON WINS ON 271
description: Denis Watson of South Africa shot a 4-under-par 68 and set a tournament record with a 17-under-par 271 to edge Payne Stewart by one stroke today in the Buick Open, earning his first PGA Tour victory.

title: Games of Onionad I
description: Now that the Games of the XXXIII Olympiad are a stirring memory of triumph and defeat, the folks in Canastota, N.Y., near Syracuse, are planning a tongue-in-cheek reprise of sorts that should bring tears to the eyes of even the most cynical sports fans - two days of pun and games known as the Onion Olympics.

title: Ruiz Wins in Solo For 2d Gold Medal
description: Tracie Ruiz of the United States captured her second Olympic gold medal with a stunning performance today in the synchronized swimming solo event.

title: Price of Victory
description: You In Tak of South Korea, who beat Andy Rein of the United States for a gold medal Saturday night in freestyle wrestling, had to be carried to the victory stand to receive it.

title: British Output Rises
description: Seasonally adjusted output in British industries rose three-tenths of 1 percent in June, putting production eight-tenths of 1 percent above the level of a year earlier, the Central Statistics Office said today. The agency said output in the manufacturing industries led the gain with a five-tenths of 1 percent rise from May and 2.9 percent over 12 months.

title: COLLEGE COSTS UP, BUT RATE SLOWS
description: THE rapid rate of increase in college costs has finally begun to drop, according to a survey by the College Board. After three years of annual increases of 10 to 11 percent in the cost of going to college, students and their families will have to cope with an increase of only 6 percent this fall, the College Board said yesterday.

title: GOLDEN NUGGET INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $2,788,000.

title: A Vacancy, But No Takers
description: Help Wanted: Armadillo. So the ad might read to conform with Deputy Mayor Stanley Brezenoff's criteria for a successor to James A. Krauskopf. Mr. Krauskopf resigned last week as Commissioner of the city's vast Human Resources Administration in the wake of charges that children were sexually abused at city-financed day-care centers.

title: 6 Held in Marine's Death
description: Five marines from Camp Pendleton and the widow of a marine have been booked on charges of murder and conspiracy.

title: Muldowney Moved
description: Shirley Muldowney, the drag racer severely injured in a 247-mile-an-hour crash June 29 in Canada, will be transferred from a Montreal hospital to Wayne State University Hospital in Detroit, closer to her home in Mount Clemens, Mich. The 44-year-old three-time champion of the National Hot Rod Association suffered three fractures of the left leg, torn knee cartilage, a broken right ankle and a severed right thumb, which was reattached by doctors. She has also undergone a series of skin grafts.

title: THOUSANDS IN ULSTER MARCH TO DENOUNCE KILLING BY THE POLICE
description: Thousands of people marched here today to protest the death of a man killed by police officers trying to arrest an American supporter of the outlawed Irish Republican Army.

title: CAIRO BACKS OFF CHARGE OF IRAN TIE TO MINING
description: Egypt backed away today from its charge that Iran might have been responsible for laying mines in the Red Sea and suggested instead that Libya alone was to blame.

title: A MANHOLE FIRE CUTS TELEPHONES IN THE 'VILLAGE'
description: At least 1,500 residents and merchants in Manhattan just north of Washington Square Park went without phone service the entire weekend and most of yesterday because of an underground fire that damaged telephone cables.

title: Personal Best Gabrielle Andersen-Schiess. Mary Decker. Jeff Blatnick. Li Ning. Evander Holyfield. Mary Lou Retton. Greg Louganis. Carlos Lopes. Winners and losers, but each an athlete of stunning endeavor. The Communist boycott notwithstanding, these and hundreds of individuals like them - not any nation, present or absent - again gave essence and inspiration to the Olympic Games.
description: Who can forget the contorted, dehydrated figure of Mrs. Andersen-Schiess staggering to finish the women's marathon? Who doesn't share Mary Decker's latest frustration - being tripped near the end of the race to which she'd been building for so many years?

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Fenimore Asset Management Inc., a Cobbleskill, N.Y., investment adviser, said it had increased its holdings in Cotton States Life and Health Insurance Co. to 107,850 common shares, or 7.7 percent of the total outstanding.

title: FREQUENCY CONTROL PRODCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COMCAST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ASEA GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WINN-DIXIE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 5-for-3 stock split paid Oct. 31, 1983.

title: MUSEUM SELLING REAL-LIFE STILL LIFES
description: The director of the Whitney Museum of American Art and his assistant have been preparing for the opening for more than a year. They have fussed over the details and invited all the celebrities. Barring rain - or drought - the gala will open this evening.

title: IT ADDS NEW SPECIALITIES
description: After impressing the financial community with the cost-cutting business practices it brought to the for-profit hospital field, Humana Inc. is now focusing on impressing the medical community by providing the most advanced hospital technology that money can buy.

title: URUGUAYAN POLITICAL CRISIS: THE INTENTIONS OF U.S. POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: TAX SHELTERS REQUIRED TO REGISTER WITH I.R.S.
description: In a new attempt to reduce its loss of revenue to abusive tax shelters, the Internal Revenue Service announced today that most shelters would have to be registered starting Sept. 1.

title: Argentine Talks Continuing
description: Bernardo Grinspun, Argentina's minister of economy, met in New York yesterday with the country's 11- bank advisory group to discuss progress in negotiations with the International Monetary Fund on an economic austerity program.

title: HATFIELD CITES 'ERROR IN JUDGMENT' ON PIPELINE
description: Antoinette Hatfield said today that she had received $55,000, not $40,000, from a Greek businessman whose trans-African pipeline venture was strongly endorsed by her husband, Senator Mark O. Hatfield.

title: MONDALE DROPS RULE CURBING PRESS
description: Following a protest from major news organizations, the Mondale campaign said yesterday that it would suspend a policy that had prohibited journalists from reporting what the candidate said on his campaign airplane or photographing him on those flights without prior agreement.

title: Astros Beat Cubs in Ninth, 2-1
description: Jerry Mumphrey's single with one out in the ninth inning gave the Houston Astros a 2-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs tonight.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BankAmerica Corp. , San Francisco, has appointed Winslow Christian to the new post of vice president and director of litigation.

title: TAX TIPS FOR MONDALE
description: When he says we need to raise taxes, Walter F. Mondale is right - but for the wrong reasons. He's thinking primarily about the budget deficits and election strategy, both important factors, no doubt. But we need tax increases - or, more specifically, we need to repeal certain tax cuts of the last few years, to redirect investment out of the low- and slow-growth industries that have received most of the tax breaks and into fast-growth businesses that create jobs and wealth.

title: HCC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Soap and Water For City Sidewalks
description: ''It's a pity,'' Gilbert DiLucia said

title: WESTWORLD COMMUNITY HEALTHCARE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: CUSHMAN PROMOTES TWO TO TOP POSTS
description: Stephen B. Siegel has been elected chairman of Cushman & Wakefield Inc., the real estate company, and Arthur J. Mirante 2d has been appointed president and chief executive officer.

title: RAIN OVER WEST TEXAS REVIVES GRASS AND HOPE
description: Up to two inches of rain fell over parched West Texas rangeland in the last week, raising hopes that more than two years of devastating drought may be coming to an end.

title: FROM ANOTHER ERA; Stiff-Necked Babies While walking along Eighth Avenue recently, a friend of ours passed a baby carriage heading north. Its top was down, its occupant in pushup position and surveying the landscape as fixedly as Buster Keaton surveyed the horizon in ''The Navigator.'' Our friend laughed, remembering when her own children had peered, stiff- necked and wide-eyed, over their carriage walls - and suddenly realized that it had been years since she'd seen a baby in just that pose.
description: It's because of collapsible strollers, in which infants are now placed immediately after birth, the better to tour department stores comfortably. Back curved into a bow, chin resting upon chest, the child has only to look straight ahead to see that the world is made of knees.

title: Of Republican Hair
description: Republicans generally may not believe in the free lunch, but Clairol, the hair goods company, seems to believe there will be takers for free hairdos at the Republican National Convention next week in Dallas. Clairol has commissioned Robin Weir, the Washington stylist who does Nancy Reagan's hair, to perform on the heads of prominent Republican women. Some 75 women scheduled to attend the convention have been designated ''special dignitaries'' and promised free hair treatment by Mr. Weir.

title: FIRST AMERICAN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW VARIETIES OF HARDY RICE HOLD PROMISE
description: LOS BANOS, THE PHILIPPINES

description: b-Net income.

title: TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid July 6.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ; OPEN SKIES
description: One of Lincoln Center's more ample cornucopias of the arts will pour forth its talent for three weeks starting today, when the 14th annual Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors Festival begins. It runs through Sept. 3. The festival, which uses the center's two main plazas and Damrosch Park, will give a platform to more than 70 groups presenting drama, dance, chamber music, children's shows, blues and bluegrass, square dancing, circus acts, and ethnic ensembles reflecting the city's many cultural roots.

title: MEDICAL DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DELOREAN JURORS EVACUATED AFTER BOMB THREAT TO COURT
description: Jurors deliberating for a fourth day in the trial of John Z. DeLorean on charges of trafficking in cocaine were evacuated from the Federal Courthouse here today, along with several hundred other people, because of a bomb threat.

title: FOR GOLDFISH, SOLITARYLIFE IS UNNATURAL
description: IF your Cleo seems nervous, it

REVCO D.S. EXECUTIVE ADDS PURCHASING DUTIES
description: Revco D.S. Inc., the drug store chain, yesterday said it had named Daniel Horwitz, a vice president of merchandising, to the new position of vice president of merchandising and purchasing.

description: To the Editor: The appalling reports of child sex

title: Koch Asks Help On Abuse Cases
description: In a letter to all employees of the city's child-care centers, Mayor Koch yesterday asked for their help in identifying instances of the sexual abuse of children. ''It would be incredible to believe,'' he said, ''that these situations are limited to the Bronx.''

title: Trilogy's Loss Widens
description: Trilogy Ltd., a company formed to develop semiconductor, packaging and computer-aided design technologies, yesterday reported a loss of $59.3 million for the second quarter, compared with a loss of $3.2 million in the second quarter of 1983. Trilogy said the latest deficit was after a charge of $43 million, primarily for the writedown of assets related to discontinued development activities and a reserve for future costs of discontinued operations. The company, which is based in Cupertino, Calif., last week abandoned its plans to build a high-speed ''wafer-scale'' computer chip, saying it would instead attempt to design circuit packages made up of conventional semiconductors.

title: SOVIET TV DRAMA MIXES SPIES AND GEOPOLITICS
description: For the last two weeks, Soviet television viewers have been following the exploits of a band of intrepid K.G.B. agents battling the machinations of American spies around the world. The 10-part series has combined aspects of a James Bond-style thriller with those of a Communist cautionary tale about the wicked intentions of the imperialist West.

title: ARGONAUT ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated for comparison purposes with 1984 presentation.

title: United Telecom
description: United Telecommunications Inc. said it had signed an agreement with the Conrail enabling United Telecom to construct a fiber optic communications network along as much as 3,250 miles of railroad right of way.

title: LYNDEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A NEW WHO'S WHO TELLS WHAT'S WHAT IN WARSAW
description: A Government publishing house has just issued this country's first modern biographical directory in Polish, and an inspection of its 1,171 pages reveals not only who is who, but also who is not and what is what, at least in the view of the censors.

title: Elton John in Video For Sasson Apparel
description: Sasson Industries, an apparel maker, has rushed onto the air with a $5 million television campaign featuring the popular rock singer Elton John. The commercial, shot in Australia and recut in New York, is a rock video.

description: b-After a foreign exchange loss of $906,000. c-After a foreign exchange gain of $724,500.

description: b-Including a special gain of $20,000. c-Net income including a special gain of $1,773,000.

title: HEAD OF G.O.P.'S PLATFORM PANEL: TRENT LOTT
description: Representative Trent Lott, chairman of the committee that will draft a Republican Party platform in Dallas, has served as a key lieutenant in the House as his outnumbered party lost many legislative skirmishes while prevailing in some important wars. Mr. Lott, a Republican from a conservative Gulf Coast region of Mississippi, has served as minority whip in the House since 1980. Like a military officer, he has had to know as much as possible about those he commands and ultimately lead them into battle.

title: FOLKS RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: LEGISLATING WITH A PERSONAL TOUCH
description: Representative Cecil Heftel, Democrat of Hawaii, held the close attention of his colleagues the other day when he testified on an automobile safety bill by reciting his own experiences in a car accident.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture in Sports Pages on Friday with an article about architectural design related to the Olympics was incorrectly identified in the caption. It showed a new building for the Aerospace Museum in Exposition Park in Los Angeles.

title: FOLK MUSIC: VAN RONK AND LAVIN
description: ALTHOUGH Dave Van Ronk and Christine Lavin, who shared the bill at Folk City Sunday, were once teacher and pupil, one would never guess that fact from watching their early show at the club.

title: Sales Tax 'Felons' Assailed by Mayor
description: Discussing his administration's efforts to curb the evasion of sales tax payments by retailers of luxury goods, Mayor Koch said yesterday that store managers and corporate directors who encouraged the practice were the ''real felons.''

title: Justice Backs Reagan On Welfare Payments
description: A Supreme Court justice, granting a Reagan Administration request aimed at cutting Federal spending, has suspended a ruling that could have meant millions of dollars in added welfare benefits to thousands of recipients.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bill Madlock, the Pittsburgh Pirate third baseman, was to undergo surgery today to remove a broken bone spur in the elbow of his throwing arm and will be out for the rest of the season, the Pirates said. . . . Rod Carew, the California Angels first baseman, has been placed on the 15-day disabled list because of a nerve injury in his neck. . . . Roger Neilson will join the Chicago Black Hawks as an asssistant coach this season, the National Hockey League Club announced. Neilson is a former head coach of the Vancouver Canucks and Los Angeles Kings.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Chevron Plans to Offer $1 Billion of New Notes
description: The Chevron Corporation said yesterday that it would offer $1 billion in three-year notes.

title: VALMAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A MARKETING PLAN EARNS PRO TRYOUT
description: In late June, a six-page brochure, enclosed in an envelope showing a 7-foot-5-inch player palming two basketballs, arrived at the Knicks' office at Madison Square Garden. The brochure's outside cover bore an action photo taken at a game between North Carolina State and Virginia showing Chuck Nevitt blocking a Ralph Sampson shot.

title: REALEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PASQUALE FOOD CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in March.

title: RYDER/P-I-E APPOINTS CHAIRMAN AND CHIEF
description: Ryder/P-I-E Nationwide Inc., one of the nation's largest general freight carriers, yesterday announced the appointment of Jack E. Schang as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: LAUREL ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MONDALE, IN POLL, FAILS TO GAIN LIFT FROM CONVENTION
description: The political lift that Walter F. Mondale hoped to gain from the Democratic National Convention and the nomination of Geraldine A. Ferraro for Vice President has not materialized at this stage of the campaign, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: BOARD VOIDS HARDING PETITIONS
description: Raymond B. Harding, the former Liberal Party leader, suffered a blow in his comeback effort yesterday when the Board of Elections invalidated the primary petitions of his state committee supporters in all boroughs of New York except Staten Island.

description: b-Net loss.

title: Housing Agency's Note Offering
description: A $120 million issue of three-year notes of the New York City Housing Development Corporation was tentatively priced to yield at 7 1/4 percent.

title: EAST GERMANS DEFEND MOVES TO IMPROVE TIES WITH WEST
description: East Germany today defended the bid by Erich Honecker, the Communist Party leader, for better ties with the West in the face of mounting Soviet criticism.

title: KEYSTONE CAMERA PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net losses after losses from operations held for sale of $703,000 for the quarter and $922,000 for the 6 months.

title: REAGAN AND ITALIAN CONFER ON RED SEA MINES
description: President Reagan and Foreign Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy agreed today that there should be ''international assistance'' for Egypt in its effort to rid the Red Sea of mines that have damaged commercial shipping, a senior Administration official said.

title: Shell Planning Recovery Project
description: The Shell Oil Company said it planned a $250 million enhanced recovery project using carbon dioxide injection to extract an additional 40 million barrels of oil from two fields in Mississippi. The company said its Shell Western E and P Inc. subsidiary had given a contract to Humble Pipeline Constructors Inc. for a 94-mile long, 20-inch line to transport carbon dioxide from underground sources northeast of Jackson, Miss., to the Little Creek and West Mallalieu fields near McComb.

title: MINING SERVICES INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. Assigns Observers
description: The Justice Department has assigned 118 observers to guard against racial discrimination at polling places in seven Georgia counties, according to Assistant Attorney General William Bradford Reynolds.

title: RAYMOND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including net gains from operations and on disposal of subsidiaries of $148,000 for the quarter and $264,000 for the 6 months and equity in the earnings of an affiliate of $34,000 for the quarter and $328,000 for the 6 months. c-Including a gain of $20,981,000 on the disposal of an affiliate.

title: Town Halts Curfew Imposed After Rioting
description: City officials lifted a dusk-to-dawn curfew today but left intact a state of emergency that helped restore peace to a neighborhood struck by two nights of rioting between Hispanic and other residents.

title: Ivaco Acquires More of Dofasco
description: Ivaco Inc. said it had acquired 1.5 million more common shares of Dofasco Inc., increasing its interest to 5.5 million shares, or 11 percent of the total outstanding, from an 8 percent holding.

title: TEXANS DO THEATER IN A SMALL WAY
description: Where this city leaves off and the prairie begins, just down the road from a barbeque joint, there stands an amphitheater made of driftwood and junk. It is where Johnny and Diane Simons have for eight years made theater out of the legend, lore and history of Fort Worth, from real flying aces to a mythical lake beast.

title: Plant Startup Challenged
description: Nuclear activists and citizens groups today asked the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia to block the scheduled startup of the Diablo Canyon nuclear plant in California. Mothers for Peace, a San Luis Obispo, Calif., group that has led opposition to the $5.1-billion plant, filed a petition with the court for an injunction to stay a Nuclear Regulatory Commission order allowing the reactor to begin operating Friday at 6 P.M. Eastern daylight time.

title: PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE FOR AN AGING COMPUTER
description: THOSE millions of personal computers purchased over the last couple of years are beginning to enter middle age. A microcomputer generation is as brief as its prefix. After one of these computers has seen two or three years of use, cataracts begin to cloud the monitor, disk drives sag and a slight palsy of the keyboard sets in.

title: FLOUNDERING JETS PUT RAY ON BENCH
description: Darrol Ray, who has often been among the most exciting performers in football with his interception returns, was benched for the first time in his pro career today.

title: Dissident Is Freed in Poland, Insisting That He Is Innocent
description: Henryk Wujec, the last imprisoned leader of the Polish dissident group KOR, was freed under a Government amnesty today but said he had refused to sign a release order to emphasize his assertion that he was not guilty.

title: DENELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
Basque Separatist Killed
description: A shootout with policemen early today in the northern Basque town of Lasarte left a Basque separatist leader dead, the police said. No police casualties were reported. The dead man was identified as Pablo Gudepego, a leader of the Autonomous Anticapitalist Command, a wing of the Basque separatist organization E.T.A.

title:
MARKET PLACE;
MORE INTEREST IN NEW ISSUES
description: THE lure of new issues, or initial public offerings of common stock, waxes and wanes with

title: PENGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $8,236,000 for the quarter and $15,646,000 for the 9 months.

title: DATACOPY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SPECTRAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Joseph Ford, 93, Dies; A Founder of Brandeis
description: Joseph F. Ford, a businessman and philanthropist who was instrumental in founding Brandeis University, died Saturday. He was 93 years old.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CINCINNATI (NL) - Called up Ron Robinson, right-handed pitcher, from team's Wichita farm club. FOOTBALL

title: STAGE: URUGUAYANS AT LATIN FESTIVAL
description: WHEN ''Puro Cuento,'' one of the many theater pieces that are part of the Festival Latino at the Public Theater, begins, it takes a moment for the audience to realize it. Four men in street clothes walk in, looking like latecomers and speaking animatedly, in Spanish, among themselves.

title: VILLAGES FILLED WITH UNFAMILAIR QUIET
description: Ecaterina Szabo, the Rumanian gymnast who captured three gold medals in the Olympic Games, left the Southern California Olympic Village to return home today.

title: REPORT SAYS SCHOOLS SHOW IMPROVEMENT
description: '' OUR hunch - and that's all it was - was that in almost every city in the land there were signs that high schools were getting better,'' said Edward J. Meade Jr., chief program officer of the Ford Foundation. On the basis of that hunch the foundation began what it called its City High School Recognition Program two years ago. The idea was to seek out city schools that by their own testimony, corroborated by field teams, had already made strides toward better quality. If they could prove that they had indeed spearheaded what was to become a nationwide reform drive, they could earn a variety of rewards, in recognition and in dollars.

title: Poll Puts Reagan Ahead of Mondale in Jersey
description: President Reagan holds a lead of 23 percentage points over Walter F. Mondale in New Jersey, The Star-Ledger reported in Sunday editions.

title: Kaufman Sees Higher Rates
description: Henry Kaufman, the influential economist at Salomon Brothers, said yesterday that the recent rally in bond prices was not likely to continue. He said in an interview that ''as I look out over the remainder of this year, I expect an upward movement in rates.''

title: POPULATION PARLEY APPROVES A RESOLUTION AIMED AT ISRAEL
description: Over the objections of the United States and Israel, the International Conference on Population tonight endorsed a recommendation condemning the establishment of settlements in occupied territories. The vote supporting the recommendation, which appeared to be aimed at Israel, threw into doubt whether the United States would endorse the final conference report, which is expected to be presented Tuesday.

title: TRANSIT BUDGET REPORT IS REJECTED
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's finance committee yesterday rejected the Transit Authority's midyear budget report, calling it ''an unbelievable performance'' that was ''totally unacceptable.''

title: 3 OFFERS ON THE LOW SIDE, REPORTED FOR TIFFANY'S
description: Avon Products Inc. has received bids for its Tiffany & Company subsidiary from three investor groups, financial sources in New York and London said yesterday. But the offers, ranging from $100 million to $140 million, fall far short of Avon's $160 million price, these sources said.

title: TEXAS INTERNATIONAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting practices.

title: Just in Case . . .
description: With the Reagan Administration preparing for the Republican National Convention and the Presidential election, there is no rush at the State Department these days to make new foreign policy. But there is considerable activity in Foggy Bottom, anyway, according to State Department officials. This is because the department is preparing transition papers that would be used to brief a new President if one is elected in November.

title: Glenn to Stump for Mondale
description: Senator John Glenn says he will campaign for the Mondale-Ferraro ticket, but plans to limit most of his activities to Ohio because it is a state the Democrats ''must win.'' Senator Glenn, who dropped out of the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination in March, said at a news conference today that, while he and Walter F. Mondale had their differences, they were far less pronounced than those he had with President Reagan. And the said the Democratic Presidential nominee ''has changed his position'' on some of the issues.

title: Suspect Is Chased Into Police Station
description: A crowd armed with sticks chased a man into a Nassau County police station after he attacked one man with a bottle and another with a brick Sunday in Manhasset, the police said.

title: CHIEF CONSOLIDATED MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Pacific and Intermountain stock exchanges.

title: BIOTECHNICA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Falcons Keep Jenkins
description: The Atlanta Falcons placed four players on waivers yesterday, and Alfred Jenkins was disappointed that he was not one of them. The 1981 and 1982 Pro Bowl receiver is unhappy with the amount of playing time he has received since returning to the club after drug rehabilitation treatment last year.

title: Caesar's Husband One of Geraldine Ferraro's first promises as a candidate for Vice President was to disclose not only her own tax returns but also her husband's. Her financial candor, she vowed, would far exceed legal requirements. John Zaccaro needn't by law expose his separate finances, she said, but they agreed ''that any exemption from disclosure for him which might otherwise be available is outweighed by my nomination and its responsibilities.''
description: Now Mrs. Ferraro has retreated from her promise. Her husband's tax returns will remain private for commercial reasons. He wouldn't tell her how to run the country and she shouldn't tell him how to run his business. ''If you've ever been married to Italian men, you know what it's like,'' she says.

title: CLOTHESTIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
Soviet Ship Rescues U.S. Flier From Sea
description: A flier was rescued today from a life raft by a Soviet merchant ship after ditching her small plane in the Pacific 535 miles northeast of Hawaii.

title: PRESIDENT'S JOKE ABOUT BOMBING LEAVES PRESS IN EUROPE UNAMUSED
description: President Reagan's joke about bombing the Soviet Union was front-page news today in Europe.

title: BRIEFS
description: Corporate Notes

title: NEWFOUNDLAND TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Wild Applause Captures Diana
description: Wild Applause, the only 3-year- old in a field of nine, made her grass debut a winning one with an easy four-length score over older fillies and mares in the $94,050 Diana Handicap today.

title: MARGIOTTA IS RELEASED FROM L.I. JAIL
description: Joseph M. Margiotta, the former Nassau County Republican Party chairman, was released this morning from the Nassau County Jail in East Meadow, where he served the last two months of a prison term for mail fraud and extortion.

title: COLLAGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $189,000 for the quarter and $764,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $384,000 for the quarter and $1,123,000 for the year.

title: U.S. SENDS COPTERS TO AID THE SAUDIS IN HUNT FOR MINES
description: The United States sent three minesweeping helicopters to Saudi Arabia today to widen the search for the source of explosions in the Gulf of Suez and the Red Sea, the Administration announced.

title: Afghans Said to Bomb A Pakistani Village
description: Three Afghan aircraft bombed a Pakistani village today, killing one man and wounding five women, a Pakistan Foreign Ministry spokesman said.

title: SCIENTISTS FIND KEY BIOLOGICAL CAUSES OF ALCOHOLISM
description: IT is near the end of the cocktail party. Several guests are still talkative, friendly, charming and witty. But in one corner a woman is crying. Two men nearby are arguing, picking fights at every turn. Another guest has passed out. Yet another, who half an hour ago was happy and friendly, is now sick and depressed.

title: LUCKY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Including a gain of $5.6 million, or 11 cents a share, from the sale of 13 Memco Stores.

title: THE DALLAS BILLIONAIRES
description: For a while there, the oil men stood out among the entrenched old cotton, cattle and retail families who ran things hereabouts. Though nary a drop of oil ever came out of the waxy, black earth, Dallas, starting in the 50's, was the place to make the deals, stash the new millions, build the big house and buy up the sables and diamonds Neiman- Marcus was only too happy to supply.

title: Weirton Layoffs
description: The Weirton Steel Corporation said it would lay off 250 steelworkers because of a ''moderating market.'' A spokesman, Chuck Cronin, said that groups of workers would be dropped from the payroll of the nation's largest employee-owned company each week until the quota was reached, presumably by the end of September.

title: CHALONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: ELEMENTS IN BEARER BOND ISSUE
description: The United States Treasury is in a quandary. On the one hand, it seeks foreign investors whose purchases would help reduce interest rates the Government must pay on notes and bonds. But on the other, the Treasury does not want to sell bonds to foreigners under the rules that prevail in the Eurobond market - where bond issuers do not know the identity of investors.

title: THE VIEWER'S MARATHON ENDS
description: The last two or three days of the Olympics had been

title: DELAYED DISCLOSURE FORM ISSUED AMID INQUIRY ON MEESE FINANCES
description: The White House today released the 1983 financial disclosure statement of Edwin Meese 3d, the Presidential counselor, whose finances are under investigation by an independent counsel.

title: Sisk, on Disabled List, Says He Fears a Trade
description: Doug Sisk, still angered by his assignment to the disabled list, today predicted it was the prelude to a trade that would end his career as one of the Mets' premier relief pitchers. Sisk conceded that he had an inflamed tendon in his right shoulder, but insisted that he could pitch anyway.

title: OCEANEERING INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company changed its fiscal year-end from Oct. 31 to March 31. Year-ago results are for the quarter ended July 31, 1983.

title: RUNNING FOR COVER
description: The growing child abuse scandal

title: 2 BIDDERS AGREE TO BUY SCA
description: Waste Management Inc., the nation's largest waste collector, and Genstar Inc., a financial services, building supplies and real estate company, have teamed to buy SCA Services Inc., No. 3 in the waste collecting business, the three companies announced yesterday.

title: Campaign on Networks A First for Showtime
description: Showtime/The Movie Channel Inc. said it plans its first network advertising for its Showtime pay-TV movie channel next month. The company will spend about $8 million for a campaign running through November.

title: Of Art and Impulse
description: According to a somewhat abstract news release, the Hirshhorn Museum will seek to demonstrate that the art of the past 10 years has not been lacking a unified approach or an underlying impulse.

title: Jersey Casinos Set Mark for Earnings
description: Atlantic City casinos won $200.1 million from gamblers in July, a record amount, the Casino Control Commission reported yesterday.

title: Reinstatement Denied
description: State Education Commissioner Gordon Ambach has refused to have Henry Monaco reinstated as athletic director of the Yonkers school system. Mr. Monaco was removed by Joan Raymond, the superintendent of the Yonkers schools, after 17-year-old Fernando Guedes collapsed and died during the the opening game of his team's junior-varsity football season 11 months ago. Dr. Raymond's action followed the disclosure that the youth had had a history of serious heart trouble and had never received proper medical clearance to play. In his appeal, Mr. Monaco argued that Dr. Raymond's removal of him as athletic director meant he had been transferred outside his tenured area without his consent. But yesterday, Mr. Ambach, in announcing his dismissal of the appeal, said that the duties assigned Mr. Monaco since his removal had fallen into the ''director of special projects-physical education'' tenure area.

title: STAUFFER ACCUSED BY S.E.C. OF FRAUD
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused the Stauffer Chemical Company of engaging in a multimillion-dollar fraudulent scheme to overstate its 1982 and 1983 earnings.

title: TOWNER PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $502,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Officer Disarms Bomb At Los Angeles Airport
description: A police officer discovered a ticking bomb aboard a bus carrying the baggage of the Turkish Olympic team to the Los Angeles International Airport today and disarmed it moments before it was to explode, the authorities said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is a Catholic law on homosexuality. There is a Catholic law on birth control.

title: Harness Driver Denies Charge
description: Ronald Ingrassia, one of four harness drivers charged with keeping their horses out of the money in a race at Monticello last month, testified yesterday that he had given his best efforts while driving Worthy Scholar, a 9-5 co-favorite, to a seventh-place finish. In explanation of that finish, he said that Worthy Scholar might have been bothered by a wet track.

title: G.O.P. SEIZES 'GENDERLESS ISSUE' OF TAX RETURNS TO ATTACK FERRARO
description: Republican leaders opened a concerted attack on Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro today after the announcement Sunday by the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate that her husband would not release his income tax returns.

title: 2D LILCO LOCAL APPROVES PACT, ENDING WALKOUT
description: Members of the second of two union locals on strike against the Long Island Lighting Company approved by a 743-to-282 margin yesterday a contract ending the five-week-old walkout. The other local approved the pact on Sunday.

title: N.F.L. Names Blount
description: The National Football League has named Mel Blount, a star cornerback for 14 seasons with the Pittsburgh Steelers, as its director of player relations. The 36-year-old Blount, who retired after last season, replaces Buddy Young, who died in an automobile accident last September. In addition to acting as a general liaison between the league and its players, Blount will counsel athletes on career opportunities.

title: LSB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $473,497. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $23,730,652. d-Net loss including an extraordinary gain of $697,073.

title: CUOMO ADDS TO DEBATE WITH CHURCH ON POLICY
description: Continuing a debate with the hierarchy of his church over religion and politics, Governor Cuomo said today that there was nothing in Roman Catholic law that requires him to work to impose the teachings of the church on others.
