Cooney Bout?
description: Gerry Cooney, who has gone from legend to myth in more than two years of inactivity, is now tentatively scheduled to come back Sept. 29. Cooney has not fought since suffering his only loss, a 13th-round knockout by Larry Holmes, on June 11, 1982.

title: New Jersey Issue Has 10.42% Yield
description: A $70 million offering of 10 3/8 percent single-family revenue bonds of the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency was tentatively priced at 99 1/2 to yield 10.42 percent.

title: Nigeria Executes 7 Thieves
description: Seven convicted thieves were executed by firing squad in public Saturday in the southern towns of Uyo and Ikot Ekpene, the News Agency of Nigeria reported today. It said five of those executed had robbed a school headmaster of more than $7,800. The other two stole a taxi, the agency said.

title: Petrolane Stake
description: The Texas Eastern Corporation said it had purchased about 49.7 million Petrolane Inc. common shares before it terminated its offer Friday.

title: REAGAN: A THANK YOU AND A HUG
description: Mary Lou Retton - all 4 feet 9 1/2 inches of her - had the responsibility for putting a bright-red United States Olympic team blazer on President Reagan's shoulders.

title: MILGRAY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: Aug. 14, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ALTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MINOR-LEAGUE PLAYERS IN GLEN FALLS DREAM OF WINNING BIG-LEAGUE CHEERS
description: Midway through a recent game here between the Glens Falls White Sox and the Nashua Pirates, the home team's batter cracked a hard drive over third base. All 1,231 people in the stands were sure it was an extra-base hit. The umpire called it foul. The fans booed.

title: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW WITH FERRARO ON CAMPAIGN PLANE
description: Following are excerpts from an interview Sunday with Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro of Queens, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, aboard her campaign plane heading to California, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: NEW SEARS PRESIDENT IS REPORTEDLY CHOSEN
description: The directors of Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, this morning will name Edward A. Brennan, 50-year-old chairman of its merchandise group, as president and chief operating officer, Sears insiders and retailing analysts said yesterday.

title: Of Methodists and Lovers

title: U.S. RELATIONS AT ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13, (Reuters) Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, said today that the Malaysian Government's decision to force a touring American orchestra to drop a musical piece containing ''Jewish elements'' could seriously damage United States- Malaysian relations.

description: b-Net income.

title: Intermountain Bid
description: Plateau Resources Inc. said it had made a tender offer of $26 a share for Intermountain Gas Industries Inc. Intermountain had about 1.5 million common shares outstanding as of April 23, which would give the offer a value of $39 million.

description: South Africans Meet With Mozambicans

title: MALAYSIAN DISMISSES LOSS OF PHILHARMONIC
description: Malaysia's Information Minister says the New York Philharmonic orchestra's cancellation of two performances because of a Government policy against Jewish music ''won't hurt anybody.''

title: 'MAE WEST', 1982 DRAMA WITH ANN JILLIAN
description: THE runners, divers and gymnasts who have been paying tribute to the human body in the Olympics have finally left ABC television, but homage to the body lingers at the network with ''Mae West,'' a two-hour drama about the actress and sex symbol of her day. The program starts tonight at 9.

title: SCIENCE MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $15,000 for the quarter and $35,000 for the 6 months.

title: Small, Cheap Windmills Outdo High Tech
description: AN odd device that looks like an inverted eggbeater has emerged on blustery hillsides across the country as the leader in the race for the best energy-producing windmill of them all.

title: SPELLMAN BIOGRAPHY CLEARED FOR PUBLICATION
description: Times Books has announced that an editorial review has been completed for ''The American Pope: The Life and Times of Francis Cardinal Spellman'' by John Cooney, and that the book will be published Oct. 31, as previously announced.

title: TUESDAY, AUGUST 14, 1984 International
description: Three minesweeping helicopters were sent to Saudi Arabia to widen the search for the source of explosions that have damaged tankers in the Gulf of Suez area, Washington announced. (Page A1, Column 6.) Egypt said Libya alone was to blame for placing mines in the Red Sea. Last Friday, President Hosni Mubarak said he suspected both Libya and Iran of involvement in the mine laying, but yesterday he told reporters, ''I believe the Libyans did it.'' (A10:1-3.)

title: TEXT OF REAGAN'S ANSWERS TO AIDE'S TAX QUESTIONS
description: Following is the texts of questions and answers on President Reagan's stand on taxes, released by the White House Sunday. The questions were posed to the President by Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman.

title: SWEDISH YOUNGSTER ON RISE
description: The Wimbledon scene is enough to test the nerves of most teen-agers on the tennis circuit. An exception is Carina Karlsson, who was 19 when she stepped on the court at the recent Wimbledon for her third-round match. Yet her composure was due less to the strength of her classicly Swedish baseline game than to her relative inexperience.

description: President Reagan's decision to issue a new statement raising the possibility of a tax increase next year was made last week after he and his advisers agreed that public confusion over the issue was hurting the President politically, campaign officials said today.

description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $4,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net losses.

description: Reversing a lower court, a New York State appeals court yesterday reinstated charges against a reputed organized crime figure in a case stemming from the gangland-style slaying of two men and a shootout with a police officer.

title: Just Kidding The problem is not that President Reagan likes to kid around, which is usually an appealing trait. It's his choice of subjects.
description: When he gave the usual voice check before his radio broadcast last weekend, he said: ''My fellow Americans. I'm pleased to tell you today that I've signed legislation that would outlaw Russia forever. We begin bombing in five minutes.'' Nuclear destruction is not something most people think of as a fit subject for summer sport. There's no danger that anyone will take a remark like that seriously - yet plenty of danger that it will be misunderstood.

title: OUTDOOR FESTIVAL STARTS
description: From 11 this morning until the evening of Sept. 3, Lincoln Center's park and plazas will be abuzz with dancing, puppetry, mime and music for hours each day.

title: MISERABLE ALLERGY SEASON IS EXPECTED
description: Plentiful rainfall this summer produced an extremely heavy crop of ragweed across most of the nation, and an immunology expert says this could be one of the worst fall allergy seasons on record.

title: Digicon to Sell Interest to NL
description: Digicon Inc. said it had entered into a letter of intent to sell a ''substantial equity interest'' to NL Industries Inc. The company said the agreement calls for it to sell 828,000 common shares to NL for $4 each and 250,000 shares of 8 percent convertible preferred stock at $36.75 each. Each share of the preferred would be convertible into 9.1875 common shares.

title: KENZO TO DO INEXPENSIVE LINE
description: The latest development in the licensing of designer names by major retailers occurred last week when The Limited Stores, a specialty chain with 550 outlets around the country, formally announced its licensing agreement with Kenzo Takada, the Paris-based Japanese designer, for a new line of inexpensive clothes to be called Album by Kenzo.

description: New York City's subway system has been troubled in recent years by hundreds of fires that started in the same piece of equipment: an electrical switch box beneath the car floors.

description: Anti-Reagan protesters complained today that city officials had removed a sign the protesters had posted on a fence surrounding the hall where the Republican National Convention will be held next week.

description: Residents of Atlanta's near west side saw something over the weekend they had not seen in more than a decade: their state Senator, Julian Bond, working the streets and sidewalks, stumping for votes in the primary Tuesday.

title: Report Says Incumbents Get Most PAC Money
description: Congressional incumbents received $40 million in contributions from political action committees over the last 18 months - 83 percent of such donations, according to a study released today by Public Citizen's Congress Watch, a group founded by Ralph Nader.

title: Raxton Unit Sale
description: The Stop and Shop Companies and its Raxton Corporation subsidiary said they had agreed to sell Raxton's 30 Off the Rax stores in the greater Washington and greater Philadelphia markets to Dress Barn Inc. Terms were not announced.

title: T.W.A. SHAKE-UP EXPECTED

title: No Headline
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 14, 1984 Companies Waste Management and Genstar agreed to buy SCA, the third- largest waste-collecting company, for $28.50 a share, or $423.2 million. The companies said Waste Management expected to transfer to Genstar any SCA businesses that it would be unable to acquire because of antitrust problems. Waste Management, the No. 1 waste- collection company, has been seeking to acquire SCA for two months; other companies were also interested. (Page D1.) Stauffer Chemical was accused by the S.E.C. of a fraudulent scheme to overstate its 1982 and 1983 earnings by $31.1 million, or 25 percent. Stauffer, without admitting or denying wrongdoing, agreed to restate its earnings for a net decrease of $2.8 million. The company said, however, that the dispute was over accounting practices that had been sanctioned by its auditors, Deloitte Haskins & Sells. The auditors were not named in the S.E.C. complaint. (D1.)

title: MUSIC: 'PASSION' ENDS BACH PROJECT
description: The Pepsico Summerfare festival was wrong, probably, to bill the ''St. Matthew Passion'' that ended its ''Bach Project'' today as a ''fully staged version.'' That conjures up an attempt to make a piece of theater, even an opera, out of the work. What took place instead was an exceptionally fine musical performance with sometimes striking visual enhancements.

title: AFRICAN NORM: RULE BY SINGLE PARTY
description: When the stirrings for independence first swept across Africa nearly three decades ago, the response by and large from European overlords was that freedom be modeled on an image of Western democracy. The notion has not endured. In 100 coups or attempted coups, at least 70 African leaders have been deposed in a quarter of a century. Almost half the member nations of the Organization of African Unity are led by soldiers.

title: 2 Burned in Crash Into a Cemetery
description: A flight instructor and his student suffered burns today when their small plane caught fire and crashed into a cemetery while trying to land at Danbury Airport, officials reported.

description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $213,000. c-Net income including extraordinary gains of $392,000 for the quarter and $832,000 for the 6 months. Year-ago second quarter net income was equal to less than one cent a share because of preferred dividend requirements.

title: ENERGY RESERVES GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Coast Office Building Barred by Its Shadow
description: In the first test of a law passed by voters in June, the City Attorney has rejected a proposed 22-story office building that would have cast a ''substantial'' shadow on a downtown park.

title: Police in India Kill 3; 4 Others Die in Punjab
description: Three people were killed and four wounded when policemen opened fire today during a protest strike in Orissa State on India's eastern coast, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: 90% of Victor To Datatronic
description: Victor Technologies Inc. said it had agreed to sell 90 percent of its common stock to Datatronic A.B., of Sweden, for $28 million. The price is payable in cash and notes guaranteed by letters of credit.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some editions yesterday, on restrictions for reporters covering the national Democratic candidates, misstated a rule change. A prohibition on reporting or photographing the activities of candidates during campaign flights without prior permission was suspended for journalists traveling with Walter F. Mondale but retained for those covering Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro. Later developments are reported today on Page B7.

title: POLICEMAN, HAILED FOR DISARMING A BOMB, IS ACCUSED OF PLANTING IT
description: A police officer credited with disarming a bomb at Los Angeles International Airport Monday night has been arrested on charges of planting the device, police officials announced today.

title: T.W.A. Makes Changes In Senior Management
description: Trans World Airlines yesterday announced a major realignment of its senior management aimed at what it called ''improved responsiveness to the deregulated industry environment and greater accountability at all levels.''

title: BASEBALL
description: Doug DeCinces drove in four runs with a single and a three-run homer to back the combined seven-hit pitching of Bruce Kison and two relievers as the California Angels beat Detroit 12-1 in the nightcap to sweep their twi-light doubleheader tonight.

De Moines Man Sought In Boy's Disappearance
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is searching nationwide for a man described as a ''loner'' in the disappearance of a newspaper carrier. Federal agents said today that there might be ''a definite connection'' to the disappearance of another paper carrier in Des Moines in 1982.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: After being cheered by the multitudes in the Los Angeles Coliseum, praised by the President in a personal audience and treated to ceremonial exaltation in our nation's capital, America's Olympic medalists are to be honored by the City of New York today with the traditional tossing of tons of trash on their heads from high buildings.

title: BRIEFS

title: RATES OFF SHARPLY FOR TREASURY BILLS
description: Treasury bill rates fell sharply yesterday, with the three-month issue falling to 10.28 percent, down from 10.49 percent at Monday's auction.

title: ORTHODONTICS FOR ADULTS: MANY TURN TO BRACES
description: LOIS SEWELL had braces put on her teeth the same day her first grandchild was born. She was 50 years old then. Nine years later Mrs. Sewell, who is president of an electrical supply company in a Boston suburb, says she doesn't regret a minute of her year-long orthodontic treatment.

title: SKEPTICISM ON BASIC INDUSTRIES

title: CAMPBELL: PURE POWER IN A SOPHISTICATED AGE
description: The ball fluttered crazily as it descended. Earl Campbell, standing in punt-return formation near the 20-yard line, took several steps forward and waited to catch it. His arms were outstretched toward the skies, as if to say, ''Please, Lord, don't let me drop it.'' He was ready.

title: WEST GERMAN PROSECUTOR BELIEVED TARGET OF SHOTS
description: Shots were fired today at a helicopter as it descended to pick up West Germany's chief prosecutor, officials said. The aircraft landed safely and no one was injured.

title: FERRARO SAYS SHE IS HOPING SPOUSE WILL DISCLOSES TAXES
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, acknowledging today that she would not be able to fulfill her pledge to make her husband's income tax returns public, said that she wished he would change his mind.

title: FOUR NATIONS IN FILM FESTIVAL
description: The 22d New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center, beginning Sept. 28 and ending Oct. 14, will include movies from the United States, Australia, Germany and Italy, according to Film Society officials.

title: CONCERT: MOZART AND HAYDN
description: THE 18th annual Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center is drawing to a close and, with expert timing, the best material has been reserved for last. Too many of this year's programs have been devoted to curiosities and minor works by Mozart and a host of lesser composers.

title: Ayers Stops King
description: The welterweight Tommy Ayers, ranked fourth by the World Boxing Council, knocked Don King down three times tonight and scored a knockout when their fight was stopped at 1:12 of the eighth round.

title: Taxi Drivers in Dallas Hear Convention Pitch
description: Taxi drivers are usually a nonconformist lot, but if city officials have their way next week the cabbies will all be wearing Republican convention caps.

title: Two Are Executed in China
description: Two men who revived a quasi-religious secret society in central China and recruited hundreds of members have been executed, the Hubei provincial daily said in a report reaching Peking today. The paper said Wang Wenhua, 68 years old, and Zhang Congde, 71, were leaders of the ''Emperor's Group'' society, which was banned by the Communist Government in 1953.

title: Cocaine Hot Line in Nassau
description: Nassau County, responding to what officials say has been a sharp rise in local cocaine use in the past three years, has set up a confidential telephone hot line for users of the drug who want help and for relatives, friends and employers of addicts. The number, 783-0111, will be answered around the clock by trained personnel, according to Scott Maidat, co-chairman of Impacts, a consortium of drug agencies that will operate the program with county funds.

What, after all, can we expect, when we fail to enforce even the most minimal standards of international conduct?

When the New York Philharmonic plays in the city's parks, as it does every summer, the concerts become popular events that transcend music alone, abstractly considered.

Irving Penn Retrospective

About 200 black and white photographs taken over the last 40 years are included. Mr. Penn is noted for his advertising and fashion photography. Afterward, the exhibition will begin a two-year national tour, stopping next at the Milwaukee Art Museum in July.

title: Dresser Profits Soar
description: Dresser Industries Inc. said today that earnings soared in the fiscal third quarter, helped by gains in productivity and improving markets for its oil- and gas-related equipment. The company earned $26.8 million, or 35 cents a share, in the quarter ended July 31, compared with profits of $3 million, or 4 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 7.2 percent, to $944 million, from $881 million.

description: Bombs exploded in two Renault showrooms in Madrid and Barcelona today, causing damage but no casualties. The police said the bombings might be linked to recent attacks by Basque separatists on French businesses after a crackdown on Spanish Basque militants living in France.

description: In a new book on catching perpetrators of fraud against the Defense Department, Government officials are advised not to turn down an attempted bribe out of hand but rather to keep the person offering the bribe on a string and to report it right away.

description: The British Government official responsible for Northern Ireland said today that the decision to ban an American supporter of the Irish Republican Army in retrospect ''looks like a bad mistake,'' for which he took responsibility.

description: be it Hunan or Sichuan, Tex-Mex, Thai, Indian or Louisiana Cajun - has led to a surge of interest in cooking with hot peppers. description: A former Deputy Justice Minister of the Soviet republic of Estonia and his wife, a pop singer, have defected to Sweden, the police said today.

description: Japan formally notified the United States today that it was reducing import barriers against American beef and citrus products under an agreement reached between the two countries in April.

title: U.S. IS WEIGHING STATUS OF KAHANE'S CITIZENSHIP
description: The State Department has begun a review into whether Rabbi Meir Kahane should lose his American citizenship after being sworn in Monday as a member of the Israeli Parliament, a spokesman said today.

title: 7 MILES TO HEAVEN
description: Sometimes I go to the country.

title: YOUNG DRUG ABUSERS NEED OUR ATTENTION
description: To the Editor:

title: BARKLEY PRESENTING HIS CASE
description: Seconds into Monday night's game between rookies and the free agents from the Philadelphia 76ers and the Washington Bullets, Charles Barkley faked Joe Kopicki and shook the basket at Princeton University's Jadwin Gymasium with a crashing dunk.

title: PRINT JOB BECKONS WOMEN
description: -year-

title: Letter: On Archeology ; Protecting Undersea 'Digs' To the Editor:
description: In your recent remarks on ''sunken treasures'' (Topics item Aug. 3), you fall victim to the Indiana Jones syndrome that has afflicted public understanding of the value of careful archeological investigation of underwater finds of historic significance.

title: MCDERMOTT INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PIMM'S CUP, ONCE JUST POSH, HAS BECOME POPULAR
description: -In England the dark brown gin-based drink known as Pimm's has long been associated with summer afternoons punting on the river, weekend house parties with croquet in the background, picnics served by white-gloved butlers in the intermissions of operas at Glyndebourne, the members' enclosures at Ascot and Goodwood, summer weddings at country estates.

title: TODAY'S WAGE, PRICE CONTROLS
description: Wage and price controls are held in low esteem by our economic policy makers, who often remind us that ''they don't work.'' I find this ironic, since the strong United States dollar - which the Reagan Administration, through its conservative economic policies, helped create - has about the same economic effects as the controls that the President and his advisers oppose.

title: BELLWETHER EXPLORATION COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DEPORTED BISHOP FLIES TO PORTUGAL
description: The Justice Department said today that Archbishop Valerian D. Trifa, the 70-year- old head of the Rumanian Orthodox Church in America, left for Portugal on Monday under a deportation order.

title: 'ANATOMY OF A LIBEL CASE,' DISCUSSION AND DISSENT
description: ''ANATOMY of a Libel Case: Business vs. The Media'' is not so intimidating as its title makes it seem. Libel cases are at once extraordinarily simple and maddeningly complex, and one way of understanding them is to examine not what they appear to be, but how they develop. ''Anatomy of a Libel Case'' does this by examining a hypothetical case. The two-hour program will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 tonight.

title: Pacific Telecom Takeover Suit
description: The Justice Department said it would file suit to block Pacific Telecom Inc.'s proposed acquisition of the Glacier State Telephone Company and the Juneau and Douglas Telephone Company of Alaska.

title: Shop's Loss, Cook's Gain
description: For 15 years Bazaar de la Cuisine, the kitchen supply store, has occupied the same corner at Second Avenue and 53d Street. Over the years the store - which sells equipment as diverse as inexpensive plastic spatulas and big copper pots costing several hundred dollars - has built a devoted clientele of amateur and professional cooks. Recently the rent was raised by about 300 percent, forcing relocation to a place yet to be determined.

title: LET THE VOTERS SPEAK
description: WASHINGTON Pollster: What do you think of the election so far? Voter: I've been watching the Olympics.

title: Martin Galvin's Message
description: Restraining free speech is always risky in a democracy, no matter what the provocation. By ignoring the risks in Northern Ireland, the British Government set itself up for a disaster - as James Prior, the minister involved, has the grit to concede. He accepts full responsibility for what he admits was a ''bad mistake'' in first barring the entry of Martin Galvin and then ordering his arrest at the rally in which blundering police officers killed a demonstrator with a plastic bullet.

title: Cut the Debt Caused by the Debt
description: The cost of interest on the national debt has doubled in the last four years and the way things are going it will double again in the next four. The best antidote: Reduce the budget deficits that make the debt rise. Next best: Fine-tune the borrowing, so the Treasury pays no higher interest than necessary. It's time for innovation.

title: RETAILERS' SALES FELL 0.9% IN JULY
description: Retail sales slumped nine-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Government reported today. It was the first drop in four months and was viewed as another sign of an economic slowdown.

title: Trawler Nets Submarine In English Channel
description: An unidentified submarine dragged a British trawler around the English Channel, eight miles off England's southwest coast, for three hours today after becoming entangled in its nets.

title: VANZETTI SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: A Statue in Memory Of a Slain Leader
description: They are not even sure the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos will let it into the Philippines. Yet more than 100 Filipinos gathered opposite the United Nations yesterday to unveil a statue of the assassinated opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr.

title: SCREEN: 'DREAMSCAPE,' A COMEDY
description: ''DREAMSCAPE'' is an enjoyably half-baked movie, and if it were any less farfetched it would be less fun. Its plot concerns psychics, dream warfare and the mental health of the President of the United States who, as played by Eddie Albert, has been having nuclear-attack nightmares and is in a very bad way. ''It's beginning to affect my job,'' the President says. ''The man is falling to pieces,'' an associate later complains.

title: LEUCADIA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $646,000 for the quarter and $970,000 for the 6 months and tax credits of $1,570,000 for the quarter and $3,639,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $246,000 for the quarter and $594,000 for the 6 months and tax credits of $2,035,000 for the quarter and $3,534,000 for the 6 months.

title: ABOUT PHILADELPHIA
description: Visitors strolling down Market Street toward the city's historic district rarely pause for a second glance at a building complex between Seventh and Eighth Streets. Hardly anyone looks up at the forlorn rooftop sign on the north side proclaiming the presence of ''A Great Store in a Great City.''

title: MISCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOW REAGAN SPENT HIS VACATION, REALLY SPENT IT
description: Like the British Railway, which according to an old joke never ceases to be surprised by the phenomenon of Saturday morning, the Reagan White House never ceases to be astonished by August.

title: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 15, 1984 International
description: With U.S. minesweeping forces steaming toward Red Sea shipping lanes off Egypt and Saudi Arabia, there is still no evidence to determine who planted explosives in the waters, according to Reagan Administration officials. (Page A1, Columns 3-4.) A new Unesco-Washington dispute has erupted over $80 million in unspent funds, a quarter of it from the United States, according to diplomats. The money has accumulated in a special account that is used to offset the impact of exchange rate fluctations on the budget of the Paris-based United Nations agency, which the United States is threatening to leave next year. (A1:1.)

title: DAIRY ITEMS FOR THOSE WHO CAN'T DIGEST MILK
description: FOR years Hedda Batwin bought a quart of milk at the store, added four to five viscous yellow drops from a vial, then refrigerated the mixture for at least 24 hours. She had to pretreat her cottage cheese the same way and to avoid such foods as ice cream because of the severe stomach cramps they caused.

title: Seagulls Killed In Jersey Park
description: More than 40 seagulls died after they apparently were fed something that ruptured their stomachs, and a $100 reward has been offered for information leading to the arrest and conviction of those responsible for killing the birds.

title: SCIENTIFIC LEASING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NETWORKS ALTER POLICY ON OFF-RECORD REMARKS
description: ABC, CBS, NBC and the Cable News Network said yesterday that they would present new ground rules to the White House that would free them to broadcast remarks by the President previously considered off the record.

title: SEVEN ARE FEARED DEAD IN FLOODING IN EAST By The Associate Press
description: Relentless thunderstorms drenched parts of the East for a fifth day yesterday and threatened more flooding in the ravaged Appalachians, where streams swollen by up to 10 inches of rain have swept away five people and stranded hundreds more.

title: MISSOURI PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ethyl Estimates Lead Ruling Costs
description: The Ethyl Corporation estimated that it would have to make a $20 million to $25 million after-tax charge against 1984 earnings if the Environmental Protection Agency prevailed in its proposal to reduce the lead content in gasoline. The E.P.A. has proposed that the lead content be reduced to 0.10 gram a gallon effective Jan. 1, 1986, from the current level of 1.10 grams a gallon.

title: ASSOCIATED DRY GOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Air Express International Corp., Darien, Conn., has elected to its board Alessandro Caffarena, managing director of Fintrasporti in Genoa, Italy; Jack Leong, president of Mutual Distributors Ltd., and Anthony Low-Beer, an associate of M. Kimmelman & Company.

Sears Names A President
description: Edward A. Brennan, who joined Sears, Roebuck & Company as a salesman 28 years ago, today was elected president and chief operating officer of the nation's largest retailer.

title: Article 134284 -- No Title
description: Americans took on $7.83 billion more in installment debt than they paid off in June, the second-biggest gain on record, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: KANSAS FARMERS WIN $3 MILLION IN LAWSUIT OVER WATER POLLUTION
description: A judge has awarded 40 property owners $3 million for pollution of their land and groundwater by a salt company.

title: OLYMPIANS CHEERED IN CAPITAL
description: With a fervor unusual even for a city accustomed to patriotic spectacles, Washington heralded the American Olympic medal winners in a flurry of cheers and flag-waving.

title: Stolen-Car Driver Is Killed in Chase
description: A high-speed car chase with an off- duty New York City corrections officer firing his pistol in pursuit ended in the Bronx early yesterday morning with the death of the driver of a stolen car after he crashed into two parked cars, the police reported.

description: b-Net income.

West German Prices
description: West German wholesale prices fell nine-tenths of 1 percent last month, and were 3.8 percent higher than in July 1983, the federal statistics office said today.

title: MAY GAINS
description: Six major retailers yesterday reported mixed earnings results in the second fiscal quarter as booming retail sales began to cool off.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Seattle Mariners, at Yankee Stadium, 1 P.M. Jim Beattie returns to the Stadium, where he once showed promise as a rookie, to face Joe Cowley, the Yankees' irrepressible rookie of 1984, (Television - SportsChannel, 1 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 1 P.M.) Mets vs. Dodgers, at Los Angeles. As recently as a year ago, many Los Angeles fans were looking forward to the day when two portly left-handers would be together in the Dodgers' starting rotation. Those lefties will both start tonight, for different teams: Sid Fernandez, traded out of the Dodger farm system to the Mets during the off-season, against Fernando Valenzuela. (Television - Channel 9, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 10:30 P.M.) Soccer

title: POLLS' DIVERGENCE PUZZLES EXPERTS
description: Recent political polls on the Presidential race have diverged widely, and while some discrepancy is inherent in public opinion surveys, experts differ over the reasons behind the unusually large differences this year.

description: THERE'S a curiously dated feeling to Gene Wilder's ''Woman in Red,'' or at least a sense of dislocation: after all, lighthearted American comedies about men desperate to cheat on their wives have been more or less out of vogue since ''The Seven Year Itch.''

description: To the Editor:

METS' BERENYI STOPS DODGERS
description: Bruce Berenyi and Jesse Orosco combined on a four-hit shutout tonight as the Mets defeated the Dodgers, 4-0, and gained a full game on the first- place Chicago Cubs.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Aug. 15, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: NOTRE DAME MUST WAIT;
description: Drazen Petrovic , an Olympic basketball star for Yugoslavia, has changed his mind and will not enroll at Notre Dame this fall, but may play for the university next year, according to Coach Digger Phelps . The coach said he had received that word from the 6-foot-4-inch guard in Los Angeles, where Petrovic led the Yugoslav team to a bronze medal.

title: THRIFT UNIT TO REPORT ON OTUFLOW
description: The American Savings and Loan Association, the principal operating subsidiary of the Financial Corporation of America, is expected to report Wednesday that it recorded a net outflow of about $550 million in deposits during July.

title: Walesa Appeals for Halt To Protests in Poland
description: Lech Walesa said today that the outlawed Solidarity union was reassessing its role and that it would be unwise to stage demonstrations or provoke authorities after a Government amnesty last month freed hundreds of political prisoners.

title: City Manager Gets ARaisein Yonkers
description: The City Council of fiscally troubled Yonkers has approved an $11,000 raise for City Manager Rodney Irwin, making him the highest paid official here.

title: DYLEX SETS ITS SIGHTS ON U.S.
description: At Dylex Ltd., the Toronto-based specialty store chain that is part of a group that reached a definitive agreement today to acquire Brooks Fashion Stores Inc., employees joke that the company name is an acronym for ''Damn Your Lame Excuses.''

title: SUNSHINE MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $8,711,000 for the quarter and 6 months and a pretax gain of $42.9 million for the quarter and 6 months in connection with the sale of the company's investment in Gulf Corp. c-Including tax credits of $1,044,000 for the quarter and $1,929,000 for the 6 months.

title: Suspect in Greek Fire Held
description: The police said today that a man who had been seen burning rubbish was being questioned in connection with one of Greece's biggest brush fires in a decade. Firefighters backed by planes and hundreds of Greek soldiers and airmen brought the fire under control today, some 24 hours after it began. The fire destroyed 10 houses and more than 7,000 acres of forests and orchards about 30 miles north of Athens.

title: LODGISTIX INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisitions of Nevada Computer Services Inc. and March & Associates Inc. which were accounted for on a pooling of interests basis.

title: BRITISH AND FRENCH VESSELS ENTER SUEZ CANAL
description: British and French minesweepers and support ships entered the Suez Canal tonight to join an international operation to clear the Red Sea of mines, which have damaged 17 ships in the last five weeks.

title: Lynn McGlothen Dies in a Fire
description: Lynn McGlothen, a former major- league pitcher, was killed in a mobile home fire today, as was a woman who had tried to rescue him.

title: Restrictions on Mopeds Set To Limit Use on Block Island
description: Beginning Friday, moped dealers on tiny Block Island will be limited to renting the motorized bicycles to those who have passed a safety course or possess a motorcycle license.

title: REAGAN AIDE SAID TO CUT DATA ON DIET
description: A public-interest group asserted today that Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block had ''systematically sabotaged'' his department's nutrition-information programs.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about the stock market in Business Day on Saturday, and several tables in the section, misreported Friday's closing value of the Dow Jones industrial average and the trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange. The Dow average closed at 1,218.09, down 5.96 points, and volume was 171 million shares.

title: Issue by Xerox
description: The Xerox Credit Corporation is offering $100 million of 12 7/8 percent notes due in 1988 at a price of 99.6 to yield 13.005 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The notes, rated Aa-3 by Moody's and AA- by Standard & Poor's, were offered with a yield 43 basis points greater than four-year Treasury notes. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

description: b-Including tax credits of $61,000 for the quarter and $117,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $560,000 for the quarter and $740,000 for the 6 months.

title: DECISION BY MOTHER, 11, ON ADOPTION IS BLOCKED
description: Ruling in a case in which an 11-year- old girl gave birth, a surrogate said yesterday that a minor could not surrender her child for adoption without the advice of a court-appointed guardian.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday on the voiding of primary petitions for Liberal Party supporters of Raymond B. Harding erroneously described the office they are seeking. They are candidates for county committees.

title: Grand Old Souvenirs
description: Republicans gathering for their national convention in Dallas may make only a smidgen of news, but they are likely to do it in style. The National Federation of Republican Women, in a fund-raising effort, has commissioned a well-known Washington designer, Frankie Welch, to run up a colorful line of scarfs, bandannas, neckties and canvas tote bags to be offered to delegates.

title: U.S. AND UNESCO IN A NEW CLASH ON SPECIAL FUND
description: The Reagan Administration and the Director General of Unesco are locked in a new dispute over the return of $80 million in unspent agency funds, a quarter of it from the United States, according to diplomats here.

title: Child-Care Workers Would Be Screened
description: A State Senator said today that she would introduce legislation requiring the psychological screening of day- care workers to eliminate potential sexual abusers.

description: ''L.A. IS MY LADY'' (Qwest/ Warner), the new album by Frank Sinatra and Quincy Jones, is a pop event of some magnitude.

description: Morocco and Libya announced plans today for a union, apparently in a move to rival an alliance between Algeria, Tunisia and Mauritania.

description: Knowing about a void can be both interesting and instructive. Most of us have a total void in our knowledge of Chinese family life, and that can be remedied by reading a book published today by Little, Brown: ''Second Daughter'' by Katherine Wei and Terry Quinn. It is an exciting and readable account of Mrs. Wei's childhood in China in the 1930's and 40's.

title: BROOKLYN UNION PRESSES BID TO BUY LILCO'S GAS SYSTEM
description: The Brooklyn Union Gas Company, whose offer of $300 million in April for the Long Island Lighting Company's gas system was firmly rejected, is now asking the State Legislature to force the sale.

description: THE winds of change are rustling the vine leaves of Tuscany, and Chianti, one of the oldest wines in the world, may never be the same again.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THERE is, according to Ecclesiastes, ''a time to be born and a time to die, a time to plant and a time to pull up that which is planted, a time to kill and a time to heal, a time to break down and a time to build up.''

description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split on April 24, 1984.

YANKEES LOSE THIRD STRAIGHT
description: Just when the Yankees were making their most serious move of the season, they have gone and stumbled against teams whose low positions in the standings are entirely justified.

title: Weinberger May Visit Convention in Dallas
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger may attend the Republican convention in Dallas next week to listen to President Reagan's acceptance speech, but he does not plan to participate in the proceedings, a spokesman said today.

title: BENGALS GET TOUGH;
description: The Cincinnati Bengals, frustrated by their inability to sign their top draft choice, Ricky Hunley , have moved to increase the pressure on him. The team announced that it was withdrawing its latest contract offer to him and would refuse to trade him even though this would mean wasting the draft choice they used to select him in the first place.

title: STRUGGLE CONTINUES AT WHEELING STEEL
description: Two weeks ago, when the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation reported its first profitable quarter in more than two years, Dennis J. Carney, the company's chairman, spent little time in congratulatory backslapping.

title: The Governor Tells Why He's Not the Mayor
description: Governor Cuomo says that he never

title: ROSAMOND Y. CHAPIN
description: Rosamond Young Chapin, an opera singer and director of music festivals in the Berkshires area of Massachusetts, died of circulatory problems on July 30 in the Mediplex Nursing Home in Beverly, Mass. She was 89 years old.

title: CREDITORS WON'T EXTEND ARGENTINE LOAN
description: Reflecting increasing frustration with Argentina's unwillingness or inability to come to agreement with the International Monetary Fund over terms of an economic adjustment program, the country's 11-bank advisory committee last night informed Argentina that it would not extend a deadline past today on a $125 million loan advanced last month.

title: 11 Are Accused in 31 Fires
description: Seven volunteer firefighters were among 11 men accused of setting 31 fires in the past two years, officials said.

title: Gold Rush Ship Uncovered
description: The remains of what may be a sailing vessel from the Gold Rush era have been uncovered in construction of a wharf on the Sacramento River. The ruins were found in 30 feet of water in an area where up to a dozen ships at a time were moored in the late 1840's and early 1850's. Historians say the ship may be the La Grange, a 125-foot seagoing vessel that was used as the jail of this central California city and sank in 1861.

title: 2 Rebel Groups Agree To Truce in Colombia
description: Two major Colombian guerrilla groups said today that they would agree to a cease-fire with the Government this month despite a recent upsurge of violence.

title: Finance Officer At MGM/UA The MGM/UA Entertainment Corporation said yesterday that it had named Sidney
description: H. Sapsowitz, senior vice president for finance since last

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Long Island/This Week column of The Long Island Weekly on Sunday gave an incorrect date for a concert by the pianist Stephanie Brown. The concert is Saturday at 8 P.M. at the Fine Arts Center of Southampton College.

title: SOME IN NAKASONE'S PARTY SEE TILT TO G.O.P.
description: The long-governing Liberal Democratic Party plans to send a delegation of senior officials as observers to the Republican National Convention in Dallas next week.

title: CUOMO GOING TO UPSTATE COUNTY TO APOLOGIZE TO ITS 'ABJECT POOR'
description: Governor Cuomo will travel to a rural corner of upstate New York Wednesday to apologize for offending some of its residents in his keynote speech to the Democratic National Convention last month.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Atlas Van Lines Inc. , a transportation services concern based in Evansville, Ind., said it had delayed, until late September, the special shareholders' meeting that had been set for August to vote on its proposed acquisition by Wesray Corp.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: by Donat Gallagher. 662 pages. Little,

title: MSI ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOTHEBY'S CRITICAL OF ABRAMS SUIT
description: In a statement released yesterday, Sotheby's criticized the New York State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, for releasing, prior to a court hearing, legal papers served on the auction house a week ago. The statement also says that the Attorney General's position is ''based on a callous disregard for both the law and the facts.''

title: Japan and the Sin Against Whales
description: Japan appears ready to defy the impending moratorium on hunting whales, perhaps by accepting a committee's proposal to continue whaling in the guise of research. If so, the Administration is legally bound to retaliate by halving Japan's permitted fish catch in American waters.

title: GAF Holdings
description: The chairman of the GAF Corporation, Samuel J. Heyman, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had increased his holdings in the company's common stock to 1,157,825 shares, or 8.1 percent of the total outstanding. Mr. Heyman, who became chairman last December, said in April that he wanted to raise his stake in the maker of specialty chemicals and building products to 15 percent. He said a company he controls bought 117,600 shares between July 26 and July 30. GAF is based in Wayne, N.J. Its stock rose 87.5 cents, to $20.62 1/2, today on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: REV. ROBERT H. HEINZE
description: The Rev. Robert H. Heinze, a writer and former publisher of A.D. magazine, died of a heart attack Monday at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J. He was 64 years old and lived in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Bank Rates Still Stable
description: For the second consecutive week, average yields on money market deposit accounts and six-month certificates of deposit remained stable, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Prudential Shifting Top Management
description: A reorganization of the top management of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, the nation's largest life insurance company, was announced yesterday with the appointments, effective this fall, of a new president and two new vice chairmen. The company considers the ranks as equal.

title: UNINS STRIKE PAN AM, BUT COURT HALTS PICKETS
description: Some of the major unions at Pan American World Airways went on strike yesterday afternoon to protest a freeze in pension benefits, but hours later the airline obtained a court order against the Transport Workers Union, which initiated the action.

title: Transactions; BASKETBALL
description: CLEVELAND (NBA) - Announced signing of the forward Ron Anderson, a second-round draft choice from California State University at Fresno.

title: LONDON HOUSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
A DUTCHESS COUNTY CITY FIGHTS TO SAVE ITS HOSPITAL
description: A container on the counter of the Yankee Clipper diner on Main Street asks for donations to save Highland Hospital, the only health-care institution in this city of 13,000 people in southern Dutchess County.

title: PAVAROTTI BRINGS BRIO TO REHEARSAL AT THE GARDEN
description: It was Luciano Pavarotti Day yesterday at Madison Square Garden.

title: Four in Soviet Doomed In Georgian Hijacking
description: Four Soviet Georgians, including a former clergyman and a movie actor, have been sentenced to death for a foiled hijacking last November in which several people were killed, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

title: AMERICAN ENTRIES ENLIVEN EDINBURGH FESTIVAL
description: American participants, more numerous than ever before, have been greeted with considerable enthusiasm in the opening days of this year's Edinburgh International Festival.

title: PETROMINERALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GEORGE H. EVANS
description: George H. Evans, a shipping executive and arbitrator, died of cancer on Aug. 8 at Memorial Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan and Bay Shore, L.I.

title: LANGLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31

Double Careers, No Double Standard Antoinette Hatfield is bitter. After two decades in Washington, she finds that ''the wife of a public figure is a second-class citizen,'' unable to have her own career apart from her husband, Senator Mark Hatfield of Oregon. They're under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee and the F.B.I., she suggests, merely because she pursued her real estate business in the nation's capital.
description: To outsiders, the Hatfield controversy stands for a very different proposition. It illustrates that married couples may have separate careers, even in official Washington - but that it's up to them to keep their careers separate. Though the Hatfields say the news media would deny them this right, they made clear at a news conference the other day that the real failure has been their own.

title: World Nuclear Power

title: THURSDAY, AUGUST 16, 1984 International

Meanwhile, Egyptian officials made public new information that further appeared to implicate Libya in the planting of mines in Red Sea waters. (Page A8, Column 1.) President Reagan's quip about outlawing and bombing Russia became the subject of heightened official reaction in the Soviet Union. The Government said that Mr. Reagan's inadvertently taped remark before a radio broadcast Saturday was ''unprecedentedly hostile'' and ''dangerous for the cause of peace.'' (A5:1-3.)

Williams would not deny reports that he had instructed the pitchers Ed Whitson , Greg Booker and Craig Lefferts t o throw at Pascual Perez after the Braves' right-hander struck Alan Wiggins with the first pitch of the game. ''We had to show them that they couldn't intimidate us,'' Williams said.

title: Cuts at Amdahl

A spokesman for the Sunnyvale, Calif., computer concern said that the reduction would affect between 250 and 300 employees out of 7,200 worldwide and he noted that the new number would still be larger than the approximately 6,500 employees at the beginning of the year. In explaining the moves, John C. Lewis, Amdahl's president, said, ''We found many areas where consolidation of function, reduction in work scope or a general trimming of expense was appropriate.''

title: TIMERMAN JOINS ARGENTINE PAPER BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 15 (AP) - Jacobo Timerman, the journalist and best-selling author who was jailed, tortured and expelled by Argentina's former military regime, said today that he is taking over as editor of the Buenos Aires daily La Razon.
description: He said he also plans to restart La Opinion, the newspaper he owned and operated until its seizure by the military regime when he was arrested in 1977. Only a few details need to be resolved with printers before publication resumes, Mr. Timerman said.

title: G.O.P. TAX FLIGHT: BUILDING A PLATFORM FOR 1988 AS WELL AS 1984
description: After the Republican platform committee spent Tuesday pushing the party's campaign document to the right, Secretary of the Treasury Donald T. Regan called up in a rage. He told Drew Lewis, the chief Reagan Administration representative here, that some of the more extreme language on economic issues had to be removed. As that telephone call indicates, the party platform is taking on more of a hard-line conservative cast than some of President Reagan's economic and political advisers would like. They worry that the ideological activists who dominate the platform panel are writing a document that will not appeal to the centrist and independent voters the party will need to attract in November.

title: Interviewing the President
description: Mr. President, what a brilliant idea having me ask you a list of questions about tax increases and then releasing a transcript. We should have thought of that before. As your press spokesman, I know exactly what you want to say, and so this format guarantees that you get asked relevant and constructive questions. Still, the reporters keep asking . . .

title: REAGAN'S GAFFE
description: President Reagan's gaffe about bombing the Soviet Union has risked tarnishing his recent foreign policy advances and undercutting deliberate efforts by the Administration to put him in a better position in this area for the election campaign. In response to a formal Soviet statement calling the President's remark ''unprecedentedly hostile'' toward the Soviet Union, the State Department accused Moscow today of ''blowing this subject way out of proportion for propaganda purposes.''

title: Suave Shoe Loss
description: The Suave Shoe Corporation, in reporting a net loss for its third quarter ended June 30, said it was suspending quarterly dividends indefinitely.

title: V.I.P. Treatment
description: Mike Rozier , the Heisman Trophy running back from Nebraska, has two years left on his $2.6 million contract with the Pittsburgh Maulers of the United States Football League and won't be free for another deal until 1986. That, as it turns out, is the year Earl Campbell 's contract with the Houston Oilers expires, which helps explain why Rozier and his agent will be the guests of the Oilers at their exhibition game at the Astrodome Saturday.

title: OPTIMUM HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: EX-LEGISLATOR IN CONNECTICUT
description: Virginia S. Connolly, a former member of the Connecticut House of Representatives, died Tuesday at her home in West Simsbury, Conn. She was 70 years old.

title: STUDY FINDS PRO-ISRAELI PAC'S ACTIVE IN '84 RACES
description: At least 54 political action committees, with names that do not reveal their political purposes, have mustered more than $4.25 million to influence the 1984 American elections in favor of policies, appropriations and Congressional candidates that support Israel.

title: Georgia Power Raises Plant Cost
description: The Southern Company's Georgia Power Company subsidiary said it was raising the projected construction cost of the Vogtle nuclear power plant about 9 percent, to $7.2 billion, from $6.6 billion. Georgia Power, which has a 45.7 percent interest in the plant, said its share of the increase came to about $240 million.

title: THE SIGNS OF IMPROVEMENT IN TAXICAB SERVICE
description: To the Editor:

title: PROPOSAL TO RESTRICT FLIGHTS WELCOMED BY PORT AUTHORITY
description: A top official of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that the agency welcomed a Federal proposal to limit takeoffs and landings at the New York City area's three major airports and was considering limits of its own if the Federal plan did not materialize.

title: Aaron's Criticism
description: The Atlanta Braves have been sagging this year, and Manager Joe Torre has come in for his share of outside criticism. Now the critics have been joined by a Brave insider, Hank Aaron , the home-run king who runs the club's minor league operations.

title: AMERICAN PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: MIDLANDS ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results are pro forma. The company was spun off from KN Energy Inc. in December 1983.

title: Intermountain Bid
description: Intermountain Gas Industries said its board had unanimously rejected an unsolicited tender offer from Plateau Resources Inc. to acquire the company for $26 a share, or a total of about $39 million. Intermountain said that the price was inadequate and that the offer was not in the best interests of the company and its shareholders. In over-the-counter trading today, Intermountain was quoted at $25.50 bid, up 75 cents.

title: STAGE: 'PAPI,' AN ARGENTINE COMEDY
description: ''PAPI,'' a one-act comedy by Carlos Gorostiza, Argentina's Minister of Culture, played the Public Theater's Festival Latino Tuesday and yesterday and marked the country's first participation in this festival, now in its fourth year, which is devoted to the arts of Latin America.

title: Dallas and Protest Group Reach Accord on Signs
description: City officials and a coalition of anti-Reagan protest groups have resolved their differences over whether protest signs may be mounted on a security fence around the Dallas Convention Center, where next week's Republican National Convention will be held.

title: A POPULATION AIDE TELLS OF ATTACKS
description: The former senior State Department official concerned with population control asked to be reassigned from his post after ''a vicious campaign'' was undertaken against him by groups opposed to family planning, the former official says in a letter.

title: Hoyt Is 'Stable' In Cardiac Unit
description: Waite Hoyt, the pitching star who won 237 games in a 21-year major league career ending in 1938, suffered a heart attack at his home Aug. 7 and is in the cardiac unit at Jewish Hospital here, where his condition is listed as stable.

description: Problems at the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company should not be used as a reason to oppose legislation granting banks broader powers, according to the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Paul A. Volcker.

description: J. B. Priestley, the British novelist and playwright who attempted to describe the English personality through character portraits, often with sharp and humorous political overtones, died Tuesday at his home in Stratford- on-Avon. He was 89 years old.

description: Massachusetts communities can be sued for damages if the local police are negligent and fail to stop a drunken driver who is later involved in an accident, the State Supreme Court ruled today, 4 to 3.

description: Thomas Harris, president and chairman of the board of the Harris Structural Steel Company of South Plainfield, N.J., died of a heart attack Monday at John F. Kennedy Hospital in Edison, N.J. He was 88 years old and lived in Metuchen, N.J.

description: A medical team has helped save two severely burned young brothers by taking tiny patches of skin from their bodies, growing the patches into large sheets and grafting them back over the burns.

title: BETTER ROBOTS FOR THE HOME

He first walked it once around the area using a control box; the robot's rotating sonar noted the location of file cabinets, tables, chairs, water fountains and other objects.

title: Cool Skates

As the curtain rises before each act of the John Curry Skating Company, a cold fog wafts off the stage, over the heads of the pit musicians, onto the audience. On Tuesday night this produced several incidents of chivalry, as men draped their jackets over the shoulders of their chilly female companions.

title: 9 Die in Yugoslav Crash

title: Bridge:A Mixed Foursome Attains Unusual Degree of Success

title: HERS
description: MY husband and I bought a farm in southern Missouri a dozen years ago and started a commercial beekeeping operation for a variety of reasons, one of which was to shore up a crumbling marriage. That sort of thing seldom works, and after a few years, holding on to the affection that we had for one another and some shreds of sense, we ended the legal arrangement that is called marriage before we became enemies.
