description: Kuwait and the Soviet Union signed an agreement today for Soviet arms to improve Kuwait's air defenses.

title: Ameritech, Harris
description: Ameritech, the parent of the Bell telecommunications companies serving Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin, said it had named the Harris Trust and Savings Bank master trustee for its $6.4 billion pension assets. Harris, a subsidiary of the Harris Bankcorp, had served as trustee on an interim basis since December. Ameritech said more than 43,000 former employees received pension payments from the trust each month.

title: Nicklaus's Course P.G.A. Title Scene
description: The 66th annual P.G.A. Championship opens Thursday at the Shoal Creek Golf Club, a course that was built seven years ago by Jack Nicklaus. The 44-year-old architect, seeking his sixth P.G.A. title, is among the 150 participants who will compete on it.

title: 5,500 Athletes In Empire Games
description: Three days after the Olympic flame was extinguished in Los Angeles, a flame was lighted here tonight to open the seventh annual Empire State Games. It will continue to burn until the closing exercises Sunday, by which time more than 5,500 athletes from throughout New York State will have competed in 23 sports.

title: Boy, 15, Charged In Fatal Shooting
description: A 15-year-old boy has been charged with murdering a 13-year-old friend while they played with a shotgun in a bedroom of the older boy's home in this upper Westchester County village, the police said today. Another boy, also 13, was wounded.

title: Court Backs Fine for Bank
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit Tuesday upheld a $1.8 million fine for civil contempt against a Canadian bank, saying the bank continuously disregarded a court order to produce documents for a grand jury in Miami.

title: NORTH EUROPEAN OIL ROYALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Revenue figures represent royalty income.

title: Missile Hits Target in Test
description: A Navy Tomahawk cruise missile scored a bullseye with a high-explosive warhead on a building of warehouse size last month after it traveled 500 miles from a submerged submarine off the California coast, the Pentagon announced today.

title: OHIO PROFESSOR SAYS HE WAS SMUGGLER OF HEBREW BOOKS
description: An 82-year-old emeritus professor at a rabbinical seminary in Cincinnati said yesterday that he foiled the Gestapo in Nazi Germany 44 years ago and smuggled to the United States 59 rare Hebrew books and manuscripts, which were sold June 26 at a Sotheby's auction.

title: THRIFT UNIT REPORTS BIG LOSS
description: The Financial Corporation of America, forced by the Securities and Exchange Commission to revise accounting methods concerning $2 billion of mortgage-backed securities, today reported an unanticipated loss of $107.5 million for the quarter ended June 30.

title: EX-C.I.A. OFFICIAL TELLS OF BID TO AID PIPELINE
description: Adm. Bobby R. Inman, former deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency, said today that he was asked almost two years ago to help win ''United States Government support and approval'' for building an oil pipeline across Africa.

title: INVENTORIES UP 0.03% IN JUNE
description: American businesses increased their inventories by a meager 0.03 percent in June from May, the smallest rise in a year, the Government reported today.

title: QUEST MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Paying Off an Old Debt
description: Princeton comes to Manhattan tonight when 100 friends of Barbara Boggs Sigmund, the Mayor of Princeton Borough, roll into town to raise funds at Chicago City Limits, on East 74th Street. They are helping to pay off an $80,000 debt from Mrs. Sigmund's unsuccessful 1982 race for a United States Senate seat.

title: POLITICAL ISSUES SNARLED U.N. POPULATION TALKS
description: Delegates to the United Nations second International Conference on Population say the meeting achieved its goal of refining a global population plan adopted 10 years ago.

title: GOLDMAN CO-LEADER RETIRING
description: John C. Whitehead, after eight years as co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, one of Wall Street's most successful investment banking firms, announced yesterday that he would step down on Nov. 30.

title: KNOPF IS EULOGIZED AS 'GREATEST PUBLISHER' IN U.S.
description: Speaking at a memorial service yesterday for Alfred A. Knopf, the publisher who died last Saturday at the age of 91, John Hersey, who wrote ''A Bell for Adano,'' ''Hiroshima'' and other Knopf books, said:

title: Astros Beat Cubs For Sixth Straight
description: Mark Bailey drove in three runs, and Bob Knepper and two relievers combined on a six-hitter as the Houston Astros defeated the Chicago Cubs, 6-2, tonight to extend their winning streak to six games.

title: ELECTRONIC ASSOCIATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Arraignment Set
description: Otis Armstrong, the 33-year-old former all-pro running back for the Denver Broncos, appeared before a state judge today and was given a Sept. 12 date for his arraignment on charges of fraudulently obtaining painkilling drugs. Armstrong made no comment during the proceeding, but his attorney, James Robnett, said, ''His position is that he's innocent and has done nothing wrong.''

title: THE VOICE OF PRIESTLEY
description: In the autobiographical volume, ''Instead of the Trees'' (1977), J. B. Priestley described his preparation for writing ''The Good Companions,'' his lengthy first novel:

title: BYERS COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Five-Year C.D. Yields Explained
description: The high yields available to consumers on five-year bank certificates of deposit, reported in The New York Times last Thursday, surprised many readers. It even surprised some of the banks that were listed as offering annual yields of nearly 18.8 percent on five-year certificates.

title: CACHE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Save the Spad
description: Toward the end of World War I,

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Sonnie Mae Begins $244.9 Million Offering
description: First-time home buyers in New York who missed out on the low-cost mortgages available from the State of New York Mortgage Agency earlier this month will have a second chance.

title: Military Contracts
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company's Ground Systems Group received a $360.6 million multiyear contract from the Navy for tactical standard display systems for ships, the Defense Department said. In addition, it said the Army had given the Harsco Corporation's BMY division a $139.5 million contract for recovery vehicles.

title: U.S. SAID TO LAG IN WARNING ON CHEMICAL ATTACKS
description: American troops lack the proper sensing equipment to tell them if they are under attack by many of the chemical and biological weapons that could be used on modern battlefields, according to a National Academy of Sciences study.

title: CALENDAR: A COUNTRY FAIR IN THE CITY
description: City Harvest Fair at Floyd Bennett

title: A NEW WAY TO PAY FOR A HISTORIC RUG
description: A MICHIGAN historical society is reproducing a lavish Victorian rug and inviting the public to buy copies - the bigger the better. After a search of a year and a half, the organization, the Marshall (Mich.) Historical Society, has finally found a loom in Pennsylvania that can nearly duplicate the original rug, whose fading flowers and thinning threads have adorned the parlor of the landmark Honolulu House for 120 years.

title: Maryland Sets $139 Million Issue
description: A $139 million issue of Maryland general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 7 percent in 1987, to 8 1/2 percent in 1994, and 9.10 percent in 1999 through underwriters led by Citibank.

title: Fredrik Mundale, Dominick Ferraro The Democratic Party proclaims its devotion to fairness, and it's in the name of social justice that its nominees, who proudly proclaim their immigrant lineage, assail the Simpson-Mazzoli immigration reform bill. Unfairness is more like it. Where is the social justice in championing the cause only of gate-crashers?
description: One investigation after another has shown that the borders are out of control. Anyone determined to enter the United States can steal in, and it's inconceivable that this open society will ever hire enough guards or uncoil enough barbed wire to stop them. But there is another way. Turn off the magnets that pull people across the border - the jobs, however menial, that pay, to foreigners' reckoning, a fortune.

title: MALIBU GRAND PRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
FINAL TEST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BLOCKER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FLOOR CANVASES IN COLOR
description: HE had worked as a theater set designer, so when he wanted something for the floors in his apartment, Paul Kelly, above, painted what he called ''more contemporary and upbeat'' canvas floor cloths with latex paints. Soon he started taking custom orders for the canvas cloths, which can be cleaned with soap and water. Some recent cloths are a striped canvas, $425; a cloth with a squiggle design, $85; a runner, $250, and a brush-stroke design, $350. Mr. Kelly can be reached at 663-3713.

title: THURSDAY, AUGUST 16, 1984
description: The Economy

title: UGANDANS CHARGE U.S. IS SEEKING TO UNDERMINE THEIR GOVERNMENT
description: The weekly newspaper of Uganda's ruling party said today that the United States was behind an international campaign to undermine the authority of the Ugandan Government.

title: ANGELICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KAPLAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lewis Loses Silver
description: Carl Lewis 's performance at the Olympics was predictable - he won the four gold medals he had been expected to win - but when he got back home to Houston on Tuesday night, there was an unpleasant surprise waiting for him. While he was in Los Angeles, someone broke into his house, smashed part of his crystal collection and stole $8,400 worth of silver and video and audio equipment. Lewis, who has been working as an intern at a Houston television station, KTRK, told a broadcaster there, Bob Allen , that he was so upset with the loss that he was postponing a trip to New York and Europe he had planned to begin today.

title: AUGUST IN TOKYO EVOKES ECHOES OF MILITARIST PAST
description: The Tokyo police staged a riot the other day. Not a big one, just large enough to give officers a feel for something they are not accustomed to nowadays in this peaceful city.

title: Successful Rehearsal EndsFor Shuttle Flight on Aug. 29
description: A dress rehearsal for the countdown for the first flight of the space shuttle Discovery, twice delayed because of computer problems and engine trouble, ended successfully today three hours behind schedule.

title: HOW TO RECOGNIZE QUALITY FURNITURE: A BUYER'S GUIDE
description: THE growing emphasis on furniture styling in the last decade has tended to obscure the quieter issue of quality in furniture construction. Whether the style of a coffee table is Memphis, high tech, traditional or colonial, however, there are underlying considerations, such as materials, workmanship, surfaces and finish, by which to evaluate it.

title: FOR IRISH PEACE
description: The events of the past few days in Belfast - particularly the killing by British-backed security forces of an unarmed, 22-year-old Roman Catholic father at a peaceful rally on Sunday - are a compelling argument for an increased American role in the quest for peace with justice in Northern Ireland.

title: RETRIEVING AND OPENING THE ANDREA DORIA'S SAFE
description: THE Italian liner Andrea Doria sank after a collision with the Swedish passenger ship Stockholm 50 miles south of Nantucket on July 26, 1956. ''Andrea Doria: The Final Chapter'' is not an epitaph for the Italian liner, however; it is a film record of the successful attempt to retrieve the Andrea Doria's safe, a project far more interesting than it may sound. It will be seen on Channel 11 at 8 tonight and again at 2 A.M.

title: TONIGHT'S 'NOAH' FLOOD' A BIG COMMUNITY EFFORT
description: ''We've worked,'' said the harried but enthusiastic director, ''with about 800 kids at this point.'' ''We expect about half to show up for the performance; the rest have worked on the costumes.'' Joseph Janeti was describing yesterday the long-range and last-minute preparations for an enormous, multimedia performance of Benjamin Britten's ''Noah's Flood'' this afternoon at 6 o'clock in Bryant Park, behind the New York Public Library.

title: THEODORE K. BROIDO
description: Theodore K. Broido, administrative secretary of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, the central body of Reform Judaism, died last Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Citizens Party Candidate Seeks Entry to Debates
description: Sonia Johnson, the Citizens Party candidate for President, asked the Federal Communications Commission today to order the nation's television networks to include third-party candidates in televised political debates.

title: DATARAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Frigitronics Stock Jumps Frigitronics Inc. jumped
description: $3.62 1/2, to $31.50, yesterday on

title: Palestinian Slain in Camp
description: A 50-year-old Palestinian, Hassan al- Ayyad, was shot to death today in the Ain al-Hilweh refugee camp near this Israeli-occupied coastal town, Lebanese security sources reported. Camp residents said they thought Mr. Ayyad had been collaborating with Israeli troops. Leaflets have threatened death to collaborators.

title: DEMOCRATS IN BROOKLYN FACE HISPANIC DEMAND
description: An effort by Hispanic Democrats in Brooklyn to increase their representation in public office has caused further dissension in the borough's already- fractious Democratic organization.

title: SOME REFLECTIONS ON THE PHILOSOPHIES OF GARDEN BOOKS
description: ONE of the unlikeliest of all garden books is a science- fiction novel called ''The City and the Stars,'' an early and classic work by Arthur C. Clarke. In it he is imagining the earth about a billion years from now, with only two surviving cultures: a small country called Lys and a city called Diaspar. The people in Lys are gardeners; those in Diaspar are not.

title: CAMPAIGN FOR CABLE INDUSTRY
description: THE 43 million American households with cable television already know that cable offers a choice of programming. But, just in case the estimated 22 million homes that have access to cable but do not subscribe are unaware of the programming choices available, the cable industry intends to remedy the situation by spending $6 million on commercial television, radio and newspaper advertising.

title: COMING OF AGE IN TENNIS
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y.

title: PANEL OF G.O.P. CONCLUDES DRAFT OF '84 PLATFORM
description: With conservatives in full control of the debate, the Republican platform committee today crushed an attempt to endorse the proposed Federal equal rights amendment. The panel then also defeated a statement saying the party respected the views of those who support the amendment.

title: NORTH AMERICAN BIOLOGICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $8,000 from the reversal of a tax credit.

title: Country at Westbury
description: The country music star Lee Greenwood will perform at the Westbury Music Fair on Long Island on Sunday at 3 and 7 P.M. The country comic George (Goober) Lindsay will perform also. Tickets are $14.75, available at the box office and all Ticketron locations. Information: (516) 333-2101.

title: Free Musical Picnic
description: A free musical picnic Sunday from noon to 4 P.M. at Coney Island's Seaside Park will close the New York Folk Festival, which began last weekend.

title: IT'S NOT THE FIRST JOKE ABOUT NUCLEAR WAR
description: Amid the stir over President Reagan's remarks about bombing the Soviet Union, journalists and politicians in several Western European countries recalled episodes in which officials on both sides have light-heartedly invoked the capacity for mutual destruction of East and West.

title: NASA PLANS TO USE SHUTTLE TO RETRIEVE A SATELLITE
description: The space agency announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement with insurance companies to conduct the first space salvage mission in November. Astronauts on board a space shuttle are to attempt to retrieve and bring back to earth a communications satellite stranded in a useless orbit.

title: TEECO PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sugar Industry Objects To Ads for Sweeteners
description: The sugar industry filed a petition Tuesday with the Federal Trade Commission asserting that advertisements for the popular artificial sweetener aspartame were misleading.

title: Suntory Winery
description: Suntory International, the United States subsidiary of Suntory Ltd., said it had signed a letter of intent to buy all the shares outstanding of Chateau St. Jean winery in Kenwood, Sonoma County, Calif., for more than $40 million. The transaction is to be completed in October. The winery's management will be retained and present marketing and other policies will be continued, Suntory said.

title: ASTRO DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a writedown of assets of $5,645,182 and a reserve for future losses of $2,295,600. c-After tax credits of $197,000 for the quarter and $737,000 for the 9 months.

title: ELCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June.

title: ANDREA DORIA YIELD: WET SMALL CHANGE
description: The luxury liner Andrea Doria, which sank 28 years ago, yielded up its treasure from the depths of the Atlantic last night - soggy wads of dollar bills and Italian lire.

title: TROUT DEEP IN LAKE ONTARIO
description: Boat fishing for Lake Ontario's lake trout and brown trout has remained excellent all summer, says Ron Gervaise of the Salmon River Sports Shop in Pulaski, N.Y. He says that a few chinook and coho salmon have also been taken.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP
description: The bond market rose moderately in thin trading yesterday, recouping most of Wednesday's losses.

title: VICTORIA STATION INC reports earnings for 12 wks to June 24
Breland May Get $1 Million Pact
description: Mark Breland, the Brooklyn welterweight who won an Olympic gold medal, may be on the verge of signing a $1 million, four-fight agreement with ABC-TV, the network that covered the Olympics.

title: NOW SUES OVER SEX-BASED INSURANCE RATES
description: The National Organization for Women today filed a $2 million lawsuit in an attempt to prevent insurance companies from using sex as a basis for setting rates. The suit charges Mutual of Omaha with illegally overcharging women for health coverage.

title: Credit Officer At Continental
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation said yesterday that it had appointed Hollis W. Rademacher to the newly established position of chief credit officer of the corporation and its unit, the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company. Mr. Rademacher, 49 years old, was formerly head of Continental's Chicago and Midwest financial services unit.

title: QUESTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PEC ISRAEL ECONOMIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: OBJECT RECOGNITION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Another Tiffany Bidder
description: The Mouawad International Corporation of Luxembourg said yesterday through a representative in Switzerland that it was preparing a bid to buy Tiffany & Company from Avon Products Inc. Mouawad, a leading international jewelry producer and retailer, is owned by Lebanese and Saudi interests.

title: DALLAS TIPS ITS HAT AS THE PARTIES BEGIN
description: The Republican National Convention here next week may turn into one grand old party.

title: Sprinter Signs
description: Ron Brown, who won a gold medal as a member of the United States Olympic 400-meter relay team, today signed a four-year $1.5 million contract with the Los Angeles Rams. The former Arizona State wide receiver is scheduled to report to camp Friday.

title: Interpreters ; Man of Letters With J.B. Priestley's death at 89, a familiar type has all but vanished from the English landscape. The breadth of his competence established him as a man of letters, a term that now rings rusty and quaint. He was at once a popular novelist and successful playwright, a social and literary critic, a prolific journalist and a fluent broadcaster. There's still Robert Graves, but who else fills this niche?
description: Mr. Priestley was aware that he stood in a line reaching from the great Victorians through Bennett and Maugham, Hardy and Wells to himself and Rebecca West. Among friends he would remark sharply about the skimpy output of younger writers whose reputation rested on a few novels or plays striking a single note: ''And you call that an

title: CADMUS COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $285,000 for one- time reorganization expenses.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday on candidates' campaign airplanes omitted the most recent restriction on reporters aboard. The campaign of Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro has stated that all activities aboard Mrs. Ferraro's plane are ''off the record'' - not to be reported without special permission.

title: EUROPE REACTS MILDLY TO BOMB QUIP
description: President Reagan appears to have escaped with relatively mild criticism from officials in Western Europe for his facetious remark last Saturday that he had outlawed the Soviet Union and that ''we begin bombing in five minutes.''

title: Marcos Opponents Seek Order Restraining Police
description: The Supreme Court was petitioned today to restrain the police from using tear gas and truncheons against demonstrators marking the Aug. 21 anniversary of the assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr.

title: DISCOVERY OIL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HEWLETT-PACKARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BROADWAY
description: ACCORDING to Irvin Feld, the man who owns and produces such spectaculars as the ''Ice Follies'' and the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, his new production is going to be ''a lot different from what might be expected.''

title: BOARD APPROVES A CONTRACT FOR 2,500 BUS-STOP SHELTERS
description: More than 2,500 new bus-stop shelters will be built throughout New York City in the next two and a half years under a contract approved yesterday by the city's Board of Estimate.

title: MARY NOYES CHAPIN
description: Mary Noyes Chapin, widow of Selden Chapin, a former United States Ambassador to Iran and Peru, died Monday at her home in Washington after suffering from a stroke last week.

title: LASER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DATA SWITCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Rights Aide Quits Campaign
description: Francis Guess, a member of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, has resigned from the President Reagan's re- election campaign in Tennessee to avoid a possible conflict of interest.

title: CONCERT: PAVAROTTI PERFORMS AT THE GARDEN
description: SOMETIMES Luciano Pavarotti seems to be reaching out, in some great man-mountain gesture, to draw all the world into the embrace of classical music. Mr. Pavarotti's latest such venture was a sold-out concert last night at Madison Square Garden. The event was telecast live by the Public Broadcasting Service, with a repeat at the Garden on Nov. 16 also scheduled for telecast, this time on a tape-delayed basis in December.

title: Z&Z FASHIONS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MONDALE'S FOREIGN POLICY OPPORTUNITY
description: Where do the Democrats stand on foreign policy?

title: POLAND ASKS TALKS ON ENDING U.S. SANCTIONS
description: The Government informed the United States today that it was prepared to begin talks on the Reagan Administration's statement of intent to lift some economic sanctions, saying that it saw ''a positive element'' in the move.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: It's a Dog's World

title: I.C.L. Agrees To Be Acquired LONDON, Aug. 16 - International Computers Ltd. P.L.C., the largest British computer maker, agreed today to a $552.5 million takeover bid from Standard Telephones and Cables P.L.C., a leading producer of telecommunications systems.
description: The merger would create a company with 51,000 employees and total sales of about $2.6 billion.

title: ENEX RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMBLING ON SUNSWEPT CAPE MAY IN NEW JERSEY
description: CAPE MAY, the southernmost tip of New Jersey, one of those rare spots where the sun can be seen both rising and setting over water, offers a range of shorefront activities for the weekend visitor well beyond frolicking on the resort's first-rate beaches.

title: SPECIAL TREASURY OFFER DUE
description: As depositors inundated the American Savings and Loan Association with inquiries today about the safety of their money and made what appeared to be an abnormally high number of withdrawals, the question of a possible Federal bailout of the nation's largest thrift institution became the most pressing issue within the industry.

title: NICARAGUA CONFIRMS IT IS BUILDING MILITARY AIRPORT
description: Nicaragua officially acknowledged today that it is building a large military airport, as the Reagan Administration has asserted, and took journalists on a tour of it. Officials said it could be operational by the end of next year.

title: JAYCEES VOTE TO ADMIT WOMEN TO MEMBERSHIP
description: The United States Jaycees today overwhelmingly approved a resolution allowing women full membership in the all-male civic organization.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; ;  New Hospital Network Appoints Chief Officers
description: Two major hospital groups that have merged into what is believed to be the nation's largest group of nonprofit hospitals have named a former Arthur Young & Company health care consultant as its first president.

title: JULY STARTS IN HOUSING DOWN 6.6%
description: Housing starts fell 6.6 percent in July, to an annual rate of 1.761 million, the Commerce Department announced today, signaling that this sector of the economy is slowing down because of the rise in mortgage interest rates.

title: MOUNTAIN MEDICAL EQUIPENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NAUGLES INC reports earnings for 12 wks to June 30
description: b-After an investment loss of $843,000. c-Net income.

title: NICKLOS OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE REGION ; ;  Kean Aide Named To Post at E.P.A.
description: Governor Kean's cabinet secretary, Christopher J. Daggett, has been named regional administrator of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency for Region 2, which includes New York, New Jersey, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.

title: U.S. Olympians Honored IRVING, Tex., Aug. 16 (AP) - America's Olympic medalists were
description: honored at halftime of the Dallas Cowboys-Pittsburgh Steelers National Football League exhibition game tonight as they neared the end

title: BUCKLEY AND STATE DEPT. IN CLASH
description: Senior State Department officials said today that James L. Buckley, the chief delegate to the United Nations population conference, asked President Reagan for permission to abstain in the vote on the conference's final declaration because of what he saw as an anti-Israeli passage.

title: Assets of Money Funds Drop $540 Million
description: The assets of the nation's 340 money market mutual funds continued to decline in the week ended Wednesday, dropping $540 million, to $179.27 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: HOSPITAL UNION GETS TRIPLE FINE IN STRIKE RULING
description: A Federal judge yesterday tripled the daily fine against the striking hospital workers union to $45,000 for as long as its member nurses refuse to return to duty at St. John's Episcopal Hospital in Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: Budget Chief Assails Mondale on Deficit
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan today chided Walter F. Mondale for attacking the Reagan Administration's economic forecasts without producing his own predictions for Federal spending, taxes and budget deficits.

title: LIMOUSINE OPERATORS TELL OF DALLAS WOES
description: Limousine company owners were rubbing their hands in glee over the prospect of being booked by big-money, image- conscious Republicans at the party's 1984 convention.

title: TRAVEL-AGENCY DISPUTE STRANDS 2,000 IN EUROPE
description: More than 2,000 tourists are in Europe without flights home after a Connecticut charter travel agency said all its flights had been canceled and it was ceasing operations.

title: DEBATE ON RISK DELAYS MOVE TO CURB RADIO TRANSMITTERS
description: An internal debate at the Environmental Protection Agency over the extent of human health risks from broadcast radiation has delayed plans to recommend Federal limits on the strength of radio and television transmitters, according to agency officials.

title: INTELLIGENT COMMUNICATION NETORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Commodore Deal With Amiga Set
description: Commodore International Ltd. said it had agreed to acquire the Amiga Corportion, a small maker of microcomputers that rival machines made by Apple Computer Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: THE FORCE BEHIND REAGAN'S POPULATION POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: AUCTIONS
description: Some New Englanders will tell you that few attitudes have changed in these parts, from the time the first colonist settled down long enough to build sturdy houses until today, when newcomers arrive in vans, station wagons and an occasional Lear jet.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: WITH heavenly bread pudding bathed in whisky sauce, exotic sausages made of alligator meat, Pernod-flavored voodoo stew and crunchy okra pickles, Bon Temps Rouler has brought Cajun-Creole cooking to TriBeCa with a flourish. This two-month-old restaurant, whose name means ''Let the good times roll'' (a summation of the Louisiana state of mind), has been designed to look like a plain early- 20th-century bar-restaurant, an appropriate setting for the kitchen's unvarnished approach to cooking.

title: Blues at the Beacon
description: The blues and soul performers B. B. King, Bobby Blue Bland and Millie Jackson will be at the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 74th Street, tomorrow night at 8 and midnight. Tickets are $15, $17.50 and $20. Information: 874-1717 after 10 A.M.

title: RECOGNITION EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $685,000 for the quarter and $1,275,000 for the 9 months. c-Including a tax credit of $430,000 and a gain of $5,752,000 from the sale of land.

title: Boesky Group Buys SCA Stake
description: A group of companies controlled by Ivan Boesky, a New York City investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its holdings in SCA Services Inc. to 1,807,300 common shares, or 12.6 percent of the total outstanding.

title: Lewis Was Given Flag by Stranger
description: Let the games end right here. Paul Tucker, from Belle Chasse, La., says it was his American flag that Carl Lewis paraded around the Los Angeles Coliseum after winning the 100- meter dash in the Olympics. And if anyone wants to see it, they can come down to Gretna, La., where Tucker says he has it hanging on a wall of his frame shop at 705 Behrman Highway.

title: Deaths of 12 Kangaroos Laid to Parasite
description: A dozen kangaroos and three wallabies at the Knoxville Zoo, including five animals listed as endangered species, have died after being infected by parasites apparently carried by stray cats, zoo officials said today.

title: Bridge:Broadway Producer StealsSpotlight From Adversary

The 32-year-old Dent was signed after an arm injury to the Royals' backup shortstop, U. L. Washington , left the club dangerously exposed at the position.

title: TAKEOUT PICNICS: MANHATTAN'S REMOVABLE FEASTS

title: STAUFFER CHEMICAL

title: SCREEN: 'SHEENA,' JUNGLE ROMANCE
description: ''SHEENA'' is the perfect summer movie for anyone who's dissatisfied with the season's intentional comedies, and who doesn't believe in looking a gift horse in the mouth. Actually, it's more like gift zebra. A zebra is what Sheena is supposed to be riding throughout the film, even though she is instead seen atop a black-and-white painted horse. This point, which is never explained, may provide some indication of just how many bats ''Sheena'' has in its belfry - and of why it's the funniest film in town.

title: Not Just 'Women's Issues' ''I was never involved in women's issues,'' said Faith Ryan Whittlesey, the Administration's public liaison director, last year. ''Only when women get beyond (them) will they be drawn into the general public debate.'' Luckily for America's poor, 57 percent of whom are women, her opinion isn't shared by Representatives Barbara Kennelly or Geraldine Ferraro.
description: It was Congresswoman Kennelly, a Connecticut Democrat, who introduced a measure to set up a system for child support enforcement covering all families, not just those on welfare. The bill was badly needed: fewer than half the 4.5 million women awarded child support get the full sum, and nearly a quarter get nothing at all.

title: PUBLISHING: TAKER FOR FAULKNER ODES
description: THE University of Mississippi had little trouble finding a publisher for the latest collection of poems by William Faulkner to come to light. In mid- July, university officials said they were looking for a publisher, and now they say the poems will be published in a limited edition, probably next spring, by the Institute for the Book Arts at the University of Alabama. Gordon Neavill, professor of the history of publishing at the institute, said that plans are to publish 180 copies at $250 to $300 each.

title: THE HURDLES FACING PAN AM
description: Pan American World Airways faces a series of hurdles in its race to regain profitability after a $49.8 million loss in the second quarter of this year, in contrast to a $10.4 million profit a year earlier. The latest hurdle came Wednesday, when two of the five unions representing its employees staged scattered work stoppages after the carrier froze the pensions of 20,000 employees. A Federal judge helped the carrier clear that one; he ordered the employees back to work and service was normal again yesterday.

title: Jacobs Stake in Disney

But Disney said it would proceed with its $314.5 million acquisition of Gibson Greetings Inc. despite opposition from the group. Under California law, a shareholders meeting must be held within 35 to 60 days after 10 percent of a company's stockholders demand it. Mr. Jacobs said he had lined up the needed 10 percent.

title: QUIET! JOINT CHIEFS ARE PONDERING OUTER SPACE
description: Talks between the United States and the Soviet Union on outer space weapons this September are probably off. But according to Reagan Administration officials, such discussions are likely to begin early next year and the battle within the bureaucracy over what position the United States should take on the subject is very much on, with the Joint Chiefs of Staff in both the hot seat and the driver's seat.

title: A CELEBRATION OF OURSELVES
description: Outside the Plaza Hotel, a herd of chartered buses waited and droned. This was Wednesday morning around 10:30. And some 200 United States Olympic medal winners and their guests and various officials and members of the press were coming out of the Plaza and into the warm August sunshine and boarding the buses for the ride downtown.

Wrong Time, Wrong Deficit When President Reagan brushes aside all the criticism of his enormous budget deficits, he's speaking from political flexibility rather than economic conviction. It's Mr. Reagan, after all, who used to serve up the homilies about fiscal irresponsibility - and who still calls, without embarrassment, for a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution.
description: But when respected mainstream economists like Robert Eisner of Northwestern University suggest that deficits may not be so bad, all that criticism is worth a second look. He offers no defense for the Administration's current course. But he does make clear that deficits can't be analyzed outside the context of their times.

description: The tiny, windowless polygraph room in the Bronx District Attorney's office has temporarily been turned into a playroom. There are no pictures on the cream-colored walls, and the linoleum floors are cold, but the polygraph equipment has been moved out and a shopping bag full of toys, a doll house and a child's desk moved in.

He is the seventh employee of a city-financed day-care center to be arrested and charged with sexual abuse in recent months.

title: Soviet Bloc Plans Exercises
description: The Warsaw Pact will hold military maneuvers involving 60,000 men in Czechoslovakia early next month, the official press agency Tass said today. The manuevers, called ''Shield 84,'' are aimed at ''practicing cooperation between staffs and forces of the allied armies during the conduct of joint combat operations,'' Tass said. Moscow has been giving advance notice of most major land exercises under the 1975 Helsinki accords on European security.

title: STUDY OF VIETNAM VETERANS FINDS NO INCREASED RISK OF BIRTH DEFECTS
description: The largest medical study of Vietnam veterans yet undertaken concludes that they appear to have no increased risk of fathering children with general birth defects, Government scientists reported today.

There is no strong favorite and plenty of potential for an upset. The entry of Track Barron and Vision was made the 9-to-5 choice on the early line, but Carr de Naskra, 2-1, and Big Pistol, 5-2, won't be far behind in the betting.

title: LINCOLN CENTER AND OTHER SITES WITH TIMETABLES
description: WEEKENDS in the summer, New York puts forth many faces. Some reflect summer sloth. Others sparkle with an urban charm visible only when days are long and nights are gentle. It is in summer that theater and dance move into the streets, like most New Yorkers. Performers may be found on most street corners, playing to the casual passer-by. But there's scheduled entertainment, too, for those who prefer the relative comfort of a folding chair or a bleacher seat in some green spot where a play's about to start.

title: FRIDAY, AUGUST 17, 1984 International
description: President Reagan assured a group of Jewish leaders at the White House that he was ''not going to bomb Russia in the next five minutes,'' according to a participant at the meeting. The comment appeared to be an attempt by Mr. Reagan to make light of an inadvertently taped quip that provoked criticism by Western European newspapers and denunciations by the Kremlin. title: FILM: 'TIGHTROPE,' NEW CLINT EASTWOOD THRILLER
description: CLINT EASTWOOD turns kinky in ''Tightrope,'' playing a police inspector investigating a string of sex crimes and succumbing to the wiles of some of the prostitutes he questions. But it's only a temporary aberration. For the most part, ''Tightrope'' is a crisp thriller that is essentially faithful to the ''Dirty Harry'' formula, notwithstanding its attempts to give Mr. Eastwood's character what the production notes call ''an added dimension of complexity.'' Kinks or no kinks, Mr. Eastwood does his usual turn as the most hard-boiled, relentless detective in town.

title: Congressional Cake

Fatemi (aide to Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware) and Nancy Blades (of the staff of Representative James J. Howard of New Jersey) to be held Sunday up in Princeton, N.J., the Bella Palermo Pastry Shop and Cafe of Elizabeth, N.J., has really outdone itself.

title: CAROL WOODS JOINS 2 STYLES IN TRIBUTE TO SAMMY DAVIS
description: CAROL WOODS'S tribute to Sammy Davis Jr., which plays at Michael's Pub through tomorrow night, is an example of how two divergent musical traditions can refresh each other in unexpected ways. Sung and narrated by Miss Woods, the Queens gospel singer who has appeared in the Off-Broadway musicals ''One Mo' Time'' and ''Taking My Turn,'' the show is a biographical tribute to a performer who seems more in the Las Vegas corner of show business than in Miss Woods's gospel-blues terrain.

Several times during the meal Enzo walked over and just stood near our table, beaming.

title: THE CITY ; ;  7 People Burned In L.I. Boat Fire
description: Seven people were burned, one of them severely, when a boat owned by a Queens man caught fire in Great Peconic Bay, the Coast Guard said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY ;  SATURDAY, AUGUST 18, 1984 International
description: The Yalta agreement was attacked by President Reagan, who said the United States could not passively accept ''the permanent subjugation of the people of Eastern Europe.'' At a White House luncheon commemorating the 40th anniversary of the Warsaw rising against Nazi troops, he said the United States ''rejects any interpretation of the Yalta agreement that suggests American consent for the division of Europe into spheres of influence,'' and that he would ''press for full compliance'' with the agreement, specifically its stipulation on free elections. (Page 1, Column 1.) Peru has taken tougher action against guerrillas, according to military and police sources. They say a more severe and systematic strategy involves military and psychological tactics and includes the use of terror as a dissuasive method and the formation of antiguerrilla peasant militias. Peruvian judicial and church sources say the army and police are increasingly resorting to kidnappings, torture and executions of civilians in their fight. (1:1.)

title: INTERIOR DEPT. REVISING RULES ON LAND LEASES
description: The Reagan Administration has unveiled revised coal leasing procedures to give new life to the Interior Department's plans to offer large tracts of Federal land for mining and development.

title: ROOKIES OPPOSITE KLECKO, GASTINEAU
description: The regular season is a little more than two weeks away, but for Karl Nelson and William Roberts, things won't get more regular than Saturday night when the Giants and the Jets meet at Giants Stadium.

title: SOCCER LEAGUES UNABLE TO AGREE
description: Professional soccer took another short step backward yesterday when the Major Indoor Soccer League and the North American Soccer League failed to reach an agreement that would have allowed five N.A.S.L. teams to compete in the indoor league this winter.

description: Nancy Andersen, a member of the jury that acquitted John Z. DeLorean of drug trafficking Thursday, said today that if he ''had been a less influential person, there wouldn't have been a case against him - they went after him because of who he was.''

description: The financially troubled Long Island Lighting Company said yesterday that it earned $80.7 million in the second quarter, but that 94.9 percent of the total represented ''noncash'' - or what Lilco called an ''allowance for funds used during construction.''

title: Japan Rightists Seize Judge
description: Two right-wing gunmen seized a judge outside his courthouse and held him captive for three and a half hours today before surrendering to 200 riot policemen and setting the judge free. The police said the two were angered by the judge's decision last month expelling them from their headquarters at the request of the landlord and forcing them to remove anti-Soviet billboards.

title: John French, 75, Dies; A Retired Law Partner
description: John French, a retired partner in the Manhattan law firm of Curtis, Mallet- Prevost, Colt & Mosle, died of a heart attack Wednesday while hiking near Jackson Hole, Wyo., with his wife. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan and Woodstock, Vt.

description: The Republican platform committee today tentatively adopted a preamble asserting that American voters face a choice ''between two diametrically opposed visions of what America should be.''

description: Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta expressed exasperation with Walter F. Mondale's campaign advisers today, calling them ''smart-assed white boys'' who refused to take advice.

title: DAKOTA WATER PROJECT: GIVEAWAY OR BLESSING?
description: A taxpayers' group calls it the giveaway of the century. Environmentalists call it a frontal attack on some of the country's last unspoiled prairie breeding grounds for waterfowl. But farmers and business owners in this North Dakota town call it the only thing between them and ruin.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Rates Are Little Changed ; ;  A Quiet Day For Trading
description: Interest rates were little changed yesterday in quiet trading. Moderate investor demand the past two days has nibbled away at securities dealers' holdings of the $16.75 billion of Treasury notes and bonds auctioned last week and helped raise prices.

title: Swedish Production
description: Sweden's industrial production dropped a seasonally adjusted 1.8 percent in June from May, but output was up 7 percent from June 1983, the Government said today. In the second quarter, production rose 7 percent from the period a year earlier, the report said. Over six months, production rose a seasonably adjusted 8.1 percent from the year before, it said.

title: Greenwood Concert Put Off
description: The performance of the country music entertainer Lee Greenwood at the Westbury Music Fair on Long Island, originally scheduled for Sunday, has been postponed to Dec. 2.

title: Government Seizes Ship That Struck Coral Reef
description: Divers surveyed damage to Molasses Reef today after Federal agents seized a 5,900-ton freighter that slammed into the delicate coral ridge two weeks ago.

title: MALAYSIAN OFFICIAL DEFENDS POSITION ON PHILHARMONIC
description: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, in his first public comment on a controversy involving the New York Philharmonic Orchestra, said today that Malaysia must put the feelings of its citizens over those of others.

title: RIDER DIES, 44 HURT IN CHICAGO RAILS
description: Two subway trains collided and two of their cars derailed in the evening rush hour today at a station on the city's Northwest Side, killing one person and injuring 44, the authorities said.

title: Soviet-bloc Athletes Thrive
description: Irina Meszynski of East Germany set a world record in the women's discus throw in Prague, and Soviet-bloc men's field athletes here bettered many of the Los Angeles Olympic winning performances today in the multi-city Friendship-84 Games.

title: Farewell to Racing
description: Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney , whose blue and brown silks have been carried to victory by numerous thoroughbred champions over the last 50 years, announced yesterday that he was retiring from the sport and would sell his 26-horse racing stable at a dispersal sale in Kentucky this fall. Whitney, who is 85 years old, said he would keep his Kentucky breeding farm in operation. Whitney's best horses have included First Flight, Phalanx, Counterpoint, Silver Spoon and Silver Buck.

'Insinuendo'
description: Governor Cuomo of New York was in Washington early in the week, and among things he is reported to have said privately was that no great political damage would come to the Mondale-Ferraro ticket because of criticism of the Vice- Presidential nominee, Geraldine A. Ferraro, on the matter of disclosing or not disclosing her husband's income tax returns. Mr. Cuomo told friends and acquaintances that the attacks on Mrs. Ferraro on the disclosure issue reminded him of Republican tactics in his home borough of Queens. He said such tactics were known as ''insinuendo.''

U.N. CONDEMNS SOUTH AFRICA OVER ITS PLAN FOR PARLIAMENT
description: The Security Council voted approval today of a resolution that ''strongly rejects and declares as null and void'' constitutional changes proposed by South Africa.

title: Stung by John DeLorean John DeLorean, rejoicing in his acquittal on cocaine charges, says he hopes the verdict will lead to changes in the law so that the Government can't entrap others into committing crimes they would not otherwise consider. Attorney General William French Smith, asked about the loss of his biggest case, says ''an acquittal in one case will not affect our use of undercover operations.''
description: Both men misread the lessons of the celebrated case. The law on entrapment worked pretty well for Mr. DeLorean. It got him off despite reels of videotape showing him deep in drug deals and admiring a 55-pound cache of cocaine as ''better than gold.'' And if Mr. Smith means there'll be no change in Government ''sting'' operations, he's learned no lesson at all.

title: Poorer Poor, and More of Them President Reagan keeps insisting that his economic and budget policies have not harmed the poor. But his assertions are not supported by the evidence. A variety of recent assessments show that the poor have gotten poorer - and that there are a lot more of them.
description: Now the Urban Institute, a distinguished Washington think tank, adds its voice to that conclusion in a report called ''The Reagan Record.''

description: Ever since Geraldine A. Ferraro reversed her pledge to release her husband's income tax returns last Sunday, Walter F. Mondale has tried to maintain a studied public distance from the sensitive situation. Mr. Mondale said that his aides had gone over the couple's financial records once before, when Mrs. Ferraro was being considered, and everything seemed fine.

title: Seoul Vehicle Exports

description: The modern Italian game of bocce was supposedly derived from the old English game of bowls, or lawn bowling, although the fact that both are variations of rolling ball games played in ancient Egypt creates just enough confusion to salvage national pride.

title: U.S. MILITARY SCHOOL TO QUIT PANAMA
description: The United States Southern Command has announced that it will close its School of the Americas in Panama on Sept. 30 after a 38-year history during which 44,000 Latin American military officers were trained.

description: Tommie Aaron, the younger brother of Henry Aaron, baseball's home-run leader, died of leukemia at Emory University Hospital Thursday. He was 45 years old and had served on the Atlanta Braves' coaching staff since 1978.

title: Judge in Minnesota Censured by State Court
description: The State Supreme Court today censured a municipal judge who referred to female attorneys as ''lawyerettes,'' was intoxicated in public and was habitually tardy for court sessions.

title: YALTA, AFTER 4 DECADES, IS STILL A DISPUTED TOPIC
description: In the four decades since Roosevelt, Churchill and Stalin secretly met near the Black Sea resort of Yalta, the meeting and its aftermath have been debated by historians and politicians.

title: THE CONSUMER CO-OP ENTERS A NEW AGE

The former, he said, were in trouble. He hoped the latter might help save them.

description: Wally Backman hit a home run for the first time in two years tonight, and he did it in the 10th inning of a scoreless game to power the Mets to a 2-0 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

description: John Z. DeLorean, who was acquitted Thursday of Federal drug charges, still faces an assortment of legal problems related to his financial conduct in the defunct DeLorean Motor Company and other business ventures.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: SIGHT TO SEE It is now three months since the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, re-opened to the public, a reborn architectural wonder that has ever since been drawing throngs to marvel, if not at the art, at least at the building. The museum is still drawing a daily press of visitors that makes the lobby seem more like an airline terminal than a temple of the arts. But the overpowering crush that marked those first days is now somewhat modified.

title: ECHOES OF THE OLYMPICS RESOUND IN THE EMPIRE STATE GAMES

description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, his 17- year-old son, Patrick, and a Cape Cod plumber were slightly injured this afternoon in a two-vehicle collision near the Kennedy compound.

title: ACRO ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sohio Buyback
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said its offer to buy back 11 million of its common shares for $47.50 each had been oversubscribed, with about 22.9 million shares being tendered.

title: SHRIVER AND GARRISON GAIN
description: For Pam Shriver and Zina Garrison, it was a day to recall the frustrations of youth.

title: ABC ADMONISHES STAFF ABOUT DELOREAN JURORS
description: The ABC network has warned the staff of its ''Good Morning America'' program against repetition of an incident last week in which a staff member for the program contacted the families of six jurors who were deliberating a verdict in the trial of John Z. DeLorean on drug-trafficking charges.

title: Hancock Textile
description: The Hancock Textile Company plans to acquire Minnesota Fabrics Inc. under an agreement in principle announced by the companies.

title: TECHAMERICA GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: STATE COUNCIL DOUBLES ITS GRANTS
description: ADRAMATIC last-minute increase in the 1985 budget for the State Council on the Arts has permitted that agency to double the amount available for grants in the crafts.

title: FOR ARMSTRONG, PAINS ARE LINGERING
description: DENVER EARLY last Wednesday morning, Otis Armstrong stood silent and motionless at a hearing in a Denver district court, listening to a judge explain the felony charges against him. Armstrong looked timid and scared, a far cry from the bold and powerful running back he was for the Denver Broncos through most of the 1970's.

title: PRISON CROWDING ON TRENTON AGENDA
description: TRENTON WHEN they return here next month, legislators will have to face an issue that their predecessors and their predecessors' predecessors have wrestled with and that has been made more pressing by recent events - prison overcrowding.

title: LABOR CHIEFS UNITED BY FEAR OF 2D REAGAN TERM
description: As union leaders were gathering here to rally behind Walter F. Mondale, their enthusiasm for the Democrat Presidential candidate is matched by a bitter and fearful animosity toward President Reagan.

title: Where Was The Soccer?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Honors for Kapp
description: Before the Minnesota Vikings reached the 1970 Super Bowl with Joe Kapp at quarterback, Kapp played pro football for eight years in Canada and was the quarterback for the British Columbia Lions when they went to the Grey Cup in 1964. Yesterday, Kapp, now head coach at the University of California, was inducted into the Canadian Football Hall of Fame. During his years in Canada, Kapp completed 1,476 of 2,709 pass attempts for 22,925 yards.

title: TENTATIVE PROGRAM OF G.O.P. CONVENTION
description: Following is a tentative day-by-day program of the Republican National Convention, which opens here Monday. The schedule was released by the Republican National Committee. (All times are Eastern daylight; central daylight time is one hour earlier.)

title: IN 1912 AS NOW, INCONSISTENCIES
description: THE pageantry is majestic, the firstathletes are superbly skilled and highly trained. One-hundred forty nations sent 7,575 athletes to compete and the business of the Games of the XXIII Olympiad moved along smoothly with each event covered in minute detail. The 1984 Olympics were a wonderful and impressive sight.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
SOMEWHERE TO GO
description: IT is evening at Samaritan

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Gourmet Delights Baked Daily The Upper Crust Bakery on North Avenue in New Rochelle is a source for gourmet concoctions baked daily in enough variety to satiate the most exotic appetites either on the spot (just three stools at a small counter), at the office or at home immediately or to be stored for a subsequent picnic.

title: K. J. Mayer Wed To Miss Danforth
description: Stephanie Birney Danforth, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Snell Danforth Jr. of Providence, R.I., was married yesterday to Kenneth Jason Mayer, a son of Oscar L. Mayer of Wrentham, Mass., and Ruth L. Mayer of Foxboro, Mass. The Rev. John Hall performed the ceremony at St. Peter's by the Sea Episcopal Church in Narragansett, R.I.

title: FATE OF PRISON DEBATED
description: WHAT should be the fate of the Long Island Correctional Facility in Brentwood?

title: HAPPINESS AND THE HARDWARE STORE
description: To Geoffrey Norman's description of the fantasies of the male shopper in a hardware store, I would add those of a woman: A hardware store offers the means to such major improvements in her home as a new kitchen floor or a fresh coat of paint, the hanging of a picture or the installation of weatherstripping.

title: G.O.P. ADDS TO DELEGATION
description: UNDER pressure from state party leaders to include women as delegates to the Republican National Convention, which opens in Dallas tomorrow, Long Island Republican leaders have selected their wives to fill several of the positions.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN WILTON
description: Since the end of World War II, when

title: Denver School Plan Backed
description: A Federal district judge has approved a $4 million plan to hire 60 teachers and 40 tutors for expanded bilingual education programs in this city's schools. The ruling Friday by Judge Richard P. Matsch stemmed from a 1980 lawsuit challenging the Denver public schools system's implementation of a decade- old desegregation order. The plan calls for the school system to spend $2.2 million a year over the next two years to hire the teachers and tutors and to train teachers.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
WILIAMS ENCOURAGED THIS 'CAT'
description: Noah James frequently reports on the performing arts.

title: Suzanne Lown and Randall Glidden Are Married
description: Suzanne Elizabeth Lown, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Freer Lown of Kingston, N.Y., and Randall Lane Glidden, the son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Lane Glidden of Shavertown, Pa., were married yesterday. The Rev. Cornelius Keith Geense performed the ceremony at the Dutch Reformed Church in Rhinebeck, N.Y.

title: WHY STUDENTS DO 'GO PUBLIC'
description: BY Christmas 1980, in his senior year in high school, Gerry Williger of Tallmadge, Ohio, seemed to have it all - top grades, a definite career goal and early acceptance to the private college of his choice. As a National Merit Scholar and recipient of an Ohio Academic Scholarship, he and his family assumed he would receive enough financial aid to help him through four years of Case Western Reserve's Institute of Technology. Today, however, Mr. Williger finds himself about to begin his fourth and final year at Ohio State University - and is glad that he ultimately chose a public institution.

title: Typhoon Holly Hits Okinawa
description: Typhoon Holly lashed the southern Japanese island of Okinawa today with winds of up to 80 miles per hour, stranding an estimated 15,000 vacationers. Officials said the winds and rough seas paralyzed air and ferry services linking Okinawa with outlying islands and Japan's main islands for the second consecutive day.

title: ; IN PRAISE OF AUTHENTIC MAQUE CHOUX
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
THE LURE OF HANDMADE PAPER
description: There is nothing timid about the way the relatively new East Hills Gallery has approached is first major theme exhibition. Contemporary Directions: Handmade Paper is a thorough, lively presentation that offers depth, variety and a fair sampling of artists who are at the cutting edge of their subject.

title:
GARDENING;
PERENNIALS CAN ADD VARIETY AND CHARM
description: BEFORE the 1940's, perennials dominated most flower plantings. They had done so since the end of the Victorian era, with its fussy plantings of tropicals and annuals. Soon after the end of World War II, plant breeders working for the seed companies began to apply the same techniques to annuals that had been used so successfully in developing hybrid corn. As a result, burgeoning numbers of greatly improved annuals came on the market. Their performance was so outstanding that they displaced perennials from many gardens.

title: MUCH THICKER THAN WATER
description: HOLLYWOOD DYNASTIES LODZ By Stephen Farber and Marc Green. Illustrated. 365 pp. New York: Delilah/Putnam Publishing Group. $16.95.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
WHEN A WOMAN CAMPAIGNED
description: WALTER MONDALE and Geraldine Ferraro have changed American political history. But if Anna Elizabeth Dickinson were alive today, Mr. Mondale may have considered her for his running mate.

title: LIVING WITH AN AILING HEART
description: THE DRAMATIC DEATH OF James F. Fixx, guru of exercise fanatics, of whom I am one, has thrown a scare into the jogging fraternity. How could a youngish man who exercised regularly and preached the benefits of a sane life go out for an afternoon run along a country road in Vermont and drop dead? The case was a real shocker, and it sent my mind thundering back to a remarkable week in 1964 that I spent with Paul Dudley White, the great heart specialist who had supervised the recovery of President Eisenhower when he was knocked down by a major heart attack in 1955, during his first term in office.

title: INNOCENCE, SIN AND J.D. SALINGER
description: THE OXFORD COMPANION TO CHILDREN'S LITERATURE

title: HEADLINERS
description: Haven in Portugal For the second time in his life, Archbishop Valerian D. Trifa appears to have gained sanctuary by keeping mum about his past. The 70-year-old head of the Rumanian Orthodox Church in America was ordered deported from the United States in 1982 after it was charged that he lied about his work for the pro-Nazi Rumanian Iron Guard during World War II.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
LIVING WITH MOUNT LAUREL II
description: IN January 1983, in what is known as the

title: My Hometown: ; 'Los Angeles Is the Place'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: TURN TO SUMMER'S FRUIT FOR RICH, COLD MOUSSES
description: THE abundance of summer fruits inspires the dessert maker. If turning baskets of blueberries, peaches, nectarines, raspberries and the like into sumptuous and appealing endings for a meal does not require lighting the oven, so much the better. Delicate but rich, cold mousses, in pale pastel shades, fill this requirement.

title: CABLE'S CNN TAKES UP CONVENTIONS' GAUNTLET
description: However fast time moves in the rest of the world, it moves faster in television. Four years ago, there was no Cable News Network. There was a UHF station in Atlanta, Ga., that had 96 employees and was owned by a wickedly dimpled man with a pencil mustache whom newspapers occasionally referred to as ''R. E. (Ted) Turner.''

title: Chekhov's Journey
description: To the Editor:

title: Flier Killed as Jets Collide
description: Two Air Force jet fighters engaged in a simulated dogfight apparently collided Friday, killing one flier and injuring two others, an official at Tyndall Air Force Base said. The dead man was identified as First Lieut. Stephen Hamilton, 28 years old, of Westwood, Mass.

title: BURLINGTON PASSES LAND CONSERVATION
description: CHESTERFIELD BURLINGTON COUNTY has negotiated the first land purchase under New Jersey's two-year-old Farmland Preservation Program, a transaction that will bring 607 acres of this small township back to agriculture.

title: CITY URGED TO ALLOT 'TENS OF MILLIONS' MORE TO HOUSING
description: A commission formed by Mayor Koch,

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM A POP CONCERT TO A PULITZER PLAY
description: Ordinary People Starring Mary Tyler Moore, Timothy Hutton, Donald Sutherland, Elizabeth McGovern, Judd Hirsch; directed by Robert Redford, 1980 Paramount Home Video 124 minutes. $39.95

title: Article 141303 -- No Title
description: To the Editor:

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A NEW COINAGE PORTRAIT
description: Art will imitate life starting in January, when the British Royal Mint begins using a new coinage portrait of Queen Elizabeth II. The more mature portrait reflects the graceful aging of the Queen since the current coinage effigy went into use 20 years ago.

title: Gay A. Crosthwait Married in Texas To John Danforth
description: Gay Aynesworth Crosthwait, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Wilson Crosthwait of Waco, Tex., was married there yesterday to John David Danforth, a son of June Gutfleisch of Los Angeles and Robert Danforth of San Francisco. The Rev. Clifton Mann performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: SUMMER CAMP JOYS: PARENTS' TIME OUT
description: After weeks of often-frantic planning and preparation, the big day had finally arrived. Every little name tag was in place, the trunk was packed and 12-year-old Eric Barbanel was ready to leave for summer camp.

title: Miss Blumenthal To Wed Sept. 29
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eli Eisner of Westport, Conn., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Eisner's daughter, Victoria Blumenthal, to John Marshall Forster, a son of Mrs. William Hall Forster of Mystic, Conn., and the late Mr. Forster. The wedding is to be on Sept. 29.

title: THIS TIME, AN OIL PRICE CUT COULD HURT
description: When the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries cut its official oil price last year from $34 a barrel to $29, American consumers benefited. So did airlines, oil importers and energy-intensive industries such as steel and chemicals. It was widely believed that the winners outstripped losers, which included oil-producing countries and companies. The world began to emerge from a recession and in many countries inflation slowed. Now, however, many experts believe that sharp price cuts could hurt more than help.

title: ASBURY PARK OPENS A DRIVE ON BLIGHT
description: ASBURY PARK WITH a report in hand saying that almost three- quarters of the beachfront neighborhood - exclusive of street rights-of-way and publicly owned land - is blighted, officials here have begun a campaign to try to revitalize their seaside community.

title: SPACE DATA HELP BUSINESSES
description: WHEN Interpack Inc. of Greenwich was developing a new grain storage facility for farmers in the Midwest, it learned that mold growth and insect development could be halted if the temperature, pressure and humidity inside the silo were kept constant.

title: Dr. A. V. Granata, Dr. Claudia Dinan Engaged to Marry
description: The engagement of Dr. Claudia Dinan and Dr. Attilio V. Granata, graduates of the Yale University School of Medicine, has been announced by Mrs. Vincent G. Dinan of Bridgeport, Conn., mother of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Attilio Granata of Hamden, Conn.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: EXPLORING PERU'S JUNGLES: A MYTHIC BEAST
description: A Kon Tiki Will Raft On the Amazon Transport is aboard native rafts identical to the famous Kon Tiki that voyaged between Peru and Tahiti in 1947. Accomodations en route are in hammocks, strung from the roof. Meals are served family style by the crew. The 14-day voyage takes place along remote Peruvian tributaries of the Amazon in the company of guides who are experts on the life of the region and fluent in tribal dialects.

title: SCARSDALE TAKES A LOOK AT ITS PAST
description: AMONG the items that will be on display at an exhibition called ''Building Suburbia: Scarsdale, 1890-1940'' is a handbill announcing a protest against the ''wretched service'' on the New York Central Railroad. The handbill begins, ''Are you interested in getting home to dinner on time?'' and goes on to announce a meeting scheduled for Dec. 18, 1906.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
LET'S NOT INVEST IN INJUSTICE
description: NEW JERSEY should no longer tolerate a situation in which the 365,000 members of the six state pension funds, many thousands of whom are black, are asked to subsidize the policies of racial injustice practiced in South Africa.

title: Another Vote For Rizzuto
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Military Money
description: Pentagon spending has surged dramatically in recent years, but fewer states have been getting a piece of the action, according to a consultant's study released last week.

title: HOW THE GOPHERS GO FOR GOLD
description: TWO decades ago the University of Minnesota, with more than 45,000 students on six campuses, raised less than $650,000 from private sources and was the last in the Big 10 in that category.

title: Aides Meet in Panama To Prepare Conference
description: The foreign ministers of the four nations in the Contadora group met here today to prepare for a conference on a draft peace agreement for Central America, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said.

description: There were cannon to the right of President Reagan and cannon to the left of him.

title: Elizabeth Ann Reamer Wed to Blake Hornick
description: The wedding of Elizabeth Ann Reamer and Blake Hornick was performed yesterday by Rabbi Jonathan Eichhorn at Temple Emanuel in Kingston, N.Y. Mrs. Hornick is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Reamer of Kingston. Mr. Hornick is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton J. Hornick of New York and New City, N.Y.

title: LONDON'S LITTLE HILL TOWN
description: LOUIS HEREN is a former foreign correspondent and deputy editor of The Times of London. His most recent books are ''Alas, Alas, for England'' and ''Growing Up on The Times.''

title: VICE PRESIDENT BARS PRESS FROM CAMPAIGN PLANE
description: No representatives of the press will be allowed on Vice President Bush's campaign plane, but a chartered plane will be available for reporters covering him, according to his press secretary, Peter Teeley.

description: ARGUING AGEE

description: CUTTYHUNK ISLAND, Mass.
