description: A fully loaded Panamanian oil tanker was struck by a missile in the Persian Gulf today, according to reports reaching here.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: An exhibition of work by amateur needlewomen is not the kind of thing that we expect to see in the Metropolitan Museum, even in high summer. But there it is, through Sept. 23, and very pretty it turns out to be.

title: Democratic Ads Set For TV as G.O.P. Meets
description: Congressional Democrats have scheduled television commercials in the course of the Republican National Convention to attack President Reagan as a rich man's President who has made the world less safe.

title: A TOUR OF THE 'WORST AND THE BEST' AT RAHWAY STATE PRISON
description: AVENEL ITS yellowish walls, roof cones

title:
GARDENING;
PERENNIALS CAN ADD VARIETY AND CHARM
description: BEFORE the 1940's, perennials dominated most flower plantings. They had done so since the end of the Victorian era, with its fussy plantings of tropicals and annuals. Soon after the end of World War II, plant breeders working for the seed companies began to apply the same techniques to annuals that had been used so successfully in developing hybrid corn. As a result, burgeoning numbers of greatly improved annuals came on the market. Their performance was so outstanding that they displaced perennials from many gardens.

title: HEADLINERS
description: The Guests Included... Despite differences with her father over nuclear weapons, abortion and marijuana use, Patti Davis has grown close to her parents over the last few years, friends say. That closeness was evident last week at her marriage in Los Angeles, which was the first of his children's weddings that Ronald Reagan has attended since being elected President.

title: CRICKET CLUB THRIVES IN NEW ROCHELLEZ
description: NEW ROCHELLE '' HEY, MAN! That's a run. No, man, two. Hey, Winston, go for four! Go for six!'' Applause broke out as Winston Barker completed four runs between the two wickets 66 feet apart.

title: MONUMENTS TO COMFORT
description: Like Kubla Khan's Xanadu, Dallas is filled with pleasure domes and marble palaces. From the most sumptuous hotel, the Mansion on Turtle Creek, to the most monumental, the 1,620- room Loews Anatole, all flat surfaces seem to be covered with marble. Formica may be the one building material not thriving in a city where every street seems to have a hole in the ground presided over by a crane.

title: Manager for Mondale Denies Issuing Jackson an Apology
description: Robert G. Beckel, campaign manager for Walter F. Mondale, has denied that he issued an apology to the Rev. Jesse Jackson in a private meeting between the two men Wednesday.

title: WHAT'S NEW AT MCDONALD'S
description: For the McDonald's Corporation, it's been quite a summer: Never were the Golden Arches more visible. The far-flung fast-food enterprise starred at the Olympics, joined the Navy, announced a new roadside complex called McStop and dealt with the aftermath of a tragic mass killing that took place at a McDonald's restaurant in San Diego. The incident prompted McDonald's to suspend its advertising for a few days.

title: Fires Investigated at Scene Of Riots in Lawrence, Mass.
description: Suspicious fires broke out Friday night in a house near the recent scene of riots between Hispanic residents and whites, a deputy fire chief said.

title: NEW JERSEY COURT RULES ON BENEFITS
description: New Jersey employers can be held liable for failing to explain with reasonable care an employee's health plan and benefit options, a state appeals court has ruled in a case involving Playboy Inc.

title: A BIG THRIFT IN TROUBLE
description: The high-risk lending practices of Charles W. Knapp, chairman of the Financial Corporation of America, haunted the nation's largest thrift institution last week. Rumors circulated that its main bank, American Savings and Loan, had a net outflow of funds in July. On Wednesday, that was confirmed, as the thrift reported a $582 million loss of funds, primarily from $1.4 billion in institutional withdrawals. Moreover, Financial reported a $107.5 million loss for the quarter ended June 30, the result of changing its accounting procedures at the insistence of the S.E.C. It was thought to be the largest quarterly loss ever reported by a thrift, and it cut the bank's net worth to 2.3 percent of its assets, well below its required 4 percent minimum. As fears mounted that the U.S. had another major banking crisis on its hands, trading in the thrift's certificates of deposit almost stopped, adding to its liquidity problems. Analysts said the next few days could be critical.

title: U.S. Sub Visits Singapore
description: The United States nuclear-powered submarine Omaha has arrived in Singapore for a five-day visit after routine operations in the Pacific, the United States Embassy said today.

title: VERSATILITY FOR FALL
description: One fall collection worth looking at is that of the young designer Yeohlee Teng. Miss Teng is working in such luxurious fabrics as alpaca, mohair and melton and is executing them in surprisingly clever ways.

title: SUEZ MINES ARE YET ANOTHER OBSTACLE IN MUBARAK'S PATH
description: The mysterious mines in Red Sea waters, which have damaged at least 18 ships since July 9, have forced Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak into a difficult position. He has publicly sought to downplay the danger to commercial shipping using the Suez Canal, one of Egypt's largest revenue earners. At the same time, he was privately pursuading the Western powers that the threat to the strategic waterway warranted emergency assistance.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
description: COMEDY IN MAHWAH

title: OF SEA LEGS AND THE GOLDEN ARCHES
description: While it becomes increasingly difficult for fast-food companies to find new places to put their outlets, a fertile new customer base has emerged: The armed services are now considered a vast potential market - perhaps especially on nights when the mess hall serves some traditional chipped beef on toast.

title: SPORTS ; A TENNIS TURNING POINT
description: IF things go according to plan,

title: No Headline
description: IN WHAT is believed would be a first in this country, a day-care center and summer day camp for children of corporate employees at an industrial park here are being planned by a real-estate developer.

title: HOW TO BE A YANK IN BRITAIN
description: STUDYING abroad grows more popular every year and has long since broken the bounds of the ''junior year abroad''; one can study abroad for a semester or during the summer, on land or at sea. One of the most picturesque and rewarding countries for Americans, according to many who have studied there, is England. There the schools are world-famous and the language is familiar; only the culture need be mastered. Following is a student's guide to a satisfying stay on the ''Sceptre'd Isle.''

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
WHY THE SNUB? THEY, TOO, ARE WINNERS IN ATHLETICS
description: A GREAT opportunity was lost. The American public could have learned that the disabled are you and me, but for the grace of God.

title: ILLINOIS COURSE REASSEMBLES THE CAUSES OF PLANE CRASHES
description: A perfect model of an F-106 fighter plane hangs from a classroom ceiling at Chanute Technical Training Center here. But below it are 5,000 pounds of compressed, fused metal that was once the engine of a real jet plane. The classroom is full of twisted and burned engines, clues that students use to figure out why jet planes crash.

title: Holly Leithead, a Teacher, Is Married
description: Holly Leithead, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger B. Leithead of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Orangeville, Pa., was married yesterday to Gregg Merrill MacKenzie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward MacKenzie of Bolivar, Pa. The Rev. Max Smith performed the ceremony at St. Michael's of the Valley Episcopal Church in Ligonier, Pa.

title: A NEW AGREEMENT HALTED ABRUPTLY IN HOSPITAL STRIKE
description: For the second weekend in a row, a tentative settlement of New York City's hospital and nursing-home strike broke apart at the last minute yesterday.

title: A VISIONARY ARTIST'S NEW OUTLOOK
description: Susan Rothenberg's gray paintings exemplify the intellectual tension and fragile balance of the human mind.

title: 'INTELLIGENT' COMPUTER READS MANY TYPEFACES
description: A computer whose makers say it marks an advance in artificial intelligence is gaining wide use among publishers, linguists, legislators and others who put it to work ''reading'' documents and storing large amounts of information.

title: MUSEUM IN KENT CELEBRATES RURAL AMERICANA
description: THERE are three joys in life, according to the painter and writer Eric Sloane of Warren. One is discovering, the second is collecting and the third, he says, is giving away.

title: SALVADOR MILITARY QUESTIONING THE U.S. ROLE
description: Salvadoran military officials say that they are unhappy with the role of some United States military advisers here and that they are asking that the Americans' mission be redefined to emphasize basic training skills.

title: GROUP AIDING USE OF RIGHTS IN CHINATOWN
description: When a group of Chinatown tenants wanted to file harassment complaints and lawsuits against their landlord last year for the leaky ceilings, peeling plaster and poor security in their building, they went to the Chinatown Planning Council.

title: BALDNESS: THE TRANSPLANT OPTION
description: DANIEL STANGO, 41 years old, has cut and styled hair for thousands of customers since his first job in a barbershop 25 years ago. He has come to know well the feelings of his clients, many of whom were slowly going bald.

title: Charleston to Monitor Plaza
description: The city of Charleston plans to use television surveillance on a downtown plaza and walkway even though the some residents may consider the move intrusive, Mayor Mike Roark said Friday.

title: AT N.Y.U., 50 YEARS OF ADULT FARE
description: BEFORE New York University held classes for full-time students during the day, it was offering evening lectures for adults. But it was not until 1934, 103 years after the university was founded, that it organized those adult classes into the New York University School of Continuing Education. This year the school celebrates 50 years of teaching adults, and in that first half-century it has grown from 6,000 students in 200 courses to more than 50,000 in 2,000 courses, making it the largest program of its kind in a private university.

title: NEW RECORDINGS OF OLD FAVORITES
description: Record companies are frequently berated for devoting the lion's share of their budgets to works already available in dozens of perfectly good versions. Label executives admit that this policy is unadventurous, but they cite a handful of reasons for pursuing it. High on the list is artist turnover: promising young conductors, orchestras new to recording, and new conductor-orchestra relationships all deserve a moment in the sun, and they all feel they'll shine brightest in the great works. Older conductors, meanwhile, have traditionally been allowed to remake their catalogues every decade or two; and improvements in recording technology are often seen as sufficient reason to re-record even the most ubiquitous works. But the bottom line, both figuratively and literally, is that no matter how many competing versions there are, new recordings of standard fare almost invariably sell a lot of copies - some of them to listeners who want to update their collections, and some to newcomers to the classical record market.

title: JINGLE MUSIC: A TOUGH TRADE
description: The ''top 40'' list of best-selling records reflects the shifting fortunes of the most popular musicians in America. Yet no matter how many millions of their records are sold, they will never become the performers most listened to. That distinction is reserved for the anonymous musicians in New York and Los Angeles who play the music for movies, television, and advertising commercials, and are also heard on many of the best-selling popular records. These are the studio musicians, whose special skill it is to sight-read nearly anything put in front of them and, after a few minutes of rehearsal, to record it.

title: 3 CHILDREN ARE KILLED IN NIAGRA FALLS BLAZE
description: An early morning fire today killed three children and critically injured a fourth, according to authorities.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Connoisseurs of fine singing have an exciting evening of television ahead of them this week. Monday night, Channel 13 will present a sequence of programs devoted to the careers of Maria Callas and Montserrat Caballe.

title: U.S. BUILDING NEW MINESWEEPERS AFTER YEARS OF RELYING ON COPTERS
description: The United States Navy, after two decades of relying primarily on helicopters to sweep mines at sea, has ordered two new classes of minesweeping ships.

title: More KillingIn Sri Lanka
description: In Sri Lanka, an island country of 15 million people near the southern tip of India, the Sinhalese majority and the Tamil minority do not speak the same language. Last week, their linguistic, ethnic and religious differences were exacerbated by Tamil terrorism and army reprisals in a revival of violence that took hundreds of lives last year.

title: FRANCES'S RICHEST COMMUNIST MAKES MONEY - AND WAVES
description: -Baptiste Doumeng owns a stable of thoroughbred

title: COUNTY'S FIRST SKYSCRAPER IN RENOVATION
description: -story, 57-year-old Con Edison Building in Mount Vernon, has undergone a $3 million renovation as part of that city's effort to upgrade its commercial neighborhoods.

title: OF PERSONAL MORALITY, PUBLIC POLICY AND PRUDENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: LETTERS ; Maternity Leave
description: To the Editor:

title: Senator Kennedy's Son Released From Hospital
description: Patrick Kennedy, the youngest son of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, was released today from Cape Cod Hospital, where he had been under observation after suffering a concussion in an automobile crash.

title: BACK TO BASICS, CONSULTANT ADVISES
description: '' THERE is a need at the moment for American companies to get back to the basics of productivity and improved production, improved quality and being in businesses that they know,'' said John M. May of Old Westbury and Southold.

title: PRESIDENTIAL BOMBING JOKE: WHAT IF...?
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 FOR G.O.P. EYES (NOT ONLY)
description: The Republican Party may have missed its rendevous with history.

title: REPLICA OR WARSHIP AFLOAT AT BRIDGEPORT
description: '' THE people who sailed out of Black Rock would have given their right arm to capture this vessel,'' Kaye Williams of Bridgeport said, with one foot up on a wooden step inside the musty gun deck of a copy of the British warship Rose.

title: TEACHING FOREIGNERS ENGLISH
description: WINOOSKI, Vt. A CAMBODIAN student is asked to describe his fondest memory, and he recalls a day at the beach in his homeland. A Japanese student recalls the day he climbed Mount Fuji. A young Bolivian describes the party his friends held for him before he left home to study in Vermont. The students' English is hesitant, but their teacher, Betty Donovan, draws their memories from them and prods them to express themselves in this new language.

title: The Shake-UpIn Teheran
description: The war with Iraq claimed some casualties in the Iranian Cabinet last week. Parliament dismissed five ministers including Defense Minister Mohammad Salmi, and sacked four other Government officials.

title: CHESS ; REAPING THE HARVEST
description: The length of time it can take to carry out a maneuver against a weakness may wrongly lead the defender to minimize his problem, but there are weaknesses that don't go away even if they are not immediately exploitable.

title: WILDLIFE TRADERS CITE MAZE OF LAWS
description: When Richard and Anna Marie Stevenson decided to go into the bird-importing business, they worked closely with agents of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. In meetings, telephone calls and letters, they recall, they were led through a maze of laws and treaties regulating foreign trade in wildlife.

title: A Small Hotel
description: To the Editor: Perhaps the last word has been said in the Yorkshire article (Travel, April 29) by R. W. Apple Jr., and in several Letters to the Editor.

title:
ANTIQUES;
COLLECTORS GATHER IN NEW LONDON
description: IN 1658 the General Assembly

title: Q & A
description: A Matter of Form Question:

title: A WELCOME CHINESE ARRIVAL
description: OMEI, a recent addition to Oyster Bay, is a good example of the improvement in Chinese restaurants on the Island since the mid-1970's. Americanized interpretations like chow mein and chop suey, once standard fare, are being replaced by a host of regional Chinese dishes, including exotic specialties that, in the past, had to be ordered in advance.

title: Charles Fontana Weds Ruth Griggs, Manager
description: Ruth Leland Griggs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Osborne E. Griggs of Northampton, Mass., and West Chesterfield, N.H., was married yesterday to Charles Richard Fontana, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Fontana of Yorktown Heights, N.Y. The Rev. Richard K. Beebe, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Park Hill Meeting House in Westmoreland, N.H.

title: MAKING COMMUNITY SERVICE A HABIT
description: ALICIA HESSE, an 11th-grader at the Noble and Greenough School in Boston, used to play field hockey after school. Now, through a different sort of extracurricular program, she spends her afternoons working with Peter, a 5-year-old who has cerebral palsy and cannot speak yet. Miss Hesse plays educational games with her young charge, helping him to do exercises designed to increase his manual dexterity and to help him breathe more easily.

title: A'S AT COLLEGE OF ADVENTISTS LEAD TO TRIPS
description: It used to be that the only rewards for earning an academic A were personal satisfaction and perhaps a spot on the dean's list. But starting this fall, students at the Southern College of Seventh-day Adventists will reap more tangible benefits: free travel to Europe.

title: GLUCK'S 'ORFEO' IN PERIOD STYLE
description: Christoph Willibald von Gluck tinkered endlessly with his operatic masterpiece ''Orfeo ed Euridice.'' Altogether, there are at least four distinct versions - sung in both Italian and French, and the title role has been essayed by sopranos, contraltos, altos, even an occasional tenor. At Marymount Manhattan Theater, beginning Thursday, Concert Royal and the New York Baroque Dance Company - two local ensembles dedicated to the reconstruction of 18th-century opera and ballet - will collaborate on what are described as the first American performances of ''Orfeo'' to utilize period instruments and dance.

NEW BRUNSWICK '' IT'S a vote of confidence,'' said Judith Leviton, director of the Princeton Ballet, of the $100,000 grant the company recently received from the State Council on the Arts. ''Now it is our obligation to deliver - and we will.''

title: TAXES ADD NEW TRAUMA TO DIVORCE
description: The new tax law has radically changed the tax

title: A FROLICSOME BALLET MAY QUALIFY AS A CLASSIC, TOO
description: Forty years ago, David Lichine's ''Graduation Ball'' entered the repertory of American Ballet Theater and became an immediate success. It was a success once again during the company's recent season at the Metropolitan Opera House. ''Graduation Ball'' remains eternally young - and eternally sturdy, too.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: DAYS OF '76 AGAIN

title: Dana Burroughs the Bride OfDavidHenryKlingesJr.
description: Dana Anne Burroughs, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Burroughs Jr. of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to David Henry Klinges Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Klinges of Bethlehem, Pa. The Rev. Edward Johnston performed the ceremony at Christ's Episcopal Church.

title: Nuclear Winter and Its Smoke After a nuclear war, according to a new conjecture, will come nuclear winter, a cold darkness so profound that land in both hemispheres will freeze, crops will fail and life perish. War between the two major powers would thus bring inevitable disaster to all other countries, too.
description: Is the thesis well founded? And if so, then what?

title: DOME'S FIGHT TO UNTANGLE A VAST FINANCIAL WEB
description: CALGARY, Alberta

title: NEW JERSEY MAY ATTEMPT CASHING IN ON ITS OWN IMAGINATION
description: Since the days of Thomas Edison, who invented the light bulb in Menlo Park, New Jersey has enjoyed a reputation as the nation's laboratory. Advanced research in pharmaceuticals and communications is maintaining the tradition; there are 700 research and development laboratories in New Jersey and more scientists than in any other state.

title: Python Victim's Father Held
description: Gerry Lloyd, the father of an 11-month- old boy who was suffocated by the family's pet python, was indicted on a charge of manslaughter Thursday. An autopsy disclosed that the boy, Matthew Lloyd, was bitten and suffocated by the 85-pound reptile on Aug. 6.

title: Rail From Paris
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed your article ''Daylong Sorties by Rail from Paris'' (Travel, July 29), but there is one thing I can't understand after all these years. Doesn't anyone know they can visit a castle at the end of a subway line? I lived in Paris years before I saw the light, I must confess.

title: Musical Museum
description: To the Editor: Your article about the Musical Museum in Deansboro, N.Y. (Travel, June 17), brings back memo

title:
GARDENING;
PERENNIALS CAN ADD VARIETY AND CHARM
description: BEFORE the 1940's, perennials dominated most flower plantings. They had done so since the end of the Victorian era, with its fussy plantings of tropicals and annuals. Soon after the end of World War II, plant breeders working for the seed companies began to apply the same techniques to annuals that had been used so successfully in developing hybrid corn. As a result, burgeoning numbers of greatly improved annuals came on the market. Their performance was so outstanding that they displaced perennials from many gardens.

title: TOWN VS. STATE ON DUMPING
description: ACONTINUING battle between the Town of Smithtown and the State Department of Environmental Conservation over rubble landfill permits could finally be resolved in the courts.

title: PUBLIC COLLEGES WITH IVY LAURELS
description: MOST parents of the highest-achieving high school seniors are willing to pay anything to get their offspring into Stanford, Yale, Williams, Georgetown, and a small club of other high-prestige private institutions. But there are others - even those with ready cash - who are wondering these days if Olde Ivy is worth two to three times the price of a respectable public institution.

title: HUSBAND PLANS TAX DISCLOSURE WITH FERRARO
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro said yesterday that her husband, John A. Zaccaro, had changed his mind and would release his income tax returns from the time she entered Congress in 1979.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: PUERTO RICO CASE STIRS NEW APPEAL
description: The Commonwealth Senate and professional organizations here have asked that the Federal authorities find out why two Justice Department investigations failed to solve a case in which two advocates of independence for Puerto Rico were shot by the police.

title: Decker Decision Near
description: Mary Decker may decide tomorrow whether to compete in Europe this year or take time off to allow her injured hip to heal, according to Dick Brown, her coach.

BUSINESS FORUM;
A LARGE NEW ROLE FOR THE WORLD BANK
description: There is no mystery about the

title: Data Bank; August 19, 1984
IN SHORT

title: Tug of WarOver RareHebrew Books
description: In 1940, Dr. Alexander Guttmann, a professor at a Berlin rabbinical seminary, smuggled 59 rare Hebrew books and manuscripts out of Germany. The head of the seminary had given him the books, Dr. Guttmann says, to keep them from being destroyed by the Nazis.

title: OF PERSONAL MORALITY, PUBLIC POLICY AND PRUDENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: BILL TO LICENSE DIETITIANS SETS OFF DISPUTE
description: ALTHOUGH few would disagree that good nutrition is vital to good health, exactly who is qualified to give nutrition advice is being vigorously debated around the state.

title: COORECTION
description: In an article last week on the Long Island Rail Road's electrification project in Huntington, the position of a proposed second track at the Cold Spring Harbor station was given incorrectly. The railroad plans to lay that track south of the present line. Residents near the station have requested that the railroad construct the track on the north side.

title: Joyce F. Katz Is Bride Of Michael S. Ettinger
description: At Temple Torah in Little Neck, Queens, yesterday Joyce Francine Katz, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Katz of Syosset, L.I., was married to Michael Saul Ettinger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Ettinger of Woodside, Queens. Rabbi Morton Gordon officiated.

description: Almost as soon as tenants receive word

title: Miss Brown Is the Bride Of a Lawyer
description: Nancy Andrews Brown, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barrett Bolton Brown of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Scott Floyd Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Sammons Smith Jr. of Hot Springs, Ark. The Rev. Stephen Chinlund performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn.

title: SWIMMER, 74, WINS 2 MEDALS
description: For decades, Harry Barr looked forward to retiring from his jobs as an assistant high school principal in Queens and a wrestling coach in Manhattan. Ten years ago, he took the plunge.

title: TIGHTER SECURITY IS ORDERED FOR YOUTH PROGRAM IN JERSEY
description: Ten of 48 juvenile offenders ordered to participate in a wilderness program over the last two years have fled while on camping trips outside New Jersey, state officials said this week as they announced that security for the program would be increased.

title: BODDICKER BEATS ANGELS, 1-0
description: Mike Boddicker pitched his second straight shutout as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the California Angels 1-0, today, the only run scoring on a first-inning error by Mike Witt, the California pitcher.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN THE CONNECTICUT RIVER VALLEY
description: Visitors to the Connecticut River Valley of New Hampshire and Vermont may recall the Whale in Rudyard Kipling's ''Just So Stories'' who ''opened his mouth wide and wide and wide, and said, 'Change here for Winchester, Ashuelot, Nashua, Keene, and stations on the

title:
GARDENING;
PERENNIALS CAN ADD VARIETY AND CHARM
description: BEFORE the 1940's, perennials dominated most flower plantings. They had done so since the end of the Victorian era, with its fussy plantings of tropicals and annuals. Soon after the end of World War II, plant breeders working for the seed companies began to apply the same techniques to annuals that had been used so successfully in developing hybrid corn. As a result, burgeoning numbers of greatly improved annuals came on the market. Their performance was so outstanding that they displaced perennials from many gardens.

title: 56 TEEN-AGERS REFUSE MEASLES SHOTS, CITING RELIGIOUS BELIEFS
description: Fifty-six teen-agers isolated at a church camp by a measles outbreak two weeks ago will stay in ''voluntary quarantine'' for two more weeks because they have refused to be vaccinated on the ground that it would violate their religious beliefs, officials said.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
PUTTERING AROUND
description: SUMMER 1979: We finally found a house we liked on the Island and have decided it's the one. Old but sturdy. The garden's not much to look at: a big crop of crabgrass and four stubby evergreens in the back. The owner said her relatives started the trees from seed. How touching.

title: Fryar Sidelined
description: The New England Patriots' first- round draft pick, Irving Fryar, the all-pro punter Rich Camarillo and the backup linebacker Johnnie Rembert will miss up to half the regular season with injuries, the team said yesterday. The injuries were suffered in the Patriots' 31-27 exhibition victory Friday over the Redskins in Washington.

title: SEEKING SOLUTIONS ON TOXIC WASTE
description: CHARLES LEVONIUS recalled a time more than 40 years ago when he would scramble down the bank behind his Canterbury home to swim in the cool waters of the Quinebaug River, taking an occasional drink to quench his thirst.

title: G.O.P. Conventioneers Favor Bush for 1988
description: Vice President Bush is the 1988 Presidential favorite of nearly half the Republican Party convention-goers who responded to a survey published today.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM A POP CONCERT TO A PULITZER PLAY
description: The Gin Game Starring Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy; produced and directed by Terry Hughes RKO Home Video 82 minutes. $39.95

title: Tessa Merritt, Broker, Will Be Wed
description: Tessa Merritt and Dr. Charles Wade LeBaron plan to be married Sept. 22. Mr. and Mrs. Philip Alden Schoettle of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, have announced her daughter's engagement to the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Wade LeBaron of New York.

title: 100 WOUNDED IN INDIA IN PROTESTS AT STATE ASSEMBLY'S OUSTER
description: About 100 people were wounded today when police officers using riot sticks and tear gas broke up new protests against the dismissal of the state government in Andhra Pradesh, a large southeastern Indian province of 55 million people.

title: 'Test-Tube' SkinFor Fire Victims
description: Burn injuries deprive victims of the one protective barrier - the skin - that keeps fluids in and infections out. About 100,000 burn patients are admitted to American hospitals each year.

title: FOR NORAID, A TOUR OF IRELAND AND ITS TROUBLES
description: To American eyes, there is a surreal quality to the ghettos of West Belfast separated, Protestant from Catholic, by grotesque two-story steel or concrete ''peace walls.'' There is little street crime here. Tiny children play in seas of broken glass, but police officers in bulletproof vests and soldiers in camouflage often look frightened. In 15 years since the British Army arrived to keep order, 200 policemen and 377 soldiers have been killed, along with 2,500 other men, women and children.

title: No Headline
description: Maribeth Feeney Is Wed

title: TREVINO IS LEADER BY SHOT IN P.G.A.
description: Lee Trevino, the 44-year-old Texan who keeps doing amazing things on a golf course without hours of practice, gained a one-stroke lead after three rounds of the 66th annual P.G.A. Championship today.

title: East Germany's Leader Asks Return to Detente
description: Erich Honecker, the East German leader, called for ''a return to detente'' and urged a resumption of negotiations on reducing nuclear arms in an interview published Friday.

title: Gail Mitchell Harrity Engaged to Wed Sheldon Tilney, a Banker, in October
description: Gail Mitchell Harrity and Sheldon Tilney plan to be married in October, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. R. Johnstone Harrity of Rosemont, Pa., have announced. Mr. Tilney is a son of Norcross Sheldon Tilney of Lawrence, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Ann Weeks Tilney.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My husband has decided that, on Monday, he will release his tax returns from the time I first entered Congress in 1979, and we began filing separately.'' - Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro. (1:5.)

title: RINGING RHETORIC: THE RETURN OF POLITICAL ORATORY
description: William Safire is a columnist for The New York Times.

title: WHEN STEAMBOATS PLIED THE SOUND
description: FOR more than a century, Long Island Sound was a major route for steamboats. The era began in 1815, when Robert Fulton's company established the first steamship line between New York and New Haven, and lasted until the outbreak of World War II, when remnants of the Depression-plagued industry were requisitioned for the war effort.

title: PEACH FARMERS GET LOAN ELIGIBILITY
description: FREEHOLD PEACH cobbler made with fresh Jersey produce is a rare item on dessert menus this year because, local farmers say, subzero weather in January led to a major crop loss.

title: HAPPINESS AND THE HARDWARE STORE
description: It is not all right with me that Geoffrey Norman selfishly clutches the joys of a good hardware store to his masculine chest.

title: CHILDREN END STAY AT CAMP FULL OF PRIDE
description: The children at Camp Hidden Valley were putting on a talent show, but Soukeyna Richards could not start her song. She opened her mouth and closed it again, smiled uncomfortably and bent at the knees, as if straining for the melody.

title: Former Nigerian Official Faces Corruption Trial
description: A former Nigerian Finance Minister is to go on trial in closed session Monday on corruption charges, the army has announced.

title:
THE SCHOOLS;
...AND INPUT BY TEACHERS
description: HIS hands poised above the keyboard, legs dangling from his wheelchair, Ronnie's mind raced ahead of the computer. Tilting his head toward a visitor he said, ''You have to wait till the word disappears before you can type.'' The world ''boil'' faded from the monitor and he quickly typed in the same word from memory. ''If I pay attention,'' he said as he waited for the computer to acknowledge his correct answer, ''I'll get them all right.''

title: Arguing Agee
description: To the Editor:

title: Travers to Carr de Naskra
description: Carr de Naskra, whose speed carried him to an explosive victory in the Jim Dandy Stakes two weeks ago, came from off the pace under a shrewd ride by Laffit Pincay Jr. today to win the $307,500 Travers Stakes at Saratoga Race Track.

title: Agent OrangeEffect Unproved
description: A decade after the end of the war in Vietnam, some of the men who served there fear that their lives are still in danger and that not even their unborn children are safe. Their exposure to Agent Orange, a chemical defoliant that contains dioxin, they say, has increased the risk of cancer and other diseases and of birth defects.

title: DEEP FACTIONAL RIFTS IMPEDE LEBANON PEACE PLAN
description: ''They don't have much influence because they don't have anything here,'' Hisham Nassereddine was saying about the Lebanese Government. ''We are running the whole game here.''

title: LETTERS
description: AUTOMATION

title: SCIENTISTS RECAST HISTORIES OF THE ANCIENT CIVILIZATIONS
description: She was a little girl, about nine years old, named Camelia by the scholars who found her bones this summer at a University of Arizona excavation at Kourion, an ancient city on the southern coast of Cyprus. From the remains and the nearby rubble, the scientists deduced that Camelia died with her hands against her face, trying to protect herself in an earthquake that devastated much of Cyprus just after sunup on July 21 in the year 365 A.D.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Lenell Geter
description: Last March, a year and a half after almost everything went wrong, Lenell Geter was legally free and clear.

title: Jennifer Marie Otto Weds Eric Lorentzen, Executive
description: Jennifer Marie Otto, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Larry Eugene Otto of Belmont, Calif., was married yesterday to Eric L. Lorentzen, a son of Mrs. Hans K. Lorentzen of Kennett Square, Pa., and the late Mr. Lorentzen.

title: GAMES BEGIN FOR GLORY OF SOCIALISM
description: Less than a week after the formal closing of the Summer Games, Friendship '84, Moscow's answer to the Los Angeles Olympics, formally opened today with the lighting of a giant torch, an array of Politburo members and a sea of youthful gymnasts tumbling and marching under national colors.

title: OF PERSONAL MORALITY, PUBLIC POLICY AND PRUDENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: A VISIONARY ARTIST'S NEW OUTLOOK
description: I don't know what all the fuss over Susan Rothenberg is about.

title: BUFFALO'S GRAIN ELEVATORS: INSPIRATION OR A BLIGHT?
description: The huge, cylindrical grain elevators along the Buffalo River stand as a testament to a time, only a half century ago, when this city was a premier grain shipment center.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
WHEN IT'S TIME FOR LETTING GO
description: -agers who recently lost their lives at the Great Adventure amusement park leave behind more than grieving families. They stir up the cauldron of doubts that simmer in the back of every parent's mind.

title: COST OF U.S. SCHOOLS IS ESTIMATED AT $240 BILLION
description: The nation's school bill is expected to increase 6 percent this fall, to $240 billion, despite a predicted enrollment decline of 350,000, according to the Government's annual forecast of education costs.

title: Art; The Lure Of Handmade Paper
description: THERE is nothing timid about he way the relatively new East Hills Gallery has approached its first major theme exhibition Contemporary Directions Handmade Paper is a thorough, lively presentation that of fers depth variety and a fair sampling of artists who rae at the cutting edge of their subject.

title:
DINING OUT;
OLD-FASHIONED FRENCH CUISINE
description: NOW and then it is comforting to go back in time and indulge in hearty, predictable French fare, to pretend that Nouvelle Cuisine, light reduction sauces and tiny portions were but a flash in the pan.

title: FILM: '83 'BED OF ROSES,' FROM ALAIN RESNAIS
description: Following are excerpts from a review by Janet Maslin of ''Life Is a Bed of Roses'' that appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 29, 1983. The film was shown as part of the 1983 New York Film Festival. It opens today at the Lincoln Plaza 3, Broadway between 62d and 63d Streets.

title: STATE'S RELIANCE ON STUDIES INCREASES
description: WITH the appointment last week of a 15-member study commission, Governor O'Neill put another potential issue - higher pay for teachers - on the agenda for the 1985 General Assembly.

title: Pakistan Seizes Heroin
description: Pakistan's Narcotics Control Board said today that it had seized 100 pounds of heroin worth an estimated $30 million at the Karachi Airport.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: SOUTHERN Cumberland County is becoming bald eagle territory again through the management efforts of the state Department of Environmental Protection's Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife.

title: Poland Asks forTalks, ReaganGives a Lecture
description: Poland's leaders wanted to talk last week about lifting sanctions, but President Reagan, speaking to Polish-Americans, had other things in mind. Warsaw, having released nearly all its 652 political prisoners, said it was ready to negotiate the lifting of American sanctions that blocked Polish airline landings and scientific cooperation.

title: SENTENCING OF SEX OFFENDERS IN DISPUTE
description: AVENEL

title: POVERTY AND POLITICS IN THE SHANTYTOWNS OF PHILIPPINES
description: Rocita Curada and her three children live in what amounts to an urban cave about three feet high, four feet wide and eight feet long. To call it a room is to exaggerate. Not even Mrs. Curada's youngest child, seven-year-old Reynaldo, can stand upright in it. To enter, you must crawl. The principal amenity is a tiny kerosene burner whose flame provides what little light there is inside. The cubicle, fashioned of pieces of plywood and home to Mrs. Curada's family for six years, is in one of the clusters of poverty in Manila's Malate district, a neighborhood of one-room, jerry-built structures of wood and corrugated steel that often house three generations.

title: ABOUT CARS ; Driving More, Costing Less
description: JUST as there are night people

title: Did Mary Decker 'Deserve' Gold?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE EX-EXECUTIVE
description: When the scaffolding comes off the old Hotel Executive at 237 Madison Avenue next month, so, too, will its name. After a $6 million renovation, the hotel is being renamed Morgans as a salute to a distinguished neighbor, the Morgan Library.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a caption on page 25 of The Times Magazine today incorrectly describes the circumstances of a quotation from President Franklin D. Roosevelt. He wrote the line for a scheduled radio speech but died the day before he was to deliver it.

title: ROOM FOR SERIOUS CHILD'S PLAY
description: THE CLIENT ALWAYS HAS CERTAIN design priorities. For 7-year-old Tony, having enough space to play with his prized collection of model cars was more important than almost anything else. Fortunately, his and his parents' architects, Ben Benedict and Carl Pucci of BumpZoid, understood. Once upon a time, when they were little boys, they too enjoyed toy cars. Working from memory, the architects created a miniature city - a child's universe that fits inside a Manhattan apartment room that is only 13 feet by 13 feet.

title: CREME DE LA CREME SAMPLERS
description: Teach her what's useful, how to shun deluding, To roast, to toast, to boil and mix a Pudding. To knit, to spin, to sew, to make or mend, To scrub, to rub, to earn, and not to spend, I tell thee Wife, once more, I'll have her bred To Book'ry, Cook'ry, Thimble, Needle, Thread First teach her these, and then the pritty Fool Shall jig her Crupper at the dancing School.

title: Victoria Fullan Is Wed to Donough McDonough
description: At St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City, L.I., yesterday Victoria Dear Fullan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Vincent Fullan of Roosevelt, L.I., was married to Donough Patrick McDonough, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas McDonough of Garden City and Southold, L.I., Msgr. Emil A. Wcela performed the ceremony.

title: CUBS TOP REDS TO LEAD BY 2 1/2
description: Leon Durham's two-run single keyed a seven-run first inning and Rick Sutcliffe won his ninth straight game tonight as the Chicago Cubs held off the Reds, 13-11. The Reds committed four errors in the first inning.

title: BAYLOR AND YANKS RIP A'S, 8-0
description: A pitcher who has been incapacitated and a hitter who has been ineffective joined forces last night in the Yankees 8-0 victory over the Oakland A's.

title: LETTERS ; Renting to Mom
description: To the Editor:

title: Creative Cookery
description: I reread the passage in the article, ''Stuffed Mushrooms,'' (by Craig Claiborne with Pierre Franey, July 1), which states: ''There is no longer any such thing as a consummately original, shake-the-foundations recipe . . . The foundations of cookery have all been laid down and what the most creative among us do is to make variations of something that has gone before.''

title: JOHN LYDON'S NEW ALBUM MAKES MUTANT MUSIC
description: Ever since the birth of the blues, popular song form has been at the center of a tug of war. On one side is the notion of old-fashioned melody - the tradition that winds from plainsong through lieder, parlor songs and Broadway, in which a tune evolves for its entire length, each phrase following up on the one before.

title: Shari Klein Engaged To Steven Nemiroff
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Klein of Manhasset, L.I., and Delray Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Shari Robin Klein to Steven James Nemiroff, a son of Gloria Nemiroff of Roslyn Heights, L.I., and Palm Springs, Calif., and the late Philip Nemiroff.

title: Newton at PGA Event
description: Jack Newton, the Australian tour golfer who lost his right arm and right eye in an accident almost 13 months ago, is now covering golf as a feature writer for The Sydney Morning Herald. This last week the 42-year-old Newton has been attending the PGA Championship at Shoal Creek, Ala., in his first visit to the United States since the accident.

title: PILOBOUS DANCERS MAKING A HOME
description: AFTER 12 years of traipsing around the globe, members of the Pilobolus Dance Theater are starting to believe they can call Connecticut home.

title: HAPPINESS AND THE HARDWARE STORE
description: Geoffrey Norman's article, ''The Hardware Store'' (About Men, July 22), brought back happy memories of my visits with my father to our local hardware store. My father not only had the pleasure ''of not having to call in a professional'' but he had the greater pleasure of saving money by fixing it himself. ALLEN H. PLATT Philadelphia

title: Women Voters Found Equally Divided in Poll
description: A Gallup Poll released yesterday found that women voters were about equally divided between the Democratic and Republican Presidential tickets.

title: Angola Rebels Report Killing 108 Soldiers and 8 Cubans
description: Angolan rebels say their forces killed 108 Government troops and eight Cubans in four days of fighting this week across five provinces in the leftist-ruled southern African country.
