description: AIDING TORRINGTON STAGE

title: Fake Izod Shirts Seized
description: Customs investigators, tipped off by alligator trademarks that did not look right, seized 54,000 shirts bearing a poor likeness of the Izod LaCoste symbol, the authorities said Friday.

title: Ann Wilbur Has Nuptials
description: Ann Elizabeth Wilbur, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Benjamin Wilbur 3d of Geneseo, N.Y., and Manchester, Vt., was married yesterday to Andrew Houston McCulloch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Carruth McCulloch of Greenwich, Conn., Brattleboro, Vt., and New York. Canon Robert L. Clayton performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Chapel in Manchester.

title: Margaret D. McCarthy To Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. McCarthy Jr. of Santa Ana, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter Margaret Duncan McCarthy to David Grove Stoeffel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Stoeffel of Milwaukee.

title: SURVIVING THE SLUMP A LOG AT A TIME
description: With the slow brightening of the sky in the east shortly after 4 A.M., the ragged hulks of the mountains, some still carrying snow, start to take on shape. Gradually, the black mountainsides turn green as the sun touches thousands of towering pines with more and more light. The shape of the forest emerges to roll on as far as the eye can see in this isolated northwest corner of Montana. Dawn has come that way to many of these trees more than 30,000 times in the near century since they were seedlings.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM A POP CONCERT TO A PULITZER PLAY
description: Gotta Dance, Gotta Sing RKO Home Video 53 minutes. $39.95

title: WASTE SITES ON COAST DEBATED
description: Regional officials of the Environmental Protection Agency have asked that as many as 20 sites contaminated by underground leaks of chemicals near San Jose be added to the list of the nation's worst hazardous waste sites.

title: YOUTH HASN'T CHANGED, SOCIETY HAS
description: I GET angry and frustrated when I read about the support for more discipline, more homework and more money for teachers as the solution to the problems of American schools. Since a national commission alarmed us last year by stating that our nation is ''at risk'' because of the poor quality of public education, experts from President Reagan on down have opted for these simplistic solutions.

title: No Headline
description: Margaret Henly Is Bride

title: Power Plant Explosion Causes Hawaii Blackout
description: Parts of Hawaii's most populous island were blacked out for more than 10 hours early today by an explosion at a power plant that shut off electric water pumps and forced hospitals and the Honolulu airport to operate on emergency generators.

title: Elizabeth P. Mills Marries a Lawyer
description: Elizabeth Parker Mills, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willis N. Mills Jr. of Wilton, Conn., was married there yesterday to James Casey Healy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Healy Jr. of Winston-Salem, N.C. The Rev. Daniel B. Kunhardt, the bride's godfather, performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church.

title: THE SWEET AND THE SOUR OF A CRITIC'S BIG APPLE YEAR
description: Nearly a year ago I arrived in New York from London, to discover something curious about the city I'd known well in my footloose 20's, but had visited all too seldom since my jowls began to sag and the fuzz on them to grey. That was that absolutely everyone wanted to talk about the theater, and almost everyone had some connection with it. Before I'd recovered from my jetlag, I'd been driven across town by a cabbie who had toured Europe in ''Bubbling Brown Sugar,'' been shown an apartment by a man who ran a theater museum, been offered another by a retired actor, been sold a phone by a resting actor, bought a book from a woman who insisted on doing her imitation of John Gielgud, and, needless to say, been brought food and drink by an assortment of aspiring hoofers and assistant stage managers masquerading as waiters. That wasn't coincidence. That was what the pollsters call a statistically significant proportion of the local population.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM A POP CONCERT TO A PULITZER PLAY
description: Who's Afraid of Opera? Vol. 1: ''Faust'' and ''Rigoletto''; featuring Joan Sutherland MGM/UA Home Video 59 minutes. $29.95

title: AT LONG LAST Legal Switch After waging a 12-year, million-dollar legal fight, the United States Jaycees last week reversed position and voted overwhelmingly to admit women to full membership. Their president, Tommy Todd, insisted that his 270,000-member organization was ''in no way . . . compelled to do this.'' It was simply an ''opportune time'' to set ''a direction for others to follow.''
description: Opportune time indeed - just six weeks after the Supreme Court ruled that excluding women from Jaycee chapters in Minnesota violated that state's prohibition against discrimination in places of public accommodation.

title: Alice C. Hunter Is the Bride of Aubrey Huston 3d
description: Alice Carter Hunter, an elementary-school teacher in Princeton, N.J., and Aubrey Huston 3d, managing editor of The Princeton Packet, a newspaper published twice a week, were married yesterday. The Rev. Leon Oliver performed the ceremony at the Chilmark (Mass.)

title: POLITICAL SHOWDOWN ON SPACE IN FALL FORESEEN
description: Supporters of the nation's space program say they hope the Presidential contest between President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale this fall will help focus more attention on America's future in space exploration.

title: THOUSANDS IN BELFAST PROTEST ACTIONS OF THE POLICE
description: After three nights of riots, thousands of Protestants marched through Belfast today to protest what they said was police brutality against suspected Loyalist guerrillas and to demand an end to police use of informers.

title: DANIEL L. SKAFF WED TO SARA GRAVES NOLIN
description: Sara Graves Nolin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Travers Nolin of Neenah, Wis., formerly of Southport, Conn., was married yesterday to Daniel Lawrence Skaff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Skaff of Arcadia, Calif. The Rev. Stephen Chinlund performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport.

title: Lisa Lucille Irwin Marries in Jersey
description: Lisa Lucille Irwin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Hayward Irwin 2d, was married yesterday to Brian Thomas Keane, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Keane of Upper Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Vincent Keane, cousin of the bridegroom, and the Rev. James F. Loughlin, Roman Catholic priests, officiated at the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents in Essex Fells, N.J.

title: Miss Kelley Wed To Dana Rowan
description: Janice Marie Kelley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy A. Kelley of London and Needham, Mass., was married yesterday to Dana Craig Rowan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Rowan of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. James A. Woods performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Roman Catholic Church in Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: British Aide Accused Of Disclosing Secrets
description: A leading Defense Ministry official has been charged with wrongfully passing on information under Britain's Official Secrets Act.

title: BURGER ME NO BURGERS
description: Sherwin D. Smith, late of The New York Times Magazine, edited the On Language column from its inception.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: Amy Jones Is Married To Dr. John Hallberg
description: Amy Butler Jones, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William N. Jones of Old Mystic, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. John Andrew Hallberg, the son of Sarah Hallberg of Mystic, Conn., and Dr. Rudolph John Hallberg of Boulder, Colo. The Rev. William F. Loutrel, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at Calvary Episcopal Church in Stonington, Conn.

title: CARPENTRY CLASS HELPS REBUILD LIVES
description: At the school she now attends, Teresa Mullins is learning a new trade and a new vocabulary. During the last few weeks she has learned how to work a folding ruler into a tight spot between working tables, to ''strike'' a line for a measurement and to handle a saw so it doesn't wobble.

title: TANDY'S SHIFTING SALES STRATEGY
description: FORT WORTH

title: OUT WHERE THE EAST BEGINS
description: One of the things that characterizes any city is its art, and in Dallas there is the pair of bronzes on Federal Street. They are life-size: two men in business suits, shaking hands. The tableau, by J. Seward Johnson Jr. of the Johnson & Johnson family, is titled, ''At Long Last.''

title: Pope Planning Trip to Peru; Visit to War Area Is Possible
description: Pope John Paul II will come to Peru for at least three days in early February, the country's Roman Catholic Church authorities have announced.

title: THE AGE OF 'ME-FIRST' MANAGEMENT
description: ''Look at the economy as a great stew. And look at those hostile takeover-related activities, and all this related money-making with no risk by the Jay Gould types which are increasingly predominating in the capital scene, and look at them as salt. In the old days we had a minor amount of salt in the stew; and all of a sudden, somebody's pouring a hell of a lot more salt in the stew. . .'' Charles T. Munger, vice chairman, Berkshire Hathaway Inc., Omaha, in testimony May 23 before a Congressional subcommittee looking into corporate takeovers.

title: United to Reduce Its Fares On Some Flights to Chicago
description: United Airlines will cut fares on flights between nine Eastern cities and Chicago's O'Hare International Airport, a spokesman for the airline has said.

title: THE COMPUTER GIFT...
description: ON parents' night last October, the principal of a California elementary school rolled a newly donated Apple computer into the hallway for all to see. Moms and dads smiled approvingly as the principal wondered in silent panic, ''What are we going to do with one computer and 700 kids?''

title: LUXURY CAMP IN THE ADIRONDACKS UP FOR SALE
description: Camp Topridge, one of the last great camps of the very wealthy in the Adirondack Mountains, was put up for sale this week by its owner, New York State.

title:
EDUCATION ABROAD;
...IN CHINA, 3-YEAR COURSES
description: IN perfect English the postal clerk at the Urumqi airport asked, ''Do you want domestic or foreign stamps?'' Urumqi, an oasis in the Gobi Desert along China's ancient Silk Route, buzzes with the sound of Mandarin, the country's official language; the sound of a Western tongue, especially one's own, made a traveler start with pleased surprise.

title: CALIFORNIA SAYS MEXICAN FRUIT FLY IS CURBED
description: Agriculture officials here declared Thursday that they had stamped out the Mexican fruit fly, but officials in Santa Barbara County are worried that a Mediterranean fruit fly trapped there could be just ''the tip of the iceberg.''

title: OUT OF COLLEGE AND INTO THE RED
description: MICHAEL P. RADILOFF, a 20-year-old from Brooklyn, passed two milestones in June. He received his bachelor's degree from Swarthmore College, and his debts to finance his education passed the $10,000 mark. ''Paying for college was difficult,'' Mr. Radiloff said. ''My mother's salary as a teacher, our savings and other sources were insufficient to cover my educational expenses, so I took out loans from the Federal Government and a bank.''

title: FEDS RUN INTO AN ENTRAPMENT BACKLASH
description: The Justice Department, which had won a string of court battles in its Abscam sting operation, the first major test of its undercover investigative tactics, lost a big one last week with the acquittal of John Z. DeLorean. The not guilty verdict - from a jury that had watched videotapes of Mr. DeLorean planning a multimillion-dollar cocaine deal with undercover agents posing as drug traffickers - was a sharp rebuff for the Government's strategy of seeking to trap its quarry.

title: NAVRATILOVA BEATS CASALE IN SEMIFINAL
description: ''Every once in a while I feel insignificant and inadequate when I'm on the court with Martina,'' Pam Shriver said after being asked about her recent contributions to the world's best women's doubles team, herself and the seemingly unbeatabale Martina Navratilova. Miss Shriver isn't alone in her feelings.

title: Severe Drought in Mali
description: One- third of Mali's 6.3 millon people are seriously affected by a prolonged drought and the food situation in the country's southeastern province of Gao is described as catastrophic in a report issued today by the United Nations Disaster Relief Office.

title: BOMB-LIKE SCULPTURE CAUSES CLOSING OF AIRPORT TERMINAL
description: A $35 sculpture that looked like a bomb caused security officers to close the Trans World Airlines terminal at Los Angeles International Airport today for 1 1/2 hours until the police determined that the traveler carrying the device was simply ''naive.''

title: WORKERS WHO START-AND STAY-AT THE BOTTOM
description: If Mark Bocchetti puts in enough years at his job on the copy desk of The Baltimore Sun, he may match the editing skills of the veterans who work alongside him. He will not match their paychecks, though.

title: BOTH TASTE AND PRICE ARE RIGHT
description: It has long been our contention, where food is concerned, that taste has little to do with cost. Although we have ample admiration for truffles, foie gras and caviar, we can content ourselves with chicken in the pot or a simple platter of boiled beef and stuffed cabbage. We honestly prefer the wings of a chicken to its breast.

title: NEBRASKA REVISES HIRING RULES FOR CHURCH SCHOOLS
description: The State Board of Education has approved regulations allowing church schools to hire teachers without state certification.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Crown Wood Rallies to Win
description: Crown Wood, who only two years ago was racing as a pacer, rallied tonight to capture the $100,000 American Trotting Championship at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Miss Westbrook Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Gurley Westbrook, a daughter of Elizabeth Estey Westbrook of Troy, N.Y., and the late Prof. James Westbrook, to Bendel Shelby Hydes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Shelby Hydes of West Bay, Grand Cayman Island in the British West Indies, took place yesterday. The Rev. J. Seymour Flinn, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Schuyler Meadows Club in Loudonville, N.Y.

title: Sutcliffe Enjoys the Prospect Of Being Premier Free Agent
description: Last winter, Rick Sutcliffe, as was his right as a player with five years' major league service, demanded a trade by the Cleveland Indians. Among his list of six teams the Indians couldn't trade him to were the Chicago Cubs.

title: Leslie N. Oweida Weds M. C. Mole
description: Leslie Najia Oweida, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Nizar N. Oweida of Lower Burrell, Pa., and Matthew Cartwright Mole, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Edward Mole of Summit, N.J., were married yesterday. The Rev. Gregory Ofiesh performed the Eastern Orthodox ceremony at the Heinz Memorial Chapel at the University of Pittsburgh.

title: ISRAEL CAUTIONED ON DUTY-FREE PLAN
description: Israeli officials, who would like to establish a duty-free trade arrangement with the United States, were told by a visiting Congressional delegation this week that they would first have to eliminate subsidies to exporters.

title: GROWING UP IN STYLE
description: Mothers try their best to make do, but children always seem to need new clothes. Thus the search for wearable and practical clothes - with a touch of style thrown in - is a never- ending one. Last spring, the grown-up markets had a great deal of influence on children's wear, and this fall that trend is stronger than ever. Initially, children's fashion began as mere adaptations of adult clothing. Then, due to the pioneer styling of Florence Eiseman and others, clothes were designed that were uniquely for children. Today, though, there appears to be a movement back toward dressing children in clothes that suggest the adult world. One of the reasons for this is that many name designers of women's and men's wear, both here and abroad, have added children's lines - scaled-down and simplified versions of their grown-up clothes - with the same quality of design and styling that adults demand.

title: International
description: A missile struck an oil tanker in the Persian Gulf, according to reports received in Cairo. There was no serious damage to the ship, a fully loaded Panamanian tanker, and apparently no casualties. Neither Iraq nor Iran claimed responsibility for the attack, the second on a vessel in the same area in four days. (Page 1, Column 3.)

title: G.O.P. PARTY MACHINERY TURNS RIGHT
description: Representative Olympia J. Snowe testified last week before the Republican platform committee in support of the equal rights amendment. Carmel Sirianni, a delegate from Pennsylvania, questioned whether women really faced discrimination and whether laws would help them anyway. Mrs. Snowe replied that there is ''example after example where discrimination exists.'' And if laws won't help, the Representative from Maine continued, ''what is available to us?'' Mrs. Sirianni shot back: ''Hard work.''

title: TRANSITION SHAPED BY AN ELITE
description: Do national political conventions still serve a purpose? I strongly believe they do, particularly for the Republican Party, which is undergoing an important transition.

title: BLACKS AND JEWS SEEKING BETTER TIES
description: NEW ROCHELLE THEY had watched as recent events inflamed passions, heightened tensions and fueled misunderstanding between blacks and Jews across the nation and in their own city.

title: STUDENT OF LETTERS IN ERA OF NUMBERS
description: I SPEND my days with Old English 0: $12 and Chaucer. My housemates explore software and the endlessly proliferating languages of the computer. At night, if we gather for dinner, translation becomes a problem. We share the pressures of exam week or the exhilaration of a good session of karate, but we cannot discuss that all-consuming passion of graduate students - our work.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
description: VANDERBILT CONCOURS

title: Wary Eyes onUnesco's Books
description: Dissatisfied members of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization want their money back. Specifically, the United States, Britain, Switzerland and the Netherlands want their share of an $80 million surplus now in an account used by the Paris-based agency to offset currency fluctuations, and last week an official of Unesco said they would get it.

title: Atom Plant Operators Face Fewer Conditions
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission says it will assume that utilities that can afford to build nuclear power plants will have no trouble getting the money needed to operate them safely, even through higher electric rates if necessary.

title: HEY, DON'T FORGET THE AUDIENCE
description: In theory, any filmmaker has at least a passing interest in how audiences will respond to what he or she puts on the screen. In practice, we've all had moments - sitting in a darkened theater watching something that has absolutely no bearing on any form of human experience - when that proposition seemed more than a little doubtful. There are times when filmmakers seem to be entirely without understanding of their audience, when they seem concerned only with posterity, or perhaps with one another. Whatever they're thinking of, they certainly aren't thinking of you.

title: IS THERE HOPE FOR A COMEBACK OF TWO NATIVE TREES?;
description: American elm and American chestnut - two of the country's most magnificent trees - have been struggling against fungus diseases for decades. They are disappearing. Is it realistic to hope of seeing these native species again?

title: SUNSETS GLEAM ON A MAINE RETREAT
description: Walter Cronkite spends the night when he is sailing along the coast of Maine, Jacqueline Onassis has stopped by for dinner and Sidney Sheldon stayed to get a setting for his novel, ''Master of the Game.'' The object of their pilgrimmages is arguably the most idyllic inn on the long, jagged Maine shore, the Isleboro Inn in Dark Harbor.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
THE MODERN STILL FAVORS THE DOCUMENTARY APPROACH
description: The bad news from the Museum of Modern Art's summer show, ''Color Photographs: Recent Acquisitions,'' through October, is that the museum's principles of selection are about as narrow as they were before the recent period of reduced exhibition activity. In contemporary photography, the Modern still concentrates on ''straight'' or ''pure'' photography with a documentary look. There are no photographically based mixed-media effects, at least not in the photography department, and little or no ''high art'' photography of either the Pictorialist or the Modernist persuasion. Furthermore, the Modern still presents even the most emotionally charged documentary photographs at a cool distance from the reality they represent.

title: Cynthia Hill Becomes Bride
description: The marriage of Cynthia Ramage Hill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Donald Hill of Irvington, N.Y., to Pierce Archer took place yesterday at the Presbyterian Church in Irvington. The Rev. Frederick F. Jenkins performed the ceremony. Mr. Archer, a son of Charlotte Liebig Archer of Wynnewood, Pa., and the late John Hoffman Archer, is a stockbroker for W. H. Newbold's Son & Company in Philadelphia. The bride is an account systems engineer with I.B.M. Information Systems Services in Wayne, Pa.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
IN FACT, ASSETS BALANCE OUT LIABILITIES
description: Tales of the over-extended consumer are still making the

title: A CO-OP PROJECT FOR MIDDLE-INCOME ELDERLY
description: -THREE years ago, Elsie and

title: NEED LIBRETTOS BE REALLY UNDERSTOOD?
description: Opera is in its origins an Italian thing; it put down strong roots in France and Germany, and much weaker ones elsewhere - as a branch of composition, that is. In performance, French, German and especially Italian opera has established itself around the globe. Practically from the beginning, this has raised the question of whether, to what extent, and by what means the words and stories of operas should be made comprehensible to audiences that speak a language other than that of the libretto.

title: MARYLAND'S HIGH COURT RULES TEEN-AGERS MAY BE EXECUTED
description: Maryland's highest court has declared that some teen-agers convicted of murder are not too young to be sentenced to death for their crimes.

title: ; Early Inductees Are Also Uneven
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: JAMAICA CONSIDERS CASINOS TO HELP ECONOMY
description: Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga has told Jamaicans that casino gambling might help ease the country's economic problems.

title: HOW THREE MEN WOUND UP IN CENTER FOR SEX OFFENDERS
description: -year-old former Air Force linguist, forced his stepdaughter to have sexual relations with him when she was 11; when she grew older and resisted, he turned to her 9-year-old sister.

title: Few Fiddle WithAuto Insurance
description: New Jersey motorists apparently don't know a good deal when they see it, state insurance officials said last week. They may also be having trouble seeing it.

title: WHAT'S NEW AT MCDONALD's ; INTRODUCING THE MCDONALD'S COMPLEX
description: In November, McDonald's plans to begin construction at a 30-acre site that will house not only one of its restaurants, but also a motel, gas station and convenience store. The complex, to be called McStop, will be located near an interstate highway north of Minneapolis and will be geared to motorists.

title: 29 Members of Church Group Hurt in Bus Accident Upstate
description: Twenty-nine members of a church group returning from an outing at Bear Mountain were injured today when their bus overturned on the Palisades Parkway here after a tire blew out.

title: A DAY'S SAIL ABOARD THE CLEARWATER
description: WHILE river towns along the Hudson struggled through another hot and humid summer morning last week, aboard the Hudson River sloop Clearwater a 12-knot breeze filled every inch of the ship's 2,900-foot mainsail, and the big boat danced back and forth between Westchester and the Palisades.

title: HONOR THY BILL OF RIGHTS
description: Most political observers expect the delegates to the Republican National Convention to ratify the positions of President Reagan and the Republican Party's platform committee without major policy debate. Yet there is one issue that deserves far more thoughtful attention than it has thus far received: the separation of church and state. Moreover, when this constitutional distinction is blurred, social policy suffers.

title: The Jets Lose Their Giant
description: Joe Klecko, the Jets' strongest player, walked on crutches through the tunnel and onto the sidelines when the third quarter started tonight against the Giants.

title: OUSTED WORKER WINS A SUIT UNDER TOXIC CHEMICAL LAW
description: A judge here has ruled that a local company illegally dismissed a pregnant woman who refused to work with toxic chemicals unless given information about them.

title: IN EACH OTHER'S COMPANY
description: Herbert Gold's

title: Lewis Is Defeated in London
description: Kirk Baptiste of the United States upstaged Carl Lewis by breezing past the four-time Olympic gold medalist tonight in the straight on his way to a world record for 300 meters. Lewis finished fourth.

title: Albert E. Holland, President OfHobartCollegeinthe60's
description: Albert E. Holland, a former president of Hobart and William Smith Colleges, died of complications from a bacterial infection Friday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 72 years old and lived in Wellesley, Mass.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Observing the Dog: Idiot or Savant? I refer to ''Frisky, How Could You?'' by Ruth Jernick (Opinion Page, July 1), in which she questions whether the dog is idiot or savant.

title: WOMEN SEEN AS HOLDING KEY TO CANADA VOTE
description: There are signs that the votes of women may turn out to be a pivotal factor in Canada's national elections next month.

title: PUBLIC-PRIVATE COLLEGE RIVALRY HEATS UP
description: THE once-genteel relations among institutions of higher education, traditionally conducted in an ivory-tower atmosphere of hushed voices, have taken on the strident tones of a street brawl as competition for students and funds has begun to supersede other concerns. Battles over funding and student aid between officials of publicly and privately financed colleges in New York State and elsewhere have spilled over into the view of students, donors and legislators as both sides have stepped up efforts to protect their separate interests. And more confrontation is expected.

title: Georgia'sSurprises
description: The state that produced Gov. Lester Maddox, who campaigned with ax handles, and Gov. Jimmy Carter, who stumped with smiles, continues to offer up notable politics.

title: Reagan Counts Down In Latest Voice Check
description: Avoiding last week's mishap, President Reagan stuck to the standard voice check today for his weekly radio address.

title:
ANTIQUES;
AS INVESTMENTS, ANTIQUESREQUIRE A DISCERNING EYE
description: -arcade at the Hickory Square Shopping Center here is Challenge Acre Antiques, which concentrates on 18th- and 19th- century formal and country furniture and appropriate accessories.

title: FOR THE AMISH IN MINNESOTA, JUSTICE MOVES IN SLOW LANE
description: Normally, the Amish of southeastern Minnesota are a law-abiding people. They help strangers, wave to passers- by and make no trouble for their neighbors.

title: PopulationPolitics
description: It was perhaps inevitable that before the United Nations Conference on Population finished its head counting, some toes would get stepped on. First, six members of Congress attending last week's sessions in Mexico City complained about the Reagan Adminstration's new policy of denying funds to private organizations that ''perform or actively promote'' abortion.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
THREE CHEERS FOR THE FUTILITY ROOM
description: IDEAS and plans featured in

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Aug. 19, 1984Fiction1 AUGUST, by Judith Rossner. (Warner, $4.50.) The five-year relationship of two women, a teen-age patient and her analyst. 2 HOLLYWOOD WIVES, by Jackie Collins. (Pocket, $3.95.) The struggle for money and power in Tinseltown. 3 THURSTON HOUSE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $3.95.) Three generations of a San Francisco family. 4

title: CAMP SETS GOALS FOR THE DISABLED
description: '' IM not your mother and not your father,'' Charles Kunzweiler says to arriving campers. ''I'm not going to do for you what you can do for yourself.''

title: WILD PITCH IN 9TH HELPS TOP METS, 6-5
description: The Mets, who beat the San Francisco Giants on a home run in the 10th inning Friday night, laid an egg for an encore today: They lost in the ninth inning, 6-5, on a wild pitch and a sacrifice fly.

title: Christen S. Frothingham Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. A. Michael Frothingham of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christen Struthers Frothingham, to William Scott Wheeler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm F. Wheeler of Darien, Conn., and Newport, R.I. A January wedding is planned.

title: WHEN CHILDREN DON'T CAMP
description: DURING the summer, there are two kinds of parents in the suburbs: Those whose children are at camp and those whose children are home. It is easy to tell them apart. The former have quiet dinners for two in local restaurants, go to the movies on weekday nights and have just seen the latest show at the Whitney. The latter are identified by a distinct squint acquired through hours of driving in the summer sun to transport their offspring from one activity to another. They can also be recognized by a marked unwillingness to talk to anyone whose childen have gone to camp.

title: LETTERS ; Automation
description: To the Editor:

title: 'TREES AND TRAILS' SHOW
description: Trees and Trails, an exhibition of paintings and drawings by six artists that focus on aspects of New York City's parks, will be on display at the Arsenal Gallery from Sept. 10 through Oct. 5. The gallery is in Central Park near 64th Street and Fifth Avenue. Hours are Monday through Friday, 9:30 A.M. to 9:45 P.M.

title: A VISIONARY ARTIST'S NEW OUTLOOK
description: As a fellow artist and mother, I read the article on Susan Rothenberg with some fascination. One paragraph leaped out at me: ''I spent a long time deciding to dare to do such a sentimental picture (of a grandmother and child).

title: SIGNS OF THE TIMES: ELECTRONIC UNIVERSITY
description: CHERYL SKILLERN, a geophysicist with an oil company in Tulsa, Okla., signed up for an adult education course entitled Memory Training Techniques. Kathleen Wasylczenko, a working mother from Paterson, N.J., enrolled in a class to improve her word power and writing skills. And Mark Teague, a teleprocessing analyst based in Seattle, has been studying various strategies to improve his financial situation in a course entitled Moonlight With Your Microcomputer.

title: Peking Reported to BuyItems for Nuclear Plants
description: China has signed a contract to buy monitoring equipment from West Germany for nuclear power plants, the Peking newspaper China Daily reported today.

title: Sports of The Times ; A Flowery Debut
description: CINCINNATI ''LOOKS like somebody died,'' said Pete Rose, observing the several bouquets of red roses and boxes of flowers - presumably roses, for that was the flower of the hour - as he entered the Reds' manager's office Friday evening.

title: SOME MISCUES ON THE WAY TO A CORONATION
description: WASHINGTON AS they prepare for the Republican National Convention in Dallas this week, Ronald Reagan's legions can hardly believe their good fortune. Riding high in the polls again, the President seems eager to accept the Grand Old Party's made-for- television salute. Yet there were signs last week that Mr. Reagan has still to exorcise the political problems that have bedeviled him since he came to the White House.

title: KLECKO HURT
description: The difficult summer took an upturn for the Giants tonight, but the Jets found new trouble to go with old. The Giants defeated the Jets, 20-14, in the Jets' first game at Giants Stadium since they made it their home field.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a review of Elinor Langer's ''Josephine Herbst'' (Aug. 5), the year when Miss Herbst went to Washington with her husband, where he was sent to help organize Communist underground groups among New Dealers, was incorrectly given.

title: 2 DEMOCRATS VYING TO RUN UPHILL HOUSE RACE
description: Two Democrats are waging a heated battle for their party's nomination to run in November against Representative Guy V. Molinari, one of the city's two Republicans in the House.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
IS EXPECTANT A FOREVER THING?
description: TWO weeks ago our obstetrician assured us it could happen any time now. And for two weeks we have gone to sleep each night wondering if we have just spent the last day of our lives without children. But the days pass, my wife grows larger and still we wait, poised with expectancy, attuned as never before to her every abdominal twinge, to every celestial sign, even to every fortune cookie, searching for the beginning of the thread that will lead us to that mystical realm where babies are born.

title: JAZZ: JORDAN ON GUITAR IN THE VILLAGE
description: By playing with both hands on the neck of his electric guitar, and tapping each amplified string as he pushes it down, Stanley Jordan turns the guitar into a kind of keyboard. He can play complex, pianistic counterpoint, yet he can bend strings and slide notes like any other guitarist.

title: THE SECRETS OF CRETE
description: Robert W. Stock is a senior editor of The Times Magazine. Caryl Stern, a freelance writer, assisted in the research and writing of this article.

title: Biotechnology
description: To the Editor:

title: No Cowboy Guarantees
description: Randy White, the all-pro defensive tackle of the Dallas Cowboys, wants a contract guaranteeing him $1.2 million a year over four or five years, but team officials say a guarantee would go against the competitive nature of the game. The Cowboys say they are willing to make White, a holdout at training camp, the highest paid defensive lineman in the National Football League, topping Mark Gastineau of the Jets, who makes $750,000 a year.

title: WEIGHT LOSS: PLAYING FOR KEEPS
description: -SUIT SEASON IS dieting season. With figure problems uncloaked each summer, hundreds of thousands of Americans take cover under the jackets of diet books in an attempt to streamline their proportions.

title: PRIVATE FUNDS FOR PUBLIC ROAD
description: WHEN a group of property owners and tenants in the Hauppauge industrial park recognized they could no longer wait for the state to allocate funds for the construction of entrance and exit ramps on nearby Northern State Parkway - ramps, they say, that would ease the park's traffic congestion problem - they undertook a plan that officials say is unprecedented in the history of the state parkway system.

title: ALICE, RALPH, TRIXIE AND ED-A RECORD HONEYMOON
description: One school of critical thought says there was a golden age of television; another, the larger one, says that television flourishes artistically now as never before. However we regard this solemn matter, it is clear that shows from the golden age (whenever it was supposed to be) have one great advantage: They've stood the test of time. Good ones linger on, turning up in syndication. Some of them not only linger, they generate fan clubs, congresses of people whose devotion to old episodes is so intense they can recite every line. Whatever the fascination these television programs hold for the loyalists, it is obvious that they attract the rest of us, too. Fan clubs alone do not keep programs in syndication; large audiences do. Something about the old programs gets us where we live.

title: MOTHER OF AUTHOR TOOLE DIES Thelma Ducoing Toole, whose unflagging belief in her son's writing led to the posthumous publication of John Kennedy Toole's ''Confederacy of Dunces,'' died Friday in a New Orleans hospital after a long illness. She was 82 years old and lived in New Orleans.
description: Mr. Toole, who had written the novel while he was in the Army in the late 1950's, tried for years to get it published. A college teacher, he committed suicide in 1969 at the age of 32 by inhaling automobile exhaust fumes.

title: MANILA COURT REBUFFS MARCOS ON AQUINO RALLIES
description: The Supreme Court rebuffed the Government today and approved plans for demonstrations next Tuesday to mark the first anniversary of the assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr.

title: TV SCHOOL FOR 500,000 THAIS...
description: FIFTEEN MINUTES before his class in political science begins, Orlan Kongparsuk leaves the table under a thatched roof where he's been studying with friends, enters a building and climbs five stories to a vast hall seating 2,000 to find a seat close to one of 20 television monitors that are dangling from the ceiling. On the ground floor the teacher will lecture to another packed hall of 2,000 while his televised performance is screened on each floor above him.

title: Blast on Ship in Belgium
description: One man was killed and another was seriously injured today after an explosion started a fire on a dredger just outside the port of Zeebrugge, port officials said. A third man was missing from the 11-member crew of the ship, the Vlaanderen 18. Maritime traffic to and from the port was halted for about eight hours.

title: SINCERELY, SHAKESPEARE'S KING
description: George Garrett's latest novel is ''The Succession,'' based on the life of Elizabeth I and James I. LETTERS OF KING JAMES VI & I

title: Elizabeth Thomas Weds John Hastings in Maine
description: At St. George Episcopal Chapel in Long Cove, Me., yesterday Elizabeth Rogers Thomas, a daughter of Mrs. Hayward Hutchinson Chappell of Princeton, N.J., and Stephen Larned Thomas of Washington, was married to John Decker Hastings, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Peter Hastings of Skowhegan, Me. The Rev. David B. Van Dusen performed the ceremony.

title: A COLLEGE FOR BLACKS: ONE WHITE'S FIGHT
description: KENDLETON, Tex.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs Oakland A's , at Yankee Stadium, 2 P.M. Dennis Rasmussen, seeking his eighth victory, goes against Ray Burris, seeking his 12th. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Giants , at San Francisco, doubleheader, 3:05 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 3 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 3 P.M.) Golf Ladies P.G.A. MasterCard International Pro-Am . This is the final day. Only the pros will be playing, and only at Wykagyl in New Rochelle, 9:42 A.M.

title: Space Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: AFFORDABILITY INDEX
description: Those in the market for a home do not need sophisticated statisticians to tell them that mortgage rates are too high for millions of American families. But for what it's worth, the National Association of Realtors says its most recent calculations show that in June, the average effective interest rate on home loans - including adjustable and fixed- rate mortgages - was 12.25 percent, 2 percentage points or more too high for half the nation's households.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
CONSTRUCTING AND MAINTAINING ROADS IS NECESSARY FOR ECONOMIC WELL-BEING
description: AT a time of governmental austerity, there suddenly seems to be an almost unlimited amount of money available for new roads, for rebuilding roads, for replacing bridges, for bringing public-transit systems to an acceptable level of safety and quality and for needed improvements to airports and waterways. For example, consider the multibillion-dollar financing that is available for the construction of the Westway - as soon as an acceptable plan is found.

title: LOPEZ POSTS 65-208 FOR 2-SHOT LEAD
description: Nancy Lopez, making up 8 shots in 14 holes, shattered two tournament and two course records today as she shot a seven-under-par 65 for the third-round lead in the Chevrolet World Championship of Women's Golf.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: JOAN B. WAITE'S cultural link with Africa began in the 1960's, when she and her husband, Robert , lived in Nigeria, where he set up the country's first electronics company.

title: CLOSE ENCOUNTERS WITH DEMOCRACY
description: ''IT makes you feel really good when they notice you. It's me and my questions they're answering. It's not as if government's in a glass ball and I can't be a part of it.''

title: COSMOS ADDING DAVIS, 2 OTHERS
description: Wladyslaw Zmuda of Poland is not a sweeper in the category of Franz Beckenbauer or Carlos Alberto, and Giuseppe Damiani ot Italy is not quite the Dennis Tueart or Steve Hunt-type of forward who created plenty of excitement for the Cosmos in recent years.

title: ALL WAS LOST, YET SOMETHING WAS PSRESERVED
SUPERFUND: ROUND 2 AHEAD IN CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON REPRESENTATIVE James J. Florio, Democrat of Pine Hill, and his environmentalist allies are still savoring House passage of an expanded $10.2 billion Superfund meant to clean up the nation's worst hazardous waste dumps.

title: MUSIC: STRAUSS'S SETTING OF MOZART'S 'IDOMENEO'
description: Purely on logical grounds, it is not easy in 1984 to justify resurrecting Richard Strauss's heavily revised edition of ''Idomeneo,'' as Gerard Schwarz did on Friday night at the Mostly Mozart Festival. An audience that knows, either on record or in live performance, the historically faithful version that Daniel Hertz edited in 1972 really does not need a cropped and recomposed ''Idomeneo,'' even if its author was himself a certified great composer. But, putting pure logic aside for the moment, there was an undeniable fascination in hearing what changes Strauss thought this noble opera needed if it were ever to be palatable to a large public. His was an effort much like Mozart's own arranging of Handel's ''Messiah,'' which also grants us a look into the mind of genius, however misguided the genius may seem from a modern viewpoint.

title: A PICK-ME-UP IN DALLAS
description: DALLAS President Reagan has recently suffered enough political aches and pains that the Republican National Convention - even as stupefying as it promises to be - comes none too soon. He needs the lift a nominating convention almost always gives the nominee, particularly an incumbent President.

title: The AirlinesMay Get a Traffic Cop
description: The Reagan Administration has concluded that, in the case of the airlines, a temporary retreat from deregulation may be in order to unclog the nation's runways.

title: No Headline
description: Miss Kennedy a Bride

title: IN CASE OF SURVIVAL
description: THE DAY AFTER WORLD WAR III

title: A VISIONARY ARTIST'S NEW OUTLOOK
description: It was impressive how much of an impact Susan Rothenberg's first horse painting had on the Minimalism- saturated art public of the middle 1970's.

title: Jefferson's Rotunda
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: New & Noteworthy WHO WAS WHO IN THE GREEK WORLD: 776 BC- 30 BC, and WHO WAS WHO IN THE ROMAN WORLD, edited by Diana Bowder. (Pocket Books, $8.95 each.) ''Who Was Who in the Greek World'' was published in 1982, ''Who Was Who in the Roman World,'' in 1980. Our reviewer, D. J. R. Bruckner, wrote that these are ''invaluable guides.'' ''In lucid, brief and accurate entries, they bring to life the people who shaped civilization in the West from the eighth century B.C. until the collapse of Rome in A.D. 476.''

title: HEROICS OF IMAGINATION
description: SELECTED POEMS STIES By Octavio Paz. Edited by Eliot Weinberger. Translated by G. Aroul, Elizabeth Bishop, Paul Blackburn, Lysander Kemp, Denise Levertov, Muriel Rukeyser, Mark Strand, Charles Tomlinson, William Carlos Williams, Monique Fong Wust and the editor. 147 pp. New York: New Directions. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $4.95.

title: Lilco GetsA 9.6% ShowOf Support
description: Having failed to find a friend at Chase Manhattan or any other bank, the Long Island Lighting Company found one last week in Albany. The State Public Service Commission granted Lilco a 9.6 percent electricity rate increase to help stave off a possible bankruptcy.

title: WILDLIFE MAKING COMEBACK IN CITY
description: To the average New Yorker, fighting the daily onslaught of noise and smog, the city might appear to be something of an ecological disaster zone.

title: NEAR BASTOGNE, DISTANT DRUMS
description: JAMES M. MARKHAM is chief of the Bonn bureau of The Times.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
WHAT WE DO NOT DO ANYMORE
description: WHOEVER made the statement that Connecticut is the land of steady habits probably is not around anymore, which is too bad, considering that this has often been considered an enlightened observation. The observer, however, would probably enjoy a new vision of our state.

title: HOW PUBLIC COLLEGES WOO THE BEST
description: AT the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, freshman applicants this year are up 25 percent; at the University of California at Santa Cruz, 24 percent; and at Western Illinois University in Macomb, which one administrator described as a small, regional public school off the beaten track, there was a 4.3 percent increase in freshman applications and a 20 percent rise in transfers from community colleges.

title: A COLLECTION OF FILM FAVORITES
description: YEARS ago, when Hartford's State Theater was referred to as ''New England's Showplace,'' Bill Schnebeeli was the backstage manager. Although much time has passed since that popular vaudeville house became a part of history, Mr. Schnebeeli is still showing movies.

title: ; 'Essential Role'
description: To the Editor:

title: PURSUER OF LOST MAIDENS
description: THE ENGINEER OF HUMAN SOULS An Entertainment on the Old Themes of Life, Women, Fate, Dreams, the Working Class, Secret Agents, Love and Death. By Josef Skvorecky. Translated by Paul Wilson. 571 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: LETTERS ; Trading Up
description: To the Editor:

title: IN ENGLAND, KENT MINES FEAR WORST
description: For most of Kent County, it is summer as usual. The pace of commuter life has slackened at Kent's western reaches, which border on London. Farmers are tending the orchards and the fields of hops and grains that have earned the county the nickname ''England's Garden.'' Tourists are flocking to Canterbury and the English Channel resorts, and village greens are crowded with cricket players.

title: ROCK-CUT TEMPLE OF THE MANY-FACED GOD
description: Michael Specter holds a Henry R. Luce Fellowship and is a correspondent for The Far Eastern Economy Review.

title: 14 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 14 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: Stephanie D. Spillane Is Wed to John Ways
description: The marriage of Stephanie Dana Spillane, a daughter of Charlotte Ford Spillane of Toms River, N.J., and the late Bernard F. Spillane, to John St. Onge Ways, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Ways of New York, took place yesterday. The Rev. John C. Pfisterer performed the Lutheran ceremony at Admiral Farragut Academy in Pine Beach, N.J.

title: PRIVATE COLLEGES: THE FIGHT TO STAY ALIVE
description: IN 1972, a year before a tornado leveled much of its campus, Arkansas College was listed by a national magazine as one of the small, independent ''invisible'' schools that would not survive into the 1980's. The four-year Presbyterian liberal-arts college in rural Batesville had 340 students, a physical plant worth about $6 million, an endowment of $829,000 and a $3 million debt. ''We were kicking to keep afloat,'' recalled Richard Thomas, the college's vice president for finance.

title: ARTICHOKES AS A CROP STUDIED IN STATE
description: GROW artichokes in Connecticut? Why not, asks Dr. David Hill, a botanist with the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station in Hamden. If his experiments continue to be successful, the state may be soon be joining California in the commercial production of the vegetables.

title: POSTINGS ; 'COLONIAL' SHOPS
description: In the mid-1970's, a fire destroyed an automobile showroom and several small stores at Madison and Washington Avenues in Dumont, N.J., and left a rubble-strewn lot. Local officials were eager to see the property redeveloped and restored to commercial life, but they rejected as unsuitable for the important intersection several proposals for fast- food restaurants and late-night convenience stores.

title: ANSWERING CITY'S ETHNIC QUESTIONS
description: Mayor Koch likes to say that what is different about the United States, and New York City in particular, is that ''the tribal rivalries'' of Europe, Asia and Africa have disappeared. ''Enemies overseas, their children are friends in the United States,'' he says.

title: SOUTHERN CULTURE GETS ITS OWN ENCYCLOPEDIA
description: There is to be a long section on Southern prisons and a short one on Rebel Yell bourbon. Someone is to discuss the impact air-conditioning has had on Southern economic development; someone else is to write about possums.

title: Illegal AliensAt the Tolls
description: Internationalism may be the currency of New York, but not where the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority is concerned. The use of cheap Mexican pesos instead of tokens at six of the authority's bridges and tunnels is increasing, according to a report last week in The New York Times.

description: Lisa Ellen Thorpe and Elliott Scott Brown were married yesterday at the Old Lyme (Conn.)

description: A FEW weeks before the Summer Games began, Al Oerter was talking about the open mood in the Olympic villages when he was winning the discus in 1956-60-64-68.

title: DRUNKEN DRIVING PORTRAYED ON FILM
description: -Old Lyme High School are concerned about the tragic effects of drunken driving and doing something about it.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
WHY SYSTEM-WIDE REFORM IS CRITICAL
description: SEVERAL debtor countries have made greater progress in adjusting their economies than seemed possible only a few months ago. Brazil's export performance, in particular, is way ahead of target and the Brazilian economy is now likely to show a small improvement in 1984, rather than a further decline. Argentina remains the major trouble spot.

title: HOW WEST SIDE NEIGHBORS RESCUED AN S.R.O. HOTEL
description: Late in the afternoon of Nov. 18, 1983, Carol

title: INQUIRY MAY WEIGH HATFIELD FINANCIAL FORMS
description: The Justice Department inquiry into Senator Mark O. Hatfield's dealings with a Greek entrepreneur is likely to touch on whether the Senator made proper disclosure of $55,000 his wife received, according to department officials.

title: FULL DISCLOSURE IS NOW A FAMILY AFFAIR
description: WASHINGTON DURING confirmation hearings in 1974 on Nelson A. Rockefeller's nomination as Vice President, the Senate was never able fully to determine whether his financial dealings constituted conflict of interest, or how much disclosure was enough. Mr. Rockefeller's fortune was so intertwined with those of his brothers that it was difficult to separate the national interest from Rockefeller interests. A decade later, such concern continues.

title: CAREER PROGRAMS: HOW TO DECIDE
description: SIX months after Janice Naiman received a master's degree in English, she enrolled in computer programming classes at New York University's School of Continuing Education. ''I wanted a career that had more options and was more future- oriented than teaching creative writing,'' explained Miss Naiman, who decided to learn more about programming after landing a freelance job writing for a computer magazine. The six courses she completed in a certificate program were the key to her being hired by the Monchik- Weber Corporation, which offers computer-software services to write its in-house newsletter.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
IN PRAISE OF THE SCAVENGER OF THE SUBURBS
description: '' CAW! CAW! CAW!'' The neighbors probably think I am daft, but the crows usually come when called that way. They have been in training since last winter, and now know well that my crowing each morning means a handout is coming.

title:
CAMERA;
ON THE MERITS OF FASTER COLOR PRINT FILMS
description: Lou Jacobs Jr. is the author of several books on photography.

title: Kristen Hughes and R. Stephen Lilly Are Married
description: Kristen D'Oyly Hughes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D'Oyly Hughes of Lakeville, Conn., was married there yesterday to R. Stephen Lilly of Scituate, Mass., and New Boston, N.H., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfed S. Lilly Jr. of DeLand, Fla. The Rev. Charles Bevan performed the Episcopal ceremony at the chapel of the Hotchkiss School.

title: AMERICAN JEWS SPLIT ALONG ORTHODOX AND REFORM LINES
description: In an unusual display of religious partisanship, 16 major American Jewish organizations last week denounced Israel's Orthodox rabbis for trying to toughen the rules by which converts are admitted to Israel as citizens. The groups warned that amending the ''law of return'' to virtually bar Reform and Conservative converts - which is what five religious parties in Israel's Parliament are demanding - could cost Israel American Jewish support.

title: AMERICAN ART GAINS NEW ENERGIES
description: I t is a dull summer that does not bring us a new book of poems by John

title: A LONG LINE OF BLACKSMITHS
description: THE blacksmithing Kriz family of Bethany travels around the country shoeing horses for the stars, as well as horses that are stars in their own right.

title: CONVENT FOR SALE
description: Word that the Little Sisters of the Assumption, a Roman Catholic order, is selling the 19th-century convent it has owned and occupied since 1954 at 81st Street and Lexington Avenue has spurred a rush of pleas to the Landmarks Preservation Commission seeking landmark designation for the four-story, Victorian Gothic building.

title: HOW TO SWITCH COLLEGES
description: EACH year thousands of college students decide for one reason or another that they would prefer a different school. Most seem to think that, after having been accepted to one school, transferring to another will be ''a cinch,'' as one student put it. But depending on their record, their academic needs, the equivalency of courses taken, requirements of the new department and the attrition rate at the college that interests them, the process may be tougher than the student expects.

title: SMALL TALK
description: I was never any good at talking to children. Even as a child I couldn't get the hang of it. When grown-ups hauled me out from under the couch and said, ''Go outside and talk to some children,'' I was miserable because I knew what would happen.

title: MOSCOW CRITICIZES REAGAN ON YALTA
description: The Soviet Union, reacting to President Reagan's remarks on the division of Europe, today accused him of distorting history and defaming both the Soviet Union and Poland.

title: BRAZILIAN CAMPAIGN OFFERS EVERYTHING BUT VOTERS
description: The campaign to pick Brazil's first civilian President in 20 years has begun with all the trappings of democracy except the people's right to vote.

title: TAXES MOVE TO FOREFRONT OF CAMPAIGNS
description: TRENTON TAXES have elbowed their way to the forefront in the Presidential and United States Senate campaigns and continue to occupy the thoughts of many state legislators as they try to read the mood of the electorate and the economic trends.

title: October Wedding For Miss Lamere
description: Mrs. J. Richard Lamere of Duxbury, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter Lynette Kent Lamere to Kevin Gill Abrams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Abrams of Wilmington, Del. The wedding is to take place Oct. 6.

title: An Olympic Flag On Victory Lap
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SPECIAL TAX T AID IN REPAIR OF ROUTE 119
description: GREENBURGH WHEN a road is becoming congested and the state is reluctant to improve it right away, how do you get the state to add it to its list of priority projects?

title: AN OLD SUBWAY TUNNEL AND A YOUNG MAN'S DREAM
description: When a 140-year-old railway tunnel was rediscovered under Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn, a local sculptor asked to exhibit art there, movie producers wanted to use it as a set and a pet adoption agency thought it would be the ideal place to give away stray cats and dogs.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Self-Made Hero The Olympics had ended, but the call to glory still hung in the Los Angeles air last week. And one who heard it apparently contrived his own event in a bid for a bit of adulation.

title: SUBSCRIPTION SERIES TO OPEN
description: EARLY subscribers to the many superb concert series in and around the county can reap a variety of benefits, including better seats, lower prices and the knowledge that they will not face ''sold out'' signs when the bigger- name artists come to town. September is only a couple of weeks away, and with it the opening of what looks like an unusually fruitful fall. Here is a brief survey of a few of the musical enticements ahead.

title: TV EVANGELISTS ASSUME LARGER CONVENTION ROLE
description: In a ballroom of the Hilton Hotel here Friday morning, the television evangelist Dr. M. G. (Pat) Robertson looked around with satisfaction as he made a proud claim.

title: RISE IN LYME DISEASE CITED
description: BECAUSE of a marked increase in reported cases of Lyme disease, caused by bacteria carried on deer ticks and by some rodents, doctors in the county and the surrounding area have admonished their patients to ''stay out of the woods'' during the remaining summer months and into October.

title: WEDDING IN OCTOBER FOR AMY N. LOWRY
description: Amy Newman Lowry and Robert William Poole plan to be married in October. Mr. and Mrs. Donald I. Lowry of Cincinnati have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mrs. Donald L. Philbrick of Portland, Me., and the late Burnell Poole Jr. of Englewood, N.J.

title: REAGAN'S ADVISERS PICTURE MONDALE AS A POOR LEADER
description: President Reagan's strategists and Republican spokesmen today used the controversy over Geraldine A. Ferraro's finances for a broadside attack on Walter F. Mondale's qualities as a leader.

description: ALICE AT 80

title: MONDALE LAUDS ZACCARO DISCLOSURE DECISION
description: Walter F. Mondale gave his Vice-Presidential nominee a big vote of confidence today as she announced in New York that her husband's tax records, as well as her own, would be disclosed Monday.

title: John R. Redmond Jr. Wed To Nancy Fagan in Illinois
description: Nancy Jean Fagan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Fagan of Northbrook, Ill., was married there yesterday to John Richard Redmond Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Redmond of West Orange, N.J. The Rev. Allan Peterkin performed the ceremony at St. Norbert's Roman Catholic Church.

title: A COZY TOUCH OF ENGLAND
description: IF you are nostalgic for a touch of England,

title: WALL STREET'S BULLISH ECONOMIST
description: Last year, institutional portfolio managers voted

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
STYLES MAY CHANGE, BUT ROCK-AND-ROLL SURVIVES
description: DANNY and the Juniors once insisted in song that rock 'n' roll is here to stay, it will never die, that it was meant to be that way, though they didn't know why. After folk rock, mellow rock, disco, punk rock and new wave, is there anything today that can really be called rock 'n' roll? Twenty- five years after Danny's brash prophecy, does even a tenuous connection exist between Bill Haley and the Comets and the B-52's? Has popular music progressed over the past generation or has it just gotten stranger?

title: THE MOUNTAIN MAN AS NOVELIST
description: JESSE

title: Japan Reports North Koreans Have Seized a Fishing Boat
description: North Korea has seized a Japanese fishing boat with a crew of eight in the Sea of Japan, an official of Japan's Fishery Agency said today.

title: Navy Reinstates Man After Drug Discharge
description: A chief petty officer has been reinstated by the Navy after arguing that he should not have been discharged solely on the basis of a drug test, his lawyer says. The chief petty officer, James A. Shell, discharged 14 months ago after a routine urinalysis showed traces of marijuana, was reinstated Friday by an assistant to Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. who agreed that the test alone was no reason for a discharge.

title: LETTERS
description: ARGUING AGEE

title: HOW TO INSURE LONG-LASTING RESULTS IN PAINTING METAL
description: PAINTING metal around the inside or outside of the house usually involves some extra preparatory steps - and in many cases a special primer or first coat - if you want to insure long-lasting results. This is true even though in many cases you will use the same paint for the finish coat that you did on many of the other surfaces around the house (so that the metal pieces will match or blend in with the other surfaces around them).

title: ZIMBABWE'S PERSISTENT ARISTOCRACY
description: Since independence from Britain in 1980, many whites have left this relatively prosperous nation, citing their abhorrence of black majority rule. But for those who have remained, some of them descendants of pioneers who trekked here in 1890 to raise the Union Jack, life has not visibly changed. The sun still shines on swanky suburbs. Clubs that bind the social fabric are still, largely, white preserves. Come evening, the ice clinks in tall glasses on the shaded verandas of comfortable homes.

title: SEEING CONTEMPORARY ART IN LIGHT OF MICHELANGELO
description: Sometimes a book can throw light upon subjects from which it may appear to be far removed. David Summer's ''Michelangelo and the Language of Art,'' published by Princeton University Press in 1981, has a breadth of interest that is characteristic of ambitious Renaissance art historical scholarship. A major objective of this sprawling, generous, sometimes inspired book is to recover the artistic language of Michelangelo and Renaissance Italy. This means tracking words like anatomy, concept, fantasy, form, imitation, judgment, movement, order, proportion and quality through the vast and sometimes overgrown Western cultural forest first settled by the Greeks. Michelangelo was acclaimed by many contemporaries as the greatest artist who ever lived in part because they believed all roads through that forest led to him.

title: October Wedding For Jean Blodgett
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Winthrop Blodgett Jr. of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean Cameron Blodgett, to Daniel John Bruns, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth H. Bruns of Melbourne Beach, Fla. An October wedding is planned.

title: PART OF THE ARMORY
description: Some modern developments in defensive signalling are so delicate and subtle that even world-class players are liable to miss the appropriate inferences.

title: THE ICE AGE COMETH
description: THE COEVOLUTION OF CLIMATE AND LIFE

title: BRYANT'S BARBECUE
description: For more than 35 years, the neon sign welcomed the world to Kansas City's House of Good Eats. To one confessed big eater, the writer Calvin Trillin, it was the single best restaurant in the world.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: IN a 112-page report, the New Jersey Supreme

title: FREED SOLIDARITY FIGURE ASSAILS AMNESTY
description: A key Solidarity figure today criticized the Government's amnesty for political prisoners, saying it had not been extended to two underground Solidarity activists and a group of seven miners imprisoned for bombing police stations.

title: HOW LOVE AND LIFE MINGLE ON FILM
description: My father, Nick Cassavetes, told me in 1947 when I graduated from high school and didn't know what to do about college or hitchhiking across the country or anything else, that for every problem, there was an answer. When Ted Allan, the co-author of ''Love Streams'' was a boy, his father whom he loved, had beaten him, and what had been a lovely relationship of a toy inventor and a little boy exchanging philosophical ideas turned into bitter memories. Because I loved my father and because Ted felt just the opposite toward his, our working together on a story directly related to fathers, mothers, sisters, brothers, husbands, wives and the delicate balance of love took us through a four-year episode in which a play with dark overtones titled ''My Sister's Keeper'' later turned into a new film called ''Love Streams.''

title: ZACCARO'S ATTORNEY FAULTS CLIENT'S ROLE IN A LOAN
description: John A. Zaccaro, the husband of Geraldine A. Ferraro, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, borrowed $100,000 from an elderly woman whom a court had appointed him to protect and lent the money to his real estate company, Mr. Zaccaro's attorney said late yesterday.

title:
THE LIVEY ARTS;
HAILING THURBER'S WIT ANEW
description: CONSIDERING the fact that ''Hail Thurber!,'' which opens a two-week run tomorrow at Guild Hall's John Drew Theater in East Hampton, is billed as a comedy, it seems a bit odd to hear Peter Turgeon, who adapted, co-directs and co-stars in the production, proudly proclaim: ''There's not a single joke in the show. No boffo laughs. No black-outs. It's not 'Saturday Night Live,' 'Lampoon House' or Cheech and Chong.''

title: DRIVES FOR REGESTERING MORE VOTERS INTENSIFY
description: THOUSANDS of new voters have registered in Connecticut this summer, as registration drives have intensified in preparation for the November Presidential election.

title: SOUNDING OFF: THE OLYMPICS
description: The following is a sampling of readers' mail in response to the competition and the coverage of the Games of the XXIII Olympiad.

title: REAGAN LAYS OUT THE BATTLE LINES FOR THE CAMPAIGN
description: As Republicans gathered here today for their party's 33d national convention, President Reagan used his weekly radio address to lay down the ideological battle lines of the general election campaign.

title: Rutgers Has New Tie With Penn State
description: After much deliberation that snowy day back in January, Dick Anderson accepted the job as head football coach at Rutgers. It was not easy, he said the other day, leaving all his friends at Penn State, where he had played under Rip Engle more than 20 years ago and where he had been an assistant coach for 11 years under Joe Paterno. Anderson decided to brave the storm. He went outside, walked two houses down Windsor Court in State College, Pa., and told the young man he had known for 19 years, ''I'm your new head coach.''

title: PROSPECTS
description: Neither 1929 Nor 1982

title: 'DEATHTRAP' PLAYED WITH MUTED THRILLS
description: IRA LEVIN'S comedy thriller

title: PLATFORM IS SEEN AS MAP OF FUTURE
description: Politicians generally hold that party platforms are forgotten as soon as the convention that writes them is over. But many delegates to the Republican National Convention say the platform written here this week provides a map of the party's future course.

title: TWO MAYORS MAKE PEACE
description: BEARING gifts rather than grudges, Stamford Mayor Thom Serrani traveled to neighboring Westchester County recently to explain, but not apologize for, his statements that his city could, without its corporate development, become another Port Chester, N.Y.

title: DEVELOPERS SAY HIGH FEES MAKE CITY LESS ATTRACTIVE
description: Last month, the New York City Department of Buildings increased its fee

title: 3 MILE ISLAND STUDY TO RESUME
description: Federal investigators say they will try to determine who falsified tests of leaks in the reactor cooling system at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant before the 1979 accident that crippled the plant.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: but just a little -

title: The Unrepublicans Amid the heat and hats and pride in President Reagan, the delegates are gathering in Dallas, 2,235 solid citizens from every state. Solid, yet there's something peculiar about them.
description: As they assemble in the convention hall, look over to the small District of Columbia delegation. Only 14 delegates. But then you'd expect that. Only about 30,000 Republicans in Washington vote in Presidential elections. Now look over to New York. It is, as you'd expect, the second largest delegation and has 136 delegates, representing 3.4 million Republican voters.

title: TRAVELING SHOW OF AMERICAN STILL LIFES IS AT HE NEUBERGER
description: '' AMERICAN Still Life 1945- 1983'': The title isn't that arresting, but the traveling show it describes is large, various and on the whole quite handsome. And, courtesy of the National Endowment for the Arts and the Westchester Arts Fund of the Council for the Arts in Westchester, it can be seen through Sept. 15 at the Neuberger Museum of the State University of New York at Purchase.

title: NANCY REAGAN DENIES GIVING PRESIDENT CUE
description: Nancy Reagan says she did not prompt President Reagan's recent response to a question on arms control but was simply talking softly to herself.

title:
STAMPS;
UNDERSCORING SUMMER'S PLEASURE
description: Summer is at its peak, a time when tourists range the globe, birds fill the skies, flowers spread their beauty over the land and fish abound in the waters.

title: A WILDERNESS CHALLENGE FOR CHILDREN
description: THE forest was dark and he could not use electricity to find his way. He scooped lit coals into an empty tin can and could see. He marched self-assuredly to the teepee in which he lived and lit a fire so his friends could see too. The boy, 13-year-old Noah Schwartz from Simsbury, Conn., was performing a nightly ritual at the Farm and Wilderness summer camp here. The camp, founded in 1939, is one of dozens across the country designed to let children develop their self-esteem by challenging the wilderness.

title: QUESTIONS GO ALL AROUND ON MONEY MATTERS
description: GERALDINE ANNE FERRARO's solo campaign swing was last week. It was a little bumpy. The Democratic Vice Presidential candidate was greeted by enthusiastic crowds during a four-day tour of Calfornia, Oregon and Washington, just as she had been on a soaring training flight through the South with Presidential nominee Walter F. Mondale earlier in the month. But at each stop, coverage concentrated mostly on the refusal of John A. Zaccaro, the New York real estate executive who is her husband, to make public his Federal income tax returns, as she had promised. Yesterday, Mrs. Ferraro announced that Mr. Zaccaro's returns would be released tomorrow. ''I am pleased,'' said Mr. Mondale.

title: STATE SEEKS PUBLIC'S HELP IN CURBING CHILD ABUSE
description: OFFICIALS responsible for child care in New Jersey say they hope the public outcry over reports that children have been sexually abused in institutions designed to protect them will develop into a statewide community effort against the problem.

title: A Visionary Artist's New Outlook
description: Susan Rothenberg's work represents the purest and strongest strain in the Expressionist mode today, even as it continues to point to the future (''Susan Rothenberg: New Outlook for a Visionary Artist,'' by Grace Glueck, July 22).

title: MONDALE PICKS HIS DEFICIT-BUSTERS
description: WASHINGTON ONE of the most effective themes

title: Robert Brewer Weds Alice Lee Arnold
description: Alice Lee Arnold, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Arnold of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Claflin Brewer, a son of Mrs. Edwin J. Dikeman Jr. of Greenwich and the late Munn Brewer of Larchmont and Armonk, N.Y. The Rev. Donald Huston of the Presbyterian Church of Bridgehampton, L.I., performed the ceremony at Sagaponack, L.I.

title: THE WOMAN BEHIND THE EISEMAN 'LOOK'
description: E. R. Shipp is a correspondent in The New York Times's Chicago bureau.

title: FINE PRESENTATION OF DRAMA BY INGE
description: THANKS to the Sharon Playhouse, William Inge's ''Bus Stop'' can be accepted, appreciated and even acclaimed anew.

title: DRIVE FOR STATUE OF LIBERTY NEARS $100 MILLION
description: Almost $100 million has been raised, mostly from corporations, for the renovation of the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island, according to officials of the $230 million centennial fund-raising drive.

title: A Myth Perpetuated?
description: To the Editor:

title: AIR-POLLUTION SOURCES CITED
description: TRENTON AREPORT on the quality of New Jersey's air, expected to be released soon, shows that more than half the highly toxic pollutants are produced by diesel- and gas-powered motor vehicles, wood-burning stoves, roof- tarring operations and asphalt paving.

title: O.M.B. PredictsA Deficit Peak
description: The Federal deficit isn't about to be done away with, as Ronald Reagan once proclaimed, but the tide of red ink will soon begin to recede, the Administration predicted last week. However, that prospect was not without doubters.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ''How does she do it? Wasn't she making records 25 years ago? She looks better now than she did back in the 60's.'' Tina Turner, who will be at the Ritz this Tuesday through Thursday, must be accustomed to hearing comments like these.

title: Recent Sales
description: Freehold $74,000 *2*75 Boulevard Drive, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*30-year-old ranch; wall-to-wall carpeting, *2*fenced yard; taxes $1,708. Hillsdale $109,900 *2*52 Beach Street, 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*65-year-old colonial; new roof, solar-assisted *2*heating; taxes $1,788. Plainfield $180,000 *2*6 Crabapple Lane, 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*34-year-old colonial; den with private entrance, *2*sliding glass doors in kitchen; taxes $3,221. Pompton Plains $116,000 *2*15 Colonial Terrace, 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*30-year-old split-level; cedar siding, living-room *2*fireplace; taxes $2,600. Ringwood $100,000 *2*126 Upper Lakeview Avenue, 4-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*12-year-old split-level; living room with cathedral *2*ceiling, garage workshop; taxes $1,883. West New York $108,000 *2*6050 Boulevard East, 2-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*17-year-old high-rise condominium; New York view, *2*pool, sauna, maintenance $334; taxes $2,943. OTHER AREAS Ossining, N.Y. $104,600 *2*13 Hawkes Avenue, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*27-year-old frame ranch; sun porch, dinette, *2*1-car garage, 1.5 acre; taxes $3,031. Bethany, Conn. $102,000 *2*58 Anthony Court, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*21-year-old Cape Cod; landscaped grounds, *2*dead end, 1 acre, taxes $1,524. Hauppauge, L.I. $137,000 *2*9 Eagle Lane, 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*22-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in *2*kitchen; taxes $3,200.

title: No Headline
description: IN an effort to strengthen its ties with its host community, the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island has begun a year-long ''museum without walls'' project to spruce up Hempstead Village.

title: Building an Image
description: Imagine being the traditional shingle-style neighbor facing your featured ''A House Divided Among the Treetops'' (by Carol Vogel, July 22). Although such ''striking'' height might ''provide a psychological shelter'' for inhabitants who feel the need to announce their affluence, it can only repel longtime Hamptons residents angered by the architecture of prounouncement, which has become a vanity license plate of the landscape.

title: Switzer No. 1
description: With the opening of the college football season only a couple of weeks away, Oklahoma's Barry Switzer continues to be the No. 1 major-college football coach in winning percentage among those coaches with at least 84 victories, and Michigan's Bo Schembechler still has the most victories. Switzer's record in 11 years as Oklahoma's head coach is 106-21-3 for a percentage of .827. Schembechler's 180 victories in 21 years at Miami of Ohio and Michigan is the most among Division I-A coaches.

title: No Headline
description: JoAnn Giam Is a Bride

title: DID LILCO STRIKE REAP SAVINGS
description: THE most recent effort of the Long Island Lighting Company to reduce its costs - an attempt to impose a 5 percent pay cut on its unionized employees, which led to a five-week strike - has ended without the company's achieving that goal.

title: INSIDERS AND OUTSIDERS
description: WASHINGTON

title: TWO CONDUCTORS ADVANCE THE CAUSE OF SIBELIUS
description: The appearance of not just one but two ongoing Sibelius cycles on compact disks is of note for several reasons. They attest to a possible resurgence of interest in the music of Sibelius, who was perhaps overpraised by conservative critics of the previous generation, but who has certainly been underpraised and underperformed in the last couple of decades.

title: A LETTER HOME FROM PAPER MOUNTAIN WRITERS' CONFERENCE
description: From time to time, The Book Review has reported on the doings at summer writers' conferences and workshops. Recently a copy of the following letter written by a participant in one such gathering came our way. Dear Unnatural Parent,

title: J.C. Vecchiarino 3d, Executive, to Wed Christine M. Niedermeier, a Legislator
description: -term Connecticut State Representative, has become engaged to Joseph Charles Vecchiarino 3d, president of a medical-supply company, her mother, Marie E. Niedermeier of Fairfield, Conn., has announced. A June wedding is planned.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: BEARING gifts rather than grudges, Mayor Thom Serrani of Stamford traveled to Westchester this month, explaining, but never apologizing for, his statements that his city could, without its corporate development, become another Port Chester.

title: EGOS SHOULDN'T STOP PRODUCTION REPAIRS
description: What would you do if you saw a man slip and fall in the street? Good person that you are, you probably would hurry to help him regain his upright dignity and to offer a few words of concern. However, you would also have to be aware of the possibility that he, a being as human as yourself, might feel humiliated at being seen in such an embarrasssing position. He might thank you curtly, and refuse to be helped. It is easier to bear a bruise on the elbow than on the ego.

title: Miss Leclerc Has Nuptials
description: Martha K. Leclerc, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Lawrence A. Leclerc of Fargo, N.D., was married yesterday to Leo F. J. Wilking 3d, the son of Drs. Leo F .J. and Virginia Wilking of New York.

title: Books
description: To the Editor: As a longtime do-it- yourself (amateur) travel planner, I would add just two ideas to Paul Grimes's excellent account of the tools of our trade (Practical Travel

title: NEW RENT-SUIT DEVELOPMENT
description: TENANTS whose landlords have not provided lease renewals under the 1983-84 rent freeze should complain by Oct. 1 to the state's Department of Housing and Community Renewal, Assemblyman John M. Perone of Mamaroneck said last week, following new developments in his court suit on their behalf.

title:
DINING OUT;
A CHEERFUL SPOT IN TARRYTOWN
description: UNLESS one were looking for it, The Gallery could be missed behind the plant- hung, unprepossessing storefront window on Tarrytown's dusty Main Street. Beyond the front door, however, the square box of a room has considerable style. Done in stark white and black, relieved only by the intense colors from paintings by Radovan (Micha) Trnavac who is also the owner of the restaurant, the dining room is, nevertheless, cheerful despite its dramatic statement.
