The small, trim adjoining bar attracts a friendly, artsy crowd.

title: TWO AVANT-GARDISTS REVEAL THEIR CLASSICISM
description: Thirty years ago, two foreign- born dramatists - one Irish, the other Rumanian - were considered to be the leaders of the Paris avant- garde. Neither was a self-declared innovator. Beckett avoided definition and kept to himself, while Ionesco, a notorious enfant terrible, proclaimed that if he belonged to any school of literature it was that of ''the cabaret.'' He enjoyed offering perverse data: ''I'm a bourgeois realist who writes in order to find out what he thinks. My ancestors, as far as my work is concerned, were a mixed bunch: Job, Shakespeare's Richard II, King Solomon, the Marx Brothers, Charlie Chaplin, the Keystone Cops.''

title: CRIME
description: William Diehl's HOOLIGANS (Villard, $15.95) is not merely macho. It is machississimo - every one of the hooligan heroes is bigger than life, tougher than life, all-wise, all-resourceful. In this big book, the social misfit is glorified into an eternal loner with the mind of Spinoza, the physical strength of Samson and the inner doubts of Hamlet. He is pictured as being better than all others. He marches in the cause of truth, and because he has discarded the hypocritical trappings of society, his heart is essentially pure.

title: OYSTER HARVEST
description: As the gray squalls of March blew the spring of 1983 into Chesapeake Bay country, the men who work the bay were gloomy. A tiny parasite known as MSX was killing oysters, further threatening a harvest and a way of life already endangered by overfishing, reduced demand and conpetition from the Gulf of Mexico.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM A POP CONCERT TO A PULITZER PLAY
description: Dionne Warwick in Concert Prism Entertainment 60 minutes. $29.95

title: LIFE IN THE YAAK: DEER, FIRE AND NATURE'S CYCLE
description: When Greg and Cindy Middag wanted to change the setting on their television the other evening, Mrs. Middag stood at the living room door watching the screen and calling directions outdoors to her husband in the woods. Up on a little ladder clutching a flashlight, he was aiming a large satellite TV dish at another satellite hovering overhead.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: The Attraction Of 'Old Neighborhoods' Lee Rush stated it perfectly, in the article entitled ''Old Neighborhoods and New'' (Opinion Page, July 15). Our children will not talk about their childhood environment as their parents did.

title: Railroad Station Is Hit In 3d French Bombing
description: A bomb exploded Friday at the Grenoble train station, and a group that claimed responsibility for two previous bombings demanded nearly $3.75 million to stop its attacks.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: '' 'Symphony in D' Workshop'' shows the Czech choreographer Jiri Kylian at work, taking a group of young dancers from the Royal Ballet School in London through rehearsals of his ballet, 'Symphony in D.' The new documentary, which will be screened this week on Bravo on Tuesday at 10 P.M. and at 3 A.M., is a model of its kind. It offers information about Mr. Kylian, a leading contemporary ballet choreographer, and about his ballet in a script that has all the sleekness and intelligence of the dance itself.

title: FOUR EXCURSIONS IN THE METROPLEX
description: Dallas is large, sprawling and eager - not so intense as its rival city in Texas, Houston, but significantly more established. Houston has the energy and passion of a place that has just come into money; Dallas wants you to know that it has been around for a while. Dallas is not only more conservative politically, it has traditionally been more conservative architecturally. Its skyline is not as exciting and fresh as Houston's, but the tradeoff is that it has rarely fallen prey to the kind of more extreme vulgarities that frequently plague Houston.

title: PRESIDENTIAL BOMBING JOKE: WHAT IF...?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWCOMERS SEEK ADMISSION TO THE FAMILY OF INSTRUMENTS
description: ''What is a musical instrument?'' The question is asked rhetorically, and rather provocatively, by Suzanne Ciani, a classically trained musician whose chosen instrument is the electronic synthesizer. Both as composer and performer, she is the creator of new sounds in a controversial medium that is just beginning to be taken seriously.

title: ACID RAIN: HIDDEN ROLE ATTRIBUTED TO THE STATE
description: COAL and oil burned to provide New Jersey with electricity contribute substantially to the acid rain problem, a new study by a nonprofit environmental group finds, but the state camouflages its role as a polluter by burning relatively little fuel inside its borders.

title: EVERYONE'S A SENIOR IN THIS PROGRAM
description: THEY have served in all walks of life: as accountants, businessmen, judges, housewives, bankers, clerical workers. And they come for a variety of reasons: for intellectual stimulation, for comradeship, for a sense of purpose or a fresh identity.

title: CONSTITUTIONAL PROTECTION OF DANCING REJECTED
description: A New York State appeals court has rejected a Staten Island nightclub operator's argument that forcing him to shut down his dance floor for patrons was illegal because ''recreational dancing is a form of expression protected by'' the Constitution.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: ALTERNATIVES TO RENTING A CAR IN EUROPE
description: While a car rented on a short-term basis is probably the most popular transportation for Americans traveling in Europe, especially for those who plan to visit cities that are relatively close together, renting is not the only way to have the flexibility that an automobile affords. Several possibilities are worth considering: leasing a car, buying one or shipping your own car.

title: CARLOS FUENTES: LIFE AND LANGUAGE
description: Carlos Fuentes, Mexico's pre-eminent novelist, was born in 1928 into a family of diplomats and has spent more of his life abroad than in his native land. As a child, he lived in Santiago, Washington, D.C., Rio de Janeiro, Buenos Aires, Montevideo and Quito; only when he was 15 did he return to Mexico City, his birthplace and the setting for so much of his fiction.

title: CITY TIGHTENS AUCITON PROCEDURES
description: The tax-delinquency rate on property auctioned off by New York City has fallen to its

title: WHAT' S A CITIZEN TO DO?
description: POLITICAL JUDGMENT

title: FISHERS ISLAND, VEXED BY TAX, EYES AUTONOMY
description: T HE teletype whirs into action. ''Effective this date the New York State police station seasonal at Fishers Island has been activated.'' The radio dispatcher in the Southold Town police headquarters expresses surprise as the bulletin comes in. Like most Southold residents, he has never been to the tiny island community that is the most distant part of the town.

title: RULES ON CHARITY DRIVE BY FEDERAL EMPLOYEES' REVIVE DISPUTE
description: The Reagan Administration has issued new regulations for a charity drive by Federal employees, reviving a three-year-old controversy over which groups will benefit.

title: NEVER-NEVER LAND OF PERFECT TEXTBOOKS
description: FOR seven years I edited high school textbooks. Given the demands made on educational publishers by teachers, parent groups, religious groups, women's groups, minority and silent-majority spokesmen, putting out a good textbook means walking a narrow and treacherous path.

title: REDISCOVERING THE ART OF MAX BECKMANN
description: Hilton Kramer is the editor of The New Criterion.

title: Leslie Jayne Fishman Marries D. L. Snyder
description: Leslie Jayne Fishman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman L. Fishman of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married there yesterday to David L. Snyder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Snyder of Brookville, L.I. Rabbi Melvin Sirner performed the ceremony at Beth El Synagogue.

title: FOR HORSE RACING, A YEAR OF WOES
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.

title: Georgia Town Sealed As Blacks Vent Anger
description: Scores of blacks outraged over the death of a black man in police custody took to the streets today, setting fires and ignoring a curfew imposed at sunset after the police sealed off the town, the authorities said.

title: ALL ABOARD FOR THE LITERARY ENTERPRISE
description: James Atlas is an associate editor of The Atlantic and the author of a forthcoming novel, ''The Great Pretender.'' DIVERSITY AND DEPTH IN FICTION

title: BRIEFS ;  Debt Issues
description: Ford Motor Credit Co. is offering $100 million of 13.20 percent notes due Aug. 15, 1989, through Goldman, Sachs & Co.

title: AQUINO STATUE SEIZED IN MANILA
description: Soldiers seized a statue of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. today on its arrival for ceremonies this week to mark the first anniversary of Mr. Aquino's slaying, the state-run Philippine News Agency reported.

title: Populist Party Ends Convention in Nashville
description: Populist Party delegates ended their first convention in 88 years today by cheering their Presidential ticket - Bob Richards, an Olympic gold medalist, and Maureen Salaman, a talk-show host.

title: Alan Michael Cohen Wed To Roberta Louise Cohen
description: At the Fifth Avenue Synagogue in New York yesterday Roberta Louise Cohen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Cohen of Delphos, Ohio, was married to Alan Michael Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Cohen of West Haven, Conn. Rabbi Nissan Shulman officiated.

title: FACES AT THE CONVENTION
description: Elizabeth Hanford Dole

title: UGANDAN DISPUTES U.S. OVER KILLINGS
description: A Government spokesman said today that 15,000 people had been killed in political and tribal violence in Uganda in the nearly four years since President Milton Obote returned to power.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Taxpayer: Cowed in Alaska
description: It's tough raising dairy cattle in Alaska. The weather is unforgiving, the grazing land is marginal, the bears are unfriendly and the transportation is uncertain. But, as a recent article in The Wall Street Journal makes plain, where there's a Government subsidy there's a way.

title: CRITIC IN PENTAGON CITES EFFORT TO PUNISH HIM
description: A Pentagon official who gave Congressional testimony that embarrassed the military says a superior tried to reduce his job performance rating and possibly to dismiss him.

title: Platform Fights Rare but Heated
description: Republican convention delegates rarely bicker over platforms, and there have been only three notable battles of this sort in the 20th century.

title: Bid to Disperse 10,000 At 'Cruise' Spurs Melee
description: Police officers trying to break up a crowd of 10,000 at a ''cruise night'' for teen-agers were pelted by rocks, bottles and firecrackers early today. Eleven officers were injured and 16 people arrested, the authorities said.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. California Angels at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Tommy John of the Angels goes against his former team. Reggie Jackson is still trying to join the 14 other men who have hit at least 500 career home runs - he has 497 - and he could do it against his former team, the Yankees, as this three- game series begins.

title: CONCERT: COUNTRY AND BLUES
description: Two classic blues performers shared the bill with a country- soul upstart Saturday for two concerts at the Beacon Theater. There were urbane innuendoes and the blues' time-honored transmutation of pain into beauty from the guitarist-singer B. B. King and the singer Bobby (Blue) Bland - both of whom have been blues mainstays since the 1950's - followed by the outright raunchiness of Millie Jackson, a tough talker and torchy singer.

title: MEROLA ASSAILS AGENCY ON INQUIRY IT MADE IN DISPUTE ON CHILD ABUSE
description: District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx yesterday called the city's Department of Investigation ''an arm of the Mayor'' and reiterated his allegation that its report on another city agency's handling of a child-abuse inquiry was ''a whitewash.''

title: U.P.I. Talking With Union
description: United Press International and the Wire Service Guild, which represents most of the company's United States employees, are discussing measures that could make the news agency profitable by the fourth quarter of 1984, U.P.I. announced yesterday.

title: New Frontiers
description: In the old days, a toothache was

title: Well-Aged Planks: Waste and Fraud
description: Here are excerpts from the Republican platform of 1860, on which Lincoln was elected:

title: JERSEY COUPLE FOUND SLAIN
description: Police officers who went to an apartment because of an anonymous call early Sunday morning found the bodies of a man and a woman with their skulls fractured and throats slit. An unharmed child slept in one room.

title: COSMOS LOSE TO STRIKERS FOR 3D STRAIGHT TIME THIS SEASON
description: A disputed goal by John Bain in sudden-death overtime gave the Minnesota Strikers their first victory ever at Giants Stadium tonight and an unprecedented three-game season sweep over the Cosmos.

title: 13 Are Killed and 3 Are Hurt In 2 Plane Crashes in England
description: Thirteen people were killed today in two air crashes, one involving 11 members of an aircraft preservation society, the police said.

title: SULLIVAN POCONO WINNER
description: Danny Sullivan overtook Rick Mears and Bobby Rahal on the 195th lap today at Pocono Raceway to win his first 500-mile race since shifting from exclusive road-course competition to oval racing in 1982.

title: BYRD ATTACKS AS MERE 'BOMBAST' U.S. MILITARY AND FOREIGN POLICY
description: Robert C. Byrd, the Senate Democratic leader, plans to charge Monday morning that President Reagan has pursued a foreign and military policy of ''noise, bombast and overstatement'' while allowing military readiness to decline.

title: DISNEY STILL APPEARS TURBULENT
description: Walt Disney Productions said this weekend that it sought to quell dissension on its board and to erase the prospect of a shareholder fight when it reversed itself late Friday and reneged on its $330 million plan to buy Gibson Greetings Inc.

title: Teacher's Right to Pry President Reagan scores a political strike whenever he calls for ''good, old-fashioned discipline'' in the nation's schools. Actually, he's done little to promote it. School discipline is, first and foremost, a local concern and there's precious little that the Federal Government can or should do.
description: But the Administration's impulse to encourage discipline has produced a useful friend-of-the-Supreme-Court intervention by the Justice Department. Though accompanied by outdated statistics to claim that school violence has reached ''epidemic'' proportions, it properly urges the Court to give school officials wide latitude to search students suspected of violating reasonable rules.

title: The Showdown That Never Was
description: When 14 Soviet-bloc nations decided to pull out of the 1984 Olympic Games at Los Angeles, it was obvious that the Friendship-84 competitions, sponsored by the Eastern-bloc, would be the showcase for the track and field athletes of those nations.

title: ADVICE FOR DISENCHANTED REPUBLICANS
description: To the Editor:

title: A Team of One's Own
description: First there was ''Rotissere League Baseball,'' a book telling how to organize and operate a mock baseball league using the performances of real major league players to determine the standings.

title: 5 Thai Soldiers Killed In a Guerrilla Ambush
description: Communist insurgents in southern Thailand threw hand grenades and fired at a truck carrying an army patrol unit, killing five soldiers and wounding nine soldiers and a civilian, a provincial police officer said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If it's there, I think we'll find it.'' - Comdr. Chester F. Harrison, searching for mines in the Gulf of Suez.

title: THE ONLY SUSPENSE WILL BE OVER SHARING THE SPOTLIGHT OF TV'S COVERAGE
description: In a convention devoid of political suspense, the biggest unanswered questions may have to do with television coverage.

title: Washington Watch; Citicorp's View Of Banking Bill
description: WASHINGTON

title: CITY OPERA: 'RONDINE,' CONDUCTED BY SICILIANI
description: It was one of those nights when

title: FERRARO, IN TV QUESTIONING, SAYS SHE IS HIDING NOTHING
description: In a spirited exchange on national television, Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro yesterday defended her actions on several personal financial matters, saying she had nothing to hide.

title: CHRISTIAN-DRUSE BATTLE REPORTED NEAR BEIRUT
description: Shells hit the grounds of the presidential palace in a hillside suburb of Beirut tonight during heavy fighting between Christian and Druse forces southeast of the capital, according to local radio stations.

title: CUBS TOP REDS, 9-6, WITH 5 RUNS IN 5TH
description: Ron Cey and Thad Bosley hit three-run homers today as the Chicago Cubs scored a 9-6 victory over the Reds.

title: Three-Part Harmony
description: When it comes to single athletic events, such as a foot race or a javelin throw, the competition itself is generally considered sufficient to justify the efforts of the competitors and hold the interest of the spectators.

title: Jeffry Levine, Student, Marries Lisa P. Yarvis
description: Lisa Pam Yarvis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Martin R. Yarvis of Long Beach and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Jeffry Levine, a son of Dr. O. Robert Levine and Dr. Alice Magarian of Grymes Hill, S.I. Rabbi Milton Rosenfeld performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: TOLL AT 25
description: Police gunfire killed at least 6 people and wounded 38 in Andhra Pradesh state today in new confrontations arising from the dismissal of the opposition-led state government, state authorities said.

title: OPERA: LEIGH MUNRO IN CITY OPERA 'TRAVIATA'
description: Leigh Munro's Violetta, heard for the first time here at the City Opera's Sunday matinee performance of ''La Traviata,'' is a dignified and touching portrayal, more involving than one would have expected from her performances in the lighter roles she has sung with the company before. She phrases her Verdi with gracious portamento, has a sense of line and showed herself on this occasion an unhurried, thoughtful actress.

title: Key Trust's President Is a Veteran Marketer
description: Henry M. Gridley has been named president and chief executive officer of the Key Trust Company, a subsidiary of Key Banks Inc., a regional bank holding company based in Albany.

title: Top Hispanic Aide Is Party Keynoter
description: Katherine Davalos Ortega, the 38th Treasurer of the United States, will deliver the convention's keynote address tonight.

title: TWINS ARE BEATEN BY RED SOX, 5-4
description: Bill Buckner and Eddie Jurak had run- scoring singles in the eighth-inning today as the Red Sox rallied for a 5-4 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

title: Lisa Gelfman Married To Gary S. Matthews
description: The marriage of Lisa Jane Gelfman to Gary Steven Matthews, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Matthews of Cincinnati, took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Gelfman, parents of the bride, in Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony.

title: TREASURY TO SELL $8.5 BILLION OF NOTES
description: The Treasury returns to the note market this week with an $8.5 billion offering of two-year notes on Wednesday. That will be in addition to the regular weekly bill auctions.

title: IRAN WARNS IRAQ OF AN OFFENSIVE 'AS SOON AS GRACE PERIOD ENDS'
description: Iranian newspapers said today that the Government had sent thousands of volunteers to its battlefront with Iraq and that a new offensive might be launched after the expiration of a deadline for Iraq to meet Iranian demands.

title: CYCLING RECORDS ARE SET
description: Three cyclists set world indoor records today and three swimmers beat medal- winning times at the Los Angeles Olympics as Soviet-bloc athletes continued to dominate the Friendship '84 games organized by the Soviet Union.

title: ROTTING IN LAOS
description: A terrible wrong was committed 11 years ago: 566 servicemen lost in Laos were abandoned without a trace. While almost 600 war prisoners held in North Vietnam came home in early 1973, not one of the 566 has ever come home - dead or alive. This tragedy continues.

title: CUOMO FINDING WAYS TO AID MONDALE WITHOUT GOING ON TOUR
description: Governor Cuomo has found a way to campaign nationally for the Democratic Presidential ticket and maintain his position that he does not want to leave New York State for very long. The answer is television.

title: Pamela Faith Fleisher Is Bride of John H. Jensen
description: Pamela Faith Fleisher, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Conrad G. Fleisher of Watertown, Conn., was married yesterday to John Howard Jensen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack E. Jensen of Columbus, Ohio, formerly of Brookhaven, L.I. The Revs. Alison Kemper and David Hoag performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: BLACK REPORTERS SUM UP DISPUTES
description: Throughout the convention of the National Association of Black Journalists, the shadow of the Presidential nomination bid of the Rev. Jesse Jackson hovered ever near as blacks pondered their place in the communications industry.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE NEW AMERICAN POVERTY. By Michael Harrington. 271 pages. Holt, Rinehart and Winston. $17.95.

title: Missing Python Is Caught Upstate
description: An 11 1/2-foot python, whose disappearance Aug. 10 had caused alarm in this suburb of Syracuse, was found curled up in the ceiling of its owner's house late Saturday.

title: KLECKO IS OUT FOR 4-6 WEEKS
description: At almost the moment when memories of the great Jets' defensive line suddenly reappeared, they crumpled like an old photograph when Joe Klecko strained his right hamstring against the Giants' Saturday night.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. PRESSES MONDALE DRIVE
description: The A.F.L.- C.I.O. today renewed its pledge to mount a voter drive for the Democratic Presidential ticket.

title: Stone to Minors
description: The Philadelphia Phillies said today they have sent their leading hitter, the rookie outfielder Jeff Stone, to the minors to make room for Garry Maddox, who has come off the disabled list.

title: Korean Car Exports
description: South Korea exported 25,816 cars in the first seven months of this year, surpassing the 24,510 units exported in all of 1983, the Trade and Industry Ministry said. Domestic sales in the seven months rose 8.5 percent to 122,342 vehicles from 112,780 in the 1983 period, it said. Ministry officials said 1984 car exports would exceed 40,000 units.

title: Vietnam Accuses China Of Border Incursions
description: Vietnam accused China today of staging air, land and sea incursions into Vietnamese territory last week and of increasing efforts to ''destabilize'' Vietnam's border provinces.

title: GRIFFEY HOMER PACES YANKEES
description: When Ken Griffey came to the plate in the eighth inning yesterday, he was the only Yankee starter without a hit. Dave Winfield already had four, including a home run in the third inning and a two-run single that had tied the game moments before. Don Mattingly already had three, including a pair of doubles, and so did Don Baylor and Butch Wynegar.

title: DALLAS OFFERS AN ELEPHANT BOUTIQUE, DAILY CATTLE DRIVES AND EXTRA SECURITY
description: Like a dinner- party hostess with a certain past, the city of Dallas carefully folded the last of the napkins this weekend and waited nervously for the first visitors to arrive.

title: 43-Year Delivery
description: The moral of this tale, it would

title: PHILADELPHIA SEEKS TO TEACH ITS ILLITERATE TO READ
description: Eleanor Lewis, at 24 years of age, has gone through two of the most pivotal experiences in her life.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alo-Scherer Healthcare Inc., Pompano Beach, Fla., a maker of pharmaceuticals and personal care products, announced that William J. Thompson had joined the company as president.

title: BOND SNARL PERSISTS IN '83 DEFAULT
description: More than one year after the Washington Public Power Supply System defaulted on $2.25 billion of its bonds, in the largest municipal bond default in history, holders of the securities are still a long way from collecting any interest payments, much less their principal.

title: A Roaring 20's Wedding
description: Nearby, in Lincoln Center Plaza, an

title: Article 144974 -- No Title
description: State and local governments spent nearly $625 million in 1982 to provide legal representation to indigent people accused of crimes, 44 percent more than in 1980, the Justice Department said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 20, 1984

title: G.O.P. IS FACING CHOICE ON WAY TO EXPAND BASE
description: In 1980, Ronald Reagan won the Presidency by appealing to voters who had traditionally identified with the Democratic Party. As a byproduct of his victory, Mr. Reagan created for the Republicans a chance to broaden their electoral base at the expense of the Democrats.

title: Today's Calendar
description: Platform: In an anticipated orgy of back-patting, the formerly temporary platform committee will convene at 3 P.M. , Eastern daylight time (2 P.M. Dallas time), as a new permanent committee, ratify the proposed platform and congratulate itself.

title: Most Trading Before Noon Although it is a multibillion
description: dollar market daily, most commercial paper is dealt well before noon. The afternoon is for

title: R. D. Browne, Illustrator, Married to Debra Kaslove
description: Debra B. Kaslove, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kaslove of Norwalk, Conn., and Robert D. Browne, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Browne of Sarasota, Fla., were married yesterday at Wilbanks House in Pelican Cove in Sarasota by Justice of the Peace William Joyner.

title: NEW TEXTILE IMPORT RULE PROTESTED
description: Critics are seeking to delay a regulation that the Reagan Administration says would improve its ability to monitor imports of textiles and apparel.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Aug. 20, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: THEATER: :TELEDEUM'
description: It was Spain's turn at the Public

title: Grand Old Party: A Variety of Views
description: The Republicans have a habit of having three bad years and one good one, and the good one always happens to be election years.

title: ; VOTES A CEMOCRACY CAN DO WITHOUT
description: To the Editor:

title: ROCK: ELVIS COSTELLO IN FOREST HILLS CONCERT
description: Rock fans get nearly all of their music in canned form - on records, radio or television - and grow accustomed to hearing a song in just one version. For familiarity's sake, many bands re-create their records when they perform onstage. But Elvis Costello and his four-piece band, the Attractions, defied their own recordings for most of their concert Saturday at Forest Hills Stadium.

title: Ellen Friedman, Teacher, Weds Mark Silverman
description: Ellen Lynn Friedman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis L. Friedman of New York, was married yesterday to Mark J. Silverman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Silverman of Brooklyn. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik performed the ceremony at the Helmsley Palace Hotel in New York.

title: VOWING TO 'FIND IT,' U.S. PRESSES MINE HUNT
description: ABOARD U.S.S. SHREVEPORT, off Ras Shukhair, Egypt, Aug. 19 - Officers aboard this Navy transport vessel searching for mines in the Gulf of Suez said today that they would not stop until they found one.

title: LOPEZ WINS ELITE TITLE
description: Nancy Lopez lost six shots to JoAnne Carner in the first eight holes today, then rallied to win the Chevrolet World Championship of Women's Golf and $65,000 - the biggest paycheck on the women's tour.

title: N.A.A.C.P. BEGINS 350-MILE MARCH IN AN EFFORT TO REGISTER VOTERS
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today began a 350-mile march through the Middle Atlantic states in an effort to register voters.

title: OUTFLOW AT THRIFT UNIT
description: Depositors withdrew about $200 million from the American Savings and Loan Association last week after its parent company, the Financial Corporation of America, reported a $107.5 million quarterly loss on Wednesday, a source close to the company said today.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: Some Gatherings Difficult to Match
description: The first Republican convention was held in Philadelphia in 1856, when the nominees were John C. Fremont of California for the Presidency and Wilburn L. Dayton of New Jersey for the Vice Presidency. Fremont attracted 520 votes, to 37 for John McLean of Ohio and 1 for William H. Seward of New York.

title: THE PARTY IS NOT WITHOUT SOME LONG-TERM CONCERNS
description: Despite an overall optimism, some Republicans worry about the party's future, with these major sources of concern:

title: DianeWed To Peter B. Levy
description: Diane Krejsa, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald G. Krejsa of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and Peter Barbin Levy, the son of Dr. Allan Levy of Hillsborough, Calif., and the late Phyllis Kulick Levy, were married yesterday. The Rev. Russell Davis, an associate minister of the Riverside Church, performed the Protestant ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: A CITY THAT LONGS TO EMBRACE AND BE EMBRACED
description: Dallas and diffidence do not sit well together. This is a young city, and in many ways it is a raw city - a city that grows fast, learns fast and just can't wait to show itself off. Whereas San Francisco knew perfectly well that its Democratic visitors would fall into a voluptuous trance with only minimal guidance from the city authorities, Dallas has a longing to embrace and be embraced that can be felt almost before the visitor's aircraft is at the gate.

title: HEROIN AS A RELIEVER OF INSUFFERABLE PAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: 16 Air Carriers Support Eastern on Scheduling
description: Sixteen air carriers are supporting an request by Eastern Air Lines for an antitrust exemption to allow the airline industry to coordinate schedules to reduce delays, an airline spokesman said.

title: ;  Soviet Team Wins Hockey Tune-Up
description: Sergei Shepelev had a goal and an assist tonight as the Soviet Union's national hockey team defeated Sweden, 4-1, in an exhibition game for the Canada Cup tournament next month.

title: NEW FILMS TRYING TO REMAIN APOLITICAL
description: With the Republican Convention taking place this week, the race for the Presidency has begun in earnest. Hollywood's marketing executives - whose main concern is the different race at the box office - are being extra cautious about keeping their movies from getting tangled up with politics.

title: George Who?
description: The August award for extreme

title: A HOSPITAL OFFICIAL'S LOST SUMMER: HEATLH-CARE STRIKE 'RUNS YOURS LIFE'
description: Since New York's health-care strike took hold of his life, Dr. Martin L. Lesser has had many dreams. But only one, he says, stands out in his memory.

title: NEW POLICE TRAINING FILMS TAKE CUE FROM TV
description: The out-of-towners, a father, mother and teen-age daughter, got off the bus at the Port Authority Bus Terminal and, suitcases in hand, began to search for their hotel.

title: P.L.O. Factions Are Planning Council Meeting Next Month
description: Representatives of the five main factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization agreed today to call a meeting of the Palestine National Council by mid-September to try to end their disputes.

title: THE U.S. STAKE IN CENTRAL AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: FERRARO CHOICE DISRUPTS G.O.P. PLANS FOR WOMEN
description: Everything was proceeding according to plan for what may be the most efficiently organized Presidential re- election campaign in history - until last month, when the Democrats nominated Geraldine A. Ferraro for Vice President.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: and most collectible - form of mail is the picture postcard, the rectangle that leaves room for a scribbled note on the address side but features something to catch the eye on the reverse. Collecting postcards became the rage early in this century, and the fever has not yet abated, judging by the numerous shows and fairs that specialize in them during the year.

title: BUSH TO PLAY KEY CAMPAIGN ROLE
description: Few people remember the debate between the two aspirants for Vice President in 1980, George Bush and Walter F. Mondale.

title: REAGAN HAS ACHIEVED MANY GOALS, BUT SOME STIR OPPOSITION
description: In three years, President Reagan has achieved much of what he promised: curbing inflation, stimulating economic growth, reducing the role of the Government, limiting access to social welfare programs.

title: Economic Calendar Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.
description: Monday

title: New France-Iraq Oil Deal
description: France's two major oil companies have renewed an oil supply contract with Iraq that last year allowed Baghdad to overcome severe financial problems stemming from its war with Iran, according to sources here.

title: UNESCO, REPUBLICANS AND IMAGE
description: An international organization that is having problems with both American public opinion and the American Government has done what a private corporation might be expected to do under such circumstances: It has hired a public relations firm with good connections to the White House.

title: DEWHURST ADAPTS TO LANGUAGE OF DEAF THEATER
description: On a hot summer afternoon in a converted old mill above a Connecticut brook, a group of actors is gathered in a room that is strangely still. The makeshift stage is full of characters in motion, but only one voice is speaking, that of a curly haired young man watching the others from a corner. Otherwise there is silence, save for the noisy splashing of the brook and the droning of a fly.

title: Go Jump in a River
description: Stacy Chanin was born in Yonkers 23 years ago, lived in New Rochelle until she was 6 years old and, as a native New Yorker, might have the common sense not to jump in the East River.

title: CAMPAIGN '84 AND THE MOSCOW FACTOR
description: With the prospect that the country next year will have either a second-term Republican President with new flexibility in international affairs or a new Democratic President with different ideas about international affairs, Soviet experts in and out of Government are beginning to turn their thoughts to what might be.

title: Lord Fermoy Shoots Himself; Uncle of Princess of Wales
description: Lord Fermoy, the uncle of the Princess of Wales, shot himself today at his home, the police said. He was 45 years old.

title: Fear of Freedom - in Haiti For 26 years under two Duvaliers, Papa Doc and Baby Doc, fear has haunted the lives of six million Haitians. Fear of hunger and disease in the hemisphere's poorest nation. Fear of the Tonton Macoutes, an elite bodyguard with a license to kill. But Jean-Claude Duvalier, who has succeeded his father as president-for-life, is also dogged by fear - of freedom.
description: In May, when Congress was reviewing an American aid package of $54 million, Mr. Duvalier opportunely promised press freedom and respect for human rights. But his word, when tested, proved worthless. At the appearance of critical newspapers, he silenced them by decree and banned all political activity except his own.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Has a major league pitcher ever hit for the cycle, getting a single, double, triple and home run in the same game?

title: REAGAN HEARS PLEADING AND PRAISE IN FARM BELT
description: Taking his re-election campaign to the Farm Belt, President Reagan drew warm applause today with an attack on Walter F. Mondale for supporting the partial cutoff of grain sales to the Soviet Union in 1980.

title: IN FRENCH BASQUES' LAND, TERROR AND TOURISTS MIX
description: Three worlds met this week along the beach in this coastal town just across the border with Spain.

title: Reaganbush, Anyone?
description: Would you pay $4.95 for five seeds that might eventually produce a birch, maple, spruce or pine in the front yard? Wait a minute: Suppose the seeds came in a small plastic cup of soil, to be nurtured indoors for 10 months, with a 20- page Planters Guide stressing love of country and traditional values as well as climate control? Still dubious? Well then, suppose the product had a catchy contemporary name like Reaganbush, and the seller promised to forward a record of your husbandry to the National Archives?

title: THEFT STIRS QUESTIONS ON HANDLING OF MASSACHUSETTS ARCHIVES
description: It was an extraordinary document: a royal English charter, gorgeously decorated, that granted to the Massachusetts Bay Company not only a tract of land stretching ''from sea to sea'' but also a form of corporate self government that evolved into a passionate political ideal. The parchment carried an odor of scandal as well, for the colonists may have well have broken English law when they removed the charter to America.

title: REGIONAL PLAY OPPORTUNITIES GROWING IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Opportunities for regional play have been growing for New York City enthusiasts in recent years. Four such tournaments have long been established in Manhattan and Long Island, and two others that have moved closer to New York are now popular.

title: STABILITY SEEN AT FED MEETING
description: Federal Reserve officials are not expected to make any changes in monetary policy or short-term interest rates at this week's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee.

title: NELSON ACHING WITH SUCCESS
description: Dull and sparkling colors lit up the right half of his body, as if all the hits and slaps and jabs had uncovered a metallic treasure hiding just below the skin. A blue mark above the hip, a yellowish hue below, and a gold charm on the small of his back.

title: MISSING MARCHERS IN A TICKER-TAPE PARADE
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY TEAMS SWEEP GAMES BASKETBALL
description: Men's basketball teams from New York City swept the gold medals in the open and scholastic divisions today, the final day of competition at the Empire State Games.

title: DIAMONDS IN THE RAW STILL GLITTER
description: Jennifer Croft has doubts about whether diamonds are forever.

title: In Defense of Free Speech
description: There were the staples of summer

title: WITKOWSKI MAY ROAR FOR DIFFERENT LION
description: ROCHESTER, Mich.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.02

title: CANDIDATES VAGUE ON CANADA DEFICIT
description: At first glance, the two main candidates for Prime Minister of Canada seem tailor-made for business. Both John Turner, the incumbent and Liberal Party leader, and Brian Mulroney, leader of the opposition Progressive Conservative Party, are former corporate lawyers and argue strongly for free enterprise.

title: Republicans Point With Pride To the Reagan Record So Far
description: Republicans arrive in Dallas proud of the record compiled in what they hope will be only the first Reagan Administration. These are some sources of that pride: National Defense

title: DEFENDING WEAK SPOT
description: On opening night the Republican National Convention will seek to take the offensive in President Reagan's most vulnerable area, foreign policy, with a sharp attack on the Democrats by one of the Administration's most vigorous proponents of the active use of American power and influence in the world. Republican leaders have tapped Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, who still calls herself ''a lifelong Democrat,'' to make the Republican case that the Reagan years have restored American strength and confidence.

title: METS WIN, 4-2, AFTER 7-6 SETBACK
description: For the second straight day, the Mets blew a game in the ninth inning. Today, the light-hitting Brad Wellman of the San Francisco Giants whacked a two-run home run off Jesse Orosco to sink the Mets, 7-6.

title: Rhonda Schwartz Weds a Reporter
description: Rhonda Ann Schwartz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Schwartz of San Diego, was married yesterday to Stephen J. Wermiel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Wermiel of Coconut Creek, Fla. Rabbi David Saperstein performed the ceremony at the Strathmore Hall Art Center in North Bethesda, Md.

title: HURRICANE LEAVING HAWAII AREA
description: Hurricane Keli, with winds up to 100 miles an hour, turned from Hawaii today but headed for the military installation of Johnston Island, where 13,000 tons of mustard gas and other lethal chemicals are stored.

title: COMMERCIAL PAPER'S GROWTH
description: Sharper competition among dealers and high long-term interest rates are reshaping the huge commercial paper market, making this once elite form of short-term corporate financing available to a broader number of borrowers.

title: THE BARBLESS HOOK
description: Although barbs have been on fishing hooks since the Stone Age, some anglers - fly fishermen in particular - have long debated the merits of getting along without them.

title: Futures/Options; Downtrend Aids Many
description: The steady erosion of futures prices in recent months has been a welcome bonanza for most investors and managers of commodity funds, for it provided them with what all futures traders pray for - a long and defined trend.

title: BRAZILIAN FACES A VATICAN INQUIRY OVER SUPPORT FOR SOCIAL ACTIVISM
description: A leading Brazilian theologian has been summoned to a formal interrogation at the Vatican to answer charges that he committed serious doctrinal errors while defending the social activism of important sectors of Latin America's Roman Catholic Church.

title: It's Two For the Crown
description: Don Mattingly and Dave Winfield are like apple and orange. Similar but dissimilar. And each is enjoying a delicious and unexpected season. Mattingly and Winfield are 3 and 4 in the Yankee batting order and 1 and 2 in the race for the American League batting championship. They've been together at the top of the league batting averages for the last two months.

title: Increase in Births Out of Wedlock
description: Of 98,225 babies born in New Jersey in 1982, 21,315 - or 21.7 percent - were born out of wedlock, officials say. And 6,406 babies out of the 8,541 born to women under the age of 19 were out of wedlock.

title: FERRARO IS TERMED SURPRISED BY LOAN TAKEN BY HUSBAND
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro, the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, was ''surprised'' to learn about 10 days ago that her husband had borrowed $100,000 for their real-estate company from the assets of an elderly woman whose finances he was overseeing as a court-appointed conservator, a lawyer for her husband said yesterday.

title: WHEN A BENEFACTOR IS A BENEFICIARY
description: To the Editor:

title: LOTION, NOT OIL, ON BEACHES
description: As they flock to the shore for relaxation and a respite from summer heat, vacationers should be aware of a battle being waged in the committee rooms of Congress - a battle that could determine whether their ocean views include oil-drilling rigs and whether their beaches are exposed to the ecological disaster of a major oil spill.

title: NEW YORKERS STRUGGLE WITH ANGST OF AUGUST
description: It is the sort of weather, as Raymond Chandler once wrote, that curls your hair and makes your nerves jump and your skin itch. ''Meek little wives feel the edge of the carving knife and study their husbands' necks,'' the writer said. ''Anything can happen.''

title: Iran Is Seeking Jewels Thought to Be Shah's TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 19 (AP) - The Government has asked for the return of jewels that were reportedly seized last week at an airport by the Pakistani police, an Iranian newspaper said today. The jewels are believed to have been stolen during the 1979 revolution against Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlavi.
description: Pakistani officials in Islamabad have not confirmed reports that they intercepted the jewels, believed to have belonged to Empress Farah, at Lahore International Airport near the Indian border.

title: AMERICAN FAMILY: WHERE IS IT GOING?
description: During the 1970's, the American family, never before much of a political hot potato, became the focus of an ongoing and angry controversy. Regarded by conservative thinkers as the guardian of traditional values and by liberals as a vehicle for social change, the family came to symbolize two divergent ideologies on its rights and responsibilities and its relationship with the government.

title: Amy Horowitz and Brian Schorr Wed
description: Amy Beth Horowitz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Horowitz of New Hyde Park, L.I., and Brian Lewis Schorr, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Schorr of Flushing, Queens, were married yesterday. Rabbis Ephraim R. Wolf and Albert Thaler officiated at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue.

title: STRIKERS FELL PRESSURES OF FIVE PAYLESS WEEKS
description: It has been five weeks since New York's health-care walkout began, and the pinch has got so bad that Marcelina Morales, one of the strikers, is finding herself counting pennies.

title: The Unequal Copper Equation
description: America's copper producers, slammed by low prices, have persuaded the U.S. International Trade Commission that they've been injured by foreign competition. Buoyed by this finding, the industry is pressing President Reagan to cut imports in half.

title: Silicon Systems Names Chief Operating Officer
description: William D. Baker has been named to the new position of executive vice president and chief operating officer at Silicon Systems Inc., the company announced.

title: Studds Declines to Focus On Homosexual Issues
description: Representative Gerry E. Studds, censured by the House last summer for a homosexual affair in 1973 with a Congressional page, says he has no intention of becoming an advocate of homosexual issues if re-elected this year.

title: QUINLAN CAPTURES GOLF
description: Sally Quinlan's rookie year on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour had been a disaster.

title: Kemp Takes a Shot At Governor Cuomo
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp does not often get involved in New York politics, but today he was highly critical of Governor Cuomo.

title: 'BESSIES' TO BE AWARDED SEPT. 13 FOR ACHIEVEMENTS IN DANCE
description: Forget about Tony. Bid Oscar goodbye. Bessie has arrived.

title: No Headline
description: Domingo Stars in Film Of a Children's Ballet

title: NIGERIA'S ECONOMIC MORASS
description: The highway to this unfinished city, designated to be Nigeria's new capital, stops short. Street lights have yet to be installed in the red earth alongside the road. Past the highway, half-built apartment houses, office buildings and hotels rise among hills that are still grazed by chalk-white cattle driven by Fulani herders.

title: UNWED TEEN-AGE FATHERS
description: On sunny weekends, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, teen-aged fathers wheel baby carriages up and down the streets. The babies are shown off to friends and relatives, who smile approvingly, and then returned to the mothers, who usually live with their own mothers.

title: REPUBLICANS PUT ACCENT ON UNITY ON EVE OF PARLEY
description: With President Reagan and his conservative followers in unquestioned command, Republicans will open their national convention here Monday in a mood of cresting optimism as they prepare to nominate Mr. Reagan and Vice President Bush for a second term.

title: PAKISTAN SAYS SHELLING BY AFGHANS KILLED 18
description: Pakistan said today that 18 people had been killed in Pakistani territory in a one-hour artillery barrage by the Afghan armed forces.

title: F.C.C. MOVES TOWARD NATIONAL PAGING SYSTEM
description: The Federal Communications Commission is taking the first steps to permit a nationwide paging network that would let people who carry beepers receive signals no matter where they are in the United States.

title: Accounts
description: BASF Wyandotte Corp., Parsippany, N.J., to Geer, DuBois for agricultural chemicals.

title: ISRAEL LABORITES AND LIKUD AGREE ON LEBANON
description: Israel's two main parties, which are trying to form a national unity government, said tonight that they had agreed that Israeli troops should be withdrawn from south Lebanon as soon as possible.

title: AN F.B.I. CHARGE AGAINST THE K.G.B. IN NEED OF SOME WEIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: REGIONAL STRENGTHS AND WEAKNESSES
description: If the electoral votes in the last four Presidential elections are totaled, Republicans have won a majority in every region of the United States and have taken less than 65 percent in only one region.

title: 3,500 in South Africa Protest Election Plan
description: About 3,500 people attended a rally today to protest elections that they contend will entrench South Africa's system of apartheid.

title: 3 Parachutists Killed; Experts Unsure of Cause
description: Three veteran sky divers died while parachuting at an exhibition Saturday in this suburb of Denver, and experts expressed uncertainty today over the cause.

title: A PHENOMENON DESTROYED AFTER INJURY
description: The top sprinter A Phenomenon had to be humanely destroyed today after fracturing his left front cannon bone and pastern while leading in the Forego Handicap at Saratoga Race Track.

title: MONDAY, AUGUST 20, 1984 International
description: 15,000 people have died in Uganda in political and tribal violence since President Milton Obote returned to power nearly four years ago, the Government Information Minister said. The official Ugandan figure differs from an estimate given by Elliot Abrams, Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, who said in interviews and Congressional testimony that more than 100,000 Ugandans may have been killed by the military or died of starvation as result of military policies. (Page A1, Column 1.) A formal Vatican interrogation has been ordered for a leading Brazilian theologian to answer charges that he committed serious doctrinal errors while defending the social activism of important sectors of Latin America's Roman Catholic Church. (A1:2.)

title: Jersey Warehouse Has a 2d Blaze
description: A explosion Saturday started a small fire in the warehouse where a five-alarm chemical fire Friday night had forced 600 people to leave their homes.

title: Director Challenges Household
description: A plan by Household International Inc. to issue ''poison pill'' warrants as a means of thwarting any takeover attempt has been challenged by one of the company's directors.

title:
CONVENTION IN DALLAS: THE REPUBLICANS;
A Conservative's Conservative Describes the Typical Republican
description: The typical Republican is a woman in her early 40's, Cleopatra Coretta Barzini, who majored in business administration and Chaucer and who last spring came happily home with her husband from the college graduation ceremonies of their third child. Mrs. Barzini is the daughter of immigrants, who educated her in a parochial school where she learned from her teachers the basic educational disciplines, plus typing, plus baking blueberry muffins. Mrs. Barzini went on to law school and became an assistant district attorney in Detroit while active in the young Republicans, which gave her training in fiscal sanity, self-restraint, patriotism, family values and compassion. She was very much in the news when she prosecuted the Democratic boss of the county, a former Latin teacher, after revealing that per capita expenses on schoolchildren in the county had come to $1 million apiece, while only 18 percent of the high school graduates knew how to read.

title: COST OF LEGALIZING LOFTS IS FOCUS OF BITTER DEBATE
description: Amid heated disputes among tenants, landlords and small manufacturers, the New York City Loft Board is working to establish regulations for legalizing thousands of illegal residential lofts.

title: 2 WOUNDED AS POLICE IN BELFAST BATTLE PROTESTANTS
description: Protestant youths hurling firebombs clashed with the police early today in the latest flareup in a week of violence in Northern Ireland.

title: Dr. Charles Levenback Married to Dr. Wilkins
description: Dr. Isabelle Wilkins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Wilkins of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to Dr. Charles Levenback, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Levenback of New York. Rabbi Walter Jacob performed the ceremony at the Wilkins home.

title: People
description: Steve Burton promoted to senior vice president-chief financial officer of the international division of Doyle Dane Bernbach International.

title: THOUSANDS ON 'WORKFARE' GET HALF-PAY FOR DOING CITY JOBS
description: About 15,000 welfare recipients in New York City are required to work in jobs for as little as half the money paid to civil servants and private workers who perform the same or similar tasks.

title: A HEALTH GUIDE FOR WOMEN
description: A new free booklet has been prepared by Planned Parenthood of New York City to assist women who may seek help relating to birth control, pregnancy, postpartum care, sexually transmitted diseases, abortion or other matters relating to reproductive health care.

title: REAGAN PROJECTS SELF-CONFIDENCE AND IMAGE AS WASHINGTON OUTSIDER
description: Even after three and a half years as President, Ronald Reagan continues to present himself as the perpetual Federal outsider, again campaigning by contrasting ''those people'' in Washington with his vision of idealized ordinary Americans.

title: WAR ALTERED PUCCINI'S PLANS TO WRITE OPERETTA FOR VIENNA
description: Puccini originally intended ''La Rondine'' (''The Swallow'') as an operetta for Vienna, but the first World War intervened and led him to alter his plans. Having lost interest in the frivolous operetta style, he decided to turn his work into a genuine comic opera.

title: U.S. Appeals Integration Case
description: The Justice Department plans to appeal a Federal district judge's order that the Government turn over $28.75 million in desegregation money to the Chicago Board of Education.

title: STANDARD-BEARER
description: After a campaign swing through the Middle West earlier in the week, President Reagan is scheduled to arrive in Dallas Wednesday. That evening, the convention will vote on his nomination. On Thursday, after a filmed introduction, Mr. Reagan is scheduled to deliver his acceptance speech.

title: MONDALE VOICES CONFIDENCE IN RUNNING MATE'S FINANCES
description: Walter F. Mondale, faced with fresh questions about the finances of his running mate, Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, said today that he maintained his confidence in her and predicted that misimpressions would be corrected by her financial disclosure Monday.

title: QUESTIONS ABOUT FERRARO'S FINANCES
description: Questions about the finances of Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro and her husband, John A. Zaccaro, began within days of Walter F. Mondale's announcement on July 12 that he had selected her to be his Democratic Vice-Presidential running mate.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Role at Control Data In Selling to Schools
description: The Control Data Corporation has announced the formation of a subsidiary to deliver products and services to schools. It named Walter H. Bruning to direct the effort.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS ; ;  Chinese Athletes Hailed in Peking
description: More than 6,000 guests crammed Peking's Great Hall of the People today to congratulate China's triumphant Olympic athletes and watch Communist Party leaders award them special merit medals, Xinhua, the official press agency, said.

title: CONVENTION JOURNAL
description: A Gravestone Prop

title: NAVRATILOVA STRUGGLES TO BEAT SHRIVER
description: The last time Pam Shriver defeated Martina Navratilova, her doubles partner and close friend, the scene was Flushing Meadow, Queens, at the United States Open. It was 1982, and the drama of the effervescent Miss Shriver ruining her opponent's chance to achieve the coveted Grand Slam was enough to touch even the most hardened observer. Today, the scene and the outcome were different.

title: RUNNING MATE
description: Vice President Bush arrived in Dallas yesterday afternoon for a welcoming rally and a Texas-style barbecue at the Apparel Mart. The convention is scheduled to vote on his nomination Wednesday evening and he is to deliver his acceptance speech Thursday evening. He is scheduled to leave Dallas Friday afternoon.

title: Caribbean Cadences
description: Silvana Magda swayed gently to the

title: Damaged Coral Reef Reopened to Divers
description: Molasses Reef, part of the only living coral reefs in North America, was reopened today, giving recreational divers their first glimpse of the damage inflicted on the delicate marine growths by an intruding freighter.

title: MANILA'S ECONOMY: SIGNS OF ANGUISH EVERYWHERE
description: In the year since the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was shot to death at the Manila Airport last Aug. 21, the political and economic situation in the Philippines has deteriorated badly.

title: NBC MAKING FIRST THEATRICAL FILM
description: ''We're calling this a learning experience,'' said John Agoglia, executive vice president of NBC Productions, referring to the network's initial toe in the sometimes icy water of theatrical films.

title: A BRITON REVIVES A FALKLAND ISSUE
description: A Labor Member of Parliament said today that he had received three confidential Defense Ministry documents that he asserted showed that the Government was not telling the truth when it described the sinking of an Argentine cruiser in the Falkland War as an act of self-defense.

title: Pope Urges Scientists To Seek World Peace
description: Pope John Paul II urged American, Soviet, Chinese and European scientists attending a conference on nuclear war today to use the meeting to promote mutual trust leading to world peace.

title: Market Place; A Rough Time At Thrift Units
description: THAT Wall Street adage, ''Let your profits

title: TREVINO CAPTURES P.G.A. BY FOUR STROKES WITH 273
description: Lee Trevino, the 44-year-old Texan with an ailing back, defied all the rules about age and the need for constant practice when he rallied on the back nine of Shoal Creek Golf Club today to win the 66th annual P.G.A. Championship by four shots over Lanny Wadkins and Gary Player.

title: NUCLEAR QUESTION NO. 1
description: For reasons that escape me, more than a dozen Federal agencies are going to spend up to $50 million in the next five years to try to determine whether the dust, soot, ash and smoke raised in a nuclear war of indeterminate proportions would blot out the light of the sun and bring on a ''nuclear winter'' in which life on earth would be all but extinguished.

title: Advertising; Bergdorf Remodels Its Image
description: When Bergdorf Goodman opens the new entrance at its Fifth Avenue store next month, there will be no doubt of the changes at the high-fashion retailer. More than $15 million is being spent to renovate the 54-year- store inside and out by 1986.

title: Hoover Dam Bill Is Signed
description: President Reagan signed legislation Friday authorizing $77 million for visitor facilities and roadway improvements at Hoover Dam and settling a power allocation dispute among Nevada, California and Arizona. The bill, sponsored by Senator Chic Hecht, Republican of Nevada, authorizes increases in the dam's power capacity and sets a surcharge to help pay for the Central Arizona Project and Colorado River salinity control program.

title: MARIETTA AND JAPANESE SET ALUMINUM VENTURE
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation yesterday announced a joint venture in production and worldwide marketing of aluminum and titanium with Nippon Kokan K.K., a major Japanese steel and shipbuilding company.

title: PATTERN OF DECEIT
description: WASHINGTON Geraldine Ferraro promises that on the first two days of the Republican convention she and her accountants will hold news conferences that will clear up, once and for all, doubts about the integrity of her husband and herself.

title: Haya Pomrenze Is Bride Of David C. Tepper on L.I.
description: At the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue yesterday Haya R. Pomrenze, a daughter of Col. Seymour J. Pomrenze, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Pomrenze of Washington, was married to David C. Tepper, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. William Tepper of the Bronx. The bridegroom's father performed the ceremony.

title: TelevisionCoverage
description: The following television coverage is planned for the Republican National Convention:

title: SUCCESS AT LAST FOR SAN DIEGO
description: SAN DIEGO They used to say major league baseball would never work here because San Diego was surrounded on the north by the Los Angeles Dodgers, on the east by the desert, on the south by Mexico and on the west by the Pacific Ocean. And, for the last 14 years, they may have been right.

title: 'Family Farmer' Opposed In Michigan Name Fight
description: Officials of the Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party have asked the state Supreme Court to stop a Congressional candidate from using ''Family Farmer'' as his middle name.

title: 12 Bodies Found in Peru
description: At least 12 bodies have been found in hidden graves on the outskirts of the capital of the Ayacucho region in the Peruvian Andes.

title: A Portrait Project
description: Authentic original portraits of King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella may hang in a place of honor in the White House or the National Gallery in 1992 while the United States celebrates the 500th anniversary of its discovery. They may, that is, if John Paul Paine has his way.

title: GERMANY IS PRESSING AHEAD ON COAL GASIFICATION
description: West Germany, the cradle of synthetic fuel technology, is cautiously pressing ahead with its development of coal gasification projects, despite depressed crude oil prices, which have halted synthetic fuel projects worldwide.

title: MIDLER IN CONCERT ON HBO
description: Bette Midler takes risks that other performers do not. She attempts to be touching, bawdy and funny, often simultaneously. When she succeeds she is brilliant, and when she fails she is done in by her own excess. On ''Bette Midler: Art or Bust!'' she succeeds more often than she fails; she is, in fact, close to being an absolute winner, and if she were an Olympic gymnast, going for a perfect 10, she would get a 9.9. Her one-hour Home Box Office special, taken from a live concert, will be seen at 8 o'clock tonight on ''Standing Room Only.''

title: Football Feedback
description: Every year about this time the National Collegiate Athletic Association conducts a survey of several hundred college football players across the country and sends out a compendium of their answers to such questions as why they play football, what rules changes they would like to see and what their most embarrassing moments have been.

title: DANCE: FLAMENCO PROGRAM AT PUBLIC'S FESTIVAL LATINO
description: Hispanic culture has been celebrated this past week in the Festival Latino en Nueva York at the Public Theater. On Saturday night, it was the art of performing that was celebrated, in an outstanding program called Cumbres Flamencas. Presented by a company of singers, musicians and dancers chosen by the Spanish Government, the program aimed at suggesting what has been and can be done with flamenco music and dance, an ancient improvisatory art form practiced by Spanish gypsies. Flamenco requires exceptional responsiveness among the performers, and it got it in Cumbres Flamencas.

title: TARDY MINESWEEPING
description: To the Editor:

title: Viveca Falberg Is a Bride
description: At Temple B'nai Chaim in Georgetown, Conn., yesterday Viveca Lee Falberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Falberg of Weston, Conn., was married to David Albert Hubbard, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Crescens Garman Hubbard of White Plains. Rabbi Charles Lippmann officiated. The bride's father is vice president of personnel of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation in New York. Mr. Hubbard's father is a retired patent counsel for the General Foods Corporation in White Plains.

title: VIDEO RENTAL ROOMS FOUGHT
description: Like some 12,000 others across the country, two small Pennsylvania merchants, Maxwell's Video Showcase and the Nickelodean Video Showcase, rent out movie cassettes. But they go one step further.

title: No Headline
description: Phoebe Frosch a Bride

title: An Elephantine History
description: In the spring of 1874, The New York Herald charged the popular President Grant with ''Caesarism,'' planning to run for a third term and make himself a dictator. That summer, The Herald published a hoax - a report that the animals in the Central Park Zoo had broken out.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 20, 1984: MONDAY BankAmerica RltyJaclynCentury Tel EnterSan Diego Gas & ElChicago Rivet & Mach

title: Lauda Takes Lead
description: Austria's Niki Lauda, cheered on by an overjoyed crowd, drove his McLaren Porsche to victory today in the Austrian Grand Prix. The victory gave Lauda the lead in the season point race for the Formula One driving title with 4 of 16 races to go.

title: Charter Planning To Shut Refinery
description: The Charter Company said it would close its 70,000-barrel-a-day Houston refinery and try to sell it.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air Products and Chemicals Inc. of Allentown, Pa., said it had begun construction of a multimillion-dollar liquid hydrogen plant in Sacramento, Calif.

title: EUROPE'S ONE CULTURE IS WORTHY OF REVIVAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Johnston & Murphy Plans a $2 Million Drive
description: Johnston & Murphy, a footwear company since 1850, will spend $2 million on a new print advertising campaign beginning next month. J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. created the campaign and the theme, ''Unmistakably Johnston & Murphy.''

title: FERRARO REVEALS HER TAX FIGURES AND HUSBAND'S
description: Text of statements, page B8.

title: CHARTER FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,354,753 on the sale of loans. c-There were no comparable year- ago results because the company converted from a Federal mutual to a stock savings and loan on March 27, 1984.

title: GREAT DISCOVERIES OFTEN RESULT FROM CHANCE
description: BOSTON THE important discovery of a new treatment for severe burns is a striking example of the serendipity of science.

title: Speedboat Racer Killed in Belgium
description: Tom Percival, a 30-year-old British speedboat driver, died today after his boat overturned and threw him onto the banks of the Meuse River during the Belgian Formula One Grand Prix here Sunday.

title: Missing Woman Was Strangled
description: An autopsy report on a missing New Jersey woman whose body was found in a Morris County landfill Friday says that the victim died from strangulation.

title: ACMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BOLIVIANS REPORT DESTROYING 2 COCAINE FACTORIES
description: In what was described as an opening attack on the multibillion-dollar cocaine industry in Bolivia, the police were reported today to have destroyed two large drug factories and confiscated 836 pounds of cocaine, as well as aircraft and weapons.

title: Bridgeport Brass
description: The Bridgeport Brass Corporation, a new company, said it had acquired substantially all of the business and assets of the Bridgeport Brass Company, a division of the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation.

title: REMARKS BY BAKER
description: Following are excerpts from the address last night by the Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, at the Republican National Convention, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of C-Span:

title: WESTSIDE BANCORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AIRLINE TO FINANCE RECALL OF A BOOK
description: Under threat of a lawsuit from American Airlines, a book publisher has recalled 25,000 copies of ''Splash of Colors: The Self-Destruction of Braniff International'' by John J. Nance. As part of the agreement, American will pay the publisher, William Morrow and Company, up to $150,000 to cover the cost of the recalled books, which had already been printed and were awaiting shipment to bookstores.

title: MANY SHOPS IN HAMPTONS SUFFER TOUGH TIMES THAT SIGNAL CHANGE
description: For the first time since David Stull opened his jewelery store on this village's fashion alley more than six years ago, he is staying open long after the sun has set.

title: California Utility Is Offering Bonds
description: The Sacramento Municipal Utility District is offering $210 million of electric revenue bonds through underwriters led by Goldman Sachs & Company. Proceeds of the Aa-rated bonds will be used for the utility's construction program and to finance its share of the Coldwater Creek geothermal power plant.

title: Big Days at the Phillips
description: The Phillips Collection, the oldest museum of modern art in

title: ON GIVING LOUIS FARRAKHAN A NATIONAL FORUM
description: To the Editor:

title: CORDIS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $5,987,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $6,438,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $300,000.

title: Lost and Found
description: Alexi Grewal , a 23-year-old from Aspen Colo., became the first American man to win an Olympic gold medal in cycling when he captured the 118-mile road race on July 29. It took only two weeks to lose the medal, but now he appears to have it back.

title: Republican Platform Is Assailed by Soviet
description: Official Soviet media today denounced the Republican Party platform as a ''kiddy- language document'' that will isolate the United States internationally and do nothing to improve relations with the Soviet Union.

title: Data Acquisition
description: The Data I/O Corporation said it had agreed to acquire all of the shares outstanding of the Futurenet Corporation in exchange for 2,160,000 Data I/O shares.

title: Deposits Up On Coast
description: The savings and loan industry in California set records for total deposits and assets during the second quarter, as well as sharply increased its mortgage-lending volume despite rising interest rates, the California League of Savings Institutions reported.

title: Power Company's $113 Million Issue
description: A $113 million issue of pollution control revenue bonds for the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company are being offered by the Lehigh County Industrial Development Authority through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Saudi King's Proposal
description: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia proposed today that oil prices be ''fixed for a specific number of years'' as a way to stabilize the market.

title: 24 HAMPTONS PARTIES FOR CULTURE
description: Summertime is always party time in the Hamptons, but this weekend took the cake - and the champagne and the caviar and the polenta - for the most concentrated partying in recent memory. In addition to the usual cocktail, dinner and birthday parties, two dozen events were held to raise money for the Guild Hall of East Hampton, the local cultural center.

title: TUESDAY, AUGUST 21, 1984 International
description: George P. Shultz voiced confidence that freedom would someday be restored to the Soviet-dominated countries of Eastern Europe. In a speech to the annual convention of the Veterans of Foreign Wars in Chicago, the Secretary of State echoed a theme struck by President Reagan on Friday in opposing the ''subjugation'' of Eastern Europe. (Page A1, Cols. 3-4.) India's main opposition parties joined in calling for rallies and demonstrations Saturday outside Government offices to protest what they consider Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's increasing disregard of democratic practices. The opposition parties rarely act together. (A3:4-6.)

title: Man, 27, Charged In Jersey Slayings
description: A 27- year-old man was charged today with killing a husband and wife who had tried to prevent him from dating their 13-year-old daughter. A second 13- year-old girlfriend of the suspect also was charged.

title: Jersey Hospital Finds Legionnaire Bacteria
description: The bacteria that causes Legionnaires' disease was found in two water samples taken from a state hospital that housed a patient who died of the mysterious ailment, officials said today.

title: Ted Brown Dies at 78; Ohio Secretary of State
description: Ted W. Brown, the former Ohio Secretary of State who held the office for 28 years, died of cancer today at his home. He was 78 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Patience is a virtue in foreign affairs as much as in our personal lives.

title: TEXT OF KEYNOTE SPEECH BY ORTEGA TO DELEGATES
description: Following is the text of the keynote address delivered last night by Katherine Davalos Ortega, Treasurer of the United States, at the Republican National Convention in Dallas, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of C-Span:

title: NOVAN ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Panel Appoints Abba Eban Interim Head of Parliament
description: Abba Eban, the former Israeli Foreign Minister, was named temporary speaker of Parliament today until a new government is formed.

title: CHAIRMAN FEELS SECURE AT MUCH-COURTED LEVITZ
description: Robert M. Elliott, chairman and chief executive officer of the Miami- based Levitz Furniture Corporation, is confident that no matter who eventually purchases his company, he will remain in his post as leader of the country's largest independent specialty retailer of home furniture.

title: ARMY EVACUATES PACIFIC ATOLL AS HURRICANE NEARS
description: A major United States Army chemical weapons dump was evacuated as Hurricane Keli threatened Johnston Island today with winds up to 100 miles an hour, military officials said.

title: MCGRAW-HILL RYERSON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RESEARCH-COTTRELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $1,898,000.

title: New SSC&B Executive
description: Frank DeVito, 45, most recently executive vice president and co-creative director of Young & Rubicam USA, is joining SSC&B Inc., New York, as vice chairman and director of creative services. Mr. DeVito, who joined Y.& R. in 1967 as an art director, became executive vice president and co-creative director along with John Ferrell early this year.

title: Cooper Stake In Frigitronics WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -
description: Cooper Laboratories Inc. told

title: The Return of Realness
description: In the sports world today, reality,

title: ALLY & GARGANO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $408,000 for bad debt provisions relating to client insolvency. c-Net income. Revenue figures represent gross billings and fees.

title: HARPER & ROW PUBLISHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
OIL INDUSTRY NUMBERS GAME
description: In a world where people can count the number of molecules on a pinhead, oil experts cannot seem to determine how much of the most widely used energy source is in commerce or even what it costs on a given day.

title: Japan-U.S. Electronics Tie
description: Japan's electronics trade group is offering membership to United States companies, which could make it easier for American electronics concerns to penetrate the Japanese market, a key Congressman said today.

title: TRANSCONTINENTAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including net income from discontinued operations of $772,000 for the quarter and $794,000 for the 6 months.

title: MILTON ROY NAMES AN HEIR APPARENT
description: The Milton Roy Company, a fluid instrumentation manufacturer based in St. Petersburg, Fla., yesterday announced the appointment of Richard E. Schmidt as president and chief operating officer.

title: Debt Rating ;  Corporate Notes
description: Humana Inc.'s ratings on senior unsecured debt were raised to A2, from A3, and on subordinated debt to A3, from Baa1, by Moody's Investors Service.

title: ISRAELIS SEAL ROAD TO SOUTH LEBANON
description: Israel, citing security concerns, today sealed off to traffic the only road linking southern Lebanon with the rest of the country. The road will stay closed until Wednesday.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: WHEN fashion designers began producing what has become known as their second lines a little over two years ago - Anne Klein II, for example - the reason was the perception that a large market for fashionable, less pricey clothes had not yet been tapped. Underlying that was the feeling among many designers that high-priced designer clothes had reached saturation level in the stores - that there were, in short, only so many ball gowns a woman could own.

title: A Weighty Issue Coach
description: Tom Osborne of Nebraska disagrees with a magazine article claiming Nebraska's well-publicized weight program takes its toll on the football players before they turn professional. In a Sports Illustrated issue due on the newstands this week, the article says: ''In the last 14 years, only three players from Nebraska, the leading collegiate football power in the stretch, have made the Pro Bowl - Andra Franklin, Junior Miller and John Dutton.

title: Employment in Italy
description: Average employment in Italian industrial companies with more than 500 employees fell 5.1 percent in the first five months of the year compared with the period in 1983, the Government said today.

title: Citibank Acquires Puerto Rican Bank
description: Citibank, after taking over a bank in Puerto Rico that had been declared insolvent, reopened its three offices yesterday as new Citibank branches in the island commonwealth.

title: METS DEFEATED, FALL 4 GAMES OUT
description: The Mets, muzzled by Eric Show and dazzled by Rich Gossage, got only five singles tonight and fell four games out of first place in the National League's East when they lost to the San Diego Padres, 3-1.

title: THE ZACCARO COMPANIES
description: Following are some of the companies controlled by Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro and John A. Zaccaro, or associated with them, that have come up in documents released today and other public records:

title: WILLIAMS GETS ROLE ON GIANTS' DEFENSE
description: With a ''clearer idea'' of how he foresees the makeup of his final 49- man roster, Coach Bill Parcells dropped four more players and addressed other matters of import today as the Giants prepared to break camp at Pace University here Tuesday. His most important decision was the naming of Perry Williams as the likely regular at right cornerback.

title: PARTNERS OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New Bolar Drug
description: The Bolar Pharmaceutical Company said it had received approval from the Food and Drug Admnistration to make and market tablets of methyclothiazide with diserpidine.

title: White Spending
description: White Consolidated Industries said it would spend $60.9 million for new equipment at six plants of its home appliance group as part of a previously anounced companywide $400 million spending program. The plants involved are: the Americold Compressor Company plant in Cullman, Ala.; the Athens Products Company plant in Athens, Tenn.; the Columbus Products Company plant in Columbus, Ohio; the Franklin Manufacturing Company plant in St. Cloud, Minn.; the Webster City Products Company plant in Jefferson, Iowa, and the Webster City Products plant in Webster City, Iowa.

title: A REMARK BY REAGAN TRANSFORMED INTO NEWS
description: To the Editor:

title: Art and Agriculture On the Lower East Side
description: Decrepit buildings surround it. On a
