title: LASERS APPLY VERY THIN FILMS TO FLAT AREAS
description: RESEARCHERS at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have developed a laser-based technique for quickly and accurately applying extremely thin films to flat surfaces.

title: TEXT OF JEANE J. KIRKPATRICK'S REMARKS AT REPUBLICAN CONVENTION IN DALLAS
description: Following is the text of remarks by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, at the Republican National Convention last night, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of C-Span:

title: Using, and Abusing, the Rackets Law
description: Rico: that's the shorthand name for the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act Congress passed in 1970 to contain organized crime. But lately, the issue has changed. People now are arguing about how to contain Rico.

title: IN DALLAS, GALA WITH CAST OF A THOUSAND
description: Neiman-Marcus, Dallas's symbol of the good life, threw a party Sunday night for Jeane J. Kirkpatrick and Margaret M. Heckler. But a youngster named Baby Star almost upstaged the two Cabinet members.

title: Black Journalist Group Honors Times Reporter
description: Sam Roberts, a reporter for The New York Times, has been honored by the National Association of Black Journalists for three articles on Congressional hearings into allegations of racially motivated police brutality in New York City.

title: CLAIRE'S STORES reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
description: b-Includes tax credits of $210,440 for the quarter and $668,900 for the 6 months. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect two 3-for-2 stock splits effective April 5 and July 10.

title: Letter: On Loans ; Let Students Work Off Their Debts To the Editor:
description: Your Aug. 4 editorial ''Increase Some Graduate School Loans'' sidesteps the main issue. Granted, the Federal Guaranteed Student Loan (G.S.L.) program does not sufficiently fund graduate education. But raising our debt limit to $37,000 is only a partial solution.

title: DIVERS IN JAMAICA SEARCH 'WICKEDEST CITY' THAT SANK IN 1692
description: PORT ROYAL, JAMAICA ONE by one the divers surfaced in the tranquil, emerald sea as a blazing sun glinted off their equipment. They had been down for three hours, working on their hands and knees in 10 feet of water, sifting through the ruins of what some archeologists regard as one of the best-preserved 17th century British colonial sites in the world.

title: ELECTRONICS CORP OF ISRAEL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in February 1984.

title: JACOBS GROUP MAY BID FOR TIDEWATER
description: Investors led by Irwin L. Jacobs, a Minneapolis financier, said yesterday that they had reached an agreement with Tidewater Inc. to study the acquisition of the New Orleans-based energy service company.

title: Bossy's Knee Sore
description: Mike Bossy , the Islander right wing, is scheduled to take a break from Team Canada's camp in Montreal today to fly to Long Island, where his sore right knee will be examined.

title: President Resigns At Needham USA
description: Peter A. Nelson, 52, president and chief operating officer of Needham, Harper & Steers/USA, resigned to ''pursue a new career opportunity which he will announce in the near future,'' the company said.

title: YAMANI SEES NEW OIL DEMAND
description: Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, was quoted today as saying that the turmoil in the world oil market would be over by the end of September and that by October OPEC would be considering an increase rather than a cut in its oil output ceiling.

title: SCOA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
CONVERTIBLE ISSUES IN DEMAND
description: The recent rally in stocks has reignited interest in one of Wall Street's more arcane products - convertible securities. Unsure whether equities will continue to forge ahead and reluctant to forgo high yields in the bond market, many professional and individual investors are turning to convertibles to hedge their bets.

title: Fortune Considers Buying North Star
description: The Fortune Systems Corporation, a maker of multi-user office computers, said yesterday that it may acquire North Star Computer Inc.

title: DOUGHTIE'S FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in July 1984.

title: Yugoslav-China Accord
description: A Yugoslav steel plant has concluded a 10-year export agreement with China worth $500 million, the Yugoslav press agency, Tanyug, said today. It added that the plant would export 100,000 metric tons of metallurgical products annually.

title: IN DALLAS, IT'S MORE THAN A FEMININE TOUCH
description: Everywhere, there are women. And, everywhere, there are Republican officials pointing out the fact that women are everywhere.

title: No Cause for Joy
description: Tim Lewis of the Green Bay Packers did some celebrating with a Mark Gastineau-like dance after he sacked Vince Ferragamo, the Los Angeles Rams' quarterback, during Sunday's exhibition. Lewis, slapped with a 5-yard penalty for unsportsmanlike conduct, became the first player penalized for celebrating after sacking a quarterback.

title: ROCK VIDEO, ALL DAY AND ALL NIGHT
description: MTV, the cable service that shows rock video clips all day and all night, has announced a claim to the top of the pops. In the second quarter of 1984, among the households that can receive MTV, it had the highest average 24-hour Nielsen rating of the advertiser-supported cable services.

title: PACIFIC INTERNATIONAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $45,000.

title: The Road Is Long
description: Madison Square Garden has been reserved for Thursday, Nov. 15, for the possible professional boxing debuts of Mark Breland and Pernell Whitaker, gold medalists in the recent Olympics. There have been negotiations with ABC and other groups that might bring the two fighters contracts worth $1 million for a series of four bouts.

title: Navratilova Duo Wins Doubles
description: The top-seeded team of Martina Navratilova and Pam Shriver won the doubles championship of the United Jersey Bank Classic today, beating Jo Durie and Ann Kiyomura- Hayashi, who were seeded second, by 7-6, 3-6, 6-2.

title: EGYPT'S DWINDLING JEWS CELEBRATE A RARE WEDDING
description: Benoit Salem and Fabienne Rousseau exchanged marriage vows recently in what was an especially joyous occasion - the first Jewish wedding in Egypt in 19 years.

title: BENEFICIAL STANDARD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain from the sale of insurance businesses of $24,325,000, or $4.20 a share, for the quarter and 6 months, and gains from discontinued operations of $1,337,000, or 23 cents a share, for the quarter and $4,008,000, or 69 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Net income, which includes gains from discontinued operations of $2,890,000, or 50 cents a share, for the quarter and $4,726,000, or 81 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: PAINTING RECOVERED AT SHOW
description: A $50,000 Colonial-era painting stolen from a Boston historical society two years ago was put back on display last Friday, after it was found on sale for $90 at a church antiques show.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 21, 1984

title: MAKE A CRIMINAL PAY BACK HIS VICTIM
description: America's criminal justice system must face the issue of economic sanctions for criminal offenders if it is ever to cope with burgeoning crime. New York State, as a result of recently enacted landmark legislation, may well be able to demonstrate to the nation the value of such sanctions.

title: THE ALL-MALE COLLEGE VANISHING
description: BOB Tomaso says he has grown accustomed to the reactions he gets from friends around home in Milford, Mass., when they find out what sort of college he attends. Mr. Tomaso is entering his senior year at Washington and Lee University in Lexington, Va., an institution that does not admit women as undergraduates.

title: London Subway Crash Kills Driver and Hurts 26
description: A crowded subway train ran into the rear of another one today, killing the motorman and injuring 26 passengers, rescue workers said.

title: DUNKIN' DONUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
A STRONGER PRESIDENT?
description: DALLAS The long, distressing runup to the

title: PAKISTANIS REPORT 16 MORE KILLED IN SHELLING
description: The Government reported a second straight day of cross-border artillery fire by Afghan troops today, saying that the latest attack had killed 16 people.

title: Argentina's Inflation Goal
description: The Argentine Government began drawing up a plan today to halve its more than 600 percent annual inflation rate, officials said.

title: HACH CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
Couple Charged With Child Abuse
description: A Haverstraw man and his wife were indicted today on charges of having beaten and burned the man's 12-year- old twin sons at his Rockland County home.

title: 'Galina: A Russian Story'
description: Each autumn in the capital, there is a rush of cocktail parties promoting new books and their authors, many of whom are unknown outside Washington, some perhaps appropriately so. But the book party to be given at the Watergate Hotel on Sept. 6 may be different.

title: CONCERT: ORGAN PROGRAM OF 20TH-CENTURY WORKS
description: THE Wall Street area, with its vast canyons of stone and steel, is almost deserted after dark and on weekends, and might therefore seem an unlikely place to attend a Sunday night concert. This summer, however, Trinity Church has sponsored a series of programs devoted to 20th-century organ music, with a preconcert ringing of the tower bells.

title: WESTMIN RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: ROONEY, PACE GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $4,345,696 for the quarter ane $50,633 for the year. c-Net income. The company changed its fiscal year-end from June to May. Year-ago results are for 2 and 11 months ended May 31.

title: CONVENTION IN DALLAS: THE REPUBLICANS; 'I WAS BORN A REPUBLICAN'
description: When the chairman of the Republican National Committee announced last June that Katherine Ortega would be the keynote speaker at the party's convention in Dallas, he described her life and accomplishments as the embodiment of Republican values and philosophies. Mrs. Ortega, the 38th Treasurer of the United States and the most prominent Hispanic official in the Reagan Administration, would be the first to agree with that assessment.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Aug. 21, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Key Rates

title: DIET SWEETNER RISK IS BEING REASSESSED AFTER NEW RESEARCH
description: -CALORIE sweeteners, perhaps the most thoroughly studied of all food additives, are undergoing a new scientific evaluation that already seems to be changing judgments about their relative value and safety.

title: REACTION ON DISNEY
description: Gibson Greetings Inc., shaken by the surprise announcement last Friday that Walt Disney Productions had canceled its $330 million plan to buy the company, said in Cincinnati yesterday that it was ''reviewing the situation'' to insure that its stockholders were protected.

title: AT 85, A BUSY COUNTRY DOCTOR
description: The blue spruce now soars 80 feet, its needled branches spreading outward in thick layers. When Dr. Anna W. Perkins planted a three-inch spruce seedling in 1929, right next to her newly built white clapboard house, she had already been practicing ''country medicine'' for one year here in the foothills of the Catskills.

IPCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: INTRODUCING REAGAN: IMAGES AND A THEME SONG
description: Republicans have spent untold dollars and three years of collecting footage preparing an 18-minute film to introduce President Reagan Thursday night. They have come up with a fast and evocative patriotic poem and a controversy over whether the television networks should broadcast it as news or spurn it as an unpaid political commercial.

title: COMPO PRESIDENT ADDS TITLE OF CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Compo Industries, a maker of shoe machinery and materials based in Waltham, Mass., has given its president, Leonard Rosenblatt, the additional title of chief executive officer. That title had been held by the company's chairman, Peter Weiss, who continues in that post.

title: ADDRESS BY HECKLER
description: Following are excerpts from the speech delivered last night at the Republican convention by Margaret M. Heckler, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of C-Span:

title: LEWIS TRIUMPHS IN BUDAPEST
description: Carl Lewis, the American sprinting star, and Steve Cram of Britain scored easy victories today at the Budapest Grand Prix track meet.

title: FERRARO AND ZACCARO DID NOT TELL AGENCY OF FINES
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro and her husband, John A. Zaccaro, told a New York State agency in signed documents that they had not been fined or charged with any violations of law by any government agency, even though Mrs. Ferraro's campaign committee and Mr. Zaccaro had paid penalties for violations of Federal campaign-finance laws.

title: THRIFT UNIT RAISES $222 MILLION
description: The Financial Corporation of America, moving to bolster its cash reserves, sold seven million shares of the American Express Company shortly after noon today at a price of $31.75 a share, for a total of $222.3 million.

title: LED DRIVE TO EXPAND
description: Eugene Stanley Northrop, a retired vice chairman and chief lending officer of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, died Sunday at Naples Community Hospital in Naples, Fla. He was 79 years old and lived in Naples.

title: SOUNDS LIKE NEWS, TASTES LIKE NEWS, BUT FACT?
description: Some of the best stories in Washington turn out not to be true and never get written. But they get around.

title: U.S. Navy Secretary Touring Chinese Bases
description: The United States Navy Secretary, John F. Lehman, began a tour of Chinese naval installations today after an ''extremely productive'' series of talks in Peking, the American Embassy said.

title: More Banks Cut C.D. Rates More New York City banks

title: RED SEA MINE HUNT CALLED LONG TERM
description: Egypt's Foreign Minister said today that the international search for mines in the Gulf of Suez was ''open ended'' and that American, British, and French forces would be invited to stay until there was no longer a threat to the strategic waterway.

title: NEW ENTRY IN CUOMO DIARY: 'TODAY, IN CHICAGO...'
description: Someone named Mario M. Cuomo flew into Chicago with a New York accent today, and a lot of people didn't know who he was.

description: b-Including tax credits of $90,000 for the quarter and $530,000 for the 6 months.

title: MANILA'S POLICE ON ALERT ON EVE OF AQUINO RALLIES
description: The police have been placed on a high state of alert for possible violence Tuesday, when a major rally is planned to mark the first anniversary of the assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr.

title: Sudan Invites Rebels To Talk Instead of Fight
description: The Government today urged rebels in the country's south to abandon violence and open talks with the authorities.

title: BARRETT RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title:
TV SPORTS;
ORGANIZER INVOLVED FROM TEE TO GREEN
description: When Mark McCormack presented the winner's trophy to Nancy Lopez on national television at the conclusion of a Ladies Professional Golf Association event Sunday, the gesture represented a confluence of his corporation's interests.

title: WINKELMAN STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
BFI COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $205,160.

title: Quartet From AC& R Starts a New Shop
description: Four former senior vice presidents of AC& R Advertising Inc., a division of Ted Bates Worldwide, have formed their own agency - Rockmore, Mosallem, Bloch & deLeo Inc. The four resigned last May ''to apply our extensive and varied backgrounds in an environment that will allow us to concentrate on the basics of the advertising business,'' said Mitchell Mosallem, 40 years old, chairman of the new agency.

title: KOCH IN ACCORD ON COOPERATION IN ABUSE CASES
description: Bronx District Attorney Mario Merola and Mayor Koch agreed yesterday to seek state legislation that would clarify the sometimes conflicting roles of district attorneys and the city's social welfare agency in the investigation of child-abuse cases.

title: CLUBMART TRIES NEW APPROACH
description: Last December, in a move closely watched by competitors, the founder of Korvettes joined a former vice president of the Mellon Bank and opened Clubmart of America, the first membership-only discount store in Manhattan in decades.

title: New York Supporter of I.R.A. Is to Appear in Dublin Today
description: An American supporter of the Irish Republican Army who eluded a police attack last week will come out of hiding Tuesday and make an appearance in Dublin, the I.R.A.'s legal political wing announced today.

title: FREED POLISH REBEL SAYS WARSAW THREATENEDTO ARREST HIM AGAIN
description: A Solidarity activist, released from jail nine days ago under an amnesty for political prisoners, said he had been threatened today with possible rearrest after speaking publicly in a church.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Heller International Corp. , a Chicago-based holding company, has named Charles T. Mallet senior vice president of information management services.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE LIFE AND LOVES OF A SHE-DEVIL. By Fay Weldon. 241 pages. Pantheon Books. $13.95.

title: INDIAN AND PAKISTANI TOUR GULF
description: Indian and Pakistani officials toured Persian Gulf nations today in a diplomatic effort to end the Iran-Iraq war.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Washington yesterday on the role of Vice President Bush in the coming campaign incorrectly described his 1980 campaign for the Vice Presidency against Walter F. Mondale. The two did not debate.

title: Crime Control Suit
description: Crime Control Inc. said the company, its president, auditors, investment bankers and three former directors had been named in a class- action lawsuit.

title: Ghana Moves on Foreigners
description: The Ghanaian Government has forbidden all employers, including private corporations, to hire foreign personnel if qualified Ghanaians are available to fill vacant positions, the Accra radio said today.

title: ALTERNACARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $21,000, or one cent a share, for the quarter and $72,000, or 3 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-There were no comparable year- ago results because the company made its initial public offering on July 5.

title: JAMES RIVER CORP OF VIRGINIA reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
TWO POSTAL UNIONS KEEPING OPTION ON U.S. STRIKE OPEN
description: Unions representing most of the nation's 600,000 postal workers today voted to leave open the option of a strike in their month-old impasse with the Postal Service.

title: Catholics in Peru Make Offer To Mediate Guerrilla Conflict
description: The Roman Catholic Church in Peru offered today to mediate in the four-year- old conflict between leftist Shining Path guerrillas and the Government.

title: WEST GERMAN VISITS ALBANIA, STIRRING TALK OF TIES
description: Franz Josef Strauss, the Bavarian Premier, went to Albania today on a visit that fueled speculation here that Mr. Strauss might be preparing the way for diplomatic links between Albania and West Germany.

title: Kestner Seeks 3d Met Title
description: The 69th Metropolitan Golf Association Open will begin Tuesday at the Old Oaks Country Club, with Darrell Kestner in position to set a record by winning it for the third consecutive year.

title: AS SEX ROLES CHANGE, MEN TURN TO THERAPY TO COPE WITH STRESS
description: A GROWING number of American men who have embraced society's changing perception of manhood are finding that the change has brought on unexpected stress for which they are seeking psychotherapy.

title: WIND PLAYS SURPRISING ROLE IN SPIN OF EARTH
description: NEW, highly precise measurements of the Earth's rotation have shown that its rate varies from day to day in a manner that, to a surprising degree, is controlled by the weather.

title: BLESSINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 14
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $331,400 for the quarter and $1,245,800 for the 6 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $364,900 for the quarter and $668,600 for the 6 months.

title: Mahar-Penders Planning Encore
description: Old Columbia University basketball coaches seem to wind up at Fordham. Buddy Mahar, whose contract was not renewed as Columbia's head coach after the Lions finished at 8-18 last season, is headed for another reunion with Tom Penders, the Fordham coach.

title: ANTI-GANDHI PARTIES CALL PROTEST RALLIES
description: India's major opposition parties called today for a series of rallies to protest what they consider the increasing disregard of democratic norms and conventions by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: THE PROVING OVER, SEASON 14 AHEAD
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I.

title: THE TROUBLE IN CATCHING A RIDE TO THE PLANE
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. TO ATTACK MONDALE'S 'TURF'
description: Increasingly confident of President Reagan's political base in the South and West and convinced that Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro remains on the defensive, Reagan strategists are preparing to challenge Walter F. Mondale in Democratic strongholds in the Northeast and Middle West.

title: BARBECUES FOR BIGWIGS
description: The score at Jim and Dorothy Collins's Wildbriar Farm on Republican Convention Tuesday was two big barbecues down and one to go. By late afternoon, when another batch of powerful Republicans arrives, the former Congressman and his wife will have welcomed nearly 2,000 foreign diplomats, tycoons and assorted bigwigs here for the Republican National Convention. That, according to Mr. Collins, who knows a thing or two about reaching out to the world, is what Dallas hospitality is all about.

title: Daughter of President Faults Party Stances
description: Maureen Reagan, the first member of the First Family to arrive at the Republican National Convention, suggested today that the party platform did not provide enough room for all Republicans to stand on.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: SHOW PLACE One of the newer museum halls in town is in an old one-time carriage house that has somehow survived at 125 West 55th Street amid the high and mighty new structures that have taken over the neighborhood. This is the interim home of the Museum of American Folk Art, which is camping out there until its new permanent headquarters are finished on 53d Street in 1986. The present hall is quite roomy inside and there are two levels, with the upper one reached by a lighthouse-type staircase.

title: ANTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $42,300,000 from the sale of the company's Four Seasons Nursing Centers Unit when it was sold as part of the company's plan of liquidation.

title: 8 HOSPITALS CITED FOR DEFICIENCIES CAUSED BT STRIKE
description: The State Department of Health cited eight struck hospitals in New York City yesterday for medical and nursing deficiencies and said it was investigating whether the deficiencies had contributed to the death of one patient.

title: Farrakhan Denounces 'Jewish Lobby' Power
description: Louis Farrakhan, the Black Muslim leader, said today that he had seen President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale ''absolutely bow down to the strength of the Jewish lobby'' and warned against being ''dragged into the third world war.''

title: F.D.I.C. Consolidation
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation will reduce its 12 regional offices to six in the next several years, officials announced today.

title: DALLAS GALLERY; CEREMONIOUS PAWING OF THE GROUND
description: John Russell is the senior art critic of The Times.

title: ATARI HEAD SUES ALLY THAT DEFECTED TO RIVAL
description: Jack Tramiel, the new chief of the Atari Corporation, has filed a suit for fraud against a small Silicon Valley computer company that once appeared a likely Atari ally and then said last week that it would be acquired by Commodore International Ltd., Atari's chief competitor.

title: Children to Testify in Public
description: A judge denied a prosecution request today to close the courtroom during testimony by children in a trial of two of 24 adults charged with sexual abuse. Judge Martin Mansur rejected the argument that the children would be harmed if forced to testify in a full courtroom. Jury selection was scheduled to begin Tuesday for the trial of a couple, Lois Bentz, 33 years old, and Robert Bentz, 36, of Jordan.

title: French Missile Accident
description: Four vehicles on a farm in southern France were damaged today by a missile inadvertently fired from a fighter plane that mechanics were working on at a nearby military base, an air force spokesman said. No one was injured when the missile exploded after hitting a tree.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: A $504 million financing by the New Jersey Turnpike Authority was tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 10 3/4 percent for bonds due in 2003 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: G.O.P. CONVENTION OPENS AS LEADERS ASSAIL DEMOCRATS
description: Speech excerpts, pages A20 and 22.

title: A BUSTLING, EXOTIC CORNER OF U.S. IS CELEBRATING SILVER JUBILEE AS 50TH STATE
description: The sun coming out of the sea will, as usual this time of the year, break the warm tropic night at about 6 A.M. Tuesday and the long, slender shadows of the beachside palms will creep across the sand.

title: CORPORATE-CITY ALLIANCE HAS HELPED REBUILD NEW BRUNSWICK
description: Atlantic City can find a trove of advice here on how a local government can join with the its major industry to redevelop a depressed city.

title: Ingalls-Ground Round
description: Ground Round Restaurants, part of Howard Johnson's Specialty Restaurants division, has named Ingalls Associates of Boston as its new agency of record. Ground Round, based in North Quincy, Mass., with more than 225 restaurants in the Northeast, central and Middle Atlantic states, was previously at Ross Roy/Colarossi Griswold, which picked up the account about the time Ross Roy merged with Colarossi Griswold less than six months ago. The account will bill about $5 million.

title: DROUGHT IS SAID TO THREATEN LIVES OF 7 MILLION IN ETHIOPIA
description: More than seven million people face starvation in Ethiopia, where the worst drought in a decade has left rivers dry and turned the nation's breadbasket into a dust bowl, according to a United Nations report made public today.

title: THOMAS NELSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on the front page of Weekend last Friday misidentified a performer in the Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors Festival. The woman, shown in the center photo, was Mary Louise.

description: b-Including tax credits of $60,000 for the quarter and $93,000 for the 6 months. c-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $106,000 for the quarter and $427,000 for the 6 months and a provision of $592,000 for the quarter and 6 months for loss on the disposal of a subsidiary.

title: Bridge:For Successful Pair, 'Push' Was an Unexpected Reply
description: For no very obvious reason the word ''push'' has a colloquial bridge meaning. When teams are comparing scores, ''push'' indicates that no points have changed hands. The players then push on to the next deal.

title: URUGUAY GOVERNMENT FREES SON OF JAILED OPPOSITION CHIEF
description: The military Government today freed Juan Wilson Ferreira more than two months after he was arrested along with his father, Wilson Ferreira Aldunate, the National Party leader.

title: FILM DEPICTS A NEGLECTED PARIS
description: PARISThere is the Paris of slums, piles of uncollected garbage, knaves, punks and thieves, the dingiest of bars and the meanest of side streets. This Paris may not appeal to many people, but the director Philippe Labro thinks it appeals a lot - too much, really - to those who make movies.

title: ANDERSON 2000 INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest quarter and 9 months include the operations of Bayliss Industries, which was acquired Jan. 1.

title: TO HONOR AQUINO, DROP MARCOS
description: A year ago today, the Philippine opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was executed at the Manila International Airport. The anniversary offers an occasion for Americans and Filipinos alike to think about their tangled and deeply ambiguous relations.

Healthy Baby Delivered From Mother in Coma

description: b-Net loss.

title: CORRECTION
description: The chart and table of short-term interest rates in Business Day yesterday misstated the discount rate for Treasury bills. The correct rate was 10.35 percent. A corrected chart appears today on page D17.

title: U.S.F.L. Set for Fall Play In '86
description: The United States Football League is expected to decide this week to shift to a fall schedule - and compete head-to-head with the entrenched National Football League - starting in 1986.

title: PRISON OFFICIALS TOLD TO PAY $90,000 TO FORMER INMATE
description: A Federal judge ruled in Manhattan yesterday that New York State prison officials must pay $90,000 to a former prisoner and his wife for violating their rights in retaliation for the man's activities as a ''jailhouse lawyer.''

title: Advertising; Manhattan Business Publication
description: AS if there were not already enough for the business executive to read, a glossy, monthly magazine - Manhattan, inc. - will be introduced today. Its publishers hope it will fill a vacuum by providing coverage of the people and personalities who run Manhattan businesses. Since Manhattan is apparently a big enough market for them, the other four boroughs are excluded.

title: Italy Revives and Hails A Lost Rossini Opera
description: Rossini's long-lost opera ''The Journey to Reims'' was rapturously received Saturday night when it was performed for the first time in 159 years, in Pesaro, his hometown on the east coast of Italy.

title: SHULTZ SAYS 'THE TIDE OF HISTORY' IS RUNNING AGAINST SOVIET SYSTEM
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, asserting that ''the tide of history is with us,'' said today that he was confident that freedom would someday be restored to the Soviet-dominated countries of Eastern Europe.

title: China Jails Vietnamese Spy
description: A Chinese court today jailed a Vietnamese spy for 10 years after he admitted repeatedly crossing the border to collect information and incite rebellion, the Chinese national radio reported. The radio said the spy operated from the Vietnamese town of Liangshan and crossed the frontier a number of times between April and July of 1982, when he was captured by Chinese security personnel.

title: THE POTENTIAL OF CASINOS TO DOMINATE ATLANTIC CITY GOVERNMENT IS DEBATED
description: One of Mayor James L. Usry's first acts in office last March was to initiate monthly meetings with top casino executives to enlist their help in rebuilding the city.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEKING OTTINGER'S JOB DIFFER ON TAXES
description: The issue of taxes produced the widest divergence in an often heated debate yesterday among four candidates for the Democratic nomination in Westchester's 20th Congressional District.

title: SHANKER URGING TEACHERS TO ACCEPT PEER REVIEW
description: Teachers across the country must be willing to take on supervisory duties and drop their opposition to judging and rating each other, Albert Shanker, the president of the American Federation of Teachers, said today.

title: Black Leaders to Meet On Supporting Mondale
description: Black leaders will meet next weekend in Alabama to discuss getting out the vote for Walter F. Mondale, despite their frustration with the Democratic Presidential candidate's campaign, City Councilman John Lewis said today.

title: GOOD COUNSEL FOR STUDENTS IS RARE
description: MIDDLEBURY, VT. AS a new class of freshmen enters college, ''an inordinately large number'' will find themselves in the wrong places - victims of faulty or nonexistent counseling. Children of poor families are most likely to get the wrong advice. Many colleges aggravate the problem by being less interested in providing accurate information than in filling their vacancies.

title: PEOPLE, WAX AND REAL, ARE DROOPING
description: The Wax Museum of the Southwest here bills itself as one of the biggest in the country, so it was natural it would add Ronald Reagan.

title: A Dim View of Lights CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (UPI) - Residents in the neighborhood of Wrigley Field, the only major league stadium without lights for night
description: games, say they're ready to play hardball if television networks and

title: DUMBARTON OAKS, THEN AND NOW
description: Forty years ago tomorrow, limousines glided through the gates of the imposing Dumbarton Oaks estate on the edge of the Georgetown section of Washington, bringing leaders of four nations to a meeting that would set much of the framework for drafting of the United Nations Charter.

title: Farm Export Estimate
description: Sluggish American farm exports this fiscal year are expected to total $38 billion, unchanged from an estimate issued in May, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: GROWTH OF ECONOMY REVISED UPWARD TO 7.6%
description: The national economy grew at a 7.6 percent annual pace in this year's second quarter, the Commerce Department reported today. The rate of growth was slightly higher than the 7.5 percent originally reported for the period but still significantly eased from the first quarter's 10.1 percent.

title: Chess:Timman of the NetherlandsWins Yugoslavia Tourney
description: The fourth all-grandmaster Bugojno (Yugoslavia) International Tournament was won by 32-year-old Jan Timman of the Netherlands, who scored 8 1/2-4 1/2 in the 14-player round- robin event.

title: Transactions
description: Placed Steve Bedrosian, pitcher, on 15-day disabled list and moved Terry Forster, pitcher, from 15- to 21-day disabled list. Recalled Mike Payne, pitcher, from Richmond of the International League. CLEVELAND (AL) - Announced that Brook Jacoby, third base, would have to undergo surgery for a broken bone in his hand. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Traded Al Oliver, first base, to Philadelphia for two minor-league players to be named later. YANKEES (AL) - Announced resignation of Murray Cook as vice president and director of scouting. BASKETBALL PORTLAND - (NBA) - Signed Bernard Thompson, the team's first-round draft pick from California State at Fresno. CLIPPERS (NBA) - Announced signing of the first round draft choice, Michael Cage, forward from San Diego State. FOOTBALL BUFFALO (AFC) - Waived David Kilson and Stacy Rayfield, defensive backs; Neal Musser, linebacker; Tony Slaton, center; Mike Morini, tackle; Cecil Ratliff, wide receiver, and Vince Williams, running back. Placed Matt Vanden Boom, free safety, on injured reserve. CLEVELAND (AFC) - Released Wade Manning, wide receiver; Thomas Brown and Kent Townsend, defensive ends; Dwayne Barnes, offensive tackle; Mike Boren and Vernon Hargreaves, linebackers, Anthony Recchia, punter, and John Vernasco, quarterback. DENVER (AFC) - Traded Luke Prestridge, punter, to New England for an undisclosed draft choice, and released the veteran tight end Ron Egloff, and Nathan Poole, running back. Also waived the free agents Gerry Dorio, offensive lineman; Scott Stankavage, quarterback; Michael Wade, wide receiver; Russ Hadderly, linebacker, and Dale Thompson, cornerback. DETROIT (NFL) - Waived Don Van Wie, kicker; Ken Watkins, defensive back; Renwick Atkins, offensive tackle, and the brothers Tom and Jim Viaene.

title: SHOW LOOKS AT CARS IN REAR-VIEW MIRROR OF ART
description: There have been many international automobile shows, and there are many auto museums - but there have been few major exhibitions that relate the car to works of art that interpret it. ''Automobile and Culture,'' an exhibition that runs through Jan. 6 in the lofty warehouses of the fledgling Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art, brings 30 vintage cars and 200 works of car-related art together into an intriguing show in which the car is the basic question, and art, the comment.

title: GAP STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
description: Results for the latest quarter and 6 months include two newly acquired subsidiaries, The Pottery Barn Inc. and The Pottery Barn West. Results for the year-ago quarter and 6 months include the Tagg's division, which was disposed of in January.

title: Freedom at Sea: Use It or Lose It Since early July, parties unknown have struck at an international jugular by mining the Gulf of Suez and the adjacent Red Sea. At least 19 ships of various nations - a Soviet vessel was the first victim - have been damaged. The operation seems meant to humiliate a vulnerable Egypt. Nearly $1 billion in annual Suez Canal tolls is at risk if shippers feel compelled to turn to safer waters.
description: Producing and sowing these weapons takes logistic skills that only governments normally possess. More than most forms of terrorism, this is an act of war, and one that thrusts indiscriminately at the navigation rights of all nations. What was unfortunately true when the C.I.A. arranged for the ''nuisance'' mining of Nicaragua's harbors is even more plainly true in the Middle East. Egypt's President Mubarak deserves help, and America's wiser second thoughts in Nicaragua made it much easier to help him get it.

title: No Rise Seen In Swedish Tax
description: Swedish companies will not face higher taxes in 1985 despite sharply rising profits this year, Finance Minister Kjell-Olof Feldt said today.

title: ARCHITECTURE: A WILLIAM LESCAZE RETROSPECTIVE
description: WILLIAM LESCAZE is a curious figure in the history of 20th-century architecture - not quite major, hardly minor. A confirmed modernist, he nonetheless was overshadowed by Mies van der Rohe and Walter Gropius. An ardent New Yorker, he was unable to leave the mark on the city that Skidmore, Owings & Merrill or Emery Roth did.

description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said it had agreed to buy the stock of Telecommunications Specialists Inc., a telecommunications systems and equipment business based in Houston.

Only a key hit by Oliver to beat his former team could have made his day more rewarding, and that's exactly what happened.

title: Maid Is Charged in Theft Of Jewels From Heiress
description: A new maid of Carolyn Skelly Burford, the oil heiress, faces charges in the theft of $2.25 million worth of jewels from her employer's estate in this coastal resort, the police said today.

description: The Moscow radio said today that Andrei D. Sakharov was alive and well and receiving medical care in Gorky, the city to which he was banished in 1980.

description: President Roberto Suazo Cordova today named four new Cabinet ministers and changed other key economic officials in a shakeup that diplomats said was chiefly aimed at curing Honduras's ailing economy.

description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday, with some short-term rates rising by about a tenth of a percentage point, while yields fell slightly for notes and bonds due in more than five years.

title: CONVENTION IN DALLAS: THE REPUBLICANS; Satirical Look at Reagan
description: Republican moderates who have drifted in despair at the fringe of this joyously conservative convention are about to strike back by mocking the President himself with a satirical depiction of a White House day when war looms with the Soviet Union.

title: YANKEES DEFEAT ANGELS
description: Some of the fans in the crowd of 27,741 may have gone to Yankee Stadium last night hoping to see Reggie Jackson hit three home runs and reach the 500 plateau. Instead, they saw Joe Cowley strike out Jackson three times as he dazzled the California Angels in the Yankees' 8-4 victory.

title: AIDES TO MONDALE SAY FERRARO GOT LIMITED REVIEW AS RUNNING MATE
description: Walter F. Mondale's top campaign official admitted today that aides had mistakenly overlooked some aspects of the finances of Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro and her husband, John A. Zaccaro, before Mr. Mondale picked Mrs. Ferraro as his running mate.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Michael Cage, a 6-foot-9-inch forward who said recently he had signed a contract worth $180,000 with Rimini of the Italian League, signed yesterday with the Los Angeles Clippers of the National Basketball Association. . . . The rookie center Melvin Turpin ended his holdout and reported to the Cleveland Cavaaliers' rookie free agent camp. . . . Brook Jacoby, third baseman for the Cleveland Indians, was placed on the 21-day disabled list after undergoing surgery for a broken bone in his left hand suffered in a game against Milwaukee Sunday.

title: West German Growth
description: West Germany's economy must grow by at least 2.5 percent to 3 percent during the second half to attain the 2.5 percent growth rate projected in the Government's economic report for 1984, the Economics Ministry said today. In an advance summary of its monthly review of the nation's economy, the ministry stressed that the metalworkers' strike in the spring caused sharp declines in production, orders, retail sales and exports.

title: On to New York
description: Because only nine days have passed since the running of the Olympic marathon in Los Angeles, Fred Lebow, director of the New York City Marathon, says that he does not yet know whether some of the world's name runners will run in the Oct. 28 event.

title: PROFIT PACE SLOWED IN 2D QUARTER
description: The after-tax profits of United States corporations rose at an annual rate of 1.5 percent in the second quarter this year, down sharply from the 6.7 percent pace set in the first quarter, the Government reported today.

description: Platform: The Republican platform, a strong conservative document, will be presented to the convention today not once but twice. A full presentation will be made by its chief framers at 11 A.M. , Eastern daylight time (10 A.M. Dallas time), with a vote to approve it afterward.

description: Greece said today it had canceled a series of joint war games with the United States, the latest of which was due to start in 10 days.

description: Several computer companies contributed a total of more than $2 million in equipment and services to the Republican National Convention, in exchange for being designated the ''official providers'' of convention computers.

description: Geraldyn (Gerri) Hodges Major, author of ''Black Society,'' a view of upper-class blacks in America, died in New York Hospital on Friday. She was 90 years old and had suffered a stroke.

title: The Future, in a Yard of Skin One day, people who need new hearts or kidneys or livers won't have to depend on risky transplants or complex machines. A laboratory will grow a new organ out of their own tissue. That's not entirely science fiction; the first step has already been taken. Skin is an organ, and can now be grown outside the body.
description: The new method, developed by Howard Green at the Harvard Medical School, has helped save the lives of two young boys who lost more than 95 percent of their skin from burns. Stamp-sized patches of skin taken from the armpit yielded a square yard of new skin for each boy.

description: FOR moderately priced personal computing, the summer of '84 seems to be what every summer has come to be for its audiovisual cousin, television: one of reruns.

description: The stock market registered mild gains yesterday, and blue chip buying in the final hour lifted the Dow Jones industrial average 5.08 points to 1,216.98, its high for the session.

title: WHO ARE THESE PEOPLE?
description: We got home from our summer camps a few days apart. He had been a junior counselor in Vermont since late June, living in the wilds with mosquitoes, mice, raccoons and 10-year-olds. I had been residing in Room 899 of the Los Angeles Hilton since shortly after the All-Star Game in early July. I was jealous of his summer.

description: Travis County officials had hoped to open their new $12 million jail with its advanced electronic locking system last year.

description: Former Representative Wayne Owens won the Democratic gubernatorial primary today, and Norman Bangerter held a wide lead on the Republican side.

description: A $50 million issue of Texas general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 7 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 8.5 percent in 1994 and 9.1 percent in 1999 through underwriters led by Citibank. By late afternoon, underwriters estimated about $20 million of the issue was unsold.

The Cubs and Mondale
description: A tremor of excitement coursed through Mondale headquarters in Washington recently when word circulated that there was historical precedent for the election of a Democrat in 1984. The Emil Verban Memorial Society, a local group of Chicago Cub fans, reported in its newsletter, ''Every time in this century that the Cubs have won a pennant in a Presidential year, a Democrat has won the White House.''

title: Local Debut for Casals Trio
description: The Pablo Casals Trio - Oswald Lehnert, violin; Jurgen de Lemos, cello, and Larry Graham, piano - will perform make its New York debut Sept. 9 at 8 P.M. at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street. Mr. Casals gave the trio permission to use his name in 1973. The group will give the United States premiere of Shostakovich's Trio, Op. 8, No. 1, and perform trios by Beethoven and Schubert. Tickets are $8; $5 for students, the elderly and Symphony Space members.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. California Angels, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Reggie Jackson continues his pursuit of 500 career home runs. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) description: The many medal-winning American athletes were not the only beneficiaries of the 1984 Olympics. The producers of the new television series ''Call to Glory'' have also reaped some gold from the recently concluded Los Angeles games.

description: William J. McKenna has been named chief executive officer of the Kellwood Company, it was announced yesterday.

title: REAGAN, EVERY INCH A KING
description: It has now become a commonplace, among Republicans and even in the nonpartisan press, to refer to what is going on in Dallas as ''The Coronation.'' So far, of course, it is only a metaphor, a way of talking about Ronald Reagan's popularity. But perhaps we should reconsider. Perhaps the Republican National Convention should indeed nominate Ronald Reagan to be King of the United States.

title: MESKELL'S 68 LEADS MET OPEN
description: The teacher and his pupil went separate ways today in the first round of the 69th Met Open, though not in predictable directions. Darrell Kestner, the defending champion, scored a melancholy 78 while his student, Rick Meskell, shot 10 strokes better.

title: AMRITRAJ UPSETS MCENROE IN 3 SETS
description: Unseeded Vijay Amritraj of India stunned top-seeded John McEnroe, 6-7, 6-2, 6-3, in the first round of the $375,000 Association of Tennis Professionals championship tournament today. The loss was only the second of the year for McEnroe. He was beaten by Ivan Lendl in the final of the French Open.

title: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 22, 1984 International
description: Egypt's suspicions that Libya was responsible for the mining of the Red Sea and the Gulf of Suez are now ''almost confirmed,'' according to a senior Egyptian military official. He said speculation had focused on one Libyan ship in particular that was believed to have dropped the mines. (Page A1, Columns 5-6.) Heavy fighting in Tripoli, Lebanon, erupted between Sunni Moslem fundamentalists and Syrian-backed militiamen. By nightfall, both leftist and rightist radio stations were saying that as many as 30 people, most of them civilians, had been killed and 125 people wounded. (A3:4-6.)

title: A.T.&.T. SEES BACKLOG TILL EARLY '85
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company told the Federal Communications Commission today that it would be early next year before it reduces to what it considers an acceptable level the huge backlog of unfilled orders from business customers for voice- and data-transmission services.

title: SHORTAGE OF NEW CARS COSTLY TO BUYERS
description: New cars are in short supply, creating a seller's market for dealers at a time of year when they traditionally are trying to unload stocks to make way for the new model year.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: SOUNDS The Staten Island Children's Museum has mounted an exhibition called ''Soundtracks,'' a look at and a listen to usual and unusual musical instruments. In this display are sounds made by humans (such as hand clapping), sounds of nature and mechanically created sounds. There are samples of sounds made with automobile hub caps, with sticks and with clay pots. And there is an array of musical instruments.

title: 'Tightrope' Is Leader At Box Office for Week
description: ''Tightrope,'' the detective movie starring Clint Eastwood, last weekend made its debut in first place at the box office, grossing $9.1 million and easily outdoing all competitors, according to studio officials.

title: Trooper Denies Assault at Fair
description: A state police sergeant was arraigned in State Supreme Court today on assault charges in the first indictment by an Onondaga County grand jury investigating allegations of police brutality at the state fair in Syracuse last year.

title: CULINARY JOYS OF SUMMER'S BOUNTIFUL HARVEST
description: FOR the cook as well as the gardener, this is the sweetest time of the year. It takes Keatsian imagery to do justice to summer's bounty, to the lushness of produce in country gardens, at farm stands and in city markets. The ripe scents commingle, the metallic fragrance of rich, red tomatoes and spicy, fresh green herbs, mellow peaches, pungent onions, moist earth still clinging to their roots, and the sweetly haunting perfume of fresh, tender, pale green ears of corn.

title: AMNIOCENTESIS: ON THE INCREASE
description: LAST April, when Ellen Biblowitz told her obstetrician she wanted to undergo amniocentesis to make sure the baby she was carrying didn't have Down's syndrome, her doctor was unperturbed that she had just turned 34, one year under the age at which the procedure is customarily offered. ''In fact, he said he performed amniocentesis quite frequently on women much younger than I,'' she said. While waiting her turn at the Manhattan hospital where the test would be administered, she found herself chatting with expectant mothers in their late 20's and early 30's.

title: Olympian Rewards
description: They may not be in line for lucrative endorsement contracts, but China's Olympic medalists are getting more than official adulation for their victories in Los Angeles. They are getting perks such as better state apartments and American-style cash rewards.

On Pursuing Ferraro
description: As the press has pursued Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, her neighbors have complained of being pestered.

title: ROCK: 3 BANDS EVOKE 60'S
description: THREE legacies of 1960's rock came back with a 1980's twist at the Beacon Theater Monday. The Fleshtones bashed away like a 1960's garage band. Billy Bragg evoked the folk scene, and the headliners, Echo and the Bunnymen, summoned back all the pretension of the psychedelic era.

title: NEW PORTABLE BURNER
description: WHAT I enjoy most about a fishing expedition on Long Island Sound in the summer is cooking freshly caught fish on the beach. I usually find a secluded spot and build a small campfire, then clean the fish and wrap them in aluminum foil before cooking. If I think ahead and bring some fresh herbs for seasoning, so much the better.

title: HOSPITALS VOW TO REPLACE STRIKERS
description: More than 15,000 health-care workers voted overwhelmingly last night to reject a proposed settlement of New York City's hospital and nursing home strike.

title: U.S.F.L. Shifts Discussed
description: The Oakland Invaders and the Oklahoma Outlaws may soon be merged into one Bay Area franchise as part of a reorganization that could mean the paring of as many as four teams from the 18-club United States Football League, according to published reports yesterday.

title: BURGER REJECTS BID FOR NUCLEAR PLANT LICENSE
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger today refused to clear the way for full operation of the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant in California.

title: U.S. and China Weigh Port Calls by Warships
description: Top United States and Chinese military officials have discussed the possibility of port calls by American warships in China, but there has been ''no firm agreement yet,'' the Pentagon spokesman, Michael I. Burch, said today.

title: EASTER I. DRIFTING TOWARD, AND AWAY FROM, CHILE
description: The 1,900 people of this tiny dot in the South Pacific are grumbling.

description: A 17-year-old youth stepped off a cliff in the dark early today and died after he plunged 60 feet to the bottom of a gorge in Bear Mountain State Park, the police said.

title: STAGE: MUSIC OF THE 20'S IN 'SHADES OF HARLEM'
description: ''SHADES OF HARLEM'' is a summerweight collage of music by Duke Ellington, Eubie Blake, the Gershwins and others. This amiable admixture of jazz, blues and show tunes, which opened last night at the Village Gate, under the direction of Mical Whitaker, does not, however, rise to the level of ''Sophisticated Ladies,'' ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' and the other anthologies that it tries to emulate in a cabaret setting.

title: GENERAL DEFENSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
description: b-After losses from investments of $1,268,000 for the quarter and $867,000 for the 6 months. c-After a loss from investments of $40,000 for the quarter and a gain from investments of $90,000 for the 6 months.

title: CENTENNIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $200,000 for the quarter and 6 months, and a gain of $143,565 for the 6 months on the retirement of debt. c-Includes a tax credit of $230,000. d-Net loss after a tax credit of $270,000.

title: Soviet Buys More Wheat
description: After a two-week lull, the Soviet Union has added another 500,000 metric tons of United States wheat to its summer grain purchases, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Citicorp Paper
description: Interest rates were mixed at yesterday's regular weekly auctions of Citicorp commercial paper, the bank holding company announced. For $100 million of 91-day paper the average rate was 11.429 percent, up from 11.378 percent, while $50 million of 182-day paper sold at an average rate of 11.324 percent, down from 11.348 percent.

title: GREAT AMERICAN PARTNERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. ASSAILS GREEK CANCELLATION OF EXERCISES
description: The United States criticized Greece today for canceling a planned military exercise with United States troops without warning. Such exercises have been regularly held for 20 years.

title: METS LOSE AND FALL 5 GAMES OUT
description: The Mets fell five games out of first place tonight when they lost again to the San Diego Padres, 7-4, and they were stung the most by the 40-year-old expatriate Yankee, Graig Nettles.

title: DANNERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
description: b-Net loss.

title: STATE PRISONS' PROBLEMS ARE BEING TACKLED
description: To the Editor:

title: Street Signs
description: The city is replacing street signs in

title: Japan's Economy Gains
description: Japan's economy continued to expand last month on the strength of exports to the United States and increased capital investments, the Economic Planning Agency said today.

title: Song, Not Sacks
description: The National Football League considers itself an entertainment business, of course. And now it's producing pop-music videos.

title: Former Spanish Premier Is Expelled by Uruguay
description: The military Government expelled former Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez of Spain today for trying to aid in the legal defense of the jailed National Party leader, Wilson Ferreira Aldunate.

title: DAVIS LEADS CUBS PAST ASTROS, 11-5
description: Jody Davis broke out of a 1-for-17 batting slump by driving in four runs with a two-run homer and bases-loaded single today to lead the Chicago Cubs to an 11-5 triumph over the Houston Astros.

title: Television Coverage
description: The following television coverage is planned for the Republican National Convention:

title: 2D LOAN BY ZACCARO FROM ESTATE
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro vigorously defended the propriety of her financial affairs yesterday, acknowledging some sloppy record-keeping and technical mistakes by others, but insisting that neither she nor her husband had done anything wrong.

title: Oil Labeling Basis of Fine
description: A Federal judge has ordered Robert B. Sutton, a former Tulsa oilman, to pay $210 million - to be shared by all 50 states - for reportedly making illegal profits on miscertified crude oil.

title: TELECAST OF LIBEL CASE ASKED
description: Cable News Network is seeking court permission to provide live courtroom television coverage in the event that Gen. William C. Westmoreland's libel suit against CBS goes to trial.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Alleghany Corp. has appointed David Stuebe president and chief executive officer of its MSL Industries subsidiary.

title: FLOOD OF SUSAN B. ANTHONY COINS CAUSES FUROR IN VILLAGE
description: The telephone book here lists everybody in town in 26 pages, the parking meters give 12 minutes for a penny and mail is delivered by boat.

title: Humana Offering
description: Humana Inc. today is offering $200 million of convertible subordinated debentures due in 2009 through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman/ American Express. The 8 1/2 percent debentures may be converted into common stock of Humana at $37.80 a share, a 20 percent premium over yesterday's closing price of $31.50.

title: COLOR OF MANY SUMMER GUISES
description: IT used to be a rule of thumb for summer clothes that one should never wear black. While that rule may still obtain elsewhere, in New York the exact opposite holds sway.

title: GOULDS PUMP OFFICER RESUMES NO. 1 ROLE
description: Robert L. Tarnow, chairman of Goulds Pumps Inc., has resumed the responsibilities of chief executive officer of the company.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE SENTENCE FOR ASSAULT IS CRITICIZED
description: Outside Neil's Steak and Oyster House here one night in December 1982, Robert G. Kindle, a local automobile dealer, punched Judge P. Martin Way 3d in the face after an incident inside.

title: DONOHUE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results are restated.

title: NEW YORKER VOWS RETURN TO ULSTER
description: Martin Galvin, the New York lawyer whose appearance at a Belfast rally last week sparked a police attack on the crowd, returned to New York yesterday and vowed to ''go back again and again'' to Northern Ireland.

title: CITY LOSES RULING ON VOTING SYSTEM OF ESTIMATE PANEL
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the structure of the New York City Board of Estimate ''would appear to be unconstitutional'' because it deviated from the one-man, one-vote principle.

title: FERRARO SAYS BUY-BACK BY HUSBAND WAS LEGAL
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro said yesterday that she had told her husband ''it doesn't look so hot'' when she found out he had bought back a Manhattan property she had sold to pay off illegal campaign loans from him.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: The Metropolitan Fair and Exposition Authority, based in Chicago, is selling $250 million worth of bonds with a maximum yield of 10.45 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. For shorter maturities, yields for serial bonds range from 7 percent in 1986 to 9.60 percent in 1996.

title: RETHINKING POLICY ON EAST GERMANY
description: For some months now, a gradual thaw has been in the making between East Germany and West Germany. So far, the United States has paid scant attention - an attitude very much in keeping with our neglect of East Germany throughout the post- war period. We should reconsider this policy before things go much further - and should in particular begin to look more closely at what is going on in East Germany.

title: ; OWNING A HOME: THE ENDANGERED PRIORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOK CHRONICLES 200 YEARS OF CITY'S INTELLECTUALS
description: Thomas Bender was a graduate student of American history in California when he read Irving Howe's literary critiques about the ''New York intellectuals,'' the term Mr. Howe used for the writer-rebels of the 1930's and 40's. Mr. Bender was struck by Mr. Howe's assertion that a full-scale history of intellectuals in the United States had not been written.

title: Monaco Group May Seek Kerr
description: The Monaco Group Fund S.A. told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had purchased 270,000 common shares, or 9.4 percent, of the Kerr Glass Manufacturing Corporation, and that it might ''determine to seek control.''

title: BANK CHIEF NAMED AT FLORIDA NATIONAL
description: E. Bruce Bower, president and chief operating officer of the Florida National Bank and its holding company, Florida National Banks of Florida Inc., will become chairman and chief executive officer of the bank, it was announced yesterday.

title: WESTERN MICROWAVE LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-Includes tax credits of $12,000 for the quarter and $39,000 for the 9 months.

title: Louis Eilers, 77, Dies; Ex-President of Kodak
description: Louis K. Eilers, who headed the Eastman Kodak Company as president and then chairman from 1967 to 1972, died Monday night in a hospital in Phoenix, a Kodak spokesman said today. He was 77 years old.

title: TALKS EXPECTED ON COAST THRIFT UNIT
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has the capacity to raise at least $25 billion in the credit markets, more than enough to cover any loans needed by the beleaguered American Savings and Loan Association to meet deposit withdrawals, according to industry sources.

title: MASTERS MERCHANDISE MART reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,355,000 from the sale of real estate. c-Net loss.

title: EXCERPTS FROM FERRARO'S NEWS CONFERENCE ABOUT FINANCES
description: Following are excerpts from Geraldine A. Ferraro's news conference yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network:

title: PENSIONS NEVER DIE, BUT THE FAT MAY FADE AWAY
description: To most career military officers in the Pentagon and elsewhere, neither the perils of nuclear war nor the promise of eternal peace causes more anxiety than the prospect of changes in their retirement plan.

title: ETHICS ACT: WHAT IT SAYS
description: The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 generally requires members of Congress to include certain financial information about their spouses and dependent children, as well as themselves, in public financial disclosure statements.

title: CONTINENTAL STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
British Interest In Mitel Rumored
description: Reports are circulating that the General Electric Company of Britain may invest in the Mitel Corporation of Ottawa. An analyst for a leading Toronto brokerage house, who asked not to be identified, said that, according to the reports, G.E.C. might buy some of Mitel's unissued stock to bring in new capital.

title: LTV to Idle Line
description: The LTV Corporation said it would indefinitely idle the seamless pipe stretch reduction line at its Campbell Works near Youngstown, Ohio.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: VITELLO tonnato, veal with tuna sauce that is a specialty of the Lombardy and Piedmont regions of Italy, is an old standby - a great dish for a dinner party. When it was prepared recently with a first-quality cut of veal, a guest who greatly admired it wondered if it couldn't be made with something less expensive. Breast of chicken can easily be substituted; hence the recipe that follows.

title: Today's Calendar
description: Nominations: The normal climax of a convention, the roll-call of the states to nominate the Presidential candidate, will be anticlimactic tonight. With no opposition to the renomination of President Reagan and Vice President Bush, the usually dramatic roll-call will be consolidated so that the President and Vice President will be nominated simultaneously. Normally, the Vice President is nominated on the last night of the convention just before the acceptance speeches. Normally, for that matter, somebody votes against even the surest of sure things on these roll-calls.

title: SCITEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Consumer's Digest Opens Guide to Ads
description: The Consumer Digest Buying Guide is is set to accept advertising for the first time. Some 10,000 copies of the prototype guide are now being circulated to advertising agencies and producers, and the prototype will be included in the magazine's regular January/February issue.

title: Florida County Sells Sewer Bonds
description: Palm Beach County, Fla., is selling $56.7 million of water and sewer revenue bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The offering, which was reduced from $73 million, includes serial bonds with yields ranging from 6.25 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 9.1 percent for those due in 1995. Longer-term offerings include 10 percent bonds due in 2002 at a price of 99 1/4 to yield 10.09 percent and 10 1/8 percent bonds due in 2011 at 99 1/4 to yield 10.207 percent.

title: FLOW SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BILL MOYERS WALKS THROUGH THE ROARING 20'S
description: ALL season ''A Walk Through the 20th Century With Bill Moyers'' has been looking at where we've been and where we're going. Tonight it looks at the 1920's, a time, Mr. Moyers says, that has ''long been a puzzle to me.'' Why should the decade have cast such a glow? The question is examined on Channel 13 at 9:05 P.M.

title: FAMILY'S ANGUISH ON TV PROMPTS MAN'S RETURN AFTER 2 YEARS
description: A 29-year-old New Jersey man who disappeared nearly two years ago and was presumed dead by his wife and two young children turned himself in to the police in his former home town early Monday after watching a television documentary on missing people that featured his case and showed his family's anguish.

title: Storm Found to Spare Atoll Weapons Stores
description: An aerial survey today showed no damage to buildings on a storm-swept Pacific atoll where 13,000 tons of chemical weapons are stored, but officials were waiting for a team to land before deciding when evacuated workers could return.

title: MISREAD NEWSPAPER
description: To the Editor:

China Objects to Terms In Republican Platform
description: China has called on the Republican Party to remove from its platform what Peking sees as offensive language on Taiwan and Hong Kong, the Chinese Embassy said today. But the Republican National Convention approved the platform without debate over any plank.

VIEWING A TV DRAMA: AS THE POLITICAL WORLD TURNS
description: For a day and a half, ending yesterday afternoon in a hot, tense hotel conference room in New York City, the American television-viewing public was exposed to a drama of political contrasts.

title: Coastal Stock Plan
description: The Coastal Corporation said it would buy as many as one million of its common shares in market transactions. Coastal, a Dallas-based oil refining and marketing company, said the purchases had been authorized because the current market price was ''substantially less'' than the underlying value of the shares. Coastal, which has about 22.4 million shares outstanding, closed at $27.50, up 50 cents, yesterday on the New York

title: KEMP EMERGES AS KEY CONSERVATIVE
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp's schedule Monday and today involved 22 possible appearances, capped by a prime-time television speech on foreign relations at the Republican National Convention here tonight.

Stouffer's Inn Case Will Be Appealed
description: The Westchester County District Attorney, Carl A. Vergari, announced today that his office would appeal the Luis Marin arson-and-murder case to the State Court of Appeals in the next 60 days.

TRICO PRODUCTS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: TAX ADJUSTMENTS HELP TO LIFT DEERE INCOME
description: Reflecting continued difficulties in the farm implement sector, Deere & Company yesterday reported net income of $29.4 million in its fiscal third quarter.

title: CITY HIGH SCHOOLS MAY OPEN 4 DAYS EARLIER IN SEPTEMBER
description: The Board of Education is to vote tonight on a proposal that would bring New York City's 260,000 high school students back to school next month four days earlier than previously scheduled.

GAMING & TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,000 for the quarter and $431,000 for the 9 months, and a gain on the early extinguishment of debt of $523,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $18,000 for the quarter and $55,000 for the 9 months.

title: The Republicans' Embrace On Monday night the Republicans in Dallas extended a welcoming hand to restless Democrats. Katherine Ortega, the keynote speaker, spoke approvingly of John Kennedy and insisted that ''Our house is your house.'' Jeane Kirkpatrick, a lifelong Democrat, said ''I realize that you are inviting many lifelong Democrats to join this common cause,'' and quoted Harry Truman, surely the first time his name has ever been invoked with approval, and without boos, at a Republican convention.
description: But last night the Republicans ratified a 1984 platform that denounced their ''Democrat opposition.'' How ironic, it said, that the party of Roosevelt, the man who said that all we have to fear is fear itself, ''itself has become the party of fear.''

title: MTV PLANS 2D MUSIC CHANNEL
description: MTV Networks Inc., which operates a cable television music channel, said yesterday that it planned to start a second 24-hour music channel in January aimed at viewers aged 25 to 49.

title: BASIC EARTH SCIENCE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Corporate Notes
description: * Calfed Funding Corp. , Los Angeles, will issue $500 million in collateralized commercial paper to fund California Federal Savings and Loan Association.

description: Markets

title: HUGHES SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FLORIDA CYPRESS GARDENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31

title: THE GUN CLUB, ON STAGE AND ON THREE ALBUMS
description: THE Gun Club was performing recently at the Pyramid, a long, narrow, dimly lit club on Avenue A, and several members of the audience were yelling ''Get serious!'' They were yelling specifically at Jeffrey Lee Pierce, who was doing what could have been an impersonation of one of his idols, the late Jim Morrison, lead singer and lyricist with the Doors. Like Mr. Morrison at many later Doors concerts, Mr. Pierce was wandering about the stage, sometimes singing into the microphone, sometimes not, and consistently throwing off the timing of his fine, steady band.

title: Diane Sawyer to Join '60 Minutes' at CBS
description: Diane Sawyer has completed her last edition of ''The CBS Morning News'' and will be moving on to work at ''60 Minutes,'' the CBS magazine program, immediately after the Republican National Convention, according to CBS network officials.

title: MURDER CASE IS CLOSED AND THE SUSPECT IS A SUICIDE
description: The murder case of a 25-year-old woman from Netcong who was reported missing June 29 has been closed, with the authorities saying that she was killed by her supervisor, who committed suicide earlier this month.

title: Southwest Airlines
description: Southwest Airlines Inc. said it had reached a new agreement with the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, effective until March 1, 1989. The company said the new contract provides for wage increases of 30 percent over the life of the pact, but newly hired employees will earn about 40 percent less than those already on the payroll. It said the accord covers about 50 percent of its union employees.

title: SUPERMARKETS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
Romero in Rio
description: Carlos Alberto, the former star defender for the Cosmos, has a glowing report for Cosmos fans on another former Cosmos player who was very popular with them - Julio Cesar Romero.

title: TWITS BUSH ON DISCLOSURES
description: An effusive Walter F. Mondale said today that his running mate, Geraldine A. Ferraro, had emerged a stronger candidate from the questions over her and her husband's finances.

title: MACKENZIE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CITICORP AIDES UNEASY IN COST-CUTTING DRIVE
description: A program instituted about three weeks ago at Citicorp, asking 2,500 of its officers to find ways to cut costs as much as 40 percent by year-end, is giving people within the banking company a bad case of jitters.

title: Plantation 'Giselle' on Way
description: A Southern-plantation resetting of ''Giselle'' will have its United States premiere on the opening night of Dance Theater of Harlem's ninth season, Sept. 25, at City Center.

title: TAYLOR DEVICES reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid in November 1983.

title: IN THE BERKSHIRES, PROGRESS MEANS CAPITALIZING ON THE PAST TO LURE VISITORS
description: On Main Street, the gas station is now a boutique selling designer napkins and teak salad bowls. Next door, Maskell Lahert Plumbers is now Shiretown Country Store, draped with New England quilts and dish towels. On Housatonic Street, the shoemaker's has been replaced by Yesterday's Antiques. Nearby, Buxton's hardware no longer sells nails, instead offering wallpaper patterned with French country prints.

title: DEMOCRATS CONSISTENT ON FOREIGN POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: THOUSANDS MARK ANNIVERSARY OF AQUINO SLAYING
description: Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators streamed into downtown Manila today to mark the first anniversary of the death of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the opposition leader.

title: HOUSEHOLD'S WARY STANCE
description: IN this age of unfriendly takeovers, companies

title: 3 U.S. AGENCIES FACING ACTION OVER HIRING GOALS
description: A Congresswoman said today that she would seek to move against three Federal agencies, including the Justice Department, that are refusing to obey a directive requiring them to set goals and timetables for hiring women and members of minority groups.

title: MODULINE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

description: Following are excerpts from the text of an address last night by Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole at the Republican National Convention, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of C-Span:
