title: EXILED CUBAN WRITERS RELISH LIBERTY
description: Reinaldo Garcia Ramos used to write poetry in longhand because typing provoked the curiosity of the ''defense committee'' in his Havana neighborhood.

title: Revco Rules Out Anti-Takeover Step
description: Revco D.S. Inc., the nation's largest drugstore chain, said yesterday that it would not seek certain anti- takeover provisions. The company had previously indicated it was considering the measures as part of a defense against threats by two dissident shareholders, Bernard A. Marden and Isaac Perlmutter.

title: The Ferraro File After nearly two weeks of self-inflicted anguish, Geraldine Ferraro has published her husband's tax returns and financial records along with her own. As finally promised, their report is extensive and more detailed than any law requires. And at first blush, the details make one wonder why there was ever any reluctance to disclose to this extent.
description: Mrs. Ferraro and her husband, John Zaccaro, turn out to be a prosperous couple who paid considerable taxes and tried, within reasonable limits, to erect some useful barriers between her career as a Congresswoman and his real estate and insurance businesses. Whether or not every one of Mr. Zaccaro's commercial transactions can withstand national scrutiny, there is nothing in the records now revealed suggesting any abuse of his close relationship with her. Nor is there even a hint that she ever betrayed her public trust or wrongly profited from public office.

title: PRESS SECRETARY OF FERRARO CAMAPIGN LEAVES POST
description: The press secretary to Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro's Vice-Presidential campaign, Patricia Bario, resigned last night after two weeks on the job, apparently under pressure from the candidate's senior staff.

title: REHABILITATION HOSPITAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EGYPT SAYS LIBYAN ROLE IN BLASTS IN RED SEA IS 'ALMOST CONFIRMED'
description: A senior Egyptian military official said today that Egypt's suspicions that Libya was responsible for the mining of the Red Sea and Gulf of Suez were now ''almost confirmed.''

title: O'BRIEN'S JET STATUS SET BACK BY TRIAL
description: Ken O'Brien's orientation to pro football - in other words, the Jets' quarterback situation - has been dealt another setback, and this time the problem is coming not from a huge pass rusher but rather in the courts.

title: RED SOX ROOKIE GETS 15 STRIKEOUTS
description: Roger Clemens struck out 15 batters, the most strikeouts by a Boston pitcher in 23 years, as the Red Sox routed the Kansas City Royals, 11-1, tonight.

title: RIVER OAKS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOUTH AFRICA ARRESTS 17 NONWHITES BEFORE MIXED-RACE VOTE TODAY
description: The South African authorities arrested at least 17 of their most prominent nonwhite opponents today on the eve of an election that the Government says will widen the nation's political base by granting a voice to people of Indian and mixed- race descent but not to the black majority.

title: WASHINGTON ERROR IN THE URUGUAYAN CRISIS
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: The Scouting column in Sports Pages yesterday incorrectly described Tom Penders's service as Fordham University's basketball coach. He is beginning his seventh season.

title: New Delta Flights
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. said it plans to begin flights to Honolulu and Paris, in a move designed to expand the company's worldwide operations.

title: MONUMENTAL WOODSTOCK, MONUMENTAL CHICAGO FIRE
description: To the Editor:

title: METHOD USED IN THE REVIEW
description: The review of the finances of Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro and her husband, John A. Zaccaro, was not as rigorous as an audit that corporations typically undergo, but the procedures employed by the accounting firm of Arthur Young & Company provided far more than a cursory review of documents supplied by Mrs. Ferraro and her family.

title: G.O.P. PONDERS FUTURE WITHOUT REAGAN
description: This is a Republican convention that came to renominate President Reagan, but, with that a certainty, its only real excitement so far has been the open jockeying for the President's mantle after his last hurrah.

title: TROUBLES FOR DEMOCRATS
description: For nearly two weeks, Walter F. Mondale's Presidential campaign has been troubled by questions about the personal finances of his running mate, Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro. But that controversy has overshadowed what some Democrats say are deeper problems for the Democratic ticket at this stage of the campaign.

title: 2 MILITIAS CLASH IN NORTH LEBANESE PORT
description: Heavy fighting broke out overnight and continued through today in the northern port of Tripoli between Sunni Moslem fundamentalists and Syrian-backed militiamen.

title: Cuomo Calls Ortega 'An Exciting New Face'
description: Governor Cuomo has called Katherine Davalos Ortega, Treasurer of the United States, ''an exciting new face'' after he saw her keynote address Monday to the Republican National Convention, but he said she had ignored significant Federal issues.

title: Bechtel-China Engineering Pact
description: The Bechtel Corporation's International Bechtel Inc. subsidiary and the China National Coal Development Corporation signed a contract forming an engineering joint venture, the New China News Agency said.

title: Wife and 3 Children Die; Husband Kills Himself
description: A man whose wife and three children drowned in a flash flood, along with the children's grandmother, shot himself to death today hours after learning of his family's fate, the Navajo police said.

title: JOSEPH A. GRAZIER, EX-OFFICIAL WITH AMERICAN STANDARD INC.
description: Joseph Albert Grazier, the former chief executive officer of American Standard Inc., died Sunday at Burke's Rehabilitation Center in White Plains. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: NIEKRO WINS NO. 15
description: In looking for reasons behind their impressive second-half resurgence, the Yankees have cited a marked improvement in their infield defense as one of the key elements. Last night, though, it was the infield offense that was the key element in an 8-2 romp over the sagging California Angels.

title: 'SUPERCLOCK' IN MARKETS
description: THE most strategic spot in any

title: Iran Again Threatens New Offensive on Iraq
description: Iran threatened again today to open a new offensive against Iraq, saying Iranian troops stood ready ''to attack and destroy the Iraqi regime and its supporters at any time.''

title: Riccar Seeks Court Aid
description: The Riccar Company, a financially troubled sewing machine maker, will reconstruct its business under court supervision rather than through negotiations with creditors, an official of the company said today. Riccar's debts total about $435 million. Creditors were unwilling to cooperate with plans for reconstruction after charges that the company's financial statement may have been altered.

title:
SCOUTING;
A Better Day For Marathoner
description: Her wobbly-legged finish in the Olympic women's marathon made Gabriela Andersen-Schiess an instant, if unfortunate, celebrity. Television viewers all over the world saw her stagger into the Los Angeles Coliseum, suffering from dehydration, then sidle and sway around the track as she finished the final 400 meters before collapsing.

title: HARRIS, UNCLAIMED, IS NOW FREE AGENT
description: Franco Harris, released Monday by the Pittsburgh Steelers, became a free agent today when he was not claimed by any National Football League team.

title: TSR INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: IN recent years Americans have

title: Hazeltine Award
description: The Hazeltine Corporation received a $61.6 million Air Force contract to continue full-scale development of an information distribution system, the Defense Department said. The contract includes 19 prototypes and integration studies for improved air-to-air and air-to-ground jam-resistant voice communications, the department said.

title: Child Abuse: At Long Last, Light Investigations of child abuse at a Bronx day care center have confirmed the obvious: a fair amount of confusion and even hostility between social workers and law enforcers. Both New York State and City inquiries have concluded, however, that these tensions resulted not from any cover-up of wrongdoing but from differences of perspective reinforced by rigid legal requirements.
description: Wisely, Mayor Koch and Mario Merola, the Bronx's District Attorney, have now resolved to sort out their respective responsibilities and to jointly seek changes in the laws that define them.

title: U.S. Lagging in China Trade
description: America's trading deficit with China in the first half of this year increased tenfold, to $338.7 million, as the volume of trade between the two nations climbed 27 percent, the United States Embassy said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The supposition was that we had something to hide and obviously we don't.'' - Geraldine A. Ferraro. (A1:1.)

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: New Horizons
description: Despite his loss in a rare 300-meter race in London last Saturday, Carl Lewis said he planned to add an even longer distance, 400 meters, to his competitive repertory next year. Lewis, who won gold medals in the 100, the 200, the 400-relay and the long jump at the Los Angeles Olympics, said he planned to try both the 400 and the 110-hurdles next year.

title: Lufthansa Labor Talks
description: A West German union announced today that it would not begin a strike at Lufthansa A.G., and proposed talks with management. Heinz Ruhnau, chairman of the airline, said he would meet with the union leadership, representing the white-collar employees and flight crews, on Aug. 31.

title: That's My Baby
description: Architects do not normally get to

title: KIRKPATRICK'S SPEECH DELIGHTS PARTY

title: Australian Turnaround

It said gross domestic product totaled $128.5 billion (Australian), over the 12 months ending June 30, up from $121.6 billion a year earlier.

title: Mobil Price Rise
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation said it had raised all wholesale gasoline prices one cent a gallon. Following its latest increase, Mobil's posted price for truckload quantities of leaded regular gasoline at its Linden, N.J., terminal, which serves the New York City area, is 79.60 cents a gallon, and in Houston is 80.5 cents. Mobil also said it was raising its New York Harbor price for bargeload quantities of distillates 0.5 cent a gallon, which increases its price for No. 2 fuel oil to 79.20 cents a gallon.

title: A QUITE CONTRARY VIEW ON ASBESTOS
description: Malcolm Ross would like to make something clear. He does not believe asbestos is good for humans. He agrees that exposure to the fiber can cause cancer and crippling lung disease. Asbestos, he says, is ''bad news.''

title: THE REGION;
description: An Atlantic City investment counselor pleaded guilty today to charges that he embezzled more than $1 million from the accounts of nine clients in an attempt to cover personal investment losses.

description: The New York Philharmonic's Asian tour is in many ways an exercise not so much in musical as in physical movement: how to transport 112 musicians, various family members, 55 other employees and officials and 11 tons of instruments through jet-lagged days and a summer that when not unpleasantly hot is unbearably so.

title: Warsaw Drops Charges Against Priest
description: The Government, acting on the final day of monthlong amnesty, said today that it had withdrawn charges of illegal political activity filed against a Roman Catholic priest who is a close friend of Lech Walesa, the founder of the Solidarity movement.

title: MINING OF MOON MATERIALS SEEN AS KEY TO SPACE WORK

title: Honor for Auerbach

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: STRANGER ON THE SQUARE. By Arthur and Cynthia Koestler. Edited and with an introduction and epilogue by Harold Harris. Illustrated. 242 pages. Random House. $16.95. IN 1983, Arthur Koestler and his third wife, Cynthia, were found dead in London of a massive overdose of barbiturates. He was 77 years old, and suffering from Parkinson's disease and terminal leukemia. She was 55 and in good health. Friends expected his suicide - he was vice president of the Voluntary Euthanasia Society - but hers was apparently a last-minute decision. In her brief suicide note, she said, ''I cannot live without Arthur, despite certain inner resources.''

title: Today's Calendar
description: The Supporting Cast:The bit players appearing tonight present the sort of balanced ticket that would make any New York political boss proud. Everett Alvarez Jr., deputy director of the Veterans' Administration, will offer the pledge of allegiance when the proceedings convene at 9 P.M. Eastern time (8 P.M. in Dallas). The singer Vikki Carr, who also has Hispanic roots, will sing ''The Star- Spangled Banner.'' The invocation will be offered by John Cardinal Krol, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Philadelphia, a well-known conservative on church doctrine. Ray Charles, the black singer, will intone ''America the Beautiful,'' and the benediction will come from W. A. Criswell, pastor of the First Baptist Church in Dallas, the nation's largest Baptist Church.

title: PHOENIX AMERICAN INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
Decker Delays Return
description: Mary Decker will not run again until the Fifth Avenue Mile in New York on Sept. 27, according to her coach, Dick Brown , who said that the injuries Miss Decker received when she fell during the women's 3,000 at the Olympics were more serious than thought. ''We've canceled the European season because there's not enough time to prepare properly,'' he said. Brown said a recent examination indicated extensive tissue damage and tears around her left hip and groin. . . . Antonio McKay , an Olympic gold medalist on the 1,600-meter relay team and a bronze medalist in the 400-meter dash, has decided not to play football for Georgia Tech.

title: Taiwan-Japan Silk Talk
description: Taiwan and Japan have failed to reach an agreement that would curtail Taiwan's exports of silk products to Japan, the Taiwan Silk Weaving Industrial Association said today. An association spokesman said that Taiwan - third-largest silk exporter to Japan - refused to accept a Japanese proposal to cut Taiwan's exports to about 1.84 million square yards this year from 2 million square yards in 1983. Both sides agreed to hold another round of talks in Tokyo in December, the spokesman said.

description: Arthur Sim Myers, a recording executive, music critic and freelance writer, died of a heart ailment yesterday in Los Angeles. He was 55 years old.

description: Shimon Peres, head of the Labor Alignment, signed an agreement today with Ezer Weizman, drawing the former Defense Minister and his party, which has three seats in the new Parliament, firmly into the Labor camp.

description: Newspapers in Ireland today sharply criticized Martin Galvin, the American supporter of the Irish Republican Army whose appearance at a Belfast rally last week preceded a police attack on a crowd in which one man was killed and 20 people were wounded.

Penalty schedule: $50 fine for first offense, $100 for second, $500 and possible 15-day jail sentence for third.

Bowater Mill
description: Bowater Inc. announced a $341 million expansion of its Catawba, S.C., mill to produce an additional 197,000 tons a year of lightweight coated publication paper. Bowater, based in Darien, Conn., said the expansion is expected to be completed by the fourth quarter of 1986. A.P. Gammie, Bowater's president and chief executive officer, said customers already had entered into contracts to buy substantially all of the new output, which would eventually raise Bowater's total coated paper capacity to about 321,000 tons.

description: The Consumer Price Index, the most widely followed gauge of inflation, rose at a somewhat faster rate in July than in the two preceding months, the Labor Department reported today. The index was up three-tenths of 1 percent last month.

title: Denis Johnston, 83, Is Dead; A Playwright and Professor
description: Denis Johnston, an Irish playwright and former chairman of the theater department at Smith College in Northampton, Mass., died in Dublin on Aug. 8. He was 83 years old.

title: Dominelli Statement
description: J. David Dominelli, the financier, admitted today that he had lied about having $112.8 million in foreign banks, saying that $60 million invested in his J. David & Company had been spent.

title: 16 ACCUSED OF SELLING DRUGS OR GAMING AT L.I.R.R. YARDS
description: Sixteen people, all but one of them employees of the Long Island Rail Road, were arrested yesterday on charges of selling drugs or committing gambling offenses at three train yards in Queens, authorities said.

title: NEW INQUIRY IN PUERTO RICO SHOOTINGS
description: The Senate of Puerto Rico will investigate whether Federal officials helped cover up the circumstances of the killing of two young radicals by the police six years ago, it was announced today.

title: Man Dies Protecting Child
description: An apartment building manager was killed saving a 3-year-old boy from a gunman's rampage Sunday. Vincent McGowan, 29 years old, and the boy, Demone Scott, were outside the building when a gunman began firing at random. Mr. McGowan began herding people into the building. A bullet hit him in the side as he grabbed the boy and another hit him in the chest as he carried the boy into the building.

title: COSMOS SAID TO JOIN M.I.S.L.

MINNESOTA (NFC) - Placed Benny Ricardo, kicker, on the injured reserve list. Cut Rick Bell and Jarvis Redwine, running backs, Dana Noel, defensive back, and Dwayne Roberts, linebacker. SAN DIEGO (AFC) - Obtained John Turner, defensive back, from the Minnesota Vikings and received a roster exemption for him. TAMPA BAY (NFC) - Acquired Perry Tuttle, wide receiver, from the Buffalo Bills in exchange for an undisclosed draft choice, and Bryon Braggs, defensive lineman, from Green Bay on waivers. Placed Johnny Ray Smith, defensive back, on the injured reserve list. WASHINGTON (NFC) - Acquired Rich Mauti, wide receiver, on waivers from New Orleans. Waived Lorenzo Zackery and Vic Vines, defensive backs, Geff Gandy, linebacker, Steve Stapler, wide receiver, Jay Pennison, offensive lineman, and Jeff Smith.

title: INVITING POST-KHOMEINI MODERATION
description: The post-Khomeini era in Iran has already begun. Rumors that the Ayatollah's health is deteriorating may or may not have any bearing in fact. It is, nevertheless, high time for the West to take account of the struggle for power that is already taking place between two factions of Iran's clerical leadership.

title: WHEREHOUSE ENTERTAINMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Digital-A.T.& T.
description: The Digital Switch Corporation said its Granger Associates subsidiary had been selected by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to provide its 7400 Transmux model through December 1985. Digital valued the contract at about $33 million.

title: TEACHERS LISTEN TO BUSINESS CHIEF
description: The head of one of the country's largest insurance companies today called for closer cooperation between business people and educators, adding his voice to a growing movement to improve American public schools through an alliance of the two groups.

title: G.M. WITHHELD BRAKE DATA IN 2D INQUIRY, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: A senior Government safety official has accused General Motors of improperly withholding documents from a second investigation into possible safety problems with brakes in the company's 1980 middle-size automobiles.

title: 3 Policemen Indicted In Casino Bribe Case
description: A police captain and two other members of the department have been indicted on charges of accepting bribes from two Chinatown gambling casinos, Manhattan prosecutors announced yesterday.

title: Counties Eligible For Drought Aid
description: The Federal Agriculture Secretary, John Block, today named 32 counties in New York and eight counties in three adjacent states eligible for emergency loans to help farmers recover from last year's drought.

title: CITY PAYS LESS IN INJURY CLAIMS
description: For at least one year, New York City was able to reverse the rising costs of injury claims and other settlements, the City Comptroller's office said yesterday, but it cautioned that the decline was probably short-lived.

title: DURABLES ORDERS UP 2.2% IN JULY
description: Factory orders for durable goods climbed 2.2 percent in July, in a partial comeback from recent declines, the Commerce Department said today.

title: NICARGUA TALKS SAID TO PROGRESS
description: Talks between the United States and Nicaragua have progressed better than either side expected, but the prospects for a negotiated solution to the two nations' differences remain remote, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Technology; The Multi-User Computers
description: IN the booming days of mainframe and minicomputers, users sat at terminals and shared the

title: THE SUBTLE COLLABORATION OF LANDSCAPE AND HOUSE
description: ''IT'S the relationship of a building to its landscape, whether it be urban, rural or suburban, that makes architecture challenging today,'' says Stanley Tigerman, the Chicago postmodern architect.

title: UNITED STATES MUTUAL FINANIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $24,000 for the quarter and $85,000 for the 6 months.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Boxing
description: Eddie Gregg vs. James Broad , North American Boxing Federation's heavyweight title bout, 12 rounds, at the Felt Forum; first preliminary, 7:30 P.M. This championship fight, originally scheduled for June, had to be postponed when Gregg's eardrum was injured in sparring. At stake is a crown left vacant when Tim Witherspoon won the World Boxing Council's heavyweight title. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M.)

title: FARAH MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $2,682,000 for the quarter and $4,830,000 for the 9 months.

title: Senior Avco Notes
description: Avco Financial Services is offering $100 million of 12 3/4 percent senior subordinated notes due in 1994 at a price of 99.65 to yield 12.82 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The notes are not redeemable before maturity by the company, but may be repaid at a price of 100 on Aug. 15, 1989, at the option of holders.

title: One New Yorker, One Vote A Federal court is pounding more nails into the coffin of New York City's Board of Estimate. The problem is fair representation.
description: As this central authority is now selected, each borough's voters have an equal chance to elect a board member. But because the boroughs vary in population, a voter's influence depends mightily on place of residence. A voter in heavily populated Brooklyn is vastly underrepresented. A voter in more sparsely settled Staten Island is greatly overrepresented.

title: CONVENTION IN DALLAS: THE REPUBLICANS; LOYAL VICE PRESIDENT
description: Four years ago, when Ronald Reagan asked George Bush to be his running mate, it was seen as a political blind date that did not entirely please either man's supporters. Mr. Reagan was the hero of the Republican Party's conservative wing and Mr. Bush was the hope of the party's moderates. They had waged a tough primary campaign against each other, and Democrats still gleefully quote Mr. Bush's description of Mr. Reagan's budget-balancing promises as ''voodoo economics,'' a choice of words Mr. Bush now says he regrets.

title: CONVENIENT FOOD MART INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 Premieres Scheduled for Y
description: Two premieres will mark the opening on Sept. 29 of the 1984-85 season of the Y Chamber Symphony at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. Led by Gerard Schwarz, the orchestra will present the world premiere of Cello Concerto by Joan Tower and the New York premiere of Nocturne by Charles Griffes. The soloists are Maurice Andre, trumpet player, and Andre Emilianoff, cellist.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article Aug. 5 on the United States Army School of the Americas misidentified the opposition candidate defeated by Nicolas Ardito Barletta in presidential elections in Panama May 6. He is Dr. Arnulfo Arias Madrid, leader of the Democratic Opposition Alliance.

title: PHYSICIANS INSURANCE COMPANY (OHIO) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOVIET PRESS TELLS OF SPIES, ALL AMERICAN
description: Suddenly the Soviet press was full of American spies. No sooner had television concluded a widely watched 10-part series pitting the K.G.B. against the C.I.A. than the newspapers weighed in with a spate of exposes.

title: SPOTLIGHT IS FAMILIAR TO 'IDOMENEO' RESCUER
description: It was a classic operatic rescue story, but with a twist. Last Friday at Avery Fisher Hall, the Mostly Mozart festival presented Mozart's ''Idomeneo'' as arranged by Richard Strauss. Last Saturday morning Jerry Hadley, who had sung the title role, woke up with allergy symptoms so severe that he knew he couldn't do the repeat performance that night.

title: PITTSBURGH BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $117,600.

title: SPOTLIGHT SWITCHES TO ANOTHER MILLER
description: Darrell Miller was eagerly looking forward to flying to California after the Angels' game with the Yankees last night. ''When I get home,'' he said, ''we'll have some serious fun.''

title: Man Tied to Iran Arms Sales
description: A California man of Iranian ancestry has been charged with shipping an estimated $12 million worth of tank, cannon and missile parts to Iran, according to a Federal indictment made public today.

title: CONGRESSMAN REACHES OUT TO BLACKS FOR MONDALE
description: After Geraldine A. Ferraro introduced her running mate, Walter F. Mondale, at a rally packed with politicians at Queens Borough Hall, Representative Charles B. Rangel, New York's leading black Democrat in Washington, received a number of pained telephone messages.

title: NEW YORK AREA PRICES CLIMB 0.4%
description: Prodded mainly by higher housing costs, the Consumer Price Index in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: WEBCOR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MONENCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $3.5 million for the quarter and 6 months from discontinued operations.

title: Solidarity Asks Poles To Mark Anniversary
description: Underground Solidarity leaders are urging Poles to show their support publicly for the banned union on the fourth anniversary of its founding, but they avoided calls for street protests.

title: INDIAN AIR TO BUY 12 BOEING JETS
description: India's domestic air carrier, Indian Airlines, has ordered 12 Boeing 757 planes worth $480 million.

title: ASTROS' SLAM STOPS CUBS, 8-3
description: Jose Cruz hit a grand slam to cap a seven- run second inning and lead the Houston Astros to an 8-3 victory today over the Cubs. Nolan Ryan held Chicago to five hits.

title: Hong Kong Rate Cuts
description: The Hong Kong Banking Corporation and the Chartered Bank said today that they were cutting their prime lending rate by one percentage point, to 14 percent. The Hong Kong Association of Banks also announced a one percentage point cut on deposit interest rates.

title: DETROIT ARCHDIOCESE OPPOSES PRODUCTION OF 'SISTER MARY'
description: The Roman Catholic archdiocese wants to stop the scheduled production of the play ''Sister Mary Ignatius Explains It All for You'' at the Birmingham Theater, calling it ''virulently anti- Catholic.''

title: ONCE-SLEEPY MONTAUK FIGHTS TO SLOW DOWN DEVELOPMENT
description: With many in their ranks plagued by typhoid and yellow fever, nearly 30,000 men returning from the invasion of Cuba with Theodore Roosevelt landed here in August 1898 and found a desolate fishing hamlet.

title: DENG AS OUTCAST: DAUGHTER TELLS OF THE ORDEAL
description: A daughter of Deng Xiaoping, in an article published on the Chinese leader's 80th birthday, today described for the first time her father's ordeal as a political outcast during the Cultural Revolution.

title: Market Place; Cigna's Fall From Favor
description: THE stock of the Cigna Corporation, one of the

title: Riblet Products
description: The Riblet Products Corporation said its directors had terminated further discussions with an investment group headed by Spear Leeds & Kellogg, a brokerage firm, concerning its proposal to buy out Riblet for $15 a share.

title: HECHINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
LIBERAL TO FACE CONSERVATIVE IN UTAH'S GUBERNATORIAL RACE
description: Wayne Owens, a former Democratic Congressman, will face Norman H. Bangerter, a conservative Republican State Representative, in the Utah gubernatorial race in November.

title: GOV. DEUKMEJIAN'S REMARKS
description: Following are excerpts from the prepared text of the speech tonight by Gov. George Deukmejian of California to the Republican National Convention renominating George Bush for Vice President:

title: Dialing the Pentagon
description: The Pentagon employs 25,000 people, who work, in one

title: A TEXAS GALA AT $1,000 A HEAD
description: Nelson Bunker Hunt, the Texas billionaire, was strolling down a hill on his Circle T Ranch near here Tuesday night when he noticed a clear plastic fork on the lawn. He picked it up, brushed it off and put it in his pocket.

title: Seagate Projection
description: Seagate Technology Inc. said it expected operating earnings for its first quarter would be ''somewhat lower'' than those of a year earlier because of a soft personal computer market. For last year's first quarter, ended Sept. 30, Seagate reported income from operations of nearly $6.4 million and net income of $9.4 million, or 21 cents a share, on sales of $50.6 million. Seagate also said that it expected revenues would be up ''only modestly'' over last year.

title: A CHURCH WHERE THINGS HAPPEN
description: It looks, at first glance, like any other aging inner-city church. The building is red- brick neo-Gothic; there are huge stained-glass windows and a ''welcome'' mat in front. But there, attached to two poles on the lawn, is a large black-and-white poster. It says, ''Let's End U.S. Support For South Africa.''

title: Oilers Pursue Rozier
description: The Houston Oilers said they were prepared to offer Mike Rozier an immediate contract to join the National Football League team this year, but Art Wilkinson , Rozier's agent, said that he had conducted no active negotiations with the Oilers, nor had any contract proposal been offered.

title: Bossy to Work Out
description: The Islanders' Mike Bossy , who left Team Canada earlier this week because of a sore right knee, was examined yesterday by Dr. Jeffrey Minkoff , the Islander physician, and rejoined Team Canada last night in Halifax, Nova Scotia. Dr. Minkoff said that Bossy was suffering from a swollen right kneecap, which is the same knee he sprained in late January when he missed six games. . . . The Rangers announced they had signed the left wing Don Maloney .

title: 3 MILITARY SERVICES SUSPEND PAYMENTS FOR MISSILES
description: Air Force contracting officials announced today that the Army, Navy and Air Force had suspended payments to Hughes Aircraft Company for work on three of the military's major missile systems.

title: LEBANON TO ASK U.N. SESSION ON ISRAEL
description: The Lebanese Government decided today to file a complaint with the United Nations Security Council against Israeli actions in occupied southern Lebanon.

title: ZACCARO APPARENTLY KNEW IN JULY OF QUESTIONS ON ESTATE LOAN
description: John A. Zaccaro was apparently aware when interviewed by an aide to Walter F. Mondale in July that his management of an elderly woman's estate was being questioned by a court referee, according to court and campaign officials.

title: Now, It's Four For the Mayor
description: So relentless an author is Mayor

title: NFA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONCERT: TINA TURNER AT THE RITZ
description: TINA TURNER sings like a woman who's seen everything, rasping out songs in a voice of grit and flint and hard traveling. After nearly three decades in the music business, she is in peak form. The show she brought to the Ritz on Tuesday, opening a three- night stand, capitalizes on all of Miss Turner's strengths - her voice, her experience and the fact that once on stage, she never stops moving.

title: Shultz Assails Platform On Hong Kong's Destiny
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz tonight repudiated the Republican platform's call for ''self-determination'' for Hong Kong, a position China has strongly criticized.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH a split shingle or two is normally of little concern, it's not a bad idea to fill the cracks quickly with caulking compound. This will help keep moisture from making the crack worse and help bind the shingle so it doesn't split even more.

title: JudgeExtendsBar On Vendor Rules
description: A state judge yesterday extended an order barring the city from enforcing new rules that would extend its ban on sidewalk food vendors to most of midtown Manhattan.

title: COUPLE TO LEAVE ESTATE TO ORCHIDS
description: Lewis Vaughn's passion for orchids began 40 years ago as a backyard hobby. Now he and his wife have arranged for the bequest of a $1 million estate, including six greenhouses, as the new headquarters of the Harvard-based American Orchid Society.

title: THURSDAY, AUGUST 23, 1984 International
description: Shimon Peres signed a pact with Ezer Weizman, drawing the former Defense Minister and his party, which has three seats in Israel's new Parliament, firmly into the Labor alignment. The agreement, reportedly a carefully constructed document, dealt a heavy blow to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's chances of continuing to govern. (Page A1, Column 1.) Two more Soviet mine-hunting ships have arrived at the Suez Canal on their way to the Red Sea, Egyptian officials said. (A3:1-3.)

title: CHRISTIAN BROADCAST NETWORK CANCELS ITS CABLE SOAP OPERA
description: ''Another Life,'' television's first soap opera designed to teach Christian principles, produced by the Christian Broadcasting Network, has been canceled - because of low ratings and a shortage of advertising revenues.

title: A JUDGE BLOCKS CLOSING OF SHELTER IN AN ARMORY
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday issued a temporary restraining order barring the city from closing a 111-bed shelter for homeless men at the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: Carbide Loses On Dismissal
description: A Federal appeals court in New York ruled yesterday that the United Carbide Corporation had acted improperly when it dismissed its chief labor lawyer when he turned 65 years of age.

title: Initial Offering Of Korea Fund
description: The initial public offering of the Korea Fund, a closed-end mutual fund, is under way through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: TIMMINCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After special losses of $141,000 for the quarter and $179,000 for the 6 months on the smelting operations of a subsidiary and tax credits of $351,000 for the quarter and $399,000 for the 6 months. c-After special losses of $44,000 for the quarter and $55,000 for the 6 months on the smelting operations of a subsidiary and tax credits of $77,000 for the quarter and $193,000 for the 6 months. The company was formerly known as Chromasco Ltd.

title: Slander Protection Widened in Jersey
description: False accusations of theft are intrinsically slanderous, even if the offense is minor, a state appeals court ruled today in ordering a new defamation trial for a woman who said she was wrongly accused of shoplifting.

title: ACS ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $21,820 from the Home Viewer Magazine unit which was acquired in the latest quarter.

title: Women's Equality Day
description: Among noteworthy historical events to have taken place on Aug. 26 are the ratification of the 19th Amendment, granting nationwide suffrage to women (1920), and the birth of Geraldine A. Ferraro (1935). So the National Organization for Women is celebrating both events this Sunday, Aug. 26, a day that is also celebrated by some as Women's Equality Day, with an outdoor rally in downtown Washington.

title: 18-MILLION-YEAR-OLD FOSSILS MAY LINK HUMANS AND APES
description: Scientists digging in Kenya have found the bones of 18-million-year-old apelike creatures from a species thought to be the common ancestors of the apes and humans.

title:
GARDENING;
EASY-TO-USE TOOLS TO AID THE ELDERLY
description: FINDING the right garden tools can be a problem for elderly or handicapped people. Conventional tools are often too heavy, and lightweight but efficient trowels, spades and clippers may not be available at local nursery or gardening stores.

title: GOODEN FANS 9 AS METS WIN
description: Dwight Gooden pitched the Mets to a 5-2 victory over the San Diego Padres tonight with a dazzling three-hit performance, and became the 11th rookie in baseball history to strike out 200 batters.

title: German Auto Output Up
description: West German auto makers, idled through much of May and June by strikes at key suppliers, increased production 20.8 percent in July from a year earlier, a trade group said today.

title: CONVENTION IN DALLAS: THE REPUBLICANS; RESIILENT STANDARD BEARER
description: He does it nearly every time he gives a speech on television. With a trademark lopsided grin and ''aw, shucks'' ducking of his head, President Reagan comes across as good-hearted, carefree and utterly unobsessed by the burdens or pleasures of power.

title: TERRORISTS SUSPECTED
description: A bomb apparently planted by a group opposed to United States policy in Central America exploded shortly before noon today outside a General Electric Company sales office.

title: WHEN GOVERNMENT ENCOURAGES A CRIME
description: To the Editor:

description: Forestry Agency refused today

title: Itel Is Planning Note Exchange
description: The Itel Corporation said it plans an exchange offer for its 10 percent notes, and will seek approval of amendments to the terms of its 10 and 14 percent notes.

title: HAYNES WALKS OUT IN CONTRACT DISPUTE
description: Mark Haynes, an all-pro at left cornerback in each of the last two seasons, walked out on the Giants late this afternoon, unhappy with the progress of contract negotiations.

title: President Denies Plans To Oust Labor Official
description: President Reagan denied today that he would remove the chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, Donald L. Dotson, to please Jackie Presser, president of the teamsters' union.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS LEAD ACTIVE LIFE AT LEHMAN
description: There are few acoustical problems in its theater or concert hall, the sightlines are good from almost any seat, parking is free, a ticket costs about $10 and critics seldom show up - to find fault with what the audience

title: UNDER THE GUNS, FARMERS TILL THE JORDAN'S BANKS
description: -Occupied West Bank - In the hot, airless valley along the Jordan River, Israeli and Jordanian soldiers watch each other through binoculars. Between the soldiers, farmers peacefully till the land.

title: A CITY'S BLIGHT: RIOTS, CRIME, GOLF IN THE STREETS
description: The city's chief executive feuded with the City Council. A shooting by a policeman touched off a race riot. Crackdowns failed to stop prostitution, smuggling and illegal dealing in intoxicants. Immigrants balked at learning the language and petitioned for bilingual services.

title: HORIZONS RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
When the Stars Align ; Banks Born a Leo
description: Federal law prohibits mergers between banks in different states unless state authorities approve. That's probably not a good rule, and it's certainly not a popular rule among the larger, more aggressive commercial banks.

title: Social Security Push
description: The Advertising Council has agreed to take on a public service campaign for the Social Security Administration and will seek a volunteer agency from the American Association of Advertising Agencies. Social Security does not expect to cut back on its own efforts to inform the public of rights and responsibilities of those entitled to benefits.

title: SOME 'SUPERMOMS' WHO LED THE WAY
description: THEY bucked the tide of their times: the women who 20, 30 or 40 years ago had babies and went to back to work, had second babies and went back to work and, in some cases, had a few more and went back to work. Their families grew and so did their power, paychecks and prestige. They were pioneers in an era when the prevailing assumption was that children precluded career.

title: Pickens Stake
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company said its chairman, T. Boone Pickens, and Harbert International Inc. each intended to buy up to one million Mesa shares.

description: To the Editor:

title: Gallup Poll Finds 49% Tie G.O.P. to Prosperity
description: Forty-nine percent of Americans, the largest proportion in more than three decades, think that the Republican Party ''will do a better job of keeping the country prosperous'' than would the Democratic Party, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Hot-Dog Packages Recalled
description: The Hygrade Food Products Corporation of Philadelphia has voluntarily recalled some hot dogs that are suspected of containing bits of metal, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. Officials said the recall affected Connecticut, Maryland, Massachusetts, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island. The products are one- pound packages of ''Hygrade Beef Frankfurters'' or ''Hygrade Hotdogs'' bearing ''sell by'' dates of May 14, June 24, July 14 and Aug. 22, and a mark of ''Est. 12PA'' on the labels.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
CARVED WOOD MOLDINGS
description: THE right architectural components can give the finishing touches to a room. Two companies that make various styles of carved wood architectural molding offer an alternative to cast plaster.

title: Tonka Stock Falls Sharply
description: A major shareholder in the Tonka Corporation told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it might sell part of its stake, and Tonka's shares plunged following the announcement. The holder, Bramah Ltd., is a Sheffield, England, manufacturer of engineering products.

title: Begorra And Shalom
description: The founder and president of the

title: BOSTON FIVE CENTS SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. The company converted to a stock form of ownership on Nov. 30, 1983.

title: SOME REPUBLICAN GOVERNORS FEAR REAGAN IS IGNORING THEM
description: Has the Reagan Administration become too Washington-oriented? Some of the Republican governors here think so, and they are not happy about it.

title: PRESIDENT VOWS TO BUILD 'AMERICA'S PARTY'
description: Speeches on pages A27 and A28.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE NOMINATING SPEECH BY LAXALT
description: Following are excerpts from the speech of Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada at the Republican National Convention last night, placing the name of President Reagan in nomination for a second term, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of C-Span:

title: WHO'S AFRAID OF THE BIG BAD FEDERAL DEFICITS?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMSERV CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Prices Are Raised By Texaco, Amoco
description: Texaco Inc. and the Amoco Oil Company, two of the nation's largest gasoline marketers, yesterday raised their wholesale prices by a penny a gallon.

title: 2 Killed in Refinery Blast
description: An explosion Tuesday ripped through a refinery of the Ashland Petroleum Company, killing two people, seriously injuring another and sending a billowing, black cloud of smoke over the Ohio River, the authorities said. The cause of the blast was not known.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Aug. 13 about a reunion of World War II survivors from the Lodz Ghetto in Poland misstated the date the area fell to the Soviet Army. It was January 1945.

title: MOSTLY MOZART: RAMPAL PLAYS A SCHUBERT SONATA
description: THERE was only the slenderest shred of Mozart in the Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall Tuesday: a brief flute quartet, the better part of which was arranged, probably not by the composer, from a Mozart Serenade.

title: TRIAL MAY CHANGE JET LINEUP
description: Coach Joe Walton, who a month ago designated Ken O'Brien instead of Pat Ryan as the Jets' No. 1 quarterback, acknowledged today that Ryan would have to start in the team's final exhibition and perhaps in the regular- season opener as well.

title: ABC Said to Decide Against Reagan Film
description: ABC has decided not show the 18-minute film that will introduce President Reagan to the Republican National Convention Thursday night, according to a senior news executive at the network.

title: Amritraj Hospitalized
description: Vijay Amritraj of India, who eliminated John McEnroe from the Association of Tennis Professionals tournament Tuesday night, had to be taken to the hospital with heat exhaustion after having lost to another Indian, Ramesh Krishnan , 2-6, 6-4, 2-6. Amritraj, 30 years old, collapsed on the court. He was treated at Bethesda North Hospital in suburban Cincinnati for heat exhaustion.

title: WISCONSIN TO STOP FIGHTING ANTENNA
description: The state plans to give up its court fight against a Navy radio project that transmits extremely low frequency radio signals to submarines, state officials said today.

title: IN BLACK AND WHITE
description: I have had several reminders lately of how lonely it is to be a member of an exclusive club - ''the first, the only, or one of a few.'' Within a few weeks, Harold Washington, Chicago's Mayor, berated Ed Bradley, the reporter, on national television; Louis Farrakhan made yet another controversial speech; and Vanessa Williams was no longer Miss America. What bothers me is that as a member in good standing of a club that consists of black achievers Westina Matthews, a program officer with a foundation, is chairman of Chicago Blacks in Philanthropy. I am expected to explain the words and actions of all black public figures. I have spent most of my lifetime as one of ''the first, the only, or one of a few.'' Beginning when I was 4 years old, I was one of the first black children to be enrolled in a newly desegregated school. In the 11th grade, I was one of the first black students to be inducted into the National Honor Society at my high school. As a college senior, I was the first black homecoming queen at my university. I went on to earn a doctorate from a prestigious, predominantly white institution; and I was the only black among more than 300 graduates at commencement. Today, I am employed in a field that has few blacks, and I often find myself sitting in meetings in various corporate headquarters wearing the lone black face.

title: A Sale, a Plan A Bargain
description: Snaking around the corner of Madison Avenue and 48th Street and stretching almost to Fifth Avenue, it was not your ordinary line.

title: Cosmos Win Exhibition
description: Johan Neeskens, Roberto Cabanas and Chico Borja scored goals and led the Cosmos to a 3-2 triumph over Argentinos Juniors in the last international soccer match of the season last night at Giants Stadium.

title: COSELL QUITS ABC 'MONDAY FOOTBALL'
description: Howard Cosell, the voluble sportcaster who has been a fixture on ABC's ''Monday Night Football'' since the popular telecasts began in 1970, has left the program, network officials said yesterday, and will not be in the broadcast booth when it begins its 15th season next month.

title: Reagan Signs Bill That Gives $70 Million in Aid to Salvador
description: President Reagan has signed a $6.7 billion supplemental appropriations bill that includes $70 million of the $114 million he requested in aid for El Salvador, the Administration said today.

title: MESKELL'S 140 HOLDS LEAD IN MET OPEN
description: With rock-hard greens and dense rough making the Old Oaks Country Club golf course much more difficult than usual, the par of 70 was nearly untouchable today in the second round of the Met Open. Only two players in the field of 130 beat par and only five others matched it.

title: BOHEMIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
TURNOUT LOW AS MIXED-RACE SOUTH AFRICANS VOTE
description: South Africans of mixed race registered widespread abstentions Wednesday in elections representing the first test of nonwhite opinion on the Government's plans for qualified political changes that ignore the black majority.

title:
SCOUTING;
A Waiting Game
description: William S. Farish 3d was surprised to pick up The Daily Racing Form yesterday morning and learn that he was the proud new owner of Fit to Fight and Hero's Honor, two of the top older horses in the country. According to the Form, Paul Mellon's Rokeby Stable had sold him the two horses, and they would race in Farish's colors this fall.

title: SHRUBS TO COLOR THE AUGUST GARDEN
description: This seems to be the year for spectcular butterfly shrubs, according to Carmen Costable. Mr. Costable, the store manager for Rosedale Nursery in Hawthorne, N.Y., was talking about one of a number of late-summer-blooming shrubs that can light up the August garden.

title: JAZZ: BAND HONORS ELLINGTON
description: SEVEN of the eight members of Duke's Men worked at various times with the Ellington band. They honor their former employer by digging deep into the Ellington song book.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; MARKETING OFFICIAL NAMED BY NYNEX
description: The Nynex Corporation said yesterday that it had appointed James E. Hennessy, a 26-year employee of New York Telephone, to the new position of executive vice president for marketing and sales.

title: GRICH HELPS ANGELS END SLIDE AT SEVEN
description: If Tommy John couldn't beat the Yankees with his pitches, he at least could beat them with his instructions.

title: Rohr in Deal With Airbus
description: Rohr Industries said it had been selected by Airbus Industrie to coordinate the design, manufacture and support of the total nacelle system for the Airbus A320 commercial transport.

title: When the Stars Align ; Reborn Glory A decade ago, the kindergarten tot at our house was moved to remark that the American flag ''looks like my lunchbox.'' That was a bad time for the flag. Graphic designers were trivializing the Stars and Stripes on cartons, shirts and towels. Opponents of the Vietnam War wore Old Glory on the seats of their pants, or burned it in public. Supporters of the war aggressively pasted the flag on hard hats and pinned it to lapels.
description: All that was bad for the manufacturers of the traditional banner flown from a pole topped by a golden ball or eagle. They had to struggle along on sales to post offices and schools.

title: DISTRESSING WOOD: IT'S A DELICATE ART
description: Distressing could be described as the endeavor to imitate age instantly or to create that lived-in look right away. Any mention of the word distressing in connection with furniture restoration is often received by a raised eyebrow or knowing laugh among those who associate the word with some less-than-desirable instant aging processes. These have involved ice picks, chains, hammers, rasps, burning cigarettes, rocks in socks and even blowtorches, to achieve the look of antiquity.

title: Bridger Draws No. 1 Post in Trot
description: Bridger, one of two entrants representing Canada, drew the No. 1 post position yesterday and was made the early 3-1 favorite in the Roosevelt International Trot, a mile-and- a-quarter race to be held at Roosevelt Raceway at Westbury, L.I., on Saturday night. Bridger, who has 6 victories in 10 outings this season, will be driven by Ron Waples, who guided Ralph Hanover to the triple crown for 3-year-old pacers last year.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Tuesday about the recall of 25,000 copies of ''Splash of Colors: The Self-Destruction of Braniff International'' quoted a word incorrectly in a comment from Lawrence Hughes, president of William Morrow & Company. He said that the recall, for which American Airlines agreed to pay up to $150,000, ''seemed the sensible and reasonable thing to do, even if it is a little unusual.''

description: Stock prices, buffeted by profit taking among blue-chip stocks, finished broadly mixed yesterday.

description: There are jinxes that seem to follow both countries and players in specific areas of the game.

title: FLAW FOUND IN INDIAN POINT 2 REACTOR VESSEL
description: A small crack has been found in the reactor vessel of the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said yesterday. The plant will not be allowed to reopen until the commission can complete a detailed analysis of the flaw.

title: NOTE AND BOND PRICES RETREAT
description: Treasury note and bond prices declined by as much as a point yesterday, reversing much of the price gains that occurred during the three previous days.

title: Bank C.D. Rates Fall
description: Shattering two weeks of stability, average effective yields on six-month certificates of deposit plummeted nationally in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported. In its survey of New York-area institutions, The Monitor found that average yields at most major thrift institutions dropped a point or more in the last week.

description: The State Health Commissioner yesterday called for an immediate settlement of New York City's 41-day hospital and nursing-home strike ''to prevent a catastrophe.''

title: Los Angeles Reports Crime Is Down 6.4%
description: Reports of major crimes decreased 6.4 percent here in the first six months of 1984, the police said today, citing increased arrests for narcotics and vice violations as the main reason.

title: PAVAROTTI, ELECTRONIC ERA SUPERSTAR
description: LUCIANO Pavarotti, who last week became the first classical artist to perform in the new Madison Square Garden, and who sold out the place, 20,000 seats at a $50 top with a simultaneous live telecast, is often spoken of as a product of the mass media. Only in an age in which performances could be disseminated through telecasts and recordings, it is argued, and reputations inflated by modern publicity techniques, could such a gargantuan reputation as his flourish.

title: National Steel
description: National Intergroup Inc. said it and Nippon Kokan K.K. had signed a definitive agreement for Kokan's purchase of a 50 percent interest in National Intergroup's National Steel Corporation subsidiary, concluding four months of negotiations. The company said Kokan would pay $273 million in cash and $19 million in notes for its shares of the steel company. It said National Steel would be directed by a six-member group equally split between Intergroup and Kokan.

title: UPROARIOUS WELCOME GIVEN REAGAN
description: With a zestful blast at the ''defeatism, decline, dependency, doom and despair'' of the Democrats, President Reagan received an uproarious welcome today as he arrived to proclaim the Republican Party ''America's party for the future.''

title: Paper Says Videotape Shows Sakharov Is Fit
description: A West German newspaper said today that it had a 20-minute videotape of Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife in Gorky that is ''unmistakable evidence'' that the Soviet physicist and dissident is alive and has ended his hunger strike.

title:
SCOUTING;
Fast-Selling Item
description: With the United States Open less than a week away, the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadow Park was bustling yesterday with telephone men installing lines, concessionaires stocking their shelves, gardeners tending the begonias and ticket-sellers doing a brisk business.

title: IMPACT OF G.O.P. RIVALRIES ON REAGAN
description: The Republican convention has been a festival of party unity behind President Reagan's campaign and a jubilant celebration of his prospects for re-election. But beneath his unifying umbrella, factional maneuvering over the party's platform and its future leadership has sown the seeds of potentially serious problems for the President's ability to govern in a second term.

title: OLD STEEL TOWN HOPES TO SURVIVE RECESSION

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ON CENSORSHIP The New York Public Library exhibition ''Censorship: 500 Years of Conflict'' is a continuing event. Its four displays run through Oct. 15 and there are hourlong tours of the censorship exhibits at the library's main building, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street, six days a week at noon and 2 P.M.

title: RULING ON BOARD VOTING NOT A DEFEAT, KOCH SAYS
description: A Federal judge's ruling that the structure of the city's Board of Estimate ''would appear to be unconstitutional'' will have no immediate effect on city politics, nor does it spell defeat for the city, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: 'OUR BLOCK' TRAVELS TO STATEN ISLAND
description: For the last year, WCBS-TV has been presenting ''Our Block,'' an intermittent series, in which Vic Miles visits the neighborhoods of New York. It is news in microcosm, concerned not with the ephemeral but the enduring. How do New Yorkers live? What is it that keeps them going? Tonight, at 11:30 on Channel 2, Mr. Miles takes us to Victory Boulevard on Staten Island. The questions, seldom asked on television, may not be fully answered, but it is good to see them raised. They touch on the human condition.

title: Houston Issue
description: A $65 million issue of Houston Housing Finance Corporation mortgage revenue bonds is offered with a maximum yield of 10 7/8 percent for bonds due in 2016 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. For shorter maturities, yields ranged from 7 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 10 1/2 percent in 1997 and 10 3/4 percent in 2002. The bonds, which are secured by payments for single-family home mortgages, were rated Aa by Moody's Investors Service Inc.

title: No. 33, Larger Than Life He has a favorite number, 33, and it's easy to see why. When he played college football, long before he played the Gipper, that was his jersey number. Later, he was elected the 33d Governor of California. And last night, the 33d convention of the Republican Party nominated its hero, Ronald Reagan, for a second term as President.
description: It was, amid the roars and balloons, a time of triumph and elation, though not of surprise. Indeed, the nominations of Mr. Reagan and Vice President Bush were telescoped into one so as not to drag out the obvious, either for the delegates, who are a captive audience, or TV viewers, who are not.

title: U.S. Officials Consider Vaccinating Drug Users
description: Federal health officials have proposed vaccinating drug users and their sexual partners against hepatitis B to try to stem an outbreak that has killed six people in central Massachusetts since April, officials said today.

Ekman, president and chief operating officer. The changes take effect in February, said A. Bronson Thayer, who became chairman of the holding company in March 1983.

title: DELAY HINTED ON TEXTILE IMPORT CURB
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan is considering delaying a hotly contested regulation to restrict textile imports, due to go into effect Sept. 7, a high-level Administration official said today.

title: 2 Germanys In Trade Shift
description: East Germany slashed imports and stepped up exports in trade with West Germany in the first half of 1984, reducing its debt in intra-German trade, the West German Government said today.

title: DANCE: WORKS OF 3 CHOREGRAPHERS
description: ''OFF TIME,'' Tuesday night's program at the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater, was the creation of David Parsons, Karla Wolfangle and Douglas Wright, three members of Paul Taylor's company. The title presumably referred to the fact that when they have time off from dancing with Mr. Taylor they choreograph works of their own. And decidedly fascinating works they proved to be, because although the dancing in them was often bright and sunny, the choreography also contained mysterious shadows.

title: FERRARO RETURNS TO CAMPAIGN TRAIL
description: Her appetite for the task apparently undiminished, Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, bounced back on the campaign trail today with an appearance here before the American Federation of Teachers, a union she once belonged to.

title: Woodward Board Backs Lower Bid
description: Woodward & Lothrop Inc. said its board had supported a proposal by A. Alfred Taubman to acquire the company for $59 a share over a bid by Monroe G. Milstein of $62.40 a share. The company, an operator of department stores with nearly 3.8 million shares outstanding, said an independent committee of its board had concluded that ''there is a substantial risk that the $62.40 price contemplated by the Milstein proposal will not be available to be paid to shareholders.''

title: MCI Appoints Leaders For 7 New Divisions
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said yesterday that it would reorganize its sales, customer service and network operations into seven geographic divisions on Jan. 1. Seven current MCI executives were named to run the divisions.

H. Robertson Company to express ''their concerns about certain recent actions'' by Robertson management.

title: Driver to Fight Murder Case

A lawyer for Daniel Lee Young, 21 years old, of Inglewood, Calif., entered the plea of not guilty to all 55 counts in an arraignment before Municipal Judge Sherman W. Smith Jr. of West Los Angeles.

title: Quake, Felt in 3 States, Shuts Down 2 Reactors
description: A strong earthquake rattled parts of three states early today, shaking some residents awake and prompting the shutdown of two nuclear reactors, but there were no reports of damage or injuries, the authorities said.

title: CONVENTION JOURNAL
description: Uncontrived emotion, devoid of sacks of colored balloons waiting overhead to descend on command, seems as dim as torchlight at the modern political convention that the Republicans have put together this week. The vast preplanning of every detail seems to extend to the very neural systems of the delegates themselves. They nestle back to the buzz of oratory in such comfort and rise to their frenzy cues with such alacrity that an unplanned whimper or chuckle heard from some single human off in a corner can be very heartening. The scraps of such humanity found so far include various moods.

title: AGENT ORANGE, PARTLY SETTLED
description: As nationwide judicial hearings on the proposed $180 million out-of-court settlement of the Agent Orange case proceed, it is apparent that few Vietnam veterans' groups are comfortable with the compromise. But for the rest of us who share an interest in protecting manufacturers from unreasonable liability claims against new products whose risks cannot always be fully anticipated, the settlement should be welcomed as the best temporary resolution of a thorny problem.

title: HOW AN ONSCREEN OAF BECAME ONSTAGE GOLEM
description: Shortly after 8 P.M., Randy Quaid rises from the earth to become a man-made monster, the title character in ''The Golem,'' H. Leivick's classic at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. It is a challenging dramatic role, and Mr. Quaid performs it with an authority that belies his limited theatrical experience.

title: Advice and Dissent at the Pentagon The Defense Department has backed off trying to punish a respected analyst who thinks the $1.6 trillion worth of weapons it is buying over the next five years may bring little real improvement in combat readiness.
description: Franklin Spinney works in the Pentagon's Program, Analysis and Evaluation Office, whose task is to give independent advice to the Secretary of Defense. Mr. Spinney's analyses afford a trenchant critique of procurement policy. In ''Defense Facts of Life,'' he traces how planners underestimate the operating and construction costs of complex new weapons, with the result that too few are produced and for even these only a low state of readiness can be afforded.

description: Orchestra of Our Time, a New York ensemble of 27 musicians, will give the United States premiere of ''El Rey de Harlem,'' by Hans Werner Henze, at Cooper Union on Oct. 12.

title: 8th Mead Film Festival At Museum Sept. 17-20
description: The American Museum of Natural History's eighth annual Margaret Mead Film Festival will be presented Sept. 17-20. This year's program of 40 documentaries, 24 of which will be New York premieres, focuses on changing cultures throughout the world.

title: LILCO IS SAID TO BE CLOSE TO A DEAL ON LONG-SOUGHT CREDIT PACKAGE
description: The Long Island Lighting Company is close to agreement with a consortium of banks and the General Electric Credit Corporation that would provide the utility with enough money to avoid bankruptcy on Sept. 1 and meet its bills well into next year, according to officials.

description: Dutch industrial production fell 1 percent in June from May, but was up 7.4 percent from June 1983, the Government said today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MARGARET MEAD: A Life. By Jane Howard. Illustrated. 527 pages. Simon & Schuster. $19.95. WHEN she was 50 years of age, Margaret Mead took a battery of tests that showed, according to the expert who analyzed her responses, that her mind ''was the least empty one he had ever seen.'' She was probably the busiest, most influential American female writer and thinker in the social sciences of this century. Apart from the immense amount of work that she did herself, she encouraged and inspired hundreds of others to do their work. In her later life, she sometimes seemed to regard American social science as a huge family in which she was the matrix or mother.

Key said the product had been developed and licensed to it by Syntex Pharmaceuticals International Ltd. and would be marketed under the trademark Aerobid. Key, based in Miami, said that it had exclusive marketing rights to the product in the United States and that shipments are expected to this year.

title: Satellite Leasing
description: Satellite Business Systems announced today that it would sell all the space on its new communications satellite to raise $100 million for the financially ailing company. Stephen Schwartz, president of S.B.S., said 10 transponders on S.B.S. 4 would be sold to Salomon Brothers Inc. and a group of other investors, which in turn would lease half the capacity back to S.B.S. for $19 million a year over seven years. S.B.S. plans to use the capacity for its ''Skyline'' long- distance telephone service. The sale- lease back agreement in effect gives S.B.S. a low-interest loan.

description: The State Department of Labor, because of a cut in Federal funds, will reduce by 370 employees the division that finds jobs for the unemployed, a department spokesman said yesterday.

title: SCREEN: LOVE IN BELFAST
description: ''Cal'' is a beautiful, mournful movie about Northern Ireland. Though much of it takes the form of a love story, intimations of violence are everywhere. The film begins with a murder and soon cuts to a scene in a slaughterhouse, where the father of the title character is employed. Cal (John Lynch), sad-eyed and painfully thin, was himself once employed at the ''abattoir'' (as his father calls the slaughterhouse) but is now out of work. Instead, he has reluctantly been recruited by friends as an accessory to Irish Republican Army terrorist activities, including the killing we have already seen.

Weston president-Southern region, and James F. Gadberry president-Southwest region.

title: Revere, Reorganizing, Names New President
description: Revere Copper and Brass Inc., which has been operating under bankruptcy protection for nearly two years, announced yesterday that Hugh H. Williamson 3d will become president and chief executive officer effective Sept. 1.

title: Arthur Nichols Young,Economist, Dies at 93
description: Arthur Nichols Young, an international economist who served as a financial adviser to the Chinese Nationalist Government and represented the United States after World War II in missions to the Middle East and Latin America, died July 19 at a retirement home in Claremont, Calif. He was 93 years old.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: A Healthy Interest

title: OCCIDENTAL OPTIMISTIC ON COLOMBIA
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, expanding on an announcement three weeks ago that it had found ''major'' oil deposits in Colombia, said yesterday that its discovery there might produce close to 100,000 barrels of crude oil a day by 1986.

title: Addenda
description: * Record magazine is increasing its circulation rate base 25 percent, to 125,000, from 100,000, and its advertising rates 15 percent, with the January issue.

title: Comings and Goings The National Collegiate Athletic Association has reversed its stance and will allow
description: Garth Jax , a junior linebacker, to play at Florida State this season. He had been declared ineligible because his photograph appeared in a local advertisement. . . . Richard Todd, the former Jet, was named as the New Orleans Saints' starting quarterback for tomorrow's exhibition against the Washington Redskins, but Coach Bum Phillips said the move did not necessarily mean Todd would replace Ken Stabler .

title: SCREEN: 'JIGSAW MAN,' BRITISH SPY THRILLER
description: With bursts of choler and sly wit, Laurence Olivier provides a zesty centerpiece for ''The Jigsaw Man,'' the latest in a long line of British thrillers to trade on spies, moles, double agents, defections, betrayed lovers and the long, cold war between the K.G.B. and M.I.6.

title: MOSCOW SAID TO BANISH BONNER FOR STATE SLANDER
description: The State Department said today that it had received a report that Yelena G. Bonner, a prominent dissident who is the wife of Andrei D. Sakharov, had been convicted last week of slandering the Soviet state and sentenced to up to five years of internal exile.

title: PAPER MOON, PAPER SUN, PAPER STARS...
description: On a recent swing through his largely rural district in West Virginia, Representative Bob Wise found some disheartened constituents wrestling with paperwork for the Federal Government.

title: RESOURCES PENSIONS SHARES 2 reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Comparable year-ago figures are not available because the company went public in March 1983.

title: POLICE BEAT CUFFED MAN, INQUIRY ON DEATH FINDS
description: Transit police officers used billy clubs or nightsticks and fatally beat 25- year-old Michael Stewart as he lay helpless and handcuffed on a sidewalk, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Ex-Bailiff Acquitted In Chicago Inquiry
description: A former bailiff was acquitted today of taking $10,000 in bribes and soliciting $30,000 to fix divorce cases investigated in a Federal inquiry.

title: Louganis Wins 28th Title
description: Greg Louganis captured a record-tying 28th national diving title tonight by winning the 1-meter springboard event at the United States Diving Outdoor Championships.

title: CONVENTION JOURNAL
description: Blithely Orchestrated

title: KAISER CUTS ALUMINUM OUTPUT AGAIN
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation yesterday announced a further cutback in aluminum production, citing poor prices and unstable market conditions, amid signs that more production curbs in the industry will follow.

title: Tulane Sued by 'Spy' A former football assistant at Tulane has filed a damage suit against the university, charging that his superiors told him to spy on a Mississippi State practice last year and then dismissed him after he was caught. The suit, which seeks $988,000 in damages, was filed in state court in New Orleans by
description: Gerald M. Materne, a 29- year-old insurance salesman, who said he had been sent on the spying venture by the head coach, Wally English, and the defensive coordinator, Bob Davie. ''I would like to reiterate we are not aware of anyone being sent to Starkville last ear,'' English said. ''And certainly, we're not a party to anyone being terminated over that incident.''

title: AVNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $2,453,000 for a loss on the Japanese distribution operation.

title: LABORITIES DEMAND FALKLAND INQUIRY
description: Opposition leaders called again today for an investigation into the Thatcher Government's conduct of the early stages of the 1982 war with Argentina.

title: Colombian Guerrillas End Their 20-Year War
description: The left-wing Popular Liberation Army signed a truce with the Government today to end 20 years of insurgency, the president of the Government Peace Commission said.

title: AMERICA'S PARTY?
description: DALLAS Not since President Thomas E. Dewey was about to take office has any American political party been as complacent and as certain of victory - confident is too mild a term - as are the Republicans meeting here.

title: New Delhi Extends Direct Rule in Punjab
description: The ruling lower house of Parliament approved a constitutional amendment today permitting the central Government to continue direct rule in Punjab state for another year.

title: Exxon U.S.A.
description: The Exxon Company U.S.A. said it had raised its wholesale distillate prices, covering such products as heating oil, diesel fuel and kerosene, in the Northeast, a spokesman said. The company, a unit of the Exxon Corporation, said it had raised the price of truckload quantities of distillate 1.25 cents a gallon at many terminals and the price of bargeloads 0.75 cent a gallon.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Suspension By H.U.D.
description: Trading in project notes of the Department of Housing and Urban Development was stalled yesterday when the Federal agency announced that it would suspend plans for additional offerings.

title: DOES THE TV LENS DISTORT CONVENTION COVERAGE?
description: ''More schmaltz!'' the veteran NBC-TV news director yelled to his camera crews Wednesday night. The pictures on his monitors blinked and changed as the cameramen responded. The crews had been training their videocameras on the delegates to the Republican National Convention as Nancy Reagan waved from the podium. Now, however, they began to scan the floor for the images the director wanted.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Reagan's Brother Greets Renomination Quietly
description: At least one Ronald Reagan delegate in the California delegation was not swept up in the excitement of the President's renomination Wednesday night.

title: LONG ISLAND CITY, NEW ARTISTS' HAVEN
description: From across the East River, Long Island City looks like the industrial center it has been for more than a century, a place where bread is baked, steel is welded and cloth is sewn. Within its borders are more than 500 factories. Train tracks and highways, carrying thousands to and from Manhattan each day, thread their way through the blackened smokestacks that rise above the Queens waterfront.

title: WILLIAMS REPORTS SHE POSED FOR OTHER NUDE PHOTOGRAPHS
description: Vanessa Williams, who relinquished her title of Miss America last month after sexually explicit photographs of her with another woman appeared in Penthouse magazine, said yesterday that she had posed nude for another photographer.

title: CITY OPERA: CAST CHANGES FOR 'LA BOHEME'
description: The newest addition to the City Opera's roster is Pamela South, who made an auspicious debut Wednesday as Mimi in ''La Boh eme.'' She has a fresh lyric soprano, sweet and unforced right up to top C, and in the upper middle range especially good to the ears.

title: M-1 IS DOWN
description: Interest rates were little changed in quiet trading yesterday as many market participants remained on the sidelines in the absence of any new developments pointing toward higher or lower rates.

title: U.S. Aide Faults Press On Coverage of Castro
description: A State Department official said today that United States news organizations had been negligent in failing to portray the Cuban leader Fidel Castro as ''one of the most vicious tyrants of our time.''

title: THE PHANTOM JOBLESS
description: Unemployment figures, like all statistics, can be misleading. In the unemployment rate, accuracy depends not just on who you count, but who you don't count.

title: FEDERATION CALLS FOR BETTER TEACHER TRAINING
description: The American Federation of Teachers ended its annual convention here today amid growing expectation that the school reform movement would expand beyond elementary and secondary schools to teachers' colleges.

title: NO MERGER SEEN IN PRO FOOTBALL
description: United States Football League team owners are misguided if they believe that, by shifting to a fall schedule, they would force a merger or prod the National Football League into accepting them, Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the N.F.L. said yesterday.

description: 23 (AP) - Chul Chang pitched

description: SFN Companies, a Glenview, Ill., publishing and broadcasting concern, said yesterday that an investor group led by E.M. Warburg Pincus & Company and Drexel Burnham Lambert had offered to acquire the company, in a leveraged buyout valued at about $425 million.

title: Midway Weighing Bid on Air Florida
description: Neil F. Meehan, the president of Midway Airlines, said company officials were attending a meeting of Air Florida's unsecured creditors in Dallas yesterday to gather more information about the carrier's financial condition before deciding whether to try to acquire Air Florida.

title: Kaat a Reds Coach
description: Jim Kaat, the left-hander who set a major-league longevity record by pitching 25 seasons with six clubs before retiring last year, is returning to baseball as the pitching coach of the Cincinnati Reds.

title: VIETNAM VETERAN IN LINE FOR CHIEF
description: What is evident at the annual convention of the Veterans of Foreign Wars here this week is that the veterans of the Vietnam era are coming of age in an organization many of them once shunned.

title: W.C.T.U. Leader Hopes For Alcohol-Free Nation
description: Martha Edgar, the president of the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union, said today that there was hope for an alcohol-free country.

Astros Win, Pounding 20 Hits
description: Terry Puhl homered and drove in three runs to highlight a 20-hit attack tonight that powered the Houston Astros past the St. Louis Cardinals, 9-6.

title: SCREEN: 'OLD ENOUGH,' ABOUT 2 YOUNG FRIENDS
description: Lonnie (Sarah Boyd), the barely adolescent heroine of Marisa Silver's ''Old Enough,'' gives her age as ''almost 11 3/4,'' which makes her new friend, Karen (Rainbow Harvest), seem grown up indeed. Karen is a very sexy-looking 14, and she knows about such mature things as wearing makeup and dressing to obvious advantage. Since Karen is also lower class and street-wise, she even knows how to shoplift the makeup from the local drugstore.
