description: People Express, the no-frills

title: Charger Woes
description: With barely a week before the beginning of the National Football League season, four first-round draft choices are still unsigned: the linebacker Ricky Hunley (Cincinnati), the wide receiver Clyde Duncan (St. Louis), the defensive back Leonard Coleman (Indianapolis) and the cornerback Mossy Cade (San Diego).

title: STEEGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Johnson Takes Knick Offer
description: The Knicks, seeking protection against the possible loss of the free- agent guard Ray Williams, signed another free agent, Vinnie Johnson of the Detroit Pistons, to an offer sheet yesterday.

description: Year-ago results are restated to adjust for a change to a 13-week quarter.

title: The Long Road To the Majors
description: Those who watch baseball on television often enough may have noticed the odd number that one of the Atlanta Braves' pitchers wears on the back of his warm-up jacket.

title: 'Yale or Death'
description: ''Give Me Yale Or Give Me Death,'' a play by Alec Klein, a 17-year-old playwright, will be presented this weekend at the Westbeth Theater Center, 151 Bank Street.

title: MET TRIP ENDS ON A GOOD NOTE
description: Like a child prodigy rescuing the performance, Dwight Gooden was the star of the cast today as the Mets took their show home after a punishing run on the road.

title: Murderer's Appeal Rejected
description: Linwood E. Briley, the convicted murderer who in May was mastermind of the largest Death Row escape in American history, lost a ruling today before the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. The court gave him another 21 days to appeal his death sentence before the United States Supreme Court, which has twice refused to hear his case.

title: PERES SUFFERS SETBACK IN COALITION EFFORT
description: Shimon Peres's chances of forming a narrow coalition government before the expiration of a preliminary deadline this weekend dimmed tonight after representatives of two small factions said they would hold out for a broader coalition that included the Likud bloc.

title: A LAB FOR DIRECTORS TO TRY AND ERR
description: Of all the skills involved in theater, directing is perhaps the hardest to define. Other theater artists work, at least to some degree, with tangible materials - a playwright with words, an actor with movement and vocal timbre, a designer with a bank of lights or a bolt of cloth.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. San Francisco Giants, twilight-night doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, 5:35 P.M. After a West Coast swing during which they picked up half a game on Chicago, the Mets return to Shea for a home stand against the three California clubs. (Television - SportsChannel, 5:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 5:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Mariners, at Seattle. John Montefusco, who sparkled last weekend in his return from a severe neck injury, goes again for the Yankees. (Television - Channel 11, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 10:30P.M.) Football

title: Brass Quintet Concert
description: A free performance by the West Side Brass Quintet is scheduled for Sunday at noon in the atrium at CitiCorp, 53d Street and Lexington Avenue. Works by Bach, Debussy, Gabrieli, Ellington and Joplin will be played.

title: Connecticut Festivals
description: Ocean Beach Park in Connecticut will be globetrotting this weekend with festivals offering the food, drink and music of Bavaria and Ireland.

title: FERRARO'S FINANCES: IS THE PRESS BEING FAIR?
description: For over a week, the financial affairs of Geraldine A. Ferraro, the Democratic candidate for Vice President, and John A. Zaccaro, her husband, have been under intense scrutiny by the nation's news media. The story has been reported with repeated front-page articles in newspapers and generous time from network television news shows.

title: Chairman Is Leaving Management Assistance
description: Asher B. Edelman, a private investor who led a group that won 4 of 10 directors' seats at Management Assistance Inc. in a heated proxy fight last March, yesterday tightened his grip on the company that he intends to liquidate.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Plan to Register Voters Can Begin
description: Governor Cuomo's program requiring state agencies to help New Yorkers register to vote can begin immediately, despite Republican claims that it is unconstitutional, a state appeals court ruled today.

title: LOANS BY 14 BANKS TO PROTECT LILCO FROM BANKRUPTCY
description: The Long Island Lighting Company said yesterday that it had struck a deal with 14 banks to get enough cash to keep out of bankruptcy through early next year, but that the deal required it to stop paying dividends on preferred stock.

title: LEVITZ FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
JAZZ FESTIVAL FILM SERIES OFFERS BLUES
description: Jazz films are doubly orphaned. The music business is absorbed in pop promotion, while the movie business prefers blockbusters to documentaries. As a result, a kind of music that gains immeasurably from being seen as well as heard has only recently begun to get filmed by people who understand it - people who also realize that jazz musicians don't live forever.

title: Firestone Lifts Earnings 55%
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said today that its net income jumped 55 percent in the latest quarter to $48 million, or $1.06 a share, from $31 million, or 65 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Dow Ahead by 0.66 On Lighter Volume
description: The stock market, affected by weakness in the credit markets, again turned in a lackluster performance yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.66 point, to 1,232.44. Stocks that advanced barely edged out those that declined, by 770 to 768. Trading slumped to 83.1 million shares, from 116.1 million the day before.

title: PROMISES TO OPPOSE TAX RISE
description: President Reagan, accepting the Republican nomination for a second term, appealed tonight for the party's help in finishing the ''unfinished agenda'' of a conservative reformation of the Government.

title: MCGREGOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
description: b-After a loss of $771,000 from discontinued operations.

title: LABOR PARTY WINS EASILY IN SOUTH AFRICAN MIXED-RACE VOTE
description: The Labor Party, led by a clergyman who has opposed apartheid, emerged today as the overwhelming victor in elections for the mixed-race chamber in South Africa's new three-chamber parliament. The body offers a limited political role to some nonwhite South Africans but not to the black majority.

title: Steel Curtain Is Now Closed for Harris
description: Several attempts were made this week to help Franco Harris and the Pittsburgh Steelers resolve their differences. But Dan Rooney, the president of the team, insists that the Steelers are no longer interested.

title: No Headline

title: Charles Whittenberg, TeacherAnd Composer, Is Dead at 57
description: Charles Whittenberg, a composer and former teacher of composition, died of heart disease at Hartford Hospital in Connecticut on Wednesday. He was 57 years old and lived in Enfield.

title: A MUSEUM RAMBLE ACROSS CONNECTICUT
description: George and Ruth Sherwood started collecting kerosene lamps in 1949. By 1981, they had so many (more than 500) that they did what any self-respecting overcollector does - they opened a museum.

description: Results for the year-ago quarter include a deferred tax adjustment equal to 5 cents a share that had not previously been recognized for financial statement purposes.

title: THELMA GREENHAUS
description: Thelma Nurenberg Greenhaus, a freelance writer, died Aug. 8, apparently of a heart attack, at the Hospital for Joint Diseases. She was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: AS TURKS GO HOME, GERMAN STEEL TOWN WITHERS
description: A five-minute walk through the H"uttenheim district of this Rhine city begins at the steel-mill gates, runs up past grocery stores and a storefront mosque into rows of 70-year-old tenements whose shutters are locked and whose doors are boarded up.

description: A fire killed two people at a store in the Bronx yesterday, the Fire Department said.

description: Andres Gomez of Ecuador, ranked fifth in the world, defeated Paul Annacone of East Hampton, L.I., 6-3, 7-6 (7-3), tonight in the wind-up of the opening round of the $150,000 Hamlet Challenge Cup.

title: Albus Wins Open Despite Prolems
description: Jim Albus poked the ball through, round and over the trees, missed five greens, missed six fairways, bogeyed the last two holes and still managed to scramble to a two-stroke victory today in the 69th Met Open. He also won this championship in 1970 and was runner-up in 1982.

description: Roscoe Dye, a 47-year-old auto worker, spent part of his day recently trying to assemble a truck. He was not working with steel, but with building blocks from a children's toy called Lego.

description: The Gannett Company and Young & Rubicam Inc. are calling it quits by year-end on Y.&R.'s consumer advertising assignment for both Gannett and USA Today, according to both companies.

description: Saratoga Race Track stewards confirmed today that Victor Lopez, the second-leading apprentice rider in New York this year with 45 winners, has been suspended indefinitely pending his successful completion of a drug rehabilitation program.

description: Governor Cuomo has been touring the state this summer with an energy that most politicians reserve for their election campaigns.

title: STATE UNIT ISSUES STUDY ON IMPACT OF 42D ST. PLAN
description: The State Urban Development Corporation yesterday issued the final environmental impact statement for the $1.6 billion 42d Street Development project. The 1,100-page statement, which is subject to modification after public hearings, says the project will provide 23,000 new jobs and generate $776 million in taxes or payments in lieu of taxes over a 20-year period.

description: Year-ago revenue figure has been restated for an accounting change.

title: COMPUTER EXCHANGE SPREADING CHRISTIAN MESSAGE
description: As John Marler sees it, the realm of computer buffs is but a mass of intellectually isolated and lost souls who, if they can just be reached, may still be saved. Through his Christian fundamentalist ministry, Mr. Marler, a 39-year-old computer salesman, consultant and programmer, is seeking to spread the Gospel into memory banks and video display terminals throughout the land.

Nowadays the shock lies around the corner, in both rich and poor neighborhoods of New York.

title: BUILDING THAT HID OSWALD HIT BY FIRE
description: An intensely hot fire was methodically set by an arsonist this morning in the old Texas School Book Depository, from which the shots that killed President Kennedy were fired 21 years ago.

description: The Chief of Staff of the Lebanese Army, a Druse, was killed today when a helicopter in which he was flying crashed into a mountainside, the army command announced.

title: NEW BRAIN STUDY TECHNIQUE REVEALS AN ALZHEIMER DEFECT
description: Scientists have found that large molecules remain intact in frozen human brains for years after death and, by studying such molecules, have discovered a basic biological abnormality in senile brains destroyed by Alzheimer's disease.

title: ZACCARO POSTPONEMENT TIED TO CONVENTION TIMING
description: John A. Zaccaro obtained postponement of a June hearing on his handling of an elderly woman's estate so the matter would not ''interfere'' with the Democratic National Convention, which subsequently chose his wife as the Vice-Presidential nominee, a court referee said yesterday.

ROTISSERIE COOKING, CONEY I. ITALIAN
description: On the Upper West Side, where a restaurant is born every minute, Amsterdam's Bar & Rotisserie is a standout. Since it opened two months ago, its simple fresh food, prepared with style, has attracted diners from far beyond the neighborhood. The fact that it is open until 4 A.M. is an added attraction.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''I think for any director, the first time they ever call 'Action!' in their lives and suddenly a scene begins to be played out just the way they had organized it to be, is sort of amazing,'' Marisa Silver said the other day. ''It's a very strange feeling. It's sort of miraculous.''

title: THE DANGERS AHEAD
description: With a united party behind him, President Reagan left the Republican National Convention tonight heading toward an election that his aides do not see how he can lose, even as they struggle to overcome the dangers of overconfidence. By most measures based on opinion polls, Mr. Reagan is substantially farther ahead of Walter F. Mondale, his Democratic opponent, than any of the President's advisers had dreamed he would be at the beginning of this year.

title: GUILFORD MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
U.S. TESTS EXPLOSIVE PIPLINE TO THWART ADVANCING TANKS
description: The United States has been testing an antitank system in West Germany and South Korea that involves underground pipelines filled with liquid explosive, the Defense Department said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Science Times on Aug. 14 about alcoholism referred incorrectly to soma, the fictional multipurpose drug. The novel that envisioned it was ''Brave New World,'' by Aldous Huxley.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Aeronca Inc., a manufacturer of aircraft parts based in Charlotte, N.C., said it had acquired just over 50 percent of Marathon Boat Manufacturing Co. of Kershaw, S.C.

title: Money Market Fund Assets Up $902 Million
description: The assets of the nation's 340 money market mutual funds increased in the week ended Wednesday, ending a three-week drop attributed to the volatile stock market. The assets grew by $902 million, to $180.17 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Unusual Hockey Fight
description: Professional hockey players are forever taking pokes at each other, and it seemed hardly surprising the other day when Chris Nilan of Team USA punched Rick Vaive of Team Canada in the face following a slashing incident during a Canada Cup exhibition game Monday night. What set this little fracas apart, however, was that it took place in the lobby of the Montreal Forum the day after the game. Now Brian O'Neil, the executive vice president of the National Hockey League, is investigating the fight and plans to submit his findings to the league's president for possible disciplinary action.

title: Rock in Chelsea
description: Two rock bands with overlapping personnel, the Feelies and the Trypes, will play tonight at Danceteria (620-0790), 30 West 21st Street. The Trypes will perform at midnight, the Feelies at 2 A.M.; admission is $6 before 11 P.M., $10 after.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about Capital Cities Communications incorrectly described labor relations at The Kansas City Star, one of the company's newspapers. It has been picketed by the International Typographical Union, but it has not been struck.

title: Gasohol Venture
description: Combustion Engineering Inc. said it had received a contract from the Tennol Energy Company to build a $90 million plant in Jasper, Tenn., to convert corn to fuel alcohol for blending with gasohol. The plant will be able to process 25 million gallons a year.

title: 'CRADLE OF LIBERTY' FIGHTS MINORITY AID PLAN
description: The hometown of John Adams and John Quincy Adams is having second thoughts about a plan to help members of minority groups find housing under a program one city official called a ''solution to a problem that doesn't exist.''

description: From behind the bullet-resistant glass of the token booth, Lilas Wills watched a rush-hour F train pull into the 23d Street station and disgorge hundreds of passengers.

title: Iraq Says Its WarplanesHit a Vessel in the Gulf
description: Iraq said today that its warplanes had scored a direct hit on a ''large naval target'' south of Kharg Island, Iran's key oil exporting terminal in the Persian Gulf. There was no immediate comment from Iran.

title: PAINTING: 55 BY HISPANIC-AMERICANS
description: The show ''IMira! The Canadian Club Hispanic Art Tour'' is being called the first national exhibition of painting by Americans from Spanish-speaking cultures. At the Museo del Barrio, 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street, through Sept. 2, the show brings together 22 artists, from Americans of Puerto Rican origin in New York to Chicanos living in Texas and California. The 55 works give a strong sense of what it means to be a Hispanic- American. Since the viewpoint in these paintings is essentially that of the outsider, the paintings also provide an unusual perspective on familiar art styles.

description: CBS News today refused to broadcast the 18-minute film the Republicans had prepared to introduce President Reagan tonight at the Republican Convention, becoming the second of the three major networks to do so.

title: Gregg Is Stopped
description: James Broad of Atlantic City stopped previously unbeaten Eddie Gregg at 48 seconds of the eighth round of a scheduled 10-rounder last night at the Felt Forum and won the North American Boxing Federation heavyweight championship. The 246- pound Broad, now 16-1, had Gregg helpless on the ropes after four hard rights to the head and Referee Tony Perez stopped the bout. The 30-year- old Gregg, from Queens, entered the fight with a 20-0-1 record.

description: The City Investing Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell three of its key operations - heating and cooling, printing and business forms - for $1.251 billion in cash.

description: The members of the United States national youth soccer team, composed of players under 19, were following almost exactly the pattern of their elders, the United States Olympic team, in trying to qualify for a major international prize.

description: United Press International and the union representing most of its 2,000 employees have agreed on a 13-month austerity program that includes an immediate 25 percent wage cut, the elimination of 200 permanent and temporary positions and a one-year postponement of company contributions to employee pension funds.

title: More on the Mortgage Lottery Today's letter from Assemblyman John Duane, responding to this page's criticism of the low-interest mortgage program for single-family housing, raises an issue that deserves further discussion. What's so bad, he asks, about using Federal tax dollars to make home ownership affordable for families with average incomes?
description: One easy answer is that this particular subsidy is painfully inefficient. The program raises mortgage funds through the sale of state housing authority bonds, which carry relatively low interest rates because investors are not taxed on their earnings.

title: WHITTAKER CUTS ITS DIVIDEND
description: The Whittaker Corporation yesterday cut its quarterly dividend to 15 cents a share from 40 cents, authorized the purchase in the open market of up to three million of its shares and announced its entry into the health maintenance organization field.

title: Deficit Rises $16.4 Billion
description: The Federal budget deficit soared $16.4 billion in July, more than eight times the $2 billion recorded in June, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Diet Center Chain Signs With J.W.T./West
description: The San Francisco office of J. Walter Thompson/West has been appointed the agency for Diet Center Inc., an international franchised chain of more than 1,900 diet and weight-control centers in the United States, Canada, Britain and South America.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; U.S. Home Shifts Senior Officials
description: In a move that surprised some analysts, the U.S. Home Corporation yesterday announced a realignment of senior corporate management.

title: Chapter 11 Filing
description: Theodore Gould, developer of the Pavillon Hotel and the giant Miami Center project, has filed under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The move automatically stays a $197.5 million foreclosure suit recently filed by Mr. Gould's largest creditor, the Bank of New York, to take possession of the center project. Mr. Gould said he had filed for Chapter 11 because of ''interference'' from the bank, which is the lead lender to the Miami Center hotel-office complex. The Miami developer said Bank of New York had got in touch with buyers of several of his properties in the Washington, D.C., area asking for the proceeds of the sale, about $34 million.

title: CORRECTION

title: 'CONDROP': A NEW EAST SIDE CONVERSION
description: The ''condop.'' It sounds rather like a new type of self-service laundry. But real estate developers and lawyers say it may become an increasingly common word in the lexicon of apartment ownership terms.

title: AUCTIONS
description: It's found money for New York

title: FILM: 'LOVE STREAMS,' WITH JOHN CASSAVETES
description: There's no other American director who can do what John Cassavetes does on the screen. There may not be many who would want to. Mr. Cassavetes's work, in ''Love Streams,'' as in his earlier films, is as overflowing with emotional constructs as it is barren of other forms of thought. It's excessive and idiosyncratic all the way. Yet Mr. Cassavetes, as both actor and director, is never without his own peculiar magnetism and authority. Once again, he is able to galvanize a long, rambling, quirky psychodrama through sheer force of personality.

title: VILLAGE CLUBS JOIN IN 11-DAY JAZZ FESTIVAL
description: The Greenwich Village Jazz Festival will enter its third year when it gets started this afternoon - and despite its tender age, the festival is quite a healthy toddler. ''Unlike other American festivals, the Greenwich Village Jazz Festival covers the entire spectrum of the music, with a strong emphasis on contemporary music,'' said Mel Litoff, who runs two clubs, Sweet Basil and Lush Life, and who is president of the Greenwich Village Jazz Festival Corporation. ''It opens with one of the greats of the swing era, Benny Carter, and closes with a day of contemporary music. In between, the full range of the music is presented - in the clubs, where jazz continues to develop.''

title: THE REGION ; ;  Court to Rule On Silent Moment
description: A Superior Court judge today set a Sept. 25 hearing on a request by state officials that Woodbury be forced to end a 20- year-old practice of starting each school day with a moment of silence.

title: SWIM MARK FOR EAST GERMAN
description: Sylvia Gerasch of East Germany set a world record in the women's 100-meter breast-stroke today, and Soviet swimmers won four of five finals on the seventh day of the Friendship '84 Games.

title: CAN IT BE? SCIENTISTS IMMUNE TO THE FEVER?
description: Back in 1950, when the National Science Foundation was created as the Government's chief agency for financing basic research, great pains were taken to insure that its top administrator would have a long and protected tenure in office.

title: First Interstate Offering Notes
description: First Interstate Bancorp is offering $150 million of two-year extendible notes with a final maturity in 1999 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The notes are offered at a price of 100, with an initial coupon of 13 percent, to yield about 55 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, more than two-year Treasury notes.

title: PUBLISHING: THE ODDS AGAINST FOREIGN AUTHORS
description: Because the financial risk of publishing unknown authors is high, and the cost of publishing translations is even higher, publishers usually bring out no more than one or two books by a foreign author before committing themselves to more. Since the odds are heavily against such books becoming commercial successes, many foreign authors are rarely heard of again.

title: SEXUAL ABUSE OF CHILDREN
description: ''Silent Shame: The Sexual Abuse of Children'' is a forthright examination of an ugly topic. Sexual abuse, we are told, ''is the hidden corner of childhood,'' seldom recognized, but of startling proportions. It is also a curse handed down from generation to generation; people molested as children become child molesters themselves. ''Silent Shame,'' a first-rate piece of work by NBC News a can be seen on Channel 4 at 10 tomorrow night.

title: Buyout at Brainreserve
description: Faith Popcorn, president of Brainreserve, has bought out her partner and creative director, Stuart Pittman. Both were creative directors at Smith/Greenland before forming their own agency 10 years ago. Miss Popcorn, who is assuming the duties of creative director, has plans to expand the agency's operations including a program to buy smaller companies.

title: Japanese Spend More
description: Japanese consumer spending in June rose an inflation-adjusted two-tenths of 1 percent from a year earlier, the Government announced today.

title: FRENCH TOWN FOILS FORMER AFRICAN EMPEROR
description: A friend of Jean- Bedel Bokassa, the former leader of the Central African Republic, tried to obtain false French identity papers for the deposed ruler this month but was foiled when a secretary recognized photographs of Mr. Bokassa, a French municipal official said today.

description: Waves of sympathetic noise washed across the ballroom at the Essex House yesterday when Colin Dowdeswell and Lea Antonopolis had their names drawn first from a manila envelope. The occasion was the draw for the United States Open, which begins next Tuesday at the National Tennis Center, and Dowdeswell and Miss Antonopolis won the dubious honor of playing John McEnroe and Martina Navratilova, the top-seeded players, in the opening round.

title: Canada-Amway
description: The Canadian Revenue Department said today that it had decided that Amway, the giant direct sales corporation, still owes the Government $105 million (Canadian) in unpaid taxes, duties and penalties on goods imported into Canada between 1977 and 1980. The decision follows an adjudication process, announced in February, under which Amway was allowed to present its arguments to the department against the department's claim that it owed $105 million.

title: REAGAN SPEECH DRAWS BATTLE LINE OVER 2 CONFLICTING VIEWS OF U.S. FUTURE
description: In an emotional, sharply partisan acceptance speech tonight, President Reagan joined the debate with Walter F. Mondale over two rival visions of American society and its future. Underscoring their philosophical differences and their political records, Mr. Reagan told the American people the 1984 election offered ''the most clear-cut political choice in half a century.''

title: Diner's Journal; MEZZALUNA, A TRATTORIA FOR PASTA AND PIZZA FANS
description: Sometimes it seems as if Manhattan has an underground gastronomic grapevine through which tips on exciting new restaurants flash at lightning speed, creating queues at the door even before the first round of dishes is washed. Such is the case with Mezzaluna, an exquisite little Italian trattoria on Third Avenue, between 74th and 75th Streets. The month-old restaurant seats about 50, and there have been substantial lines during peak lunch and dinner hours.

There were 200 outfits paraded in an hour and a half yesterday afternoon at the Plaza Hotel, spanning the time from late lunch to early cocktails for many of the viewers.

title: DALLAS GALLERY; AND NOW, A GANDER GAP

Ever since the Albany convention of 1754, at which the union of the states first began to take shape, an American political convention should be a hallowed thing. description: ''In the White City'' was shown at last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times Sept. 26, 1983. The film opens today at the Cinema Studio, Broadway near 66th Street.

title: BROADWAY
description: What do Ralph Allen, Cy Coleman, Betty Comden, Fred Ebb, Adolph Green, John Kander, Richard Camp and John Weidman have in common? Probably nothing except that they and some 20 other writers, composers and lyricists are involved in ''Diamonds Are Forever,'' which will open Nov. 29 Off Broadway (Circle in the Square Downtown is being talked about).

title: LIETZKE, AT 4-UNDER 66, HOLDS TWO-SHOT LEAD
description: Bruce Lietzke, helped by an eagle on the second hole, overcame windy and showery conditions to take a four- under-par 66 and a two-shot lead after today's first round of the $700,000 World Series of Golf.

title: ZAPMAIL MAY BECOME PASSE
description: The Federal Express Corporation has made a habit of turning businesses into industries. In 1973, the business was shipping packages overnight. Three years later, it pushed into overnight documents. Then in 1981 came overnight letters. Now the company, flush with confidence from its success so far, is turning to electronic mail.

title: The Extremists, and The Optimist Whenever Ronald Reagan stands up to address America, as he did in Dallas last night, he demonstrates anew what a priceless asset he is to his party.
description: One way to test that proposition is to look around the Republican Convention and ask, Who are these Republicans without him? Again and again, the answer is true believers. They're decent but extreme, like their godfather, Barry Goldwater, whom they cheered as he denounced ''Democrat wars'' - as if, on Dec. 7, 1941, a Republican President could have charmed Tojo out of attacking Pearl Harbor.

title: REAGAN, AT PRAYER BREAKFAST, CALLS POLITICS AND RELIGION INSEPARABLE
description: President Reagan, in a rousing appearance before religious leaders and laymen, said today that politics and religion were inseparable and that those who argued otherwise were ''intolerant of religion.''

If it rains, the concert site will be Lincoln High School, Ocean Parkway and West Avenue. Information: 889-6800.

title: May Shoe Unit

title: Concerns Lose Ruling In School Lunch Case
description: An administrative law judge has ruled that Federal meat inspection should be withdrawn from three meat packing plants linked to a scandal over ground beef supplied for school lunches, officials said today.

title: BATTERY PARK COMPLEX ATTRACTS GIANT TENANT
description: In one of the largest real-estate deals in New York City history, Merrill Lynch & Company signed a rental contract yesterday to move its corporate headquarters into two towers in Battery Park City.

description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $11,489,000 on the exchange of stock for debt. c-Net loss.

title: FED POLICY UNCHANGED LAST MONTH
description: The Federal Reserve decided last month to maintain ''the existing degree of restraint'' on credit, and to raise, by a modest half-point, the target interest rate range for overnight loans among commercial banks, according to minutes, published today, of its main policy-making arm.

title: Carter Profit Lifted by Sale
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., one of the nation's leading retailers, said today that the $295 million sale of its Waldenbooks unit helped increase its profits in the second quarter to $39.5 million, or $1.58 a share, from $4.7 million, or 13 cents a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier.

title: Article 158188 -- No Title
description: Although cost-cutting measures proposed by New York City's budget office fell short of the goal in the 1984 fiscal year, the city saved $371 million on its $17 billion budget, officials said yesterday.

title: WEINBERGER AND THE PRESS: AN EBB IN THE FLOW
description: When Caspar W. Weinberger became Secretary of Defense nearly three and a half years ago, he started out with a candor in public that was refreshing to some and distressing to others.

title: 8 Killed in Philippine Battle
description: Constabulary forces raided a suspected Communist guerrilla command post in the southern Philippines on Thursday, and eight men, including a former soldier and a local town councilman, were killed in the gunbattle that followed, the official Philippines News Agency reported today.

title: Three Enter Not Guilty Pleas In Bridge Player's Kidnapping
description: Three men accused of kidnapping a wealthy, internationally known bridge player at a Washington bridge tournament last month pleaded not guilty today in Federal District Court.

title: 'Sea Monster' Captured
description: Fishermen have captured a giant white ''sea monster'' that for decades drew chilling tales among visitors to a lake just north of San Francisco. But state fish and game officers said the ''monster'' hauled out of Novato's Stafford lake Wednesday turned out to be a huge white sturgeon that they estimated had been living in the lake for 30 years. The 6-foot-5-inch, 125-pound fish, thought to be more than 50 years old, was taken to San Francisco's Steinhart Aquarium, where it is to be the largest sturgeon ever displayed there.

description: A Jewish leader yesterday charged President Reagan with ''rewriting'' the Constitution and trying to divide religious groups by his remark that politics and religion were inseparable.

title: Allis-Chalmers To Sell Credit Unit
description: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Allis-Chalmers Credit Corporation subsidiary to the Security Pacific Corporation.

title: DALLAS, DESPITE PROBLEMS, PULLS AHEAD OF HOUSTON
description: For a time it seemed that Dallas was losing the race to become the capital of the Southwest to Houston, its huge, muscular and unruly rival to the south. While Houston soared ahead in the energy boom, staid Dallas just lumbered along like the tortoise in the race with the hare.

title: OPERA: A 1762 VERSION OF 'ORFEO ED EURIDICE'
description: Gluck's 222-year-old ''Orfeo ed Euridice'' is not a rarity on the contemporary stage despite its venerable age. But an attempt to mount the opera in its original form - with period instruments, historically correct choreography and gestures, and a male alto in the role of Orfeo - is decidedly unusual. Concert Royal and the New York Baroque Dance Company collaborated in just such a performance on Thursday evening at Marymount Manhattan Theater, claiming it as the first such staging in this country.

title: SCOTLAND'S TROUBLED WHISKEY
description: Visitors are flocking in record numbers to the 209-year-old Glenturret distillery here at the southeast edge of the Highlands.

title: Global Steel Output
description: Steel production in non-Communist countries rose 11.4 percent in July from a year before, the International Iron and Steel Institute said today. The institute said the 29 countries surveyed produced 35.9 million tons in July, which accounted for 96 percent of steel production in the non-Communist world and 60 percent of world output. United States production rose 9.8 percent, to 6.8 million metric tons; Japan was up 7.9 percent, to 9.1 million tons, and the 10-nation European Economic Community showed an 18.3 percent increase, to 9.9 million tons, it said.

title: ABSENCE OF HAYNES HINDERING GIANTS
description: Another dust ball has kicked up, and, as always, the Giants are trying to continue forward as if it were not there.

title: A.T.& T. PLANNING TO CUT 11,000 JOBS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it will eliminate 11,000 management and blue-collar jobs nationwide by early next year as part of its continuing effort to cut costs.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday gave an incorrect price in some editions for an offer by Tamco Enterprises for the Home Insurance Company and Motel 6 subsidiaries of the City Investing Company. It was $1.13 billion.

title: GROUP WOULD OUST DELOREAN AS HEAD OF A UTAH COMPANY
description: The creditors of John Z. DeLorean, whose automobile company is in bankrupty, have asked a court in Detroit to remove him immediately from control of a Utah concern, the Logan Manufacturing Company.

description: Charles H. Silver, former president of New York City's Board of Education and a civic leader in the city for more than half a century, died of a stroke yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 98 years old.

description: Chile's military Government said today that the police had killed eight suspected guerrillas in a drive against terrorists.

title: G.M. Workers
description: The General Motors Corporation said it had recalled 1,000 hourly workers from indefinite layoff, beginning Monday, for jobs in its parts manufacturing operations. The company said the action reduces to 29,000 the number of hourly workers on indefinite layoff who have rehire rights. G.M. also said its Norwood, Ohio, assembly plant would be idled through Sept. 24 for model change-over, resulting in temporary layoffs for 2,700 hourly workers.

title: Late Arrival
description: From the full circle department: Six years ago next week, the Knicks signed Marvin Webster, then a free agent who had been with the Seattle SuperSonics, to a $600,000-a-year contract. As compensation for the signing, Larry O'Brien, then the National Basketball Association commissioner, awarded the Sonics Lonnie Shelton, $450,000 in cash and the Knicks' top 1979 draft choice.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $39,595. c-Net income.

description: Federal District Judge George P. Kazan sentenced a 39-year-old woman today to three years' probation for smuggling Mexican babies into the United States for adoption.

title: OPERA: CORSARO'S STAGING OF 'RIGOLETTO' REVIVED
description: The New York City Opera is billing its 1969 production of ''Rigoletto,'' which returned to the company's repertory Thursday night for the first time in two years, as ''traditional,'' clearly to contrast it with Jonathan Miller's gangster version seen recently with the English National Opera. This must be the first time in which that once-and-future enfant terrible, Frank Corsaro, has been stigmatized as traditional.

title: Spectra-Physics Settles Litigation
description: Spectra-Physics Inc. said it had reached agreements in principle that would settle all pending litigation arising from its 1983 loss of $9.4 million from unauthorized foreign-exchange transactions. Spectra-Physics said the settlement, totaling $7,150,000, would be funded by an insurance company.

title: Sohio's Outlook
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) believes ''it will be difficult for the last half of 1984 to match the first half unless petroleum products and metal prices improve more quickly than we expect,'' it said in its second-quarter report to shareholders. In the first half, profits rose 11.4 percent, to $839 million, from $753 million in the period a year earlier. Sohio, 53 percent of which is owned by the British Petroleum Company, said petroleum product inventories, especially gasoline, are high.

title: JACOBSON STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
description: b-Net income.

title: THE CITY ; ;  Libyan Admits Buying Silencers
description: A Libyan national whom Federal authorities accused of being linked to Libyan Government officials admitted in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday that he had bought three handguns with silencers from an undercover agent last May.

title: Jazz Schedule Is Changed
description: In a change from its original Greenwich Vilage Jazz Festival schedule, Seventh Avenue South is presenting Quest, the quintet featuring the saxophonist David Leibman, this weekend. The group will perform at 10 o'clock tonight and tomorrow night. The club's address is 21 Seventh Avenue South, near Downing Street; the number for information is 242-4694.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Reported Crimes Decrease in Jersey
description: Reported crimes in New Jersey in 1983 declined by 9 percent from the number in 1982, according to the State Attorney General, Irwin I. Kimmelman.

title: Fugitive of 12 Years Surrenders to the U.S.
description: A 75- year-old man has surrendered to Federal prosecutors 12 years after he walked away from a Pennsylvania prison where he was serving time for mail fraud stemming from his purchase of charters for three Maryland savings and loan associations and for contempt of court, the authorities said Thursday.

title: Pianos From Olympics Enter Collectible Game
description: The 84 pianos used in the performance of George Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue'' at the opening ceremony of the Olympics last month are making music for some memorabilia collectors.

title: Mondale Camp Returns Funds to U.S. Arabs
description: Walter F. Mondale's Presidential campaign has returned $5,000 in donations to an American Arab group because of a ''misunderstanding'' about a conference that turned into an ''anti-Semitic diatribe,'' according to a campaign official.

title: TIMBER REALIZATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Timber Realization, a limited partnership, is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about Governor Cuomo's tours of New York State misidentified the vice chairman of the Dutchess County Democratic Party. She is Fredrica Goodman.

title: BEST SELLERS: NEW AND LESS COSTLY CLOTHES
description: Two weeks ago Bloomingdale's ran an advertisement for a collection of designer clothes and, by the following day, most had been sold. Although that is not an unusual occurrence at the store, it is significant on three counts. First, the women's apparel business is in a slump this month. Second, the clothes were styled not by a well-known designer but by someone new to the fashion scene, Danny Noble. Third, and most important, the clothes were not high-priced merchandise in designer boutiques but inexpensive items in the so-called contemporary department.

title: ARCHDIOCESE IS OPPOSED TO REPLACING STRIKERS
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has asked two Catholic hospitals in Manhattan not to begin permanently replacing striking hospital workers on Monday, as threatened by the bargaining group for the struck hospitals in the city.

description: To the Editor:

title: 2 BRITONS DENY A PLAN FOR A-ARMS IN '82 WAR
description: Two admirals in charge of the Royal Navy during the Falkland war in 1982 have denied that Britain ever considered attacking Argentina with nuclear weapons, The Times of London reported today.

title: Military Contracts
description: The Raytheon Company received contracts from the Army and Air Force totaling $369.6 million for production of Patriot missiles and for spare parts for jamming systems. In addition, the Martin Marietta Corporation got $48.9 million in Air Force and Army contracts and the General Electric Company received a contract from the Air Force for $40.1 million.

title: PAZ BIRTHDAY IN MEXICO PROMPTS WEEK'S SALUTE
description: Latin America's intellectual community, which thrives on political infighting as much as on art, put aside its differences this week to celebrate the 70th birthday of one of its most renowned members, Octavio Paz.

title: Give Green Stripes a Green Light Manhattan suffers from a shortage of street- hail taxis at rush hour. In Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx it's hard to find a taxi at any hour. Residents must telephone for car service or rely on illegal gypsy cabs, often unsafe and underinsured.
description: That's where ''green-stripe'' taxis fit in. First proposed by Mayor Koch's Taxi Committee in 1982, they would, like regular yellow cabs, pick up passengers on the street and take them anywhere. But they could not serve street hails below 96th Street in Manhattan or at the airports.

title: PONDEROSA INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Aug 9

description: A watch that will display the picture of a cartoon character and, when a button is pressed, announce the time in the character's voice has been patented by Norbert M. Puff of Newport Beach, Calif. Patent 4,466,743, issued this week, displays a character from an animated cartoon pointing at the hour on a clock face.

description: A new study indicates that the stock market is more bullish after a Republican is elected President. The study, by two professors at West Virginia University, Morgantown, says that there is a ''surprisingly strong and predictable connection'' linking the Presidential election result and stock market performance.

And now, to stop the slaughter, thousands of wild burros are being rounded up in the Death Valley desert and shipped to other parts of the country to be adopted as household pets.

title: BOSTON BLACKOUT PRECEDED BY FIRES
description: An underground electrical fire that forced the Boston Edison Company to black out much of downtown Boston Thursday was preceded by a series of similar fires and smaller power failures in the same area in recent weeks, a spokesman for the private utility said today.

Tickets are $6.

It said the officers arrived Wednesday to take part in a program ''directed toward the peacekeeping role of the police'' in the Caribbean nation, a former British colony.

description: One university student was shot to death and at least four were injured, none seriously, today during clashes between police officers and rioting youths at the Autonomous University of Santo Domingo. At least 20 students were reported arrested.

title: Mr. Zaccaro's Plea Did John Zaccaro know it was wrong to mix with his own the funds entrusted to him as conservator of an estate? He says he didn't, though he had a lawyer, attended night law school and is married to a former Queens prosecutor, Geraldine Ferraro.
description: Should he have known? Obviously. It's a lame defense for the attorney he hired to help with the estate's legal problems to plead that his client was inadequately advised.

description: Heinz Gunthardt of Switzerland fought off 3 match points in the second tiebreaker to defeat Brad Gilbert, 6-4, 6-7, 7-6, today and advanced to the semifinals of the $150,000 Hamlet Challenge Cup.

title: IN NEW YORK, MILK IS GRAVEY
description: New York State residents pay far more than they should for milk because an outdated state law and practice keep a lid on competition. In fact, New York City and Long Island consumers needlessly pay some $72 million a year more for milk than they would if they bought it in northern New Jersey.

description: Bill Kenney , the Kansas City quarterback who passed for 4,348 yards last season, fractured his right thumb last night in the first half of an exhibition game with the Patriots in Foxboro, Mass. Kenney hit his thumb on a helmet and came off the field holding his hand.

title: 2 More Are Accused Of Theft of Navy Codes
description: Two more people have been charged with stealing classified Navy codes and trying to sell them to the Soviet Union. The charges bring to four the number accused in what the Federal Bureau of Investigation says was a plot that could have caused ''grave damage'' to national security.

title: METRO-NORTH FINDS CRACKED METAL UNDER ONE-THIRD OF ITS NEW CARS
description: Cracks have been found in the aluminum straps under a third of the new M-3 cars running on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, officials for the railroad said yesterday.

title: LANE WOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.N. Again to Try Mediating Afghan-Pakistani Settlement
description: The United Nations began a new attempt today to mediate a settlement between Afghanistan and Pakistan that would call for the departure of Soviet forces from Afghan territory.

title: SMUCKER, J M CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Ethiopia and Kenya To Get More U.S. Grain
description: Ethiopia and Kenya, two countries hard hit by drought, will receive additional shipments of American grain, United States officials said today.

title: GANDHI ALLY QUITS AS GOVERNOR OF STATE
description: The Governor of Andhra Pradesh, a Gandhi appointee who touched off a major political furor a week ago by dismissing the state's Chief Minister, submitted his resignation today, saying he was ''pained by the controversy.''

title: AMERICAN RESTAURANTS CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $275,000 for the quarter and $320,000 for the 6 months.

title: Textile Rule Comment
description: Local textile manufacturers and American retailers today hailed the Reagan Administration's decision to delay putting into force a tough new regulation restricting textile imports.

title: POLAND STILL HOLDS 22 WHO WERE DUO FOR AMNESTY
description: Polish authorities announced today that 22 of 652 prisoners originally listed as eligible for release were still being held on charges not affected by the Government's amnesty for political prisoners.

title: Champion Loser
description: Shiaway Moses finished out of the money last Thursday night in a trot that carried a purse of $1,800 at Saginaw Valley Downs in Michigan. It was the 117th consecutive start without a victory - a modern-day record - for the 9-year-old gelding, who is owned, driven and trained by Frank Crnkovich of South Haven, Mich.

title: BRUSSELS RESTAURATEUR
description: Marcel Kreusch, a director of La Villa Lorraine restaurant in Brussels, died Thursday at the Erasme Hospital in Anderlecht, a Brussels suburb. He was 70 years old.

title: V.F.W. ELECTS FIRST VIETNAM VETERAN
description: It was a package of nourishment from home that his Marine Corps unit in Da Nang received in 1967 that led Billy Ray Cameron to the Veterans of Foreign Wars.

title: Muggers Also Take Arm
description: A woman has lost her artificial arm because thieves yanked her purse and the $9,000 custom-made limb from her shoulder. Three men and a woman attacked Rosa Visser, a 33-year-old immigrant from El Salvador, and stole $600 worth of jewelry and $60 cash Tuesday night, the police said Thursday.

title: INTERNATIONAL RECORD CARIER reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Jersey Fire Kills 2 In Rooming House
description: A fire in a four-story rooming house here early today killed 2 people and injured 13 others, authorities said. Some of the other 150 residents jumped to the ground and onto the roof of an adjacent building.

title: ANOTHER UTILITY TO RELIEVE LILCO OF COST OF PLANT
description: The Long Island Lighting Company said yesterday that the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation would take over payment of Lilco's share of the construction expenses of the upstate Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear reactor. which Lilco defaulted on in February.

title: CITY INVESTING UNIT SALE MARKS A REPOSITIONING
description: With the City Investing Company's announcement Thursday that it had agreed to sell three of its units for $1.25 billion, the conglomerate will be effectively out of manufacturing and printing.

title: Warren Zevon Solo Shows
description: The singer-songwriter Warren Zevon will play solo shows tonight at 9 o'clock and midnight at the Bottom Line (228-7880), 15 West Fourth Street, at Mercer Street. Tickets are $10.

title: BREAK DANCING, MINUS THE CARBOARD
description: A small company in California is rushing to market with a $20 solution to a problem break dancers may not have known they had.

title: U.S. TROOPS TERMED ABLE TO FIGHT FOR 30 DAYS IN CONVENTIONAL WAR
description: The Defense Department's senior official responsible for military readiness says American forces could fight in a conventional conflict of the intensity of World War II for at least 30 days with the supplies on hand, twice as long as four years ago.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If it's not a U.F.O., I want to know exactly what it is and what it's doing around here. And I want it stopped.'' - Irene Lunn of Mahopac, N.Y. (25:5.)

title: Dow Up 4.09, to 1,236.53, As Trading Drops Off
description: Stocks gained modestly yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average registering a 4.09-point advance, as volume fell back to 69.6 million shares, from 83.13 million shares the day before.

title: JETS TOP RAIDERS TO END PRESEASON
description: The Jets made some amends for a disappointing and frustrating exhibition season tonight by defeating the reigning Super Bowl champions, the Los Angeles Raiders, 20-14, in the Los Angeles Coliseum.

title: U.S.F.L.'S FEDERALS NOT GOING TO MIAMI
description: Sherwood Weiser said today that he would not purchase the troubled Washington Federals, a decision that left Howard Schnellenberger without a job.

title: Bridge: Alert' System Breaks Down In Use of a Negative Double
description: The idea of the ''alert'' system, long firmly established in tournament play, is to advise an opponent that something unusual has happened in the bidding. He can therefore infer normality in the absence of an alert.

title: INTERMAGNETICS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
5 HURT BY BOMB IN JOHANNESBURG
description: Five people, four of them police officers, were wounded today when a bomb exploded at a building housing the Government department that oversees apartheid regulations, the authorities announced.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: -minute New York Harbor ferry crossing from Manhattan to Staten Island is traditionally accompanied by boat whistles, sometimes foghorns and always by sea gulls. This afternoon, however, one of the boats is to be used as a multistage theater for half a dozen dance companies performing in a shipboard program.

title: 2 WORLD SWIM RECORDS FALL
description: East German swimmers set two world records in one race and won four of five swimming events at the Friendship '84 Games here today.

title: Contingency Plan on Bonds
description: In an attempt to protect $6 billion in bonds invested in three nuclear plants under construction, the Washington Public Power Supply System passed a ''safety net plan'' today by agreeing to turn over to the Bonneville Power Administration the system's rights in the plants.

title: TRITON ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $140,000 for the quarter and $946,000 for the year.

title: Soviet Is Silent About Bonner Report
description: Britain asked the Soviet Union today if the Government could confirm a report that the dissident Yelena G. Bonner, wife of the physicist Andrei D. Sakharov, had been sentenced to internal exile, the Foreign Office reported.

title: Hammermill
description: The Hammermill Paper Company said it planned to spend $255 million to expand its Riverdale plant in Selma, Ala.

title: MODERATES AND CONSERVATIVES DISAGREE ON WHY G.O.P. TURNED TO THE RIGHT
description: Republican conservatives and moderates differ on why their party took a turn to the right and whether conservative domination is likely to continue into the next decade.

title: Your Money; Family Sharing Of Home Costs
description: MANY adults have helped their elderly parents pay their home mortgage expenses, and many parents have helped their children become first-time home buyers. Now both practices have been made formal by new arrangements that allow the help to be given in a business-like setting.

title: Article 158290 -- No Title
description: A jury has awarded $1.26 million to a woman who sued the Worldwide Church of God, charging that church officials had humiliated her by using the breakup of her marriage as an example of guidelines for divorce at a conference.

title: PATENTS ; G.E. Robotic Machine For Assembly Jobs
description: The General Electric Company received a patent this week for a robotic machine that is adapted to a wide variety of assembly jobs.

description: The public hearing was plodding along routinely at the Town Hall one night last month.

The Other Howe
description: Gordie Howe, a special assistant to Howard Baldwin, the chairman of the Hartford Whalers of the National Hockey League, has spent the last three days in Washington speaking at graduation exercises at the Federal Bureau of Investigation Academy. Last week, Howe, who travels thousands of miles annually on behalf of the Whalers, was in Alberta, Canada, where he helped raise more than $20,000 for the upkeep of a Ronald McDonald House, a facility for parents of children who are hospitalized for cancer treatment.

title: MAKING AN ISLAND BLOOM: ISRAELIS HELP IN JAMAICA
description: Two years ago the vast Clarendon Plain here, 35 miles west of Kingston, was covered with thick jungle and underbrush.

description: Results are based on the pooling-of- interest accounting method for the 1981 acquisition of Allen Services Corp.

title: BRITISH PORTS HIT BY NEW DOCK STRIKE
description: Three major British ports were at a standstill today after dockworkers heeded a strike call by their union. It is the second dock strike in Britain in just over a month and poses a further threat to an economy already hit by a 24-week-old strike by coal miners.

title: 2 EMBASSIES ATTACKED IN WEST BEIRUT
description: Pro- Iranian gunmen set fire to the Saudi Arabian Consulate in West Beirut today, while others launched two rocket-propelled grenades at the British Embassy, causing extensive damage. No injuries were reported.

title: No Headline
description: Infant to Receive Drug Over Mother's Protest

title: WHO SHALL GET AN ARTIFICIAL HEART?
description: To the Editor:

title: The President's Sin President Reagan's prayer breakfast speech in Dallas was a self-righteous assault on those who disagree with his dangerous, divisive mixing of religion and politics. Not content to debate the merits of difficult issues like school prayer and abortion, he professed to know the hearts and minds of his opponents, and he found them evil. Mr. Reagan has exceeded the bounds of tolerable debate.
description: He began innocently enough with the truism that faith and religion figure prominently in American political history. But before he was through, he was claiming God for only his side and proclaiming the ''real truth'' that his adversaries are ''intolerant'' of religion and care only for the state.

title: MILLICOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE REGION ; ;  StamfordCityHall Termed a Firetrap
description: City Hall is the worst firetrap in the city and would ''burn like crazy'' if a blaze were to start, according to the city's chief fire marshal,

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: 10 Brooklyn Tours

title: Bid Is Increased For Motel Chain ;  By Reuters
description: Prime Motor Inns Inc. said it intended to raise its tender offer for American Motor Inns Inc. to $21.50 a share, from $19.50. Prime said it would offer the higher price subject to its original conditions and contingent on American Motor Inns' rescinding an option it has proposed granting to a subsidiary of the Americana Hotels Corporation.

title: SATURDAY, AUGUST 25, 1984 International
description: A cease-fire agreement in Colombia was signed by the Government with one of the country's principal leftist guerrilla groups. The agreement with the April 19 movement, also known as M-19, followed a similar accord Thursday with two smaller rebels groups and with the powerful Colombian Revolutionary Armed Forces last March. Colombia is the first Latin American country to have successfully negotiated an armistice with leftist guerrilla movements. (Page 1, Column 4.) A Gandhi appointee resigned as Governor of Andhra Pradesh State, saying he was ''pained by the controversy'' over his dismissal a week ago of the state's Chief Minister, who was an opponent of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. (3:4.)

title: G.O.P STRATEGISTS SEEK TO COUNTERACT EUPHORIA
description: President Reagan's top campaign strategists moved quickly today to dispel some of the euphoria of this week's convention and prepare Republicans for what they say will be a tough campaign this fall.

title: Miami Couple ChargedWith Abusing Children
description: A convicted child molester and his wife were in jail without bond today on charges that they had sexually abused children kept in their $150,000 suburban home through an unlicensed baby-sitting service.

title: YOUTHS CHARGED WITH A SLAYING IN CENTRAL PARK
description: Three youths, one of them 12 years old, were charged yesterday with murdering a homeless woman whose body was found a month ago at the Conservatory Water model-boat house in Central Park, the police said.

title: FILM: 'OXFORD BLUES' OPENS
description: If midtown seems suddenly aswarm with figures bent under an invisible weight, they may be moviegoers taxed by the burden of credulity imposed by ''Oxford Blues,'' which opened yesterday at the Embassy and other theaters.

title: BRAINTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because at the time the company was still in the development stage. Net loss figure represents net expenses.

title: FIRM CITING C.I.A. LINK IS CHARGED
description: The head of a Hawaiian investment firm, who contends that his firm was financed by the Central Intelligence Agency, was accused today by the Securities and Exchange Commission of engaging in a wide-ranging securities fraud.

title: NATIONAL PARAGON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $43,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $757,000, or 21 cents a share, for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $162,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $164,000, or 5 cents a share, for the year.

title: LEWIS, PALMER G CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 25
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect the 4 percent stock dividend distributed in September 1983. Shares outstanding in 1984 reflect the 747,732 shares issued in conjunction with the acquisition of Sea-Pac Sales Co.

title: Dome Suit Award Protested
description: Erie County today asked a state judge to overturn a multimillion-dollar jury award to a businessman for profits he claimed he lost after the county backed out of a 1969 agreement to build a domed stadium.

title: BLACKS PICKET STORE IN BOYCOTT OF BIG SUPERMARKET CHAIN IN SOUTH
description: Calling for a three-day demonstration, members of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People have set up picket lines in several Southern cities, urging shoppers to boycott stores operated by one of the region's largest supermarket chains.

title: ABBOUND OUT AS OCCIDENTAL PRESIDENT
description: Armand Hammer, the autocratic chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, has forced out yet another president of the company because of differences between the two.

title: Twain Book Not Required
description: School officials have removed ''The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'' from a required reading list after an alderman complained the book was offensive to blacks. Alderman Robert Evans Sr. had threatened a lawsuit or student boycott if Mark Twain's novel about a boy and a runaway slave was not taken off the list. The decision to drop the book came Wednesday at a meeting between a school board committee and Mr. Evans, who objected to the book's use of the word ''nigger.''

title: ALLIED SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income which includes a tax credit of $307,000 for the quarter and and a tax credit plus a credit from the termination of a pension plan totaling $11,729,000 for the year. The company is listed on the Philadelphia, Boston, and Pacific stock exchanges.

title: Manatt Sees Reagan Age As Factor in Campaign
description: Charles T. Manatt, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today that Ronald Reagan's age of 73 was ''on the minds of the American public'' and suggested that the President's joke about bombing Russia would remind people of it.

title: Offer for Tripucka
description: Kelly Tripucka , the Detroit Pistons' 6-foot-6-inch free-agent forward, has signed a multiyear offer sheet with the Cleveland Cavaliers that would reportedly pay him more than $700,000 a season. The Pistons have 15 days to match the offer or lose the 25- year-old Notre Dame graduate, who last season averaged 21.3 points in 76 games.

title: MANAGER OF FAULTED MISSILE PLANT IS REPLACED
description: The Hughes Aircraft Corporation, hoping to stave off a Government halt in payments for faulty missiles, announced late today that it would replace a key manager in the manufacturing division of its trouble-plagued plant in Tucson, Ariz.

title: Injury Sidelines Coe
description: Sebastian Coe , who won two successive Olympic gold medals in the 1,500- meter run, has withdrawn from the European track season because of an injury to his left foot, according to a close friend. The 28-year-old Coe, who had the foot strapped for a race in Zurich this week, had already withdrawn from meets in Cologne and Rome next week, and, according to his friend, Res Bruger , he will also miss the rest of the European season.

title: DUCKWALL-ALCO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
Gas Supplier Loses Case
description: The United Gas Pipeline Company was found guilty today of breach of contract and was ordered by a state judge to repay to utilities $84.7 million in fuel-adjustment costs that were passed on to consumers.

PATENTS;
A SHIRT TO RESIST BULLETS
description: -proff dress shirt is being manufactured and sold by Progressive Apparel Inc., in Fairfax, Va. Patent 4,466,135 was granted for the shirt this week to Edward A. Coppage Jr., president of the company.

title: PERU DISPERSES A RIGHTS RALLY
description: Riot policemen fired tear gas and water cannon today at hundreds of demonstrators massing to protest human rights abuses attributed to Government troops pursuing Maoist guerrillas in the country's Andes region.

description: The 73-year-old leader of one of this French-ruled island's two powerful clans was elected president of the 61- seat Regional Assembly today in the third round of voting.

description: A leading Iranian politician today blamed ''terrorist leaders living under French support'' for a bomb explosion that killed 18 people in Teheran Thursday, and he said France was ''a party in this crime.''

description: Ellis Island was never fun. Must it now be turned into a second South Street Seaport?

title: African Music in Brooklyn
description: ''Celebrate Brooklyn'' (768-0699) is presenting African music free this weekend at the Prospect Park bandshell, Ninth Street and Prospect Park West. Tonight, the African Connection will play juju, Afro-beat and Congolese rock, on a double bill with Indigo Drum and Spirit. Tomorrow, Djimo Kouyate, the Senegalese kora (harp) player and griot (troubadour), will share a double bill with the drummer Olatunji and his group. All concerts begin at 8 P.M.

Duke of Chevy Chase, was married to Robert Farrington Reach, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Reach of Ridgefield, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David Rider, assisted by the Rev. title: Policing Problem
description: Walter Byers, the executive vice president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, said violations of recruiting and financial aid rules in college sports are becoming so widespread the N.C.A.A. is having trouble clamping down on all the offenders. ''I believe there is a growing acceptance of the belief that the conditions of intercollegiate athletics are such that you have to cut corners, you have to circumvent the rules,'' Byers said. Byers said there may be significant violations in as many as 30 percent of all upper-division programs at colleges.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES ;  Broadcast TV
description: Monday night at 9, Channel 13 will present a retrospective look at the life and career of the late Arthur Fiedler, who conducted the Boston Pops for some 50 years. ''Fiedler's Greatest Hits,'' as this nostalgic celebration has been christened, combines interviews with footage of both maestro and orchestra, captured in performance both in the concert hall, and on the Charles River Esplanade.

title: Williams's Options
description: Doug Williams , the quarterback of the Oklahoma Outlaws, says the United States Football League team may be headed for California, but he isn't ready to leave yet.

title:
ART ;
SCULPTURE SHOW IN A GARDEN COURT
description: THERE are times when a potpourri exhibition is welcome. It can give the sensation of being in touch with general trends, and it can also help to clarify current personal inclinations. Art styles evolve constantly, and so do the preferences of gallery visitors.

title: THE REGION ; A New Lease forBattery Park City
description: To the relief of New York City officials, Merrill Lynch & Company has decided to go west, but only as far as the Hudson River. Officials of the world's largest brokerage company signed a contract last week to move their corporate headquarters into two towers in Battery Park City.

title: YANKEES WIN, 14-1 ON 23 HITS
description: Perhaps it was punishment for the Mariners' unavoidable mediocrity. Perhaps it was the Yankees frustration at having found their groove too late to make a pennant run.

title: THE WORLD ; Syria's TroublesIn Lebanon
description: Syria, which maneuvered so adroitly to replace the United States and Israel as the arbiter of peace in Lebanon, may well have wondered last week if it was worth the effort. Fighting outside Beirut and in the northern port of Tripoli attested to the Lebanese Government's ineffectiveness in extending its authority beyond Beirut and in getting the country's many factions to replace fratricide with cooperation.

title: South Africa Train-Bus Crash
description: A freight train rammed into a bus at a crossing near this northern town Friday night, killing 2 people and injuring 75, the police said today. Ten of those injured in the bus, which was ferrying black workers from Pietersburg, were in serious condition, a hospital spokesman said.

title: ZACCARO MAY HAVE PAID TOO MUCH IN '80 TAXES
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro indicated today that her husband, John A. Zacarro, may have overpaid his income taxes on his 1980 return.

description: Steve Knoll frequently reports on developments in cable.

title: TODAY'S PARTY CONVENTIONS STAND MOSTLY ON CEREMONY
description: -seasoned politician-watcher and dogged televiewer of last week's Republican National Convention in Dallas was compelled to conclude, late Thursday evening, that one underlying question had been posed by the exercise. It was: ''What were all those people doing there?''

description: A NEW system of child care is being developed in New Jersey in response to growing problems of child abuse, and the case of a mother long at odds with the state's Division of Youth and Family Services has been chosen to test its validity.

title: EL SALVADOR'S MILITARY TRYING TO WIN PEASANTS AND BATTLES
description: The colonel and the peasant stared into the dark, listening to the murmur of soldiers settling into bivouac. A soldier had toppled a hen from a tree branch with a slingshot, and the officer and farmer were waiting for their chicken dinner.

title: ARBITRATORS TESTED TO AVOID TRIALS
description: Morris County residents will be able to submit claims in many consumer and civil disputes to voluntary arbitrators instead of courts under an experimental program beginning next month, officials said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL WON BY LUTIN D'ISIGNY
description: Lutin d'Isigny, a 7-year-old horse and the lesser known of the two French entrants, won the $250,000 Roosevelt International Trot tonight in the world record time of 2:30 for a mile and a quarter on Roosevelt Raceway's half- mile track.

title: Diann H. Kim Is Wed to John B. Frank
description: Diann Hyung Kim, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Young Song Kim of Calabasas, Calif., was married yesterday to John Bernkopf Frank, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard A. Frank of Brookline, Mass. The Rev. Roger L. Dunnavan, the bride's uncle, performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Harvard Memorial Church in Cambridge, Mass.

title: S. B. Penick 4th Weds Anne Hog g
description: At the First Presbyterian Church of Ardmore, Pa., yesterday Anne Rutledge Hogg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Renwick Hogg of Haverford, Pa., was married to Sydnor Barksdale Penick 4th, the son of Mrs. Penick 3d of Princeton, N.J., and Pointe au Baril, Ontario, and the late Dr. Penick. The ceremony was performed by the bride's uncle, the Rev. Charles E. Carson.

Amory Jr. of Beverly, Mass., was married to Robert Arthur Bachelder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richmond W. Bachelder of Weston, Mass. The Rev. Harry Hoehler, assisted by the Rev. Robert Bryan, performed the ceremony.

title: A SHORT SWIM THAT WAS NEARLY THE LAST
description: I CAN'T say that my life flashed before my eyes. It didn't. Nothing nearly as dramatic. In fact, the only things I do remember feeling are utter exhaustion, complete panic, and, as an afterthought, total humiliation.

title: MEN AND WOMEN IN FILM: A WAR ZONE UPDATE
description: It's been a long while since Hollywood abandoned its traditional model for relations between the sexes: the boy-meets-girl, boy-loses-girl, boy-gets-girl romance, followed by a middle-aged period devoted, happily or otherwise, to intense domesticity. It's even been a while since, in the early 70's, changing perceptions of men's and women's societal roles left Hollywood increasingly unable to deal with romantic relationships at all. Hollywood's bewilderment in a period of vigorous social change brought about movies in which the lovers never quite fell in love, or the kinds of working-woman stories in which Jane Fonda (as she did in ''The China Syndrome'') came home alone to a pet turtle and an answering machine. The silence on the subject of sexual relations has been prolonged and uneasy. But it now appears to be drawing to a close.

title: 2 GERMANYS AT ODDS OVER LEADER'S VISIT
description: East Germany today accused ''certain forces'' in Bonn of trying to sabotage a visit to West Germany next month by Erich Honecker, the East German Communist Party leader.
