title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: The Quality Is High, The Price Otherwise Countess Mara's Factory Outlet is in Highland, across the Hudson River from Poughkeepsie in Ulster County about 60 miles north and west of White Plains. The outlet provides half-price, first-quality merchandise from its licensees, some of it discontinued lines, and sells its own monogrammed ties at 70 percent off as ''seconds,'' although some are ends of four-color runs and actually without any imperfection and others have imperceptible flaws.

title: REPUBLICANS CITE TREND FOR PARTY
description: Republican campaign strategists say their latest polling data show a favorable nationwide trend toward their party for Congressional races that raises the potential of significant gains in the House of Representatives this fall.

title: FARM SURPLUS GROWS AS ELECTION ISSUE
description: Willard Severns, a corn and soybean farmer for most of his 53 years, hunched over his field of 2 1/2-foot-tall soybean plants, looking for lingering traces of moisture in the soil.

title: ILLUMINATING ACCESSORIES
description: Fashion always symbolically preserves a dialectic of the sexes. Therefore, to insure the straightforwardly glamorous appeal of clothes inspired by men's wear and to keep at a distance any touch of the silly or the scandalous, they are worn most effectively with traditional female adornments. The straight shapes of coats and pants in wool acquire an emotional dimension from the attendant flow of silk scarfs and the gleam of occasional jewels. Such effects have enhanced the beauty of women since antiquity, and they carry an enormous cumulative sexual charge.

title: John Kelly, 88, Retired Head Of Connecticut State Police
description: John C. Kelly, a retired State Police Commissioner who had been promoted through every rank in the department, died Wednesday in Danbury Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Ridgefield.

title: MONDALE CONFERS WITH 15 GOVERNORS TO SEEK SUPPORT
description: Seeking to solidify support behind his underdog candidacy, Walter F. Mondale today conferred with 15 Democratic governors and set a meeting for Tuesday with the Rev. Jesse Jackson and other black leaders.

title: A SOUND RETREAT
description: While the Hamptons on Long Island's South Fork have long been known as chic summer retreats, vacationers are becoming more familiar with the pleasures of the villages along the North Fork on Long Island Sound. To meet what it sees as a growing demand for vacation housing there, a development group is building Stirling Cove, a 48-unit condominium colony on a 5-acre site on Stirling Harbor in Greenport.

title: Paper Suspends Publication In Labor Dispute in Montreal
description: The Montreal Gazette locked out members of two unions and suspended publication today for the first time in its 206- year history, claiming union negotiators were threatening to ''pull the plug'' on the paper.

title: HOW BOTH SIDES CAN WIN
description: THE EVOLUTION OF COOPERATION

title: THE ENIRONMENT
description: AN extensive study of Barnegat Bay has found that the destruction of salt marshes, bulkheading and pollutants from sewage and other sources have brought about a steady decline in water quality.

title: THE NATION ; Postal Unions
description: A walkout by United States Postal Service workers would be illegal, and Postmaster General William F. Bolger has promised to dismiss any of his employees who participate. Nonetheless, in separate conventions in Las Vegas last week, delegates representing the 300,000-member American Postal Workers Union and the 200,000-member National Association of Letter Carriers gave their leaders the authority to call a strike.

title: PLOTLESS DANCE-DRAMA THAT DEALS IN EMOTIONS
description: An increasing number of choreographers are creating works that attempt to present dramatic situations in a nonliteral manner. These works lack conventional narratives and yet are charged with such intense emotional conflicts that they cannot be categorized as ''abstract.''

title: WHAT'S ON BABIES' MINDS WHEN THEY COME INTO THE WORLD
description: Babies may know far more than they are telling. Recent research shows they are aware of some forms of stimulation while still in the womb. This news, the result of rapid expansion in the field of infant cognitive studies, has wide ramifications. Expectant parents who will be making goo-goo noises and silly faces at their baby once it's born have been observed somberly reading Tennyson and playing classical music to the bulge under the maternity dress, perhaps believing that they can nurture another Mozart, who was a musical prodigy at three, or a John Stuart Mill, who read Greek while learning to walk. At the very least, many parents feel, they will be giving their child-to-be a head start in life. Science fictions concerning learning in the womb now seem to be as prevalent as scientific facts and need to be sorted out.

title: 2 SHIPS COLLIDE NEAR BELGIUM
description: A Dutch ferry carrying more than 1,000 people collided with a French cargo ship 12 miles off the Belgian coast today, and the French ship sank after the two were separated, officials said. No one was reported injured.

title: LETTERS ; ; Competition
description: To the Editor:

title: A FIRST FOR THE IRISH
description: Spurred by the growth in the American economy and the recession in Europe, an Irish development company has entered the real-estate market in this country with a $10 million condominium project in Westchester County.

title: SORREL'S SWEET SOURNESS
description: IN MY YEARS AS A FOOD writer, I have witnessed a remarkable broadening of taste in the American palate, especially when it comes to herbs. When I first began my career, basil was an all but unknown quantity in this country, and then along came pesto sauce. Shallots, fresh thyme and tarragon once seemed almost too ''fancy'' for native taste. Today, of course, it is not at all uncommon to see fresh coriander leaves and the excellent Italian green known as arugula in markets that deal in fresh produce.

title: 4 FUNGI-FILLED DAYS LURE FORAGERS TO PINE BARRENS
description: GLASSBORO

title: SOCCER TALKS ARE TERMINATED
description: The on-again, off-again agreement between the Major Indoor Soccer League and four North American Soccer League teams that would have the clubs play indoor in the M.I.S.L. this winter was declared ''definitely off'' by the commissioner of the indoor league yesterday.

title:
ANTIQUES;
MIGHTIER THAN THE SWORD
description: OCEAN OBJECTS once useful and decorative have an attraction as collectibles, and one such groups of objects - fountain pens - appears to be on the verge of resurgence.

title: VIEWS OF A CULTURE HEROINE
description: WITH A DAUGHTER'S EYE A Memoir of Margaret Mead and Gregory Bateson. By Mary Catherine Bateson. Illustrated. 242 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $15.95.

title: BRENLY STARS AGAIN
description: In the first 127 days of the season, through Aug. 6, the Mets either were in first place or were within two games of first for all but 16 days. In the 19 days since Aug. 6, though, they have been more than two games out 18 days. In other words, the Mets have picked the worst time of the season to have their worst time of the season.

title: CRITICS SHOULD 'CLOSE THEIR MOUTHS,' REAGAN SAYS
description: President Reagan used his weekly radio address today to challenge Congressional Democrats to ''close their mouths forever about budget deficits'' unless they give the President new authority to cut spending.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
description: SANDY HOOK FESTIVAL

title: Strike Shuts 19 British Ports; Dover Terminal Is Still Open
description: A strike by dockworkers paralyzed 19 British ports today. The nation's largest passenger port, at Dover, remained open.

title: PARIS STREET CHIC
description: :By the end of the summer season, the makers of the wrinkled cotton jump suits that have become a way of summer dressing in Paris expect to have sold one million of them, at an average price in France of $50.

title: NEW DEMANDS STALL ATLANTIC CITY RAIL PROJECT
description: New financial demands from city, county and state agencies have raised doubts about whether Resorts International will go forward with plans to restore rail service to Atlantic City.

description: Jersey Crime

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
FIRE-SAFTETY REQUIRES EDUCATION
description: NEW JERSEY is on the threshold of a new and exciting era in fire safety. In just a few short months the long-awaited state fire-prevention code will be in place and functioning.

title: SHELTER I. QUAKERS MARK AN ANNIVERSARY
description: SHELTER ISLAND'S Quaker community today will mark the 100th anniversary of a monument honoring Nathaniel Sylvester, the island's first white settler, and the 17th-century Quakers whom he sheltered from religious persecution.

title: No Headline
description: Janet McCabe Is a Bride

title: Heroism Award Presented
description: Timothy Hampson, who fought off a shark that attacked his fiancee on a skin-diving trip in the Florida Keys last year, has received the Coast Guard's highest civilian heroism award. The 23- year-old Mr. Hampson accepted the Gold Lifesaving Medal with tears in his eyes Thursday, the 650th person to receive the medal since it was established by Congress in 1974. The medal citation praised him ''for extreme and heroic daring'' in saving 22-year-old Jackie Lynn, who had suffered a ''massive'' leg wound from the shark's bit.

title: The Region ; Lilco Plugs Into
description: A Money Grid

title: Sentence From Judge: Let Them Eat Free
description: A Federal judge has ordered that two restaurant partners who pleaded guilty to charges of income tax evasion provide free meals for one year to a charitable organization.

title: Columbia Comes Home Again
description: Bob Naso, the Columbia football coach, sounded relieved. ''It will be nice to have a home crowd again,'' he said.

title: How to Talk 'Texian'
description: Robert Reinhold's contribution to On Language, ''How to Talk 'Texian' '' (July 22), was a reminder of my own adjustment to a new dialect several years ago. Mr. Reinhold used Jim Hightower, state agriculture commissioner, as an example of a linguistically inventive politico, and I thought New York readers might appreciate Mr. Hightower's latest Texian pronouncement.

title: Data Bank;  August 26, 1984
LETTERS
description: DEFENSE DOLLARS AREN'T FOR SHARING ALIKE

title: New & Noteworthy
description: HISTORY: A NOVEL, by Elsa Morante. (Aventura/ Vintage, $8.95.) Our reviewer, Robert Alter, wrote that ''History'' ''has a good many arresting moments.'' He said, ''There is a peculiar Dostoyevskian visionary quality in (Elsa) Morante's writing that occasionally illuminates her somber Naturalistic landscape. At a number of crucial junctures she manages to carry out wonderful forays into the uncanny, moving from bleak earthbound things to metaphysical vistas.'' The characters in this 1977 novel are ''downtrodden and . . . oppressed,'' and the setting is akin to that of Italian postwar neorealist films. A MOVING TARGET, by William Golding. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $7.95.) William Golding won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1983. When his nonfiction collec-tion ''A Moving Target'' was published in 1982, our reviewer, Jan Morris, felt no ''rush of grace or vision as Mr. Golding passes by,'' but she allowed that the best pieces were about writing novels. ''The care and balance of his craft - the demands of artistry and readability, the matter of theme, the interaction of thought and feeling - all are delicately and thrillingly explored and ought to make the book essential reading for less articulate writers in residence or associate professors.''

title: SANDINISTAS MAY WIN BIG IN ELECTIONS, BUT AGAINST WHOM?

description: Common Cause said today that there was ''no justification whatsoever'' for the White House to charge taxpayers for President Reagan's trip to Chicago Friday and urged that he reconsider the decision.

Gerry Cooney's scheduled Sept. 29 return to boxing will be in Anchorage, Alaska, against Phillip Brown, according to an Anchorage promoter, Bill McConkey .

description: Elizabeth Catherine Gardella and John David O'Connor were married yesterday at St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in East Norwalk, Conn., by the Rev. John T. O'Connor, the bridegroom's uncle. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Gardella and her husband is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jeremiah A. O'Connor.

description: A strategy session of about 15 black political leaders in the South, an outgrowth of frustration at the slowness of the Democratic Presidential campaign in organizing itself, turned into a strong show of support.

description: Government officials said this week that Thailand intends to make a strong bid for a seat on the United Nations Security Council this fall.

description: The marriage of Jane Marian Schmeiser, a corporate planner with the First National Bank of Chicago, to Andrew Charles Power, a management consultant for McKinsey & Company in Chicago, took place yesterday in Pittsburgh. Mayor Richard S. Caliguiri of Pittsburgh performed the ceremony at the Concordia Club.

description: The Federal authorities investigated 863 nationwide incidents of tampering with Girl Scout cookies this year, a newspaper has reported.

title: PUFFING UP DEFLATION
description: Inflation, as we have been told a thousand times, is the cruelest tax of all. Inflation, goes the political-economic cliche, steals your savings and hits hardest at the poor. Inflation is a word to be said with a frown; the only time a smile is permitted is when inflation is down.

description: For years Lucille P. Markey, owner of Kentucky's famed Calumet Farm racing stables, listened to critics complaining that her thoroughbreds won too much and too often, and she typically retorted, ''I give to charity but not at the track.''

title: Lendl, Gomez Advance To Final
description: Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia, admitting that he cannot play much better than he did in today's 22-minute opening set, advanced to the final of the $150,000 Hamlet Challenge Cup at the expense of Jimmy Arias, pro of the host club, 6-0, 7-6.

title: Soviet Reported to Bar Papal Visit to Lithuania
description: The Vatican said today that Pope John Paul II was refused permission to visit the Soviet republic of Lithuania this month for a religious celebration.

title: Carol A. Connolly Weds B.K. Bruce
description: Carol Ann Connolly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Connolly of Rye, N.Y., was married at the Home Moravian Church in Winston-Salem, N.C., yesterday to Branson Key Bruce, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Luther C. Bruce Jr. of Raleigh, N.C. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. D. Wayne Burkette, assisted by the Rev. Anthony Kovacic, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: A TOAST TO THE TOE SHOE
description: Toasts were once drunk from them to honor reigning ballerinas. Ground glass poured into them could put a rival at least temporarily out of commission. They helped to define the spirit of Romanticism in the ballet. They are often the object of almost fetishistic attention. And classical ballet seems faintly cloddish today unless there are toe shoes somewhere evident on stage.

title: Emily Greenspan Wed To Howard Kelting Jr.
description: Emily A. Greenspan, the daughter of Taube Greenspan of Stamford, Conn., and the late Charles M. Greenspan, was married yesterday to Howard W. Kelting Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kelting of Brooklyn. The Rev. Theodore Smith performed the Unitarian ceremony at Caramoor, the art and music center in Katonah, N.Y., of which the bride's mother is the museum director.

title: Translating Humor
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CITY'S NEW ENDURANCE TEST
description: After more than two hours of swimming, biking and running through and around Manhattan yesterday, Mark Allen of San Diego, and Scott Molina of Del Mar, Calif., who was making his first visit to the city, decided to have a chat. The two were near the finish line of the first New York Triathlon, a grueling three-stage race that included a 1.9-mile swim in upper New York Bay, a 21.3-mile bicycle excursion on the West Side Highway and the Henry Hudson Parkway and a 7.4-mile run through a picturesque Central Park on a bright and breezy morning. They were running side-by-side.

title: L.I. FAMILIES FEAR FUMES OF LEAKING GASOLINE
description: Along Bluebell Lane, it has been a summer of concern over the hazards of gasoline fumes.

description: Image- conscious Dallas was hot, efficient, peaceful and friendly. But President Reagan's son Ron says he liked San Francisco better.

title: TAKING LUMPS AT WRESTLER SCHOOL
description: Georgianna Passariello, a diminutive former beautician whose voice barely rises above a whisper, surrounds herself with 250-pound men who like nothing better than to throw each other through the air.

title: PACE U., CHANGING PRESIDENTS, TO FOLLOW A BUSINESS MODEL
description: When Dr. Edward J. Mortola steps down as president of Pace University at the end of the month, he will step up to the job of chancellor, clearing the way for Dr. William G. Sharwell to succeed him as president and creating an unusual dual leadership.

description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

description: Forty-six more upstate local property-tax assessors were dismissed this week by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment for failing to take a required training course.

title: PARIS CELEBRATES 40 YEARS OF FREEDOM
description: Thousands of Parisians today commemorated the 40th anniversary of the liberation of their city from four years of German occupation.

title: The Arms Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Landfills and Sewer District: A Case of Chauvinism?
description: The articles ''Efforts to Meet Landfill Deadline Lag'' and ''Sewer District Hookup: When?'' (Aug. 5) call attention to some very serious political hangups that are obstructing progress in these areas. Unfortunately, these hangups are unique neither to the geographical area, the particular problems or any one political party.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
WHEN A 68-YEAR-OLD MOTHER RETURNS TO THE DATING SCENE
description: WHEN my mother revealed three years ago that she was dating, I did not know how to react. Just when I thought I had it all together at 31 years of age, the revelation threw me a bit off balance.

title: 5 HIT BY AUTO NEAR TIMES SQ. REPORTED IN CRITICAL CONDITION
description: Five people were in critical condition yesterday after being struck by a car that plowed through a crowded intersection near Times Square late Friday night.

title: COLOMBIA HOLDING U.S. REPORTER
description: An American journalist who has been held in a Colombian jail for the last six weeks on drug charges says he was ''set up'' while doing research for an article on the narcotics traffic here.

title: COLLEAGUE CRITICAL OF SOTHEBY SELLER
description: The president of Hebrew Union College has said he is upset that a colleague, Dr. Alexander Guttmann, consigned rare books and manuscripts smuggled out of Nazi Germany to an auction house.

title: TOPLESS BATHER ARRESTED IN CAPE COD PROTEST
description: A longstanding controversy over nudity on Cape Cod National Seashore beaches has flared anew with the arrest of a woman who was sunbathing topless in a challenge to a Federal regulation prohibiting nude bathing.

title: THE UNTOLD STORY OF THE LODZ GHETTO
description: I was born and raised in the city of Lodz. We do have a unique legacy to hand down to Jew and non-Jew alike.

title: ISRAELIS PLAY CATCH-UP BUT INFLATION RUNS FASTER
description: ''You want to know what inflation means? It means my 12-year-old daughter coming to me a few days ago and asking if we could do some Hanukkah shopping,'' a former Israeli official said last week. ''She said, 'Because of the inflation, I don't want to get stuck.' So we went shopping,'' he said. It was about four months ahead of time.

title: FEAR IS LOTS OF MONEY
description: The rash of takeovers in recent months has spread anxiety in corporate boardrooms. Some financiers have now found a seemingly foolproof way to turn those fears into cash.

title: Pincay Scores With Adored
description: Adored, a daughter of Seattle Slew, staked a strong claim to the leadership of the nation's handicap fillies and mares with an easy 3 1/4- length triumph in the Delaware Handicap today at Saratoga Race Track.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: A MAVERICK OUT OF EXILE
description: DALLAS For Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the Republican National Convention last week was ''a return from exile,'' he said. The Senator, a career maverick, was not even a delegate at the last two conventions largely because of the residual Republican hostility stemming from his role in the Senate Watergate hearings as the Republican who was the sharpest critic of President Nixon and interrogator of Mr. Nixon's White House and campaign aides.

title: THE NATION ; The Case That
description: Won't Go Away

title: VACCINE IS ELUSIVE WEAPON IN NEW WAR ON MALARIA
description: As medical scientists announce new strides toward developing a vaccine against malaria, public health experts are reminding them that victory over malaria is less easily achieved than laboratory breakthroughs. The control of this parasitic disease is hampered not only by its complicated life cycle, but by formidable political, social and economic barriers.

title: THE SUDDEN FAME OF WILLIAM KENNEDY
description: AS HE SITS IN HIS STUDY in the countryside near Albany, William Kennedy is surrounded by photographs: William Faulkner, Samuel Beckett, Robert Penn Warren and Saul Bellow on one hand, and Louis Armstrong, Frank Sinatra and Mae West on the other. This eclectic array of heroes is indicative of Kennedy's personality: the serious novelist who reveres literature and the ebullient Irishman who enjoys pop music, movies and American mythic figures such as Sinatra, whose recording of ''New York, New York'' filters in from another room. That Kennedy - winner this year of a Pulitzer Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award for his novel ''Ironweed,'' which evokes the psychic life of an alcoholic bum - is fascinated by, and apparently lives in, many contradictory worlds may be a source of his imaginative powers.

title: STYLISH STATEMENTS
description: Reports of European exaggeration, when it comes to clothes for fall, are by no means exaggerated. Big is better. The continent's leading designers have taken classically shaped garments - trench coats, overcoats, balmacaans, bathrobes - and have magnified their details, whether it be epaulet, collar or lapel. It is a season of broad shoulders. Oversize coats are worn over man-tailored suits and pants that play up fabric and pattern mixes, frequently gabardine, cashmere, plaids and stripes.

title:
DINING OUT;
GALLIC FARE IN WHITE PLAINS
description: PASCAL'S understated beauty will impress even the jaded, from the curving walls upholstered in a rich burgundy floral pattern and French doors of the front dining room to the sleek inner room illuminating in the halo of pure light a magnificent arrangement of lilies, roses and other summer blooms echoed singly in black ceramic vases on every tabletop. On beige suede walls, caricatures by Sem recall La Belle Epoque and add Gallic interest.

title: 87-YARD PASS PLAY LIFTS GIANTS, 16-9
description: A torturous preseason ended on a festive tone for the Giants tonight when Byron Williams, a wide receiver in a fight for a job, scored on an 87-yard play with just 1 minute 45 seconds left in the game.

title: Crew of Stranded Ship Seeking Aid on Coast
description: A freighter owned by a Taiwanese concern that is apparently bankrupt has been anchored off the California coast for nearly a month, and its crew of 25 to 30 men is nearly out of food and fuel, the Coast Guard says.

title: MEDICARE LIMITS MAKE HOSPITALS CAREFUL ON COSTS
description: A new Medicare payment system has profoundly altered the way hospitals do business, making them more efficient and cost-conscious, apparently without damaging the quality of health care.

title: PUTTING GOD BACK IN POLITICS
description: THE NAKED PUBLIC SQUARE

title: MAINE'S MISTY KINGDOMS
description: DAVID YEADON is the author of several travel books, including the newly published ''Secluded Islands of the Atlantic Coast.''

title: POLITICS, IN PUBLIC ; UNCONVENTINAL PINS To some people, the Republican convention in Dallas was as interesting for its pins as its politics. Not the usual tin pins that used to eagerly spread such messages as ''Win With Willkie'' or ''I Like Ike.'' Those are rarer now that their cost counts against Federal spending limits; most candidates prefer to save the money for TV. The new lapel pins are more elaborate, on the order of the small silver shoes with a hole in the sole once worn by Adlai Stevenson fans or the PT-109 tie clips favored by Kennedy partisans. There's another difference between the new pins and the old buttons. More than convey the sentiments of their wearers, the new pins reflect a collector's mentality. Theyre the currency of eager trading.
description: Trading such pins is an old Russian custom, and a student trader from Aurora College in Illinois thinks the craze was brought to America at the Lake Placid Winter Olympics in 1980, when athletes exchanged national pins. He wore a multicolored example bearing the Illinois state seal.

title: CARING FOR MAN-TAILORED CLOTHES
description: Alan Flusser is a men's-wear designer and an author. His new book, ''Dressing the American Way,'' will be published by Random House in the fall of 1985.

title: Santana on Disabled List
description: Rafael Santana, whose right thumb was spiked when he tried to steal Friday night, was placed on the 15-day disabled list. Ron Gardenhire, who went on the 15-day list Friday night with a hamstring injury, was moved to the 21-day list. Santana's thumb needed three stitches. . . . To fill the shortstop gap, the Mets recalled Jose Oquendo from Tidewater, where he batted .159 in 38 games after being optioned there July 11.

title: McCANN RETAINS OPTIONS ON PRESIDENCY
description: TRENTON WHEN Ronald Reagan carried New Jersey four years ago on his way to winning the Presidency, he lost Hudson County by less than 5,000 votes, which qualified as a resounding victory for a Republican in anyone's book.

title: ALL THOSE GRADES OF BLANK TAPE ARE NEARLY ALIKE-OR ARE THEY?
description: The makers of blank video cassettes have lately been offering their wares in different grades of quality. Most brands are now available in standard and premium versions, with the latter touted for their superior performance.

title: MASCOT TRAINS TO LEAD YALE
description: Hidden from his fans, the new Yale mascot is quietly training for the coming football season in quarters near downtown New Haven, jumping for balls and running in circles in a small backyard.

title: MONEY: MAKING IT AND MULTIPLYING IT
description: Karen W. Arenson is a reporter for the Business Day section of The New York Times. CORPORATE MESSIAH: The Hiring and Firing of Million-Dollar Managers. A financially troubled International Harvester lured Archie R. McCardell from Xerox with a multimillion-dollar compensation package, only to dismiss him five years later as the scapegoat for its worsening problems. Burdened with a high debt and lacking a long-term strategy, RCA recruited Maurice Valente from I.T.T., providing him an annual compensation of at least $600,000. He lasted five and a half months before being asked to resign. Puritan Fashions snared Warren Hirsh - the marketing genius who scrawled Gloria Vanderbilt's signature across the hip pockets of blue jeans - with the promise of more autonomy. Eight weeks later he was out on the street, $1 million richer. For anyone looking for problems in corporate America, the tales of hirings and firings in ''Corporate Messiah'' are a good place to start. They offer a peek into a fascinating corner of corporate management, where executive psyches often override any semblance of management rules or even common courtesy. Musical chairs is being played in the executive suite with increasing frequency, Patricia O'Toole, a business writer, says. Economic problems have sent companies searching for salvation in the form of a supremely capable executive, or corporate messiah. And businesses have been willing to pay extraordinary sums to attract extraordinary leaders. But the strategy has often backfired. When a new executive proves ''unable to walk on water,'' Miss O'Toole notes, his days are numbered.

title: Priscilla Painton Weds Timothy Smith
description: Priscilla Painton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Painton of Paris and Orleans, Mass., was married yesterday to Timothy K. Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Kellum Smith Jr. of New York and Chatham, Mass. The Rev. George Beilby, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Federated Church in Orleans.

title: TRYING NEW PATHS
description: One nice thing about playing a new opening is that you do not have to feel embarrassed for not having checked out all the analyses and hundreds of footnotes in the Encyclopedia of Chess Openings. If you get it fresh enough, there won't be anything in print on it.

title: A SPECTACLE STIRS THE JUMBLE OF NATIONALISM
description: GRADUALLY, somewhat reluctantly, I fell prey to the seductions of the Olympic Games this summer. They had never enticed me much in previous years. They were simply too many events that were alien to my background. When it came to sports, I was strictly big-city meat and potatoes. The riding of horses meant nothing to me unless there was a parimutuel window at hand. Hopping around on parallel bars and pommel horses were activities inflicted on high school freshmen as part of the rites of passage. Swimming, diving, volleyball, the lifting of weights . . . none of these meant anything to me, certainly not when baseball could be had at the touch of a button.

title: Correction
description: In the Aug. 5 edition, the glance box accompanying a story about Hamish Maxwell, chairman of Philip Morris, misstated the percentages that beer and tobacco contribute to the company's total operating revenue. Tobacco accounts for 70 percent, beer 23 percent.

title: NEW SIGNS OF OLD GLAMOUR ON FIFTH AVE.
description: EVER since it opened more than five

title: WHAT'S NEW IN HEALTH CARE COSTS
description: Despite constant political talk about bringing health care costs under control, the price of getting well continues to soar.

title: No Headline
description: WINNING times are welcome times and, with good reason, the following - all New Jersey related - are flying the colors of champions these days. ''The de Nemethy Years: One Man's Influence on American Riding,'' by Paula Rodenas (Arco, New York, $14.95), describes the creation of the United States Equestrian Team in 1950 and lauds Bertalan de Nemethy, a resident of Far Hills since 1961 and now an equestrian- course designer, for his role in the team's remarkable progress.

title: HOW RENT VOUCHERS WILL BE TESTED
description: -income families in the tristate area who have applied for housing under the Federal Government's old Section 8 rent-assistance program will be among the first to receive nearly $15 million in benefits under the Government's new rent-voucher program, according to spokesmen for the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

description: IN 1983, the New York State Assembly, through its Codes Committee, rejected a bill that would have speeded up jury selection in felony cases. In 1984, the people can reject the Assembly.

description: NEW HAVEN A new marquee on an old movie house has lighted up a once-abandoned block of College Street.

title: THE NEXT OLYMPICS-IF ANY
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch is about to depart on a fruitless mission to Moscow. Mr. Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Committee, will plead with Soviet sports authorities not to boycott the next Games. His eye is on the wrong target.

description: What a terribly sad picture of the young woman wiping her brow while on her soup break within the horror of the Lodz ghetto.

title:
STAMPS;
U.N. FLAG SERIES
description: The United Nations is issuing a new segment of 16 stamps in its continuing Flag Series showing the flag of each member. The new issue is the fifth in the series approximating the halfway mark with five years to go. There are now 158 member states and the upcoming issue brings the total to 80. It is highly likely that there will be two more members in the next five years to give the world body a nice round number of flag stamps.

title: SALMON FARMING BRIGHTENS A TOWN'S OUTLOOK
description: Atlantic salmon are being grown in a hatchery here and in early September the fish will be going to market.

title: HEADLINERS ; Out of Reach Not being anxious to travel to Afghanistan,
description: Valdo Randpere , an Estonian Communist official, traveled to Sweden instead last month. In his first public statement since he defected, Mr. Randpere said last week that the fear of being drafted contributed to his decision to get out of range of Soviet authority.

title: A CHELSEA TURNAROUND
description: Long-time residents of Chelsea remember when one of RKO Theaters' grandest movie houses stood at the corner of Eighth Avenue and 23d Street. It has been almost 10 years since RKO operated a movie theater on the block between Eighth and Ninth Avenues.

title: NOT JUST A PRETTY FACE
description: Makeup has long been recognized as a means of enhancing physical beauty. Artfully applied, it can improve the look of skin, adding a healthy glow to disguise weariness or winter pallor. It can dramatize eyes, help mask signs of age, highlight a well-shaped mouth or redefine any problem areas of the face by means of deftly applied shading.

title: Resentencing Is Ordered For Upjohn Drug Heir
description: The Michigan Supreme Court has ordered that Roger Gauntlett, an heir to the Upjohn pharmaceutical fortune, be resentenced for child molesting. The court held that the sentence of probation and ''chemical castration'' by an Upjohn drug was illegal.

title: SIKH HIJACKERS GIVE UP PEACEFULLY IN GULF NATION
description: Hijackers who seized an Indian Airlines jetliner and demanded to be flown to the United States freed the remaining 79 passengers and crew of 6 today and surrendered more than 24 hours after commandeering the aircraft.

title: THE HILLMAN FAMILY COLELCTION AT THE NEWARK MUSEUM
description: NEWARK ALEX HILLMAN came to art collecting through the artists that he, as a publisher, commissioned to illustrate new editions of the classics.

title: Elizabeth Joslin Is Wed To Douglas Orr Logan
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Guilford, Conn., yesterday Elizabeth Dandridge Joslin, an assistant corporation counsel for the City of New York, was married to Douglas Orr Logan, an editor of nautical books for Dodd, Mead & Company in New York. The Rev. Bradford Locke performed the ceremony.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Tina the Terrible

title: THE UNTOLD STORY OF THE LODZ GHETTO
description: ''The Chronicle of the Lodz Ghetto'' makes an enormous contribution to our knowledge of life and death in this enclave, which came so close to outlasting the Nazis. But the story of Lodz is not entirely ''untold.''

title: Q & Q
description: Florida gives all legal residents a $25,000 homestead exemption on the assessed value of their homes. There are other exemptions for the disabled and for widows. Does New York have similar programs? . . . G. R. W., Manhattan

title: KEEPING AN EAR ON BEARS
description: WALLPACK CENTER '' THE score is bears 1, humans 2,'' said Patricia McConnell, a state wildlife biologist who had just ended a grueling but unsuccessful chase after a black bear and her two cubs up the rugged northern base of the Kittatinny Ridge here.

title: HAY FEVER: A (SNIFF) 'BUMPER CROP' OF POLLEN THIS YEAR
description: Hay Fever season arrived ahead of schedule this month in Connecticut, and for thousands of state residents, the next few weeks will be marred by nasal congestion, watery eyes and itchy noses and throats.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: A VARIETY OF TRANS-ATLANTIC CROSSINGS
description: Contrary to a common impression, there are still many passenger ships that cross the Atlantic. Only two passenger liners - Britain's Queen Elizabeth 2, whose American base is New York, and Poland's Stefan Batory out of Montreal - have frequent crossings in the spring, summer and fall, but many other vessels make at least one round trip a year.

title: IN REMEMBERING, A REMSEN REFLECTS
description: '' NOT the least of my luxuries is Listerine toothpaste,'' reads the sepia- colored poster from the days when the large size cost 25 cents. The cover girl, shown both smiling behind her motorcar's wheel and seated on horseback, was a young socialite, Elisabeth Remsen.

title: SAILING ALONG WITH DEMON RUM
description: HERE IS A RECIPE FOR A rum punch that might be just the thing for a suburban garden party. It was served in the British West Indies in the middle of the 18th century: ''A marble basin, built in the middle of the garden especially for the occasion, served as the bowl. Into it were poured 1,200 bottles of rum, 1,200 bottles of Malaga wine and 400 quarts of boiling water. Then 600 pounds of the best cane sugar and 200 powdered nutmegs were added. The juice of 2,600 lemons was squeezed into the liquor. Onto the surface was launched a handsome mahogany boat piloted by a boy of 12, who rowed about a few moments, then coasted to the side and began to serve the assembled company of 600, which gradually drank up the ocean upon which he floated.''

title: CALL BOXES PLACED ON BRIDGE IN ATTEMPT TO DETER SUICIDES
description: Two emergency radio call boxes have been placed on the Mid- Hudson Bridge to offer people contemplating suicide a chance to seek help. Officials said today that it was the first such arrangement in the country.

title: A TRADITIONALIST'S HOPES FOR VATICAN ACCORD DIM
description: Chances have dimmed for a reconciliation between the Vatican and more traditional-minded Roman Catholics led by Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, according to the Archbishop's successor as titular head of his movement.

Plunkett of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Harold J. Plunkett. title: Red Cross Nurses Strike

The strike began Thursday after members of the Michigan Health Care Associates, District 1199M, voted to reject a tentative new contract that called for a reduction in the ratio of nurses to donors.

title: ARE MUSIC'S MYSTERIES IN DANGER OF BEING SOLVED?
description: Whenever it is reported that another famous mystery in the arts has been solved, at least to some scholar's satisfaction, I experience a twinge of regret - along, of course, with a Bunyanish feeling of satisfaction that Truth has triumphed over Error. For some time now, mystery has been taking a thumping from pure reason and that is probably a good thing. For most practical purposes, as Thoreau said, any fact is better than make-believe. Still, if all traces of mystery were eliminated, the world would be a drab and predictable place. See ''Erewhon,'' ''Animal Farm'' or almost any electronic- music concert.

title: CAVEATS ON BUYING ABROAD
description: WHETHER for retirement or as a vacation retreat, a home overseas - a beach house in the Carribean or a villa on the French Riviera - is an almost universal fantasy. This summer, the strength of the dollar abroad is encouraging more people to turn those dreams into reality.

title: THE 'GREEN LAND' OF THE ARAB WORLD
description: Two storks nested on the platform below the belfry of the church in Beja this spring. Two storks had been there 41 years ago, looking down superciliously at the columns of tanks and trucks winding through the town on their way to war. The storks' nest was about the only thing in Tunisia that hadn't changed.

title: MERCY'S PRESIDENT LEAVES HIS 'CALLING'
description: DOBBS FERRY WHEN Dr. Donald Grunewald arrived at Mercy College as its president in 1972, he found a one- campus college struggling to survive on a $2.25 million budget. There were 1,500 students at the college. Classes were held in one building, which also housed the administrative offices. The college had a full-time faculty of less than 60 - 25 percent of whom had doctorates - a library of 60,000 volumes and offered only one degree program, in education.

Hanly performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of Hollidaysburg.

title:
ART ;
PHOTOGRAPHY IN THREE SHOWS AT HUDSON MUSEUM
description: THE camera reigns at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers in three exhibitions of photography. The two under review here are ''The Lens in the Garden,'' which is the curator Rick Wester's attempt to show a relationship between gardens as manipulations of the landscape and photographs as manipulations of images, and ''Domestic Rituals: Photography by Mary Frey,'' which records the foibles of human beings. A third show documents the history of homes and gardens in Westchester.

title: PENNSYLVANIA AIDE FOCUS OF SCANDAL
description: Pennsylvania State Treasurer R. Budd Dwyer, once considered a shoo-in for re-election this fall, has found himself in a fight for his political life at the center of a scandal punctuated by allegations of bribes, sexual favors and a secret Swiss bank account.

description: It was with great interest that I read Wayne Smith's article, ''Cuba: Time for a Thaw?'' (July 29). President Reagan would do well to pay heed to Mr. Smith's suggestion that Castro is ''a man with whom we might deal.''

title: HAPPY DAYS ARE HERE AGAIN
description: President Reagan claims that in 50 years the distinctions between the Republicans and the Democrats have never been greater. In truth, judging by both parties' conventions, they have rarely looked more alike. What's striking is not their divergence of positions but their convergence.

title: HOW TO TALK 'TEXIAN'
description: Cash money is archaic English, perhaps, but not a redundancy. Money is currency, which includes cash.

title: BALLET SCORES MIX FINE MUSIC WITH FOND MEMORIES
description: Balletomanes get double pleasure from recordings of complete ballets, for not only do they enjoy the music but, in their mind's eye, relive the dancing. Few ballet scores have been more influential than Adolphe Adam's 1841 ''Giselle'', which has been regularly heard in the theater ever since. Although it seems far more decorative than ''symphonic'' to modern ears, for its time it represented a breakthrough from the usual pastiches that made a mockery of any sort of dramatic unity between dance and music. As such, it served as a model for Delibes, who served as a model for Tchaikovsky, who served as a model for Prokofiev, all of whom composed full-evening ballet scores of the finest quality.

title: FOR WHOLESALERS, A NEW LOOK
description: At the busy Embarcadero Center

title: THE NEW KIND OF GLAMOUR
description: Overscaled coats hang to the ankles, covering jackets that are almost as well tailored as those from London's Savile Row. The pants beneath are double- pleated, loose-hanging, straight-legged and cuffed. They break over low-heeled moccasins or trim-line, oxfordlike shoes, and, fly- fronted, even button from left to right. The finishing touches are loose sweaters or soft shirts, sometimes a tie and certainly a watch. As often as not, these clothes are made of twills or tweeds.

title: CONCERT: ALL MOZART
description: Pinchas Zukerman and Marc Neikrug presented a disappointing program of Mozart compositions for violin and piano at Avery Fisher Hall Thursday night.

description: Have you ever wanted to learn to cast a flyrod, take your child largemouth bass fishing or troll for rainbow trout without having to rent a boat or plan ahead?

description: Near this remote Maui village, on a knoll overlooking the Pacific, the man who made the first nonstop solo flight across the Atlantic was buried a decade ago Sunday in the volcanic soil of a church cemetery.

title: THE ROCK CONNECTION
description: Stephen Sprouse, wearing black clothes and a black wig, sat at his table in his showroom on West 57th Street. The walls, the floor, the ceiling, the sofas and the telephones were all painted silver. On the table, there were books: one on the Velvet Underground, the cult rock group of the 1960's; one entitled ''Skinhead'' and several large black portfolios filled with the mountain of press clippings he has amassed in little over a year. In one corner, a video camera projected images onto a small Sony television. In another, his Day-Glo orange and yellow clothes seemed to breathe. The room seemed ready to take off.

description: I read the story of the Lodz ghetto with a pounding heart.

title: POP MUSIC
description: Gladys Knight and the Pips, who will be at the Gershwin Theater, 222 West 51st Street, for eight performances, beginning Tuesday, and running through next Sunday, have appeared infrequently in Manhattan in recent years. Last June, in a rare concert at Avery Fisher Hall, Miss Knight and the three Pips - Edward Patten, Merald Knight, and William Guest - put on a show that mixed romantic pop-soul and Las Vegas production values into a nearly perfect adult pop entertainment.

title: Nets Sign Turner The Nets announced yesterday that they had signed
description: Jeff Turner , their first-round selection in the National Basketball Association draft, to a multiyear contract. Turner will receive $75,000 next season, the maximum a rookie can receive if he is drafted by a team, like the Nets, whose payroll exceeds the salary cap.

title: BEHIND BECKER'S UNHAPPY BREAKUP
description: On Monday morning, Aug. 6, the denizens of Wall Street arrived at work with a sense of glee. Only a few days earlier, the stock market - finally - had snapped out of its year-long slump and had started to generate the heady gains that reminded brokers of the glory days of August 1982. There was money in the air that morning and everyone felt it.

title: Donna Kraemer Wed To William Read 4th
description: Donna Ann Kraemer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Kraemer of Sparta, N.J., was married there yesterday to William M. Read 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Read 3d of Clifton, N.J. The Rev. William Nelson Cramer performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Lake Roman Catholic Church.

title: Making Realistic Plans For One's Old Age
description: I read the article ''Aiding Those Who Aid the Aged'' (July 15) with interest and with much concern both for the members of the support group observed and for their parents. When the roles of parent and child must be reversed, at least some dissatisfaction and resentment on both sides is inevitable.

title: CAMPUS HOUSING FOR PEOPLE OF ALL AGES
description: Several universities in New York City are hoping to build more rooms for students by opening doors for the elderly. Along with some community service and housing groups, the universities are advocating campus-based developments to house the young and old together. Such plans, they hope, can overcome the shortage of housing for the elderly and community opposition to building dormitories near campuses.

title: DINING OUT ; TANGY SICHUAN IN CANAAN
description: The Yale in China program is well-known in academia, but in Canaan, it is China in Yale - the Yale Barn restaurant, that is. A few years ago it was a respected French restaurant. Redecorated and with new ownership, the Yale Barn is respected once again, but this time for its Sichuan Chinese cuisine.

description: Twenty-two years after its conception, nearly two years after its theatrical release, 17 months after winning eight Academy Awards, the motion picture ''Gandhi'' will be shown on television this week for the first time.

title: Bar May Prove Historic
description: Trader Jon's, a ramshackle waterfront bar crammed with military memorabilia and popular with Navy aviation cadets over the years, has been nominated for the National Register of Historic Places, a state official said Friday.

title: SOUND ; PROGRESS IN SMALL SPEAKERS
description: For decades, audio designers were nagged by a persistent challenge: how to get musically creditable sound out of very small speakers. The easy answer was that it couldn't be done, and the sound of most small speakers unhappily proved the point. But to some engineers the word ''impossible'' is a spur, and circa 1980 a few imaginative companies - notably ADS and KEF - came up with shoebox-size speakers that perked up the ears of even the most exigent listeners. Experimenting with offbeat cone materials, more efficient magnets, and revving up their computers to ferret out previously unexplored design possiblities, these companies tackled the intractable problems of small speakers. Their efforts toppled the axiom that only big speakers can achieve musical verisimilitude.

title: NEW AT $3.5 MILLION
description: Without the cushion of a single prospective buyer, two New Jersey brothers have begun construction of a stone mansion in Saddle River, for which they plan to ask at least $3.5 million when work is completed next spring.

title: Ready or Not?
description: The dispute over just how ready the United States is to engage in conventional armed conflict may well be an argument that could only be settled by going to war.

title: CARY ANN LINDBLAD
description: Cary Ann Lindblad, a travel expert and conservationist, died of cancer yesterday in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital.

title: Rome Court Frees 3 Leftists
description: A Rome court today ordered three leftist guerrillas freed on bail under a new law reducing the period of so-called preventive detention. The court ordered the release of Emilio Vesce, Luciano Ferrari Bravo and Gianni Sbrogio on bail of $56,000 each and assigned them to obligatory residence in separate small towns.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Arches for Rent
description: ''O harp and altar, of the fury fused.'' ''Terrific threshold of the prophet's pledge.'' ''Unfractioned idiom, immaculate sigh of stars.'' Those were some of the ways the poet Hart Crane saw the Brooklyn Bridge in 1930.

title: Tunisian Ruler Names Aide
description: President Habib Bourguiba named Mohammed Sayah today as Minister of Equipment and Housing in a move seen as reinforcing the 82-year-old leader's control over the Government.

GARDENING;
PROBLEMS CAUSED BY HUMIDITY

title: TRUMPET: WYNTON MARSALIS
description: The sensational young trumpeter Wynton Marsalis, who has appeared most often hereabouts as a jazz player, walked away with the show at the Mostly Mozart Festival's final program Friday in Fisher Hall. He played the Hummel concerto - usually thought of as being in E-flat, but, the program note informed us, originally written in the more difficult key of E, and played that way here - and won a mid-program standing ovation. (Mr. Marsalis has an unassuming, modest stage presence, but is showman enough to make his public wait between bows; nevertheless he was called back for several.)

title: U.S. EX-DIPLOMAT SAYS SOVIET DISTORTED HIS VIEWS
description: A former American diplomat said today that he was astonished to learn that the Moscow radio had attributed to him assertions that the South Korean airliner shot down last year was actually destroyed by a bomb planted on the aircraft and set off by remote control.

title: NEW U.S. PLAN ON OIL LEASES IN ATLANTIC DRAWS CRITICISM
description: The Interior Department has announced final plans for a scaled-down sale of offshore oil and gas leases in the North Atlantic. The department said the program had been revised to meet objections from environmentalists.

title: Alison R. Rowe, a Broker, Is Married

title: KREMLIN REPORTS SUCCESSFUL TESTS OF CRUISE MISSILES
description: The Soviet Defense Ministry said today that it has been conducting successful tests of long-range ground-launched cruise missiles in response to what it called widespread deployment of such weapons by the United States.

title: ENGLISH MUSIC SHOWS MANY FACETS
description: Among recordings of British music made available here recently, one of curious and historical interest is called ''Masters of the English Renaissance in Music'' (Forlane UM 3529/3531, three disks). The choice of title is odd. Only one of the three composers represented had any great influence in revitalizing the English scene. He was Sir Hubert Parry (1848-1926), whose activities as composer, scholar and teacher took his country's creative art out of the doldrums in the late 19th century and gave it a higher set of standards.

title: U.S. Plans Talks With Greece On Voice of America Stations

title: INSIDE A SINGER'S WORLD IN THE U.S.S.R.
description: The following are excerpts from ''Galina: A Russian Story,'' the forthcoming autobiography of the Russian soprano, Galina Vishnesvkaya. Miss Vishnevskaya and her husband, Mstislav Rostropovich, the cellist and conductor, both had distinguished careers in the Soviet Union. However, after years of political harassment, they left in 1974 never to return.

description: All of the state's public schools must adopt policies governing homework, attendance and promotion by next June, according to a new law, and a State Department of Education panel is going to make some suggestions.

description: A number of administrators, archivists and historians have become concerned that the rapidly growing use of computers and word processors may be undermining the Government's administrative and historical record.

title: Twin Dies in Crash With Twin
description: Andrew Barrera, 22 years old, was killed in a traffic accident. The driver of the other car was his twin, Anthony, the California Highway Patrol said today. Officers said Andrew Barrera of Livermore was a passenger in a car driven by Jose Martinez, 24, when it was hit Friday by a car driven by Anthony Barrera. Mr. Martinez was reported in critical condition at Valley Memorial Hospital; Anthony Barrera was treated and released.

title: TINA TURNER TURNS A PAGE IN THE EVOLUTION OF POP-SOUL
description: ''Private Dancer'' (Capitol ST 12330), Tina Turner's first solo album in many years, is a landmark not only in the career of the 45-year-old singer who has been recording since the late 1950's, but in the evolution of pop-soul music itself. An innovative fusion of old-fashioned soul singing and new wave synth-pop, ''Private Dancer'' caps several years of struggle to find a recording contract by a singer who was considered by many to be an over-the-hill oldies entertainer.

title: WHEN THE PLAYWRIGHT'S LIFE IS VISIBLE IN HIS WORK
description: From Anton Chekhov to David Mamet, playwrights have always used elements of autobiography in the creation of their work, but it is rare to see a play that is itself the raw material of a writer's life. Such is the case with Tennessee Williams's ''Vieux Carre'' and Lanford Wilson's ''Balm in Gilead,'' both seen recently in revivals, the Williams at the Williamstown Theater Festival, the Wilson at the Circle Repertory Company. In each instance, events that the playwrights were later to shape into various artistic semblances are encountered in their natural state. It is almost as if after seeing art, we now are confronted with the reality that inspired it. The plays are prophetic as well as experiental. They tell us about the making of art and the making of a playwright - each a major American playwright with a lyric sensibility - approaching themes, attempting motifs and experimenting with style. We learn about the playwright's life as it crucially affects his work.

BANDING TOGETHER FOR A LOT MORE CLOUT
description: The old adage about safety in numbers is getting plenty of play in the health care arena. Across the country local employers are banding together to get health costs down. They are forming coalitions that provide a forum for exchanging ideas and information, that lobby for favorable legislation, put pressure on hospitals to put cost containment programs into effect and even help member companies join together in inter-company insurance plans.

title: A MOROCCAN-LIBYAN 'UNION' JOLTS U.S.

The call went something like this: ''I'm here with Colonel Qaddafi, and we're about to sign a treaty of federation between Morocco and Libya. Don't worry about it.''

title: PUBLIC SCHOOLS ENGAGINGLY STUDIED
description: The public schools are a precious commodity; virtually everyone agrees about that. They are also threatened, and virtually everyone who has looked at them thoughtfully agrees about that, too. Troubles multiply in the school system; governmental and private agencies try to define them. Now it is television's turn. It is doing this in a praiseworthy program tonight, and in a monumental, even unprecedented, broadcast on Sept. 3. The program tonight, ''The Class of '84,'' on Channel 2 at 10 o'clock, is in its way also unprecedented. It is the first documentary ever to be produced for prime time by the five CBS-owned stations. The Sept. 3 broadcast, ''To Save Our Schools, to Save Our Children,'' will be presented by ABC. This critic has not yet seen it but is already impressed by the network's high purpose. ABC that night is committing its entire prime-time schedule, 8 to 11 o'clock, for the broadcast.

title: THE POLITICAL HUCKSTERS

title: EARLY-MUSIC STYLES STRESSED AT JUILLIARD

And the American musical establishment has begun gradually to respond. Now the august Juilliard School has announced a new program of instruction in performance styles of Baroque and early Classical music, starting with the new school year this September.

title: PLEASURES OF THE POISON PEN
description: WRITING in the pages of this review a couple of years ago, the poet Anthony Hecht looked at himself and his fellow poets and concluded they were a pretty bad lot. He recalled how shocked a reviewer of the final volume of Lawrance Thompson's Robert Frost biography had been at the ''less attractive aspects'' of Frost's character. On the contrary, Mr. Hecht professed to be shocked not at all by those revelations, and not because of any William H. Pritchard is Henry Clay Folger Professor of English at Amherst College. His ''Frost: A Literary Life Reconsidered'' will be published this fall. thing special he knew about Frost, but rather ''because the chief faults of Frost that so offended the critic - vanity, paranoia, selfishness - seemed to me to be the characteristic afflictions, amounting almost to professional deformations, of most poets. I recognized them instantly in myself and, after a moment's thought, in most other poets I knew. On the whole we are rather an unpleasant lot, and have to try to be nice by strenuous exertion and muscular effort and can only envy those who are effortlessly kind and considerate.''

title: THE WORLD ; Mines RemainA Mystery

description: Jean Grady of Berwyn, Pa., and Nathaniel C. Wyeth of Kennett Square, Pa., were married yesterday at St. Davids (Pa.) Episcopal Church.

title: Elizabeth Hartzell Wed to Samuel DeSimone Jr.
description: Elizabeth B. Hartzell, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harry E. Hartzell Jr. of Palo Alto, Calif., was married yesterday to Samuel R. DeSimone Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. DeSimone of Worcester, Mass. The Rev. Clyde Dodder performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Palo Alto.

title: SPECIALISTS AT UCONN STUDY THINNING OF BONES
description: For 10 years Yvonne Cooper of Forestville has spent her days in a back brace. Today, the 71- year-old woman speaks of the ease in which her bones fracture and how brittle her skeleton has become. ''It's not old age,'' she said. ''It's osteoporosis.''

title: EX-STATE SENATOR FACES ETHICS INQUIRY
description: HACKENSACK JOHN M. SKEVIN, once a legislator and still a redoubtable figure in state and Bergen County politics, is battling to retain his license to practice law amid charges that he comingled clients' funds with his own and complaints that are before the State Office of Attorney Ethics in Trenton.

title: HEADLINERS ; Among the Found When
description: William Catterson of Lodi, N.J., called his wife in 1982 and told her he would be a bit late coming home from work, he wasn't kidding. He didn't see her again until last week, after nearly two years during which his two children and his wife, Patricia, came to assume he was dead.

title: U. OF NEW MEXICO EMBROILED IN DISPUTE ON NEW PRESIDENT
description: The selection of a new president for the University of New Mexico has set off a dispute at the institution.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
BEHAVIOR IN THE ORIENT IS A MODEL
description: AWAKENED by the sound of a crashing beer bottle last night, I lay in bed reminded again of the many questions I have been asking myself since returning to the United States after living in Japan and Korea for a year. The questions arise out of a nagging perception that there seems to be a rapidly diminishing sense of good manners and friendliness in America today. A year abroad has made me more aware of just how far we have regressed. I am not referring to the still frightening statistics of crime in the street but rather to the way that we average, law-abiding Americans behave and treat one another in our everyday encounters.

title: TEMPERANCE UNION IS SEEKING A NEW IMAGE
description: The Women's Christian Temperance Union is trying to swap the image of Carrie Nation chopping up saloons for that of a ''peace-loving people'' persuading Americans of all ages to take the pledge against liquor.

title: DEMOCRATS IN RACE FOR OTTINGER'S SEAT OUTLINE POSITIONS
description: T HE four Democrats waging a primary battle for the seat being vacated by Representative Richard L. Ottinger clashed last week over such issues as raising income taxes and financing their own campaigns. But they also agreed in a 90-minute debate at The New York Times that the major issues in the county were housing and education.

title: CHANEL TODAY
description: One of the basic ingredients of any fashion is fabric, and here two prints designed by Jenny Kee turned up in very different circumstances. One, inspired by Australian opals, appeared first in an outfit of pajamas, turban, scarf and cape at Madison Square Garden and, the same evening at Lincoln Center, worked into a classic Chanel gown.

title: LILLIAN HELLMAN'S GIFT TO A YOUNG PLAYWRIGHT
description: People lie to girls. At least, when I was growing up, they did. They said there was always some way to make everybody happy. They said fighting wouldn't get you anywhere. And they said that conversation was how you kept people from knowing what you were thinking.

title: AVERAGE PAY OF MOST WORKERS PUT AT $17,544
description: The annual pay of the 89 million Americans covered by the unemployment compensation system averaged $17,544 in 1983, an increase of 4.8 percent over the previous year, the Bureau of Labor Statistics has reported.

title: Munson Case Settled
description: Diane Munson, the widow of Thurman Munson, has settled her wrongful death action filed against the Cessna Aircraft and Flight Safety International for more than $1.69 million, according to a published report. The Canton Repository in Canton, Ohio, reported that Mrs. Munson had reached an out-of-court settlement shortly after the trial began in a United States District Court in Akron last May, but the amount of the settlement was not revealed at the time.

For all that, Tom Jones's and Harvey Schmidt's simplistic ode to the ups and downs of marriage has to rely on sheer showmanship and visual values to bring it off.

TUNING INTO AMERICAN INSTRUMENTS
description: Among collectors, interest in American musical instruments surfaced during the Bicentennial and now appears to be rising in pitch. The exhibition ''The Art of Music, American Paintings and Musical Instruments, 1770-1910,'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris (Park Avenue and 42d Street) through Sept. 19, underscores this fresh interest and whets the appetite for fuller fare, being more appetizer than main course.

description: Although most homeowners try to make sure that there are good locks on their front door to keep burglars out, all too often they actually ''invite'' break-ins when they are away on a trip simply because they don't follow some common-sense rules.

title: PUTTING THE OFFICE OF PROSECUTOR ON THE MAP

title:
CAMERA;
GUIDELINES FOR THE USE OF INFRARED FILMS
description: Sandy Sorlein is a freelance photographer and writer. Most photography is a representation of the world as we see it, that is images formed by the reflection of visible light. However, the range of visible light is only part of the total range of radiation that exists. At one end of the visible spectrum lies ultraviolet light, and at the other end, infrared.

title: DESIGN TRENDS 1985
description: ONCE UPON A TIME, ANYTHING REmotely electronic was such an esthetic disgrace that designers would go so far as to hide the telephone in a tea cozy. Times have changed. Now, between home computers, laser disks and wall-sized television screens, electronics are an inevitability every designer must cope with. In fact, building the proper place to house state-of-the-art equipment has become an art in itself. The team of Bromley/Jacobsen created an entire media world in a room they designed for the Kip's Bay Show House in New York. Sitting in a space-age love seat, one can, with a mere flick of a switch, control everything from television monitor to tape deck. ''Much of this new equipment is beautiful to look at,'' says Robin Jacobsen.

title: CLOUD OF COMPLACENCY SHADOWS G.O.P. 'SPRINGTIME OF HOPE'
description: DALLAS BY the standards that customarily apply to President Reagan, acknowledged by friend and foe alike as the nation's consummate political performer, last week's reviews and the response were surprisingly tepid. Mr. Reagan's speech accepting renomination lasted almost an hour. A laundry list of Democratic failings lent it an uncharacteristically negative tone. By the time the President reached his extended peroration, with its trademark rhetorical flourishes about ''a springtime of hope for America,'' both the speaker and audience seemed to be flagging. In the end, they were joined in a mood of subdued optimism. The convention closed without the cresting emotion that would seem to be in order for a candidate who many think may be on the verge of an electoral landslide, and for a party that seems to have a strong chance to achieve a new period of conservative ascendancy in American politics.

title: STERN RULE AND YEARS OF WAR DRIVE IRANIANS TO FLEE TO EUROPE
description: Stern theocratic rule and four years of war between Iran and Iraq have driven thousands of Iranians to Scandinavia and other European countries in search of asylum, Government agencies report.

title: THE REGION ; Agreement in Hospital Strike
description: The strike against New York City's private nonprofit hospitals looped through enough twists and turns last week to rival a hyperkinetic summer adventure film. The strike was the longest and largest health-care strike in New York City's history and state health officials said it ended without one major hishap at the struck hospitals.

By day she labors in an office, answering phones and typing, all the while dreaming of the big break that will land her a career in the movies. Just another hopeful with glitter in her eyes: the town's full of them. But it doesn't deter her. She's got spirit.

title: SEARCH AND DESTROY
description: Michael Shapiro is a freelance journalist who writes frequently about sports. By Michael Shapiro LAWRENCE TAYLOR is on the couch, watching himself play football on a wide television screen. ''I'll show you my favorite tackle,'' he says. He finds on a videotape the moment in a game against the Detroit Lions when, at the snap of the ball, he bursts from his position at linebacker, tosses the opposing blocker from his path like a rag doll, grabs the quarterback by the back of the collar and slams him to the turf with one hand.

title: PLEASING SIGNALS FROM THE ECONOMY
description: The economy showed continued signs of slowing, but still exhibited strength. The Government reported that consumer prices rose three- tenths of a percent in July, more than in the previous two months, but still well under control, according to economists. Most of the increase came from higher electricity and natural gas prices. After-tax corporate profits pointed to slower growth, rising only 1.5 percent in the second quarter - substantially less than the 6.7 percent increase in the first three months of the year. And the Government adjusted second-quarter real gross national product a notch higher to 7.6 percent from 7.5 percent. But in an erratic signal that the economy still has strength, new orders for durable goods jumped ahead 2.2 percent in July, after a 3 percent June drop. ''Essentially catch-up,'' was how one economist described the unexpected spurt.

title: Allen to Stay
description: George Allen, after more than a month of contemplation, said yesterday that he has decided to return as head coach of the United States Football League's Arizona Wranglers. Allen, 66 years old, postponed his scheduled European vacation for the second straight year to attend the Wranglers' free-agent tryout camp and told The Associated Press: ''I wouldn't be here today if I wasn't coming back to coach.''

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Arts and Taxes

Under the plan, which required legislative approval, the money would go to a new fund to be administered by the State Council on the Arts and be distributed to local arts councils, museums and theater, dance and opera groups.
