title: Briefcases
description: - The Energy Department's Office of Competition, already shrunk by the Reagan Administration to five employees, from 10, is scheduled next month to be left with only one - Leonard Coburn, its director.

title: American History Belongs to America Whenever Ronald Reagan leaves office, historians will have to wait only 12 years until his White House papers become public. Some secrets will stay secret, but professionals at the National Archives rather than the President or his staff will decide which. Not so, however, for members of the Reagan Cabinet. They may say which documents are personal and then limit access to them for as long as 25 years - as former Secretary of State Haig has already done.
description: Truth loses under this illogical policy. It gives lieutenants more discretion than their chief to bury their mistakes in locked vaults.

title: Robot to Run Car's Gearshift TOKYO, Aug. 26 (AP) -
description: Isuzu Motors Ltd. said Friday

title: Perspective on Auto Profits
description: W. Paul Tippett, chairman of the American Motors Corporation, said today that the United States auto industry has only partly recovered and that huge past losses are being obscured by current record profits.

title: U.S. FILM MAKERS LURED BY JAMAICAN INCENTIVES
description: This Caribbean island, which was used as the backdrop for a number of Hollywood movies in the 1960's, is going to be bustling again with film crews in the fall.

title: Reagan Campaign Plans $2 Million Jersey Effort
description: The Northeast regional director of the Reagan campaign confidently predicts that New Jersey will be ''the state that breaks Walter Mondale's back'' and says Republicans will spend at least $2 million there to insure a victory in November for President Reagan.

title: DENMARK IS INVESTIGATING REPORT ON CHILD PRONOGRAPHY
description: The police said today that an investigation of possible mass production of child pornography has been ordered after a United States television report said that Denmark was a major exporter of such material.

title: WHEN BASS ARE FUSSY
description: RELIEF, N.C.

title: NUCLEAR EXPERTS SAY THE DANGER IS MINIMAL
description: The nuclear material reportedly being carried by the Mont Louis when it sank in the English Channel is only mildly radioactive, according to nuclear experts, and would seem to pose little hazard to divers in a salvage operation.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As a person and a writer, I seem to have had little effect on improving the world I came into.

title: Ellen Epstein Marries Dr. Roy Cohen
description: Ellen Faith Epstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Epstein of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Roy Shelley Cohen, a son of Winifred Cohen of Brockton, Mass., and Marvin Cohen of Miami Lakes, Fla. The ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., was performed by Rabbi Morris Pickholz, assisted by Cantor Gerhard Gluck.

title: U.S. News's Expectations
description: Associates of Mortimer Zuckerman, the Boston real estate developer turned publisher, do not expect any major changes in the editorial leadership and staff of U.S. News and World Report when he officially takes over the news magazine next week. Marvin L. Stone will continue as editor for the immediate and, probably, indefinite future, it is said, although Mr. Zuckerman might replace the head of the business side, James H. McIlhenny, who has the title of president of U.S. News.

title: PANEL LINKS MOB AND HOTEL UNION
description: In a report to be made public Monday, a Senate subcommittee will accuse the 400,000-member Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union of being under the ''substantial influence'' of organized crime. It will urge that top officers of the union resign or be voted from office.

title: RETIRED ARCHBISHOP OF BALTIMORE
description: Lawrence Cardinal Shehan, a retired Roman Catholic Archbishop of Baltimore and a prominent advocate of racial integration and religious ecumenism, died yesterday in Baltimore. He was 86 years old.

title: The Burden in Manila A vivid figure in the Arabian Nights is the Old Man of the Sea, whom Sinbad meets and offers, out of kindness, to carry. Once aloft, the Old Man locks his legs and refuses to let go. So it is with President Marcos of the Philippines, a now ruinous burden to the 52 million people compelled to bear him. With the Old Man's effrontery, Mr. Marcos counts on American aid to rescue him from a mess of his own making.
description: Nothing has prospered for the House of Marcos since the murder a year ago of the opposition leader, Benigno Aquino. Having promised a thorough and impartial inquiry, the Marcos regime has failed to deliver. Its obstruction is typified by the refusal to permit the testimony of a Japanese journalist who witnessed the killing. He was barred from the country as an ''undesirable alien.''

title: LET THEM REGISTER ON ELECTION DAY
description: To the Editor:

title: Nurses at L.I. Hospital Striking for Higher Pay
description: About 175 registered nurses went on strike early today against Southampton Hospital after contract talks between the hospital and the New York State Nurses Association broke down.

title: ART: SHOW IN JERSEY CITY FOCUSES ON TERRA COTTA
description: Beavers rampant commemorate the Astor family (and the furs that made its fortune) at Astor Place; turtles at 81st Street signify the proximity of the American Museum of Natural History. Not the real beavers and turtles, of course, but images done in mosaic on the walls of subway stations, they are among the few remaining charms of the New York public transport system.

title: AQUINO PANEL REPORTED SET TO ACCUSE GENERAL
description: A newspaper said today that the commission investigating the assassination a year ago of the Philippine opposition leader, Benigno S. Aquino Jr., would accuse the nation's top military officer of ordering the killing. But a lawyer for the panel said the newspaper report was based on ''guessing.''

title: POST NO BILLS
description: To the Editor:

title: Kinder-Care
description: Kinder-Care Learning Centers Inc. said it had been asked by the Securities and Exchange Commission to restate its earnings for the year ended last Sept. 2. The revised figures will include an extraordinary charge of $5.1 million, reducing net income for the year to $6.1 million, or 37 cents a share. The charge relates to the conversion of the company's convertible subordinated debentures into common stock in December 1982.

title: ROOM FOR OPTIMISM ON JETS
description: The disintegration of the Jets, who seemed to be coming apart just as the start of the regular season loomed, may not happen as quickly as critics predicted or fans feared.

title: PETRO-CANADA ISSUE WON'T FADE AWAY
description: Many people say that one reason Joe Clark, the leader of the Progressive Conservative Party, lost out in Canada's national elections four years ago was because he advocated selling Petro- Canada, the national oil company, to the private sector.

title: YANKEES COMPLETE SWEEP OF MARINERS WITH 7-2 TRIUMPH
description: The Yankees completed a three-game sweep of the Mariners this afternoon, though compared with Saturday night's rout, today's 7-2 victory was merely a spanking.

title: MONDAY SPORTS ;  Baseball
description: Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers , at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. The Mets' Dwight Gooden, the National League's strikeout leader, and Fernando Valenzuela, who is 11 behind Gooden, are the pitching adversaries.

title: Reagan Spurns Mondale On Six-Debate Series
description: President Reagan is willing to debate Walter F. Mondale ''on reasonable terms at a reasonable time'' the White House says, but will not accept the Democrat's challenge to a series of six.

title: Louganis Wins 29th Title
description: Greg Louganis set a record for most national diving titles Saturday night when he captured the platform competition at the United States Outdoor Diving Championships.

title: MUNICIPAL BOND FIRM SURVIVES A RISKY START
description: When Jim Cashman, Joe Gabriele and Steve Hueglin decided to start their own firm in the Death Valley that was the municipal bond market in September 1979, many friends and colleagues on Wall Street raised their eyebrows.

title: STUDY URGES FLIGHT CONTROLS TO EASE PEAK-HOUR DELAYS
description: Airline passengers would experience fewer delays if flights were spread throughout the day instead of concentrated at peak travel times, according to a Government study released today.

title: WHERE NEXT FOR ELECTRONICS?
description: When employees of the Victor Company of Japan make valuable suggestions, they are often rewarded with little statues of a dog, the company mascot.

title: Of God and Break Dancing
description: An evangelist stood on a corner in

title: FERRARO STAFF HAS TROUBLES IN MIDST OF FINANCIAL ORDEAL
description: In the turmoil surrounding the disclosure of her finances, Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro's newly appointed senior political adviser vacationed on Cape Cod and one of the three people who have served so far as press secretary to her young campaign was dismissed, according to aides.

title: F.B.I. Chief's Collection
description: Agood many Washingtonians, particularly longtime members of Congress, follow the custom of papering their offices, libraries and anterooms with pictures of themselves taken with Presidents, Cabinet members and all manner of other well-known folks. Most of these collections mercifully disappear from sight with the departure of the owner from public or private life, but there are exceptions.

title: ;  Tigers 12, Angels 6
description: Chet Lemon hit a grand slam to cap a six- run third inning that sent Detroit to victory.

title: ; TWO AMERICAN MARINES IN LENINGRAD
description: To the Editor:

title: BOARDMAN BUMP
description: Boardman Bump, an investment manager and former treasurer of Mount Holyoke College, died of an abdominal infection Aug. 23 at Newton- Wellesley Hospital in Newton, Mass. He was 75 years old.

title: ANTICOMPUTERISM
description: I've considered the appeals to reason, figured the payback periods and suffered pangs of parental guilt, but my answer is the same. I won't have a computer in my house.

title: Mystery Israel Mission
description: David L. Aaron, one of Walter F. Mondale's chief foreign policy advisers, was in Israel last week on what can only be described as a mystery mission. Before he left, Mr. Aaron said he would be traveling on business for Oppenheim & Company, the Wall Street banking firm for which he works when he is not involved, as now, in a political campaign.

title: FAMED BOWLER WAS 93
description: Andy Varipapa, recognized as the supreme bowler of his time and one of the sport's best attractions for more than a quarter of a century, died Saturday. He was 93 years old.

title: TOOL ORDERS UP IN JULY
description: Machine tool orders surged 63.4 percent in July from a depressed level in June, the National Machine Tool Builder's Association said yesterday.

title: Futures/Options; The Popularity In Eurodollars
description: NOT long ago, Treasury bills were the ''90-day wonders'' of the short-term financial futures market. No more. Today the wunderkinds of the short-term market are the 90-day Eurodollar deposit futures, which until recently were considered too esoteric to use as either hedging or speculative vehicles.

title: TRADITION OF ROCK BOTTOM
description: WASHINGTON It is only half right to say, as the

title: ANIMATION AGAIN A PRIORITY AT DISNEY
description: After nearly 30 years of throwing its energies into amusement parks and movies and television programs featuring live actors, the studio founded by Walt Disney is turning back to the brush strokes of its youth. Because of recent changes in the entertainment industry, including the arrival of video cassettes, animation has become a priority once more at the empire built by Mickey Mouse.

title: Melissa Gordon Marries
description: Melissa Gordon, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Samuel Z. Gordon of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Peter Clive Lewis, a son of Mrs. Robert C. Lewis of New York and the late Mr. Lewis. Rabbi Samuel Scolnic performed the ceremony at the Gordon home. Mrs. Lewis, a registered nurse, is studying for a master's degree in children's psychiatric nursing at Columbia University. Her father is an administrative law judge with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. Mr. Lewis, who graduated from Syracuse University, is an electronics engineer at the Eaton Corporation in Melville, L.I. His father was an assistant editor of The New York Times Magazine.

title: Politics and Small Business
description: The National Federation of Independent Business, which for its entire 40-year history has shunned making political endorsements, may be about to abandon its neutrality.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Aug. 27, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: MCCARTHY IS RECIPIENT OF MACDOWELL MEDAL
description: Mary McCarthy, literary lioness, received the Edward MacDowell Medal here today for her career as an author. She proceeded to show that, at the age of 72, she still has her growl and her claws.

title: CHRISTIAN REPUBLICAN PARTY?
description: WASHINGTON

title: NO MINES, SAUDI OFFICIAL SAYS
description: Saudi Arabia said Saturday that its territorial waters, used by commercial ships and Moslem pilgrims, were free of mines.

title: Red Sox 4, Indians 2
description: Roger Clemens pitched a three-hitter and struck out 10 as the Red Sox completed a three- game sweep of Cleveland. Jim Rice drove in the tie-breaking run on a fourth-inning single for his 100th r.b.i.

title: OUTLOOK FOR DECLINE IN YIELDS IS DIMMER
description: After an exhilarating rally that brought Treasury bond yields down to around 12 1/2 percent currently, from 14 percent at the end of May and 13.6 percent in early July, optimism in the credit markets has waned considerably.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Looking for Judge Hardy
description: Lynn Price, a delegate to last week's Republican convention, knows an ideal home when she sees one. It's made up of ''the husband as breadwinner and the mother nurturing and guiding the moral fiber.''

title: IT'S INSTINCT: IN FLORIDA, MONKEYS BALK AT RULES
description: ''The trouble with the monkeys at Silver Springs,'' says Linda Wolfe, professor of anthropology at the University of Florida, ''is that they don't know they are in Florida. They think they're somewhere in Southern Asia and they go looking for other monkeys.''

title: Hopeful Is Taken By Chief's Crown
description: Chief's Crown swung three wide on the turn for home and rolled to a 3 3/4-length victory today in the 80th running of the Hopeful Stakes for 2-year-olds at Saratoga.

title: Washington Watch; The Balanced Budget Bill
description: WASHINGTON THE balanced budget amendment, a Reagan

title: A Purchase Less Than the Sum of its Parts
description: And now, a fishy lesson in modern

title: SHORTAGE OF SEMICONDUCTORS EASES
description: A critical shortage of semiconductors appears to be easing, after a year of scarcity that forced many makers of computers, video cassette recorders and other electronic products to reduce their production.

title: CAPITAL MAKES MARK ON THE ART SCENE
description: ''This is a tough town to make it as an artist,'' said Charles Sleichter, a painter who lives in one of four apartment-studios carved out of a former Washington school that he and some fellow artists bought at auction.

title: METS TOP GIANTS TO END SKID AT 3
description: The Mets received two big surprises yesterday, one from the Giants and the other from one of their own, and both were instrumental in thwarting San Francisco's thoughts of shattering the Mets with a sweep of their four-game series.

title: TROUBLING UNAWARENESS OF CHILD MOLESTATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: New Shuttle Is Readied For 3d Try Wednesday
description: The space shuttle Discovery, its debut canceled twice before by mechanical failures, began its countdown tonight for a third launching attempt at 8:35 Wednesday morning. ''We fully intend to make it this time,'' said the ship's commander, Henry W. Hartsfield Jr.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: BUS COMPANY PROFITS FROM TRAINS' TROUBLES
description: For years, Bernard J. Flynn says, his private bus company struggled along on several routes in northern New Jersey.

title: Corporate Notes
description: Midlantic Banks Inc., Edison, N.J., said it plans to offer $50 million in convertible subordinated debentures due 2009 through a syndicate of underwriters.

title: A VARIETY OF STYLES FOR THE PALATE, TOO
description: Between 35,000 and 40,000 hamburgers, 7,000 gallons of soda syrup, and close to 200,000 all-beef hot dogs, with or without sauerkraut and Grey Poupon mustard, are among the food items that will be sold at concession stands, outdoor restaurants, stand-up bars, banquet halls and white-tablecloth dining rooms at the United States Open this week and next.

title: FIRST NICARAGUAN STRIKE SINCE '79 IS OVER
description: Workers at the state-owned Victoria Brewery who staged a five-day strike, the first by Nicaraguan workers since the 1979 revolution, agreed to go back to work this weekend after an appeal by the Labor Minister.

title: Some Dockworkers Defy British Strike
description: Longshoremen at the port of Immingham in Lincolnshire voted to defy a strike call today, creating the first rebellion against a two-day-old nationwide dock strike.

title: ;  Orioles 13, A's 6
description: Eddie Murray drove in four runs and Rich Dauer had four hits for the Orioles as they handed the A's their eighth straight loss.

title: VICTORY RELAXES GIANTS
description: Relief rolled across the lockers, brushing against each player for different reasons. The young Giants who had sparkled seemed to feel that finally, after a summer of trials, they had passed the last test. Any lingering anxiety was subdued, because finally, the coach's decision on whether they would remain Giants was out of their control. The exhibition season was over.

title: FIRST AUTOPSY RESULTS FAIL TO SHOW FACTORS CAUSING CAPOTE'S DEATH
description: The Los Angeles County coroner's office said today that an autopsy had failed to determine the cause of death of Truman Capote, who died here Saturday at the age of 59.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 27, 1984

title: Kudlow Firm Sold
description: Lawrence A. Kudlow, the former Wall Streeter who left his post last year as chief economist at the Office of Management and Budget to set up a consulting firm, has cashed in by selling it to the Rodman & Renshaw Capital Group Inc., a Chicago securities house. Mr. Kudlow, one of whose financial backers is Saul P. Steinberg, says he has been somewhat ''lucky'' to gain 53 bank and other institutional clients and first-year revenues of about $1 million. He declined to disclose the sales price.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.02

title: EXHAUST TAMPERING ON RISE
description: One in four late-model cars in a recent survey had at least one pollution-control device that had been tampered with, a sharp increase from an earlier survey, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: ;  Vote of Confidence
description: First he popped off at his bosses publicly. Then the team he coaches got eliminated in the first round of the Olympics. And then he failed to show up at a crucial tournament in which the national youth team is playing, where he was supposed to observe the young players.

title: BLEAK DAYS FOR FARM EQUIPMENT
description: For the past five years, the depressed farm equipment industry has been hoping for an upturn. But this year's high interest rates, drop in exports and weak grain prices have aggravated many farmers' cash-flow problems and have kept equipment orders extremely low.

title: Adina M. Avery Weds Harman M. Grossman
description: At Beth El Synagogue in New Rochelle, N.Y., yesterday Adina Michele Avery, a daughter of Cantor and Mrs. Lawrence Avery of New Rochelle, was married to Harman Michael Grossman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Grossman of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by Rabbis Melvin Sirner, Alvin Kass and Edward Feld, assisted by the bride's father.

title: GOMEZ IS BEATEN BY LENDL, 6-2, 6-4
description: When Andres Gomez was growing up in the seaside city of Guayaquil, Ecuador, he spent much of his free time at the beach. Occasionally, he would surf, and when he was older, he learned to water ski. Sometimes, he would just sit and watch the waves and read books about the ocean.

title: UGANDA'S LEADER DEFENDS HIS RULE
description: President Milton Obote, without referring specifically to allegations that thousands of people have been killed in his country, today defended the policies of his Government and army troops.

title: DUARTE TO STUDY POLITICAL SLAYINGS
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte has announced the formation of a special commission to investigate what appear to be politically-motivated killings, including the murder of the country's Roman Catholic Archbishop four years ago.

title: EXPERTS ON THINKING FEAR A DECLINE OF REASONING
description: A fear of mental powers lost, and hopes of paradigms regained, converged here this week in a conference on thinking.

title: Woman Turns Sprinkler Off Lawn After 1 1/2 Years
description: A 73-year-old woman who angered her neighbors for a year and a half by continuously watering her lawns has stopped the round-the-clock sprinkling.

title: URANIUM SHIPMENT WENT DOWN WITH FRENCH SHIP
description: A French cargo ship that sank off the coast of Belgium Saturday night was carrying containers filled with a form of uranium used to make fuel for nuclear reactors, the ship's owner and French Government officials said tonight.

title: MEXICAN PARTY'S MEETING: OLD PLOT, CHANGING CAST
description: The thousands of delegates crammed into the convention hall listened to speeches about bringing equality to society and renewing commitments to historic values. In awe they watched as a little- known congresswoman was thrust into the party's No. 2 slot, the first woman to be so honored in the nation's history.

title: Pell to Resign
description: Charley Pell, the football coach at the University of Florida, told his team today that he will not return as coach after the 1984 season, according to a published report based on comments from an assistant coach and three players.

title: STEEL CURB CONSENSUS IS FORMING
description: A consensus is building within the Reagan Administration to negotiate limits on steel imports with third world suppliers, including Brazil and South Korea, according to Administration trade officials. They said the limits would be part of plans being formulated to protect the domestic industry from foreign competition.

title: TOTS AT PLAY: A LITTLE PURPOSE WON'T HURT
description: To the Editor:

title: Blacks Charge Improper Use Of Fund to Restore Riot Area
description: A $6 million Federal emergency grant to revitalize areas torn by the 1980 Miami riots is not being used properly, black businessmen and leaders say.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ; SYMPATHY STRIKE
description: On this day in 1920, five actresses in an Irish repertory company in New York picketed futilely for a while in front of the British Consulate in support of Ireland's battle for independence, and then moved down to the docks, where their words had spectacular effect.

title: Stephen E. Kesselman Wed to Miss Fischbein
description: Margery Beth Fischbein, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome W. Fischbein of Newton, Mass., and Delray Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Stephen E. Kesselman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Kesselman of Highland Park, N.J. Rabbi Terry Bard performed the ceremony at the Belmont (Mass.) Country Club.

title: ;  Pirates 7, Reds 1
description: Brian Harper drove in three runs with a home run and a single to back Rick Rhoden's eight-hit pitching for Pittsburgh.

title: Wave Hill Is No Longer Best-Kept Secret in Bronx
description: ''Most institutions start out with a purpose,'' said Peter H. Sauer, executive director of Wave Hill, ''and look for a home. We had a home and needed a purpose.''

title: MALAYSIA'S REACH FOR INDUSTRY
description: For any country to make the transition from producer of raw materials to producer of finished goods is a formidable task. But this country, which wants to be industrialized by the end of the century, intends to try.

title: Brooklyn Man Drowns in Pool At a Jersey Amusement Park
description: A 20-year-old Brooklyn man drowned in a crowded swimming pool at Action Park amusement park, a park official said today.

title: SOUTHEAST, AWASH IN WATER, WORRIES OVER RUNNING SHORT
description: With its abundance of swamps and streams and wide, swollen rivers, the southeastern United States has always seemed a region rich in water resources, a humid landscape where water management has usually meant flood control.

title: AGILE KING HOPING MIAMI STUMBLES
description: David King's first cultural excursion in the New York metropolitan area occurred early this afternoon, more than 24 hours before the business portion of his trip.

title: Robin Wolfe Married To William L. Kaskel
description: Robin Jill Wolfe and William Lewis Kaskel were married yesterday at Congregation Sons of Israel in Upper Nyack, N.Y. Rabbi Norton L. Shargel performed the ceremony.

title: POLITICAL TALK AT FACTORY IS FERRARO AND HUSBAND
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro's finances, not President Reagan's nomination for a second term, were the talk of the Colso baking products factory lunchroom this week.

title: MOSCOW PURSUES PEACE
description: As a Russian, I would like to assure American readers that the Soviet Union had enough self-control to survive President Reagan's ''nuclear joke'' that he was outlawing Russia forever and preparing to bomb it in the next five minutes.

title: NEW CARS TO HAVE DEBUT ON THE MORRISTOWN LINE
description: Monday morning, in what officials are calling the start of a new era for commuters, rush- hour passengers on the Morristown Line of N.J. Transit will ride in modern Arrow III rail cars for the first time.

title: BERRY INDUSTRIES' CHIEF LEAVES UNDER PRESSURE
description: Arne Kalm has resigned as president and chief executive officer of Berry Industries, Charles B. Evans, Berry's chairman, said.

title: TRAITS SHARED BY MASS KILLERS REMAIN UNKNOWN TO EXPERTS
description: Before being convicted of murdering two women and a young girl in Florida and linked to the murders of 36 others, Theodore Bundy had helped the Seattle Crime Prevention Commission design a program for preventing rapes.

title: DANCE: JACOB'S PILLOW JAZZ PARADE
description: The Pillow Jazz Parade offered just about something for everyone tonight at the Ted Shawn Theater, as the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival gave students, faculty and guest artists a chance to perform. There was even a bit of Irish step dancing, and it nearly stopped the show.

title: ;  Mixing It Up
description: Golf, a game where accuracy generally counts more than distance, is one of the few sports in which men and women can compete on more or less equal terms. But even with the special equalizing factor for distance, separate ladies' tees, they seldom seem to.

title: Liberian Church Leaders Call for End to Arrests
description: Church leaders called on the Liberian leader, Gen. Samuel K. Doe, today to stop what they called arbitrary arrests and mysterious disappearances in an effort to end unrest in this West African nation.

title: Advertising; Growing Creatively At Y. & R.
description: ON Madison Avenue, the big cry always is for better creativity. But there's another cry that inevitably puts a strain on creativity - growth.

title: JAZZ: RAN BLAKE ON PIANO
description: As chairman of the Third Stream department at the New England Conservatory of Music, Ran Blake has worked to create music that melds jazz improvisation with classical structure. His own hybrid was heard Saturday, when Mr. Blake played a program of piano solos at the Jazz Center of New York. The material included old Sephardic songs, Mr. Blake's compositions, and a medley of Cole Porter, Thelonious Monk, John Philip Sousa and the soundtrack composer Bernard Hermann, among others.

title: WHEN A PUPIL IS HELD BACK
description: As vacation days dwindle down to

title: JOHN HENRY ROMPS IN ARLINGTON MILLION
description: It seemed as if everyone at Arlington Park was rooting for John Henry to win the Arlington Budweiser Million today, and the Methuselah of thoroughbred racing did not let them down. The 9-year-old gelding, whose entire career has defied time and credibility, won so easily that it was difficult to remember that horses of his age are supposed to be out to pasture.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BLOODS. An Oral History of the Vietnam

title: AN EVENT THAT REFLECTS THE CITY'S BRASH SPIRIT
description: Just beyond the rim of the Louis Armstrong Stadium at the National Tennis Center, the sky flushes pink and flames orange each evening shortly after 7 o'clock. The sun, a blazing ball, dips behind the silhouetted New York City skyline and a commuter train snakes across the horizon, silent in the distance, a pretty toy.

title: Suzanne Kelsey Becomes a Bride
description: Suzanne Courtney Kelsey, a sportswear buyer for Bergdorf Goodman, and Andrew Thomas Malloy, an account executive for Bear Stearns & Company, were married yesterday in the Manhattanville College Chapel in Purchase, N.Y. The Rev. James E. Hentges, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Georgia Voting Changes Put More Blacks in Office
description: A shift this year to elections by district has helped put more blacks in county offices in Georgia than at any time since Reconstruction, officials say.

title: Car Runs Into Bus Stop In Capital, Killing Seven
description: A mother and her three small children were among seven people killed when a car careened onto a sidewalk near a crowded bus stop, hurling some victims into the air and pinning others against a brick wall.

title: PRESSURES ON POLAND
description: The pressures of political geography that have shaped and reshaped Poland since the days of the Teutonic knights and Muscovite czars have increased perceptibly this summer, first in response to the prospect of German reconciliation and then in the wake of President Reagan's remarks challenging Soviet views of the Yalta agreement.

title: CAPITAL MAKES ANOTHER PITCH
description: WASHINGTON Unless you count their triumph in the 1955 Broadway musical ''Damn Yankees,'' the singularly inept Washington Senators won the American League pennant only three times in this century, and managed to get themselves hijacked not once, but twice, assuring them a dubious record in a sport that keeps track of almost everything.

title: A WILLIAM MORRIS EXECUTIVE
description: Abe Lastfogel, a talent agent who represented clients ranging from Marilyn Monroe to Frank Sinatra and built the William Morris Agency into one of the world's largest theatrical agencies, died of a heart attack Saturday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Hollywood. He was 86 years old and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: Bee Parasite Spreading
description: The Agriculture Department has confirmed that acarine mites, honeybee parasites found in Texas this summer in their first appearance in the United States, have spread to Louisiana. Mites were found earlier this week in a bee yard in New Iberia, La. Scientists have confirmed that the mites are the tiny parasites that can interfere with bees' ability to fly and result in large reductions in crop pollination.

title: LEARNING TO LIVE WITH A COLLEGE ROOMMATE
description: In the dormitories of Pennsylvania State University last week, freshmen sat down with their new roommates and traded views on drugs, alcohol, sex and religion.

title: MOSLEMS AND BEIRUT TROOPS CLASH ALONG THE GREEN LINE
description: Fighting between Moslem militiamen and Lebanese Army troops broke out along the Green Line in Beirut tonight for the first time since a security plan for the capital took effect on July 4.

title: ASTRONOMERS FIND QUASARS MAY MARK EDGE OF UNIVERSE
description: Astronomers said today that they had new evidence confirming that quasars, the mysterious, starlike objects that are the most powerful energy sources known, are near the edge the universe and are not simply illusions reflecting some unknown law of physics.

title: GOLF 'SERIES' WON BY DENIS WATSON
description: Denis Watson, a 28-year-old from Zimbabwe, gained his second victory on the PGA Tour today just two weeks after his first, beating Bruce Lietzke by two strokes in the World Series of Golf.

title: ;  Cardinals 3, Astros 2
description: Ozzie Smith drove in two runs, David Green had three hits and Bruce Sutter picked up his major league-leading 35th save as the Cardinals won. Sutter finished up for the rookie Kurt Kepshire (4-3).

title: BOTH PARTIES PUSH FOR WOMEN'S VOTE ON EQUALITY DAY
description: The rights and achievements of American women were feted at the White House and on the campaign trail yesterday as President Reagan and his Democratic rivals courted votes on the birthday of women's suffrage in the United States.

title: Brewers 6, Rangers 3
description: The Brewers' Bill Schroeder hit his 12th homer of the season and his fifth in the last five games.

title: MILLER TACKLES BEER MYSTERY
description: The question at the Miller Brewing Company is: When is it going to be Miller time again?

title: ABC'S 'VELVET,' AEROBICS AND SPYING
description: ''Velver,'' the ABC movie on Channel 7 at 9 tonight, will not do you irreparable damage. It is about four beautiful aerobics instructors who also do odd jobs in the spy business, and it is distinguished by its glossiness. Everything shines with a Southern California, capped-teeth roseate glow.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Common Stock column in Business Day Friday on an American Can Company offering incorrectly implied that it had just been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The filing took place Aug. 8 and the stock was priced and sold on Aug. 10.

title: MISJUDGMENT OF AN OVERCALL PROVES FATAL TO A DEFENDER If a player overcalls at the two-level with a broken suit when vulnerable, it is safe to assume that he has at least a six-card suit. If the expert in the East seat on the diagramed deal had taken this into account, he would have avoided a play that looked harmless but proved fatal.
description: The occasion was the North Jersey Double Knockout Team Championship. A team of New York stars had to fight hard to beat some rising young players, and did so in spite of the diagramed deal.

title: Results of Blood Tests Are Disputed by Union
description: Testimony before the National Transportation Safety Board indicated that alcohol in the blood of two Burlington Northern workers killed in a train collision in June was due to decomposition of their bodies, a union official has said.

title: Market Place; Biotechnology: Novo's Outlook
description: MONEY managers in the United States have come to expect a pattern of consistent earnings growth from Novo Industri A/S, the Danish company that became a popular way to play investments in biotechnology. Novo is the world's largest producer of enzymes for industrial uses and a leading manufacturer of insulin preparations used in treating diabetes.

title: MORE PEOPLE WAITING TO MARRY
description: More and more young Americans are putting off marriage, possibly to begin careers, according to a a new Census Bureau report saying that three-quarters of American men and more than half of American women under 25 are still single.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ashton-Tate, Culver City, Calif., a software publisher, has appointed Barry Berke vice president of operations.

title: Social Security Title
description: President Reagan is being urged

title: Fleeing Suspect Causes Gas Truck Explosion
description: Crews worked today to repair a downtown street that was damaged when a gasoline tank truck exploded, igniting utility poles, melting metal canoes at a store and forcing the evacuation of 1,500 people, the authorities said.

title: On the Record ; Mondale on Arms Control
description: Following are excerpts from remarks yesterday by Walter F. Mondale:

title: OF TIMBER, MEXICANS AND TAXES
description: A kind of hush has fallen over the forests and sawmills of the Pacific Northwest this summer as timber companies await a decision by Congress that would enable them to back out of deals they made with the Federal Government and, in the process, save more than $1.3 billion.

title: HOSPITAL ACCORD IS SAID TO CONTAIN STATE-AID CLAUSE
description: As union members prepared to vote tonight on a settlement to end New York's health-care strike, hospital officials said yesterday that the contract called on Governor Cuomo to provide more state funds if they should be needed to pay for higher labor costs.

title: Danish Price Reports
description: Danish consumer prices fell two- tenths of 1 percent in July from June, but were up 6.6 percent from a year earlier, the Bureau of Statistics said Friday.

title: Ship Grounded; 24 Rescued
description: A Coast Guard cutter rescued 24 people, including 19 Sea Scouts, from a 65-foot vessel that ran aground Saturday about 140 miles southeast of Juneau. The privately owned, wooden-hulled Propeller ran aground near Level Island 20 miles south of Petersburg, according to the Coast Guard. The cutter Cape Hatteras rescued the people on board and provided pumps for the vessel, which took on some water, the Coast Guard said.

title: BLUE JAYS EDGE TWINS BY 2-1
description: Dave Stieb pitched a four-hitter and Rance Mulliniks went 3 for 3 and scored both Toronto runs as the Blue Jays defeated the Minnesota Twins today, 2-1.

title: Helene Herman Weds Aaron Krupnick
description: Helene Sharon Herman, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Joseph Herman of Passaic, N.J., was married at Temple Emanuel there yesterday to Aaron Benjamin Krupnick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fredric Krupnick of Melrose Park, Pa. The bride's father, who is spiritual leader of the temple, performed the ceremony.

title: Pilot Says Sikh Hijackers Got Gun in Pakistan
description: The pilot and several passengers from a hijacked Indian airliner said today that their captors were given a pistol during a stopover in the Pakistani city of Lahore. In Islamabad, the Pakistani Foreign Ministry denied the accusation.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: With runners on first and third and one out, the batter from Team A hits a fly ball deep enough to enable both runners to tag up. After making the catch for the second out, the outfielder attempts to throw out the runner from third base, but fires the ball toward home plate too high for it to be cut off by an infielder. After the runner crosses the plate, though, the catcher for Team B makes a snap throw to second base, where the runner from first has rounded too far, and the runner is tagged for the third out. Under the rules, the run counts. But what if the runner from third left the base before the ball was caught by the outfielder and Team B wants to appeal the play? Can they do so, since there already are three outs?

title: DANCE: PERFORMANCE ON THE FERRY
description: There was dancing on the water on Friday night. But no one got wet. This was because all the dancing took place on a Staten Island ferry boat as it made journeys, beginning at 6:30 P.M., between Manhattan and Staten Island.

title: Jodi Daynard Married To Mark A. Polizzotti
description: Jodi Patricia Daynard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Saunders Daynard of Hartsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mark Allen Polizzotti, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mario Polizzotti of New Canaan, Conn. Rabbi Charles Lippman and the Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Scarborough, N.Y.

title: MUSIC: CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA IN TANGLEWOOD DEBUT
description: This weekend's concerts at Tanglewood were notable for several reasons. The orchestra was not the Boston Symphony, whose regular summer home this is, but the Cleveland Orchestra, making its Tanglewood debut. This is only the second orchestra other than the Bostonians to perform here, the first having been the New York Philharmonic in 1979, and both times the reason was the same: The Boston Symphony left Tanglewood early for a European tour.

title: TRW AIDE NAMED GENCORP PRESIDENT
description: -ranking official at TRW Inc., has been named president and chief operating officer of Gencorp Inc., formerly the General Tire and Rubber Company, it was announced this weekend. The appointment, effective immediately, is subject to approval by Gencorp directors at a meeting Sept. 6.

title: New Deutsch Accounts
description: David Deutsch Associates has added three new accounts with combined billings of $2 million.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Washington Aug. 16 on testimony by the Governor of Pennsylvania on safety questions about the Three Mile Island nuclear power station incorrectly described actions taken by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. The commission voted in closed session Jan. 26 and in a public vote Jan. 27 to proceed toward a decision on restarting the plant's undamaged Unit 1 without waiting for a number of incomplete investigations of the reactor operators. On Feb. 10, the United States ruled only that closed meetings of the N.R.C. on this issue were invalid.

title: SALVADORANS USE VIDEO IN THE PROPAGANDA WAR
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini inspired his followers on tape cassettes. The Salvadoran guerrillas now promote their cause on Betamax - and the Government is battling back in kind.

title: Treasury Is Active This Week
description: The United States Treasury will be active in the debt market this week, with auctions of Treasury bills as well as a note issue due in five years, two months.

title: LOOKIN' TO GET LUCKY
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.

title: 8 Killed Near Naples In Gangland Vendetta
description: Fifteen men with hunting rifles leaped from a 50-seat private bus outside a church in a Naples suburb today and killed eight people and wounded five in what the police said was an organized crime vendetta.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 27, 1984: MONDAY PetrolaneRepublic CorpRio Grande IndusStandard ProductsWatkins-Johnson

title: FULFILLING A PROMISE, ARZOBISPO O'CONNOR SAYS A SPECIAL MASS
description: Before nearly 10,000 people standing on a carpet of grass, Archbishop John J. O'Connor walked up to the pulpit at the outdoor Shrine of Marian here this morning.

title: MONDALE ACCUSES PRESIDENT OF OPPOSING ARMS CONTROLS
description: Walter F. Mondale said today that President Reagan had a ''hang-up'' about arms control and accused him of following ''very, very dangerous'' policies on nuclear weapons.

title: Any Way You Say It, It's Franglais
description: Even the Alliance Fran,caise, that

title: The Sakharov Tapes It's no accident, to use a comradely locution, that videotapes have reached the West purporting to show Andrei Sakharov and his wife, Yelena Bonner, in good health. Though Soviet leaders pretend indifference to protests against the mistreatment of the couple, it is just that - a pretense. Only the gravest concern, you may be sure, caused them to make such films available in the West, reputedly through Victor Louis, the Soviet operative who often serves as unofficial press broker for the K.G.B.
description: This is as close as the Soviet Union has come to acknowledging the world's concern over the Sakharovs. Some footage was apparently filmed in July, without the knowledge of the Nobel laureate and his ailing wife.

title: ;  In the Saddle Again
description: His teammates on the Mets' Little Falls farm club started off calling him ''Cowboy,'' and not because he sometimes wears western boots.

title: CUBS WIN ON DURHAM'S HITS
description: Leon Durham broke out of a 1-for-21 slump by blasting two home runs and driving in four runs while Steve Trout scattered eight hits today, giving the Chicago Cubs a 5-0 triumph over the Atlanta Braves.

title: THE U.S.-FUNDED FOREIGN ASSAULT ON THE U.S. COPPER INDUSTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: MONDAY, AUGUST 27, 1984 International
description: Shimon Peres was given 21 more days to form an Israeli government coalition. The additional time was granted to Mr. Peres, the head of the Labor Alignment, by President Chaim Herzog. Mr. Peres said a ''great deal of progress'' had been made in the first 21 days of his mandate and agreement had been reached on several issues with the rival Likud bloc. (Page A1, Column 5.) Containers of uranium were carried by a French cargo ship that sank off Belgium Saturday night after colliding with a Dutch ferry, the ship's owner and French Government officials said. The uranium is used to make fuel for nuclear reactors and is mildly radioactive. But a French environmental official said there was no indication that any of the 30 separate uranium containers had broken when the cargo ship and the ferry struck each other. (A1:3.)

title: CHICAGO PROSTITUTION INVESTIGATED
description: Federal law- enforcement authorities said today that they had concluded a 42-month undercover investigation of a $75-million- a-year prostitution business in the Chicago area.

title: Kidnap Victim's Body Is Found Near Miami
description: A body found in a ditch six days ago was identified Saturday as that of a 22-year-old man kidnapped for ransom by two men and a woman who said they were members of a terrorist group.

title: A BLUEFISH IN LONG ISLAND SOUND IS THE $1 MILLION THAT GOT AWAY
description: Somewhere out in Long Island Sound this weekend was a fish worth a million dollars. And everywhere out on Long Island Sound this weekend there were fishermen trying to catch it.

title: LEWIS AND MOSES WIN AT COLOGNE MEET
description: Carl Lewis won a 200- meter race and Edwin Moses posted his 108th straight victory in the 400-meter hurdles today at the International Cologne Sports Festival track and field meet.

title: LENDL DEVELOPS A LIGHTER TOUCH
description: He had battled dozens of irresolute umpires in his day, hundreds of unruly fans, even an occasional top-ranked player or two throughout his eccentric career as perhaps the most volatile player ever to swing a tennis racquet. Yet this was going to be an entirely different challenge. Ilie Nastase knew that well enough as he strode boldly onto the bright and breezy center court at the Hamlet East, a high-priced condominium complex in Jericho, L.I., one evening last week for his opening- round match in an exhibition tournament that is a tune-up for this week's United States Open.

title: MOSCOW'S HARD LINE GETS A BOOST
description: To the Editor:

title: PERES IS GIVEN 21 MORE DAYS FOR CABINET BID
description: President Chaim Herzog today gave Shimon Peres, head of the Labor Alignment, an additional 21 days to form an Israeli government coalition. The move had been expected.

title: Complacency Worries A Top Aide to Reagan
description: James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, said today that the Reagan campaign was worried that Republicans across the country were too complacent about the President's re-election chances in November.

title: 3 Are Injured as Boat Blows Up in Hudson
description: Three people were injured, two of them seriously, when a boat they were on exploded and burst into flames today while it was being launched into the Hudson River near the George Washington Bridge, authorities said.

title: 'RIVIERA OF THE BRONX' SHINES AGAIN
description: The people of the Bronx never stopped coming; where else would you go on a hot day other than Orchard Beach? But for a few years, an afternoon spent beside its waters seemed less an escape from the city than yet another urban trial to be endured.

title: HEAD OF RB INDUSTIRES GOES BACK TO INVESTING
description: James A. Nathan has resigned as president and chief executive officer of RB Industries, a retail furniture chain.

title: OPEL STRATEGY TIED TO SPORTY NEW CAR
description: Adam Opel A.G., the European subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, is introducing a model next month that highlights broad changes in the company's production and design strategies. The new model may help the company reverse a slide in its key West German market.

title: Prost Captures Dutch Grand Prix
description: Alain Prost of France finished in first place, and his teammate, Niki Lauda of Austria, was second in the Dutch Grand Prix today in another sweeping victory for the McLaren-TAG-Porsche team

title: U.S. WEALTH, NOT FOREIGN POVERTY, COMES FIRST
description: Stanley Barr runs a shoe factory in Seabrook, N.H. Ivanio Batista represents the shoe manufacturers of Franca, a provincial city in the state of Rio Grande do Sol, Brazil. They are joined in a tale of the international economy.

title: ROXY PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: INTERMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Net loss including a tax credit of $6,052,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Including a tax credit of $1,223,000. Results for the latest 9 months reflect restatement of first quarter results to recognize the effects of the Tax Reform Act of 1984 on previously deferred income taxes.

title: Dow Futures Plan Dropped
description: The Toronto Futures Exchange has withdrawn its proposal to trade a futures contract based on the 30 stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average. Dow Jones & Company, which compiles the average, had opposed the idea, saying it would go to court to block it if necessary.

title: 5th Chicagoan Is Held In Prostitution Inquiry
description: A fifth arrest was made today in connection with a three-year inquiry into organized criminal ties to prostitution in Chicago's suburbs, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced.

title: MOSCOW ASSERTS STRATEGIC PARITY
description: In a newly revised publication on American military power, the Soviet Government reiterates assertions that the Reagan Administration is seeking military superiority and maintains that East and West are in rough strategic balance.

title: ISRAELI RIVALS AGREE TO DISAGREE ON SOME UNRESOLVED ISSUES
description: Shimon Peres and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said tonight after their longest in a series of talks on establishing a national unity government that they had agreed on a formula for dealing with issues they could not resolve.

title: Weighing In
description: Washington may not be the weight-watching capital of the nation, but weight is discussed here regularly, sometimes with malice.

title: SYRIAN LEADER VISITS LIBYANS AMID REPORTS OF DIFFERENCES
description: President Hafez el-Assad of Syria, who visited here last week, returned to Libya Sunday night for more talks with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi that are believed to have centered on several issues that have strained their usually close relations, according to diplomats here.

title: Topics ; Learning by Example
description: Help, at Last

title: Stolen Alaskan Art Recovered in Seattle
description: Five 19th-century Alaskan native artifacts worth more than $1.5 million that disappeared last April from a village where two clans disputed their ownership have turned up in Seattle, according to the police.

title: Sun Refining
description: The Sun Refining and Marketing Company said it had reduced its cargo and barge price for No. 2 fuel oil, the basic component of heating oil and diesel fuel, 0.75 cent a gallon, to 79.75 cents, effective Saturday. In four moves earlier this month, the Sun Company subsidiary raised its wholesale No. 2 fuel oil prices a total of 4.5 cents a gallon.

title: 22 BANDS PLAYED ON, AT 2-DAY IRISH FESTIVAL
description: FOXBORO, Mass.

title: Texaco Filing
description: Texaco, striving to reduce short- term debt incurred from its $10.1 billion acquisition of the Getty Oil Company earlier this year, has filed a registration statement for $1 billion of debt securities with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The securities, which may be sold whenever the company chooses, will be issued by Texaco Capital, and guaranteed by Texaco. Since early June, Texaco has sold $1.5 billion of notes in the domestic market.

title: People
description: * Kathie McKirdy has been elected a senior vice president of Needham, Harper & Steers/USA.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Cordero Captures Title at Saratoga
description: Tiltalating won the Spinaway Stakes for 2-year-old fillies on closing day at Saratoga Race Track today to insure that her jockey, Angel Cordero Jr., would win his ninth consecutive riding title here.

title: U.S. BALANCED BUDGET MEASURE TAKEN OFF BALLOT
description: In a move that may have stalled the drive for a Federal constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget, the State Supreme Court today removed a voter- initiated measure on that issue from the November ballot.

title: REACH OUT AND PORN SOMEONE
description: Pornography is the new family value. People call the cops to chase prostitutes out of their neighborhoods, but pornography has become as American as, well, your telephone.

title: SHANLEY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring extraordinary gain of $683,170. Corrected from Saturday's editions.

title: Mozart 'Impresario' Billed
description: An updated version of Mozart's one-act comic opera ''The Impresario'' will be presented, in English, by the Opera for Our Time Repertory Company on Sept. 19 at the Paper Moon Cabaret, 82 West Third St. Admission is $5. Reservations: 477-0622.

title: DEBATE SPACE WEAPONS
description: Is the function of a Presidential campaign to score debating points or to educate the public on the most important issues facing the nation and the world? Unfortunately, this time around, the opportunity for debate on the fundamental issues has been lost in a welter of charges and countercharges about issues of vastly less significance - and meanwhile the prospects for a September meeting between the United States and the Soviet Union on the threat of the militarization of outer space have gone glimmering.

title: Cotton Stocks
description: Off Sharply WASHINGTON, Aug. 27

title: NOTES ON FASHIONS
description: HERE it was the sunniest week of the summer, with work the last thing on anyone's mind, and there was Diane Von Furstenberg talking nonstop about her first store and her first couture collection.

title: SCAN-TRON CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Comings and Goings The New Jersey Devils have acquired the goaltender
description: Sam St. Laurent from the Philadelphia Flyers for future considerations. St. Laurent has played all or parts of the last five seasons with the Maine Mariners of the American Hockey League and was the club's top goaltender last season when the Mariners won the Calder Cup. . . . Bo Diaz, the Philadelphia Phillies catcher, underwent arthroscopic surgery to repair torn cartilage in his left knee and will be out the rest of the season, the team said.

title: Family Planning Isn't Socialism
description: Even the most insightful and widely accepted theories can sometimes be pressed into the service of gibberish. Consider the argument, advanced by the Reagan Administration against family planning, that poor societies should stop worrying about all those mouths to feed and get on with the business of free enterprise.

title: Wells Fargo Offer
description: Wells Fargo & Company is offering $150 million of 13 1/2 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The notes, which are rated A-2 by Moody's and Ax by Standard & Poor's, were offered with a yield seven-tenths of 1 percent more than seven-year Treasury notes.

title: GOODEN WINS, FANS 12
description: Fernando Valenzuela, who not long ago was an awesome rookie himself, has learned for the second time this season what it must have been like for older pitchers to pitch against him in 1981.

title: EARLY BIRD GETS THE GOLD
description: To say that American television rules the

title: MET-PRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Break-In ReportedAt Transit Agency
description: Someone broke into the law offices of the Transit Authority over the weekend and stole a portable radio, the transit police reported yesterday.

title: VARLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 4
SUMMIT OILFIELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $96,637 for the quarter and $163,312 for the 6 months.

title: A Trying Rise for Annacone
description: When you're fresh out of college, and have decided to embark on a career as a professional tennis player, every penny counts. That is why Paul Annacone, who was ranked No. 243 in the world last June, cringed at the date on his return-trip airplane ticket from London, where he was playing in his first pro tournament, Wimbledon. It read July 5, which meant that Annacone would have to remain overseas for almost two weeks if he failed to survive the qualifying rounds and gain a place in the main draw.

title: Even the Bird Wore Blue
description: A young woman emerged from the

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Capital Holding Corp., Louisville, Ky., has named Robert W. Crispin and Thomas H. Schnick senior vice presidents.

title: CHICAGO, SINGAPORE NEAR FUTURES LINK
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission on Tuesday is expected to approve a link between the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Singapore International Monetary Exchange. The link would be an important step toward creating the first round-the-clock market for a United States exchange.

title: Sweden Surplus Down
description: Sweden had a current account surplus of 400 million kronor, or about $48.1 million, in June, down from a revised 500 million kronor surplus in May and 1.9 billion kronor surplus in June 1983, the central bank said today. The current account measures a country's international dealings in merchandise and services.

title: CIVIC LEADERS PLANNING REFORMS FOR ATLANTA ZOO
description: The story of the Atlanta zoo began to unfold earlier this summer like scenes from some macabre children's story.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: HUGH MASEKELA The South African trumpeter Hugh Masekela got his first instrument after watching the movie ''Young Man With a Horn'' at the age of 13. He took lessons and played in a be-bop band. But, he notes, there were no opportunities in South Africa for blacks to get a proper musical education. So, in 1960, he left for London and then New York, where he studied classical and jazz trumpet at the Manhattan School of Music and became a protege of Harry Belafonte, Miriam Makeba and Dizzy Gillespie.

title: 2D QUARTER PRODUCTIVITY INCREASED AT A 4.7% PACE
description: Business productivity jumped at an annual rate of 4.7 percent in the second quarter, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Ulster Dockers Reject Strike
description: Longshoremen at two ports in Northern Ireland voted today to defy a three-day-old British dock strike, in a growing rebellion against the walkout called to support the 24-week-old strike by coal miners.

title: Ratings Review
description: * City Investing Co.'s senior notes and sinking fund debentures, rated Ba1, and the $2.875 convertible exchangeable preference stock, rated ba2, are under review by Moody's because of City Investing's recently announced agreement to sell three units to an investor group for $1.25 billion in cash.

title: Comedy Contest
description: Did you hear the story about the 60

title: Arundel Purchase
description: The Phoenix Management Corporation, a Cockeysville, Md., investment adviser, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its holdings of common stock of the Arundel Corporation to 302,100 shares, or 15 percent of the total outstanding.

title: Managua Says It Shot Down Plane With Arms for Rebels
description: A cargo plane dropping arms and supplies to anti-Sandinista rebels in northern Nicaragua was shot down today by Government soldiers, the Ministry of Defense announced.

title: BUSY TIME IN POLITICAL CAMPAIGNS
description: THIS week is the calm before the

title: BEYOND KANGAROOS, BILLABONGS AND KOALAS
description: Since taking up his post here two years ago as Australia's Ambassador to the United States, Sir Robert Cotton has discovered that Americans experience a bit of a tussle when it comes to titles.

title: A Visit to the Museum
description: Marjorie Phillips, a painter who is the widow of Duncan Phillips, the founder of the Phillips Collection, the first modern art museum in the country, is 89 years old and in frail health. She was unable to attend ceremonies last June surrounding the museum's exhibition of paintings by Pierre Bonnard, which closed Sunday. Mrs. Phillips had helped her husband choose and buy Bonnard works 60 years ago, and the work of that post-Impressionist painter had influenced her own painting.

title: ABUSE AT CENTERS: UNDERLYING FLAWS
description: REPORTS of sexual abuse of children, even of infants, in day-care institutions have shocked the nation, provoking demands for harsh penalties and instant reforms.

title: SYSTEMS ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Daily News SuedBy U.S. Over Bias
description: The Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed suit yesterday against The Daily News, charging that it had discriminated against black reporters.

title: Zimbabwe Re-estimates Guerrillas in Grave Site
description: At least 10,000 black nationalist guerrillas who fought against white rule when this country was known as Rhodesia were buried in shallow graves southeast of here, Information Minister Nathan Shamuyarira said Sunday night.

title: McCann Official JoiningNeedham in New York
description: James Kuras, the 44-year-old executive vice president and general manager of McCann-Erickson/New York, will join Needham, Harper & Steers/USA as president of the agency's New York office on Sept. 4.

title: DAY-CARE JOB STANDARDS UNDER STUDY
description: An 18-year-old individual at an eighth-grade literacy level meets New York City's minimum standards for a teacher's aide at a city-financed day- care center.

title: SWAB-FOX COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
VICORP RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 22
description: The shares outstanding were adjusted for 2-for-1 stock split in August 1983.

title: DR. A. M. WOODRUFF, ECONOMIST
description: Dr. Archibald M. Woodruff, a land and taxation economist and former president of the University of Hartford, died of lymphatic cancer Sunday in Farmington, Conn., at the John N. Dempsey Hospital of the University of Connecticut Health Center. He was 72 years old and lived in Bloomfield, Conn.

title: Fire Kills 7 Turks in Germany
description: Seven members of a Turkish family, including a six-week-old baby and three other children, died today in a fire in their apartment building here, the police said. The family's father returned home as fire was raging through the building.

title: FLUOROCARBON CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BUELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
YANKS WASTE LEAD, THEN RALLY TO WIN
description: The Yankees continued their West Coast joyride tonight, but it took some late heroics by Bobby Meacham to give New York an 8-7 victory over the A's.

title: White House Goes to Records
description: The White House made an effort today to back up a contention by Mr. Bush that Mr. Mondale had wanted to halt missile deployments in Europe and scrap the Trident 2 missile.

title: WILEY, JOHN & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Revco Dissidents Seek Stock List
description: A group of dissident shareholders of Revco D.S. Inc. told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had asked management for a copy of the company's shareholder list. The group also said it had retained Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and Martin Wygod to advise it.

title: U.S. MODERN DANCERS SPREAD MESSAGE IN JAPAN
description: During her 26 years as an American Dance Festival instructor, the modern dancer Betty Jones has traveled all over the United States following the annual summer- dance program to its various homes in California, Connecticut and most recently North Carolina. But this summer was different; Miss Jones came to Japan.

title: FIGHTING IN BEIRUT INCREASES FEARS THAT ARMY COULD AGAIN BREAK UP
description: Military and political sources said today that fears that Lebanon's Army could again break apart along religious lines have increased in the aftermath of the fighting Sunday along the Green Line dividing the two parts of the city.

title: INQUIRY ON MURDERS IN HAWAII BRINGS GOVERNOR AND PROSECUTOR INTO CONFLICT
description: An investigation of gangland-style murders has brought the Honolulu prosecutor, a Republican, and the Democratic Governor, George Ariyoshi, into a public conflict that has significant implications for the state's political future.

title: Morrison Pact
description: The Morrison-Knudsen Company said its National Steel and Shipbuilding unit had received a $250 million contract from the Exxon Corporation to build two tankers. The company said the tankers, each 987 feet long and weighing 209,000 deadweight tons, would transport crude oil between Valdez, Alaska, and Panama. Including the new contract, the company said its subsidiary had an $820 million backlog.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am directing N.A.S.A. to begin a search in all of our elementary and secondary schools and to choose as the first citizen passenger in the history of our space program one of America's finest: a teacher.'' - President Reagan. (A1:6.)

title: Japan Vehicle Output
description: Japan's auto makers built 1.03 million cars, trucks and buses in July, up 2.8 percent from July 1983, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers' Association said today. The association cited strong truck production for the fourth consecutive year-on-year rise.

title: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 4
TESLA, A BIZARRE GENIUS, REGAINS AURA OF GREATNESS
description: THE world of science is belatedly recognizing the genius of one of its most important, eccentric and enigmatic inventors, Nikola Tesla.

title: CARLSBERG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,345,000 for the quarter and $1,985,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $955,000 for the quarter and $2,014,000 for the year.

title: CLOTHES THAT LOVE LIFE IN A WARM CLIMATE
description: An expanse of pristine white linen contrasts with the glitter of sequins and beads. Full flaring shorts bare the knees, while skirts fall in a plumb line to or ripple around the ankles.

title: A Senate Hurdle for Women, and Others The Congress that recessed last week has an important duty on its return next month: to pass the proposed Civil Rights Act of 1984, designed to insure that Federal money doesn't subsidize discrimination. Opponents, including the Reagan Administration, may waste precious days with obstructionist tactics, yet the time will be well spent. When the tumult dies down, an expected large majority of the Senate can vote to reinvigorate key civil rights laws.
description: The bill should have been law by now. The House passed it, 375 to 32, in June but Senator Orrin Hatch of Utah, who calls it the ''Civil Privileges Act of 1984,'' has delayed it with diversionary amendments. There has nonetheless now been a big advance. Just before the recess the Senate majority leader, Howard Baker, agreed with the bill's sponsors that the time for floor action had arrived.

title: THE WAR OF WORDS IN WARSAW
description: Every Saturday for the last few months, a columnist in an officially supported Polish weekly has assailed columnists for a rival weekly, also backed by the Government, for such things as living too well and being too soft on private vendors who sell single avocados for $10.

title: MIAMI WINS KICKOFF CLASSIC
description: Bernie Kosar threw for 329 yards and Greg Cox kicked the first two field goals of his college career in the fourth quarter tonight to give Miami a 20-18 victory over Auburn in the second Kickoff Classic at Giants Stadium.

title: Lost and Found
description: It's a good thing the Giants don't have a road game with the league-champion Raiders this season.

title: FILIPINOS ARE OF 2 MINDS ABOUT THE U.S.
description: The Philippines has seemed at times to be a nation brimming with anti-American sentiment. In the anti-Government demonstrations last week, the United States trailed only President Ferdinand E. Marcos as a target of criticism.

MATRIX SCIENCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bogota Backs Stable Prices
description: Colombia will work toward continued stability of coffee prices on the international market in the wake of a freeze damaging part of Brazil's coffee crop, the Colombian Coffee Federation said today.

title: Revelations
description: In preparation for the publication of the Rangers' yearbook, some 60 questionnaires were sent to the players who will report to training camp Sept. 17 at Rye, N.Y. The forms asked the players to respond to specific questions dealing with their likes and dislikes on and off the ice, hobbies and life styles that might interest the fans.

title: Arrow Air Appoints Chief Operating Officer
description: Grant G. Murray has been named president and chief operating officer of Arrow Air, it was announced yesterday.

title: Union Says L.I. NursesWere 'Pushed' to Strike
description: The 175 striking nurses at Southampton Hospital were ''pushed to the wall'' or they would not have walked off the job Sunday, said a union spokesman, Cathy Holland.

title: Danspace 10th Anniversary
description: The 10th anniversary of the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church will be marked on Oct. 13 and 14 with performances by Bebe Miller, Dana Reitz, Joan Jonas and other dancers.

title: Studio 54 Sued
description: David Thompson of the Seattle SuperSonics has filed a $20 million lawsuit against the owners of the Studio 54 discotheque in Manhattan, charging that its employees may have ended his career by assaulting him. In the suit, filed in United States District Court in Manhattan, the 6-foot- 4-inch guard charged that, as a result of a beating he suffered inside the club last March 10, his ''career as a professional basketball player has been placed in severe jeopardy and may not be continued.'' He said the beating caused him to miss most of the 1983-84 season and also caused a permanent knee injury.

description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $2.4 million from the sale the the company's card and gift stores.

title: Xerox Debentures
description: The Xerox Corporation is selling $100 million of 13 1/4 percent debentures due in 2014 at a price of 99 5/8 to yield 13.30 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The debentures, which are not callable for 10 years, are rated Aa-2 by Moody's and AA- by Standard & Poor's.

title: MUSIC: 'DEAD END' AT BATTERY PARK
description: CREATIVE Time's ''Art on the Beach'' series at the Battery Park Landfill continued Sunday afternoon with a performance by the saxophonist Peter Gordon, framed in an ''installation'' entitled ''Dead End,'' by Mac Adams and Henry Smith-Miller.

description: The radioactive material on board the freighter that sank in the English Channel Saturday was part of a lively international trade in the raw materials for nuclear reactor fuel, according to experts in the field.
