title: Foodarama Off
description: Interstate Properties, a real estate partnership based in Paramus, N.J., told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had reduced its holdings in Foodarama Supermarkets Inc. common stock to 111,600 shares, or 8.3 percent of the total outstanding. Interstate said it had sold a total of 21,000 shares since July 19. Foodarama, based in Freehold, N.J., dropped $1.75, to $7.50, today on the American Stock Exchange, where it was the biggest percentage loser.

title: Steel Output
description: Shows Drop By The Associated Press Steel production fell to 1.523

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: DETROIT (AL) - Acquired Bill Scherrer, left-handed reliever, from Cincinnati in exchange for cash and a player to be named.

title: CHARISMA? WASHINGTON? MADISON? JEFFERSON?
description: Presidential candidates generally look too small for the job until they have been elected. Then the trappings of office and the fierce concentration of the media add 10 or 12 inches to their stature overnight. The phenomenon, which might be called Tom Thumb's Law, is as old as politics, but television has greatly heightened its effect by displaying, day after day, the challenger's desperate struggle to look Presidential while his incumbent opponent has only to stand tall to the strains of ''Hail to the Chief.'' It is not surprising then that Walter F. Mondale gives off something less than an aura of Presidential authority. What is to be wondered at is that so many liberal Democrats, especially those encountered at New York cocktail parties, are disappointed about this and make no secret of it. The sad word in these circles is that the former Vice President has had a charisma bypass.

title: Stanley S. Surrey, 74;Taxation Law Expert
description: Stanley S. Surrey, an expert on tax law who served as an Assistant Treasury Secretary in the 1960's, died at Brigham and Women's Hospital here today at the age of 74.

title: ORGAN MUSIC: BRUCE NESWICK AT TRINITY CHURCH
description: FOR the fourth installment in Trinity Church's August Sunday evening organ series, Bruce Neswick, the organist of St. Paul's Cathedral in Buffalo, chose two grandly scaled sacred works of Olivier Messiaen, the ''Mass of the Pentecost'' and ''The Ascension.''

title: A STRIKE FULL OF ERRORS
description: The strike by hospital workers has been so marked by errors, bitterness and disintegrating agreements that those involved say they have never witnessed a labor dispute quite its equal. There were a number of reasons that set this strike apart; among them, the interest of the city's municipal union leaders, who are in the process of negotiating contracts for their 250,000 members. The leaders have been mindful of the influence a hospital settlement, particularly a modest one, would have on their talks, and their position was felt at the negotiations.

title: 40,000 Acres in Montana Burned in Series of Fires
description: A swarm of blazes, most of them out of control, continued to rage today in central and eastern Montana, where 40,000 acres of range and timberland have been blackened since Saturday, officials said.

title: CABINETS WORTH A LOOK
description: To the Editor:

title: Calvin Klein, Kayser-Roth
description: The Kayser-Roth Corporation has acquired the women's underwear division of Calvin Klein Industries and the use of the designer's name for that business, the companies said.

title: REGIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ex-F.B.I. Agent Admits Extortion
description: A former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation pleaded guilty yesterday to extortion and other charges stemming from his demands for payoffs for helping a confessed mail thief get his sentencing postponed.

title: A NEW CLASS OF STOCK IS PROPOSED BY HERSHEY
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation's directors yesterday proposed issuing a new class of common stock as part of a plan to raise new capital while insuring voting control remains in the hands of a company-founded school for orphans.

title: Horse Sense
description: Horses have feelings, too. For many

title: FRANCE SEES NO NUCLEAR LEAK FROM SHIP
description: French officials continued today to give assurances that no dangerous materials were released into the environment as a result of the sinking in the English Channel of a French freighter that was carrying uranium bound for the Soviet Union. Environmentalist groups accused French industry and Government leaders of secrecy and carelessness in transporting nuclear substances.

title: Pell to Step DownThe University of Florida accepted the resignation of
description: Charley Pell, head football coach, yesterday, but Marshall Criser, incoming school president, said the school would determine how long Pell will coach this season. Pell, whose program has been under investigation for 20 months, reportedly for numerous recruiting violations, submitted his hand-written resignation Sunday.

title: MAYORAL MASCOT IS LOST AND FOUND
description: Every dog has his day, and today, Archie, a 3-foot-tall mutt that looks like a Labrador retriever will step before the City Hall press corps for a noon news conference.

title: CRUISE MISSILES: WHAT THEY ARE AND DO
description: The cruise missile is an advanced type of military technology that is playing an increasingly important role in the arsenals of both superpowers, according to weapons experts.

title: Crack Closes LaneOf Norwalk Bridge
description: The center lane of a bridge on the Connecticut Turnpike in Norwalk was closed today after inspectors found a crack in one of its supports, state transportation officials said.

title: A FILIPINO EX-SENATOR REBUFFED BY THE PEOPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Offer For Miami Bank Company
description: Hugh F. Culverhouse, a Tampa lawyer and owner of the National Football League's Tampa Bay Bucaneers, offered $27 a share to acquire control of Florida Commercial Banks Inc. of Miami. Mr. Culverhouse ha been maneuvering to gain control of Florida Commercial, a bank-holding company with assets of $773 million, since late last year.

title: TUESDAY, AUGUST 28, 1984 Companies
description: Atlantic Richfield said it would take a $785 million write-down against third-quarter after-tax earnings in its troubled metals and minerals businesses, which it intends to sell. With the sales proceeds, it plans to buy 25 million of its shares, probably during the next six months. (Page D1.)

title: Seoul Is Spurned
description: North Korea rejected a South Korean proposal today to reopen talks aimed at forming single teams for future international sports events, including the 1988 Summer Olympics, the South Korean Amateur Sports Association said. The North Korean decision, conveyed in a letter delivered in Panmunjom, held South Korea responsible for the failure to field a single team for the recent Games in Los Angeles.

title: Chess:Soviet Emigres Tie for First In United States Open Play
description: Roman Dzindzichashvili, a 40-year- old Soviet emigre grandmaster from Queens, and Sergey Kudrin, a 24- year-old Russian emigre international master from Stamford, Conn., tied for first place in the United States Open Championship.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Oklahoma Housing Bonds Priced
description: A $200 million bond issue of the Oklahoma Housing Finance Agency was tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 10 1/4 percent for bonds due in 2008 through underwriters led by Stifel, Nicolaus & Company, a St. Louis-based firm. For shorter maturities, yields ranged from 7 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 10 percent in 2000 and 10 1/8 percent in 2004.

title: Portrait of a Writer Truman Capote was a famous writer by the time he was 23 for his first novel, ''Other Voices, Other Rooms,'' and for his photograph on the dust jacket. It showed a blond young man reclining on a chaise longue and fixing the world with a fawn's big- eyed stare. He was the spitting image of the novel's hero, Joel Knox - ''too pretty, too delicate and fair- skinned'' - and, in every sense, a new face in American writing.
description: There were hundreds of photographs in the years that followed: the ''tiny terror,'' as gossip columnists called him, dancing with heiresses, dining with movie stars, chattering on talk shows. There were, in fact, so many images that after a while they buried the man.

title: Chief Merrill Economist Given New Assignment
description: Jack W. Lavery, who has been chief economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, since 1981, yesterday was named director of securities and economic research at the firm. The appointment is effective Sept. 1.

title: THE U.S. RESPONSE ON CRUISE MISSILES
description: The Reagan Administration said today that the Soviet Union had been developing cruise missiles ''long before'' the deployment of new American-made medium-range missiles in Europe last December.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. The Cubs are playing a doubleheader today, so this is a particularly good chance for the Mets to try to make up some ground.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Washington Thursday about investigations into reported problems with brakes in General Motors X-model cars contained two inaccuracies. It should have said that a Federal case against General Motors focused on allegations that the brakes had a tendency to lock, not that Federal officials had found a high incidence of brakes locking. Also, the case is a civil suit, not a criminal action.

title: Group at Household To Discuss Options
description: An investment group led by a dissident board member of Household International Inc. disclosed yesterday that it intends to discuss with other shareholders proposals that may involve the merger or sale of some or all of Household's businesses.

title: African Exhibition to Open
description: ''Beauty by Design: The Aesthetics of African Adornment,'' an exhibition of over 100 objects, will open on Sept. 19 at the African-American Institute, 833 United Nations Plaza, First Avenue and 47th Street.

title: Madeline R. Lee and Martin Horwitz Are Married
description: Madeline R. Lee, a daughter of Leo C. Rosten of New York, the writer, and the late Priscilla Mead Rosten, was married yesterday to Martin Horwitz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Horwitz of Los Angeles. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Bienstock in Wallkill, N.Y.

title: TAKING THE MEASURE, OR MISMEASURE, OF IT ALL
description: The Urban Institute, a private, nonprofit research organization, set the town abuzz a few days ago when it issued a 415-page report concluding that President Reagan's domestic policies had ''helped the affluent, but were detrimental to the poor and the middle class.''

title: FIRST SHUTTLE RIDE BY PRIVATE CITIZEN TO GO TO TEACHER
description: President Reagan announced today that an elementary or secondary schoolteacher would be chosen as the first ''citizen passenger'' to fly into space aboard the space shuttle.

title: MISTLER, NEILL CUT; GIANTS GET KENNY HILL
description: With moves on different fronts, the Giants announced today a set of changes that continued to overhaul their team.

title: BUSH RIDICULES MONDALE ARMS VIEW
description: Vice President Bush praised President Reagan's arms buildup Monday and said Walter F. Mondale was ''so hot'' for an arms control agreement with the Soviet Union that ''he will do almost anything to get it.''

title: FILLING INVESTMENT NICHE
description: IN the business world, a ''niche industry'' is usually small and operates in some specialized field. The bearings industry, specialty chemicals, water system companies and check printers are typical examples. But Wall Street also has its niches - firms ranging from investment research boutiques to money managers that, largely hidden from the public eye, serve a variety of clients.

title: MONDALE REBUTS REAGAN ON RELIGION
description: Walter F. Mondale tonight criticized President Reagan's recent comments involving the roles of religion and politics.

title: ; UNWED MOTHERS-TO-BE: BENEATH BRASHNESS
description: To the Editor:

title: LEARNING BY EXAMPLE Teachers Know In the uproar over educational reform, few policy makers have concerned themselves to ask what teachers think. Now, two studies make clear the need to pay more attention to them. Three out of four of the 2,000 teachers canvassed by Louis Harris for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company feel that their views have been ignored in the long debate about educational reform. About half say they lack respect and support from parents and the community. Yet overwhelming majorities say they ''love to teach,'' welcome innovation in school management and support greater teacher accountability.
description: As most teachers surveyed recognize, recruiting is central. According to a recent Rand Corporation study, the most able teachers are leaving, while ''fewer academically able young people'' are being hired.

title: WRONG DEFICIT EFFECT
description: To the Editor:

title: TUESDAY, AUGUST 28, 1984 International
description: Iraq has won a military advantage in its war with Iran as a result of ''massive arms sales'' to Baghdad by France and the Soviet Union and an effective American-led boycott on military sales to Teheran, a staff report of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said. (Page A1, Col. 1.) The sixth poor Soviet grain harvest in a row appears likely. After a summer of hot, dry weather in some areas and unusually heavy rain in others, a cold snap now threatens to cut short the Siberian growing season. The United States estimates that Moscow will have to import 43 million tons of grain, only 3 million less than the record in 1982. (D1:1-2.)

description: About TV Ads

title: BRIEFS
description: Audiotronics Corp.'s employee stock ownership trust said it had increased its holdings in the Hollywood- based company's common stock to 258,243 shares, or 21.7 percent of the total outstanding.

title: THE REGION ; Jean Harris TakenTo Medical Center
description: Jean Harris, who is serving a 15-year- to-life sentence for the 1980 murder of Dr. Herman Tarnower, was hospitalized today after complaining of chest pains.

title: Dillard Stake Being Liquidated
description: The American National Insurance Company told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had begun liquidating its 17.8 percent stake in the class A common stock of Dillard Department Stores Inc. of Little Rock, Ark. American National said it intends to sell all of its 1,107,248 shares because the stock is selling at a price ''very substantially above'' the price at which the shares were bought.

title: NAMES OF 6 CITED BANKS PUBLIC
description: The names of the six banks censured by the Comptroller of the Currency earlier this month for ''window-dressing'' their balance sheets have become publicly known as a result of filings made at the request of the Comptroller.

title: VIDEO CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $458,000, or 27 cents a share, for the latest year and $39,000, or 2 cents a share, for the earlier period.

title: SHARP CLAWS EARN A NAME FOR DINOSAUR
description: STUDIES of a dinosaur skeleton discovered in Montana in 1964 by a Yale University scientist have revealed that the 150- pound reptile had a large sickle- shaped claw on each hind foot and used the claws as weapons to kill dinosaurs up to 10 times heavier.

title: ARCO SETS CHARGE OF $785 MILLION
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said today that it would take a one-time $785 million write-down against third-quarter after-tax earnings to reflect the anticipated sale of the company's minerals and metals units and a portion of its chemical operations. The amount, which would be the difference between the value of the units and their sale price, represents 7 percent of Arco's net worth.

title: COUNTDOWN IS SMOOTH FOR 3D ATTEMPT TO LAUNCH DISCOVERY
description: Preparations were running smoothly today for the new attempt Wednesday to launch the maiden mission of the space shuttle Discovery, earthbound for two months after the dramatic shutdown of its engines seconds before a planned liftoff in June.

title: DISPUTES AMONG BLACKS THREATEN EFFORTS BY DEMOCRATS IN THE SOUTH
description: The passions unleashed by the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Presidential candidacy are complicating affairs for Walter F. Mondale, particularly in the South, where supporters of the two men continue to fight each other.

description: uf891

title: 8 G.M. Plants to Stay Open As Pollution Controls Go In
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Federal Government agreed today that eight automobile assembly plants could remain open while the automaker installs $80 million worth of equipment to prevent the discharge of hazardous heavy metals and organic wastes.

title: Train Kills ConductorAs He Fights a Blaze
description: An off-duty subway conductor was struck and killed by a southbound IRT No. 2 train at the Pelham Parkway station yesterday as he tried to put out a track fire.

title: SLIGHTING ARAB-AMERICANS
description: Last May, Walter F. Mondale met with five people in Chicago - all of them Arab-Americans - to listen to their point of view concerning the Middle East conflict. They talked, Mr. Mondale disagreed with some of their points and each wrote out a check for $1,000 as a contribution to his campaign. A few days later, Mr. Mondale's finance chairman in the Chicago area, Thomas Rosenberg, returned the checks with a statement that it was policy to refuse contributions from Arab-Americans for the Mondale campaign.

title: CONCERT: A FIRST FOR EAST HAMPTON
description: THE American Symphony Orchestra gave a concert in the East Hampton High School Auditorium on Sunday night, and a little bit of history was made.

title: Common Cause Objects To Reagan Expenses
description: Common Cause, the public affairs lobby, asked the Federal Election Commission today to decide if Friday's trip by President Reagan to address the Veterans of Foreign Wars was a campaign expenditure or official business.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Ramsay Refuses To Limit Himself
description: The Portland Trail Blazers' training camps are said to be among the most strenuous in the National Basketball Association. On the opening day, Coach Jack Ramsay runs along with, and often beats, some of his players, who are expected to run a mile in under five and one-half minutes.

title: POSTAL INSTANT PRESS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Paralyzed Man and G.M. Settle Trans Am Suit
description: General Motors and lawyers for a paralyzed 22-year-old man reached a settlement today in a $50 million lawsuit that charged the company manufactured an unsafe Pontiac Trans Am.

title: AIR FLORIDA RESCUE IS PROPOSED
description: Chicago-based Midway Airlines and Air Florida yesterday were given until Sept. 14 to complete a transaction that could rescue the debt-ridden Miami-based carrier.

title: RECORD 454,136 IN PRISON AS CRIME RATES FALL
description: With crime rates declining, the Justice Department reported today that the nation's prison population had reached a record of 454,136, or almost double the total of 10 years ago.

title: FROM CARTOONS TO PRIME TIME
description: On entering the sleek corporate offices of the Taft Entertainment Company in a high-rise office building in Westwood, one is greeted by a menagerie of stuffed animals depicting popular cartoon characters. But the unusual interior decoration tells only part of this burgeoning company's story.

title: FOR FRENCH PRESS, MONACO IS FRONT-PAGE JACKPOT
description: It was a shimmering sapphire of a day. The doormen in front of the casino parked the Ferraris and the Daimlers in color-coordinated clusters. Waiters served caviar from an ice block sculptured into a cobra's coils.

title: ALBERTSON'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN IN FILMS
description: TORONTO FILMS that portray extreme violence against women sexually stimulate nearly a third of all men - even though the films may contain relatively little that is explicitly sexual, according to a newly reported study.

title: A Team for Orlando
description: Meetings are scheduled this week on the possibility of bringing a United States Football League team to Orlando with Howard Schnellenberger as the coach. The team in question is the Washington Federals franchise that was destined for Miami under Schnellenberger, the former coach of the University of Miami, until the plan was abandoned last week.

title: Turning Pro
description: Steve McCrory and Frank Tate, two Olympic boxing gold medalists, will announce at a news conference tomorrow that they have turned pro and that their first fights will be on Oct. 15 at Madison Square Garden. McCrory was the 112-pound medalist, and Tate the 156-pound winner. Although their opponents have not been selected, Top Rank, which will promote the bouts, will also reveal tomorrow at the Garden's Hall of Fame Club that McCrory and Tate will fight on the same card as Marvelous Marvin Hagler, who will defend his undisputed middleweight title against Mustafo Hamsho in a 15-rounder.

title: TEXON ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Year to April 30
Suspects ListedIn Child Abuse
description: New Jersey is compiling a list of child- abuse suspects, and officials said today that the file would be used to screen child-care workers and those seeking to adopt children or to become foster parents.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; American Electric In Restructuring
description: As part of what it called a major reorganization of its senior management, the American Electric Power Service Corporation announced yesterday that Richard E. Disbrow would become president and chief operating officer on Jan. 1.

title: AVANT-GARDE: FOUR BENEFIT CONCERTS
description: THE New Music Distribution Service has served for 12 years as a central source for thousands of independently produced avant-garde albums - jazz, classical music and many things in between. Sunday in the Public Theater, the New Jazz program put on four benefit concerts for the service - two at 4 P.M., two at 8:30 P.M. - with musicians who have had their work distributed by the company.

title: New V.O.A. Chief
description: For the time being at least, the

title: RELEVANT QUESTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreclosure in Philippines
description: The Marinduque Mining and Industrial Corporation said today that two banks had begun foreclosure proceedings against substantially all of the company's assets.

title: Ryder System
description: The Ryder System is offering $100 million of 13 3/8 percent notes due in 1994 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The notes, which are rated A-3 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's, were offered with a yield six-tenths of 1 percent greater than 10-year Treasury notes.

title: Bridge:Older People Find the Game Tones TheirMental Muscles
description: Those whose daily occupation calls for some brain work are liable to find that the mental muscles atrophy after retirement. Regular bridge- playing is an excellent antidote for this, and is one of the best competitive activities available to octogenarians.

title: PHILS TOP PADRES, 9-1; 14TH FOR KOOSMAN
description: Ivan DeJesus hit a two-run double to lead a four-run fourth inning, and Jerry Koosman earned his 14th victory tonight as the Phillies beat the San Diego Padres, 9-1.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Aug. 28, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Mary Harmon Bryant,Widow of Coach, Dies
description: Mary Harmon Bryant, widow of the Alabama football legend Paul (Bear) Bryant, died Sunday night afer suffering a stroke on Friday. She was 68 years old.

title: People Express
description: People Express Airlines said it had agreed to acquire four used Boeing 747-200 aircraft for $106 million from the Boeing Company.

title: Arvida, Chevron In a Land Deal
description: The Arvida Corporation, a unit of Walt Disney Productions, said it had entered into an agreement with the Chevron Corporation for the joint development of Coto de Caza, a 5,000- acre residential and resort community in Orange County, Calif.

title: FROM U.S. CUSTOM HOUSE TO HOLOCAUST CENTER
description: To the Editor:

title: MISTLER, NEILL CUT; JETS PROMISE NEGOTIATIONS
description: Wesley Walker, the Jets' all-pro wide receiver, ended a 37-day holdout today, reported to camp and said that he was optimistic about being ready to play in the regular-season opener against the Colts at Indianapolis next Sunday.

title: Conventional Wisdom
description: Fresh from Dallas and back at her

title: Auto Workers Union Airs TV Commercials
description: The United Automobile Workers union unveiled a series of television commercials today to tell the public it is struggling with auto companies in this year's negotiations to keep American jobs at home and keep the nation strong.

title: MINERAL RESOURCES INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RATES CLIMB IN QUIET TRADING
description: Interest rates rose yesterday in quiet trading. Market participants were discouraged by a lack of investor demand and a Federal Reserve report published last Friday showing that the central bank is not adverse to rising interest rates so long as the economy continues to expand at a brisk rate.

title: Liberia Links Speaker of Assembly to a Plot
description: The Speaker of Liberia's interim National Assembly, Maj. Gen. Nicholas Podier, has been detained in connection with a plot to overthrow the Government, the Justice Ministry said tonight.

title: VENTURE CAPITAL THEN AND NOW
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Child Find Official Regains Daughter
description: The founder of Child Find Inc., a missing-children's organization based in New Paltz, was reunited with her daughter today, almost 10 years after the child disappeared.

title: TERMS OF HOSPITAL ACCORD
description: Talks in New York's six-week health-care strike led to this compromise on wages, weekends off and other major issues between the League of Voluntary Hospitals and Homes and District 1199, Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Workers Union, A.F.L.- C.I.O.: Wages - The union first demanded 10 percent raises in each year of a two-year contract. Management offered 4 percent raises in each year, but the union said delays in putting them into effect and other ''givebacks'' in effect cut the offer to 2.3 percent in each year.

title: Reagan Said to Refrain From Personal Attacks
description: The White House said today that President Reagan planned to stay away from personal attacks on Walter F. Mondale and ''did not imply Mondale was a jackass'' in addressing the Veterans of Foreign Wars Friday in Chicago.

title: ROCK: ZAPPA SEPTET PLAYS TWO CONCERTS AT PIER 84
description: FRANK ZAPPA, now in his 20th year as a bandleader-composer, is one of rock's saddest cases of arrested development. Amid the naivete of much 1960's rock, Mr. Zappa's songs for the Mothers of Invention were bluntly realistic and musically far-reaching.

title: Private Memorial ServicesAre Set For Truman Capote
description: Truman Capote will be memorialized at a private service Tuesday and then be cremated, a spokesman for those arranging the services said today. The ashes are then scheduled to be taken to New York, the writer's home.

title: Cowboys Sign White The Dallas Cowboys yesterday ended their summer-long contract dispute with
description: Randy White b y signing the all-pro defensive tackle to a new agreement that will make him the highest-paid lineman in football. White would have been entering the option year of a contract that was to have paid him something more than $300,000 this season.

title: BREAKTHROUGH SEEN ON MEXICO DEBT
description: The names of six banks cited for balance sheet ''window-dressing'' have become public. Page D19.

title: MASSAGE OR MESSAGE
description: ASPEN, Colo.

title: ANDERSON SCHEDULED TO ENDORSE MONDALE AT ILLINOIS RALLY TODAY
description: John B. Anderson, the Republican-turned-independent who ran for President in 1980, is scheduled to endorse Walter F. Mondale Tuesday in Illinois, aides to the Democratic Presidential nominee said tonight.

title: KAISER SEES A LOSS
description: The Kaiser Cement Corporation said today that it expected to report a loss of $50 million for the third quarter as a result of the write-off of its 36 percent interest in the China Cement Company, a Hong Kong concern.

title: JOHN HENRY'S UNSILENT PARTNER
description: It was less than an hour after John

title: AWKWARD JUNIOR HAS GROWING PAINS
description: WHEN I began a perusal last week of I.B.M.'s equivalent of television's summer reruns, the improved-model PCjr, I started with the keyboard, which replaces the deservedly maligned chiclet-style version. The new keyboard is the best currently available for any computer selling for less than $1,000. The desirability of the rest of the PCjr is more subject to debate.

title: DIVESTITURE OF A.T.& T.
description: ''BREAKING UP IS HARD TO DO'' is about the divestiture of A.T.& T. The world's largest corporation, responding to a Government suit brought eight years before, announced in early 1982 that it would break up its family. Specifically, it said it would give up the 22 Bell System companies. The documentary, on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight, tells us how this was done.

title: ATARI PLANS RANGE OF COMPUTERS
description: The Atari Corporation, in its first major announcement since being taken over in July by Jack Tramiel, said yesterday that it would soon introduce a broad range of personal computers, both for home and office.

title: Offer for Miami
description: Bank Company Hugh F. Culverhouse, a

title: IRAQ SAID TO HOLD ADVANTAGE IN WAR
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee issued a staff report today that said the military balance in the Iranian-Iraqi war had shifted in recent months to Iraq.

title: JAPAN'S BIOTECHNOLOGY EFFORT
description: For centuries, soy sauce has been made by fermenting soybeans and other ingredients for six to eight months. Now, the Kikkoman Corporation, the world's largest soy sauce producer, is experimenting with a process that can reduce the time to one week.

title: WAITE HOYT IN THE RAIN
description: On Saturday, the Brooklyn Schoolboy died. Waite Charles Hoyt was just two weeks shy of his 85th birthday, but during his 21- year major league career and for much of his life, the Hall of Fame pitcher bore that fledgling's nickname.

title: SOTHEBY'S TOLD TO HOLD HEBREW BOOK PROCEEDS
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice ordered Sotheby's auction house yesterday to withhold the proceeds of a June 26 auction of rare Hebrew books and manuscripts until a full trial on the case could begin in approximately four months.

title: HOSPITAL WORKERS VOTE ON ACCORD TO END WALKOUT
description: Nearly 20,000 hospital and nursing home workers jammed Madison Square Garden last night and voted by secret ballot on whether to end their 46- day strike against 30 private, nonprofit hospitals and 15 nursing homes in New York City.

title: WATERS OF LAKE CHAMPLAIN YIELD 225-YEAR-OLD WARSHIP
description: When the British began their campaign to dislodge the French from Lake Champlain in 1759, a young captain in the Royal Navy came to Fort Ticonderoga and built two fighting vessels - the Duke of Cumberland and the Boscawen.

title: Jackson Still LookingFor Mondale Concessions
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, preparing for a meeting Tuesday with Walter F. Mondale, said today that he was still looking for concessions on issues and campaign staff appointments before wholeheartedly supporting the Democratic Presidential nominee.

title: NATIONAL HARDGOODS DISTRIBUTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
description: b-Including a tax credit of $81,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: SPENCER COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. to Help China Build Largest Dam
description: The United States and China have signed an agreement under which the Interior Department will help China design the world's largest hydroelectric dam, the department said today.

title: AN AMERICAN ERROR ABOUT SOUTH AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES ;
description: DOS PASSOS: A Life. By Virginia Spencer

title: Massachusetts Ratings Raised
description: On the eve of today's $140 million bond sale by Massachusetts, analysts at Standard & Poor's raised ratings slightly to AA from AA- for general obligation bonds of Massachusetts.

title: Airline PassengerStricken by Food Poisoning on Flight Dies
description: -year- old British engineer who spent five months in intensive care in a San Francisco hospital after developing food poisoning on a British Airways flight from London, died on Aug. 14, the hospital said yesterday.

title: A SHAKEOUT IN LONG DISTANCE
description: Early in 1983, a small company opened its doors in Oklahoma City with a bright idea: It would buy access to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's long-distance lines at a discount and resell the service to local customers. Thus was born Otelco - but not for long.

title: REDM Offer
description: REDM Industries said its board had recommended that shareholders reject an $18-a-share tender offer from the Mark IV Acquisition Corporation.

title: ALBERT CHAPMAN, EX-KODAK CHAIRMAN, DIES
description: Dr. Albert Kinkade Chapman, who retired as chairman of the Eastman Kodak Company in 1967 after nearly 50 years with the company, died yesterday at his home in suburban Rochester. He was 94 years old.

title: 14 South Pacific Nations Seek Nuclear-Free Zone
description: Leaders of 14 South Pacific nations unanimously agreed today that their region should become a nuclear- free zone.

title: SOVIET UNION IS FACING ANOTHER POOR HARVEST
description: The Soviet Union appears to be heading for its sixth poor grain harvest in a row. After a summer of hot, dry weather in some areas and unusually heavy rain in others, a cold snap now threatens to cut short the Siberian growing season.

title: BATTLE OVER CORNICES AND LINTELS RAGES IN 'VILLAGE'
description: It isn't that James Stewart Polshek has anything against cornices, projecting lintels and windowsills. In fact, the architect rather likes them.

title: Thomson Merger
description: An agreement in principle has been reached for Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc. to acquire Schneider, Bernet & Hickman Inc., a Dallas- based investment firm, the companies said. Terms were not announced. Under the agreement, Schneider, Bernet would operate with its 19 offices and 155 account executives under its present name as a subsidiary of Thomson McKinnon, which has more than 140 offices and 2,000 account executives.

title: The Ball Game
description: Two Washington agencies that

title: Salvador Massacre Reported
description: El Salvador's army high command has ordered a full investigation into an alleged massacre of 68 peasants last month by a United States- trained army unit, military officials said.

title: REAGAN ASKS OFFICIALS TO IMPROVE SCHOOLS WITHOUT MORE U.S. AID
description: President Reagan today challenged educators to improve the achievement and discipline of students, but he also suggested once again that they do so without more help from the Federal Government.

title: SHANKER'S BOLD NEW IMAGE
description: WASHINGTON ALBERT SHANKER, the president of the American Federation of Teachers, recognized when the reports deploring the condition of the nation's schools began pouring out that there was going to be a great deal of pressure on teachers.

title: MYSTERIOUS FORM OF HEPATITIS SEEN AS WIDESPREAD THREAT
description: SCIENTISTS have discovered a deadly and mysterious form of hepatitis caused by two viruses that act in concert in a manner never previously detected. The disease, called delta hepatitis, poses ''an ominous specter for much of the world,'' according to a team of American and Venezuelan researchers who reported a devastating outbreak of the disease among Venezuelan Indians.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary of the author Truman Capote on Sunday incorrectly gave the place of death. He died at the home of Joanne Carson, the divorced second wife of the entertainer Johnny Carson.

title: Rabbit Redford?
description: The Smithsonian Institution

title: Ingersoll Prizes Awarded to 2 Authors
description: The British novelist Anthony Dymoke Powell and Russell Kirk, an American social critic, have been named the 1984 winners of the Ingersoll Prizes. The winners of the annual awards each receive $15,000.

title: 4 Oil Contracts Signed in Egypt
description: The General Petroleum Corporation of Egypt signed agreements with the Exxon Corporation, the British Petroleum Company, Conoco Inc. and Texaco Inc., awarding concessions for oil exploration and production, the official Middle East News Agency said.

title: STOCKS DECLINE BROADLY IN VERY SLOW TRADING
description: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday in the slowest trading in almost a year.

title: DEFECTS IN GOVERNMENT'S ENTRAPMENT STANDARD
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 AFGHAN REBELS VOW COOPERATION
description: Two Afghan rebel leaders said today that they had decided to bury their differences and unify their fight against the Afghan Government and the Soviet forces backing it.

title: The 2 Faces Of Dallas
description: THE Dallas city fathers hoped the Republican National Convention would show their culturally accomplished and worldly city as the sophisticated and hospitable oasis it is, and as far as they are concerned they succeeded.

title: RESORT'S NIGHTSPOTS JOIN DRUNKEN-DRIVING BATTLE
description: While Melanie Traper's three friends drank screwdrivers and danced under a shimmering model car suspended from the ceiling of the LeMans Discoth eque here not long ago, she sipped orange juice provided free by the bartender.

title: WICKES COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
description: b-After income from discontinued leasing business of $762,000 for the quarter and $1,602,000 for the 6 months and tax credits of $2,514,000 and $2,627,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-After income from discontinued leasing business of $956,000 for the quarter and $2,213,000 for the 6 months and a tax credit of $569,000 for the quarter and 6 months. The company filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the United States bankruptcy code in April 1982.

title: RIGHTS OF CHILDREN THAT OUTRANK A TEACHER'S RIGHT TO PRY
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: REAGAN WORSENED POVERTY
description: It is important that we criticize Ronald Reagan's unfairness fairly.

title: Experts' Averages
description: Most fields have their institutes,

title: BANK OF NOVA SCOTIA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: ISRAELI JETS RAID A P.L.O. CAMP IN EAST LEBANON
description: Israeli Air Force jets attacked a Palestinian guerrilla base today in the Bekaa region in eastern Lebanon and reportedly inflicted heavy casualties. Israel said the base had been used to prepare for raids against Israeli troops.

title: BETTER MEASURING CUP
description: IN the field of kitchen equipment,

title: CINEPLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $1,700 for the quarter and $164,000 for the 6 months. c-Including extraordinary gains of $75,000 for the quarter and $148,000 for the 6 months. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: City Workers Tied ToStolenCarSales
description: Two employees of the city's Sanitation Department were arrested yesterday and charged with selling late- model stolen cars to fellow workers.

title: CONCEPT DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
Killer Sentenced To 75 More Years
description: A convicted murderer already serving a 179-year sentence in a New Jersey prison was sentenced in Manhattan yesterday to an additional 75 years to life for the murders of three prostitutes in midtown hotels.

title: COM SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $90,000 from discontinued operations.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JAZZ AT GRANT'S TOMB Many jazz fans identify the initials MJQ with the Modern Jazz Quartet. The initials were reportedly first used to refer to the Milt Jackson Quartet, led by Mr. Jackson, the vibraharpist. He came to the attention of the jazz world in 1945 working with Dizzy Gillespie, and went on to achieve international fame with the Modern Jazz Quartet.

title: WESTERN-WORLD TELEVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: HAYNES IS BACK AFTER GETTING LETTER
description: In the end, it was a letter from General Manager George Young that forced Mark Haynes to return to the Giants today, after a walkout that began with the end of practice last Wednesday.

title: KRICKSTEIN STRUGGLES BUT WINS IN 5 SETS
description: The United States Open, a dizzying jamboree for spectators and a testing ordeal for players, began yesterday at the National Tennis Center with Aaron Krickstein, one of last year's young stars, surviving what his father called ''first round heebie- jeebies.''

title: Transactions
description: Called up Paul Runge, infielder, from Richmond of International League. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Announced that Bo Diaz, catcher, would be out for remainder of season. Purchased contract of Steve Fireovid, pitcher, from Portland of Pacific Coast League. FOOTBALL BUFFALO (AFC) - Placed Mark Brammer, tight end; Mike Mosley, wide receiver; Eric Richardson, wide receiver, and Leroy Howell, defensive end, on injured reserve list. Re-signed Len Walterscheid, safety; Mark Merrill, linebacker; Craig White, wide receiver, and Joey Smith, wide receiver. CINCINNATI (AFC) - Recalled Brian Pillman, linebacker, and Clay Pickering, wide receiver, and placed Mike Obrovac, guard, and Bobby Kemp, defensive back, on injured reserve list. CLEVELAND (AFC) - Waived Larry Braziel, cornerback. DENVER (AFC) - Placed Bob Swenson, linebacker, and Scott Brunner, quarterback, on injured reserve list and re- signed Jesse Myles, running back, and Robert Jackson, safety. DETROIT (NFC) - Claimed Mike Meade, fullback, on waivers from Green Bay and released Rick Kane, running back. GREEN BAY (NFC) - Acquired Bill Neill, nose tackle, who was waived by Giants. JETS (AFC) - Placed Bob Crable, middle linebacker, and Johnny (Lam) Jones, wide receiver, on injured reserve list and re-signed Glenn Inverso, quarterback, and Nick Bruckner, wide receiver. KANSAS CITY (AFC) - Waived Lucious Smith and Don Jones, cornerbacks; Dino Mangiero, nose tackle; Larry Ricks and Leonard Williams, running backs; Dean Prater, defensive end; James Walker, inside linebacker, and Al Wenglikowski, linebacker. Placed Mark Lang, linebacker, and Daryl Posey, running back, on injured reserve list. LOS ANGELES RAMS (NFC) - Placed Johnnie Johnson, starting safety; Gary Jeter, defensive end; Mike Barber, tight end, and Gary Kowalski, tackle, on injured reserve list.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Aug. 29, 1984 SECURITY COUNCIL

title: COMPROMISE MOVE ON ISRAEL EMBASSY
description: House backers of a bill to move the United States Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem have offered to make it nonbinding and to postpone a vote until next year if President Reagan will drop his opposition to it, key sponsors said today.

title: Fire Hits U.S. Army Complex
description: A fire raged through a United States Army shopping complex before dawn today, causing an estimated $1 million in damage but no injuries, an Army spokesman said. The structure was part of the main shopping complex near Benjamin Franklin village, a large United States military housing complex outside Mannheim in central West Germany. The complex was not occupied at the time of the fire.

title: House Panel to Review Labor Board Position
description: The House subcommittee that oversees the National Labor Relations Board plans decided not to dismiss Donald L. Dotson as chairman of the board, according to Representative William Clay, the subcommittee's chairman.

title: ALGONQUIN MERCANTILE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $105,723 on the sale of an investment.

title: A CALLOUS HAITIAN ELITE IS INVITING UPHEAVAL
description: To the Editor:

title: THAI BIRTHDAY BOUQUET HAS HEADY POLITICAL SCENT
description: Thailand's Prime Minister, Gen. Prem Tinsulanonda, celebrated a birthday Sunday, his 64th. The sun was hardly up over Bangkok when military and police officers began gathering outside General Prem's residence. By 9 A.M. there were more than 500 of them, representing the country's top brass. At the head of the delegation was Thailand's Supreme Commander and army chief, Gen. Arthit Kamlang-ek, bearing a big bouquet of flowers.

title: BURTON RECALLED WITH TEARS AND JOY
description: With Welsh songs, lines from Shakespeare and Dylan Thomas, with favorite jokes and fond anecdotes, with tears and laughter and, finally, with their departed comrade's own thrilling voice, a theater full of his friends and fans paid tribute yesterday to the late Richard Burton.

title: Dispute on Prayer Book Reported to Be Ended
description: The pastor of St. Mark's Church said today that he awaited confirmation that his dispute with Colorado's Episcopal Bishop over which prayer book to use had ended.

title: PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: The company said that the net income for the year-ago quarter and 6 months includes respective gains of 5 cents and 9 cents a share as a result of reduction of certain inventory levels accounted for on the LIFO method.

title: CRACKER BARREL OLD COUNRY STORE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
JONES AND CRABLE PUT ON INJURED LIST
description: While the Jet players took the day off from practice, the front office continued busy yesterday, engaging in a bit of bookkeeping that allowed the team to stay at the 49-man regular- season limit while protecting two of the injured regulars.

title: Honor for Harrelson
description: Bud Harrelson , the former Met shortstop, has been named manager of the year in the New York-Pennsylvania League, according to the league president, Vincent McNamara . Harrelson, who in his first year with the Little Falls Mets, has led the team to the Yawkey Division lead and a 40-28 record, was selected in voting by fellow managers in the Class A league.

title: Idaho Natural Gas
description: Intermountain Gas Industries and the Idaho Natural Gas Company said they had entered into a definitive agreement under which Idaho Natural Gas would begin a $32-a-share tender offer for all of Intermountain's common shares.

title: INTERPHASE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FERRARO SUGGESTS REAGAN VICTORY WOULD INCREASE CHANCES OF WAR
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro reminded a crowd here today that as a mother she was concerned about her son going to war and suggested that a second term for President Reagan could increase the chances of armed conflict.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: IN response to the pain, many of the 40 million Americans who suffer from arthritis stop trying to move arthritic joints, aggravating the problem and causing permanent crippling. Potent anti-inflammatory medications notwithstanding, exercise is now recognized as one of the most effective treatments - and preventives - of crippling arthritis.

title: SAVINGS INDUSTRY LAUDS CHOICE OF A SUCCESSOR
description: William J. Popejoy's appointment to succeed Charles W. Knapp as chairman and chief executive of the Financial Corporation of America drew enthusiastic endorsements tonight from executives, analysts and consultants in the thrift industry.

title: AT THE F.T.C., THE TRADE IN MUD IS BRISK
description: No one expected Michael Pertschuk to go quietly, and he has not disappointed.

title: A Quiet Return
description: Kyle Burns returned to school this week in Justin, Tex., but this time without all the controversy. The 14- year-old entered the eighth grade with little fanfare - the way he wanted it.

title: Guilty Plea in Fraud
description: Joel Nelson, a financier who eluded arrest for more than two years after bilking millions of dollars from thousands of small investors, has pleaded guilty in Federal court to five counts of mail fraud. An Assistant United States Attorney, Richard Kendall, said that Mr. Nelson masterminded a $20 million pyramid scheme for 13 years out of his Los Angeles business, the Shirley Company.

title: MOHAMMED NAGUIB, FIRST PRESIDENT OF EGYPT, DIES
description: Mohammed Naguib, the Egyptian Army officer who became the country's first President after a bloodless coup toppled King Farouk in July 1952, died yesterday. He was 83 years old.

title: Daley Son in Mondale Camp
description: William Daley, a son of former Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago, has been named an aide to a top assistant in Walter F. Mondale's Presidential campaign, The Chicago Sun Times said today.

title: Sigel Begins Bid
description: The defending champion, Jay Sigel, began his bid for a third straight United States Amateur title with a 3-under 68 today to tie the Oak Tree Golf Club course record and share the lead after first-round qualifying. Sigel shared the lead with University of Florida senior Scott Dunlap and Richard Miller of Columbus, Ohio.

title: Senator Boren Is Victor In Oklahoma Primary
description: Senator David L. Boren swept to an easy victory today in the Democratic primary in Oklahoma.

title: MOHAWK DATA SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Soviet Bank Tries Eurobond Market
description: The London-based Moscow Narodny Bank offered a $50 million bond issue today in what is thought to be the first foray into the Eurobond market by a Soviet borrower and the first such issue for foreign investors since the Russian Revolution of 1917.

title: CUBS' FANS THINK GAME'S BETTER WITH NO LIGHTS
description: Wrigley Field, the home of the Chicago Cubs baseball team since 1916, is laden with tradition: ivy-covered outfield walls, an old- fashioned scoreboard where numbers are changed by hand, 40 years of having losing teams and games that are played in the afternoon only.

title: CLERK IS SHOT AT OFFICES OF HEALTH-CARE UNION
description: A sniper on the roof of the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan fired across 42d Street yesterday into the union headquarters of the city's health-care workers, wounding a clerical worker in the head as she sat in the cafeteria, the police said.

title: S & K FAMOUS BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
COST OF MILLSTONE 3 INCREASES
description: Northeast Utilities said yesterday that its Millstone 3 reactor, in Waterford, Conn., would cost as much as 10 percent more than the $3.54 billion limit set by the Connecticut General Assembly.

title: COMP-U-CARD INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $149,000 for the quarter and $178,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Washingtonians Help Capitol Mugging Victim
description: Washingtonians offered help today to a multiple sclerosis victim who reported being mugged on the Capitol grounds after walking 600 miles to stress the need for more research on his disease.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Business Products Inc. , a supplier of business paper products and office supplies based in Atlanta, said it had reached an agreement for an option to acquire all the shares outstanding of Switched Transaction Services Inc., a closely held provider of electronic funds transfer services through automated teller machines.

title: A 7TH LIBERIAN IS LINKED TO PLOT
description: The acting chief of a new opposition party surrendered today to the military Government, becoming the seventh prominent Liberian arrested on charges of plotting to overthrow the head of state, Gen. Samuel K. Doe.

title: THE LIVES A CARING WORLD COULD SAVE
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN'S POLITICAL RELIGION
description: WASHINGTON The White House strategists are

title: A SEEMINGLY INNOCENT HAND CAN CONTAIN A BURIED IRONY
description: Some bridge deals contain ironies buried deeply below the surface.

title: Felicitous Trade
description: When Steve Schreiber, the Mets' director of minor league operations, telephoned John Jason Felice on Dec. 16, 1982 to inform him he had been traded for Tom Seaver, the young minor leaguer, reportedly said, ''You mean I have been traded for a future Hall of Famer?''

title: A'S TOP YANKS WITH 3 IN 12TH
description: The A's, facing a 10th straight loss, came back once, then twice to defeat the Yankees in 12 innings tonight, 4-3.

title: COURT ASSAILS U.S. ON MENTALLY ILL
description: A Federal appeals court in New York has ordered the Social Security Administration to restore benefits denied to 50,000 mentally ill people in the state under what it called a ''clandestine policy'' of determining eligibility.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IT is fascinating to hear what

title: Endurance Swim
description: Stacy Chanin, a 23-year-old University of Maryland physical education major, began a record-breaking attempt to swim three laps around Manhattan at noon yesterday when she dived into the East River from the the 96th Street bulkhead. If successful, Miss Chanin should complete her swim of 84 miles at about 8:30 tonight. Diana Nyad holds the world distance swimming record of 89 miles, set on a Florida-to-Cuba swim.

title: MORE SHIPS TO JOIN MINE EFFORT
description: A British minesweeper arrived at the northern end of the Suez Canal today to await three Italian vessels for a trip south to join the growing international task force searching for mines in the Gulf of Suez, where explosions have damaged 18 ships since July 9.

title: RESTAURANT PRICING, CONTINUED
description: RESTAURANTGOERS will never agree on where to find the best pesto, but when it comes to wine prices they appear to be of one mind: wine prices in restaurants are too high. A few comments on this subject appeared here last week and the calls and letters continue to arrive.

title: Big Price Slide For Gasoline WASHINGTON, Aug. 28
description: Gasoline prices have

title: A FAST-PACED CHAIRMAN COMES TO ABRUPT HALT
description: When visitors entered Charles Knapp's spacious office atop a Los Angeles skyscraper, their attention was invariably drawn to a ship's telegraph, the device sea captains use to signal the engine room for power. As helmsman of the Financial Corporation of America, Mr. Knapp had always been proud that he had his telegraph set at flank speed, the fastest a ship can go.

title: THE POLLSTERS' UNCHOSEN
description: To the Editor:

title: FLAW RESULTS IN 3D POSTPONEMENT OF SHUTTLE FLIGHT
description: A fault in the onboard timing device for controlling critical launching activities forced at least a one-day delay in the liftoff of the space shuttle Discovery, the third time the spaceship's maiden mission has been postponed.

title: GIANT FOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
6 MORE BRITISH PORTS ARE STRUCK
description: Dockworkers at Southampton and five other ports joined the British dock strike today, but workers at 11 other ports refused to take part in the four-day-old walkout.

title: 14 Are Indicted In Jersey Fraud
description: Fourteen people, including three state troopers, and an Atlantic City bank were indicted on conspiracy charges today in connection with a scheme that defrauded investors of $1.4 million over a five-month period in 1981, according to the New Jersey Attorney General.

title: THE REGION;
description: Justice Irving R. Fudeman of State Supreme Court has upheld a $53.9 million jury verdict against Erie County for breaking a contract to build a domed stadium in suburban Lancaster.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Chief Is Replaced At Western Union
description: In a move that seems certain to reignite speculation that it is ripe for a takeover, the Western Union Corporation and its principal subsidiary, the Western Union Telegraph Company, said yesterday that Robert M. Flanagan, its chairman, president and chief executive officer, had been replaced by T. Roland Berner, the head of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, Western Union's largest stockholder.

title: CONTEXT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income. Year-ago revenue figure restated for bulk sale of real estate.

title: BOOKS ARE PROLIFERATING ON THE CARE OF CHILDREN
description: SINCE it was issued in paperback in 1946, Dr. Benjamin Spock's ''Baby and Child Care'' has made publishing history. The book went through 167 printings in its first 10 years, but since then, a spokesman for Pocket Books said recently, it has had ''so many printings we can't keep count.'' Thirty million copies are in print. And in his recent book ''Two-Bit Culture: The Paperbacking of America,'' Kenneth C. Davis says the Spock book ''has become the second-best-selling book in American history, trailing only the Bible.''

title: Ovation for a New Judge
description: The swearing in of new judges

title: CITY SUES JUDGES TO SPEED ORDERS IN SUPPORT CASES
description: New York City is suing six Family Court judges, charging they have refused to sign in advance payroll-deduction orders for use when a parent becomes delinquent in support payments for children on welfare.

title: 5 VENTURES BACKED FOR BELL UNITS
description: The Justice Department, completing a court-ordered review, said today that it could support five of eight proposals by Bell regional telephone companies to diversify.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 29, 1984

title: PAN AM DISCUSSING JET LEASES
description: Pan American World Airways is negotiating with Airbus Industrie to lease a number of A300 passenger jets to be used on its domestic, Caribbean and European routes.

title: UPSTATE FACTORY EQUIPS COUNTRY'S KAZOO PLAYERS
description: Maurice J. Spectoroff rummaged through a stack of small boxes labeled ''The Bowery,'' ''Name Dropper,'' ''Kalamazoo'' and ''Mohawk'' before pulling out a 4 1/2-inch brass tube with a little tower on top, a Lilliputian submarine.

title: St. Regis Takeover By Champion Gains
description: The Federal Trade Commission said today that it had decided against blocking the Champion International Corporation's acquisition of $1.2 billion worth of the St. Regis Corporation's stock.

title: CUBS TURN BACK REDS TWICE
description: Keith Moreland hit two doubles and a single and drove in two runs to lead Chicago to a 5-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today and give the Cubs a sweep of their doubleheader.

title: Topics ; Bestiary ; Early Foot Until this week, we never thought of dinosaurs as frightening. Stupid maybe, pin-headed certainly, but not the stuff of which movie monsters are made. Then we saw a photograph of what a 150-pounder known as
description: Deinonychus sported on his hind feet - sickle-shaped claws more lethal that anything ever utilized by Ian Fleming's Oddjob.

title: UNSEEMINGLY 'JUDO CHOPS' FROM AN EX-U.S. AIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: Redskin Runner
description: On Nov. 23, 1980, the Washington Redskins played the Dallas Cowboys at Texas Stadium in Irving, Tex. Bobby Beathard, the Redskins' general manager, remembers the day well.

title: Debt Review
description: * Bethlehem Steel Corp.'s debt and preferred stock ratings are being reviewed by Moody's for a possible downgrading.

title: Yamani Sees Stable Prices
description: The danger to oil producers of further price declines has ended, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the oil minister of Saudi Arabia, said today. He added that OPEC might consider increasing production later this year.

title: ENTERTAINMENT PUBLICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $186,000.

title: Ugandan Reported Slain
description: Solomon Asea, the former personal physician of President Milton Obote and former Ugandan Ambassador to the United States, was shot dead in his home here on Sunday by unidentified gunmen, The Star, an independent newspaper, reported today.

title: HARDEE FARMS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COWBOYS TO START HOGEBOOM
description: Coach Tom Landry of the Dallas Cowboys yesterday named Gary Hogeboom as the starting quarterback for the team's season opener, a surprising decision that left Danny White, the veteran incumbent at the position, bitter and emotionally spent.

title: Gentle Ben Planning A Comeback in Movie
description: Gentle Ben, the 1,600-pound Kodiak bear who starred on the ''Grizzly Adams'' television series, is going to return to the screen.

title: CHIEF QUITS TROUBLED THRIFT UNIT
description: Charles W. Knapp, the chairman and chief executive of the Financial Corporation of America, said today that he was resigning both posts as well as his seat on the company's board of directors. Financial Corporation is the parent of the American Savings and Loan Association, the nation's largest thrift institution.

title: SECT DEFECTOR SAYS HE FABRICATED ABUSE CHARGES
description: A defector from the Northeast Kingdom Community Church said today that he had fabricated stories that have been a key factor in an investigation into allegations of child abuse in the sect.

title: Theft of Gasoline Leads To 3-State Police Chase
description: More than a dozen police cars chased two Maine teen-agers through three states today at speeds reaching more than 100 miles per hour for stealing $16 worth of gasoline in New Jersey, the police said.

title: South African Growth
description: The reserve bank governor of South Africa, Gerhard de Kock, said today that he expected growth in the country's real gross domestic product to slow next year because of the country's austerity policies.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Continental Corp. , Phoenix, an investment company, has named Nikolaus O. Klotz president and chief executive officer of its new Crescent Hotel Group.

title: FRENCH DIVERS SURVEY WRECK
description: Salvage company divers today began surveying the site where a French freighter carrying 225 tons of radioactive cargo sank off the Belgian coast.

title: IN VIENNA, THE DAY OF NEW WINE AND CHEER
description: Viennese and crowds of tourists are raising brimming mugs of wine to celebrate the 200th anniversary of the Heurige, one of Austria's most popular institutions.

title: DENNY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
Accounts
description: * Solgar Co., Lynbrook, L.I., to Franznick & Cusatis.

title: Jaguar Increasing Jobs
description: With American demand rising for its sleek luxury cars, Britain's Jaguar Company said today that it would create 530 new jobs at three assembly plants, two in Coventry and one in Birmingham. The company sold 29,000 cars last year and expects to sell 33,000 this year.

title: LEGAL QUESTIONS IN WINANS CASE
description: Some lawyers familiar with the case of R. Foster Winans, the former Wall Street Journal reporter indicted yesterday along with two associates for securities fraud, said the step could be seen as a symbolic victory for those concerned about fairness in the marketplace. They questioned, however, whether the legal foundation for the Government's case, most notably the contention that Mr. Winans had legally enforceable duties both to The Journal and to its readers, is consistent with the United States Supreme Court's restrictive definition of what is prohibited ''insider trading.''

title: BURNUP & SIMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $924,000 from discontinued operations.

title: E-Z-EM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
NO BLOOMS FOR HUBBY
description: When John Zaccaro's wife was nominated for Vice President his thoughts were not recorded, but I can guess what he anticipated, because I have often feared my own wife would run for one of the big jobs, and I have thought about what my role would be.

title: HURTFUL ETHNIC BIAS
description: To the Editor:

title: Trilogy, Sperry
description: Trilogy Ltd. said that it had signed a letter of intent with the Sperry Corporation to develop a high-performance computer chip for use in communication and computer systems.

title: BEWARE CIGARETTE RELABELING
description: The House is soon to consider a proposal to strengthen health warnings on cigarette packs and to change the language of the warnings quarterly. This change should be resisted. While it might help reduce cigarette smoking marginally, it would deprive the public of its greatest potential weapon against smoking: product liability lawsuits against cigarette makers.

title: U.S. SECURITIES RATES MIXED
description: Interest rates on Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with Treasury bill rates rising slightly, while yields fell modestly for notes and bonds due in seven years or more.

title: Chrysler-Korea Plan Opposed DETROIT, Aug. 28 (AP) -
description: The Chrysler Corporation and

title: Taiwan Hails Philharmonic
description: The New York Philharmonic's debut performance Monday in Taiwan drew thunderous applause and cheers and a standing ovation from 2,600 fans.

title: On the Record ; Blacks' Aims For Mondale
description: A Mailgram sent in advance to participants in a meeting of black leaders with Walter F. Mondale over the signature of Mayor Richard G. Hatcher of Gary, Ind.

title: Peru's Military Ousts Antiterrorist Chief
description: The military high command today dismissed Gen. Adrian Huaman, head of Peru's antiterrorist troops, two days after he bitterly blamed Government neglect and corruption for subversion in the central Andes.

title: Bank of Indiana
description: The Money Management Corporation, a bank holding company, said its board had approved a proposal that the company's employee stock ownership plan should take control of Money Management and its Bank of Indiana subsidiary. The company said that each three of its approximately 1.5 million common shares outstanding, other than common stock owned by the stock ownership plan, would be converted into $12.50 cash plus two shares of a newly authorized 12 percent cumulative preferred stock. On the American Stock Exchange today, Money Management rose 12.5 cents, to $10.25.

title: TAMIL PARTY LOSING SUPPORT TO MORE MILITANT IN SRI LANKA
description: A three-day visit to Sri Lanka's northern province indicates that popular support is gradually moving away from the main political party representing Tamil separatism and toward militant groups committed to terrorism.

title: Home Resales Down in July
description: Sales of existing homes declined in July from the previous month, largely because of climbing interest rates, the National Association of Realtors said today.

title: On Acronym Abuse
description: In a rare, illuminating contribution

title: Occidental Silent On Unit's Future
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation declined to comment on a report that it had decided to sell a subsidiary, IBP Inc., the nation's largest beef packer.

title: PILAFS: A WORLD OF SATISFYING DISHES BUILT AROUND GRAINS
description: EVEN in these times of light menus, most of us still secretly hanker for meals that have a bit of starch in them. Potatoes and pasta, of course, are by no means absent from modern diets, but in addition to the general obloquy they must sometimes put up with, they also suffer from a reputation for sameness. True enough, variations of cut, shape, cooking method or garnish can enable them to appear in different guises; but in the end, ''spuds is spuds'' and pasta, even whole- wheat pasta, is, well, pasta.

title: INTERNATIONAL THOMSON ORANIZATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $25.8 million for the quarter and 6 months on the disposal of B shares of Reuters Holdings PLC.

title: Options on Soybeans
description: The Chicago Board of Trade said today that it had set Oct. 31 as the day to start trading in options on soybean futures.

title: F.B.I. ENDED INQUIRY JUST BEFORE NEWS DISCLOSURE
description: A three-year Federal undercover investigation into links between organized crime and suburban prostitution rings was ended one day before a newspaper disclosed the operation.

title: IRAQ AND IRAN: NOW A WAR OF WAITING
description: The conflict between Iraq and Iran has settled down into a war of waiting in the muggy summer heat, with small patrols from each side probing a no man's land to spot targets for sporadic artillery fire, according to American military analysts.

title: CLASSIC-PRINT SHOES, KNITS FOR THE LITTLE ONES
description: 1.*Scarf-Print Shoes

title: Tax Forms Sold for Scrap
description: A supervisor in the Internal Revenue Service admitted today that he had found another way to make money out of tax forms: He sold them to paper recyclers.

title: People
description: Joseph N. Walsh Jr. elected vice president, regulatory, planning and marketing for New York Telephone.

title: G.M. AND FORD MAKE OFFERS BUT THE UNION SPURNS THEM
description: General Motors and Ford made their first offers today in contract talks with the United Automobile Workers. Both were quickly denounced as ''meager'' and ''inadequate'' by union leaders.

title: Bell Building Reopens
description: Bell of Pennsylvania's headquarters reopened today, a day after a spill of PCB's forced the closing of the telephone company building.

title: METZENBAUM BROKE NO RULE ON HOTEL FEE, BOARD DECIDES
description: The District of Columbia Real Estate Commission has decided to take no further action against Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, after receiving a report today that he apparently did not violate any city law, rule or regulation in his role in the June 1983 sale of a Washington hotel.

description: Senator Ted Stevens, an Alaska Republican, faced no challengers in the state's primary today, but five Anchorage Democrats were running for the right to challenge him in November.

title: PLANES SENT DATA BEFORE COLLISION
description: A spokesman for the National Transportation Safety Board said today that both the commuter airliner and the small private plane that crashed last Friday near San Luis Obispo, Calif., were reporting their altitudes to a computer that generates radar displays for air traffic controllers.

title: Tax Exemption Is Lifted For Mail-Order Ministry
description: The Internal Revenue Service today revoked automatic tax exemptions for contributions to a central California church that gives out ministry titles and church charters worldwide through the mail.

title: JERSEY CASINO STARTING A COPTER AIRLINE
description: Resorts International will begin operating a commercial helicopter airline today between Manhattan and the Boardwalk in Atlantic City, officials of the casino hotel announced yesterday.

title: 'A RIGHT TO LIVE, A RIGHT TO VOTE'
description: When Raymond E. Lamb and Willie R. Jenkins Jr. decided to add their names to the District of Columbia voter rolls last spring, the residence they listed on the registration forms was ''Steam Grate, 21st and E Streets, N.W.'' It was an address that presented both a painful glimpse of reality and a vexing challenge to the officials who run the District's election apparatus.

description: Mayor Koch and the city's Investigation Commissioner never made public a report that praised the work of a welfare official who had been critical of city social workers, but did make public a later one that criticized the official.

title: Dealer Testifies In 'Hitler Diaries' Trial
description: A dealer in Nazi memorabilia, Konrad Kujau, testified today that a journalist talked him into forging 62 volumes of ''Hitler diaries'' by offering him money and treasures from Nazi Germany and Fascist Italy.

title: VOTE IS 19,332 TO 98
description: A 47-day strike against 30 hospitals and 15 nursing homes in New York City officially ended yesterday when the hospital workers' union announced that its members had overwhelmingly ratified an agreement.

title: Board Backs Bid For Motel Chain
description: American Motor Inns Inc. said its board had voted to recommend to shareholders that they tender shares to Prime Motor Inns Inc. for $21.50 a share. American Motor said its board had taken the vote in consideration of Prime's agreeing to eliminate certain conditions under which it could terminate or amend its offer.

title: A HAMLET COLONIZED BY ARTISTS
description: One morning early this summer, Patrick Sciarratta put on some grease paint, climbed onto a pair of stilts and ambled over to the post office. It was his way of letting this hamlet of 800 know that the artists had arrived.

title: Beach Boys Concert Peaceful in Bridgeport
description: A controversial concert by the Beach Boys at Kennedy Stadium here went off with little trouble Monday night. More than 12,000 people heard the band play for 67 minutes; one person was arrested.

description: An article Aug. 21 on a Jewish wedding in Egypt misstated the date of the last such wedding. It was 1978.

description: South African policemen fought running battles with students and demonstrators outside Johannesburg today as voters from the country's Indian minority voted for a new Parliament that the Government has depicted as a major reform in this racially divided nation.

''There are a lot of offers,'' said Mike Jacki .

title: Eastern Pilots
description: Eastern Airlines, which has not hired pilots since 1981, said that it planned to hire between 75 and 100 pilots in the next six months.

The subsidiaries - LTV Aerospace and Defense, LTV Energy Products and LTV Steel - will have a budget of about $4 million, most of which will be spent in trade advertising.

description: Team Canada won't see its old nemesis, Vladislav Tretyak , during the Canada Cup tournament, but that doesn't mean the Soviet goaltender will never strap on the pads again, says the Soviet national coach. ''He could come back at any time,'' said Viktor Tikhonov .

title: FOREST FIRES BURN BIG MONTANA AREA
description: Scores of wind-whipped fires raged today across Montana, charring 100,000 acres of forests and rangeland and forcing hundreds of people to flee their homes, while fresh firefighters began arriving from other states.

title: Hospital Winners and Losers Confusion breeds mistrust and mistrust breeds bitterness: that's the story of the protracted bargaining to settle New York's hospital workers' strike. It produced a reasonable agreement, but at disturbing public cost.
description: The state controls hospital revenues through its regulation of health insurance rates. In past labor negotiations, governors have intervened to guarantee pay increases. This time, Governor Cuomo insisted that the hospitals could not count on any state money other than the normal revenue increases based on ''trend factor'' estimates of inflation.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: LET'S HEAR IT FOR A BEAUTIFUL GUY. By Bruce Jay Friedman. 252 pages. Donald I. Fine. $15.95. ''LET'S HEAR IT FOR A BEAUTIFUL GUY,'' the title story of Bruce Jay Friedman's latest collection, is inspired by an item from Earl Wilson's gossip column. ''Sammy Davis,'' according to Mr. Wilson, ''is trying to get a few months off for a complete rest.'' This is the kind of thing Mr. Friedman does best: exploiting the pretensions and incongruities of a culture that takes itself too seriously.

title: New York Sued On Park Stabbing
description: A New Jersey man has filed a $10.5 million lawsuit in Federal District Court here seeking damages for wounds he said he suffered in a stabbing during a Diana Ross concert in New York City's Central Park last year.

title: Hello, Grass Roots
description: -SPAN, the public service wing of the cable television industry, is going to look at the Presidential and Congressional campaigns this fall in a different way: from the grass roots up instead of from the candidates down. Breaking away still further from strict documentary broadcasting of public events, the network will visit 15 communities, from Seattle to New Haven, between Labor Day and Election Day to see what the voters in each of them are saying about the campaign.

title: DISSENT GROWS AMONG JEHOVAH'S WITNESSES
description: Clutching a Bible, the preacher at the Kingdom Hall of the Jehovah's Witnesses at Central Park West and 102d Street railed against ''discos, videos and designer clothes.'' The teen-agers in the congregation, with skinny leather ties and slicked-back hair, shifted in their seats and stared at their shoes.

description: The Air Force has denied a plea by the Hughes Aircraft Company to release $37 million for three major missile projects.

description: Which is the best phrase to describe this city of rusty blast furnaces and abandoned railroad lines: ''Cleveland's a plum'' or ''Cleveland - love it or leave it''?

description: Teacher strikes yesterday extended summer vacation for more than 76,000 pupils in five states, including community college students in Michigan and Illinois.

description: The Communications Workers of America, angered by the pending elimination of 11,000 jobs by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, today called on A.T.& T. as well as the new Bell regional companies to open national negotiations on the issue of employee layoffs.

title: Economic Scene; Mondale's Plan For the Deficit
description: HAVING assailed Mr. Reagan for withholding until after the election his plans for raising taxes and cutting spending to shrink the deficit, Mr. Mondale is under pressure to disclose his proposals. He and his staff are planning to submit a four-year budget plan in about two weeks.

title: Serving Style Off the Court
description: Some might call it cheesecake, others might call it glamour, but the hottest souvenir item on sale at the United States Open is a 1985 calendar produced by the Womens' Tennis Association and featuring photographs of 13 of its members in evening gowns, bathing suits and glittery jewelery.

title: Neighbor Charged In Slaying of 2
description: A man who said his two neighbors made too much noise was charged yesterday with fatally shooting them in their Harlem apartment building, the police said.

title: MIAMI PAST FIRST STOP ON ROUGH ROAD
description: The University of Miami's football team headed south very early yesterday morning, hours after its victory over Auburn, touching down just about as the sun came up. Just three months after the Hurricanes had wondered who their new coach would be, they arrived home to sleep and begin to prepare for the second leg of their 3-game, 12-day road show.

description: Grey Advertising has bought half of Ideas y Hechos S.A. of Mexico, a subsidiary of Ideatec S.A. and an affiliate of Grey Advertising since 1982.

description: The four members of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission today approved an experimental link between exchanges in Chicago and Singapore. The innovation will permit nighttime trading through a United States commodities market for the first time.
