A TEST ON PAYING HEALTH COST OF AGED
description: Brandeis University is about to begin a pilot project aimed at reducing health costs for the elderly and keeping them off welfare by coordinating all their health care through a prepaid plan.

title: Holmes Fight On The boxing promoter
description: Don King said yesterday that the heavyweight title fight between Larry Holmes and Gerrie Coetzee , long delayed by financial problems, would be held in Las Vegas, Nev., in November. ''We're just refining a few little details and cleaning up the language,'' King said of his negotiations with Steve Wynn, the owner of the Golden Nugget hotel-casinos in Las Vegas and Atlantic City, who, King said, is to co-promote the fight.

title: HOURLONG DOCUMENTARY ABOUT AIDS VICTIMS
description: ''AIDS: PROFILE OF AN EPIDEMIC'' is terribly solemn but not very serious. It is not so much about the disease as about the victims of the disease. This is its strength and its weakness, too. For one thing, the victims we see aren't representative of AIDS victims. The one-hour documentary, followed by a discussion, will be seen on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight.

description: Plenty of executives dabble in music, if only to play a few bars of ''Sentimental Journey'' now and then. It's far less likely to find a musician whose second career happens to be that of vice chairman of a corporation that grosses about $100 million a year.

description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson has been told by the South African authorities that a trip to their county this year would be ''inopportune.''

description: Walter F. Mondale and the Rev. Jesse Jackson announced tonight that, despite disagreements, Mr. Jackson would campaign actively for the Democratic ticket headed by Mr. Mondale and Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro.

title: No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 29, 1984 International Israeli Air Force jets bombed a Palestinian guerrilla base in the Bekaa region of eastern Lebanon and reportedly inflicted heavy casualties. Israel said the base was being used to prepare guerrilla raids against Israeli troops. The radio station of the Lebanese Christian Phalangist Party said as many as 100 people might have been killed. (Page A1, Col. 1.) An Iran Air jetliner was forced to fly to Iraq by a young, unarmed Iranian couple. At Baghdad, they surrendered, freed their 204 captives and said they wanted political asylum. An Iraqi official said the hijackers would be granted asylum and the other passengers and the crew would have three options: ''To stay in Iraq, return to Iran or leave for any destination they choose.'' (A1:1-3.)

title: NEWEST FRENCH CUISINE SIMPLER THAN NOUVELLE
description: If the period from the early 1970's to early 80's celebrated the flourishing of nouvelle cuisine in France, the remaining years of the decade may go down as an era of equilibrium. More than ever the French are paying greater attention at table to health, as a tempered nouvelle cuisine becomes modern cuisine - a style defined most simply as light, creative and sophisticated, with roots in both classical and robustly regional French cooking.

description: Year-ago results do not include operations of Vidtronics Inc. which was acquired Nov. 29, 1983.

description: Two years after Ronald Reagan first committed United States Marines to Lebanon on Aug. 24, 1982, the lessons of our involvement there can be summarized by the aphorism: If you don't succeed at first, don't try again too quickly or too strenuously.

description: DEAR DIARY: One of the the things I've noticed in the few months since we moved to Scarsdale from Greenwich Village is that women seem to sport more jewelry in the suburbs. While shopping in the local Gristede's on a recent afternoon, I turned around from the frozen food case to find my 18-month-old daughter, Bonnie, being given a lesson in pronunciation by one of them.

title: ISRAMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-No comparable year-ago results are available because the company began business in August 1983.

title: GRANTREE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
METS OBTAIN KNIGHT AS EXTRA INFIELDER
description: The Mets, seeking right-handed hitting help for the stretch run and the future, acquired Ray Knight from the Houston Astros yesterday for three minor league players to be named later.

title: STANDARD BRANDS PAINT CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 29

Help on the Way to Freighter Damaged by Storm in Pacific LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug. 28 (AP) - Rescue vessels hurried toward a hurricane-damaged freighter that lay dead in the water today with a hole in her bow after the captain and 22 crew members stabilized the foundering vessel.
description: Aircraft dropped pumps early today to the 350-foot Blue Falcon, which sent a Morse Code distress signal Monday evening saying she was sinking in the Pacific Ocean about 900 miles southwest of San Diego.

title: URUGUAY'S PARTIES FILE VOTING SLATES
description: Uruguay's political parties completed filing their presidential slates at midnight Monday for a Nov. 25 election that is designed to end 11 years of military rule.

title: Differences Reported At Parley in Panama
description: Differences on elections and the arms buildup in Central America marked a four-day meeting of the so-called Contadora group and Central American diplomats here, a communique said today.

title: FOUR COOKBOOKS WITH AN ITALIAN ACCENT
description: WITH the ripe scarlet tomatoes, glossy purple eggplants, tender young zucchini and fragrant bunches of basil at the produce stands, the first consideration is how best to combine them with garlic and olive oil. Several recent cookbooks provide some fresh Italian ideas.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Monday about steel imports misstated Brazil's share of carbon and alloy steel shipped to the United States in 1983. It was 7.3 percent.

title: THEATER: AYCKBOURN PLAY
description: ALMOST every season Alan Ayckbourn is represented on the London stage, and not just with a single play, with a round-robin evening of alternate acts and endings, some of which are decided by the toss of a coin.

title: AMIGA'S HIGH-TECH GAMBLE
description: In the obscure headquarters here of a two-year-old corporation lies a prototype of a computer that has sparked a pitched battle between the two largest competitors for the home computer market, Commodore and Atari.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Obviously with the first offer across the table, they're not going to give you the kitchen sink.

title: SHAMIR DEFENDS MOVES IN LEBANON
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today denied Lebanese assertions that Israel was hampering access to southern Lebanon, which it controls, and that it was diverting water from the area.

title: PAN-WESTERN CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; M.T.A. Revenue Issue To Yield Up to 10.839%
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which operates New York City's subway and bus system, is selling $135 million of revenue bonds backed by passenger fares plus subsidies from the state and city governments and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority. The sale is part of the authority's five-year, $6.3 billion capital improvement program to improve mass transit service.

title: MSGR. GENO BARONI, A LEADER IN NEIGHBORHOOD ORGANIZING
description: Geno C. Baroni, a Roman Catholic priest, civil rights activist, community organizer and former Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, died of cancer Sunday at Providence Hospital. He was 53 years old.

title: DANISH 'PHOENIX' AND 'NEIGHBOR'S SON'
description: THE quest for truth that tempts its seekers to employ the techniques of fiction becomes an issue in two provocative Danish films - ''Phoenix Bird'' and ''Your Neighbor's Son: The Making of a Torturer'' - opening today at the Film Forum 1.

title: MAYOR OF WASHINGTON IS SUBJECT OF PERJURY INQUIRY BY GRAND JURY
description: A Federal grand jury, looking into drug use among city employees here, asked Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. in January whether he had obtained cocaine from Karen K. Johnson, a friend who had worked for the city.

title: CHARGIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Soviet Copters Reported Deployed in Afghanistan
description: Nearly 50 Soviet helicopters have left Kabul, the Afghan capital, for southeastern Afghanistan in a new drive against guerrillas near the Pakistani border, Western diplomats said today.

title: Prisoner Slain
description: Inmates were locked in their cells at the maximum-security state prison here today as the authorities investigated stabbings that left one inmate dead and two others wounded.

title: EX-WALL ST. JOURNAL REPORTER INDICTED IN STOCK FRAUD CASE
description: Some lawyers questioned the legal foundation of the indictments. News Analysis, Page D4.

title: Reagan to Ask Pay Increase Of 3.5% for Federal Workers
description: A 3 1/2 percent pay increase for Federal workers, both civilian and military, is expected to be requested of Congress this week by President Reagan.

title: Japan Bank Files Bond Sale in U.S.
description: The Japan Development Bank, which makes long-term business loans in Japan, yesterday filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of up to $500 million of debt securities in the American capital market.

title: Givenchy Sale
description: Sterling Drug Inc. plans to sell the Givenchy fragrance unit of its Lehn & Fink Products Group to Parfums Givenchy S. A., the companies said.

title: SALVADOR FORMALIZES UNIT ON POLITICAL KILLINGS
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte issued an executive decree today officially creating a new commission to investigate politically motivated killings here.

title: MIGHT MAKES RIGHT FOR A HEAVY HITTER
description: There are tennis matches that are studies in

title: NEWSPRINT SALES KEEP MILLS BUSY
description: In 1981 MacMillan Bloedel Ltd. added the first new newsprint machine in 10 years at its Powell River plant in British Columbia. Like many of its competitors, this Vancouver- based forestry products company was expanding in response to what had been a severe shortage of newsprint in western North America from mid-1979 to 1981.

title: DEMOCRATS SET UP $27 MILLION DRIVE
description: Heavily outspent by the Republicans and encumbered by millions of dollars in debt, the Democratic Party today announced plans to raise $27 million for the forthcoming election campaign.

title: Market Place; Avon Outlook: Analysts Differ
description: A VON PRODUCTS is a company with a household name that often finds securities analysts and investment advisers disagreeing about prospects for its stock - and the present time is no exception.

title: Easco, a Toolmaker, Appoints President
description: Robert L. Swam has been named president of the Easco Corporation, the Baltimore-based hand tool manufacturer. The appointment is effective immediately, Easco said.

title: A Reorganization At Hill & Knowlton
description: Hill & Knowlton Inc., an international public relations company, said yesterday that it had reorganized its 52 offices worldwide into domestic and international units. Hill & Knowlton is a subsidary of the JWT Group.

title: BOMBARDIER INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BANK OF MONTREAL (California)A reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: SAKHAROV TV FILM, IN RERUN, RETAINS TOPICALITY
description: When the stepchildren of Andrei D. Sakharov asked HBO to give its made-for-television movie about the Nobel Laureate a special broadcast in June, in advance of the scheduled September broadcast date, HBO agreed. And some company executives expressed an apprehension that, in any case, by the time the September date came around, Dr. Sakharov's circumstances might be old news or, worse, he might be dead.

title: ANECO REINSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Operating earnings. c-Net income.

title: SAMUEL HENDEL OF CITY COLLEGE
description: Dr. Samuel Hendel, professor emeritus of political science at City College and a specialist in civil rights, died after a long illness Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 75 years old.

title: A Disease That Infects Weapons
description: The Pentagon suffers from a severely debilitating disease - lack of control over its contractors. In its last bout, the symptoms involved spare parts - paying $436 for a hammer or $1,118 for a plastic stool-leg cap. A new and far more serious strain of the disease has now struck: it involves a massive breakdown of quality control in the manufacture of three major missiles.

title: WIEBOLDT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
American National Shifts on Dillard
description: The American National Insurance Company told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had modified its plans for its holdings in Dillard Department Stores Inc. class A common stock. The company said it now intends to maintain an investment in Dillard.

title: HOME FOR DINNER
description: It is a ball park in the middle of a neighborhood,

title: RUMORS FOCUS ON CARNATION
description: TAKEOVER rumors are standard fare on Wall

title: Randy White Is Signed
description: Randy White , the Dallas Cowboys' all-pro defensive lineman who recently ended his holdout, signed a lucrative new contract. But it was not as lucrative as the contract he said he wanted: $1.3 million for each of four years. According to a National Football League source familiar with the terms, White's new four-year contract has a total value of $2,950,000, for an average of $740,000 a year.

title: The Greening Of Staten Island
description: James Miller began work on his

title: 3 STATES REBUFFED BY U.S. ON EFFORT TO CURB ACID RAIN
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today rebuffed an appeal by three Eastern states for Federal action to curb acid rain and other air pollution from sources in the Middle West.

title: CUOMO PICKS HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSIONER
description: Governor Cuomo has chosen Douglas H. White, a Koch aide, to be commissioner of the State Division of Human Rights, a spokesman for the Governor's office said yesterday.

title: PARLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THURSDAY, AUGUST 30, 1984 The Economy
description: The Government index of leading indicators fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Commerce Department reported. It was the first time this index - intended to predict changes in economic direction - had declined two consecutive months since the beginning of 1982. The report was widely regarded as confirming a slowdown in the nation's economic growth. (Page A1.)

title: PRESSURE BUILDING FOR A THRIFT UNIT GUARANTEE
description: Pressure on thrift industry regulators to announce a guarantee of all deposits at the American Savings and Loan Association appeared to be mounting today, despite the appointment on Tuesday of a new chairman and chief executive of the Financial Corporation of America, the embattled parent of American, the nation's largest thrift institution.

title: SUTCLIFFE NOW 13-1 AS CUBS BEAT REDS
description: Leon Durham drove in three runs with a homer and a single, and Bob Dernier broke an 0-for-20 slump with a home run today to lead the Chicago Cubs to a 7-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: ELECTROMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
URANIUM SHIP IS LEAKING OIL, SLOWING DOWN SALVAGE EFFORT
description: A leak of fuel oil hampered efforts today to salvage the 225-ton radioactive cargo of a French freighter that sank off the Belgian coast.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Long-Term Rates Up Slightly
description: Long-term interest rates rose slightly in quiet trading yesterday, while short-term rates were mixed.

title: YORK FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes benefits of $436,000 generated by a tax credit and other extraordinary items. York Federal Savings & Loan went public on March 6.

title: HOSPITALS THREATEN A DELAY IN STRIKERS' RAISE
description: Hospital workers will not receive the 5 percent raise they won in their 47-day strike until Governor Cuomo gives assurances that he will provide additional state funds, if needed later, to pay for the higher labor costs, the chief negotiator for the hospitals said yesterday.

title: NBC Bancshares
description: The Whitney Holding Corporation said it had agreed in principle to acquire NBC Bancshares Inc. for $85 a share.

title: WEISFIELDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid March 8, 1984.

title: ACCOUNTING MERGER TALKS CITED
description: Price Waterhouse and Deloitte Haskins & Sells, two of the nation's leading accounting firms, have reportedly discussed a possible merger of the two Big Eight firms.

title: 4 Bomb Blasts in Corsica
description: Separatists demanding independence of Corsica from France set off four bombs overnight, causing damage but no injuries, the police said today. They said pamphlets signed by the outlawed Corsican National Liberation Front had been found in Porticcio, outside Ajaccio, at the sites of the blasts - a bank, a police station, a commercial building and the apartment of a teacher from the mainland.

title: Nissan's U.S. Unit Sees Delay in Profit
description: Nissan's American manufacturing operations will not be profitable until 1987, Marvin T. Runyon, president of the Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corporation U.S.A., said today.

title: SILVERCREST INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income. c-Net loss.

title: Arrest in Dog-Maiming
description: A 20-year-old man was arrested today and charged with cruelty to animals in the maiming of six dogs with a corrosive, apparently a drain cleaner. The suspect, Charles V. Dukes, a resident of the Mount Airy section, was arrested at Municipal Court where he was to appear on unrelated charges, according to Inspector Joseph Stasnik.

title: Benton & Bowles Executive Resigns
description: Charles Blakemore, 56, has resigned as executive vice president, director of creative services worldwide for Benton & Bowles.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Zimmer Utility Ratings
description: The bond ratings may be raised of four Ohio utilities that plan to convert the Zimmer nuclear power plant to coal use, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: Reynolds to Idle Aluminum Lines
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said it would temporarily idle two aluminum production lines at its Jones Mills plant, a decision that would affect about 225 employees.

title: PIERRE GEMAYEL, A COURTLY CHIEFTAIN OF CHRISTIANS
description: Pierre Gemayel, a pharmacist from a mountain village outside Beirut, rose by dint of shrewdness and force of will to become Lebanon's paramount Christian political chieftain.

title: STAGE: JEFF WEISS'S 'RENT GETS PAID'
description: JEFF WEISS is a triple threat as playwright, actor and director - a man with an unbridled field of energy. Bottle him and he could give Con Edison a run for your money. He is the driving force behind ''. . . And That's How the Rent Gets Paid - Part IV (or, The Confessions of Conrad Gehrhardt),'' an apparently endless series of episodes in the life of an actor manque who may also be a maniac.

title: NEW-HOME SALES FLAT LAST MONTH
description: Sales of new homes held steady in July, the Government reported today, but sales activity was well below the high point of earlier this year as rising mortgage interest rates continued to dampen housing activity.

title: HEIST, C.H. CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 24
description: b-Net loss after a charge of $486,000 related to the disposal of aircraft. Corrected from last Saturday's editions.

title: COMMAND AIRWAYS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income.

title: WARD PUT ON WAIVERS BY JETS
description: Only four days before their season opener, the Jets continued today to make dramatic alterations in their team, waiving Chris Ward, who had been their starting left offensive tackle since they made him the fourth player selected over all in the 1978 draft.

title: SHARP SEEKING NEW LOOK
description: WHEN the Sharp Electronics Corporation selected Scali, McCabe, Sloves Inc. as its advertising agency last April, the consumer and industrial products marketer said it wanted a campaign that would insure that Sharp's name would be up there with the industry leaders.

title: DECORATING WITH SERENDIPITY AND A PERSONAL TOUCH
description: THE slightly tattered floral silk that upholsters the Venetian chair in Kathleen Lepercq's living room is a cloak she bought from a band of gypsies in Portugal. The wood-paneled walls, of English quartered oak, were unearthed in a Manhattan warehouse more than 20 years ago. And in the corner of the coatroom is a fragile 17th-century chair she found on the street outside the Doris Duke mansion on East 78th Street. ''My apartment is filled with everything cheap and curious,'' Mrs. Lepercq said of her new East Side duplex.

title: Stauffer Case Under Study
description: A House Government Operations subcommittee has begun an inquiry into the failure of the Securities and Exchange Commission to identify by name the accountants in a securities fraud case against the Stauffer Chemical Company.

title: Museum Postpones Kertesz Photo Show
description: A retrospective photographic exhibition of the works of Andre Kertesz, originally planned for next December in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has been postponed for a year because of scheduling problems, according to museum spokesmen.

title: COSMOS TRIUMPH IN SLOPPY MATCH
description: In one of the least appealing soccer games ever played at Giants Stadium, the Cosmos scored twice in the last 7 minutes 28 seconds and defeated the Vancouver Whitecaps, 2-1, tonight before a crowd of only 11,444.

title: DeLorean Aide Indicted
description: A Hunterdon County grand jury has indicted the personal secretary to John Z. DeLorean on two counts of cocaine possession and conspiracy to distribute the drug, the county prosecutor said. The former automobile maker's secretary, Cynthia Lee Brady, 30 years old, was one of four people arrested on June 27, the prosecutor, William Palleria, said on Tuesday.

title: Oilers Won't Get Rozier This Year
description: Mike Rozier, who won the Heisman Trophy as a running back at Nebraska last season, won't be playing for the Houston Oilers this year, General Manager Ladd Herzeg said today.

title: THATCHER CANCELS A TRIP TO FAR EAST
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that she had called off a trip to the Far East because of Britain's labor problems. A dock strike, the second this summer in support of a long walkout by coal miners, is in its fifth day.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: COLORFUL VIEWS Jim Dow is a photographer whose name is associated with panoramic photographs of major-league baseball stadiums. Rebecca Blake is a fashion photographer, many of whose female subjects appear in pictures with a narrative angle. Mr. Dow's stadiums and Miss Blake's women are on display, along with the work of 18 other photographers, in the Brooklyn Museum exhibition ''Color in the Summer.''

title: LEADER OF LEBANESE CHRISTIANS DIES, ADDING TO UNREST
description: Pierre Gemayel, the senior Christian political figure in this divided country, died today, casting more uncertainty on the deteriorating political situation.

title: ASPEN RIBBONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KAPPA NETWORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Worm and the Apple; Sweeping Up, Filling In Sanitation's Doorstep
description: ''I for one am totally dismayed, disappointed and embarrassed by the filthy condition shown,'' wrote Sanitation Commissioner Norman Steisel in a memo to his borough and district superintendents. He was referring to a photographic editorial published recently on this page showing a trash- strewn stretch of pavement directly in front of the Manhattan sanitation garage on 12th Avenue.

title: GENERAL MAGNAPLATE CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
PRACTICES CHANGING ON FLOOD INSURANCE
description: WHEN severe storms hit, as they did this spring in parts of New Jersey, thousands of homes can be damaged or destroyed by flood waters. According to the Federal Emergency Management Agency, there are six million to eight million properties in the United States in flood-hazard areas.

title: Stocks Mixed, but Dow Drops 5.19
description: Stock prices finished mixed yesterday in accelerated trading despite new evidence that the nation's economic growth is tapering off, which many investors believe is favorable for equities.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: CRAFTS FAIR AT LINCOLN CENTER
description: Autumn Crafts Festival , Fordham

title: Sigel Qualifies For Match Play
description: Playing in 104-degree heat, Jay Sigel, the defending champion, shot a 4-over-par 74 today but easily qualified for match play in the United States Amateur Championships.

title: CONTINENTAL ASSET SALE SOUGHT
description: The prospective buyer of Continental Group Inc. disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that it expected to sell about $1 billion of Continental's assets.

title: 2 Aides Suspended In Atlantic City
description: Two of Mayor James L. Usry's aides have begun serving one-week suspensions for ''exercising poor judgment'' in mixing private affairs with municipal business, city officials said.

title: PROGRESS MADE ON HAY FEVER
description: THE Labor Day holiday may mean rest to

title: 'EMPIRE' VIDEO RIGHTS BOUGHT FOR $12 MILLION
description: With the heavy breathing of Darth Vader and a five-minute laser show shredding the darkness, CBS/Fox Video tonight unveiled its purchase of ''The Empire Strikes Back'' for video cassettes. The video rights to the second film in George Lucas's ''Star Wars'' trilogy were sold for $12 million, a price undreamed of a few years ago.

title: SMUGGLING PLOT ON BIRDS OF PREY LAID TO SAUDIS
description: A United States Fish and Wildlife Service agent has testified that the Saudi Arabian Embassy helped smuggle birds of prey out of the United States, possibly by using diplomatic privileges.

title: She Takes Manhattan
description: Stacy Chanin , only 10 days ago ill with a virus, emerged from the East River last night to become the first person to swim around Manhattan three times. Miss Chanin, 23 years old, spent 33 hours 29 minutes in the water but did not attempt to swim the additional five miles needed to equal the long-distance record of 89 miles, held by Diana Nyad .

title: Reaching Out And Touching 3 Boroughs
description: The new 718 telephone area code for Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island - which has been denounced by politicians from those boroughs as an unwarranted separation from the rest of the city, which will continue to use 212 - is not supposed to take effect until Saturday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amdahl Corp., Sunnyvale, Calif., a manufacturer of large computer systems, has named David J. Horton vice president and general manager of its Communications Systems division in Marina Del Rey, Calif.

title: PARKS AND BRIDGES GO UP FOR 'ADOPTION'
description: ADOPTION is a concept that seems to bring out the best in people. At least that is the experience of park commissions and preservation and conservation societies, and they are applying the principle of adoption to everything from neighborhood parks to the restoration of Revolutionary War uniforms. In addition to Adopt-a-Park programs in New York, Memphis and Berkeley, Calif., the Los Angeles Conservancy is calling its program of watching historic houses Adopt- a-Building. In Baltimore the label Adopt-a-Lot applies to vacant city-owned property that neighborhood associations can take over for community gardens. In Tennessee it is possible to adopt parks, schools and even old bridges.

title: KNIGHT GETS START IN DEBUT FOR METS
description: Ray Knight, the newest Met, was in such a rush to get to New York yesterday that in his hectic departure he might have grabbed his 9-month-old daughter and left his equipment bag at his Houston home. Fortunately, after he had kissed his daughter, Ashley Marie, goodbye, he left her with his wife, Nancy. But he also left his equipment bag with Nancy.

title: AHC Enterprises
description: A unit of the Americana Hotels Corporation, AHC Enterprises Inc., said it had decided not to continue with its previously announced intention to make a $21-a-share tender offer for American Motor Inns Inc. On Tuesday, American Motor said its board had voted to recommend to shareholders that they tender shares to Prime Motor Inns Inc., which is offering $21.50 a share. American Motor, based in Roanoke, Va., has about 11.3 million shares outstanding.

title: MONDALE INTENDS TO REBUT REAGAN ON RELIGION ISSUE
description: Walter F. Mondale has decided to make a major campaign issue out of President Reagan's comments that religious and political ideas are linked. Mr. Mondale made it clear today that he was planning a major statement on the subject soon.

title: Moses Continues Hurdles Streak
description: Edwin Moses, unbeaten since 1977, scored his 109th consecutive victory in the men's 400-meter hurdles, clocking the world's best time this year of 47.32 seconds at an international track and field meet here today.

title: SIGMAFORM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings for both years reflect a 2-for-1 stock split on June 18.

title: KOCH IS ACCUSED OF BACKING'BOSSISM' IN A VILLAGE CONTEST
description: Mayor Koch was accused by some political leaders yesterday of trying to reintroduce to Greenwich Village the ''bossism'' he helped defeat there a quarter of a century ago.

title: INVESTIGATION AGENCY ASSAILED ON 2 REPORTS
description: City Councilwoman Ruth W. Messinger, citing discrepancies between two city reports on the conduct of the Human Resources Administration, yesterday questioned the independence of the agency that prepared them, the Department of Investigation.

title: SOUTHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $12,328,000, or 58 cents a share. c-After tax credits of $7,946,000, or 26 cents a share, for the latest year and $24,900,000, or $1.18 a share, for the earlier period.

title: TROUBLE-PLAGUED SHUTTLE IS SET TO FLY
description: The computers willing, and if the fuel valve and master timing device behave and no other problems arise, the trouble-plagued space shuttle Discovery is at last to begin its inaugural voyage with a load of three satellites and a crew of six on Thursday.

title: BOOKS TO HELP ANTIQUES BUFFS
description: For those who enjoy antiques, these recent books offer helpful information on choosing and repairing furniture and decorative objects:

title: AT MUNICH'S U.S. RADIO STATIONS, WHAT'S NEWS?
description: Never exactly a center of calm, Radio Liberty and Radio Free Europe in Munich are going through a new phase of unrest, agitation and dissent.

title: CERTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $47,000. c-Net income

title: Dominican Troops Deployed To Prevent Street Protests
description: The Dominican Republic, fearing another round of violent protests in response to price increases, deployed troops in its major cities today and ordered schools to remain closed for three more weeks, senior officials said.

title: STEVENS, J.P. & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 4
Stadium Squabble
description: The prospective Cleveland Indian owner, David LeFevre , could decide to take the team out of town for two years if he cannot obtain a lease at 78,000-seat Cleveland Stadium. Although the New York lawyer has an agreement to purchase the American League team, he has yet to obtain a new lease for the stadium with Stadium Corporation.

title: POP: MASEKELA'S VARIETY OF STYLES
description: AT Sounds of Brazil through tonight, Hugh Masekela is leading his most African- sounding band in two decades. Since he exiled himself from South Africa in 1961, Mr. Masekela has worked primarily as a pop-jazz fluegelhornist - most successfully in the late 1960's, with the hit ''Grazing in the Grass.'' Spurred, perhaps, by the current interest in African pop, Mr. Masekela recorded his new album, ''Techno-Bush,'' in Botswana, in southern Africa, where he now lives. He also recruited a new 12- member band of musicians from southern Africa.

title: LAZARE KAPLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a gain of $2,804,000 from the restructuring of debt.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE FOURTH PROTOCOL. By Frederick Forsyth. 389 pages. Viking Press. $17.95.

title: HOW SOTHEBY'S RESEARCHED RARE HEBREW BOOKS
description: In June 1983, George Snyder, an expert in Jewish books and manuscripts at Sotheby's in New York, received a packet of four Polaroid photographs from a visitor to the auction house. The pictures showed an illuminated Hebrew manuscript of a Bible, dating from the 15th century, that Mr. Snyder immediately recognized as being an extremely valuable work.

title: SHONEY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 5
ATLANTA AWAITS BANK MERGERS
description: Despite Atlanta's rapid growth in the last quarter-century, it lacks a locally based bank big enough to rival the leading money-center institutions. While Atlanta is unlikely to challenge New York or San Francisco anytime soon, it is showing new signs of strength.

title: ALVARADO TAKES A CONSULTANT'S POST
description: Anthony J. Alvarado, the former New York City Schools Chancellor, has got his first job since leaving office under pressure last May.

title: Top Matches For Today
description: STADIUM Morning 11 A.M. - Andres Gomez vs.

title: INSURING TAX-EXEMPT BONDS
description: With each calamity of the municipal bond market, the investor's appetite for security has grown. And that, in turn, has meant that more bonds than ever are being sold with the backing of insurance companies.

title: Canada Steel Warning
description: Canada's international trade minister threatened retaliation against the United States today in a last-ditch effort to persuade the White House to exempt Canada from proposed import barriers on steel.

title: MONTEFUSCO HELPS YANKS GAIN TIE FOR 3D
description: The Yankees, rebounding from a 12-inning loss to Oakland a night earlier, banged out nine hits to defeat the A's, 4-1, tonight.

title: OL' LIBERAL-BAITING IS BACK
description: Throughout Dixie, the letters sections of newspapers are crammed with frantic appeals to all the good ol' boys and girls to rise up on Election Day and save America from the godless liberals. This call follows many years of conditioning by such Southern leaders as Jesse Helms, Jerry Falwell and Strom Thurmond and their ideological ancestors, who have let us know strongly and often that what liberals are for, good conservative WASP's are against. Here in the Bible Belt, it's either God or Satan and you had better be for or against, 'cause we don't like fence-straddlers.

title: Rating Review
description: Atlantic Richfield Co.'s long-term debt and debt rating are being reviewed for a possible downgrading by Moody's. About $2.1 billion of debt would be affected, although the company's prime rating is not under review.

title: KAHANE BARRED FROM ENTERING AN ARAB TOWN
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane and three busloads of armed supporters were blocked by the police today when they tried to enter Israel's largest Arab town as part of a campaign to drive Arab citizens from the country.

title: Greek Power To Battle Graffiti
description: ''Eureka! I have found it! That's redundant.''

title: Center Quits Kentucky
description: Citing ''circumstances at home,'' the University of Kentucky's highly touted 7-foot-4-inch center, Gunther Behnke , left the school yesterday for his native West Germany.

title: FINE ART ACQUISITIONS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $16,000 for the quarter and $28,800 for the 6 months.

title: White House Outlines Policy On Sticks at Election Rallies
description: Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said Tuesday that decisions on whether to let protesters carry homemade signs on sticks at campaign rallies for President Reagan would be made ''on a case-by-case basis.''

title: A MILD COMPETITOR WANTS TO BE TOUGH
description: Agresivo. Translated into English,

title: U.S. Cyclist Wins
description: Connie Paraskevin of the United States defeated Ericka Saloumiaee of the Soviet Union in a tiebreaker to capture her third consecutive world championship in the women's cycling sprints. Capitalizing on a judge's decision to annul the second final heat, won Tuesday by the Soviet rider, Miss Paraskevin surged ahead to win the last 200 meters by a bike length in 12.10 seconds.

title: No Headline
description: THURSDAY, AUGUST 30, 1984 International Rabbi Meir Kahane was blocked from entering Israel's largest Arab town as he tried to launch a campaign to drive Arab citizens from the country. The Brooklyn-born rabbi and three busloads of armed supporters were barred by the police at a roadblock two miles outside Um el Fahm, a community of 25,000 in the Galilee region. The rabbi was detained and then released. (Page A1, Column 2.) Pierre Gemayel died of a heart attack, casting more uncertainty on Lebanon's deteriorating political situation. The death of the 78-year-old senior Christian political figure could set off a power struggle and perhaps undermine the position of his eldest son, President Amin Gemayel. (A10:3-6.) The elder Mr. Gemayel was a founding member and the perennial leader of the right-wing Phalangist Party, which is Lebanon's strongest Christian political group, with its own armed militia. (A10:3-6.)

title: Who's Who Honors 5 For High Achievement
description: Lee A. Iococca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, and Malcom Cowley, writer and literary critic, were among the five winners of the 1984-85 Achievement Awards presented by

title: Lee Charges Bias
description: Deputy State Athletic Commissioner Robert W. Lee denied charges that he violated conflict-of-interest laws and labeled the accusations of a New Jersey ethics committee a ''smokescreen.'' Lee's comments came on the deadline for a response to the nine-count civil complaint filed by the Executive Commission on Ethical Standards that accused him of violating the conflict-of-interest laws by soliciting and receiving contributions from boxing promoters regulated by the athletic commission.

title: Shultz's Travels
description: Partly to avoid Congressional

title: EDITOR ANGERS FELLOW SINHALESE IN SRI LANKA
description: A story about Gamani Navaratna going the rounds of this capital of the Tamil-dominated Northern Province goes like this:

title: Bridge:F
description: One of the principal problems of bridge clubs is that they are virtually invisible. If you do not already know the name of a club, the Manhattan telephone directory, like most others, is useless. The would-be player who searches under ''Clubs'' in the Yellow Pages will find only one, and that is not identified as a bridge club.

title: CENTRAL AMERICA: POINTS FOR A MONDALE POSITION
description: To the Editor:

title: Julie Stevens Is Dead at 67; Broadway and Radio Actress
description: Julie Stevens, who played the role of Helen Trent from 1944 to 1960 on the radio soap opera ''The Romance of Helen Trent'' and appeared on the early prime-time television program ''Big Town'' with Patrick McVey, died of cancer at her home in Wellfleet, Mass., last Sunday. She was 67 years old.

title: Certificates Set At American Air
description: American Airlines Inc. is issuing $103 million of secured equipment certificates series B with a top yield of 14.375 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: A CLERICAL ERROR COSTS CANDIDATE PLACE ON TICKET
description: On the basis of a mistake with a calculator, New York State's highest court yesterday invalidated the designating petitions of a State Senator, denying her renomination on the Democratic Party line.

title: OF ZERO-COUPON BONDS AND RUNAWAY DEFICITS
description: To the Editor:

title: Magazine Focuses On Intrigue, Suspense
description: Jacqueline Lewis and Geraldine Winston, the 50-year-old twin sisters of the publisher of Penthouse, Bob Guccione, have begun their own magazine venture - Espionage - that will be introduced Oct. 11.

title: WALESA IS HARSH AND HOPEFUL ON POLISH SITUATION
description: Lech Walesa, the founder of the banned Solidarity union, assailed Poland's leaders today for what he called their failure to abide by the accords on free speech, free press and independent unions that were signed here nearly four years ago.

title: Textile Import Rules
description: A bipartisan group of Senators, concerned that China could halt promised purchases of United States farm goods, urged President Reagan in a letter today to scrap new rules governing textile imports.

title: ATOMIZING BASES
description: The Defense Department is bullish on nuclear power. This is, to say the least, a curious stance, given that the civilian nuclear power industry is virtually dead in the water because of financial and safety problems.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; The Top Executive At Horizon Quits
description: The Horizon Corporation said yesterday that it had accepted the resignation of Floyd Bailey as its chairman, president and chief executive officer, effective today.

title: First-Class Stamp Cost Seen as Rising to 23/
description: Postmaster General William F. Bolger says the cost of mailing a letter may increase to 23 cents by early 1985 but should stay at that rate until the 1990's.

title: U.N. COUNCIL IS URGED TO GET ISRAEL OUT OF LEBANON
description: Lebanon's chief delegate here appealed to the Security Council today to put into effect past resolutions calling on Israel to withdraw from Lebanon and to immediately ''lift its siege'' on southern Lebanon.

title: A HARVEST OF GRAPES ON A CITY TERRACE
description: A GRAPE arbor seemed the most practical solution for Bill Barnes's midtown penthouse garden. Mr. Barnes, a producer and managing agent for actors and writers who has gardened on his sunny terrace for 10 years, had replaced awning after awning on the south side. Four years ago, to temper the summer sun, he decided to create a shady arbor.

title: WASHINGTON MAYOR ASSAILS DISCLOSURE ON INQUIRY
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of the District of Columbia today assailed reports that he was the target of a Federal investigation into cocaine use in city government. He said Federal investigators had resorted to ''a leak a week'' because they had no evidence against him.

title: POWER TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: REVIEW AND OVERVIEW OF OPERA SUPERTITLES
description: English translations or condensations projected on a screen over the stage. A number of observers have seen in them what Donal Henahan, the chief music critic of The New York Times, called in these pages ''hope for the befuddled,'' a potential solution to the age-old problem of opera in foreign languages.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: SCOPE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $1,737,250 from the sale of Avnet stock. c-After an extraordinary gain of $22,393,178 related to the sale of Avnet stock.

title: CCX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,178,000 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $605,000 for the 6 months, and tax credits of $333,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,564,000 for the quarter and $942,000 for the 6 months. d-Net loss. Year-ago results are restated to exclude the operations of CCS Cable division and to include them as discontinued operations.

title: AVCO TO BUY ITS STOCK TO END LEUCADIA
description: The Avco Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy back a huge block of its stock held by the Leucadia National Corporation, eliminating the threat of an unwanted takeover by Leucadia.

title: STRIKERS RETURN TO HUGS AND CHEERS
description: Gone yesterday were the picket lines, the chants for higher pay, the doctors working overtime to help fold sheets.

title: ; GET SET, FANS, FOR KEMP VS. BRADLEY IN '88
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-FEDERAL ATTORNEY IN OKLAHOMA PICKED BY G.O.P. FOR HOUSE RACE
description: Oklahoma Republicans chose former United States Attorney Frank Keating on Tuesday to oppose Representative James R. Jones, who the Republicans say is vulnerable for defeat this fall.

title: Miami Beach Fire Kills One
description: A woman was killed and six firefighers were treated for heat exhaustion today in a fire that destroyed the victim's fifth- floor apartment at the Arlen House East Condominiums. The identity of the woman was not released pending notification of relatives. Ob Caudle, manager of the complex, said the apartment where the fire originated was owned by an elderly woman who lived alone.

title: COURT REJECTS REAGAN VETO ON SALVADOR
description: The United States Court of Appeals here ruled today that President Reagan did not have the constitutional authority to try to use a pocket veto between two sessions of Congress, as he did last November.

title: Basques Protest in France
description: Supporters of seven Spanish Basque refugees threatened with extradition from France today occupied two town halls in the French Basque country in a peaceful two-hour protest, witnesses said. They said 25 people at Ispoure and about 30 in Hendaye entered the town halls with anti-Government posters to protest against court rulings that France should extradite the seven, who are wanted in Spain to face charges of murder and assault.

title: PAUL THEROUX JOINS CRITICS ON 'FIRST EDITION'
description: CERTAINLY the aim of ''First Edition'' is a worthy one: use television - the medium responsible for distracting so many Americans from reading - to get people thinking about books. To say the least, it's a difficult assignment.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: C.D. Rates Fall Again
description: Average effective yields on six- month certificates of deposit continued to plummet nationally in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported. Once again, the drop in The Monitor's national index for the six-month products, to 11.16 percent, from 11.26 percent, could be traced to steep declines in yields offered by major New York- area institutions.

title: Commuter Yields As a Tax Resister
description: A commuter whose challenge of Philadelphia's wage tax was rejected by the New Jersey Supreme Court has decided to pay $15,000 in back taxes and penalties and urges others to do the same.

title: 23 Abandon Freighter Stricken in Pacific
description: The 23 crew members of a crippled Cypriot freighter were safe today after they abandoned ship in storm-tossed Pacific waters, and the 360-foot vessel was listing dangerously as her forward holds filled with water.

title: Transactions
description: Placed Scott McGregor, pitcher, on 21-day disabled list because of broken left ring finger and reactivated Jim Dwyer, outfielder. LOS ANGELES (NL) - Recalled Sid Bream, first baseman; R. J. Reynolds, outfielder, and Jack Fimple and Gilberto Reyes, catchers, effective Sept. 1, from Albuquerque of the Pacific Coast League. Sold the contracts of Alex Taveras, infielder, and Mike Vail, outfielder, to Albuquerque. METS (NL) - Placed Doug Sisk, pitcher, on active roster and optioned Wes Gardner, pitcher, to Tidewater. Announced that they were purchasing contract of Calvin Schiraldi, pitcher, from Tidewater. TEXAS (AL) - Danny Darwin, pitcher, was suspended for two games for making physical contact with Ken Kaiser, an umpire, during an argument on Aug. 18. BASKETBALL HOUSTON (NBA) - Acquired Hank McDowell, forward, from Los Angeles Clippers in exchange for third-round draft pick in 1985. INDIANA (NBA) - Signed Vern Fleming, guard. COLLEGES HARTFORD - Named Bill Denehy head baseball coach. FOOTBALL BUFFALO (AFC) - Acquired on waivers Ulysses Norris, tight end. Cut Russell Davis, tight end. CHICAGO (NFC) - Acquired from waivers Rusty Lisch, quarterback, and Mitch Krenk, tight end. Placed Steve Fuller, quarterback, and Pat Dunsmore, tight end, on injured reserve. CLEVELAND (AFC) - Claimed Ted Petersen, tackle, from waivers. DETROIT (NFC) - Signed Leonard Thompson, wide receiver, to three-year contract. GREEN BAY (NFC) - Placed Eddie Lee Ivery, running back, on injured reserve list. HOUSTON (AFC) - Waived Bill Kay and Greg Hill, defensive backs; Stan Edwards, running back; Walt Arnold, tight end; Juan Jones, linebacker; Doug Kellermeyer, offensive lineman, and Kevin Baugh, wide receiver-kick returner.

title: SAXTON PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $96,483 and a tax credit of $80,775. c-Net loss after income from discontinued operations of $181,102.

title: METS TRIUMPH ON PINCH-HITTING
description: Despite allowing only 3 hits and striking out 12 in 7 innings, Ron Darling did not emerge with a victory in the Mets' 3-2 decision over the Los Angeles Dodgers last night at Shea Stadium. But then, considering recent developments involving Darling, that was nothing new.

title: Gas Blast Wrecks A House on L.I.
description: An explosion of natural gas shattered a house here at dawn today, spreading debris across the neighborhood and touching off a fire that destroyed what was left of the home.

title: SPACE STRATEGY APPROVED, MINUSNEW GOALS
description: President Reagan has approved a long-awaited ''national space strategy'' that sets forth no new goals but instead assigns responsibilities for carrying out studies or accomplishing the goals already announced.

title: JERSEY ASBESTOS CHECK AT SCHOOLS SAID TO LAG
description: About 200 of the 300 New Jersey schools where asbestos was removed this summer have not been inspected and given final approval to reopen next week, the State Public Advocate's Office said today.

title: D'Arcy Canada
description: William M. McKechnie, 48, has joined D'Arcy MacManus Masius/ Canada as chief operating officer. Mr. McKechnie, who has owned and operated two Canadian communications concerns, McKechnie & Company and Willhurst Communications, will succeed Charles J. Prince, 56, as president and chief executive officer of the agency when Mr. Prince retires at the end of the year.

title: Environment Unsafe For an E.P.A. Official
description: The regional chief of the Environmental Protection Agency has vacated his office for his own protection from its environment.

title: Bossy's Back To Business
description: Mike Bossy plans to take part in his first full workout with Team Canada today after returning to New York last week with an ailing right knee. And, if all goes well, the Islander right wing hopes to be in the lineup Saturday night when Canada faces West Germany in the opening round of the six-nation Canada Cup series in Montreal.

title: WEAVER: A BOXING FOOTNOTE
description: The admirers were mostly young women who asked Mike Weaver for his autograph while fixing their gaze on the cresting biceps that earned Weaver the nickname Hercules. But before the news conference had ended, even a young boxer named Slammin' Sammy Scarf - an imposing man in his own right - had politely handed Weaver a sheet of note paper to sign. More than just a fellow boxer, Scarf recognized Weaver as a former champion - heavyweight champion of the world at that.

title: Stanford U. Is Granted Gene-Molecule Patent
description: Stanford University has been granted a patent covering genetically engineered molecules that can be used to develop products in bacteria, such as vaccines and drugs.

title: ADVANCED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
California Group Seeks Vote on a Budget Plan
description: The Supreme Court is being asked to rule whether Californians may vote on a referendum calling for their state's support of a budget-balancing amendment to the United States Constitution.

title: 'Tightrope' First Again In Sales for Week
description: Clint Eastwood, in ''Tightrope,'' remained the top box-office draw for a second consecutive week.

title: Nuclear Plant Is Restarted
description: The Washington Public Power Supply System's No. 2 reactor was back in operation today, ending a six-day shutdown caused when a large pipe shifted after hot water was mixed with cold.

title: 50 DIED IN PROTESTS, LIBERIAN GROUP CHARGES
description: The Liberian Community Association in New York charged yesterday that more than 50 students have been killed and more than 400 wounded in Liberia since Aug. 22, when troops were sent to quell a demonstration at the University of Monrovia.

title: YRI-YORK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,037,000 for the quarter and $4,261,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $631,000 for the quarter and $1,361,000 for the 6 months. There are no share earnings for the latest periods because the company only has preferred shares listed.

title: Gallup Poll Reports Equal Rating for Parties
description: The public rates the two political parties about equally on their ability to handle the nation's most important problem, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: HOW TO TELL THE GOVERNMENT STORY
description: After a two-year study of press officers in Government, Stephen Hess says one of the best he found was Linda Gosden, who worked in 1982 for Drew Lewis, then Secretary of Transportation.

title: Canadian G.N.P. Rises
description: Canada's economy grew at an annual rate of 2.8 percent in the second quarter from the period a year earlier, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today.

title: Making a Match
description: Teddy Brenner, the matchmaker for Top Rank Inc., which will promote the card on which Steve McCrory will make his pro debut, Oct. 19 at Madison Square Garden, was introducing the 112-pound division gold medalist yesterday to the boxing world.

description: Directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority voted today

title: I.B.M. CUTS SOME MAINFRAME PRICES
description: The International Business Machines Corporation cut prices on its most advanced line of mainframe computers and disk drives yesterday for the second time in a year, in a move analysts said would place greater pressure its competitors at the high end of the market.

title: IN NILE HUTS, TV AND OLD VALUES
description: Will the stampede toward the consumer society cause unbearable strains on Islam? Everybody in Egypt keeps watching for signs.

The Big Bucks
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey was the clear winner of a race to the bank with rebate checks to large pubic customers that John S. Dyson, chairman of the New York Power Authority, took to City Hall yesterday. The refunds reflected the lower-than-anticipated cost of generating power for those customers.

The August Respite
description: Mugginess returned to the capital yesterday after an unusual two weeks of dry, cool, breezy air.

description: b-The company broke even in the latest quarter.

title: Storm Forms in Mid-Atlantic
description: Tropical Storm Arthur, with winds of 50 miles an hour, formed in the warm waters of the mid-Atlantic today and headed toward Barbados in the southeastern corner of the Caribbean Sea. Forecasters said the first Atlantic-Caribbean tropical storm of the season was expected to sweep over the Windward Islands with gales and heavy rains by Thursday.

title: Moroccan Dead After Fast
description: One of 30 Moroccan prisoners who have been on a hunger strike since July 4 died yesterday in a hospital, their families said in a statement distributed in Rabat.

title: Armory Saved
description: For more than six decades, the armory at 168th Street and Fort Washington Avenue, has been the city's busiest indoor track facility and has been the site of most major high school, college and amateur indoor track meet. Dozens of high schools and colleges, as well as the Metropolitan Athletic Congress, use it for practice. In addition, in the last several years it has been used as a shelter for hundreds of homeless men.

title: CHESSCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $111,000, or 13 cents a share. c-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $679,000.

description: b-Includes a gain of $11,600,000, or 26 cents a share, from the adjustment of tax reserves established in prior years, and a one-time pre-tax charge of $6,200,000 to establish a voluntary retirement assistance program.

title: Midlantic Banks
description: A $50 million issue of convertible subordinated debentures due in 2009 was offered by Midlantic Banks Inc. of Edison, N.J., through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The company said the proceeds would replace $20 million principal amount used to repay the company's 8 7/8 percent notes due Sept. 1, with the balance being used to repay other debt and for general corporate purposes.

title: Ogilvy and Marriott End Their Affiliation
description: Ogilvy & Mather and Marriott Hotels and Resorts have agreed to terminate their partnership of seven years.

title: B-1 CRASH SEEN HAVING LITTLE EFFECT
description: Supporters and opponents of the B-1 bomber in Congress predicted today that the fatal crash of a test aircraft in California would have little long-term effect on the multibillion-dollar program.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN PLAYERS FIND SECOND HOME ON HARLEM STAGE
description: For the actors and many in the audience, it was not just the opening of a play, but a celebration and a homecoming.

title: MORRIS WILL START AT HALFBACK
description: The Giants will have new looks in many ways when they open the season here Sunday against the Philadelphia Eagles. To begin with, 27 of the 49 players who dressed for last year's opener are gone. And there has been shuffling even among those who remain.

description: For many grown-ups, Labor Day seems the equivalent of the first day of school - at least for getting one's pens and pencils in order.

title: MONDALE PASSES BLACK LEADERS' TEST
description: Until the final moments of a tense showdown between the Democratic Presidential nominee and 50 black leaders, no one was quite sure how much support the group would throw behind Walter F. Mondale's candidacy.

title: WHITHER THE COUNCIL OF ECONOMIC ADVISERS?
description: When Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers, left the Government to return to Harvard in July, the wind went out of the Council's sails. And the Reagan Administration is seeing to it that it remains becalmed.

description: -business jack-of- all-trades for more than 35 years, Steve Allen has long augmented his role of variety-show host and comedian by displaying his talents as a pop-jazz pianist and composer. On television, Mr. Allen's relationship to pop has been more that of an erudite fan than an accomplished virtuoso.

description: John R. Bolin has been named president and chief executive officer of Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc., a Los Angeles-based regional brokerage house, the firm's parent company, the Kemper Corporation, announced yesterday.

title: Harry Doll, Episcopal Bishop And Maryland Rights Activist
description: The Right Rev. Harry Lee Doll, a retired Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Maryland, an activist in religious programs and civil rights, died Monday at the age of 81.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: -gloss varnish or enamel to a flat surface knows how difficult it can be to get a smooth finish that doesn't show brush marks, runs or other blemishes. Although this will occasionally be the fault of the paint, usually it is the result of one of three things: A poor-quality brush was used; the surface was not properly cleaned and prepared beforehand, or poor brushing techniques were used when applying the finish.

title: THERE'S STILL TIME TO SOW COOL WEATHER CROPS
description: GARDENERS have a tendency to let up now. After all, they rationalize, faithfulness to the trowel and mower have earned them a respite. But soil in the vegetable patch does not take kindly to time off. Weeds soon take over and valuable ground space is lost.

title: Security Pacific
description: The Security Pacific Corporation said its Security Pacific National Bank had agreed to acquire the remaining shares outstanding of the Bank of Canton, based in Hong Kong. Security Pacific, which now holds 69 percent of the Bank of Canton, said it would pay $59.31 a share, or about $42.4 million, for the 714,128 common shares it does not already own. Stockholder and governmental approvals are required before completion of the final agreement, which has been approved by the boards of both companies, Security Pacific said.

description: b-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $221,000 for the quarter and $417,000 for the 6 months, and losses from the disposal of discontinued operations of $13,489,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in June. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: COMPUTERCRAFT INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 28

Cocaine vs. Democracy in the Andes The foreign relations of Peru, Bolivia, Colombia and the United States are linked by one word: cocaine. Most of the drug that's sold in this country comes from those three states in the Andean region of South America. Much of the money that circulates in those countries comes from drug users in this one. As a result, Washington's domestic and foreign policy interests coincide.
description: The United States wants to fight its drug problem at the source, and doing so depends on programs undertaken by fragile democratic governments. How fragile is demonstrated by recent events in all three countries. Peru's Government is losing ground. Bolivia's is barely holding even. Only in neighboring Colombia is there some basis for optimism.

title: A FOREST PLANTED ON A LOT IN CHICAGO
description: Less than half a block from a busy street of fashionable restaurants and ice- cream parlors grows a dense, dark forest of tall pine, birch and cottonwood trees. It is a wild place where people are not supposed to go.

title: LIBYA BUILDS A RIVER ACROSS THE DESERT
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, pushed a green button as the amber sun slipped slowly into the Great Sand Sea, a vast expanse of barren desert. A second later, a geyser of fresh water gushed 100 feet from the sand.

title: NINE LINKED TO PLOTS IN DALLAS
description: Federal agents believe they foiled a pair of terrorist plots against the Republican National Convention last week, including a plan for an ultralight aircraft attack, by arresting nine Iranians and Palestine Liberation Organization supporters, officials said today.

title: Firebomb on Capitol Steps
description: A 20-year-old man was charged today with throwing a firebomb that singed the steps of the Capitol and slightly injured a bystander, the authorities said. Sgt. Karen Magee of the Capitol Police said the suspect, Henry David Briody, 20 years old, was arrested on an arson charge shortly after the device ignited at 6:35 A.M.

title: SPLIT CITED ON COPPER IMPORT BAR
description: A subCabinet Trade Policy Review Group has recommended overwhelmingly that President Reagan reject a plea for import protection brought by domestic copper producers, according to a senior trade official.

title: NBC TEAM GAVE DANES CHILD PORNOGRAPHY DATA
description: The correspondent and the producer of a recent NBC documentary on sexual abuse of children, which included examples of child pornography produced in Denmark, gave some of the research material they had collected to the Danish police.

title: CLASSIC CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Key Official Resigns At Pacific Scientific
description: The Pacific Scientific Company said yesterday that Stephen J. Toth had resigned as president, chief executive officer and director of the company.

title: Philippine Bank Merger
description: Two of the largest banks in the Philippines said today that they would merge to create the country's largest private bank, with assets of about $1 billion. The Bank of the Philippine Islands, with assets of about $676 million, said it was acquiring the Family Bank and Trust Company.

title: INSITUFORM EAST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

description: The missing names are formidable. Vladislav Tretyak has retired. Vyacheslav Fetisov is back in the Soviet Union with a broken ankle. And Nikolai Drozdetski is still recovering from a kidney injury he suffered this spring.

description: 1984 earnings estimate of $9.54

title: Hunt Acquisition
description: The Hunt Manufacturing Company said it had agreed to acquire Innovative Concepts Inc. for stock valued at $18 million. Innovative Concepts, a closely held concern that supplies parts for floppy disks used in personal and small-business computers, had sales last year of $13 million. Hunt makes art and office supplies and metal products.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Boxing Marvin Johnson vs. John Davis, light heavyweights, 10 rounds, at the Sands Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City; first preliminary, 8 P.M. Johnson captured the World Boxing Council crown in 1978 and then the World Boxing Association title in 1979.

title: AEROFLEX LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SPACE PHOTOS SHOW NEW SOVIET ROCKETS
description: Air Force satellite photographs of launching pads in central Asia show that the Soviet Union is developing a booster rocket for a Russian version of the space shuttle and a new family of big rockets similar to those used by the United States for the Apollo moon program, according to space industry experts and Government intelligence officials.

title: OUR TOWNS
description: The subject this morning is fruits and vegetables and cultural isolation and sunburned farmers trying to make a buck. And if it begins with Carleta Lucas, rest her soul, there is no disrespect intended.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Acme-Cleveland Corp., a maker of foundry equipment in Cleveland, said it had acquired Spline Gauges Ltd. of Tanworth, England, and its Picadilly Precision Engineering Ltd. affiliate. Terms were not disclosed.

title: REAGAN VETOES 1987-89 FUND INCREASES FOR PBS
description: President Reagan today vetoed the higher spending authorizations passed by Congress for public broadcasting for three years beginning in 1987, saying that if he did otherwise, the spending ''would be increased much too fast.''

title: NAVRATILOVA DEFEATS ANTONOPLIS AT OPEN
description: This time Martina Navratilova is defending a United States Open title, not grinding herself down in practice trying to win her first one. This time she is relaxed and confident, building a record that has already earned a place in tennis history rather then fending off questions about the Grand Slam event she had never won.

title: Turks Hold American Over Claim to the Ark
description: An American who said he had found the remains of Noah's Ark on Mount Ararat was detained for several hours today at the Istanbul airport.

title: BOY SACRIFICES LIFE TO AID HIS HUNGRY FAMILY
description: A shocked community sent food and money today to the Army family of a 13-year-old boy who hanged himself after telling his mother, ''If there was one less mouth to feed, things would be better.''

title: U.S. INVESTIGATING TRAVEL TO CUBA
description: The Reagan Administration, in an effort to tighten the enforcement of curbs on travel to Cuba, is investigating trips to Havana by scholars, journalists, lawyers and other professionals, Administration officials said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is this pervasive distrust. The Government can say everything is working, but people will see the long lines that form overnight in front of the stores, and they know.''

title: LIFEGUARDS DEPRIVED OF NECESSARY GEAR
description: To the Editor:

title: A FIFTH-FLOOR WALK-UP HAS PERSONALITY
description: WHAT my apartment lacks in space and chic, it makes up in lovableness and vulnerability. Four steep and winding flights, more often than not in need of sweeping, lead me to a rent-controlled aerie with a view of Gramercy Park. I admire the view through windows whose sashes have worn so loose that during a gale it is necessary to insert pieces of folded cardboard to still the rattling. Yet none of the windows move up and down easily. Which is awkward when I hear fire engines at 2 A.M. and want to open the window and look out to see if it is my building the firefighters are entering. The 8-by-12-foot bedroom has a window that doesn't move up or down at all; it just remains slightly open, winter and summer.

title: EVEN DAM PLANS NEVER DIE
description: When the Interior Department announced this month that its Bureau of Reclamation would help China build a hydroelectric project on the Yangtze River, it demonstated what some in Washington regard as a truism about such projects: Old dam plans never die; they just ebb and flow with the political tides.

title: Opposition Leader Steps Down in Greece
description: Evangelos Averoff, leader of the conservative opposition New Democracy Party, submitted his resignation from the leadership today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about Democratic fund-raising misidentified a man shown pointing to a chart. He was Timothy W. Finchem, head of the Democratic Victory Fund.

title: Intertec Moves
description: The Intertec Data Systems Corporation said it had moved production for its European dealers and distributors to its main plant in Columbia, S.C., from Dublin, in a move to consolidate and to strengthen cost- containment measures. It also said it had moved its Fixfire Research subsidiary from Hilton Head Island, S.C., to Columbia, to cut expenses. Intertec said it would consolidate some departments and eliminate some positions, but it expected no more than 25 employees to be affected.

title: JOBLESSNESS CITED IN URBAN SURVEY
description: The National League of Cities said today that, despite the economic recovery, more than half of 388 cities responding to a new survey cited unemployment as a ''severe'' or ''substantial'' problem.
