title: B-1 TEST FLIGHT CRASHES IN DESERT, KILLING CREWMAN
description: A prototype of the B-1 bomber crashed into the Mojave Desert on a test flight today, killing one crewman and injuring the two others.

title: DENNY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
APARTMENT LOBBIES: A NEW INTEREST IN ELEGANCE
description: THERE have always been impressive residential lobbies in New York City - some that appear changeless. With marble floors, scattered Oriental carpets and occasional furniture, many look like the comfortable old-guard living rooms or hotel lobbies after which they were originally modeled.

title: Mercury Is Near 100 From Illinois to Texas United Press International
description: Schools closed early yesterday, emergency shelters were opened and a Kansas utility gave fans to poor people sweating out a late August heat wave that pushed hot desert air into the Plains and sent the mercury toward 100 degrees from Illinois to Texas.

title: TURNOUT LOW IN VOTING BY INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: A political party that seeks change within the current system emerged as the strongest Indian party today after elections among South Africa's Indian minority for a new, three-chamber Parliament.

title: Bluefish Catches Outstanding
description: 1 Margate, N.J.: Phenomenal catches of

title: 3,500 Held in India in Bid To End Demonstrations
description: The authorities arrested at least 3,500 people in northern and eastern India today in an effort to end protests over the ouster of an opposition leader and to block a planned Sikh convention.

title: OFFSHORE LOGISTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a nonrecurring writedown of $7,555,000. c-Net income.

title: AIDS Victims at Greater Risk From Cancer, Doctors Report
description: Homosexuals with acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, are also susceptible to a rare form of fast- growing cancer that attacks the bone marrow, brain and abdomen, doctors reported today.

title: Bush Joins Dedication Of Jewish Veterans
description: Vice President Bush, in a week of campaign appearances stressing his military record, participated in a dedication ceremony today at the Jewish War Veterans' new building here and pledged vigorous support for Israel.

title: Life of Stress And Isolation Tied to Risk
description: People who lead isolated lives filled with stress are four times as likely as more carefree and sociable people to die in the first years after a heart attack, a study shows.

title: INDEX OF ECONOMIC TRENDS FELL AGAIN IN JULY
description: The Government index that is intended to predict changes in economic direction fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the first time this index had declined two consecutive months since the beginning of 1982, the department said.

title: ON WISHFUL THINKING
description: WASHINGTON Senator Claghorn, that parody of

title: UNION PICKS TWO AUTO MAKERS AS STRIKE TARGETS
description: The United Automobile Workers today chose both Ford and General Motors as strike targets in the current negotiations for a new labor contract.

title: Hawkins Dance's Season
description: ''Avanti,'' a new work by Erick Hawkins, will open the fall season of the Hawkins Dance Company Oct. 10 in the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue. A second premiere by Mr. Hawkins - ''The Joshua Tree, or Three Outlaws'' - will be performed Oct. 14. The season, which runs through Oct. 21, also features performances of ''Angels of the Inmost Heaven,'' ''God's Angry Man - the Passion Play of John Brown'' and ''Trickster Coyote.''

title: FRANCO WAS THE REBEL
description: To the Editor:

title: HERS
description: ''MORNING, T.J.,'' I said to the man who runs the furniture store in town. ''I need a cheap radio that chickens can't knock over.'' He looked thoughtful. ''It's for the barn,'' I added. ''They broke the last one I had out there.'' T.J. is a pillar of this Ozark community and I wouldn't want him to suspect that I was the sort who lets chickens come into my cabin.

title: Yankee Oil Offer
description: Yankee Oil and Gas Inc. said a group of company executives had withdrawn its proposal to buy all of Yankee's common shares outstanding. The company said the group - Paul Montle, president and chief executive; Graham Jones, chairman, and Lance Schneier, senior vice president - had withdrawn the July 20 offer because of unanticipated delays in receiving necessary approvals. Yankee, which has nearly 5 million shares outstanding, closed at $9.25, unchanged, today on the American Stock Exchange.

title: HEARING-AID SYSTEM PLEASING THEATERGOERS
description: For years, the hard of hearing could sometimes be heard speaking out loud in theaters, asking their companions to repeat what was said on stage. Through the Infrared Listening System, installed over the last five years in 24 theaters and concert halls in New York City, those with hearing disabilities can tune in to every word as it is spoken.

title: Reagan Again Denies Deal on Labor Unit Chief
description: President Reagan would welcome endorsement by the teamsters' union but has made no deal to remove the chairman of the National Labor Relations Board Chairman, Donald L. Dotson, in exchange for the support, a spokesman repeated today.

title: Opelika Names Chief
description: The Opelika Manufacturing Corporation said yesterday that it had named Lee N. Mortenson president and chief executive officer. Mr. Mortenson, who is 48 years old, succeeds Donald P. Cohen, 58. Mr. Cohen has held the top posts at Opelika, a textile and service apparel manufacturer, for the past 25 years. The company said that Mr. Cohen would continue as chairman.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Price Company, a wholesale cash-and-carry membership-only business selling a variety of merchandise, filed a public offering of $75 million principal amount of 8 percent convertible subordinated debentures, due Aug. 31, 2009, through Shearson Lehman/American Express Inc.

title: The Non-White House
description: For two weeks now, the building

title: PROFESSIONAL INVESTORS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Are These Jobs Worth $146,000 Each? ''We are committed,'' says the Republican platform, ''to a free and open international trading system.'' So much for the good intentions. Down in the bureaucratic trenches where policy is actually made, free trade has few potent defenders. And there is good reason to fear that the Reagan Administration is drifting toward restrictions on steel imports that would cost consumers billions.
description: Big Steel's big problems haven't changed much in the last 10 years. Factories are still old and aging, labor costs remain very high, foreign competition intensifies, demand stands still and so does management. What has changed is the industry's perception of what can be done to solve these difficulties.

title: QUEENS MAN GUILTY OF FATALLY SHOOTING 2 CORNELL FRESHMEN
description: A Queens man accused of killing two women who were freshmen at Cornell University last December pleaded guilty today to one count of first-degree manslaughter and one count of second- degree murder.

title: PERES AND SHAMIR STEP UP TALKS
description: Shimon Peres and Yitzhak Shamir, contenders to head the next Israeli government, agreed today to step up their negotiations to form a national unity administration centered on their parties.

title: Seoul Students Protest Chun's Visit to Japan
description: The Japanese Embassy's information center was stoned today as thousands of students demonstrated in streets and campuses demanding that President Chun Doo Hwan cancel his visit to Japan next week.

title: French Prices Rise
description: French retail prices rose seven-tenths of 1 percent last month from June and 7.5 percent from July 1983, the National Statistics Institute said today.

title: New Officer at Sieber
description: Robert McCaffrey, 39, executive vice president, creative director with Sudler & Hennessey in New York, is joining the Chicago-based pharmaceutical agency of Sieber & McIntyre, where he will hold the same title.

title: Looting of 2 Train Cars Is Reported in Miami
description: A group of people from the low-income Liberty City area looted two cars of a train that struck and seriously injured a teen- ager and threw stones at the police when they responded to the accident, the police said today.

title: Hair Cuttery Account
description: The Baltimore office of W. B. Doner & Company was named advertising agency for the 150 units of Hair Cuttery salons, a subsidiary of Creative Hairdressers in Arlington, Va. The account is worth more than $1 million, the agency said. Irv Kline & Associates in Alexandria, Va., was the previous agency.

title: ENGINEERING MEASUREMENTS COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: STUDY QUESTIONS 3 MILE ISLAND RADIATION FINDINGS
description: A review of estimates of possible radiation exposure from the 1979 accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant in Pennsylvania has found contradictions and defective methods in the earlier studies.

title: R.G. Barry Plants
description: The R. G. Barry Corporation said it would sell or close two slipper-manufacturing plants in a move to cut costs.

title: HORIZON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After tax credits of $1,459,000 for the quarter and $1,057,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $101,000 from discontinued operations.

title: 2 STATES RESOLVE HUGHES'S TAX BILL
description: Texas and California today signed inheritance tax agreements that bring closer the day when Howard R. Hughes's assets will be distributed to his heirs.

title: E.P.A. Moves to Trim Animal Deaths in Tests
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today announced new guidelines to encourage a reduction in the number of laboratory animals killed in testing new chemicals for acute toxicity.

title: Music TV Unit Set By Turner
description: The Turner Broadcasting System announced yesterday that it would start a 24-hour video music channel on Oct. 26 with a broad range of music and five million initial subscribers around the nation.

title: BIG ST. LOUIS CROWD CHEERS FERRARO ATTACK ON REAGAN
description: Attracting the most boisterous crowd of her campaign so far, Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro today concentrated on attacking President Reagan for the second day in a row.

title: DYNEX PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HAUSERMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss after recognition of tax benefits of $3,979,000, or $1.65 a share.

title: FUTURES/OPTIONS ; Pork Contracts Climb While Soybeans Ease
description: Live hog and pork belly futures ran higher today as traders anticipated fewer slaughterings because of hot weather and the upcoming Labor Day holiday.

title: SOVIET IS PRESSING CASE ON K.A.I. 007
description: The approach of the first anniversary of the Soviet downing of a South Korean jetliner has prompted a barrage of articles in the Soviet press arguing and rearguing Moscow's fundamental defense, that the jumbo jet was on a spying mission for the United States.

title: No Headline
description: FRIDAY, AUGUST 31, 1984

title: New President Named At Beech Aircraft
description: James F. Walsh has been named president and chief executive officer at the Beech Aircraft Corporation, the company announced yesterday. The appointment is effective immediately.

title: LONG ISLAND
description: Between summer's final barbecue and the last swim at the beach, Long Islanders and visitors have been invited to the Nassau County Celebration of the Arts this Labor Day weekend. The four-day event begins today and runs through Monday. It includes works by more than 100 artists - exhibited in a parklike setting - poetry readings, musical performances, dancing and mimes. The site is the 145-acre Nassau County Center for the Fine Arts, the grounds of the former Gold Coast estate of Charles Frick, in Roslyn Harbor. Organizers suggest bringing a lunch, blankets and chairs, for a day of wandering through the gardens, woodlands and nature trails, or through the Frick mansion, now the Nassau County Museum of Fine Arts. Snacks will be available. Gates open 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Free. Also free parking on the grounds or across Northern Boulevard at the Pall Corporation. The museum is north of Exit 39 of the Long Island Expressway; from there, Glen Cove Road north 2 1/2 miles to Route 25A, or Northern Boulevard, turning west and proceeding half a mile to the center. Information: (516) 484-9333 or (516) 484-9337.

title: INDIAN LEADER'S FAST REVIVES QUESTIONS ON CONVICTION IN 2 MURDERS
description: A fast begun by a leader of the American Indian Movement last April has revived interest in a case that has long been championed by human rights activists.

title: Assets of Money Funds Rise
description: Assets of the nation's 340 money market mutual funds continued to rise during the week ended Wednesday, climbing $361 million, to $180.53 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Export-Aid Loans Set
description: The Export-Import Bank and the Small Business Administration announced today a program of loans to increase exports by small American business.

title: PAUL ZWEIG, POET AND CRITIC PRAISED FOR WHITMAN STUDY
description: Paul Zweig, a poet and critic whose recent study of Walt Whitman was highly acclaimed, died in the American Hospital in Paris on Wednesday. The official cause of death was not disclosed, but Mr. Zweig had suffered from lymphatic cancer for the last six years. He was 49 years old.

title: School Budget Reverses Cuts
description: The Los Angeles School Board today adopted a record $2.4 billion budget for 1984-85 including nearly $96 million in reserves, most of it for salary increases.

title: DOWNING OF JET A YEAR AGO SAID TO LEAD TO U.S. GAINS
description: In reviewing the year since a Soviet fighter shot down a South Korean jetliner, Reagan Administration officials assert that worldwide criticism of the Soviet handling of the crisis has strengthened the United States in its relations with Moscow.

title: TV WEEKEND;
description: Although far from the peak of her vocal powers, Peggy Lee at 62 is still an intensely absorbing pop-jazz vocalist. Health problems, including a serious stroke, have given Miss Lee's dreamy passivity an occasionally disconnected air, but the singer hasn't lost her ability to invest the subtlest hesitations of phrase and bending of notes with intimations of mischief and eroticism.

title: MONTANA KEEPS AN EYE ON WIND AS BLAZES RAGE
description: Like so many people in fire-ravaged Montana, Helena residents are focusing their attention on the wind.

title: Georgetown Loses Star
description: Michael Graham , the power forward who was one of the stars of Georgetown's drive to the national collegiate basketball championship last season, will not play this season because of academic reasons, the school said.

title: SUBARU OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DOW DECLINES 3.64 AMID RATE CONCERN
description: Profit taking and concern over interest rates weakened stock prices slightly yesterday in quiet pre-Labor Day trading.

title: Tekulve Is Available
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates are reportedly trying to trade the 37-year-old relief pitcher Kent Tekulve , who has a 2-9 record, only 10 saves and a 3-year, $4 million contract that he signed last winter. ''If some scout will look through the numbers, he'll see I'm throwing as well as I ever have,'' Tekulve said, fueling speculation that he might be attractive to some team in the middle of a pennant race.

title: Ex-Midland Bank Head Is Charged by S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that the former chairman and chief executive of the defunct Midland National Bank made false and misleading statements to the commission and the bank's shareholders about its financial condition. The bank's failure was one of the largest in the nation's history.

title: WELDED TUBE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: KARCHER, CARL, ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 10
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of restaurants and from investment and other extraordinary income of $2,693,000 for the quarter and $5,130,000 for the 6 months.

title: SANDINISTA DELEGATION SAID TO PLAN VISIT TO VATICAN
description: Roman Catholic Church officials here said today that a delegation of Nicaraguan officials hoped to visit the Vatican next month, but that Pope John Paul II probably would not receive them.

title: PUBLISHING: BOOK FAIR ADJUSTS FOR YOM KIPPUR
description: Many American publishers, editors and agents were outraged toward the end of the Frankfurt Book Fair last October, when they learned that the 1984 fair coincided with Yom Kippur, the highest of Jewish holy days. The book fair, the world's largest, will take place Oct. 3-8. Yom Kippur this year is Oct. 6.

title: LEBANESE CHRISTIANS BURY CHIEF IN MOUNTAIN TOWN
description: Grim- faced in their black robes, the patriarchs, bishops, priests and monks of the Eastern churches today ringed a platform in front of the coffin of Pierre Gemayel, the founder of Lebanon's Phalangist Party.

title: Household to Sue Dissident Group
description: Household International Inc. said that it was filling suit in Federal District Court in Delaware against an investment group lead by a dissident board member.

title: Mack Slowdown
description: Mack Trucks Inc. said it would cut daily truck production by 13 percent in mid-November, in anticipation of a seasonal winter sales slowdown.

title: HOUSE REPORT ON E.P.A. CHARGES WHITE HOUSE STILL WITHHOLDS DATA
description: A House subcommittee charged today that the White House was continuing to withhold documents related to its involvement in the toxic waste programs administered by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Another Face For Tammany Hall

title: SLIDE GUITAR CONCERT
description: Ce Dell Davis, a blues singer from Arkansas who is known for playing slide guitars with a knife, returns tonight and tomorrow to Tramps (777-5077), 125 East 15th Street. Sets begin at 10 P.M. and midnight; there is a $7 cover and $5 minimum.

title: No Headline
description: Dali Burned at Home

title: ; New facet in gem auctions.
description: This is the time of year when devotees of jewelry auctions, a kind of sale whose nature has changed over the years, feel the same rising blood pressure as baseball addicts gripped by pennant fever. Jewelry sales, which were once dominated by dealers and the syndicates they often formed, are now much more open to individuals - both buyers and sellers - who are not in the business, the private clients referred to as ''privates.''

title: A PUBLIC WEARY OF PUBLIC AGENCIES' WOES
description: To the Editor:

title: FACTORY ORDERS UP SLIGHTLY 1% IN JULY
description: In a further sign that the pace of economic expansion is slowing, orders to United States factories for new manufactured goods rose a modest 1 percent in July, the Government reported today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Paris on Aug. 15 about a dispute over unspent funds held by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization incorrectly described a fee to be paid by the agency to a Washington-based public relations firm. The firm, Wagner & Baroody, is to receive about $15,000 a month.

title: People
description: Alan T. Kalter promoted to executive vice president at W. B. Doner, Detroit.

title: COMMERCIAL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Year to May 31
LETHAL NATIONAL PRODUCT
description: To the Editor:

title: RESPIRATOR REMOVAL IS BACKED
description: A judge who heard pleas from the family of a comatose Long Island woman that she be allowed to die - then visited the woman's hospital bedside - ruled today that her respirator could be disconnected.

title: BROWN-FORMAN DISTILLERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BROADWAY;
description: 1985 target date for a play about the O'Neills.

title: Norwest Charge
description: The Norwest Corporation said its Norwest Mortgage Inc. subsidiary would record an after-tax charge of about $30 million for the third quarter, due primarily to losses and fees in hedging transactions not offset by corresponding increases in the market value of mortgage inventory. It said the charge would be ''significantly reduced'' by after-tax gains from sales of more than $2 billion of mortgage servicing this quarter. After giving effect to third-quarter servicing sales, the company said Norwest Mortgage's servicing portfolio would approximate $12.5 billion.

title: Expos Dismiss Virdon The Montreal Expos dismissed
description: Bill Virdon as manager yesterday and replaced him with Jim Fanning, who managed the Expos for part of the 1981 season and in 1982. Fanning was replaced by Virdon for the 1983 season.

title: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Sales include sales results of Winkelman Stores Inc. of $22,660,000 for the latest quarter and $44,185,000 for the latest 6 months.

title: FREE MUSIC IN PARK
description: Music from Cole Porter to Tchaikovsky will be played by the Seuffert Band at a free concert Sunday at 3 P.M. in the music grove of Forest Park, off Woodhaven Boulevard, in Woodhaven, Queens. If it rains, the site will be the Monsignor Mulz Auditorium, Jamaica Avenue and 88th Street.

title: POREX TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,683,000 for the quarter and $3,462,000 for the year, and an after-tax gain of $6,717,000, or 64 cents a share, for the quarter and year from an initial public offering of common stock for the Medco Containment Services Inc. subsidiary.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAYY;
description: Of Crime And Red Faces

title: TEAMSTERS VOTE TO ENDORSE REAGAN
description: Vice President Bush today reached out for the support of organized labor's rank and file as the International Brotherhood of Teamsters became the first major labor union to endorse President Reagan for re-election.

title: Quake Rocks Alaska Area
description: A moderate earthquake today shook Ketchikan and Petersburg, Alaska, but there were no reports of damage or injuries, the United States Geological Survey reported.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. San Diego Padres, twilight-night doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, 5:35 P.M. The Mets open a critical series against the National League's Western Division leaders, whom they play five times in the next three days. Another dismal weekend like the one against San Francisco could have them sinking fast out of sight in the East, especially with the Cubs playing a woefully slumping Atlanta team. Preventing that scenario will be the task tonight of Sid Fernandez and Bruce Berenyi, Manager Dave Johnson's designated starters. (Television - SportsChannel, 5:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 5:30 P.M.)

title: WHEN THE AUDIENCE ACTS
description: The Democratic and Republican conventions are over at last, but two events still reverberate, somewhere between politics and metaphysics.

title: COAL NEGOTIATIONS ARE BIGGEST TESTS FOR NEW MINE UNION CHIEF
description: In 20 months as president of the United Mine Workers of America, Rich Trumka has raised enormous expectations that he can rebuild his proud but diminished union and perhaps earn a place as a labor leader of national stature.

title: New Jersey
description: The Flemington Fair, begun 128 years ago, is the state's oldest and biggest agricultural fair and offers something for the entire family this Labor Day weekend. There will be car races each day starting at 2 P.M. and a demolition derby Monday, as well as country music each day from 4 to 8 P.M. in the barn on the fairgrounds. There are rides for the youngsters, a children's variety show and a petting zoo, where visitors can feed and pet a number of domestic animals. In front of the grandstand at 2 P.M. each day, there will also be a high-wire act and later in the afternoon a horse expo, featuring barrel races and jumping by standardbred horses. More than 25 Hunterdon County volunteer fire companies will participate in a parade at 7:30 P.M. today to begin the holiday weekend. There also will be a motorcycle thrill show. Admission is $3; $1.50 for those 6 to 13 years old. There is a $1.50 parking fee. The best way to the fairgrounds by car is Route 22 west to Route 202 south and then Route 31 north to Flemington, or Route 80 west to Route 287 south to Route 202. Information: (201) 782-2413.

title: A HOCKEY CUT STRIKES CLOSE TO HOME
description: Brent Sutter first apologized and then, abruptly ending a conversation in midsentence, said that he couldn't talk anymore. ''Later,'' he said. ''I'll just talk later.'' His eyes became glassy and would soon be red.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some editions of Metropolitan Report yesterday on appointments by Governor Cuomo incorrectly described the racial makeup of the Port Authority board. It currently includes one black.

title: THE VOICE OF THE LISTENERS
description: Each month the Voice of America compiles excerpts from letters from listeners and circulates them within the Administration and on Capitol Hill.

title: Advertising; Encore Ads Go a Step Further
description: Last September, when Renault introduced the Encore, a new

title: UTL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CREDIT MARKETS ; Rates Flat; Money Supply Up
description: In a day of listless trading, interest rates were little changed yesterday. Analysts said there were no new economic developments pointing toward higher or lower rates.

title: ROCK: THE MIDNITS
description: There's a lot of wasted potential in Bobby and the Midnites, who played Wednesday at the Beacon Theater. With a moonlighting Grateful Dead guitarist, the drummer Bill Cobham from the now-defunct Mahavishnu Orchestra and the bassist Kenny Gradney, formerly of Little Feat, plus experienced West Coast musicians, the band has everything except good songs and someone to sing them.

title: NCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
JERSEY PROJECT SELLS OUT IN A WEEKEND
description: Selling homes from a trailer, with no models to show would-be buyers and only empty ground for a view, is not the easiest of propositions. But in this area of central New Jersey, which has experienced a rapid influx of companies, the demand for new housing is strong enough to make such weak selling tools all that are needed.

title: WARRINGTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: There were no share earnings in the latest quarter because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: DOCKERS' VOTES REFLECT BRITISH UNIONS' CONFUSION
description: Tilbury, London's main port, became a symbol of the confusion afflicting Britain's labor movement today when dockworkers there held contradictory votes on whether to continue to support a nationwide strike called by their leaders.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: FRIDAY, AUGUST 31, 1984 International An accord for an Israeli Government has been reached by Shimon Peres and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, according to the Israeli radio. Broadcasts said the agreement called for Mr. Peres, leader of the Labor Party, and Mr. Shamir, head of the Likud bloc, to alternate as Prime Minister in a national unity government. (Page A1, Columns 1-2.) Moscow's handling of the crisis generated a year ago when a Soviet fighter shot down a South Korean airliner with 269 people aboard prompted worldwide criticism and strengthened Washington in its relations with the Kremlin, according to Administration officials. (A3:5-6.) National

title: Poll Reports Satisfaction On Ferraro Finances
description: Nearly two-thirds of those interviewed in a national poll said that Geraldine A. Ferraro had answered doubts about her and her husband's finances, the latest Harris Survey reported today.

title: ARMCO: A STRATEGY BACKFIRES
description: For the nation's troubled steelmakers, an increasingly popular strategy for survival has been diversification. Armco Inc., the fifth-largest steelmaker, blazed that trail decades ago. But if the strategy has had mixed results for some in the industry, it has been particularly unkind to its pioneer: Although Armco's steel operations currently show a profit, some of its other businesses are dragging down overall results.

title: 'MOTIVATIONAL' EXERCISE FATAL
description: A 20-year-old sophomore in Texas A&M University's Corps of Cadets died today, hours after he was awakened by fellow cadets and forced to run and perform calisthenics until he dropped, officials said.

title: PURCHASERS SEE SLOWER GROWTH RATE
description: The economy's rate of growth continued to slow in August, the fourth consecutive month that its momentum has eased, the National Association of Purchasing Management has concluded.

title: ENDURING THE BOUNCES
description: The fans may have come to Court

title: DANCE: '16 FALLS,' BY CYDNEY WILKES
description: Cydney Wilkes is a bold performer with a presence that suggests interior stillness and private activity. And she laid it all on the line in her new ''16 Falls in Color,'' presented on Wednesday at the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater to a packed house that included, interestingly, several of the most accomplished of the new modern-dance choreographers on the scene. But then Miss Wilkes herself clearly promises much.

title: 4 QUEENS DEMOCRATS SEEKING FERRARO'S SEAT IN HOUSE
description: While Geraldine A. Ferraro campaigns across the country for the Vice Presidency, back home in Queens, four Democrats are vying for her seat in the House of Representatives.

title: FREE BROOKLYN MAP
description: Visitors to Brooklyn can have the borough in the palm of their hands with a free map, available through the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, 125 Park Avenue, at 42d Street. The map, titled Brooklyn on Tour, identifies ethnic neighborhoods and points of interest and provides historical and sociological data. It can also be ordered by mail for $1 from the Fund for the Borough of Brooklyn, 16 Court Street, Eighth Floor, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11201.

title: Cuomo Advises Caution On Debating Religion
description: Governor Cuomo, who has debated the Archbishop of New York on the role of the Catholic Church in politics, said yesterday that he was not sure it was a good idea for Walter F. Mondale to start a similiar debate with President Reagan.

title: AT THE MOVIES ; ; 'Cal' director tried to focus on the tragic.
description: ''At a certain remove from Northern Ireland,'' Pat O'Connor, the Irish-born director of ''Cal,'' said the other day, ''one has fairly glib assumptions as to who's in the right and who's in the wrong, whereas the problem is, in fact, extremely complex. The film, if it does nothing else, will hopefully allow people to see a scenario that is a little bit wider than the stereotypes that are projected either from the Catholic or Protestant point of view.''

title: Diner's Journal
description: Arranging dinner around a Broadway show can present a dilemma, especially for working couples: to have a leisurely meal before the show, one must be in a restaurant by 6 P.M., which for some is too early to dine; postponing dinner until after the show, however, means surviving until 10:30 or 11 P.M., and then foraging for a place that is still serving meals. One solution is to have substantial appetizers with a drink before the show to hold you over until a late supper. A good place for pre-theater nibbling is Nirvana Club One, the new Indian restaurant on the 16th floor of 1 Times Square.

title: ROCK: MARTY BALIN SINGS
description: Like many rock band members who launch solo careers, Marty Balin, a vocal mainstay of the Jefferson Airplane and its offshoot, the Jefferson Starship, hasn't had the kind of commercial success on his own that he enjoyed with either group. At the Lone Star Cafe on Wednesday, where the singer and a rock band ended a three- night engagement, some of the reasons became clear.

title: Vice-Presidential Statuary
description: Virtually all Capitol tourists are familiar with Statuary Hall, the former House chamber now populated with marble figures representing two sons or daughters of each state. But few visitors are aware of the nearby sculpture gallery of Vice Presidents, busts of all the men who served, pursuant to constitutional mandate, as president of the Senate.

title: 3-STATE LABOR DAY WINDUP TO SUMMER
description: Calypso bands will clash in Brooklyn this weekend, carpenters will put up a house in the middle of 42d Street, poets will be reading their works at Madison Square Garden, and plumbers will be marching up Fifth Avenue with the tools of their trade.

title: General Mills Plan
description: General Mills Inc. said it would ask shareholders at the annual meeting on Sept. 24 to approve measures that would assure equal treatment of stockholders in case of a two-tier acquisition proposal. It said a proposed amendment requires that in case of a two-step takeover transaction a stockholder owning 10 percent or more of the company's voting stock be paid the same amount as the stockholder acquiring its largest block of shares. Otherwise, the company said any such transaction must be approved by 51 percent or more of the voting stock outstanding, excluding shares held by the stockholder who is a party to the transaction.

title: GERULAITIS EASILY GAINS AT OPEN
description: Last year, Vitas Gerulaitis was out of shape. He was also out of money, which, he said, became the primary reason that he continued to play competitive tennis, despite any real success in major tournaments. Several embarrassing losses forced him out of the top 10 ranking for the first time since 1977.

title: B-1 CRASHED IN TEST OF SLOW FLIGHT, AIR FORCE SAYS
description: The B-1 bomber prototype that crashed Wednesday in the Mojave desert was on a mission to test flight control at low speeds, an Air Force spokesman at the Pentagon said today.

title: LIKE IT OR NOT, CITY GETS 2D AREA CODE TODAY
description: What more than 80 years of healthy suspicion and rivalry have joined together New York Telephone is about to put asunder. Tonight at midnight, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island will get a new area code: 718.

title: NOEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: THE REPUBLICAN NATIONAL CONVENTION OF '1984'
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today
description: Aug. 31, 1984 SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on complaint by Lebanon at 11 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLYAd hoc committee on the Indian Ocean - 3 P.M.

title: PADRES TO TEST METS' PITCHING
description: The Chicago Cubs loom on the Mets' horizon, but a large, ominous cloud blocks the Mets' view of that team, which leads the National League's Eastern Division. The cloud is the San Diego Padres, the best club in the West, and the Mets must play them five times within 48 hours at Shea Stadium.

title: REEVES COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE SIGNALS ARE HEARD
description: Presi An international group of finance and business experts has been mulling over the U.S. and world economy here where the air is pure and thin, far from the dense smog of politics in the lowlands.

title: THE YEARLONG SHADOW OF K.A.L. FLIGHT 7
description: On Saturday, it will be one year since the brutal destruction of Korean Air Lines Flight 7. The Soviet Union still has not offered restitution for downing the airliner. In fact, it never has admitted its responsibility for the death of 269 innocent people. And Soviet leaders have publicly implied they are prepared to do the same thing again.

title: ACAPULCO Y LOS ARCOS RESTAURANTES reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Includes tax credits of $166,000 for the quarter and $278,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss.

title: AFTICAN GENESIS OF 'WOZA ALBERT!'
description: Hoe did ''Woza Albert!'' the acclaimed two-man South African play that is going to Harlem this weekend, come into being?

title: SEVEN OAKS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
REAGAN BRINGS UP TAX ISSUE IN TALK TO SPACE SCIENTISTS
description: President Reagan campaigned gently in the wake of the space shuttle launching today, telling a group of space scientists that he supported ''high tech, not high taxes.''

title: JUDGE REMOVES ESTATE'S CONTROL FROM ZACCARO
description: John A. Zaccaro was removed yesterday as overseer of the financial affairs of an elderly woman from whose assets he had borrowed $175,000.

title: BELL PETROLEUM SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Westchester
description: There is plenty to do in Westchester this weekend, and a lot of it is outdoors and in places where you can bring a picnic basket.

title: SIX ASTRONAUTS SHARE LIFELONG LOVE OF FLIGHT AND A DREAM TO SEE THE STARS
description: Henry W. Hartsfield Jr.

title: ITT TO SELL BAKING UNIT TO RALSTON
description: The ITT Corporation announced yesterday that it had signed a preliminary agreement to sell its ITT Continental Baking Company to the Ralston Purina Company for $475 million in cash.

title:
3-STATE LABOR DAY WEEKEND WINDUP TO SUMMER;
 Hudson Valley
description: If you want to fly a kite, the place to go this Labor Day weekend is Washington's Headquarters in Newburgh, where an annual kite day gets off the ground tomorrow from 2 to 4 P.M. Free kites will be provided for the first 70 visitors younger than 15. In addition, homemade kites are welcome for testing, and members of the staff will operate a ''kite hospital'' for those with ailing kites. Free. The best way there by car from New York City is the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway north to Exit 17 in Newburgh and Route 17K east into the city. Information: (914) 562-1195.

title: FRESHMAN RULE CALLED BIASED
description: The head of a special committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association recommended today that the association change the rule setting strict academic qualifications for freshmen in college sports because a new study shows the rule ''discriminates'' against blacks.

title: SMUIN QUITS AS HEAD OF COAST BALLET
description: Michael Smuin has resigned as director of the San Francisco Ballet. A company spokesman said that no reason for the resignation had been announced.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AM International Inc., Chicago, a diversified company, has elected to its board Charles S. Arledge, senior vice president, corporate development and planning for the Signal Companies; Norman E. Auerbach, retired chairman of Coopers & Lybrand; Stephen F. Hinchliffe Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of the Leisure Group, and Carl Kaysen, director of the Program in Science, Technology and Society, Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: U.S. Investigates Role Of Companies in Libya
description: The State Department said today that it was looking into participation by American companies in a water project in Libya, but it said there was no indication so far that any law had been broken.

title: Kaiser Aluminum May Sell a Unit
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it was discussing the potential sale of most of its refractories business, which manufactures industrial insulation materials used to line large furnaces that make steel and glass.

title: TOP EXECUTIVE RETIRING AT AETNA
description: In an unexpected move, Filer, chairman and chief executive officer of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, the nation's largest stock- owned insurance company, announced that he would be taking early retirement. Replacing him will be James T. Lynn, a director of Aetna and former head of the Federal Office of Management and Budget.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CITY'S SCHOOL SYSTEM WILL GET A REPORT CARD LIKE STUDENTS'
description: New York City's school system will use one of its tools for measuring pupil performance - report cards - to grade itself, the Schools Chancellor said yesterday.

title: FERRARO ASSAILS PRESIDENT'S VIEW OF NUCLEAR WAR
description: Sharpening her attack of the Reagan Administration on the peace issue, Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro charged today that the Reagan Administration had left the impression that nuclear war would be an acceptable event.

title: Speechless
description: Several weeks ago, the Buffalo Sabres of the National Hockey League conducted an audition to replenish their list of national anthem singers.

title: OCELOT INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 STRATEGIES, BOTH RISKY
description: THE right economic strategy for the next four

title: Quick Aid Doubted for Thrift Unit ; Limit Remains On Insurance
description: Federal banking regulators said today that they had no plans for an announcement of Government support for the American Savings and Loan Association, the $32 billion California institution that has suffered an outflow of deposits. American Savings and Loan, a unit of the Financial Corporation of America, is the country's biggest thrift institution.

title: Coastal to Pay Fine To Settle Charges
description: The Coastal Corporation has agreed to pay a $230,000 civil penalty to settle charges that it violated the law in acquiring stock in the Houston Natural Gas Corporation earlier this year, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

title: Human Billboard
description: The way corporate logos are sprouting all over the world's tennis players, from headbands to wristbands, shirts to shorts, racquets to shoes, was enough to start the good folks at the Men's International Professional Tennis Council worrying - about socks.

title: Accounts
description: Roma Industries, St. Petersburg, Fla., to Sacks & Rosen for its leather watch straps.

title: CANINES IN TRANSIT
description: Just when the dog days of summer should by all rights be over and done with, a look around the city's streets shows that man's best friend travels well.

title: Store Roof Collapses, Hurting 15 in Oklahoma
description: Shoppers had only a 30-second warning today before a rain-soaked roof collapsed at a discount department store, injuring at least 15 people, the authorities said.

title: CUOMO REFUSES TO ASSURE HOSPITALS OF REVENUE RISE TO PAY FOR STRIKE PACT
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that he would not give assurances to New York City hospitals that he would approve an increase in revenue to pay for the strike settlement with the hospital workers union.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; 3 Utilities' Ratings Up
description: Five years after the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant accident in Pennsylvania, the utilities that owned the two nuclear units are recovering from the financial burden. While the cleanup of Unit No. 2 continues, the utilities are seeking to restart Unit No. 1, which was undamaged in the accident.

title: NEW TENOR, NEW TONE AT THE VOICE OF AMERICA
description: In many corners of the world, the Voice of America's shortwave radio broadcasts come through with all the authority of a whisper at a crowded cocktail party.

title: U.S. Steel Idles 300 More in Gary
description: Three hundred additional workers have been laid off at the United States Steel Corporation's Gary Works, bringing to almost 6,000 the number of steelworkers without jobs there in recent months, the steelmaker said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're happy the orbiter and its crew finally left town. The launch team is ecstatic.

title: No Headline
description: 3 Guilty of Conspiracy In Florida Murder Trial

title: Nets Win Abroad
description: The Nets beat Tel Aviv Hapoel, 101-82, in an exhibition here today before a crowd of 7,500. Albert King, with 27 points, led the Nets.

title: Debt Ratings
description: Austin, Tex., combined utility system revenue bonds were lowered to A, from A-1, by Moody's. The city plans to sell $160 million of bonds next month.

title: PATRIOTISM DESCENDING INTO CHAUVINISM
description: On returning to the United States after a year's absence, I am troubled by the unabashed, unreflective, zesty - yet somehow childish and insecure - style of patriotism that seems to abound these days.

title: Baby Elephant Dies Of Mysterious Illness
description: A baby elephant, given to President Reagan by the president of Sri Lanka, died today of a ''mysterious'' diet-related illness at the National Zoo.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE MIRACLE. By Irving Wallace. 436

title: No Headline
description: Alpert Concerts Put OffThe concerts by Herb Alpert and the Tijuana Brass, originally announced for Carnegie Hall Sept. 6-8, have been postponed indefinitely.

title: THE NEW YORK STATE FAIR: A MOSAIC OF COLORFUL SCENES
description: Eight hundred pounds of black-and-white Holstein calf named Baby suddenly balked and 75 pounds of Jarad Kramer, his hand clutching the calf's halter, tumbled backward in a heap on the sawdust-covered floor.

title: UNIVERSAL COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Long-Term Goals For a Swimmer
description: Stacy Chanin, who spent 33 hours 29 minutes in the East River to become the first person to swim around Manhattan three times, has set her immediate goals. They include her graduation from the University of Maryland where she returns next week to complete her senior year, a possible try at Diana Nyad's long-distance record of 89 miles and gaining support for the addition of marathon swimming in the 1988 Olympics.

title: COMEDY ABOUT JUDGES AT CENTRE STREET COURT
description: The show ''100 Centre Street'' is an ''ABC Comedy Special,'' which means it is also a failed pilot film, a potential series come to nought. It is interesting in the way a failed pilot is always interesting; it shows us what a network thought might be funny. In this case, there is one small additional attraction: the pilot shows us what someone thought of New York. It will be seen on Channel 7 at 10:30 tonight.

title: Reagan Proposes 3.5% Raise For Federal Employees in '85
description: President Reagan, rejecting a recommendation to raise Federal employees' pay 18.3 percent, formally asked Congress today to approve a 3.5 percent pay increase for 1.4 million Federal civilian white-collar workers.

title: HADCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
TEXFI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: b-Net income

title: ENDEVCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 Iranians Fly to Iraq In an F-4 Fighter Jet
description: Two Iranians flew their F-4 fighter jet to an Iraqi airport today and were granted political asylum, a military spokesman said. It was the first Iranian military plane known to have landed here in four years of war between the two countries.

title: Seabrook Cost Estimate Rises The new management in
description: charge of the Seabrook nuclear

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Edwards Air Force Base in California yesterday on the crash of a B-1 bomber prototype gave its top speed incorrectly. It is 1,300 miles an hour.

title: Connecticut
description: Lest anyone's favorite playground be left out, Connecticut's Labor Day weekend activities are set in the air, on the land and on the sea.

title: Lucky Stores Inc. Selling Division
description: Lucky Stores Inc. said it had signed a definitive agreement to sell its Atherton Industries division to The Limited Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: BASS TIME AT UPSTATE ISLANDS
description: Smallmouth-bass fishing in the

title: THE PUB-CINEMA ARRIVES IN CONNECTICUT
description: When Lyn Short and her date, Larry Batter, decided to go to the movies to see ''Bachelor Party'' one recent Tuesday night they did not need to worry about where they would eat before the show, or even where they might go for a drink later on.

title: Copying Ferraro
description: As was presumably inevitable, a television commercial has appeared starring a woman who is nearly a dead ringer for Geraldine A. Ferraro, hair style and color and dress design copied with uncanny accuracy. The Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, who just celebrated her 49th birthday, might not be flattered by the sponsoring product: a denture adhesive.

title: Transplant Patient, 20, Dies
description: A 20- year-old Vermont man whose new heart had to be transplanted backward three weeks ago because of a birth defect died today of an overwhelming infection believed caused by drugs to prevent rejection of the tissue. Officials at Brigham and Women's Hospital said Mike Barrett of Milton, Vt., died 23 days after becoming Boston's fourth heart transplant recipient. Doctors replaced Mr. Barrett's heart backward because of a birth defect that left his own heart twisted.

title: G.O.P. Efforts Rebuffed By Justice O'Connor
description: When Geraldine A. Ferraro was selected as Walter F. Mondale's running mate, President Reagan cited Justice Sandra Day O'Connor of the Supreme Court to show that Republicans were advancing women's rights.

title: OLD-FASHIONED BEEF ON SECOND AVENUE
description: Despite statistics to the contrary, plenty of Americans are still looking for a good piece of beef. The old-fashioned kind: juicy, tender and prime. The sleek, sophisticated restaurant on the corner of Second Avenue and 43d Street, with narrow black blinds, brass-trimmed glass entryway and a discreetly lighted neon sign that says Jake's, is serving some of the best in town. Jake's took over the premises from the defunct Lobel's Steak House last April, and though it suffers from some of the same problems - disorganized staff and mediocre side dishes - if it's a big hunk of soul-satisfying meat that you are after, you will find it here.

title: U.S. EDUCATION FUNDS THAT ARE NO SUBSTITUTE
description: To the Editor:

title: VIE DE FRANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Soviet Men Win
description: The Soviet men's basketball team trounced Czechoslovakia today, 105- 70, to win the title at the Friendship '84 Games, and Coach Aleksandr Gomelsky said his team could defeat the United States.

title: DRAWINGS: EUROPEAN MASTERS AT MORGAN LIBRARY
description: Not to have been to the Watteau exhibition at the National Gallery of Art in Washington is a great deprivation. It can be seen through Sept. 23, but New Yorkers who have to stay home and mind the store can recoup their losses in part by seeing ''Master European Drawings from the National Gallery of Ireland,'' the show with which the Pierpont Morgan Library opens its fall season tomorrow.

title: Thyssen Penalty In Trade Case
description: A West German steel company agreed to pay the United States Government $3.25 million in civil penalties to settle a fraud case involving steel imports.

title: VOLUNTEERS FLOOD APHRODISIAC STUDY
description: Scientists at Stanford University say they have been inundated by men volunteering to test a purported aphrodisiac that has been found extremely effective in laboratory animals.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday MUCH ADO' ON 54TH ST.

title: FLORIDA TO 'CLEAN UP' FOOTBALL
description: The new president of the University of Florida said yesterday that the institution has been embarrassed by the problems that resulted in the football coach Charley Pell's submitting his resignation, effective at the end of this season.

title: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC MAKES AUSTERITY MOVES
description: President Salvador Jorge Blanco announced tonight that the price of gasoline would increase by 20 cents a gallon, less than had been predicted by leftists and labor leaders who have threatened a general strike.

title: DELAY BY U.S. SEEN IN LEASING OF COAL
description: The Interior Department will prepare a new statement on the impact that leasing federally owned coal reserves would have on the environment, and this may delay the resumption of leasing until July, the department said today.

title: End the Commodity Shuffle
description: Few sophisticated investors in gold or silver have ever heard of a ''leveraged contract,'' and for good reason. It's a variation on the more familiar commodity futures contract, apparently created for no other purpose than to avoid the rules protecting investors. Congress has tolerated this dubious activity despite a mass of complaints. It should atone by letting the Commodity Futures Trading Commission put an end to it.

title: SCREEN: 'FLASHPOINT,' WITH KRIS KRISTOFFERSON
description: Bob Logan (Kris Kristofferson) and Ernie Wiatt (Treat Williams) are border-patrol officers in a remote part of southern Texas, which means that it is their job to find things in the desert. During the course of ''Flashpoint,'' which opens today at the National and other theaters, they come across a drug-smuggling operation, a stalled car with two attractive women inside, and a buried jeep containing very mysterious and controversial cargo. It is this last discovery that turns ''Flashpoint'' from a good-humored buddy movie into a conspiracy story - a chilly, paranoid fantasy of a sort no longer fashionable on the screen.

title: Rejected Rule Lives On
description: The Reagan Administration's requirement that birth control

title: U.S. Identifies 2,000 Receiving Pornography
description: More than 2,000 people who regularly receive shipments of child pornography from abroad have been identified by Customs Service officials and many have been arrested as part of a nationwide move against its importation, a department official said today.

title: Boise Cascade Earnings Charge
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation said it expects 1984 earnings to include a charge of 40 cents a share resulting from further consolidation of its West Coast wood-production operations. No details were made available on the planned consolidation program.

title: U.S.-Latin Debt Talks
description: Latin American and United States economic experts tentatively agreed to seek relaxed lending policies by United States-financed development agencies during a two-day international conference on debt and trade that opened today.

title: Bell Helicopter Layoffs
description: Bell Helicopter Textron has laid off 113 workers at its eight plants in Tarrant County. Martin Reisch, a spokesman, said Wednesday that 89 production workers and 24 clerical workers would be let go on Friday.

title: THE REPUBLICAN NATIONAL CONVENTION OF '1984'
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH PURSES FAIL TO ATTRACT QUALITY
description: The big races and big money are in place for a busy Labor Day racing weekend around the country, but the big horses are missing. Rarely has so much money been given away amid such mediocrity.

title: The Disability Disaster
description: In October 1981, a Manhattan social

title: SCHULLER RESIGNS AS TANGLEWOOD CENTER DIRECTOR
description: Gunther Schuller has resigned as artistic director of the Berkshire Music Center, the Boston Symphony's summer school at Tanglewood, the orchestra announced yesterday.

title: Saints Re-sign Rogers
description: George Rogers , the New Orleans Saints' star running back, signed a series of one-year contracts, ending any threat that he might play out his option and shop his talents around. Neither Rogers nor Pat Peppler , the team's personnel director, would say how much the player had signed for, or for how long.

title: New Chief Comments
description: The new chairman and chief executive of the Financial Corporation of America declared that a Federal guarantee was not needed to support American Savings and Loan.

title: REPORT ON ASBESTOS PROMPTS QUESTIONS ON START OF SCHOOL
description: Parents and students throughout the state sought out education officials today trying to find out whether there were asbestos problems in their schools and whether classes would begin as scheduled next Wednesday.

title: NORTHWESTERN STEEL & WIRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a charge of $10,074,000 to recognize costs associated with the establishment of a limited term early retirement incentive program for salaried employees.

title: BUSINESS EXECUTIVES BRIEFED BY MONDALE ON TAX INCREASE
description: After meeting Walter F. Mondale this morning, a group of business executives said the Democratic Presidential nominee had assured them that revenue from a tax increase in a Mondale Administration would be used to reduce the Federal budget deficit and would not be allocated for new social programs.

title: VINTAGE YEAR FOR CHAPMAN
description: The grapes are ripening near

title: WESTCHESTER FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $600,000 from the sale of securities.

title: Deficit Grows At Volkswagen
description: Volkswagenwerk A.G., West Germany's largest auto maker, said today that its loss widened in the first half of 1984 from a year earlier, mainly because of a nationwide strike by metalworkers that paralyzed the auto industry in May and June.

title: LATE CORRECTION
description: In 1948, Henry Laskau, then 31 years old, represented the United States in the 10,000-meter race walk in the Olympic Games in London. After a seventh-place finish in his heat, Laskau was told by the race- walking judge at the finish line that he had been disqualified for overstridding momentarily on the 25th and final lap.

title: NEWEST SHUTTLE FIRED INTO ORBIT AFTER 3 DELAYS
description: After three postponements over two months, the space shuttle Discovery rocketed into orbit today on its maiden flight and successfully deployed the first of three communication satellites in its cargo.

title: THE DOLLAR'S OVERSEAS ROLE
description: THE continued strength of the United States

title: Dining Out Guide: Mixing Music and Dinner
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. ASTOR'S, St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel, 2

title: Homer W. Davis, 88; Ex-Greek College Chief
description: Homer W. Davis, who retired in 1960 after nearly 30 years as president of Athens College, an American-supported institution in the Greek capital, died on Monday in Orleans, Mass. He was 88 years old and had lived in retirement in nearby Brewster.

title: SUCCESSOR NAMED
description: Lewis H. Young, the editor in chief at Business Week magazine since 1969, said yesterday that he intends to resign at the end of October. John G. Wrede, president of the McGraw-Hill Publications Company, said that Stephen B. Shepard, executive editor at the magazine, would succeed Mr. Young.

title: Jersey Simulcast
description: The New Jersey Racing Commission granted permission to Monmouth Park today to simulcast thoroughbred racing from the Meadowlands starting next week.

title: SALSA AT THE GARDEN
description: Major salsa stars will appear in concert tomorrow night at 8 at Madison Square Garden, Seventh Avenue and 33d Street.

title: AN ISSUE OF GODLESSNESS
description: To the Editor:

SHAMIR AND PERES SAID TO AGREE TO ALTERNATE AS ISRAEL'S PREMIER
description: The Israeli radio said early today that Shimon Peres and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir had reached an agreement on the formation of a national unity government in which they would alternate as Prime Minister.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''We didn't have the word 'happening' then,'' Ted Tinling was saying the other night, ''otherwise what I did for Gussie would certainly have been a 'happening.' ''

title: Sturm und Drang
description: The West German Embassy in

title: U.S. WOULD CUT RESCUE PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration's budget office is trying to cut in half the American commitment to an international satellite rescue program.

title: GERALD ZORNOW, 68, A RETIRED PRESIDENT OF EASTMAN KODAK
description: Gerald B. Zornow, retired president and chairman of the board of the Eastman Kodak Company, died Wednesday at his home in Pittsford, N.Y. He was 68 years old.

title: THE REPUBLICAN NATIONAL CONVENTION OF '1984'
description: To the Editor:

title: THE REPUBLICAN NATIONAL CONVENTION OF '1984'
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Envoy to Nepal Named
description: President Reagan has appointed Leon J. Weil, a New York City stockbroker, as Ambassador to Nepal. Mr. Weil has been general partner and senior vice president at Herzfeld & Stern, a Manhattan brokerage concern. Born in New York City, he has been a member of the President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports since 1981.

title: T.W.A. Registers $100 Million Offer
description: Trans World Airlines Inc. has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a $100 million public offering of senior exchangeable variable-rate notes due in 1994.

title: NBD Bancorp Plans a Purchase
description: NBD Bancorp Inc. said it had agreed to acquire the United Michigan Corporation in a cash and stock transaction valued at about $78 million. Under the agreement, United Michigan shareholders could receive either $56.10 a share in cash or the equivalent in NBD stock for each share owned.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;
description: South Africa Pays a Call On a Harlem School

title: TROMBONES TO SLIDE IN FINALE OF FESTIVAL
description: There's a long, music-filled weekend left at the Greenwich Village Jazz Festival. This year, as in the last two years, the festival is the occasion for clubs in the Greenwich Village area to trade competition for cooperation. A $10 festival pass brings discounts on cover charges at a dozen jazz clubs - virtually every club in the Village as well as outposts in SoHo, the East Village and Gramercy Park - ranging from half-price early sets to free late shows, and half-price admission to the festival's film series at the Bleecker Street Cinema. The pass is available at participating clubs, and full schedules for the festival can be found all around the Village area.

title: DAMNED EITHER WAY
description: When a President seeks re- election, what he does or doesn't do with the powers of his office - whether silently or showily - is often more decisive than any amount of formal campaigning.

title: Bolivian Aide to Stay On Amid Torture Charges
description: Bolivia's Interior Minister, Federico Alvarez Plata, resigned today over accusations of torture, but he then withdrew his resignation at the request of President Hernan Siles Zuazo, a senior official said.

title: ON GIVING PROTECTION TO MAINE SHOE WORKERS
description: To the Editor:

title: UNITED STATES DESIGN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Grain for China, Soviet
description: China and the Soviet Union, in separate deals, have bought an additional 450,000 metric tons of United States grain for delivery in 1984-85, the Agriculture Department said today. Officials said the latest deals included 300,000 tons of corn bought by the Soviet Union for delivery after Oct. 1, the beginning of the second year of a long-term supply agreement with the United States. In its deal, China bought 150,000 tons of wheat for delivery in 1985.

title: FRANCE DESCRIBES FREIGHTER'S CARGO
description: French officials confirmed today that the cargo of a French freighter that sank in shallow water off Belgium last weekend included some more highly radiocative material than the uranium originally reported aboard.

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
BILLY SANDS
description: Billy Sands, an actor who was a regular on the television comedies ''McHale's Navy'' and ''The Phil Silvers Show,'' died of lung cancer Monday at U. C. L. A. Medical Center.

title: GENOVESE DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 17
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed in October 1983.

title: FLAWS AT AIR BASE HELD NO PROBLEM FOR SHUTTLE
description: A high- level investigation of construction flaws at the military's space shuttle complex at Vandenberg Air Force Base, Calif., found no problems that would prevent safely launching a shuttle by 1985, the Air Force announced today.

title: Top Matches For Today
description: STADIUM Morning 11 A.M. - Pam Shriver vs.

title: Peoples Gas Rise
description: The Illinois Commerce Commission said it had granted the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company an increase in natural gas rates of $62.6 million, or 5.1 percent, in annual revenues. Peoples Gas, a unit of the Peoples Energy Corporation, had requested a $106.4 million, or 8.7 percent, rate increase last October. The commission said the increase that was granted means that a typical Peoples Gas customer will see monthly natural gas costs rise to $120.62 from $115.48.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
THE RUDEST CABBIES IN THE NATION?
description: As H. R. Crawford, a member of the District of Columbia City Council, tells it, taxicab drivers here are among the rudest in the nation and, too often he says, they don't know their way around the city. He intends to do something about it.

title: YALE STUDY HABITS HELPING HILL ADJUST
description: The National Football League's record books show that Kenny Hill spent four years with the Oakland and Los Angeles Raiders as a defensive back. The record books exaggerate.

title: EX-REAGAN AIDE INDICTED IN CASE OF $431,000 INSIDER STOCK PROFIT
description: The Federal Government brought criminal charges yesterday against Thomas C. Reed, a former national security official under President Reagan, accusing him of using inside information to turn a $431,000 profit in the stock market three years ago.

title: MINORITY OFFICERS SCORE LOW ON TEST
description: A disproportionately small number of black and Hispanic police officers earned passing grades on a New York City police sergeants exam designed to overcome racial and sexual biases, according to figures made available yesterday.

title: LUNDY ELECTRONICS AND SYSEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $135,000 on the settlement of litigation.

title: KOREANS IN JAPAN: FOREVER ALIENS IN AN ALIEN LAND
description: On a street corner in Hiroshima, near a small bridge, a stone monument stands in memory of 20,000 Koreans killed in the 1945 atomic bomb attack.

title: Marvin Johnson Wins Decision
description: Marvin Johnson, hoping to become the first fighter to win the light- heavyweight title three times, scored a unanimous 10-round decision over John Davis tonight.

title: U.S. Says 9 Arrested Did Not Pose Threat
description: Federal officials, who arrested nine Middle East nationals in the belief they were plotting terrorist acts against the Republican National Convention, now say the men did not pose a serious threat.

title: Key Banks Stake
description: The Edinburgh Investment Trust P.L.C., an Edinburgh-based investment concern, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it holds 701,900 common shares, or 5 percent of the total outstanding, of Key Banks Inc. The trust said that it had acquired the stake out of a desire to invest in an American regional bank, and that it might buy additional Key securities but had no firm plans to do so. On the New York Stock Exchange today, Key, which is based in Albany, closed at $18.875, up 87 1/2 cents.

title: DRAWINGS: 112 YEARS OF PRESIDENTIAL CARTOONS
description: The scene is the Charles Addams-ish castle in Rye Brook, N. Y., that houses the Museum of Cartoon Art on Comly Avenue, the ''action'' an exhibition of political cartoons - original drawings and prints published during Presidential election years. The show begins in 1872, when Ulysses S. Grant beat Horace Greeley, and the main outlets for graphic spite were weekly journals such as Puck and Judge; it ends inconclusively in 1984 with a bulletin board of newspaper cartoons keeping track of the present race.

title: First Paper Issue For Toyota Credit
description: The Toyota Motor Credit Corporation said yesterday that it plans to make its debut in the commercial paper market Sept. 11. Merrill Lynch Money Markets, Nomura Securities International and the Nikko Securities Company were named as dealers for the company's paper.

title: Afghan Rebels Leaving Border City in Pakistan
description: Afghan rebel groups began moving out of Peshawar today in line with a Pakistani Government order to shift their headquarters out of this frontier city by Friday.

title: OHIO JUDICIAL INQUIRY ENDS WITHOUT INDICTMENTS
description: Without indicting anyone, a Federal grand jury has ended a 17-month investigation of Chief Federal District Judge Frank J. Battisti and allegations of influence peddling in United States Bankruptcy Court in Cleveland.

title: CITY CONSIDERS SUING CONCERN OVER BIAS RULE
description: New York City may sue Bell Helicopter Textron for what it says is the company's violation of a contract that includes a ban on discrimination against homosexuals, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: HAMILTON TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
TIFFANY'S SALE SET TO EXECUTIVES
description: A investor group including William R. Chaney, the chairman of Tiffany & Company, and others said yesterday that they would acquire the famous jewelry retail chain from Avon Products for $135.5 million in cash.

title: U.S. Arms Delegate Retires; He Cites a Lack of Progress
description: Louis G. Fields Jr. announced his retirement today after three years as United States representative to the 40-nation United Nations Conference on Disarmament. He expressed disappointment at its lack of progress.

title: QUERIES ON SERGEANTS EXAM TEST EMERGENCY RESPONSES
description: Questions based on videotaped scenes of police officers responding to various emergencies made up the bulk of the New York City Police Department's sergeants test in June 1983.

title: Greeks Say U.S. Military Has Violated Labor Pact
description: Greece protested to the United States today over purported violations of a recent labor agreement that ended a monthlong strike at the American bases here. The strike had aggravated the already strained relations between the two countries.

title: POLL FINDS BLACKS UNITED ON POLITICAL VIEWS
description: Black Americans are unified by their political attitudes far more than are whites, and the consistency cuts across region, age, income, sex and other lines, according to the results of a public opinion poll released today by the Joint Center for Political Studies.

title: NICHOLS, S E, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
VICTIMS OF IGNORANCE, TOO
description: After his 22 years behind bars, his wife says that at the age of 66 ''he is as upright and proud as the day he was arrested.'' He has spent most of his life defying the most repressive Government on earth. Doing much the same, his wife, an exile in her own country and labeled a threat to public order, has enjoyed only 11 months of qualified freedom in two decades. The Democratic Party platform demands their release, and a bill in Congress calls upon President Reagan to secure it.

title: Nuclear Device Passes Test
description: A nuclear weapon was successfully detonated 1,200 feet underground today at the Nevada Test Site, a Government spokesmen said. The Department of Energy announced that the weapon had an explosive force less than 20 kilotons, an equivalent of 20,000 tons of TNT.

title: Sigel Defeated In U.S. Amateur
description: Jay Sigel's effort to become the first man to win the United States Amateur Championship for three straight years ended today when he missed a putt on the 17th hole and lost to Rocco Mediate of Greensburg, Pa., on the first day of match play.

title: 4 ARE INDICTED IN PLOT TO EXPORT WARFARE OUTFITS
description: Four men - including one from Brazil - were indicted today on charges they illegally conspired to export 400,000 chemical warfare protective suits to Iran.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about banking in Atlanta misidentified the chairman and chief executive officer of the Citizens and Southern Corporation. He is Bennett A. Brown.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Abbott Laboratories , a maker of hospital and laboratory products based in North Chicago, Ill., said Burroughs Wellcome Co., a drug and pharmaceutical concern in Research Triangle Park, N.C., had agreed to market its line of injectable drugs.

title: Basketball Steps
description: The Atlantic 10 Conference has decided to use both a 45-second shot clock and a 3-point field goal next basketball season, a move that sits just fine with Coach John Chaney of Temple. ''The 45-second shot clock takes the stall out of the game and yet still lets us play basketball,'' he said, ''while the 3-point play is like a home run: You're never out of the game.''

title: CUBS WIN WITH 5-RUN 10TH
description: Even before the Cubs rallied for five runs in the 10th inning tonight, scored an 8-3 victory over the Atlanta Braves and stretched their lead to six games over the idle Mets, Chicago had come up a winner.

title: NATIONAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
COMMERCIAL SHEARING INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Houston Schools Settle Suit on Desegregation
description: Attorneys for a Mexican civil rights group and the city schools signed an out-of- court settlement today in a 28-year-old desegration suit. Lawyers for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People expressed last- minute reservations.

title: LA-Z-BOY CHAIR CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
POSNER INCREASES BID FOR CITY INVESTING UNITS
description: Victor Posner, the Miami businessman, increased his offer yesterday for three major subsidiaries of the City Investing Company by $46 million. He also filed suit to block the sale of the units to a rival investor group put together by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets and Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

title: PARLEX CORP.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TIPS ON THEATERGOING FOR THE HOLIDAY WEEKEND
description: Holiday weekends, like this one, are bad for theater business but great for theatergoers. With most people heading for the shore or the hills, box- office business at all but a few shows will fall by at least 10 percent. And both on Broadway and Off Broadway, Labor Day is an especially quiet time, the last breathing spell before the start of the fall season.

title: ALL IS LOOKING FINE FOR WITHERSPOON
description: He stepped out on the small patio with its view of the hotel pool and said he now was feeling good about being the heavyweight champion. For the time being, Tim Witherspoon added, he had tabled all the talk about his personal finances and share of the purse, to direct his attention to Pinklon Thomas, the challenger who can deprive Witherspoon of the title - one thing that money can't buy.

title: No Headline
description: Brazilians to PerformThe Brazilian singer Jamelao will perform tonight with Combo Brasileirinho at 9 P.M. at Via Brasil (997- 1158), 34 West 46th Street. There is a $10 cover charge.

title: CITY SAVINGS BANKS IMPROVE
description: The financial condition of New York City's savings banks improved substantially in the second quarter, according to figures released yesterday by the New York State Banking Department.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: The Grandaddy Of All News Conferences

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:Sometimes the French Have A More Colorful Term for It

title: No Headline
description: Pioneer to Sell Unit to Cabot The Pioneer Corporation and

title: E.P.A. STRATEGY SET ON SAFEGUARDING OF WATER SUPPLIES
description: Calling contamination of underground water by man-made toxic substances a potentially grave threat, the Environmental Protection Agency today announced its plans to protect these water supplies.

title: Walker Agrees to Pact HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 30 - Wesley Walker, the star wide receiver who ended a 37-day contract holdout Monday, said today that he
description: had agreed to a new deal with the Jets and would sign it imminently.

title: FRANK N. TRAGER, 78, AN EXPERT ON ASIA, DIES
description: Dr. Frank N. Trager, a professor emeritus of international affairs at New York University who served for many years as a consultant to the Government on Southeast Asia and national security, died of heart disease last Sunday in Carmel, Calif. He was 78 years old and lived in Carmel.
